过去或许是序章，但究竟是哪段过去？

Past may be prologue, but which past?

—H ENRY H U

—HENRY HU

作者注及致谢

AUTHOR’S NOTE AND ACKNOWLEDGMENTS

这份关于长期资本管理公司（Long-Term Capital Management）的历史资料未经授权。项目伊始，我曾与该公司两位合伙人埃里克·罗森菲尔德（Eric Rosenfeld）和大卫·穆林斯（David Mullins）进行过几次正式访谈，但这种正式合作很快便终止了。之后，我多次尝试恢复访谈，并试图正式接触公司创始人约翰·W·梅里韦瑟（John W. Meriwether）及其他合伙人，但均以失败告终。尽管如此，在我的研究过程中，我反复通过电子邮件和电话向罗森菲尔德提出了看似无穷无尽的问题，他慷慨地同意回答我的许多问题。此外，长期资本管理公司各个层级的员工也私下里为我的研究提供了帮助，使我得以了解公司的内部运作以及许多合伙人的个人特质；我对此深表感谢。

This history of Long-Term Capital Management is unauthorized. At the project’s outset, I was granted several formal interviews with two of the firm’s partners, Eric Rosenfeld and David Mullins, but such formal cooperation quickly ceased. Subsequent attempts to resume the interviews, and to gain formal access to John W. Meriwether, the founder, and others of the partners, proved fruitless. Nonetheless, over the course of my research, I repeatedly conveyed (via e-mail and telephone) seemingly endless lists of questions to Rosenfeld, and he generously consented to answer many of my queries. In addition, various Long-Term employees at all levels of the firm privately aided me in my research, helping me to understand both the inner workings of the firm and the nuances of many of the individual partners; I am deeply grateful to them.

我的其他主要资料来源是对华尔街各大投资银行的采访，其中包括在长期资产公司成立和最终救助过程中发挥关键作用的六家银行。如果没有贝尔斯登、高盛、摩根大通、美林证券、所罗门美邦和瑞士联合银行众多人士的合作，本书不可能完成。

My other primary sources were interviews conducted at the major Wall Street investment banks, including the six banks that played a crucial role in the genesis and ultimate rescue of Long-Term. Without the cooperation of many people at Bear Stearns, Goldman Sachs, J. P. Morgan, Merrill Lynch, Salomon Smith Barney, and Union Bank of Switzerland, this book could not have been written.

我在经济学方面也遇到了很多慷慨的导师。虽然还有其他人，但彼得·伯恩斯坦、尤金·法玛、约翰·吉尔斯特、布鲁斯·雅各布斯、克里斯托弗·梅和马克·鲁宾斯坦帮助我理解了期权、套期保值、钟形曲线和肥尾分布的世界，而这正是长期投资的核心所在。

I also had generous tutors in economics. There were others, but Peter Bernstein, Eugene Fama, John Gilster, Bruce Jacobs, Christopher May, and Mark Rubinstein helped me to understand the world of options, hedging, bell curves, and fat tails where Long-Term plied its trade.

此外，长期基金合伙人于1999年1月撰写的关于该基金失败的机密备忘录，提供了该基金存续期间的资本、资产总额、杠杆率和月度收益率等事实和数据，以及投资者的收益情况。这份备忘录是一份极其宝贵的资料，事实上，本书中的许多数据都来源于此。最后，我衷心感谢纽约联邦储备银行的鼎力合作。

In addition, the confidential memorandum on the fund’s debacle prepared by Long-Term’s partners in January 1999 provided facts and figures on the fund’s capital, asset totals, leverage, and monthly returns throughout the life of the fund, as well as information on the results of investors. It was an invaluable resource and, indeed, the source of many of the figures in this book. Finally, I am grateful to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York for its free-spirited cooperation.

凡有可能，我都会在文末标注资料来源。然而，在很多情况下，我不得不依赖那些不愿透露姓名的资料来源。撰写近代史总是一件棘手的事情，而“长期计划”（Long-Term）的故事——本质上是一个失败和失望的故事——尤其敏感。“长期计划”的合伙人生性低调，即使在最好的情况下，他们也会对这样的项目感到不自在；他们对这样一个巨大失败的历史缺乏热情，这完全可以理解。因此，我必须恳请读者谅解，文中有很多资料未注明出处。

Whenever possible, sources are indicated by an endnote. However, in many cases, I had to rely on sources that declined to be identified. Writing recent history is always a touchy business, and the Long-Term story—essentially, one of failure and disappointment—was particularly delicate. Long-Term’s partners are by nature private people who would have been uncomfortable with such a project during the best of times; that they were unenthusiastic about a history of such a titanic failure is only human. Therefore, I must ask the reader’s indulgence for the much material that is unattributed.

我由衷感谢研究助理维肯·贝贝里安，他不仅是一位孜孜不倦的资料搜集者，更是一位足智多谋、见解独到的助手。尼尔·巴尔斯基、杰弗里·坦南鲍姆和路易斯·洛温斯坦——两位挚友和一位无可比拟的父亲——孜孜不倦地阅读了这篇初稿，并为我提供了宝贵且至关重要的建议；他们的匠心独运为本书的每一页都增色不少。我的经纪人梅兰妮·杰克逊和编辑安·戈多夫，如同蒙大拿州到赖斯州的黄金搭档，默契十足地指导着这个项目从构思到完成。她们的不断鼓励和支持，照亮了我许多原本孤独的时光。我的三个孩子，马特、扎克和艾莉，也一直激励着我。在本书的写作过程中，还有许多人在专业和个人层面给予了我帮助，我对他们的感激之情难以言表。

I am deeply grateful to Viken Berberian, a research aide who proved to be not only an intrepid gatherer of facts but a resourceful and insightful assistant. Neil Barsky, Jeffrey Tannenbaum, and Louis Lowenstein—two dear friends and a nonpareil dad—tirelessly read this manuscript in crude form and provided me with invaluable and much-needed suggestions; their inspired handiwork graces every page. Melanie Jackson, my agent, and Ann Godoff, my editor, as unerring a team as Montana-to-Rice, skillfully shepherded this project from conception to finish. Their repeated shows of confidence lightened many otherwise solitary hours. And my three children, Matt, Zack, and Alli, were a continuing inspiration. Many others helped the author, both professionally and personally, during the course of writing this book, and my gratitude to them knows no bounds.

介绍

INTRODUCTION

纽约联邦储备银行矗立在华尔街中心一块灰色的砂岩地基上。尽管这座建于1924年的城市地标建筑，在周围充满活力、商业气息浓厚的街区中却显得低调内敛，几乎难以察觉。这片区域遍布折扣店和简餐店，几乎随处可见经纪公司和银行。美联储的近邻包括一家修鞋店、一家日式烤肉店，以及大通曼哈顿银行；摩根大通银行也仅几步之遥。再往西走一点，深受大众喜爱的美林证券隔河相望，河对岸便是美国其他地区以及美林的大部分客户。银行摩天大楼营造出一种开放包容的氛围，而美联储大楼——这座佛罗伦萨文艺复兴时期的杰作——却显得格外冷峻肃穆。它的拱形窗户被金属格栅包裹着，位于自由街的主入口由一排黑色铸铁哨兵把守。

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is perched in a gray sandstone slab in the heart of Wall Street. Though a city landmark building constructed in 1924, the bank is a muted, almost unseen presence among its lively, entrepreneurial neighbors. The area is dotted with discount stores and luncheonettes—and, almost everywhere, brokerage firms and banks. The Fed’s immediate neighbors include a shoe repair stand and a teriyaki house, and also Chase Manhattan Bank; J. P. Morgan is a few blocks away. A bit farther to the west, Merrill Lynch, the people’s brokerage, gazes at the Hudson River, across which lie the rest of America and most of Merrill’s customers. The bank skyscrapers project an open, accommodative air, but the Fed building, a Florentine Renaissance showpiece, is distinctly forbidding. Its arched windows are encased in metal grille, and its main entrance, on Liberty Street, is guarded by a row of black cast-iron sentries.

纽约联储只是美国联邦储备系统（美国中央银行）的一个分支机构，但却是最重要的分支机构。由于纽约联储毗邻华尔街，它充当着联邦储备系统（位于华盛顿，由雄辩的艾伦·格林斯潘领导）的耳目，密切关注市场动态。纽约联储主席威廉·J·麦克唐纳身材魁梧，经常与银行家和交易员交谈。麦克唐纳希望了解交易员之间的各种消息，尤其关注任何可能扰乱市场，甚至在极端情况下危及金融体系的信息。但麦克唐纳尽量保持低调。美联储一直以来都是一个备受争议的监管机构——一个与华尔街并肩而行的“人民公仆”，一个在民主的市场乱象中保持神秘的机构。麦克唐纳要想出手干预，哪怕只是小规模的干预，也需要一场危机，甚至可能是一场战争。 1998 年秋季的最初几天，麦克唐纳确实介入了——而且介入的程度不小。

The New York Fed is only a spoke, though the most important spoke, in the U.S. Federal Reserve System, America’s central bank. Because of the New York Fed’s proximity to Wall Street, it acts as the eyes and ears into markets for the bank’s governing board, in Washington, which is run by the oracular Alan Greenspan. William J. McDonough, the beefy president of the New York Fed, talks to bankers and traders often. McDonough wants to be kept abreast of the gossip that traders share with one another. He especially wants to hear about anything that might upset markets or, in the extreme, the financial system. But McDonough tries to stay in the background. The Fed has always been a controversial regulator—a servant of the people that is elbow to elbow with Wall Street, a cloistered agency amid the democratic chaos of markets. For McDonough to intervene, even in a small way, would take a crisis, perhaps a war. And in the first days of the autumn of 1998, McDonough did intervene—and not in a small way.

麻烦的根源似乎如此渺小，如此遥远得可笑，以至于微不足道。但事情不总是如此吗？一堆茶叶被倾倒进港口，一位大公被刺杀，突然间，一个火药桶被点燃，危机爆发，世界从此改变。这一次，引爆点是长期资本管理公司（LTCM），一家总部位于康涅狄格州格林威治的私人投资合伙企业，格林威治是距离华尔街约40英里的高档郊区。LTCM只为一百位投资者管理资金；员工不足两百人，而且肯定一百个美国人中没有一个听说过它。事实上，五年前，LTCM甚至还不存在。

The source of the trouble seemed so small, so laughably remote, as to be insignificant. But isn’t it always that way? A load of tea is dumped into a harbor, an archduke is shot, and suddenly a tinderbox is lit, a crisis erupts, and the world is different. In this case, the shot was Long-Term Capital Management, a private investment partnership with its headquarters in Greenwich, Connecticut, a posh suburb some forty miles from Wall Street. LTCM managed money for only one hundred investors; it employed not quite two hundred people, and surely not one American in a hundred had ever heard of it. Indeed, five years earlier, LTCM had not even existed.

但1998年9月23日星期三下午，长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的规模却不容小觑。由于LTCM危机爆发，麦克唐纳召集了——用美联储谨慎的说法是“邀请”——华尔街各大银行的负责人。这是银行家信托公司、贝尔斯登、大通曼哈顿银行、高盛、摩根大通、雷曼兄弟、美林证券、摩根士丹利添惠和所罗门美邦的首席执行官们首次齐聚美联储十楼会议室，在油画肖像下开会——他们此行的目的并非救助某个拉丁美洲国家，而是为了商讨如何拯救他们自己的一家银行。纽约证券交易所主席以及欧洲各大银行的代表也出席了会议。由于美联储不习惯举办如此大规模的会议，真皮椅不够用，首席执行官们不得不挤进折叠金属椅里。

But on the Wednesday afternoon of September 23, 1998, Long-Term did not seem small. On account of a crisis at LTCM, McDonough had summoned—“invited,” in the Fed’s restrained idiom—the heads of every major Wall Street bank. For the first time, the chiefs of Bankers Trust, Bear Stearns, Chase Manhattan, Goldman Sachs, J. P. Morgan, Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, and Salomon Smith Barney gathered under the oil portraits in the Fed’s tenth-floor boardroom—not to bail out a Latin American nation but to consider a rescue of one of their own. The chairman of the New York Stock Exchange joined them, as did representatives from major European banks. Unaccustomed to hosting such a large gathering, the Fed did not have enough leather-backed chairs to go around, so the chief executives had to squeeze into folding metal seats.

尽管麦克唐纳是位公职人员，但这次会面却是秘密进行的。在公众看来，美国正处于历史上最伟大的牛市之一的鼎盛时期，尽管最近，如同以往许多个秋季一样，股市出现了一些回调。自8月中旬俄罗斯卢布债务违约以来，全球债券市场尤其动荡不安。但这并非麦克唐纳召集银行家的原因。

Although McDonough was a public official, the meeting was secret. As far as the public knew, America was in the salad days of one of history’s great bull markets, although recently, as in many previous autumns, it had seen some backsliding. Since mid-August, when Russia had defaulted on its ruble debt, the global bond markets in particular had been highly unsettled. But that wasn’t why McDonough had called the bankers.

长期基金是一家债券交易公司，当时濒临破产。该基金由约翰·W·梅里韦瑟管理，他曾是所罗门兄弟公司一位知名的交易员。梅里韦瑟是一位和蔼可亲但谨慎的中西部人，在银行家圈子里颇受欢迎。正是因为他，银行家们才同意为长期基金提供融资——而且条件非常优厚。但梅里韦瑟只是长期基金的门面。该基金的核心是一群才华横溢、拥有博士学位的套利交易员。他们中许多人曾是大学教授。其中两人还获得了诺贝尔奖。他们个个都非常聪明。而且他们也深知自己非常聪明。

Long-Term, a bond-trading firm, was on the brink of failing. The fund was run by John W. Meriwether, formerly a well-known trader at Salomon Brothers. Meriwether, a congenial though cautious mid-westerner, had been popular among the bankers. It was because of him, mainly, that the bankers had agreed to give financing to Long-Term—and had agreed on highly generous terms. But Meriwether was only the public face of Long-Term. The heart of the fund was a group of brainy, Ph.D.-certified arbitrageurs. Many of them had been professors. Two had won the Nobel Prize. All of them were very smart. And they knew they were very smart.

四年来，长期基金一直是华尔街艳羡的对象。该基金年均收益率超过40%，从未出现亏损，波动性极低，似乎没有任何风险。其背后的智囊团似乎能够将充满不确定性的世界简化为严谨冷静的概率计算——就目前来看，他们代表了现代金融的最高水平。

For four years, Long-Term had been the envy of Wall Street. The fund had racked up returns of more than 40 percent a year, with no losing stretches, no volatility, seemingly no risk at all. Its intellectual supermen had apparently been able to reduce an uncertain world to rigorous, cold-blooded odds—on form, they were the very best that modern finance had to offer.

这家名不见经传的套利基金竟然积累了惊人的1000亿美元资产，几乎全部都是借来的——确切地说，是从麦克唐纳餐桌上的银行家那里借来的。尽管这笔债务已经十分庞大，但这还远不是长期基金最严重的问题。该基金签订了数千份衍生品合约，使其与华尔街的每一家银行都紧密地联系在一起。这些合约本质上是对市场价格的场外押注，其涉及的金额高达天文数字——超过1万亿美元的风险敞口。

This one obscure arbitrage fund had amassed an amazing $100 billion in assets, virtually all of it borrowed—borrowed, that is, from the bankers at McDonough’s table. As monstrous as this indebtedness was, it was by no means the worst of Long-Term’s problems. The fund had entered into thousands of derivative contracts, which had endlessly intertwined it with every bank on Wall Street. These contracts, essentially side bets on market prices, covered an astronomical sum—more than $1 trillion worth of exposure.

如果长期信贷公司违约，在场的所有银行都将只持有合同的一方，而另一方已不复存在。换句话说，它们将面临巨大且难以承受的风险。毫无疑问，届时将会一片混乱，每家银行都会争先恐后地摆脱单方面债务，并试图出售其在长期信贷公司持有的抵押品。

If Long-Term defaulted, all of the banks in the room would be left holding one side of a contract for which the other side no longer existed. In other words, they would be exposed to tremendous—and untenable—risks. Undoubtedly, there would be a frenzy as every bank rushed to escape its now one-sided obligations and tried to sell its collateral from Long-Term.

恐慌与市场一样古老，但衍生品却是相对较新的事物。监管机构一直担忧这些创新型证券的潜在风险，因为它们将全国的金融机构连接成一条错综复杂的互惠义务链。官员们一直在思考，如果这条链条上的一个重要环节出现故障，将会发生什么。麦克唐纳担心市场会停止运转；交易会停止；整个体系会彻底崩溃。

Panics are as old as markets, but derivatives were relatively new. Regulators had worried about the potential risks of these inventive new securities, which linked the country’s financial institutions in a complex chain of reciprocal obligations. Officials had wondered what would happen if one big link in the chain should fail. McDonough feared that the markets would stop working; that trading would cease; that the system itself would come crashing down.

贝尔斯登首席执行官詹姆斯·凯恩（James Cayne）总是叼着雪茄，他曾信誓旦旦地表示，如果长期基金（Long-Term）的可用现金低于5亿美元，他将停止清算该基金的交易——这将导致该基金破产。年初时，这似乎还遥不可及，因为长期基金的资本高达47亿美元。但在过去五周，或者说自俄罗斯违约以来，长期基金遭受了惨重的损失——日复一日，难以承受。其资本已降至最低水平。凯恩认为它撑不过一天了。

James Cayne, the cigar-chomping chief executive of Bear Stearns, had been vowing that he would stop clearing Long-Term’s trades—which would put it out of business—if the fund’s available cash fell below $500 million. At the start of the year, that would have seemed remote, for Long-Term’s capital had been $4.7 billion. But during the past five weeks, or since Russia’s default, Long-Term had suffered numbing losses—day after day after day. Its capital was down to the minimum. Cayne didn’t think it would survive another day.

该基金此前已向沃伦·巴菲特求助，也曾向乔治·索罗斯求助，还曾向美林证券求助。它几乎找遍了所有能想到的银行。如今，它已走投无路。正因如此，麦克唐纳才像教父召集敌对家族、甚至可能兵戎相见的家族一样，邀请了这些银行家。如果每家银行都各自抛售债券，后果可能不堪设想，引发全球恐慌。但如果他们齐心协力，或许就能避免这场灾难。虽然麦克唐纳没有明说，但他希望这些银行投资40亿美元，拯救该基金。他希望他们立刻行动——明天就来不及了。

The fund had already asked Warren Buffett for money. It had gone to George Soros. It had gone to Merrill Lynch. One by one, it had asked every bank it could think of. Now it had no place left to go. That was why, like a godfather summoning rival and potentially warring families, McDonough had invited the bankers. If each one moved to unload bonds individually, the result could be a worldwide panic. If they acted in concert, perhaps a catastrophe could be avoided. Although McDonough didn’t say so, he wanted the banks to invest $4 billion and rescue the fund. He wanted them to do it right then—tomorrow would be too late.

但银行家们觉得，长期基金已经给他们带来了太多麻烦。长期基金那些行事隐秘、关系紧密的数学家们，对华尔街其他所有人充满了蔑​​视。美林证券——这家一手创建了长期基金的公司——长期以来一直试图与该基金建立互惠互利的合作关系。许多其他银行也曾这样做过。但长期基金拒绝了他们。这些教授们只愿意按照自己的条件进行交易，绝不愿与银行妥协。银行家们不喜欢曾经傲慢的长期基金如今却向他们求助。

But the bankers felt that Long-Term had already caused them more than enough trouble. Long-Term’s secretive, close-knit mathematicians had treated everyone else on Wall Street with utter disdain. Merrill Lynch, the firm that had brought Long-Term into being, had long tried to establish a profitable, mutually rewarding relationship with the fund. So had many other banks. But Long-Term had spurned them. The professors had been willing to trade on their terms and only on theirs—not to meet the banks halfway. The bankers did not like it that the once haughty Long-Term was pleading for their help.

银行家们自身也深受长期投资公司引发的动荡之苦。高盛首席执行官乔恩·科尔津面临着合伙人的反抗，他们对高盛近期的交易亏损感到震惊，而且与科尔津不同，他们不愿动用日益减少的资本去帮助竞争对手。旅行者/所罗门美邦董事长桑福德·威尔也遭受了巨额损失。威尔担心这些亏损会危及公司与花旗集团即将进行的合并，而威尔认为这是他辉煌职业生涯的巅峰之作。他最近关闭了自己的套利部门——该部门多年前曾是梅里韦瑟职业生涯的起点——因此他并不热衷于出手拯救另一个类似的部门。

And the bankers themselves were hurting from the turmoil that Long-Term had helped to unleash. Goldman Sachs’s CEO, Jon Corzine, was facing a revolt by his partners, who were horrified by Goldman’s recent trading losses and who, unlike Corzine, did not want to use their diminishing capital to help a competitor. Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Travelers/Salomon Smith Barney, had suffered big losses, too. Weill was worried that the losses would jeopardize his company’s pending merger with Citicorp, which Weill saw as the crowning gem to his lustrous career. He had recently shuttered his own arbitrage unit—which, years earlier, had been the launching pad for Meriwether’s career—and was not keen to bail out another one.

麦克唐纳环顾餐桌，发现每位宾客都或多或少地陷入了困境，其中许多人的困境都直接源于长期资本。银行家们的股票价值暴跌。和麦克唐纳一样，银行家们也担心，这场始于亚洲货币贬值、蔓延至俄罗斯、巴西，如今又波及长期资本的全球风暴，最终会席卷整个华尔街。

As McDonough looked around the table, every one of his guests was in greater or lesser trouble, many of them directly on account of Long-Term. The value of the bankers’ stocks had fallen precipitously. The bankers were afraid, as was McDonough, that the global storm that had begun, so innocently, with devaluations in Asia, and had spread to Russia, Brazil, and now to Long-Term Capital, would envelop all of Wall Street.

雷曼兄弟董事长理查德·富尔德正努力平息有关该公司因过度投资长期基金而濒临破产的传言。代表瑞士联合银行的戴维·索罗认为，该行已深陷其中；他们愚蠢地投资了长期基金，并遭受了巨额损失。托马斯·拉布雷克的摩根大通银行曾向这家对冲基金提供了5亿美元的贷款；拉布雷克希望在考虑追加投资之前，先收回这笔贷款。

Richard Fuld, chairman of Lehman Brothers, was fighting off rumors that his company was on the verge of failing due to its supposed overexposure to Long-Term. David Solo, who represented the giant Swiss bank Union Bank of Switzerland, thought his bank was already in far too deeply; it had foolishly invested in Long-Term and had suffered titanic losses. Thomas Labrecque’s Chase Manhattan had sponsored a loan to the hedge fund of $500 million; before Labrecque thought about investing more, he wanted that loan repaid.

身材魁梧的美林董事长大卫·科曼斯基最为忧心忡忡。短短两个月内，美林的股价就下跌了一半——市值蒸发了190亿美元。美林在债券交易方面也遭受了惊人的损失。如今，它的信用评级也岌岌可危。

David Komansky, the portly Merrill chairman, was worried most of all. In a matter of two months, Merrill’s stock had fallen by half—$19 billion of its market value had simply melted away. Merrill had suffered shocking bond-trading losses, too. Now its own credit rating was at risk.

科曼斯基本人在该基金投资了近100万美元，他非常担心长期基金一旦倒闭会引发混乱。但他深知在场其他人对长期基金的反感程度。他认为，要让银行家们达成一致的可能性微乎其微。

Komansky, who personally had invested almost $1 million in the fund, was terrified of the chaos that would result if Long-Term collapsed. But he knew how much antipathy there was in the room toward Long-Term. He thought the odds of getting the bankers to agree were long at best.

科曼斯基意识到，特立独行的贝尔斯登首席执行官凯恩将是关键人物。贝尔斯登负责清算长期对冲基金的交易，比任何其他公司都更了解这家对冲基金的运作模式。其他银行家们不安地挪动着身子，科曼斯基的二把手赫伯特·艾利森问凯恩他的立场。

Komansky recognized that Cayne, the maverick Bear Stearns chief executive, would be a pivotal player. Bear, which cleared Long-Term’s trades, knew the guts of the hedge fund better than any other firm. As the other bankers nervously shifted in their seats, Herbert Allison, Komansky’s number two, asked Cayne where he stood.

凯恩明确表明了他的立场：贝尔斯登不会向长期资本投资一分钱。

Cayne stated his position clearly: Bear Stearns would not invest a nickel in Long-Term Capital.

华尔街的精英们，银行家们，沉默了一会儿。然后，房间里爆发了冲突。

For a moment the bankers, the cream of Wall Street, were silent. And then the room exploded.

长期资本管理的兴起

THE RISE OF LONG-TERM CAPITAL MANAGEMENT

1

1

梅里韦瑟





MERIWETHER





如果说约翰·梅里韦瑟在所罗门兄弟公司发现了一条人生信条，那就是要坚持亏损，直到亏损转化为盈利。梅里韦瑟顿​​悟的那一刻或许可以确定。1979年，一家名为JF Eckstein & Co.的证券交易商濒临破产。惊慌失措的埃克斯坦找到所罗门兄弟公司，与包括几位合伙人在内的一群人会面，其中也包括当时31岁、面容稚嫩的交易员梅里韦瑟。“我做了一笔很棒的交易，但我不能继续持有，”埃克斯坦恳求道，“你们能不能把我的股份买下来？”

IF THERE WAS one article of faith that John Meriwether discovered at Salomon Brothers, it was to ride your losses until they turned into gains. It is possible to pinpoint the moment of Meriwether’s revelation. In 1979, a securities dealer named J. F. Eckstein & Co. was on the brink of failing. A panicked Eckstein went to Salomon and met with a group that included several of Salomon’s partners and also Meriwether, then a cherub-faced trader of thirty-one. “I got a great trade, but I can’t stay in it,” Eckstein pleaded with them. “How about buying me out?”

情况是这样的：埃克斯坦交易的是国库券期货——顾名思义，国库券期货是一种合约，约定在未来以固定价格交付美国国库券。它们的交易价格通常略低于实际国库券的价格。埃克斯坦运用了一种经典的套利策略：买入期货，卖出国库券，然后等待两者的价格趋于一致。由于大多数人愿意为持有近期到期的国库券支付的价格与现在持有国库券的价格大致相同，因此价格趋于一致是合理的。这种交易中蕴含着一些神奇之处，这也是埃克斯坦的生意、长期资本公司的期货业务，乃至所有从事套利交易的人的秘诀所在。埃克斯坦并不知道这两种证券的价格是上涨还是下跌，他也不在乎。对他来说，唯一重要的是这两种价格的相对变化。

The situation was this: Eckstein traded in Treasury bill futures—which, as the name suggests, are contracts that provide for the delivery of U.S. Treasury bills, at a fixed price in the future. They often traded at a slight discount to the price of the actual, underlying bills. In a classic bit of arbitrage, Eckstein would buy the futures, sell the bills, and then wait for the two prices to converge. Since most people would pay about the same to own a bill in the proximate future as they would to own it now, it was reasonable to think that the prices would converge. And there was a bit of magic in the trade, which was the secret of Eckstein’s business, of Long-Term Capital’s future business, and indeed of every arbitrageur who has ever plied the trade. Eckstein didn’t know whether the two securities’ prices would go up or down, and Eckstein didn’t care. All that mattered to him was how the two prices would change relative to each other.

通过买入国库券期货并做空（即押注国库券价格下跌），埃克斯坦实际上同时进行了两笔方向相反的押注。* 因此，他预期一笔交易会盈利，而另一笔交易会亏损。但只要价格较低的资产——期货——的涨幅略大于（或跌幅略小于）国库券，埃克斯坦盈利交易的利润就会大于亏损交易的损失。这就是套利的基本原理。

By buying the bill futures and shorting (that is, betting on a decline in the prices of) the actual bills, Eckstein really had two bets going, each in opposite directions.* Thus, he would expect to make money on one trade and lose it on the other. But as long as the cheaper asset—the futures—rose by a little more (or fell by a little less) than did the bills, Eckstein’s profit on his winning trade would be greater than his loss on the other side. This is the basic idea of arbitrage.

实际上，做空者卖出的是他们借入的证券。他们之后必须归还这些证券——他们相信，到那时价格会下跌。低买高卖的原则依然成立。做空者只是颠倒了顺序：先高卖，再低买。

* In practical terms, those who go short sell a security they have borrowed. They must return the security later—by which time, they believe, the price will have declined. The principle of buying cheap and selling dear still holds. Short sellers merely reverse the order: sell dear, then buy cheap.

埃克斯坦曾多次进行过类似的赌博，通常都能获利。随着盈利的增加，他逐渐加大了赌注。然而，不知何故，1979年6月，正常的趋势发生了逆转：期货价格竟然高于国库券价格。埃克斯坦自信地认为这种惯常的价差会恢复，于是进行了一笔巨额交易。但结果却出乎意料，价差不仅没有收敛，反而进一步扩大。埃克斯坦收到了巨额的追缴保证金通知，被迫仓促抛售。

Eckstein had made this bet many times, typically with success. As he made more money, he gradually raised his stake. For some reason, in June 1979, the normal pattern was reversed: futures got more expensive than bills. Confident that the customary relationship would reassert itself, Eckstein put on a very big trade. But instead of converging, the gap widened even further. Eckstein was hit with massive margin calls and became desperate to sell.

恰巧，梅里韦瑟最近在所罗门公司内部组建了一个债券套利小组。他立刻意识到埃克斯坦的交易是合理的，因为价格迟早会趋于一致。但与此同时，所罗门公司将面临数千万美元的风险，而其总资本仅有约2亿美元。合伙人们虽然忐忑不安，但还是同意接手埃克斯坦的仓位。接下来的几周，价差持续扩大，所罗门公司遭受了重大损失。公司的资本账户过去一直潦草地记在一本小册子上，放在一位名叫艾伦·芬恩的合伙人办公室外。每天下午，合伙人们都会忐忑不安地走到芬恩的办公室，查看损失情况。梅里韦瑟冷静地坚持认为他们最终会扭亏为盈。“我们最好如此，”管理合伙人约翰·古特弗伦德对他说，“否则你就等着被炒鱿鱼吧。”

Meriwether, as it had happened, had recently set up a bond-arbitrage group within Salomon. He instantly saw that Eckstein’s trade made sense, because sooner or later, the prices should converge. But in the meantime, Salomon would be risking tens of millions of its capital, which totaled only about $200 million. The partners were nervous but agreed to take over Eckstein’s position. For the next couple of weeks, the spread continued to widen, and Salomon suffered a serious loss. The firm’s capital account used to be scribbled in a little book, left outside the office of a partner named Allan Fine, and each afternoon the partners would nervously tiptoe over to Fine’s to see how much they had lost. Meriwether coolly insisted that they would come out ahead. “We better,” John Gutfreund, the managing partner, told him, “or you’ll be fired.”

价格最终趋于一致，所罗门大赚了一笔。当时几乎没人交易金融期货，但梅里韦瑟却精通此道。第二年他就被提拔为合伙人。更重要的是，他领导的小部门——名字不太吉利的“国内固定收益套利小组”——现在拥有了全权使用所罗门的资金进行价差交易。事实上，梅里韦瑟找到了他毕生的事业。

The prices did converge, and Salomon made a bundle. Hardly anyone traded financial futures then, but Meriwether understood them. He was promoted to partner the very next year. More important, his little section, the inauspiciously titled Domestic Fixed Income Arbitrage Group, now had carte blanche to do spread trades with Salomon’s capital. Meriwether, in fact, had found his life’s work.

梅里韦瑟1947年出生，在芝加哥南区罗瑟兰的罗斯摩尔社区长大。这里是民主党和爱尔兰天主教徒的聚居地，也是市长理查德·戴利的堡垒。他是家中三个孩子之一，但实际上他属于一个大家庭，包括住在巷子对面的四个堂兄弟姐妹。事实上，整个社区就像一个大家庭。梅里韦瑟几乎认识社区里的每一个人，这是一个自成一体的小世界，围绕着篮球场、汽水店和教区教堂运转。社区东临伊利诺伊中央铁路，北面是一道红色木板围栏，围栏外是一片铁路货场和工厂林立的无人区。如果说这里不是贫民区，那也绝非富裕。梅里韦瑟的父亲是一名会计，母亲在教育委员会工作。父母都很严厉。梅里韦瑟一家住在一栋不大的房子里，房子是肉桂色的砖砌结构，草坪修剪整齐，花园也打理得井井有条，和大多数邻居一样。所有人都把孩子送去教会学校（少数不送的孩子会被排斥，被视为“公立学校”）。梅里韦瑟身穿浅蓝色衬衫，系着深蓝色领带，就读于圣约翰·德拉萨尔小学，后来又进入门德尔天主教高中，这两所学校的老师都是奥斯定会的修士。学校的纪律非常严苛。男生会被用尺子打屁股，极端情况下，还会被罚跪在地上，用指关节抵住膝盖，一整节课都不能动。在这种乔伊斯式的教育环境下，梅里韦瑟从小就习惯了无处不在的秩序感。正如梅里韦瑟的一位朋友，一位理发师的儿子回忆说：“我们在小学的时候不敢胡闹，因为修女会惩罚你一辈子，把你送进地狱。”至于他们的下场，人们半开玩笑地说，罗斯摩尔的年轻人只有三个选择：上大学、当警察，或者进监狱。梅里韦瑟对自己的选择毫不怀疑，他的同辈人也同样如此。

Born in 1947, Meriwether had grown up in the Rosemoor section of Roseland on the South Side of Chicago, a Democratic, Irish Catholic stronghold of Mayor Richard Daley. He was one of three children but part of a larger extended family, including four cousins across an alleyway. In reality, the entire neighborhood was family. Meriwether knew virtually everyone in the area, a self-contained world that revolved around the basketball lot, soda shop, and parish. It was bordered to the east by the tracks of the Illinois Central Railroad and to the north by a red board fence, beyond which lay a no-man’s-land of train yards and factories. If it wasn’t a poor neighborhood, it certainly wasn’t rich. Meriwether’s father was an accountant; his mother worked for the Board of Education. Both parents were strict. The Meriwethers lived in a smallish, cinnamon-brick house with a trim lawn and tidy garden, much as most of their neighbors did. Everyone sent their children to parochial schools (the few who didn’t were ostracized as “publics”). Meriwether, attired in a pale blue shirt and dark blue tie, attended St. John de la Salle Elementary and later Mendel Catholic High School, taught by Augustinian priests. Discipline was harsh. The boys were rapped with a ruler or, in the extreme, made to kneel on their knuckles for an entire class. Educated in such a Joycean regime, Meriwether grew up accustomed to a pervasive sense of order. As one of Meriwether’s friends, a barber’s son, recalled, “We were afraid to goof around at [elementary] school because the nuns would punish you for life and you’d be sent to Hell.” As for their mortal destination, it was said, only half in jest, that the young men of Rosemoor had three choices: go to college, become a cop, or go to jail. Meriwether had no doubt about his own choice, nor did any of his peers.

他聪明伶俐，人缘极好，似乎前途一片光明。他入选了国家荣誉协会，数学成绩尤其优异——这对于债券交易员来说可是不可或缺的科目。或许数学的条理性和严谨性吸引了他。他始终保持着一种克制，仿佛越界就会招来惩罚。正如一位朋友回忆的那样，梅里韦瑟虽然说话有点儿直，但他从未惹过什么大麻烦。¹ 他很注重保护自己的隐私，任何鲁莽的冲动都被他严加隐藏，并将自己的干劲掩藏在俊朗的外表之下。他聪明，但并非神童；人缘好，但并非鹤立鸡群。在那个年代，在那个街区，他确实只能算是个普通人，因为在那个年代，任何不平凡的人都会面临巨大的压力。

A popular, bright student, he was seemingly headed for success. He qualified for the National Honor Society, scoring especially high marks in mathematics—an indispensable subject for a bond trader. Perhaps the orderliness of mathematics appealed to him. He was ever guided by a sense of restraint, as if to step out of bounds would invite the ruler’s slap. Although Meriwether had a bit of a mouth on him, as one chum recalled, he never got into serious trouble.¹ Private with his feelings, he kept any reckless impulse strictly under wraps and cloaked his drive behind a comely reserve. He was clever but not a prodigy, well liked but not a standout. He was, indeed, average enough in a neighborhood and time in which it would have been hell to have been anything but average.

梅里韦瑟也喜欢赌博，但前提是赔率对他足够有利，能让他占尽优势。事实上，赌博领域正好能让他谨慎的风险承受能力发挥到极致。他学会了赌马，也学会了玩二十一点，后者要感谢他那位爱玩牌的祖母。凭借着与生俱来的对赔率的敏锐感知，他会赌芝加哥小熊队，但前提是他得先查好天气预报，知道瑞格利球场的风向。² 他大约十二岁时就开始涉足投资，但如果说他的同龄人，甚至梅里韦瑟本人，会认为这个身材矮小、栗色头发的男孩会成为华尔街的霍雷肖·阿尔杰式的英雄，那就大错特错了。“约翰和他的哥哥在高中时就靠买股票赚钱了，”几十年后他的母亲回忆道，“他父亲给他出主意。” 仅此而已。

Meriwether also liked to gamble, but only when the odds were sufficiently in his favor to give him an edge. Gambling, indeed, was a field in which his cautious approach to risk-taking could be applied to his advantage. He learned to bet on horses and also to play blackjack, the latter courtesy of a card-playing grandma. Parlaying an innate sense of the odds, he would bet on the Chicago Cubs, but not until he got the weather report so he knew how the winds would be blowing at Wrigley Field.² His first foray into investments was at age twelve or so, but it would be wrong to suggest that it occurred to any of his peers, or even to Meriwether himself, that this modestly built, chestnut-haired boy was a Horatio Alger hero destined for glory on Wall Street. “John and his older brother made money in high school buying stocks,” his mother recalled decades later. “His father advised him.” And that was that.

梅里韦瑟逃离罗斯摩尔，靠的是一种独特的爱好：不是投资，而是高尔夫。从小，他就经常出入公园里的高尔夫球场，这对于一个罗斯摩尔男孩来说，算得上是一种不同寻常的消遣。他是门德尔学校高尔夫球队的杰出成员，曾两次赢得芝加哥郊区天主教联盟高尔夫锦标赛冠军。他还曾在弗洛斯莫尔乡村俱乐部当球童，那里位于芝加哥南部，需要乘坐相当长的火车或巴士才能到达。弗洛斯莫尔的管理人员很欣赏这位真诚友善的年轻人，让他为最富有的球手当球童——这是一项收入颇丰的特权。一位会员提名他申请奇克·埃文斯奖学金，该奖学金以20世纪初一位名叫奇克·埃文斯的高尔夫球手的名字命名，这位球手曾萌生了一个美好的想法：设立一项大学奖学金，专门资助球童。梅里韦瑟最终选择了位于伊利诺伊州埃文斯顿的西北大学，那里坐落在密歇根湖畔，距离罗斯摩尔25英里，却仿佛是另一个世界。他此前的经历凸显了两个看似矛盾的真理。首先，融入某个群体，比如邻里或教会，能带来幸福感；虔诚地遵守群体的价值观和仪式，本身就是一种美德。但其次，梅里韦瑟也明白，培养优势——比如在街区里没人玩的游戏里拥有极低的胜算——是至关重要的。

Meriwether made his escape from Rosemoor by means of a singular passion: not investing but golf. From an early age, he had haunted the courses at public parks, an unusual pastime for a Rosemoor boy. He was a standout member of the Mendel school team and twice won the Chicago Suburban Catholic League golf tournament. He also caddied at the Flossmoor Country Club, which involved a significant train or bus ride south of the city. The superintendents at Flossmoor took a shine to the earnest, likable young man and let him caddy for the richest players—a lucrative privilege. One of the members tabbed him for a Chick Evans scholarship, named for an early-twentieth-century golfer who had had the happy idea of endowing a college scholarship for caddies. Meriwether picked Northwestern University, in Evanston, Illinois, on the chilly waters of Lake Michigan, twenty-five miles and a world away from Rosemoor. His life story up to then had highlighted two rather conflicting verities. The first was the sense of well-being to be derived from fitting into a group such as a neighborhood or church: from religiously adhering to its values and rites. Order and custom were virtues in themselves. But second, Meriwether had learned, it paid to develop an edge—a low handicap at a game that nobody else on the block even played.

从西北大学毕业后，他当了一年高中数学老师，然后前往芝加哥大学攻读商科学位。在那里，他的同学中有一位名叫乔恩·科尔津（Jon Corzine）的谷物农户之子（后来成为梅里韦瑟在华尔街的竞争对手）。梅里韦瑟一边在CNA金融公司做分析师，一边完成商学院的学业，并于1973年毕业。第二年，这位身材健硕、眼神迷人、脸颊圆润、带着酒窝的27岁青年被所罗门兄弟公司聘用。当时，所罗门兄弟公司规模仍然很小，但它正处于席卷全球债券市场的巨大变革中心。

After Northwestern, he taught high school math for a year, then went to the University of Chicago for a business degree, where a grain farmer’s son named Jon Corzine (later Meriwether’s rival on Wall Street) was one of his classmates. Meriwether worked his way through business school as an analyst at CNA Financial Corporation, and graduated in 1973. The next year, Meriwether, now a sturdily built twenty-seven-year-old with beguiling eyes and round, dimpled cheeks, was hired by Salomon. It was still a small firm, but it was in the center of great changes that were convulsing bond markets everywhere.

直到20世纪60年代中期，债券交易一直乏味无趣。投资者购买债券（通常是从当地银行的信托部门购买）是为了获得稳定的收益，只要债券不违约，他们通常都会对自己的投资感到满意，如果他们真的会对此进行更深入的思考的话。很少有投资者积极进行债券交易，而管理债券投资组合以获得比其他人更高的回报，或者跑赢基准指数，这种概念在当时完全是陌生的。这倒也是一件好事，因为当时根本没有这样的基准指数。当时的债券界权威是所罗门兄弟公司的西德尼·霍默，他毕业于哈佛大学，是一位古典学者，与画家温斯洛·霍默有远亲关系，他的母亲是一位大都会歌剧院的女高音歌唱家。霍默是巨著《利率史：公元前2000年至今》的作者，是一位文艺绅士——这种类型的人物在华尔街很快就要消失了。

Until the mid-1960s, bond trading had been a dull sport. An investor bought bonds, often from the trust department of his local bank, for steady income, and as long as the bonds didn’t default, he was generally happy with his purchase, if indeed he gave it any further thought. Few investors actively traded bonds, and the notion of managing a bond portfolio to achieve a higher return than the next guy or, say, to beat a benchmark index, was totally foreign. That was a good thing, because no such index existed. The reigning bond guru was Salomon’s own Sidney Homer, a Harvard-educated classicist, distant relative of the painter Winslow Homer, and son of a Metropolitan Opera soprano. Homer, author of the massive tome A History of Interest Rates: 2000 BC to the Present, was a gentleman scholar—a breed on Wall Street that was shortly to disappear.

荷马时代的市场，至少与今天的市场相比，具有固定的市场关系：固定货币、受管制的利率和固定的黄金价格（每盎司35美元）。但20世纪60年代末席卷西方的通货膨胀彻底摧毁了这个安逸的世界。随着通货膨胀的加剧，利率也随之攀升，那些在4%利率看似诱人时买入的金边债券，如今价值已缩水一半甚至更多。1971年，美国取消了黄金价格管制；随后阿拉伯国家又对美国实施了石油禁运。如果债券持有人还抱有一丝稳定的幻想，那么宾夕法尼亚中央铁路公司（Penn Central Railroad）的破产——该公司主要由蓝筹股持有——则彻底粉碎了这种幻想。债券投资者，其中大多数人损失惨重，再也无法安于现状。世界各国政府逐渐被迫放弃对利率和货币的限制。固定市场关系的世界就此终结。

Homer’s markets, at least in contrast to those of today, were characterized by fixed relationships: fixed currencies, regulated interest rates, and a fixed gold price ($35 an ounce). But the epidemic of inflation that infected the West in the late 1960s destroyed this cozy world forever. As inflation rose, so did interest rates, and those giltedged bonds, bought when a 4 percent rate seemed attractive, lost half their value or more. In 1971, the United States freed the gold price; then the Arabs embargoed oil. If bondholders still harbored any illusion of stability, the bankruptcy of the Penn Central Railroad, which was widely owned by blue-chip accounts, wrecked the illusion forever. Bond investors, most of them knee-deep in losses, were no longer comfortable standing pat. Gradually, governments around the globe were forced to drop their restrictions on interest rates and on currencies. The world of fixed relationships was dead.

大豆突然显得有些过时了；如今，金钱才是炙手可热的商品。期货交易所设计出新的金融合约，例如国库券、债券和日元，到处都是新的金融工具、新的期权、新的债券可供交易，而此时，专业的投资组合经理们也正开始意识到这些工具的价值，并渴望进行交易。到了20世纪70年代末，像所罗门兄弟这样的公司对债券进行了前所未有的拆分和重组，例如将抵押贷款合并，并将其提炼成易于消化、便于交易的小型证券。

Soybeans suddenly seemed quaint; money was the hot commodity now. Futures exchanges devised new contracts in financial goods such as Treasury bills and bonds and Japanese yen, and everywhere there were new instruments, new options, new bonds to trade, just when professional portfolio managers were waking up and wanting to trade them. By the end of the 1970s, firms such as Salomon were slicing and dicing bonds in ways that Homer had never dreamed of: blending mortgages together, for instance, and distilling them into bite-sized, easily chewable securities.

另一个重大变革是计算机的出现。直到20世纪60年代末，交易员们想要查询债券价格时，仍然需要翻阅一本厚厚的蓝色债券价格手册。1969年，所罗门公司聘请了数学家马丁·莱博维茨，并为他配备了所罗门公司的第一台计算机。莱博维茨一度成为历史上最受欢迎的数学家，至少在债券市场火爆、所罗门公司的交易员们忙得不可开交，急需债券价格信息时，他似乎成了最受欢迎的数学家。到了20世纪70年代初，交易员们已经拥有了简陋的手持计算器，这在不知不觉中加快了债券市场的节奏。

The other big change was the computer. As late as the end of the 1960s, whenever traders wanted to price a bond, they would look it up in a thick blue book. In 1969, Salomon hired a mathematician, Martin Leibowitz, who got Salomon’s first computer. Leibowitz became the most popular mathematician in history, or so it seemed when the bond market was hot and Salomon’s traders, who no longer had time to page through the blue book, crowded around him to get bond prices that they now needed on the double. By the early 1970s, traders had their own crude handheld calculators, which subtly quickened the rhythm of the bond markets.

梅里韦瑟加入所罗门公司融资部门（即回购部门）时，正值债券市场风云变幻之际。曾经可预测且风险相对较低的债券市场，如今却充满了变革和机遇，尤其对那些年轻敏锐的分析师而言更是如此。梅里韦瑟初到纽约时举目无亲，便在曼哈顿一家健身俱乐部租了一间房，很快便发现债券市场简直是为他量身打造的。债券对数学爱好者有着特殊的吸引力，因为决定其价值的诸多因素都易于量化。本质上，债券价格由两个因素决定。其中一个因素可以从债券的票息中看出。如果今天的贷款利率为10%，那么购买收益率为12%的债券就需要支付溢价。那么溢价究竟是多少呢？这取决于债券的到期日、支付时间、你对未来利率的预期（如果你有的话），以及精明的发行人设计的各种复杂条款，例如债券是否可以赎回、是否可以转换为股权等等。

Meriwether, who joined Salomon on the financing desk, known as the Repo Department, got there just as the bond world was turning topsy-turvy. Once predictable and relatively low risk, the bond world was pulsating with change and opportunity, especially for younger, sharp-eyed analysts. Meriwether, who didn’t know a soul when he arrived in New York, rented a room at a Manhattan athletic club and soon discovered that bonds were made for him. Bonds have a particular appeal to mathematical types because so much of what determines their value is readily quantifiable. Essentially, two factors dictate a bond’s price. One can be gleaned from the coupon on the bond itself. If you can lend money at 10 percent today, you would pay a premium for a bond that yielded 12 percent. How much of a premium? That would depend on the maturity of the bond, the timing of the payments, your outlook (if you have one) for interest rates in the future, plus all manner of wrinkles devised by clever issuers, such as whether the bond is callable, convertible into equity, and so forth.

另一个因素是违约风险。在大多数情况下，这种风险既无法严格量化，也不算很大。但它确实存在。通用电气（GE）的风险较低，但不如美国国债（国债）那么高。惠普（Hewlett-Packard）的风险略高于GE；亚马逊（Amazon.com）的风险则更高。因此，债券投资者在向亚马逊贷款时，会要求比向GE贷款更高的利率，或者向玻利维亚贷款时，会要求比向法国贷款更高的利率。决定利率高多少是债券交易的核心，但关键在于债券交易是基于一个数学上的利差。债券风险越高，利差就越大——也就是说，债券收益率与（几乎无风险的）国债收益率之间的差异就越大。通常情况下（尽管并非总是如此），利差也会随着时间的推移而扩大——也就是说，投资者对两年期债券的收益率要求略高于30天期短期债券，因为两年期债券的不确定性更大。

The other factor is the risk of default. In most cases, that is not strictly quantifiable, nor is it very great. Still, it exists. General Electric is a good risk, but not as good as Uncle Sam. Hewlett-Packard is somewhat riskier than GE; Amazon.com, riskier still. Therefore, bond investors demand a higher interest rate when they lend to Amazon as compared with GE, or to Bolivia as compared with France. Deciding how much higher is the heart of bond trading, but the point is that bonds trade on a mathematical spread. The riskier the bond, the wider the spread—that is, the greater the difference between the yield on it and the yield on (virtually risk free) Treasurys. Generally, though not always, the spread also increases with time—that is, investors demand a slightly higher yield on a two-year note than on a thirty-day bill because the uncertainty is greater.

这些规则是债券交易的准则；它们规定了全球债务证券收益率和利差的庞大矩阵。它们如同伟大宗教的教规般复杂而不可更改，难怪梅里韦瑟——他的公文包里总是装着念珠和祈祷卡——会觉得这些规则令他感到满足。他求知若渴，像个神学院的学生一样向他的老板们抛出一连串的问题。萨洛蒙公司的高管们看出了他的潜力，便安排他交易政府机构债券。不久之后，纽约市几乎违约，各种机构债券的利差飙升。梅里韦瑟认为市场出了问题——当然，并非所有政府机构都即将破产——于是他买入了所有他能买得起的债券。利差确实收窄了，梅里韦瑟的交易让他赚得盆满钵满。³

These rules are the catechism of bond trading; they ordain a vast matrix of yields and spreads on debt securities throughout the world. They are as intricate and immutable as the rules of a great religion, and it is no wonder that Meriwether, who kept rosary beads and prayer cards in his briefcase, found them satisfying. Eager to learn, he peppered his bosses with questions like a divinity student. Sensing his promise, the suits at Salomon put him to trading government agency bonds. Soon after, New York City nearly defaulted, and the spreads on various agency bonds soared. Meriwether reckoned that the market had goofed—surely, not every government entity was about to go bust—and he bought all the bonds he could. Spreads did contract, and Meriwether’s trades made millions.³

他于1977年组建的套利集团标志着所罗门公司发展历程中一次微妙却重要的转变。这也是长期资本在20世纪90年代逐一复制的模式——一个让梅里韦瑟逐渐习惯并乐于承担高风险的实验室。尽管所罗门公司一直从事债券交易，但其主要业务一直是为客户买卖相对安全的债券。然而，由梅里韦瑟领导的套利集团成为了主要参与者，开始投入所罗门公司自身的资本进行交易。由于该领域尚属新兴，梅里韦瑟的竞争对手寥寥无几，因此获利颇丰。与埃克斯坦交易类似，他经常押注价差（例如期货合约与标的债券之间的价差，或两种债券之间的价差）会趋于收敛。他也可以押注价差扩大，但价差收敛是他的主要策略。与他进行交易的另一方可能是保险公司、银行或投机者；梅里韦瑟对此毫不知情，通常他也不会在意。偶尔，其他投资者可能会感到恐慌，撤回资金，导致价差进一步扩大，使梅里韦瑟蒙受损失，至少暂时如此。但如果他有足够的资金坚持下去，从长远来看，他终将获得回报，至少他的经验似乎证明了这一点。最终，价差总会扩大；这是他从埃克斯坦事件中学到的教训，也是多年后他在长期资本公司工作时所倚重的教训。但如果梅里韦瑟的成功来得没有那么快，他或许还能从埃克斯坦事件中汲取另一个同样宝贵的教训：虽然亏损的交易最终可能会扭亏为盈（当然，前提是交易一开始就经过了正确的规划），但这种转变可能来得太晚，对交易者没有任何好处——这意味着，他在此期间可能会破产。

The Arbitrage Group, which he formed in 1977, marked a subtle but important shift in Salomon’s evolution. It was also the model that Long-Term Capital was to replicate, brick for brick, in the 1990s—a laboratory in which Meriwether would become accustomed to, and comfortable with, taking big risks. Although Salomon had always traded bonds, its primary focus had been the relatively safer business of buying and selling bonds for customers. But the Arbitrage Group, led by Meriwether, became a principal, risking Salomon’s own capital. Because the field was new, Meriwether had few competitors, and the pickings were rich. As in the Eckstein trade, he often bet that a spread—say, between a futures contract and the underlying bond, or between two bonds—would converge. He could also bet on spreads to widen, but convergence was his dominant theme. The people on the other side of his trades might be insurers, banks, or speculators; Meriwether wouldn’t know, and usually he wouldn’t care. Occasionally, these other investors might get scared and withdraw their capital, causing spreads to widen further and causing Meriwether to lose money, at least temporarily. But if he had the capital to stay the course, he’d be rewarded in the long run, or so his experience seemed to prove. Eventually, spreads always came in; that was the lesson he had learned from the Eckstein affair, and it was a lesson he would count on, years later, at Long-Term Capital. But there was a different lesson, equally valuable, that Meriwether might have drawn from the Eckstein business, had his success not come so fast: while a losing trade may well turn around eventually (assuming, of course, that it was properly conceived to begin with), the turn could arrive too late to do the trader any good—meaning, of course, that he might go broke in the interim.

到了20世纪80年代初，梅里韦瑟已是所罗门兄弟公司冉冉升起的新星。他腼腆的性格和一副冷若冰霜的扑克脸，完美地衬托出他高超的交易技巧。曾面试过他的所罗门合伙人威廉·麦金托什评价道：“约翰的头脑非常敏锐，你根本猜不透他在想什么。”梅里韦瑟的前同事、作家迈克尔·刘易斯在《说谎者的扑克牌》一书中也表达了对梅里韦瑟的类似评价：

By the early 1980s, Meriwether was one of Salomon’s bright young stars. His shyness and implacable poker face played perfectly to his skill as a trader. William McIntosh, the Salomon partner who had interviewed him, said, “John has a steel-trap mind. You have no clue to what he’s thinking.” Meriwether’s former colleague, the writer Michael Lewis, echoed this assessment of Meriwether in Liar’s Poker:

无论输赢，他脸上都带着同样的茫然和半紧张的表情。我认为，他拥有极强的能力来控制两种通常会摧毁交易员的情绪——恐惧和贪婪——这使他成为一个如此执着于自身利益的人所能达到的高尚品格。4

He wore the same blank half-tense expression when he won as he did when he lost. He had, I think, a profound ability to control the two emotions that commonly destroy traders—fear and greed—and it made him as noble as a man who pursues his self-interest so fiercely can be.4

这本书着重强调了梅里韦瑟据称曾怂恿古特弗伦德玩一局价值1000万美元的扑克牌的事件，这令人遗憾。这不仅是因为这个故事听起来像是杜撰的，更因为它将梅里韦瑟的鲁莽行为奉为圭臬，而这种鲁莽并非他的本性。⁵梅里韦瑟是精于算计的赌徒。他谨慎得近乎偏执，从不轻易流露自己的任何信息。他的背景、家庭、过往经历对同事来说就像一片空白，正如一位同事所说，他仿佛“划了一条界线”。他极其注重隐私，以至于在长期资本丑闻成为头版头条新闻时，《纽约时报》的一位记者在试图弄清梅里韦瑟是否有兄弟姐妹后，最终只能引用朋友的错误说法，认为他是独生子。⁶这种沉默寡言对于交易员来说固然是完美的品质，但这还远远不够。梅里韦瑟一定感觉到了，他所缺乏的是优势——某种特殊的本领，就像他在高中打高尔夫球时培养出来的那种本领一样，某种能让所罗门与其他债券交易员区别开来的东西。

It was a pity that the book emphasized a supposed incident in which Meriwether allegedly dared Gutfreund to play a single hand of poker for $10 million, not merely because the story seems apocryphal, but because it canonized Meriwether for a recklessness that wasn’t his.5 Meriwether was the priest of the calculated gamble. He was cautious to a fault; he gave away nothing of himself. His background, his family, his entire past were as much of a blank to colleagues as if, one said, he had “drawn a line in the sand.” He was so intensely private that even when the Long-Term Capital affair was front-page news, a New York Times writer, after trying to determine if Meriwether had any siblings, settled for citing the inaccurate opinion of friends who thought him an only child.6 Such reticence was a perfect attribute for a trader, but it was not enough. What Meriwether lacked, he must have sensed, was an edge—some special forte like the one he had developed on the links in high school, something that would distinguish Salomon from every other bond trader.

他的解决方案看似简单：为什么不雇佣更聪明的交易员呢？那些将市场视为一门理性学科，而不是像民间传说中那样，凭感觉进行交易的原始人？学术界充斥着书呆子气的数学家，他们多年来发表着晦涩难懂的市场论文。华尔街也开始雇佣他们，但仅限于研究工作，这样他们就能远离危险。在华尔街，这些书呆子被贴上了“量化交易员”的标签，被认为不适合从事交易这种“男人的游戏”。所罗门兄弟公司政府债券交易主管克雷格·科茨二世就是交易大厅里典型的典型人物：身材高大，性格讨喜，相貌英俊，肯定能与客户相处融洽。没错，他大学时是个游手好闲的人，但他曾是篮球队的前锋，而且他热爱交易。梅里韦瑟想要消除的正是这种激情。他更喜欢学者们冷静的纪律，以及他们对市场严谨而高度量化的研究方法。

His solution was deceptively simple: Why not hire traders who were smarter? Traders who would treat markets as an intellectual discipline, as opposed to the folkloric, unscientific Neanderthals who traded from their bellies? Academia was teeming with nerdy mathematicians who had been publishing unintelligible dissertations on markets for years. Wall Street had started to hire them, but only for research, where they’d be out of harm’s way. On Wall Street, the eggheads were stigmatized as “quants,” unfit for the man’s game of trading. Craig Coats, Jr., head of government-bond trading at Salomon, was a type typical of trading floors: tall, likable, handsome, bound to get along with clients. Sure, he had been a goof-off in college, but he had played forward on the basketball team, and he had trading in his heart. It was just this element of passion that Meriwether wanted to eliminate; he preferred the cool discipline of scholars, with their rigorous and highly quantitative approach to markets.

大多数华尔街高管对学术界感到困惑，但梅里韦瑟却很适应。他是一位数学老师，拥有芝加哥大学的工商管理硕士学位。这正是他的优势所在。 1983年，梅里韦瑟打电话给埃里克·罗森菲尔德，一位性格温和、毕业于麻省理工学院、现任哈佛商学院助理教授，询问罗森菲尔德是否能推荐他的学生。罗森菲尔德的父亲是马萨诸塞州康科德市一位小有成就的基金经理，他本人是个电脑迷，此前就已开始运用量化方法进行投资。然而，在哈佛，他却举步维艰。罗森菲尔德言简意赅、略显枯燥，虽然才华横溢，但在课堂上却缺乏感染力。从远处看，他就像一只戴着眼镜的瘦弱老鼠。学生们对他很苛刻；据他未来的一位同事回忆，“他们把他揍得鼻青脸肿”。罗森菲尔德当时正在批改试卷，梅里韦瑟打电话来时，他回忆说自己年收入大约是3万美元。罗森菲尔德立即表示愿意亲自去萨洛蒙那里试镜。十天后，他被录用了。8

Most Wall Street executives were mystified by the academic world, but Meriwether, a math teacher with an M.B.A. from Chicago, was comfortable with it. That would be his edge. In 1983, Meriwether called Eric Rosenfeld, a sweet-natured MIT-trained Harvard Business School assistant professor, to see if Rosenfeld could recommend any of his students. The son of a modestly successful Concord, Massachusetts, money manager, Rosenfeld was a computer freak who had already been using quantitative methods to make investments. At Harvard, he was struggling.7 Laconic and dry, Rosenfeld was compellingly bright, but he was less than commanding in a classroom. At a distance, he looked like a thin, bespectacled mouse. The students were tough on him; “they beat the shit out of him,” according to a future colleague. Rosenfeld, who was grading exams when Meriwether called and was making, as he recalled, roughly $30,000 a year, instantly offered to audition for Salomon himself. Ten days later, he was hired.8

梅里韦瑟的招募并未止步于此。继罗森菲尔德之后，他又聘请了维克多·J·哈加尼，一位拥有伦敦政治经济学院金融硕士学位的伊朗裔美国人；格雷戈里·霍金斯，一位曾协助比尔·克林顿竞选州检察长的阿肯色州人，之后在麻省理工学院获得了金融经济学博士学位；以及威廉·克拉斯克，一位思维严谨、数学素养极高的经济学家，同样拥有麻省理工学院的博士学位，并且是罗森菲尔德在哈佛大学的同事。或许最书呆子气，也无疑是最聪明的，当属劳伦斯·希利布兰德，他拥有麻省理工学院的两个学位。希利布兰德最初被安排在所罗门兄弟的研究部门——量化分析师的传统聚集地——但梅里韦瑟很快将他调入套利团队，而该团队正是未来长期资本的核心所在。

Meriwether didn’t stop there. After Rosenfeld, he hired Victor J. Haghani, an Iranian American with a master’s degree in finance from the London School of Economics; Gregory Hawkins, an Arkansan who had helped run Bill Clinton’s campaign for state attorney general and had then gotten a Ph.D. in financial economics from MIT; and William Krasker, an intense, mathematically minded economist with a Ph.D. from—once again—MIT and a colleague of Rosenfeld at Harvard. Probably the nerdiest, and surely the smartest, was Lawrence Hilibrand, who had two degrees from MIT. Hilibrand was hired by Salomon’s research department, the traditional home of quants, but Meriwether quickly moved him into the Arbitrage Group, which, of course, was the heart of the future Long-Term Capital.

这些专家们立刻涌入华尔街。他们把能找到的所有历史债券价格数据下载到电脑里，提炼出债券的历史走势，并建立模型预测这些价格未来的变化。然后，一旦某个市场的债券价格出现异常波动，电脑模型就会发出警报。

The eggheads immediately took to Wall Street. They downloaded into their computers all of the past bond prices they could get their hands on. They distilled the bonds’ historical relationships, and they modeled how these prices should behave in the future. And then, when a market price somewhere, somehow got out of line, the computer models told them.

这些模型并没有命令他们进行交易；它们只是为人类计算机提供了一个可供思考的背景论据。它们简化了一个复杂的世界。或许两年期国债的收益率与十年期国债的收益率比通常情况更接近；又或许两者之间的利差异常狭窄，与其他一些国家的债券相比。这些模型将市场简化为一个明确的问题。正如其中一位成员所说：“鉴于全球形势——收益率曲线的形状、波动性和利率——金融市场是否在发出相互矛盾的信号？” 这就是他们的讨论方式，也是他们的思考方式。每一个价格都是一种“信号”；如果两种信号相互冲突，就可能存在套利机会。

The models didn’t order them to trade; they provided a contextual argument for the human computers to consider. They simplified a complicated world. Maybe the yield on two-year Treasury notes was a bit closer than it ordinarily was to the yield on ten-year bonds; or maybe the spread between the two was unusually narrow, compared with a similar spread for some other country’s paper. The models condensed the markets into a pointed inquiry. As one of the group said, “Given the state of things around the world—the shape of yield curves, volatilities, interest rates—are the financial markets making statements that are inconsistent with each other?” This is how they talked, and this is how they thought. Every price was a “statement”; if two statements were in conflict, there might be an opportunity for arbitrage.

若非两个幸运的巧合，整个实验肯定会失败。首先，教授们都很聪明。他们专注于自己的研究领域，而且机会众多，尤其是在衍生品等新兴市场。教授们把机会看作是市场效率低下的表现；在一个完全有效的市场中，所有价格都正确，因此没有人会进行交易。然而，由于他们交易的市场仍在发展演变，价格常常不准确，因此机会比比皆是。此外，教授们还秉持着一种从学术界习得的坚定信念：随着时间的推移，所有市场都会变得更加高效。

The whole experiment would surely have failed, except for two happy circumstances. First, the professors were smart. They stuck to their knitting, and opportunities were plentiful, especially in newer markets such as derivatives. The professors spoke of opportunities as inefficiencies; in a perfectly efficient market, in which all prices were correct, no one would have anything to trade. Since the markets they traded in were still evolving, though, prices were often incorrect and there were opportunities aplenty. Moreover, the professors brought to the job an abiding credo, learned from academia, that over time, all markets tend to get more efficient.

他们尤其认为，风险较高债券和风险较低债券之间的利差会趋于收窄。这合乎逻辑，因为利差在一定程度上反映了风险较高资产所伴随的不确定性。随着时间的推移，如果市场效率提高，这类风险较高的债券波动性会降低，因此看起来更确定，投资者要求的溢价也会趋于下降。例如，在20世纪80年代初期，互换（一种衍生品交易，稍后会详细介绍）的利差为2个百分点。“他们看到这种情况后说，‘这不可能；风险不可能这么大，’”套利公司的一位初级成员回忆道。“他们说，‘市场效率将会逐渐提高，这是一个长期趋势。’”

In particular, they believed, spreads between riskier and less risky bonds would tend to narrow. This followed logically because spreads reflect, in part, the uncertainty that is attached to chancier assets. Over time, if markets did become more efficient, such riskier bonds would be less volatile and therefore more certain-seeming, and so the premium demanded by investors would tend to shrink. In the early 1980s, for instance, the spreads on swaps—a type of derivative trade, of which more later—were 2 percentage points. “They looked at this and said, ‘It can’t be right; there can’t be that much risk,’ ” a junior member of Arbitrage recalled. “They said, ‘There is going to be a secular trend toward a more efficient market.’ ”

互换利差确实收窄了——先是收窄到1个百分点，最终收窄到0.25个百分点。整个华尔街都在进行这种交易，包括由日益谨慎的科茨掌管的所罗门集团政府债券交易部门。不同之处在于，梅里韦瑟的套利团队投入了巨额资金。如果交易对他们不利，套利者们，尤其是信心十足的希利布兰德，只会加倍下注。凭借他们的模型，他们比其他人更有把握——几乎是无敌的。只要有足够的时间和资金，这些来自学术界的年轻天才们就觉得自己永远不会犯错，而经常奔赴学术会议招募这类人才的梅里韦瑟也开始相信这些天才们是对的。

And swap spreads did tighten—to 1 percentage point and eventually to a quarter point. All of Wall Street did this trade, including the Salomon government desk, run by the increasingly wary Coats. The difference was that Meriwether’s Arbitrage Group did it in very big dollars. If a trade went against them, the arbitrageurs, especially the ever-confident Hilibrand, merely redoubled the bet. Backed by their models, they felt more certain than others did—almost invincible. Given enough time, given enough capital, the young geniuses from academe felt they could do no wrong, and Meriwether, who regularly journeyed to academic conferences to recruit such talent, began to believe that the geniuses were right.

这是第二个令人欣喜的巧合：教授们有位保护者，让他们免受公司政治的干扰，并为他们提供交易所需的资金。但对梅里韦瑟来说，这个实验不可能成功；教授们与公司格格不入。希利布兰德，一位来自新泽西州樱桃山的工程师之子，就像学术界的阿尔·戈尔；他社交笨拙，对看似最简单的问题也总是给出生硬而专业的回答——尽管他的回答在数学上十分精确。有一次，一位非套利交易组的交易员试图劝阻希利布兰德买卖某对证券。希利布兰德仿佛在进行一场教学讲座，回答说：“但它们的定价实在太离谱了。 ”他的同事早已习惯了交易大厅里粗俗的玩笑，立刻反驳道：“我也是这么想的——‘离谱’！”在一群桀骜不驯的交易员的包围下，这些套利者就像一群安静的知识分子。克拉斯克是一位谨慎的教授，他构建了团队的许多模型，但却毫无个人魅力。罗森菲尔德则颇具讽刺意味的幽默感，但在一个许多合伙人都没上过大学，更别提在麻省理工学院读研究生的公司里，他显得腼腆寡言。

That was the second happy circumstance: the professors had a protector who shielded them from company politics and got them the capital to trade. But for Meriwether, the experiment couldn’t have worked; the professors were simply too out of place. Hilibrand, an engineer’s son from Cherry Hill, New Jersey, was like an academic version of Al Gore; socially awkward, he answered the simplest-seeming questions with wooden and technical—albeit mathematically precise—replies. Once, a trader not in the Arbitrage Group tried to talk Hilibrand out of buying and selling a certain pair of securities. Hilibrand replied, as if conducting a tutorial, “But they are priced so egregiously.” His colleague, accustomed to the profane banter of the trading floor, shot back, “I was thinking the same thing—‘egregiously’!” Surrounded by unruly traders, the arbitrageurs were quiet intellectuals. Krasker, the cautious professor who built many of the group’s models, had all the charisma of a tabletop. Rosenfeld had a wry sense of humor, but in a firm in which many of the partners hadn’t gone to college, much less graduate school at MIT, he was shy and taciturn.

梅里韦瑟拥有将这群人带到华尔街的独特天赋——所罗门兄弟的竞争对手后来都效仿了这一举动。“他招揽了一群在企业界被视为怪胎的人，”当时在所罗门兄弟担任投资银行家的杰伊·希金斯说道，“如果不是约翰，这些人可能还在贝尔实验室里摆弄计算尺，他们自己也明白这一点。”

Meriwether had the particular genius to bring this group to Wall Street—a move that Salomon’s competitors would later imitate. “He took a bunch of guys who in the corporate world were considered freaks,” noted Jay Higgins, then an investment banker at Salomon. “Those guys would be playing with their slide rules at Bell Labs if it wasn’t for John, and they knew it.”9

这些教授们精于将交易简化为利弊；他们甚至能把一个火腿三明治的风险都拆解开来；但他们却几乎无法进行正常的对话。梅里韦瑟为他们创造了一个安全、自给自足的环境来提升技能；他满怀热情地将套利交易打造成了一个独立的世界。正因为有了梅里韦瑟，交易员们彼此之间才建立了友谊，他们也无需再与其他人交往。

The professors were brilliant at reducing a trade to pluses and minuses; they could strip a ham sandwich to its component risks; but they could barely carry on a normal conversation. Meriwether created a safe, self-contained place for them to develop their skills; he adoringly made Arbitrage into a world apart. Because of Meriwether, the traders fraternized with one another, and they didn’t feel the need to fraternize with anyone else.

梅里韦瑟会说：“我们星期天打高尔夫。”他无需再补充一句：“我希望你们都能来。”像希利布兰德和罗森菲尔德这样以前没打过高尔夫的交易员，很快就学会了。梅里韦瑟还迷上了马，买了几匹纯种马；自然而然地，他也带着他的交易员们去赛马场。他甚至每年都带着这群人及其配偶去安提瓜岛。他不仅希望他们在交易时间出现，而是希望他们所有人，时时刻刻都陪伴在他身边。他悉心培育他的交易员，同时为他们筑起一道如同罗斯摩尔红木板围栏般坚固的保护屏障。

Meriwether would say, “We’re playing golf on Sunday,” and he didn’t have to add, “I’d like you to be there.” The traders who hadn’t played golf before, such as Hilibrand and Rosenfeld, quickly learned. Meriwether also developed a passion for horses and acquired some thoroughbreds; naturally, he took his traders to the track, too. He even shepherded the gang and their spouses to Antigua every year. He didn’t want them just during trading hours, he wanted all of them, all the time. He nurtured his traders, all the while building a protective fence around the group as sturdy as the red board fence in Rosemoor.

梅里韦瑟的作风一贯如此，他将赌博融入了这群人的共同生活。这些套利者会在高尔夫球周末精心策划复杂的赌局；他们会赌马；还会一起去大西洋城一日游。他们会赌选举结果。只要是能激发他们对赔率热情的事情，他们都会赌。当他们谈论体育时，讨论的不是比赛本身，而是让分盘。

Typical of Meriwether, he made gambling an intimate part of the group’s shared life. The arbitrageurs devised elaborate betting pools over golf weekends; they bet on horses; they took day trips to Atlantic City together. They bet on elections. They bet on anything that aroused their passion for odds. When they talked sports, it wasn’t about the game; it was about the point spread.

梅里韦瑟喜欢让他的交易员玩“说谎者扑克”，这是一种用美元钞票上的序列号组成扑克牌型的游戏。他喜欢考验他的交易员；他认为这种游戏能磨练他们的直觉，如果他们玩得不好，他就会变得很粗鲁，甚至威胁要退出。一开始只是玩玩，但后来就变得很认真了；交易员们会玩上好几个小时，有时赌注高达数万美元。罗森菲尔德的办公桌里放着一个信封，里面塞满了数百张零散的钞票。后来，当某些钞票出现的频率过高时，他们就放弃了用钞票，转而使用电脑生成随机数字列表。套利交易员们似乎对赌博上瘾了：“你和梅里韦瑟的人出去吃饭，总会玩‘说谎者扑克’，看看谁来买单，”所罗门兄弟公司的首席财务官杰拉尔德·罗森菲尔德回忆道。梅里韦瑟是个高手，埃里克·罗森菲尔德（与他没有亲戚关系）也是，他总是面无表情，让人捉摸不透。为人正直的希利布兰德有点过于拘泥于字面意思。他从不说谎，而且很长一段时间里从不虚张声势；他留着小胡子，聪明得令人毛骨悚然，身上有一种近乎超凡脱俗的超脱感。有一次，有人问他，妻子从事抵押贷款业务（希利布兰德本人也从事抵押贷款交易），这是否会让他感到尴尬，他直截了当地回答说：“嗯，我从不和妻子谈论生意。”

Meriwether loved for his traders to play liar’s poker, a game that involves making poker hands from the serial numbers on dollar bills. He liked to test his traders; he thought the game honed their instincts, and he would get churlish and threaten to quit when they played poorly. It started as fun, but then it got serious; the traders would play for hours, occasionally for stakes in the tens of thousands of dollars. Rosenfeld kept an envelope stuffed with hundreds of single bills in his desk. Then, when it seemed that certain bills were cropping up too often, they did away with bills and got a computer to generate random lists of numbers. The Arbitrage boys seemed addicted to gambling: “You could never go out to dinner with J.M.’s guys without playing liar’s poker to see who would pick up the check,” Gerald Rosenfeld, Salomon’s chief financial officer, recalled. Meriwether was a good player, and so was Eric Rosenfeld (no relation), who had an inscrutable poker face. The straight-arrow Hilibrand was a bit too literal. He was incapable of lying and for a long time never bluffed; mustachioed and eerily intelligent, he had a detachment that was almost extrahuman. Once, when asked whether it was awkward to have a wife who worked in mortgages (which Hilibrand traded), he answered flatly, “Well, I never talk to my wife about business.”

套利小组大约十二人，关系非常密切。他们坐在所罗门银行喧闹的交易大厅中央的两排办公桌旁，这间大厅正是汤姆·沃尔夫小说《虚荣的篝火》中投资银行的原型。套利小组的抵押贷款交易员兰迪·希勒受不了小组的排外氛围，离开了。另一位离职者被当成了叛徒；梅里韦瑟出于报复，命令小组成员甚至不许和他一起打高尔夫。但最终离开的交易员寥寥无几，留下来的人几乎都崇拜梅里韦瑟。他们低声谈论他，就像摩西带领他们来到巴勒斯坦一样。梅里韦瑟并没有完全回报他们的赞美，但他给予了他们更有价值的东西。他的兴趣和好奇心激励着这些教授们；它挑战着他们，使他们变得更好。而他则以发自内心的忠诚回报他们。他从不咆哮，但即便他咆哮，也无济于事。对于交易员来说，“JM”这两个字母——因为这是他始终如一的绰号——就像任何两个字母一样具有强大的力量。

The Arbitrage Group, about twelve in all, became incredibly close. They sat in a double row of desks in the middle of Salomon’s raucous trading floor, which was the model for the investment bank in Tom Wolfe’s The Bonfire of the Vanities. Randy Hiller, a mortgage trader in Arbitrage, found its cliquish aspect overbearing and left. Another defector was treated like a traitor; Meriwether vengefully ordered the crew not to even golf with him. But very few traders left, and those who remained all but worshiped Meriwether. They spoke of him in hushed tones, as of a Moses who had brought their tribe to Palestine. Meriwether didn’t exactly return the praise, but he gave them something more worthwhile. His interest and curiosity stimulated the professors; it challenged them and made them better. And he rewarded them with heartfelt loyalty. He never screamed, but it wouldn’t have mattered if he had. To the traders, the two initials “J.M.”—for that was his unfailing sobriquet—were as powerful as any two letters could be.

尽管梅里韦瑟在楼上有一间私人办公室，但他通常坐在交易大厅里，和其他人挤在一张狭小的桌子旁。他一边抽着烟，一边进行欧洲美元交易，并通过提出尖锐的问题来指导教授们。不知何故，他将雄心壮志包裹在一种令人敬佩的谦逊之中。他喜欢说，他从不雇用比自己不聪明的人。他从不谈论自己，但没人注意到这一点，因为他真心实意地关心其他人的工作。他没有亲自构建模型，但他能理解模型的运行规律。他信任这些模型，因为它们是他的团队成员构建的。有一次，一位名叫安迪的交易员在抵押贷款交易中亏损，请求允许加倍投入，梅里韦瑟漫不经心地答应了。“你不想多了解一下这笔交易吗？”安迪问道。梅里韦瑟信任的回答深深地打动了这位交易员。梅里韦瑟说：“我做这笔交易就是雇用你。”

Though he had a private office upstairs, Meriwether usually sat on the trading floor, at a tiny desk squeezed in with the others. He would chain-smoke while doing Eurodollar trades, and supervise the professors by asking probing questions. Somehow, he sheathed great ambition in an affecting modesty. He liked to say that he never hired anyone who wasn’t smarter than he was. He didn’t talk about himself, but no one noticed because he was genuinely interested in what the others were doing. He didn’t build the models, but he grasped what the models were saying. And he trusted the models because his guys had built them. One time, a trader named Andy who was losing money on a mortgage trade asked for permission to double up, and J.M. gave it rather offhandedly. “Don’t you want to know more about this trade?” Andy asked. Meriwether’s trusting reply deeply affected the trader. J.M. said, “My trade was when I hired you.”

1981年，梅里韦瑟与来自加利福尼亚的马术爱好者米米·默里结婚，两人住在上东区约克大道一套简朴的两居室公寓里。据一位同事说，他们想要孩子，但一直没有孩子。除了米米，梅里韦瑟的家人就是萨洛蒙公司。他甚至连午饭都不离开办公桌；事实上，他的午餐时间就像教授们的模特一样一成不变。萨洛蒙公司提供瓷器餐具的午餐，很长一段时间里，每天都会有一位侍者端着一份白面包夹博洛尼亚香肠的三明治、两个苹果和一瓶藏在银色玻璃罩下的健怡可乐，轻盈地走到梅里韦瑟面前。梅里韦瑟会吃掉一个苹果，然后随机把另一个苹果递给一位同事，作为一种象征性的举动。其他人可能会点中餐外卖，如果酱汁漏到 JM 的桌子上，JM 就会怒气冲冲地说：“看来我得放弃我的桌子，回我的办公室去工作了。”

Meriwether had married Mimi Murray, a serious equestrian from California, in 1981, and the two of them lived in a modest two-bedroom apartment on York Avenue on the Upper East Side. They wanted children, according to a colleague, but remained childless. Aside from Mimi, J.M.’s family was Salomon. He didn’t leave his desk even for lunch; in fact, his noontime was as routinized as the professors’ models. Salomon did a china-service lunch, and for a long time, every day, a waiter would waft over to Meriwether bearing a bologna sandwich on white bread, two apples, and a Tab hidden under a silver dome. J.M. would eat one of the apples and randomly offer the other to one of the troops as a sort of token. The rest of the gang might order Chinese food, and if any sauce leaked onto his desk, J.M., his precious territory violated, would scowl and say, “Look, I guess I’m going to have to give up my desk and go back to my office and work there.”

在华尔街那些傲慢自大的银行家圈子里，JM显得格格不入。他更认同自己从小一起长大的那些乡下学校的男孩们，而不是他后来加入的那些富有的企业高管。与上世纪八十年代其他那些迅速成为社交版面常客的金融家不同，梅里韦瑟不屑于引人注目（他甚至把自己的照片从所罗门兄弟的年度报告中抹去），也拒绝食用任何带有法式风味的食物。在东京，他只去麦当劳。他始终是个局外人，并将自己的圈子打造成了一个同样局外人的部落，其凝聚力、忠诚度和保护欲都堪比他在罗斯摩尔离开的那个世界。他的伙伴们都以学生时代的绰号为人所知，比如维克、酋长、ER和鹰眼。

A misfit among Wall Street’s Waspish bankers, J.M. identified more with the parochial school boys he had grown up with than with the rich executives whose number he had joined. Unlike other financiers in the roaring eighties, who were fast becoming trendy habitués of the social pages, Meriwether disdained attention (he purged his picture from Salomon’s annual report) and refused to dine on any food that smacked of French. When in Tokyo, he went to McDonald’s. Ever an outsider, he molded his group into a tribe of outsiders as cohesive, loyal, and protective as the world he had left in Rosemoor. His cohorts were known by schoolboy nicknames such as Vic, the Sheik, E.R., and Hawk.

尽管梅里韦瑟精通市场，但他作为交易员的名声却被过分夸大了。他真正的本事在于塑造人心，而他在这方面的风格却异常低调。他不太擅长与人交谈；他的话语断断续续，让人难以理解。然而，他对部下的信心却写在脸上，这如同良药般鼓舞着他们的士气。交易员们本身就拥有非凡的自信，再加上梅里韦瑟对他们的信任，形成了一种强大却又暗藏危险的组合。这进一步助长了他们原本就极度的自信。此外，梅里韦瑟愿意用所罗门的资金资助希利布兰德等人，这危险地让这些人误以为他们总能获得更多资金。

Although J.M. knew his markets, his reputation as a trader was overwrought. His real skill was in shaping people, which he did in singularly understated style. He was awkward when speaking to a group; his words came out in uneven bunches, leaving others to piece together their meaning.10 But his confidence in his troops was written on his face, and it worked on their spirits like a tonic. Combined with the traders’ uncommon self-confidence, Meriwether’s faith in them was a potent but potentially combustible mix. It inflated their already supreme self-assurance. Moreover, J.M.’s willingness to bankroll Hilibrand and the others with Salomon’s capital dangerously conditioned the troops to think that they would always have access to more.

随着套利业务盈利不断增长，该集团的业务范围也必然扩大。梅里韦瑟超越了科茨等竞争对手，掌控了所有债券交易，包括政府债券、抵押贷款、高收益公司债券、欧洲债券和日本权证。该集团将自身模式应用于新的、更有利可图的领域，这似乎顺理成章。但所罗门集团内部其他人开始感到不满。梅里韦瑟会派他的手下——希利布兰德或维克多·哈加尼——前往所罗门集团的伦敦或东京办事处，这些使者会宣称：“这笔交易很不错，但你们应该投入十倍的规模。”不是两倍，而是十倍！仿佛他们绝对不会失败似的。希利布兰德和哈加尼当时才二十几岁，而他们面对的却是比他们年长一倍的人。于是，这些人开始说：“别做这笔交易；我们比任何人都擅长，所以我们会在套利部门包揽所有交易。”

As Arbitrage made more money, the group’s turf inevitably expanded. Meriwether, eclipsing rivals such as Coats, gained command over all bond trading, including government bonds, mortgages, high-yield corporate bonds, European bonds, and Japanese warrants. It seemed logical, for the group to apply its models in new and greener pastures. But others in Salomon began to seethe. J.M. would send one of his boys—Hilibrand or Victor Haghani—to Salomon’s London office or its Tokyo office, and the emissary would declare, “This trade is very good, but you should be ten times bigger in it.” Not two times, but ten times! As if they couldn’t fail. Hilibrand and Haghani were in their twenties, and they might be talking to guys twice their age. Then they started to say, “Don’t do this trade; we’re better at this than anyone else, so we’ll do all of this trade on the arbitrage desk.”

希利布兰德尤其令人恼火。他举止正式，彬彬有礼，但老手们却觉得他居高临下，他那套数学式的笃定更是让他们火冒三丈。有一次，他试图说服一些商品交易员，让他们押注石油价格会像债券价格一样波动。交易员们半信半疑地听着，希利布兰德则不停地点头。突然，他举起一只手，高声宣布：“考虑以下假设。” 仿佛他是在颁布一道神圣的法令，要刻在石头上。

Hilibrand was particularly annoying. He was formal and polite, but he struck old hands as condescending, infuriating them with his mathematical certitude. One time, he tried to persuade some commodity traders that they should bet on oil prices following a pattern similar to that of bond prices. The traders listened dubiously while Hilibrand bobbed his head back and forth. Suddenly he raised a hand and sonorously declaimed, “Consider the following hypothesis.” It was as if he were delivering an edict from on high, to be etched in stone.

交易员们的生活焦虑不安；他们整天对着电话大喊大叫，在房间里大声喧哗，紧张地盯着电脑屏幕。套利小组就身处这看似平静的混乱之中，却像是一个神秘而特权的亚文化群体。他们一半时间用晦涩难懂的术语讨论交易，仿佛在参加研讨会；另一半时间，他们则在嬉笑玩闹，打着扑克。穿着廉价的西装，一副悠闲自在的样子，他们似乎总能挑选出最佳交易机会，而其他人却都在疯狂地工作。

Traders had an anxious life; they’d spend the day shouting into a phone, hollering across the room, and nervously eyeballing a computer screen. The Arbitrage Group, right in the middle of this controlled pandemonium, seemed to be a mysterious, privileged subculture. Half the time, the boys were discussing trades in obscure, esoteric language, as if in a seminar; the other half, they were laughing and playing liar’s poker. In their cheap suits and with their leisurely mien, they could seemingly cherry-pick the best trades while everyone else worked at a frenetic pace.

这个团队极其注重隐私；他们似乎把JM与生俱来的神秘感当作了一种保护伞。虽然任何交易员都应该谨慎行事，但教授们拒绝与所罗门兄弟公司的同事分享任何信息，这加剧了科茨等人的不满。尽管套利公司吸收了顶级债券交易大厅里所有有价值的信息，但它仍然建立了自己的私人研究部门，并严禁所罗门兄弟公司的其他人员了解其交易情况。有一次，竞争对手保诚-巴切挖走了所罗门兄弟公司的一名抵押贷款交易员，这被视为一次重大胜利。“他第一个想要的是什么？”当时保诚-巴切公司的一位经理笑着回忆道，“分析工具？更好的电脑系统或软件？都不是。他想要的是文件柜上锁。这正体现了他们的心态！”在对梅里韦瑟的狂热忠诚驱使下，套利集团滋生了一种“我们与他们”的派系斗争，这使得长期投资公司未来的发展与华尔街其他公司之间存在着危险的脱节。希利布兰德对自己的隐私如此痴迷，甚至拒绝让所罗门兄弟公司给他拍照。11

The group was extremely private; it seemed to have adopted J.M.’s innate secretiveness as a protective coloring. Though any trader is well advised to be discreet, the professors’ refusal to share any information with their Salomon colleagues fueled the resentment felt by Coats and others. Though Arbitrage soaked up all of the valuable tidbits that passed through a premier bond-trading floor, it set up its own private research arm and strictly forbade others in Salomon to learn about its trades. One time, the rival Prudential-Bache hired away a Salomon mortgage trader, which was considered a coup. “What was the first thing he wanted?” a then-Pru-Bache manager laughingly remembered. “Analytics? Better computer system or software? No. He wanted locks on the filing cabinet. It reflected their mentality!” Driven by fanatical loyalty to Meriwether, the Arbitrage Group nurtured an us-against-them clannishness that would leave the future Long-Term dangerously remote from the rest of Wall Street. Hilibrand became so obsessed with his privacy that he even refused to let Salomon Brothers take his picture.11

随着所罗门兄弟其他部门步履维艰，套利部门的影响力却日益膨胀。希利布兰德力主公司裁撤投资银行部门，他认为该部门奖金过高，业绩却不尽如人意，这种说法不无道理。随后，他又宣称套利部门无需支付公司食堂的费用，因为他们根本不在那里用餐。秉持着右翼自由主义的原则，希利布兰德抱怨公司“垄断供应商”，仿佛每个交易员和每个职员都应该自己去讨价还价吃午饭似的。更深层次的真相是，希利布兰德和他在套利部门的同僚们对公司其他部门的同事（大多是资历较老的同事）缺乏尊重。“他们就像宇宙飞船里的太空舱，”希金斯这样评价希利布兰德的下属，“他们呼吸的空气和其他人不一样。”

As other areas of Salomon floundered, Arbitrage increasingly threw its weight around. Hilibrand pressed the firm to eliminate investment banking, which, he argued with some justification, took home too much in bonuses and was failing to carry its weight. Then he declared that Arbitrage shouldn’t have to pay for its share of the company cafeteria, because the group didn’t eat there. True to his right-wing, libertarian principles, Hilibrand complained about being saddled with “monopoly vendors,” as if every trader and every clerk should negotiate his own deal for lunch. The deeper truth was that Hilibrand and his mates in Arbitrage had little respect for their mostly older Salomon colleagues who worked in other areas of the firm. “It was like they were a capsule inside a spaceship,” Higgins said of J.M.’s underlings. “They didn’t breathe the air that everybody else did.”

希利布兰德和罗森菲尔德不断向JM施压，要求增加薪酬。他们认为所罗门公司慷慨地将利润分配给所有部门的薪酬制度是社会主义式的。既然套利部门赚了大部分钱，他们就觉得，只有他们才能独享这些利润。

Hilibrand and Rosenfeld continually pressed J.M. for more money. They viewed Salomon’s compensation arrangement, which liberally spread the wealth to all departments, as socialistic. Since Arbitrage was making most of the money, they felt, they and they alone should reap the rewards.

1987年，收购狂人罗纳德·佩雷尔曼对所罗门兄弟公司发起恶意收购。古特弗伦德的担忧不无道理：如果佩雷尔曼得逞，所罗门兄弟作为一家值得信赖的银行的声誉将一落千丈（事实上，所罗门兄弟的企业客户很可能成为佩雷尔曼的攻击目标）。为了击退佩雷尔曼，古特弗伦德将公司的控制权出售给了一位关系密切的投资者——亿万富翁沃伦·巴菲特。希利布兰德凡事都用数学来衡量，他对这笔他认为对所罗门兄弟不利的交易感到愤怒。这位年仅27岁的天才少年，虽然为人正直，却未能意识到所罗门兄弟的道德形象这种无形资产也价值连城。他甚至飞到奥马哈，试图说服当时已是所罗门兄弟公司董事会成员的巴菲特卖回他的投资，但巴菲特当然拒绝了。

In 1987, the raider Ronald Perelman made a hostile bid for Salomon. Gutfreund feared, with ample justification, that if Perelman won, Salomon’s reputation as a trusted banker would go down the tubes (indeed, Salomon’s corporate clients could likely find themselves on Perelman’s hit list). Gutfreund fended Perelman off by selling control of the firm to a distinctly friendly investor, the billionaire Warren Buffett. Hilibrand, who weighed everything in mathematical terms, was incensed over what he reckoned was a poor deal for Salomon. The twenty-seven-year-old wunderkind, though unswervingly honest himself, couldn’t see that an intangible such as Salomon’s ethical image was also worth a price. He actually flew out to Omaha to try to persuade Buffett, now a member of Salomon’s board, to sell back his investment, but Buffett, of course, refused.

JM试图安抚那些急躁的年轻交易员，并培养他们对整个公司的忠诚。当交易员们的抗议声越来越大时，JM邀请希利布兰德和罗森菲尔德与资深合伙人威廉·麦金托什共进晚餐，了解所罗门兄弟的历史。JM是一位秉持爱尔兰天主教传统的自由民主党人，他对公司的整体利益有着更强烈的意识，他的优雅也缓和了他残酷职业中的锋芒。对于下属们偶尔提出的套利业务应该从所罗门兄弟公司分离出来的呼声，他不以为意。他会告诉他们：“我对这里的人有忠诚。而且，你们太贪婪了。看看哈莱姆区的人们吧。”他敦促所罗门兄弟公司进行内部整顿，但同时也关心其他部门。当需要的时候，他会体贴地告诉首席财务官：“我们有一笔大交易；我们可能会损失惨重——我只是想让你知道。” 1987年的股灾中，套利业务一天之内就损失了1.2亿美元。所罗门兄弟公司的其他12名员工并不清楚该团队的具体操作或杠杆水平，但他们本能地信任梅里韦瑟。甚至连公司里的竞争对手也对他赞赏有加。然后，一切都崩塌了。

J.M. tried to temper his impatient young Turks and imbue them with loyalty to the greater firm. When the traders’ protests got louder, J.M. invited Hilibrand and Rosenfeld to a dinner with William McIntosh, an older partner, to hear about Salomon’s history. A liberal Democrat in the Irish Catholic tradition, J.M. had a stronger sense of the firm’s common welfare and a grace that softened the hard edge of his cutthroat profession. He shrugged off his lieutenants’ occasional cries that Arbitrage should separate from Salomon. He would tell them, “I’ve got loyalty to people here. And anyway, you’re being greedy. Look at the people in Harlem.” He pressed Salomon to clean house, but not without showing concern for other departments. Thoughtfully, when the need arose, he would tell the chief financial officer, “We have a big trade on; we could lose a lot—I just want you to know.” In the crash of 1987, Arbitrage did drop $120 million in one day.12 Others at Salomon weren’t sure quite what the group was doing or what its leverage was, but they instinctively trusted Meriwether. Even his rivals in the firm liked him. And then it all came crashing down.

在年轻交易员们不肯放弃的坚持下，梅里韦瑟于1989年说服古特弗伦德采用一种新的薪酬方案：套利交易员将获得集团利润的15%作为固定份额。这项协议是在希利布兰德威胁要离开后秘密达成的。13梅里韦瑟一如既往地将自己排除在外，告诉古特弗伦德，他可以随意支付给他任何他认为合理的金额。那一年，套利业务迎来了辉煌的一年，而获得最大份额的希利布兰德更是获得了惊人的2300万美元。尽管希利布兰德依然保持着低调的生活方式，每天乘坐火车上班，开着雷克萨斯，但他的高薪还是激起了公司内部长期积压的不满，尤其是因为所罗门兄弟的其他部门都没有采用这种薪酬方案。正如巴菲特的合伙人、所罗门兄弟董事查理·芒格所说：“所罗门兄弟里那些甲状腺功能亢进的人彻底疯了。”

Pressed by his young traders, who simply wouldn’t give up, in 1989 Meriwether persuaded Gutfreund to adopt a formula under which his arbitrageurs would get paid a fixed, 15 percent share of the group’s profits. The deal was cut in secret, after Hilibrand had threatened to bolt.13 Typically, J.M. left himself out of the arrangement, telling Gutfreund to pay him whatever he thought was fair. Then Arbitrage had a banner year, and Hilibrand, who got the biggest share, took home a phenomenal $23 million. Although Hilibrand modestly continued to ride the train to work and drive a Lexus, news of his pay brought to the surface long-simmering resentments, particularly as no other Salomon department was paid under such a formula. As Charlie Munger, Buffett’s partner and a Salomon director, put it, “The more hyperthyroid at Salomon went stark, raving mad.”

尤其令一位名叫保罗·莫泽的34岁交易员怒不可遏。莫泽曾是套利部门的一员，但几年前他被迫离开这个利润丰厚的领域，转而负责政府债券交易。莫泽身材精瘦，双眼间距较近，举止严肃认真。1991年，在希利布兰德薪酬风波爆发一年后，莫泽找到梅里韦瑟，坦白了一件惊人的事：他曾向美国财政部提交虚假投标，试图非法获得政府债券拍卖的份额。

In particular, a thirty-four-year-old trader named Paul Mozer was enraged. Mozer had been part of Arbitrage, but a couple of years earlier he had been forced to leave that lucrative area to run the government desk. Mozer had a wiry frame, close-set eyes, and an intense manner. In 1991, a year after the storm over Hilibrand’s pay, Mozer went to Meriwether and made a startling confession: he had submitted a false bid to the U.S. Treasury to gain an unauthorized share of a government-bond auction.

梅里韦瑟震惊地问道：“还有其他事吗？”莫泽说没有了。

Stunned, Meriwether asked, “Is there anything else?” Mozer said there wasn’t.

梅里韦瑟将此事禀告了古特弗伦德。两人以及另外两位高管都认为此事性质严重，但不知为何却什么也没做。尽管对莫泽心怀不满，梅里韦瑟依然对他忠心耿耿。很难想象，一向抱团、忠诚的JM会做出其他选择。他为莫泽辩护，称他工作勤奋，只是犯过一次错，并让他负责政府业务。这的确是个错误——并非道德上的错误，而是JM固守忠诚准则导致的判断失误。事实上，莫泽是个反复无常的交易员，他与其说是出于对利润的合理追求，不如说是出于一时冲动，屡次鲁莽地违反规则，损害了梅里韦瑟、他的上司以及整个公司的声誉。必须承认，莫泽的“罪行”实在愚蠢，以至于他的上司们都轻易地睁一只眼闭一只眼。很自然地，当时已是所罗门债券业务主管的梅里韦瑟并没有想到要调查他手下是否有交易员向美国财政部撒谎。但事后梅里韦瑟的宽容令人费解。几个月后，到了八月份，所罗门发现莫泽向梅里韦瑟的供述本身就是谎言，因为他还犯下了其他诸多违规行为。尽管所罗门最终还是上报了此事，但​​财政部和美联储仍然勃然大怒。这场丑闻引发的轩然大波似乎与引发它的那点轻微不当行为不成比例。14无论如何，欺骗美国财政部是行不通的——也不可能行得通。华尔街巨头古特弗伦德被迫辞职。

Meriwether took the matter to Gutfreund. The pair, along with two other top executives, agreed that the matter was serious, but they somehow did nothing about it. Although upset with Mozer, Meriwether stayed loyal to him. It is hard to imagine the clannish, faithful J.M. doing otherwise. He defended Mozer as a hard worker who had slipped but once and left him in charge of the government desk. This was a mistake—not an ethical mistake but an error in judgment brought on by J.M.’s singular code of allegiance. In fact, Mozer was a volatile trader who—motivated more by pique than by a realistic hope for profit—had repeatedly and recklessly broken the rules, jeopardizing the reputation of Meriwether, his supervisor, and the entire firm. It must be said that Mozer’s crime had been so foolish as to be easily slipped by his superiors. Quite naturally, Meriwether, now head of Salomon’s bond business, hadn’t thought to inquire if one of his traders had been lying to the U.S. Treasury. But J.M.’s lenience after the fact is hard to fathom. A few months later, in August, Salomon discovered that Mozer’s confession to Meriwether had itself been a lie, for he had committed numerous other infractions, too. Though now Salomon did report the matter, the Treasury and Fed were furious. The scandal set off an uproar seemingly out of proportion to the modest wrongdoing that had inspired it.14 No matter; one simply did not—could not—deceive the U.S. Treasury. Gutfreund, a lion of Wall Street, was forced to quit.

巴菲特从奥马哈飞来，成为新的（尽管只是临时）首席执行官。他立即问焦头烂额的所罗门高管们：“我们有什么办法能救下JM吗？”梅里韦瑟当然是公司最赚钱的经理，而且以无可挑剔的职业道德著称。他的交易员们极力维护他，指出JM已经立即向上级汇报了此事。但丑闻中的所有相关人员都承受着越来越大的压力。麦金托什，这位最初将梅里韦瑟带入所罗门的合伙人，亲自前往JM位于42楼的办公室，告诉他为了公司好，他应该辞职。几乎在套利团队还没反应过来之前，他们的负责人就辞职了。这太出乎意料了，梅里韦瑟感觉一切都像在做梦；更糟糕的是，他还因为成为头版新闻而遭受了损失。“我是一个相当害羞、内向的人，”他后来在接受《商业周刊》采访时说道。15真相远比这残酷：JM被排挤——甚至被暗中指责——尽管他自认为没有做错任何事。这突如其来的关注让他更加隐秘，而长期资本后来对此感到后悔。与此同时，在套利集团内部，让JM重返公司成了一场运动。希利布兰德和罗森菲尔德保留了JM的办公室，他的高尔夫球杆、办公桌和电脑都一应俱全，仿佛他只是在休假。新任首席执行官德里克·莫恩敏锐地意识到，只要JM的“神龛”还在，JM就仍然活着，是他潜在的竞争对手。果然，一年后，当梅里韦瑟解决了莫泽事件引发的法律问题后，希利布兰德和罗森菲尔德——此时分别是套利集团和政府部门的负责人——游说JM回归担任联席首席执行官。*

Buffett flew in from Omaha and became the new, though interim, CEO. He immediately asked the frazzled Salomon executives, “Is there any way we can save J.M.?” Meriwether, of course, was the firm’s top moneymaker and known as impeccably ethical. His traders heatedly defended him, pointing out that J.M. had immediately reported the matter to his superior. But pressure mounted on all involved in the scandal. McIntosh, the partner who had first brought Meriwether into Salomon, trekked up to J.M.’s forty-second-floor office and told him that he should quit for the good of the firm. And almost before the Arbitrage Group could fathom it, their chief had resigned. It was so unexpected, Meriwether felt it was surreal; moreover, he suffered for being front-page news. “I’m a fairly shy, introspective person,” he later noted to Business Week.15 The full truth was more bitter: J.M. was being pushed aside—even implicitly blamed—despite, in his opinion, having done no wrong. This painful dollop of limelight made him even more secretive, to Long-Term Capital’s later regret. Meanwhile, within the Arbitrage Group, resurrecting J.M. became a crusade. Hilibrand and Rosenfeld kept J.M.’s office intact, with his golf club, desk, and computer, as if he were merely on an extended holiday. Deryck Maughan, the new CEO, astutely surmised that as long as this shrine to J.M. remained, J.M. was alive as his potential rival. Sure enough, a year later, when Meriwether resolved his legal issues stemming from the Mozer affair, Hilibrand and Rosenfeld, now the heads of Arbitrage and the government desk, respectively, lobbied for J.M.’s return as co-CEO.*

美国证券交易委员会提起民事诉讼，指控梅里韦瑟未能妥善监管莫泽。梅里韦瑟既不承认也不否认有罪，最终与对方达成和解，同意暂停从事证券行业三个月，并支付5万美元罚款。

* The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint charging that Meriwether had failed to properly supervise Mozer. Without admitting or denying guilt, Meriwether settled the case, agreeing to a three-month suspension from the securities industry and a $50,000 fine.

莫恩是个官僚，他太聪明了，不会接受这种做法，而是试图将所罗门银行改造成一家全球性的全方位服务银行，套利业务仅仅作为一个部门。希利布兰德坚决反对这一方案，在莫恩不在的情况下，他越来越强势。他要求所罗门银行解雇投资银行家，并围绕套利业务进行裁员。与此同时，他在抵押贷款领域进行了一次近乎灾难性的豪赌，亏损了4亿美元。大多数交易员在这种情况下都会选择收手，但希利布兰德却只是在热身；他冷静地提议所罗门银行将投资额翻倍！由于希利布兰德对自己的交易深信不疑，他能承受其他交易员无法承受的损失。他说，市场就像一个变形的弹簧——最终会恢复原状。据说他一生中只遭受过一次永久性损失，这证明他并非赌徒。但他对自己正确性的极度自信，需要一些约束，以免发展成鲁莽的倾向。

Maughan, a bureaucrat, was too smart to go for this and tried to refashion Salomon into a global, full-service bank, with Arbitrage as a mere department. Hilibrand, who was dead opposed to this course, increasingly asserted himself in J.M.’s absence. He wanted Salomon to fire its investment bankers and retrench around Arbitrage. Meanwhile, he made a near-catastrophic bet in mortgages and fell behind by $400 million. Most traders in that situation would have called it a day, but Hilibrand was just warming up; he coolly proposed that Salomon double its commitment! Because Hilibrand believed in his trade so devoutly, he could take pain as no other trader could. He said that the market was like a Slinky out of shape—eventually it would spring back.
