It was said that only once had he ever suffered a permanent loss, a testament to the fact that he was not a gambler. But his supreme conviction in his own rightness cried out for some restraining influence, lest it develop a reckless edge.

双倍投入风险太大，但管理层还是允许希利布兰德保留了他的交易。最终，这笔交易盈利了，但这让所罗门的管理层意识到，希利布兰德一边批评各个部门是累赘，一边套利部门却可以随意动用所罗门的资金。高管们始终无法就套利部门究竟占用了多少资金以及其交易风险有多大达成一致，而固执己见的希利布兰德就这些问题滔滔不绝地讲了几个小时。简而言之，如果“弹簧玩具”（指套利交易）最终没有反弹，套利部门可能会损失多少？巴菲特和芒格都对希利布兰德回答中那种数学式的语气感到不安。巴菲特同意让希利布兰德回归，但并没有像希利布兰德希望的那样，把整个公司都交给他管理。

Doubling up was too much, but management let Hilibrand keep the trade he had. Eventually, it was profitable, but it reminded Salomon’s managers that while Hilibrand was critiquing various departments as being so much extra baggage, Arbitrage felt free to call on Salomon’s capital whenever it was down. The executives could never agree on just how much capital Arbitrage was tying up or how much risk its trades entailed, matters on which the dogmatic Hilibrand lectured them for hours. In short, how much—if, sometime, the Slinky did not bounce back—could Arbitrage potentially lose? Neither Buffett nor Munger ever felt quite comfortable with the mathematical tenor of Hilibrand’s replies.16 Buffett agreed to take J.M. back—but not, as Hilibrand wanted, to trust him with the entire firm.

当然，梅里韦瑟绝不会满足于这种有条件的回归。莫泽丑闻彻底断送了梅里韦瑟接替他执掌所罗门集团的希望，但也埋下了更大阴谋的种子。如今四十五岁的梅里韦瑟，一头波浪状的少年发垂至深邃的眼眸，他终止了与所罗门集团的谈判。他开始筹划成立一个新的独立套利基金，或许是一个对冲基金，并着手洗劫他一手组建的套利集团。

Of course, there was no way Meriwether would settle for such a qualified homecoming. The Mozer scandal had ended any hope that J.M. would take his place at the top of Salomon, but it had sown the seeds of a greater drama. Now forty-five, with hair that dipped in a wavy, boyish arc toward impenetrable eyes, J.M. broke off talks with Salomon. He laid plans for a new and independent arbitrage fund, perhaps a hedge fund, and he proceeded to raid the Arbitrage Group that he had, so lovingly, assembled.

2

2

对冲基金

HEDGE FUND

先生，我喜欢树篱。

I love a hedge, sir.

——亨利·菲尔丁，1736年

—HENRY FIELDING, 1736

你可以尽情预言，但一定要有所保留。

Prophesy as much as you like, but always hedge.

—O利弗· W·恩德尔·H·奥尔姆斯，1861年





—OLIVER WENDELL HOLMES, 1861





到了20世纪90年代初，当梅里韦瑟开始重振事业时，投资业已步入黄金时代。拥有投资的美国人比以往任何时候都多，股价也飙升至惊人的高度。市场指数一次又一次地突破了曾经难以想象的障碍。新的纪录一次又一次地被刷新，旧的标准也被一次又一次地超越。投资者们欣喜若狂，但远非自满。这是一个黄金时代，但也是一个令人焦虑的时代。美国人闲暇时会焦急地盯着闪烁的屏幕，关注着市场的最新动态。股票屏幕随处可见——健身房、机场、单身酒吧。专家们反复预言股市即将回调或崩盘；尽管他们的预言总是落空，但却难以忽视。投资者们既贪婪又谨慎。那些一夜暴富的人们渴望找到一个可以再次投资的地方，但同时也希望这个地方在股市最终崩盘时不会遭受太大的损失。

BY THE EARLY 1990s, as Meriwether began to resuscitate his career, investing had entered a golden age. More Americans owned investments than ever before, and stock prices were rising to astonishing heights. Time and again, the market indexes soared past once unthinkable barriers. Time and again, new records were set and old standards eclipsed. Investors were giddy, but they were far from complacent. It was a golden age, but also a nervous one. Americans filled their empty moments by gazing anxiously at luminescent monitors that registered the market’s latest move. Stock screens were everywhere—in gyms, at airports, in singles bars. Pundits repeatedly prophesied a correction or a crash; though always wrong, they were hard to ignore. Investors were greedy but wary, too. People who had gotten rich beyond their wildest dreams wanted a place to reinvest, but one that would not unduly suffer if—or when—the stock market finally crashed.

当时富人比比皆是。很大程度上得益于股市繁荣，全球至少有600万人跻身百万美元富翁行列，总资产高达17万亿美元¹。至少对这600万幸运儿而言，投资对冲基金有着特殊的吸引力。

And there were plenty of rich people about. Thanks in large part to the stock market boom, no fewer than 6 million people around the world counted themselves as dollar millionaires, with a total of $17 trillion in assets.¹ For these lucky 6 million, at least, investing in hedge funds had a special allure.

就证券法而言，并不存在所谓的“对冲基金”。实际上，这个术语指的是有限合伙企业，至少有一些这类企业自20世纪20年代以来就一直在运营。被誉为价值投资之父的本杰明·格雷厄姆运营着可能是最早的对冲基金。与更常见的共同基金不同，这些合伙企业在华尔街的阴影下运作；它们是富人的私人且基本不受监管的投资池。它们无需在美国证券交易委员会（SEC）注册，尽管有些必须向另一个华盛顿机构——商品期货交易委员会（CFTC）提交有限的文件。大多数情况下，它们对其投资组合的内容保密。它们可以随意借贷（或者说，只要它们的银行愿意借给它们——这通常意味着借贷金额相同）。而且，与共同基金不同，它们可以集中投资于单一资产而无需考虑多元化。事实上，对冲基金可以自由地尝试任何或所有较为特殊的投资方式，例如期权、衍生品、卖空、极高杠杆等等。

As far as securities law is concerned, there is no such thing as a hedge fund. In practice, the term refers to a limited partnership, at least a small number of which have operated since the 1920s. Benjamin Graham, known as the father of value investing, ran what was perhaps the first. Unlike mutual funds, their more common cousins, these partnerships operate in Wall Street’s shadows; they are private and largely unregulated investment pools for the rich. They need not register with the Securities and Exchange Commission, though some must make limited filings to another Washington agency, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. For the most part, they keep the contents of their portfolios hidden. They can borrow as much as they choose (or as much as their bankers will lend them—which often amounts to the same thing). And, unlike mutual funds, they can concentrate their portfolios with no thought to diversification. In fact, hedge funds are free to sample any or all of the more exotic species of investment flora, such as options, derivatives, short sales, extremely high leverage, and so forth.

作为这种自由的交换，对冲基金必须限制投资者数量；事实上，它们的运作方式就像私人俱乐部。根据法律规定，基金最多只能招收99位个人或机构投资者，每位投资者的资产至少为100万美元；或者最多招收500位投资者，前提是每位投资者的投资组合至少为500万美元。其隐含的逻辑是，如果一个基金只对少数百万富翁和机构开放，那么像美国证券交易委员会（SEC）这样的监管机构就无需费心监管。想必百万富翁们都清楚自己在做什么；如果他们不清楚，那么他们的损失也只是他们自己的事。

In return for such freedom, hedge funds must limit access to a select few investors; indeed, they operate like private clubs. By law, funds can sign up no more than ninety-nine investors, people, or institutions each worth at least $1 million, or up to five hundred investors, assuming that each has a portfolio of at least $5 million. The implicit logic is that if a fund is open to only a small group of millionaires and institutions, agencies such as the SEC need not trouble to monitor it. Presumably, millionaires know what they are doing; if not, their losses are nobody’s business but their own.

直到最近，对冲基金经理还鲜为人知。但在上世纪八九十年代，一些大型基金经理声名鹊起，其中最引人注目的是移居海外的货币投机者乔治·索罗斯。1992年，索罗斯的量子基金因“击垮”英格兰银行并迫使其贬值英镑（他此前一直持续做空英镑）而名声大噪，这一壮举为他带来了10亿美元的利润。几年后，索罗斯被指责——或许并不公正——导致东南亚货币大幅贬值。正是由于索罗斯以及其他一些知名基金经理，例如朱利安·罗伯逊和迈克尔·斯坦哈特，对冲基金经理才被塑造成敢于冒险、能够搅动市场的“海盗”。斯坦哈特吹嘘说，他和他的同伴是仅存的几个边疆资本主义堡垒之一。² 人们普遍认为他们是敢于冒险、恣意妄为的人，​​要么获得巨额利润，要么遭受惨重损失；1998 年韦氏大学词典将对冲基金定义为使用“高风险投机方法”的基金。

Until recently, hedge fund managers were complete unknowns. But in the 1980s and ’90s, a few large operators gained notoriety, most notably the émigré currency speculator George Soros. In 1992, Soros’s Quantum Fund became celebrated for “breaking” the Bank of England and forcing it to devalue the pound (which he had relentlessly sold short), a coup that netted him a $1 billion profit. A few years later, Soros was blamed—perhaps unjustifiably—for forcing sharp devaluations in Southeast Asian currencies. Thanks to Soros and a few other high-profile managers, such as Julian Robertson and Michael Steinhardt, hedge fund operators acquired an image of daring buccaneers capable of roiling markets. Steinhardt bragged that he and his fellows were one of the few remaining bastions of frontier capitalism.² The popular image was of swashbuckling risk takers who captured outsized profits or suffered horrendous losses; the 1998 Webster’s College Dictionary defined hedge funds as those that use “high-risk speculative methods.”

尽管对冲基金给人以豪迈的印象，但实际上大多数对冲基金都相当稳健；事实上，这正是它们真正的吸引力所在。“对冲基金”一词源于“对冲风险”的俗语，意指通过押注另一方来限制投机损失的可能性。这种用法源于花园中常见的篱笆作为边界或限制的概念，莎士比亚也曾使用过这个词（例如“英格兰与主干道相接”³）。直到1949年，梅里韦瑟的真正先驱阿尔弗雷德·温斯洛·琼斯组建了一家合伙企业，才有人想到将这个词应用于投资基金。⁴虽然此类合伙企业早已存在，但这位出生于澳大利亚的《财富》杂志撰稿人琼斯是第一个运营平衡型或对冲型投资组合的人。由于担心股票会在市场整体低迷时下跌，琼斯决定通过对冲——即同时做多和做空——来抵消市场因素的影响。和大多数投资者一样，他买入他认为价格低廉的股票，但同时也卖空那些看似价格过高的股票。至少在理论上，琼斯的投资组合是“市场中性”的。任何导致市场上涨或下跌的事件——战争、弹劾、天气变化——都只会使琼斯投资组合的一半升值，另一半贬值。他的净收益完全取决于他能否准确判断哪些股票表现最佳，哪些股票表现最差。

Despite their bravura image, however, most hedge funds are rather tame; indeed, that is their true appeal. The term “hedge fund” is a colloquialism derived from the expression “to hedge one’s bets,” meaning to limit the possibility of loss on a speculation by betting on the other side. This usage evolved from the notion of the common garden hedge as a boundary or limit and was used by Shakespeare (“England hedg’d in with the maine”³). No one had thought to apply the term to an investment fund until Alfred Winslow Jones, the true predecessor of Meriwether, organized a partnership in 1949.4 Though such partnerships had long been in existence, Jones, an Australian-born Fortune writer, was the first to run a balanced, or hedged, portfolio. Fearing that his stocks would fall during general market slumps, Jones decided to neutralize the market factor by hedging—that is, by going both long and short. Like most investors, he bought stocks he deemed to be cheap, but he also sold short seemingly overpriced stocks. At least in theory, Jones’s portfolio was “market neutral.” Any event—war, impeachment, a change in the weather—that moved the market either up or down would simply elevate one half of Jones’s portfolio and depress the other half. His net return would depend only on his ability to single out the relative best and worst.

这是一种保守的投资策略，收益可能较低，但损失也可能较小，这迎合了上世纪90年代那些焦虑不安的投资者。与索罗斯的冒险精神不同，大多数现代对冲基金与其说是标榜盈利，不如说是标榜自身的稳健性。他们期望长期获得丰厚的回报，但并不打算紧跟大盘的波动。理想情况下，他们的收益应该与普通股票基金持平甚至更高，同时在大盘下跌​​时也能保持稳健。

This is a conservative approach, likely to make less but also to lose less, which appealed to the nervous investor of the 1990s. Eschewing the daring of Soros, most modern hedge funds boasted of their steadiness as much as of their profits. Over time, they expected to make handsome returns but not to track the broader market blip for blip. Ideally, they would make as much as or more than generalized stock funds yet hold their own when the averages suffered.

在那个美国人痴迷于比较投资回报率如同曾经痴迷于飙升的房价的年代，这些对冲基金——尽管当时人们对它们知之甚少——却获得了一种神秘的魅力，因为它们似乎找到了一条通往财富的捷径，同时又规避了通常的风险。人们在烧烤聚会上谈论的无非是他们的共同基金，但共同基金在当时是如此——普通！对于那些富裕人士，对于那些在汉普顿避暑、用沃霍尔的画作装饰房屋的人来说，对于那些艺术赞助人和慈善晚宴的参与者来说，投资对冲基金象征着某种身份，象征着跻身华尔街最聪明、最精明之人的行列。当全世界都在谈论投资时，还有什么比在球场边低调地提及一位年轻老练的对冲基金经理的名字更令人兴奋的呢？这位经理正以谨慎、精明和精准的方式管理着你的资金。对冲基金成为了最富有、最优秀的人的象征。矛盾的是，对冲基金经理收取的高额费用反而增加了他们的吸引力，因为除了天赋异禀的人之外，谁又能承担得起如此惊人的费用呢？对冲基金经理不仅从投资者的利润中攫取了巨额份额，还贪婪地攫取了资产的一定比例。

At a time when Americans compared investment returns as obsessively as they once had soaring home prices, these hedge funds—though dimly understood—attained a mysterious cachet, for they had seemingly found a route to riches while circumventing the usual risks. People at barbecues talked of nothing but their mutual funds, but a mutual fund was so—common! For people of means, for people who summered in the Hamptons and decorated their homes with Warhols, for patrons of the arts and charity dinners, investing in a hedge fund denoted a certain status, an inclusion among Wall Street’s smartest and savviest. When the world was talking investments, what could be more thrilling than to demurely drop, at courtside, the name of a young, sophisticated hedge fund manager who, discreetly, shrewdly, and auspiciously, was handling one’s resources? Hedge funds became a symbol of the richest and the best. Paradoxically, the princely fees that hedge fund managers charged enhanced their allure, for who could get away with such gaudy fees except the exceptionally talented? Not only did hedge fund managers pocket a fat share of their investors’ profits, they greedily claimed a percent-age of the assets.

正因如此，美国的对冲基金数量呈爆炸式增长。1968年，美国证券交易委员会（SEC）进行调查时，仅发现了215家对冲基金。 5 到20世纪90年代，对冲基金的数量可能达到了3000家左右（确切数字无人知晓），涵盖了多种投资风格和资产类型。大多数对冲基金规模较小；总而言之，它们的资本规模可能只有3000亿美元，而股票型共同基金的资本规模则高达3.2万亿美元。 6 然而，投资者渴望获得更多。他们寻求的是一种既大胆又稳健的投资方式，而非平庸之作：并非风险最高的投资风格，而是最稳妥的选择；并非声势最浩大，而是最精明的选择。这正是梅里韦瑟（Meriwether）所设想的那种对冲基金。

For such reasons, the number of hedge funds in the United States exploded. In 1968, when the SEC went looking, it could find only 215 of them.5 By the 1990s there were perhaps 3,000 (no one knows the exact number), spread among many investing styles and asset types. Most were small; all told, they held perhaps $300 billion in capital, compared with $3.2 trillion in equity mutual funds.6 However, investors were hungry for more. They were seeking an alternative to plain vanilla that was both bold and safe: not the riskiest investing style but the most certain; not the loudest, merely the smartest. This was exactly the sort of hedge fund Meriwether had in mind.

效仿阿尔弗雷德·琼斯，梅里韦瑟设想长期资本管理公司将专注于债券市场的“相对价值”交易。因此，长期资本管理公司会买入一些债券，卖出另一些债券。它会押注于债券价差的扩大或缩小。如果意大利的利率远高于德国，意味着意大利债券比德国债券便宜，那么投资意大利债券并做空德国债券的交易员，如果价差缩小，就能获利。这是一种风险相对较低的策略。由于债券价格通常同步涨跌，价差的波动幅度远小于债券本身。与琼斯的基金一样，理论上，无论市场上涨、下跌，甚至崩盘，长期资本管理公司都不会受到影响。

Emulating Alfred Jones, Meriwether envisioned that Long-Term Capital Management would concentrate on “relative value” trades in bond markets. Thus, Long-Term would buy some bonds and sell some others. It would bet on spreads between pairs of bonds to either widen or contract. If interest rates in Italy were significantly higher than in Germany, meaning that Italy’s bonds were cheaper than Germany’s, a trader who invested in Italy and shorted Germany would profit if, and as, this differential narrowed. This is a relatively low-risk strategy. Since bonds usually rise and fall in sync, spreads don’t move as much as the bonds themselves. As with Jones’s fund, Long-Term would in theory be unaffected if markets rose or fell, or even if they crashed.

但有一个显著的区别：梅里韦瑟从一开始就计划让长期投资公司利用杠杆进行20到30倍甚至更高的投资。这是长期投资公司战略的必要组成部分，因为该公司计划买入和卖出债券之间的价差通常微乎其微。为了从如此小的价差中获得可观的利润，长期投资公司必须通过借贷将投资规模成倍放大。任何去过游乐场的人都能体会到这种策略的吸引力。就像跷跷板能让孩子举起比自身重量重得多的重量一样，金融杠杆也能倍增你的“力量”——也就是你的赚钱能力——因为它让你既能从借来的资金中获得收益，也能从自己的资金中获得收益。当然，你的损失风险也会成倍增加。如果长期投资公司的策略因为某种原因失败，其损失将会更大，而且累积速度更快；事实上，这些损失甚至可能危及生命——尽管这种情况发生的可能性似乎微乎其微。

But there was one significant difference: Meriwether planned from the very start that Long-Term would leverage its capital twenty to thirty times or even more. This was a necessary part of Long-Term’s strategy, because the gaps between the bonds it intended to buy and those it intended to sell were, most often, minuscule. To make a decent profit on such tiny spreads, Long-Term would have to multiply its bet many, many times by borrowing. The allure of this strategy is apparent to anyone who has visited a playground. Just as a seesaw enables a child to raise a much greater weight than he could on his own, financial leverage multiplies your “strength”—that is, your earning power—because it enables you to earn a return on the capital you have borrowed as well as on your own money. Of course, your power to lose is also multiplied. If for some reason Long-Term’s strategy ever failed, its losses would be vastly greater and accrue more quickly; indeed, they might be life-threatening—an eventuality that surely seemed remote.

1993年初，梅里韦瑟拜访了美林证券董事长丹尼尔·塔利。由于莫泽事件给他的名誉蒙上了不公的污点，梅里韦瑟仍然忧心忡忡，他立刻问道：“我是否已经名誉受损？”塔利回答说没有。塔利将梅里韦瑟介绍给了美林证券负责为对冲基金募集资金的人员，不久之后，美林证券同意承担为长期基金募集资金的任务。

Early in 1993, Meriwether paid a call on Daniel Tully, chairman of Merrill Lynch. Still anxious about the unfair tarnish on his name from the Mozer affair, J.M. immediately asked, “Am I damaged goods?” Tully said he wasn’t. Tully put Meriwether in touch with the Merrill Lynch people who raised capital for hedge funds, and shortly thereafter, Merrill agreed to take on the assignment of raising capital for Long-Term.

JM的计划雄心勃勃，令人叹为观止。他一心想要复制套利集团的模式，拥有其全球影响力以及进行大规模交易的能力，但却无法获得所罗门兄弟数十亿美元的资本、信贷额度、信息网络和七千名员工的支持。他曾为所罗门兄弟做出过巨大​​贡献，如今却被迫在舆论的阴影下流亡，这让他耿耿于怀，他渴望证明自己的清白，或许可以通过创造更美好的未来来实现。

J.M.’s design was staggeringly ambitious. He wanted nothing less than to replicate the Arbitrage Group, with its global reach and ability to take huge positions, but without the backing of Salomon’s billions in capital, credit lines, information network, and seven thousand employees. Having done so much for Salomon, he was bitter about having been forced into exile under a cloud and eager to be vindicated, perhaps by creating something better.

梅里韦瑟想要募集巨额资金，高达25亿美元。（一般基金的初始规模可能只有这个数字的1%左右。）事实上，长期基金的一切都雄心勃勃。它的费用将远高于平均水平。除了每年2%的资产管理费外，梅里韦瑟和他的合伙人还将获得25%的利润分成。（大多数基金只收取20%的利润分成和1%的资产管理费。）梅里韦瑟认为，如此高昂的费用是维持全球运营所必需的——但这仅仅表明了他的雄心壮志远大无比。

And Meriwether wanted to raise a colossal sum, $2.5 billion. (The typical fund starts with perhaps 1 percent as much.) Indeed, everything about Long-Term was ambitious. Its fees would be considerably higher than average. J.M. and his partners would rake in 25 percent of the profits, in addition to a yearly 2 percent charge on assets. (Most funds took only 20 percent of profits and 1 percent on assets.) Such fees, J.M. felt, were needed to sustain a global operation—but this only pointed to the far-reaching nature of his aspirations.

此外，该基金坚持要求投资者至少锁定三年，这在对冲基金领域几乎闻所未闻。锁定期合情合理；如果市场波动不利，长期基金将拥有真正“长期”资本的缓冲；它将成为一家可以对储户说“明天再来”的银行。然而，这要求投资者表现出极大的信任——尤其是在JM没有正式业绩记录可供展示的情况下。虽然坊间传闻套利业务贡献了所罗门兄弟近期的大部分收益，但该集团的利润并未公开披露。即使是那些对套利业务盈利情况略知一二的投资者，也完全不了解其盈利方式。具体细节——模型、价差、奇异衍生品——都晦涩难懂。此外，在梅里韦瑟因莫泽事件受到美国证券交易委员会制裁后不久，人们对投资他的业务也深感不安。

Moreover, the fund insisted that investors commit for at least three years, an almost unheard-of lockup in the hedge fund world. The lockup made sense; if fickle markets turned against it, Long-Term would have a cushion of truly “long-term” capital; it would be the bank that could tell depositors, “Come back tomorrow.” Still, it was asking investors to show enormous trust—particularly since J.M. did not have a formal track record to show them. While it was known anecdotally that Arbitrage had accounted for most of Salomon’s recent earnings, the group’s profits hadn’t been disclosed. Even investors who had an inkling of what Arbitrage had earned had no understanding of how it had earned it. The nuts and bolts—the models, the spreads, the exotic derivatives—were too obscure. Moreover, people had serious qualms about investing with Meriwether so soon after he had been sanctioned by the SEC in the Mozer affair.

随着美林开始制定融资策略，JM 的老团队开始陆续离开所罗门兄弟公司。埃里克·罗森菲尔德于 1993 年初离职。接下来是伊朗裔塞法迪犹太人维克多·哈加尼；当他宣布这一消息时，所罗门兄弟公司的交易大厅里响起了热烈的掌声。7 月，格雷格·霍金斯也辞职了。尽管希利布兰德仍然在所罗门兄弟公司的苦苦挽留下犹豫不决，JM 仍然缺少他，但梅里韦瑟此时正与他手下的核心交易员们密谋着新的计划。他对昔日的同事们依然怀有深厚的感情，他动情地向所罗门兄弟公司落魄的首席执行官古特弗伦德提出担任非执行董事长一职——条件是古特弗伦德必须放弃与所罗门兄弟公司就拖欠工资问题进行的激烈斗争。尽管常被忽视，古特弗伦德在套利集团的成功中扮演了关键角色：他有效地抑制了交易员们偶尔的过度扩张倾向。但事与愿违。在长期投资公司，JM 不得不约束自己的门徒。

As Merrill began to chart a strategy for raising money, J.M.’s old team began to peel off from Salomon. Eric Rosenfeld left early in 1993. Victor Haghani, the Iranian Sephardi, was next; he got an ovation on Salomon’s trading floor when he broke the news. In July, Greg Hawkins quit. Although J.M. still lacked Hilibrand, who was ambivalent in the face of Salomon’s desperate pleas that he stay, Meriwether was now hatching plans with a nucleus of his top traders. He still felt a strong loyalty to his former colleagues, and he touchingly offered the job of nonexecutive chairman to Gutfreund, Salomon’s fallen chief—on the condition that Gutfreund give up an acrimonious fight that he was waging with Salomon for back pay. Though overlooked, Gutfreund had played a pivotal role in the Arbitrage Group’s success: he had been the brake on the traders’ occasional tendencies to overreach. But it was not to be. At Long-Term, J.M. would have to restrain his own disciples.

总之，JM想要的声望远超古特弗伦德，甚至也超过他那些才华横溢却默默无闻的年轻套利交易员所能提供的。他需要优势——一些能够向投资者证明其大胆计划合理性的东西。他必须重塑团队，让他们不仅仅是一群债券交易员，而是一项更宏大的金融实验。这一次，招募一位名不见经传的助理教授是行不通的——如果他想筹集25亿美元的话。这一次，梅里韦瑟将目光投向了学术界的顶峰。哈佛大学的罗伯特·C·默顿是金融领域的领军人物，被业内许多人视为天才。他培养了几代华尔街交易员，其中包括埃里克·罗森菲尔德。上世纪80年代，罗森菲尔德曾说服默顿担任所罗门兄弟公司的顾问，因此默顿与套利团队早已熟识。更重要的是，默顿的名字本身就足以打开大门，不仅在美国，而且在欧洲和亚洲也是如此。

In any case, J.M. wanted more cachet than Gutfreund or even his talented but unheralded young arbitrageurs could deliver. He needed an edge—something to justify his bold plans with investors. He had to recast his group, to showcase them as not just a bunch of bond traders but as a grander experiment in finance. This time, it would not do to recruit an unknown assistant professor—not if he wanted to raise $2.5 billion. This time, Meriwether went to the very top of academia. Harvard’s Robert C. Merton was the leading scholar in finance, considered a genius by many in his field. He had trained several generations of Wall Street traders, including Eric Rosenfeld. In the 1980s, Rosenfeld had persuaded Merton to become a consultant to Salomon, so Merton was already friendly with the Arbitrage Group. More important, Merton’s was a name that would instantly open doors, not only in America but also in Europe and Asia.

默顿的父亲罗伯特·K·默顿是哥伦比亚大学一位杰出的社会科学家，曾研究过科学家的行为。默顿出生后不久，老默顿提出了“自我实现的预言”的概念。他认为，储户因担心银行违约而挤兑银行就是这种现象的典型例子——对他的儿子来说，这简直就是预言。 7小默顿在纽约市郊的哈斯汀斯长大，他展现出一种天赋，能够系统地处理任何事情。他酷爱棒球和汽车，先是认真地记住了球员的击球率，然后又记住了几乎所有美国汽车的发动机规格。 8后来，当他玩扑克时，他会盯着灯泡看，让瞳孔缩小，以此来干扰对手。仿佛是为了效仿他父亲研究的那些科学家，他早已成为后来一位作家所描述的那种“处处寻求秩序”的人。 9

Merton was the son of a prominent Columbia University social scientist, Robert K. Merton, who had studied the behavior of scientists. Shortly after his son was born, Merton père coined the idea of the “self-fulfilling prophecy,” a phenomenon, he suggested, that was illustrated by depositors who made a run on a bank out of fear of a default—for his son, a prophetic illustration.7 The younger Merton, who grew up in Hastings-on-Hudson, outside New York City, showed a knack for devising systematic approaches to whatever he tackled. A devotee of baseball and cars, he studiously memorized first the batting averages of players and then the engine specs of virtually every American automobile.8 Later, when he played poker, he would stare at a lightbulb to contract his pupils and throw off opponents. As if to emulate the scientists his father studied, he was already the person of whom a later writer would say that he “looked for order all around him.”9

在加州理工学院读本科期间，他对投资产生了浓厚的兴趣。默顿经常在早上6点半纽约股市开盘时就去当地的经纪公司，花几个小时进行交易并观察市场。后来，他转学到麻省理工学院攻读经济学，可谓顺理成章。20世纪60年代末，经济学家们才刚刚开始将金融学转变为一门数学学科。在著名经济学家保罗·萨缪尔森的指导下，默顿开创了一个全新的领域。在此之前，经济学家们构建的模型只是描述市场在任何特定时间点的形态——或者说理论上应该如何。默顿实现了牛顿式的飞跃，他用一系列无限小的时间点来模拟价格走势。他称之为“连续时间金融”。多年后，法国兴业银行的衍生品专家斯坦·乔纳斯评论道：“金融领域的其他一切，都不过是默顿在20世纪70年代所做贡献的注脚。”他用油印机打印的蓝色讲义成了一件纪念品。

While he was an undergrad at Cal Tech, another interest, investing, blossomed. Merton often went to a local brokerage at 6:30 A.M., when the New York markets opened, to spend a few hours trading and watching the market. Providentially, he transferred to MIT to study economics. In the late 1960s, economists were just beginning to transform finance into a mathematical discipline. Merton, working under the wing of the famed Paul Samuelson, did nothing less than invent a new field. Up until then, economists had constructed models to describe how markets look—or in theory should look—at any point in time. Merton made a Newtonian leap, modeling prices in a series of infinitesimally tiny moments. He called this “continuous time finance.” Years later, Stan Jonas, a derivatives specialist with the French-owned Société Générale, would observe, “Most everything else in finance has been a footnote on what Merton did in the 1970s.” His mimeographed blue lecture notes became a keepsake.

20世纪70年代初，默顿着手解决一个此前已被费舍尔·布莱克和迈伦·斯科尔斯两位经济学家部分解决的问题：推导出股票期权“正确”价格的公式。默顿深刻理解了期权与标的股票之间的密切关系，并以精妙的数学推导完成了这一难题。随后，他谦逊地等到同行发表后才发表，因此，这个公式最终被称为布莱克-斯科尔斯模型。鉴于当时期权市场并不活跃，恐怕很少有人会关注这个公式。但巧合的是，就在该公式发表前一个月，芝加哥期权交易所开始上市股票期权交易。不久之后，德州仪器公司在《华尔街日报》上刊登广告： “现在您可以使用我们的……计算器找到布莱克-斯科尔斯价值。” 10这才是衍生品革命的真正开端。此前，教授们从未对华尔街产生过如此巨大的影响。

In the early 1970s, Merton tackled a problem that had been partially solved by two other economists, Fischer Black and Myron S. Scholes: deriving a formula for the “correct” price of a stock option. Grasping the intimate relation between an option and the underlying stock, Merton completed the puzzle with an elegantly mathematical flourish. Then he graciously waited to publish until after his peers did; thus, the formula would ever be known as the Black-Scholes model. Few people would have cared, given that no active market for options existed. But coincidentally, a month before the formula appeared, the Chicago Board Options Exchange had begun to list stock options for trading. Soon, Texas Instruments was advertising in The Wall Street Journal, “Now you can find the Black-Scholes value using our . . . calculator.”10 This was the true beginning of the derivatives revolution. Never before had professors made such an impact on Wall Street.

20世纪80年代，梅里韦瑟和许多其他交易员开始习惯于交易这些新式金融工具，就像交易股票和债券一样。与实际证券不同，衍生品仅仅是合约，其价值（因此得名）来源于股票、债券或其他资产。例如，股票期权（即在特定价格和特定期限内购买股票的权利）的价值会随着标的股票价格的波动而变化。

In the 1980s, Meriwether and many other traders became accustomed to trading these newfangled instruments just as they did stocks and bonds. As opposed to actual securities, derivatives were simply contracts that derived (hence the name) their value from stocks, bonds, or other assets. For instance, the value of a stock option, the right to purchase a stock at a specific price and within a certain time period, varied with the price of the underlying shares.

默顿欣然接受了加入长期资本公司的机会，因为这似乎是一个在现实世界中检验其理论的良机。他最近一直在论证，衍生品模糊了投资公司、银行和其他金融机构之间的界限。在默顿参与创建的无缝衍生品世界里，任何人只需设计一份合适的合约，就能承担放贷或提供股权的风险。重要的是功能，而非形式。这一点在抵押贷款领域已经得到了验证：抵押贷款曾经完全由地方银行提供，而现在则主要由无数分散的投资者购买证券化抵押贷款池中的小份额来融资。

Merton jumped at the opportunity to join Long-Term Capital because it seemed a chance to showcase his theories in the real world. Derivatives, he had recently been arguing, had blurred the lines between investment firms, banks, and other financial institutions. In the seamless world of derivatives, a world that Merton had helped to invent, anyone could assume the risk of loaning money, or of providing equity, simply by structuring an appropriate contract. It was function that mattered, not form. This had already been proved in the world of mortgages, once supplied exclusively by local banks and now largely funded by countless disparate investors who bought tiny pieces of securitized mortgage pools.

事实上，默顿并不把长期资本视为他和其他合伙人嗤之以鼻的“对冲基金”，而是视为一家先进的金融中介机构，像银行一样为市场提供资金。街角的银行从储户那里借款，再贷给当地居民和企业。它将资产（即贷款）与负债相匹配，试图通过向借款人收取略高于储户的利率来赚取微薄的利差。同样，长期资本也会通过出售一组债券来“借款”，并通过购买另一组债券来“放款”——这些债券的需求量可能略低，因此收益率也略高。这样，该基金就能像银行一样赚取利差。虽然这种描述过于简化，但长期资本通过投资风险较高（即收益较高）的债券，实际上是在为市场“提供流​​动性”。而银行的职责不正是提供流动性吗？正是由于默顿的远见卓识，这家初创的对冲基金开始以更宏大的视角看待自身。

Indeed, Merton saw Long-Term Capital not as a “hedge fund,” a term that he and the other partners sneered at, but as a state-of-the-art financial intermediary that provided capital to markets just as banks did. The bank on the corner borrowed from depositors and lent to local residents and businesses. It matched its assets—that is, its loans—with liabilities, attempting to earn a tiny spread by charging borrowers a slightly higher interest rate than it paid to depositors. Similarly, Long-Term Capital would “borrow” by selling one group of bonds and lend by purchasing another—presumably bonds that were slightly less in demand and that therefore yielded slightly higher interest rates. Thus, the fund would earn a spread, just like a bank. Though this description is highly simplified, Long-Term, by investing in the riskier (meaning higher-yielding) bonds, would be in the business of “providing liquidity” to markets. And what did a bank do but provide liquidity? Thanks to Merton, the nascent hedge fund began to think of itself in grander terms.

可惜的是，默顿在推销这支基金方面几乎毫无用处。他过于严肃，而且当时正忙于哈佛的课程。但在1993年夏天，JM招募了第二位学术明星：迈伦·斯科尔斯。尽管在其他学者眼中，斯科尔斯的声望不如默顿，但由于布莱克-斯科尔斯模型，他在华尔街的知名度更高。斯科尔斯也曾在所罗门兄弟公司工作过，因此他与梅里韦瑟团队关系密切。有了这两位金融界最杰出的头脑——据说他们都曾是诺贝尔奖的候选人——长期基金就如同拥有了迈克尔·乔丹和穆罕默德·阿里这样的组合。“这简直是把神秘感发挥到了极致，”一位最终投资该基金的基金经理说道。

Unfortunately, Merton was of little use in selling the fund. He was too serious-minded, and he was busy with classes at Harvard. But in the summer of 1993, J.M. recruited a second academic star: Myron Scholes. Though regarded as less of a heavyweight by other academics, Scholes was better known on Wall Street, thanks to the Black-Scholes formula. Scholes had also worked at Salomon, so he, too, was close to the Meriwether group. And with two of the most brilliant minds in finance, each said to be on the shortlist of Nobel candidates, Long-Term had the equivalent of Michael Jordan and Muhammad Ali on the same team. “This was mystique taken to a very high extreme,” said a money manager who ultimately invested in the fund.

1993年秋季，美林证券及其多个合作伙伴团队奔赴各地与投资者洽谈。这场声势浩大的路演遍及纽约、波士顿、费城、塔拉哈西、亚特兰大、芝加哥、圣路易斯、辛辛那提、麦迪逊、堪萨斯城、达拉斯、丹佛、洛杉矶、阿姆斯特丹、伦敦、马德里、巴黎、布鲁塞尔、苏黎世、罗马、圣保罗、布宜诺斯艾利斯、东京、香港、阿布扎比和沙特阿拉伯等城市。长期投资计划规定每位投资者的最低投资额为1000万美元。

In the fall of 1993, Merrill Lynch and various groups of partners fanned out to talk to investors. The madcap road show included stops in New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Tallahassee, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Cincinnati, Madison, Kansas City, Dallas, Denver, Los Angeles, Amsterdam, London, Madrid, Paris, Brussels, Zurich, Rome, São Paulo, Buenos Aires, Tokyo, Hong Kong, Abu Dhabi, and Saudi Arabia. Long-Term set a minimum of $10 million per investor.

路演开局不利。JM举止沉稳，却又沉默寡言，仿佛生怕说错话会泄露团队的秘密。“大家都想见JM，但他一句话也不说，”美林证券的戴尔·迈耶抱怨道。低调的罗森菲尔德过于低调，一位投资者甚至觉得他像个昏迷不醒的人。默顿的学生格雷格·霍金斯表现最差——满嘴都是希腊字母和代数符号。合伙人们根本不会讲故事，听起来就像数学教授。就连基金的名字也缺乏吸引力，只有认真的默顿自己觉得不错。投资者们有各种各样的理由望而却步。许多人对JM不愿讨论投资策略感到反感。一些人则对潜在的高杠杆感到恐惧，而JM对此却讳莫如深。像洛克菲勒基金会和洛伊斯公司这样的机构也对支付如此高昂的费用犹豫不决。长期投资的整个前提似乎未经检验，尤其是对于那些为机构提供咨询并决定大量资金投资方向的顾问而言。

The road show started badly. J.M. was statesmanlike but reserved, as if afraid that anything he said would betray the group’s secrets. “People all wanted to see J.M., but J.M. never talked,” Merrill’s Dale Meyer griped. The understated Rosenfeld was too low-key; he struck one investor as nearly comatose. Greg Hawkins, a former pupil of Merton, was the worst—full of Greek letters denoting algebraic symbols. The partners didn’t know how to tell a story; they sounded like math professors. Even the fund’s name lacked pizzazz; only the earnest Merton liked it. Investors had any number of reasons to shy away. Many were put off by J.M.’s unwillingness to discuss his investment strategies. Some were frightened by the prospective leverage, which J.M. was careful to disclose. Institutions such as the Rockefeller Foundation and Loews Corporation balked at paying such high fees. Long-Term’s entire premise seemed untested, especially to the consultants who advise institutions and who decide where a lot of money gets invested.

梅里韦瑟一直想方设法提升长期投资公司的声誉，他前往奥马哈与巴菲特共进牛排晚餐，因为他知道如果巴菲特投资，其他人也会跟进。这位和蔼可亲的亿万富翁一如既往地友善、热情，却始终不愿开支票。

Meriwether, who was continually angling to raise Long-Term’s pedigree, went to Omaha for a steak dinner with Buffett, knowing that if Buffett invested, others would, too. The jovial billionaire was his usual self—friendly, encouraging, and perfectly unwilling to write a check.

被美国首富拒绝后，JM转而寻求Jon Corzine的帮助。Corzine一直对Meriwether在Salomon的部门垂涎已久，当时他正试图在高盛打造一个与之竞争的业务。Corzine向Meriwether抛出了诱人的条件：高盛可能成为他的大股东，或者将Meriwether的新基金纳入麾下。最终，高盛两者都没有采取。瑞士联合银行也曾认真考虑过，但最终也放弃了。未能赢得这些大银行的支持令他感到沮丧。尽管JM信心满满，但他仍然担心自己会被Salomon排除在外。他迫切需要一个机构投资者的支持。

Rebuffed by the country’s richest investor, J.M. approached Jon Corzine, who had long envied Meriwether’s unit at Salomon and who was trying to build a rival business at Goldman Sachs. Corzine dangled the prospect of Goldman’s becoming a big investor or, perhaps, of its taking Meriwether’s new fund in-house. Ultimately, it did neither. Union Bank of Switzerland took a long look, but it passed, too. Not winning these big banks hurt. Despite his bravura, J.M. was worried about being cut out of the loop at Salomon. He badly wanted an institutional anchor.

JM化劣势为优势，接下来开始与几家外国银行接洽，希望它们成为长期基金的准合作伙伴，以提升该基金的国际化形象。每位合作伙伴——JM称之为“战略投资者”——将投资1亿美元，并分享其所在市场的内部信息。至少在理论上，长期基金也会做出相应的回报。这完全是梅里韦瑟式的策略，用“战略”一词来讨好潜在投资者。默顿非常赞同这个想法；它似乎印证了他的理论，即旧有的机构关系是可以被打破的。这开辟了第二条道路：JM独立地与外国银行接洽，而美林则专注于招揽客户。

Turning necessity to advantage, J.M. next pursued a handful of foreign banks to be Long-Term’s quasi partners, to give the fund an international gloss. Each partner—J.M. dubbed them “strategic investors”—would invest $100 million and share inside dope about its local market. In theory, at least, Long-Term would reciprocate. The plan was pure Meriwether, flattering potential investors by calling them “strategic.” Merton loved the idea; it seemed to validate his theory that the old institutional relationships could be overcome. It opened up a second track, with J.M. independently courting foreign banks while Merrill worked on recruiting its clients.

美林通过设计一套巧妙的“分红渠道”系统推进了募资进程，使长期基金能够从各种税务和法律领域的投资者那里募集资金。其中一个渠道面向普通美国投资者；另一个面向免税养老金；还有一个面向希望以日元对冲利润的日本投资者；还有一个面向欧洲机构投资者，这些机构只能投资于在交易所上市的股票（该渠道在爱尔兰证券交易所进行了虚拟上市）。

Merrill moved the fund-raising forward by devising an ingenious system of “feeders” that enabled Long-Term to solicit funds from investors in every imaginable tax and legal domain. One feeder was for ordinary U.S. investors; another for tax-free pensions; another for Japanese who wanted their profits hedged in yen; still another for European institutions, which could invest only in shares that were listed on an exchange (this feeder got a dummy listing on the Irish Stock Exchange).

这些中间机构并不持有资金；它们只是将资金输送至一个名为“长期资本组合”（LTCP）的中央基金的纸面渠道，该基金是一家开曼群岛合伙企业。实际上，“长期资本组合”就是真正的基金：它负责买卖债券并持有资产。运营该基金的工具是“长期资本管理公司”（LTCM），这是一家特拉华州合伙企业，由JM、他的合伙人以及部分合伙人的配偶所有。如此复杂的组织结构或许会让其他人望而却步，但合伙人们却欣然接受，因为他们认为自己能够构建复杂的交易是他们相对于其他交易员的优势之一。当然，实际上，合伙人们并不在开曼群岛或特拉华州，而是在康涅狄格州格林威治和伦敦的办公室里办公。

The feeders didn’t keep the money; they were paper conduits that channeled the money to a central fund, known as Long-Term Capital Portfolio (LTCP), a Cayman Islands partnership. For all practical purposes, Long-Term Capital Portfolio was the fund: it was the entity that would buy and sell bonds and hold the assets. The vehicle that ran the fund was Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM), a Delaware partnership owned by J.M., his partners, and some of their spouses. Though such a complicated organization might have dissuaded others, it was welcome to the partners, who viewed their ability to structure complex trades as one of their advantages over other traders. Physically, of course, the partners were nowhere near either the Caymans or Delaware but in offices in Greenwich, Connecticut, and London.

就在他们开始进行市场推广之际，合伙人迎来了一个转机。当时他们正在律师托马斯·贝尔（Thomas Bell）的办公室里，贝尔是辛普森·撒切尔律师事务所（Simpson Thacher & Bartlett）的合伙人。罗森菲尔德（Rosenfeld）突然兴奋地跳起来，说道：“快看！你看到所罗门（Salomon）做了什么吗？”说着，他扔下一张纸——所罗门的盈利报表。这家银行终于决定单独披露套利业务的收益，这样长期投资公司（Long-Term）就可以拿出合伙人之前的业绩作为佐证了。从报表中可以看出，所罗门之前的大部分利润都来自JM的团队——在他任职的最后五年里，每年超过5亿美元。然而，即便如此，也未能说服投资者。尽管美林（Merrill）苦苦哀求，合伙人对他们的策略仍然守口如瓶。长期投资公司甚至拒绝提供交易案例，因此潜在投资者对合伙人的提议几乎一无所知。毕竟，债券套利当时并不为人所熟知。

The partners got a break just as they started the marketing. They were at the office of their lawyer, Thomas Bell, a partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, when Rosenfeld excitedly jumped up and said, “Look at this! Do you see what Salomon did?” He threw down a piece of paper—Salomon’s earnings statement. The bank had finally decided to break out the earnings from Arbitrage, so Long-Term could now point to its partners’ prior record. Reading between the lines, it was clear that J.M.’s group had been responsible for most of Salomon’s previous profits—more than $500 million a year during his last five years at the firm. However, even this was not enough to persuade investors. And despite Merrill’s pleading, the partners remained far too tight-lipped about their strategies. Long-Term even refused to give examples of trades, so potential investors had little idea of what the partners were proposing. Bond arbitrage wasn’t widely understood, after all.

负责募资的美林高管埃德森·米切尔是个烟不离手的家伙，他迫切希望JM能敞开心扉；JM似乎忘了自己才是那个要钱的人。即使在与米切尔的私下会面中，JM也不愿透露他联系的银行名称；他把每个细节都看得像国家机密一样。面对这样一个戒备森严的客户，米切尔甚至无法说服自己的上司。尽管米切尔建议美林成为战略合作伙伴，但负责美林资本市场的戴维·科曼斯基却谨慎地拒绝了。他同意投资美林收取的约1500万美元费用，但对于投入更多资金却犹豫不决。

Edson Mitchell, the chain-smoking Merrill executive who oversaw the fund-raising, was desperate for J.M. to open up; it was as if J.M. had forgotten that he was the one asking for money. Even in private sessions with Mitchell, J.M. wouldn’t reveal the names of the banks he was calling; he treated every detail like a state secret. With such a guarded client, Mitchell couldn’t even sell the fund to his own bosses. Although Mitchell suggested that Merrill become a strategic partner, David Komansky, who oversaw capital markets for Merrill, warily refused. He agreed to invest Merrill’s fee, about $15 million, but balked at putting in more.

在巡回演讲期间，包括斯科尔斯、霍金斯和一些美林员工在内的一行人，进行了一次艰苦的印第安纳波利斯之行，拜访了康塞科保险公司——一家大型保险公司。他们抵达时已筋疲力尽。斯科尔斯开始讲述长期投资策略如何在相对有效的市场中赚取巨额利润。突然，一位名叫安德鲁·周的三十岁衍生品交易员，语气轻佻地脱口而出：“机会没那么多；你不可能在国债市场赚到那么多钱。”周的学历仅仅是金融硕士学位，他对这位著名的布莱克-斯科尔斯模型的发明者似乎丝毫没有敬畏之心。斯科尔斯勃然大怒，他身子前倾，坐在皮椅上说道：“正是因为有你这样的傻瓜，我们才能赚到这么多钱。”康塞科的人很不高兴，会议最终以不愉快的方式结束。美林要求斯科尔斯道歉。霍金斯觉得这事儿太滑稽了，他捂着肚子笑个不停。

At one point during the road show, a group including Scholes, Hawkins, and some Merrill people took a grueling trip to Indianapolis to visit Conseco, a big insurance company. They arrived exhausted. Scholes started to talk about how Long-Term could make bundles even in relatively efficient markets. Suddenly, Andrew Chow, a cheeky thirty-year-old derivatives trader, blurted out, “There aren’t that many opportunities; there is no way you can make that kind of money in Treasury markets.” Chow, whose academic credentials consisted of merely a master’s in finance, seemed not at all awed by the famed Black-Scholes inventor. Furious, Scholes angled forward in his leather-backed chair and said, “You’re the reason—because of fools like you we can.”11 The Conseco people got huffy, and the meeting ended badly. Merrill demanded that Scholes apologize. Hawkins thought it was hilarious; he was holding his stomach laughing.

但事实上，斯科尔斯才是这支基金最优秀的推销员。投资者们至少都听说过斯科尔斯；甚至还有几位上过他的课。斯科尔斯天生就是个讲故事的高手，虽然脾气有点暴躁，但性格外向。他用生动的比喻来推销这支基金。他解释说，长期基金就像吸尘器一样，在成千上万笔交易中赚取微薄的点差，就像在吸积别人看不见的镍币。他一边说着，一边仿佛凭空变出一枚镍币；这种表演技巧总是很管用的。即使谈到基金那些晦涩难懂的细节，斯科尔斯也能信手拈来地讲解其中的数学原理，让大多数潜在客户都觉得自己像个谦逊的学生。“他们利用迈伦来震撼人心，”康塞科投资部门负责人麦克斯韦·布布利茨说道。

But in truth, Scholes was the fund’s best salesman. Investors at least had heard of Scholes; a couple had even taken his class. And Scholes was a natural raconteur, temperamental but extroverted. He used a vivid metaphor to pitch the fund. Long-Term, he explained, would be earning a tiny spread on each of thousands of trades, as if it were vacuuming up nickels that others couldn’t see. He would pluck a nickel seemingly from the sky as he spoke; a little showmanship never hurt. Even when it came to the fund’s often arcane details, Scholes could glibly waltz through the math, leaving most of his prospects feeling like humble students. “They used Myron to blow you away,” said Maxwell Bublitz, head of Conseco’s investment arm.

斯科尔斯的父亲是安大略省的一位牙医，他本人却不太可能成为一名学者。他天生具有创业精神，和他的兄弟一起涉足了一系列商业活动，例如出版业和销售缎面床单。12 1962年大学毕业后，不安分的斯科尔斯在芝加哥大学找到了一份暑期计算机程序员的工作，尽管他对计算机几乎一窍不通。当时商学院的教职员工刚刚意识到计算机的强大功能，并大力推广基于数据的研究，特别是基于股票市场价格的研究。斯科尔斯的计算机工作如此出色，以至于教授们力劝他留下来，亲自研究市场。13

The son of an Ontario dentist, Scholes was an unlikely scholar. Relentlessly entrepreneurial, he and his brother had gotten involved in a string of business ventures, such as publishing, and selling satin sheets.12 After college, in 1962, the restless Scholes got a summer job as a computer programmer at the University of Chicago, despite knowing next to nothing about computers. The business school faculty had just awakened to the computer’s power, and was promoting data-based research, in particular studies based on stock market prices. Scholes’s computer work was so invaluable that the professors urged him to stick around and take up the study of markets himself.13

恰巧，斯科尔斯当时正身处新保守主义思潮的漩涡之中。尤金·F·法玛和默顿·H·米勒等学者正在发展后来成为现代金融核心思想的理论：有效市场假说。该假说的前提是股票价格永远是“正确的”；因此，没有人能够预测市场的未来走向，而市场走向必然是“随机的”。当然，要保证价格的“正确”，定价者必须既理性又消息灵通。实际上，该假说假设世界各地的每个交易大厅和经纪公司——或者至少足够多的足以决定价格的交易大厅和经纪公司——都由一群冷静沉着的拉里·希利布兰德式的人物组成，他们支付的价格永远不会高于或低于任何证券的“价值”。据维克多·尼德霍夫（Victor Niederhoffer）所说，斯科尔斯是芝加哥大学“随机漫步黑手党”（Random Walk Cosa Nostra）的一员。尼德霍夫曾与斯科尔斯一同学习，后来自己也创办了一家对冲基金，结果却以失败告终。斯科尔斯肤色黝黑，能言善辩。他曾斥责一位房地产经纪人，这位经纪人极力劝说斯科尔斯在芝加哥大学附近的海德公园买房，并声称该地区的房价每年将上涨12%。斯科尔斯反驳道，如果真是这样，人们现在早就把房子都买光了。尽管斯科尔斯信奉这一信条，但他始终对自己能否战胜市场心存疑虑。20世纪60年代末，他将自己的工资全部投入股市，并借钱维持生计。当股市暴跌时，他不得不恳求银行家延长贷款期限，以免被迫以巨额亏损抛售股票。最终，他的股票价格回升——但这并非长期投资者最后一次体会到一位友善的银行家的价值。 14

As it happened, Scholes had landed in a cauldron of neoconservative ferment. Scholars such as Eugene F. Fama and Merton H. Miller were developing what would become the central idea in modern finance: the Efficient Market Hypothesis. The premise of the hypothesis is that stock prices are always “right”; therefore, no one can divine the market’s future direction, which, in turn, must be “random.” For prices to be right, of course, the people who set them must be both rational and well informed. In effect, the hypothesis assumes that every trading floor and brokerage office around the world—or at least enough of them to determine prices—is staffed by a race of calm, collected Larry Hilibrands, who never pay more, never pay less than any security is “worth.” According to Victor Niederhoffer, who studied with Scholes at Chicago and would later blow up a hedge fund of his own, Scholes was part of a “Random Walk Cosa Nostra,” one of the disciples who methodically rejected any suggestion that markets could err. Swarthy and voluble, Scholes once lectured a real estate agent who urged him to buy in Hyde Park, near the university, and who claimed that housing prices in the area were supposed to rise by 12 percent a year. If that were true, Scholes shot back, people would buy all the houses now. Despite his credo, Scholes was never fully convinced that he couldn’t beat the market. In the late 1960s, he put his salary into stocks and borrowed to pay his living expenses. When the market plummeted, he had to beg his banker for an extension to avoid being forced to sell at a heavy loss. Eventually, his stocks recovered—not the last time a Long-Term partner would learn the value of a friendly banker.14

默顿是位精通理论的学者，而斯科尔斯则以其巧妙的理论检验方法而闻名。他与默顿的内敛截然相反，他好辩，热情地提出一个又一个奇思妙想，其中大多数最终都未能付诸实践，但往往闪耀着创造性的火花。凭借其务实的作风，他为所罗门兄弟公司做出了真正的贡献，在那里他创建了一家衍生品交易子公司。斯科尔斯还是美国和海外税法方面的顶尖专家。他将税收视为一场巨大的智力游戏：“实际上没有人会缴税，”他曾不屑地说道。斯科尔斯无法相信有人会不采取极端手段来避税，或许是因为他们不符合芝加哥学派将人视为经济机器的模式。在长期投资公司，斯科尔斯主导了一项巧妙的计划，允许合伙人将利润分成推迟长达十年，从而延缓缴税。他滔滔不绝地向律师们讲述各种细节，但合伙人们往往都能理解他时不时的潮热症状。他们被斯科尔斯的活力和对生活的热情所吸引。他不断地重塑自我，尝试滑雪等新的运动，还因为梅里韦瑟的缘故，开始打高尔夫，并且对这项运动充满热情。

While Merton was the consummate theoretician, Scholes was acclaimed for finding ingenious ways of testing theories. He was as argumentative as Merton was reserved, feverishly promoting one brainstorm after the next, most of which were unlikely to see the light of day but which often showed a creative spark. With his practical bent, he made a real contribution to Salomon, where he set up a derivative-trading subsidiary. And Scholes was a foremost expert on tax codes, both in the United States and overseas. He regarded taxes as a vast intellectual game: “No one actually pays taxes,” he once snapped disdainfully.15 Scholes could not believe there were people who would not go to extremes to avoid paying taxes, perhaps because they did not fit the Chicago School model of human beings as economic robots. At Long-Term, Scholes was the spearhead of a clever plan that let the partners defer their cut of the profits for up to ten years in order to put off paying taxes. He harangued the attorneys with details, but the partners tended to forgive his hot flashes. They were charmed by Scholes’s energy and joie de vivre. He was perpetually reinventing himself, taking up new sports such as skiing and—on account of Meriwether—golf, which he played with passion.

随着斯科尔斯的加入，营销活动逐渐升温。该基金向投资者抛出了诱人的橄榄枝，声称年回报率高达30%（扣除合伙人费用后）并非遥不可及。此外，尽管合伙人明确指出存在风险，但他们强调计划进行多元化投资。他们的投资组合遍布全球，他们认为分散投资可以有效降低风险。因此，任何单一市场都无法拖垮整个基金。

With Scholes on board, the marketing campaign gradually picked up steam. The fund dangled a tantalizing plum before investors, who were told that annual returns on the order of 30 percent (after the partners took their fees) would not be out of reach. Moreover, though the partners stated clearly that risk was involved, they stressed that they planned to diversify. With their portfolio spread around the globe, they felt that their eggs would be safely scattered. Thus, no one single market could pull the fund down.

合伙人锲而不舍地寻找最优质的投资者，经常邀请潜在投资者前往他们在格林威治水岸边汽船路（Steamboat Road）上那间环境优美的总部。有些投资者甚至与合伙人会面七八次之多。合伙人身着休闲的卡其裤和高尔夫球衫，显得信心十足。事实上，他们在所罗门兄弟公司赚得盆满钵满，投资者们也相信他们能够再次创造奇迹。面对如此卓越的才智，投资者们——由于对梅里韦瑟团队的实际运作方式知之甚少——逐渐忘记了自己是在进行一场冒险。“这是一群懂得如何赚钱的人，”瑞士银行家（后来也成为投资者）雷蒙德·贝尔（Raymond Baer）评论道。到1993年底，尽管基金尚未正式启动，进度也严重滞后，但资金承诺却开始源源不断地涌入。当希利布兰德最终离开所罗门兄弟公司加入他们时，合伙人的士气得到了极大的鼓舞。默顿和斯科尔斯或许能为营销增添光彩，但希利布兰德才是真正能让收银机发出欢呼声的人。

The partners doggedly pursued the choicest investors, often inviting prospects back to their pristine headquarters on Steamboat Road, at the water’s edge in Greenwich. Some investors met with partners as many as seven or eight times. In their casual khakis and golf shirts, the partners looked supremely confident. The fact was, they had made a ton of money at Salomon, and investors warmed to the idea that they could do it again. In the face of such intellectual brilliance, investors—having little understanding of how Meriwether’s gang actually operated—gradually forgot that they were taking a leap of faith. “This was a constellation of people who knew how to make money,” Raymond Baer, a Swiss banker (and eventual investor), noted. By the end of 1993, commitments for money were starting to roll in, even though the fund had not yet opened and was well behind schedule. The partners’ morale got a big boost when Hilibrand finally defected from Salomon and joined them. Merton and Scholes might have added marketing luster, but Hilibrand was the guy who would make the cash register sing.

JM还邀请了他的两位老朋友——所罗门集团高管理查德·F·利希和创办债券交易公司的好友詹姆斯·J·麦肯蒂——加入合伙。两人都不符合长期投资公司书呆子交易员的形象。利希是一位和蔼可亲、随和的销售员，他需要与华尔街银行家打交道——这并非那些固执己见的交易员的强项。然而，麦肯蒂的角色却令人费解。出售公司后，他过着奢华的生活，乘坐直升机往返于汉普顿的住所，并乘坐私人飞机前往格林纳丁斯群岛，因此赢得了“酋长”的绰号。与那些精于算计的套利交易员不同，出生于布朗克斯的麦肯蒂是一位凭直觉进行交易的传统主义者。但梅里韦瑟喜欢有这样的朋友在身边；与这些老友闲聊时，他感到轻松自在，甚至有些外向。并非巧合的是，莱希和麦肯蒂都是爱尔兰裔美国人，JM 一直觉得和他们在一起很自在。他们两人也都是 JM 最珍视的资产——位于爱尔兰西南部海岸、风景优美、维护精良的沃特维尔高尔夫球场的合伙人。

J.M. also offered partnerships to two of his longtime golfing cronies, Richard F. Leahy, an executive at Salomon, and James J. McEntee, a close friend who had founded a bond-dealing firm. Neither fit the mold of Long-Term’s nerdy traders. Leahy, an affable, easygoing salesman, would be expected to deal with Wall Street bankers—not the headstrong traders’ strong suit. McEntee’s role, though, was a puzzle. After selling his business, he had lived in high style, commuting via helicopter to a home in the Hamptons and jetting to an island in the Grenadines, which had earned him the sobriquet “the Sheik.” In contrast to the egghead arbitrageurs, the Bronx-born McEntee was a traditionalist who traded from his gut. But Meriwether liked having such friends around; bantering with these pals, he was relaxed and even gregarious. Not coincidentally, Leahy and McEntee were fellow Irish Americans, a group with whom J.M. always felt at home. Each was also a partner in the asset that was closest to J.M.’s heart—a remote, exquisitely manicured golf course, on the coast of southwestern Ireland, known as Waterville.

1994年初，JM获得了最令人震惊的人物：美国联邦储备委员会副主席大卫·W·穆林斯，他是美联储的二号人物，仅次于美联储主席艾伦·格林斯潘。穆林斯也曾是默顿在麻省理工学院的学生，后来在哈佛大学任教，他和罗森菲尔德在那里结下了友谊。作为一名中央银行家，他为长期投资公司提供了无与伦比的国际银行资源。此外，穆林斯还是美联储处理莫泽案件的关键人物。这意味着梅里韦瑟现在已经获得了华盛顿的认可。

Early in 1994, J.M. bagged the most astonishing name of all: David W. Mullins, vice chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve and second in the Fed’s hierarchy to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. Mullins, too, was a former student of Merton’s at MIT who had gone on to teach at Harvard, where he and Rosenfeld had been friends. As a central banker, he gave Long-Term incomparable access to international banks. Moreover, Mullins had been the Fed’s point man on the Mozer case. The implication was that Meriwether now had a clean bill of health from Washington.

穆林斯和梅里韦瑟一样，都曾是少年投资者，他的父亲是阿肯色大学校长，母亲是哈佛大学一位极受欢迎的讲师。讽刺的是，他的职业生涯始于政府部门，担任金融危机专家；如果市场再次崩盘，人们都指望他能成为长期投资公司的危机应对专家。1987年股市崩盘后，穆林斯参与撰写了一份备受瞩目的白宫报告，将主要责任归咎于新兴的衍生品市场，认为正是这些市场助长了雪球式抛售。之后，他加入了财政部，参与起草了救助破产储贷机构的法案。作为一名监管者，他敏锐地意识到，市场远非完美的定价机器，而是会周期性地出现危险的过度反应。“我们的金融体系节奏快、极富创造力。它的设计本身就允许频繁出现险些崩盘的情况，”他在跳槽到长期投资公司前一年曾这样说道。穆林斯对自己的未来基金有着远超想象的洞察力，他认为美联储的部分使命应该是拯救那些受到“流动性问题”威胁的私人机构。16

Mullins, like Meriwether a onetime teenage investor, was the son of a University of Arkansas president and an enormously popular lecturer at Harvard. Ironically, he had launched his career in government as an expert on financial crises; he was expected to be Long-Term’s disaster guru if markets came unstuck again. After the 1987 stock market crash, Mullins had helped write a blue-ribbon White House report, laying substantial blame on the new derivatives markets, where the snowball selling had gathered momentum. Then he had joined the Treasury, where he had helped draft the law to bail out the country’s bankrupt savings and loans. As a regulator, he was acutely aware that markets—far from being perfect pricing machines—periodically and dangerously overshoot. “Our financial system is fast-paced, enormously creative. It’s designed to have near misses with some frequency,” he remarked a year before jumping ship for Long-Term. With more omniscience regarding his future fund than he could have dreamed, Mullins argued that part of the Fed’s mission should be saving private institutions that were threatened by “liquidity problems.”16

穆林斯为人谦逊温和，举止文雅，衣着打扮却像个银行家，被认为是格林斯潘的潜在接班人。他之前在财政部的上司尼古拉斯·布雷迪在穆林斯加入长期投资公司时，不禁疑惑他与“那些人”合作究竟有何目的。不过，投资者们对这位和蔼可亲的穆林斯的加入感到安心，因为他对市场的看法或许与他们不谋而合。事实上，通过招揽一位央行行长，长期投资公司获得了私人基金前所未有的机会，得以接触到世界各地准政府机构的巨额资金。很快，长期投资公司便赢得了香港土地发展局、新加坡政府投资公司、台湾银行、曼谷银行以及科威特国家养老基金的投资承诺。更难能可贵的是，长期投资公司甚至成功说服意大利央行外汇管理局投资1亿美元。要知道，这类机构通常不会投资对冲基金。但负责这家意大利机构投资的皮埃兰托尼奥·钱皮卡利并不认为长期投资是一家“对冲基金”，而是一家“声誉卓著”的精英投资机构。 17

Wry and soft-spoken, the intellectual Mullins dressed like a banker and was thought to be a potential successor to Greenspan. Nicholas Brady, his former boss at Treasury, wondered when Mullins joined Long-Term what he was doing with “those guys.” Investors, though, were soothed by the addition of the congenial Mullins, whose perspective on markets may have been much like their own. Indeed, by snaring a central banker, Long-Term gained unparalleled access for a private fund to the pots of money in quasi-governmental accounts around the world. Soon, Long-Term won commitments from the Hong Kong Land & Development Authority, the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, the Bank of Taiwan, the Bank of Bangkok, and the Kuwaiti state-run pension fund. In a rare coup, Long-Term even enticed the foreign exchange office of Italy’s central bank to invest $100 million. Such entities simply do not invest in hedge funds. But Pierantonio Ciampicali, who oversaw investments for the Italian agency, thought of Long-Term not as a “hedge fund” but as an elite investing organization “with a solid reputation.”17

私人投资者同样对这家汇聚金融界顶尖人才、并拥有常驻央行行长的基金感到敬畏，这位央行行长似乎能在华尔街这场痴迷于揣摩格林斯潘心思的博弈中领先一步。其成员名单令人印象深刻。在日本，长期基金成功吸引了住友银行投资1亿美元。在欧洲，它又吸引了德国金融巨头德累斯顿银行、列支敦士登环球信托以及瑞士私人银行宝盛银行（后者向其百万富翁客户推介了该基金），投资金额从3000万美元到1亿美元不等。由国际银行家埃德蒙·萨夫拉运营的神秘机构——纽约共和公司，也被长期基金的资历所折服，并被从该基金获得业务的可能性所吸引。该公司投资了6500万美元。长期基金还成功吸引了巴西最大的投资银行——加兰蒂亚银行。

Private investors were similarly awed by a fund boasting the best minds in finance and a resident central banker, who plausibly would be a step ahead in the obsessive Wall Street game of trying to outguess Greenspan. The list was impressive. In Japan, Long-Term signed up Sumitomo Bank for $100 million. In Europe, it corralled the giant German Dresdner Bank, the Liechtenstein Global Trust, and Bank Julius Baer, a private Swiss bank that pitched the fund to its millionaire clientele, for sums ranging from $30 million to $100 million. Republic New York Corporation, a secretive organization run by international banker Edmond Safra, was mesmerized by Long-Term’s credentials and seduced by the possibility of winning business from the fund.18 It invested $65 million. Long-Term also snared Banco Garantia, Brazil’s biggest investment bank.

在美国，Long-Term从形形色色的名人和机构那里获得了资金。好莱坞经纪人迈克尔·奥维茨（Michael Ovitz）投资了该公司；耐克（Nike）首席执行官菲尔·奈特（Phil Knight）、精英咨询公司麦肯锡（McKinsey & Company）的合伙人以及纽约石油高管罗伯特·贝尔弗（Robert Belfer）也参与了投资。贝尔斯登（Bear Stearns）首席执行官詹姆斯·凯恩（James Cayne）认为，Long-Term的盈利能力如此强大，以至于其管理费可以忽略不计。和其他人一样，凯恩也对JM及其合伙人愿意自掏腰包投资1.46亿美元感到放心。（罗森菲尔德（Rosenfeld）和其他人也投入了子女的资金。）学术界，尤其是教授们才华横溢的学术界，很容易就接受了投资：圣约翰大学（St. John's University）和叶史瓦大学（Yeshiva University）各自投资了1000万美元；匹兹堡大学（University of Pittsburgh）也投入了其一半的资金。在沙克高地（Shaker Heights），Paragon Advisors将其富有的客户投资了Long-Term。 Paragon公司总裁特伦斯·沙利文在攻读商科学位期间读过默顿和斯科尔斯的著作；他认为这项业务风险很低。19

In the United States, Long-Term got money from a diverse group of hotshot celebrities and institutions. Michael Ovitz, the Hollywood agent, invested; so did Phil Knight, chief executive of Nike, the sneaker giant, as well as partners at the elite consulting firm McKinsey & Company and New York oil executive Robert Belfer. James Cayne, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, figured that Long-Term would make so much money that its fees wouldn’t matter. Like others, Cayne was comforted by the willingness of J.M. and his partners to invest $146 million of their own. (Rosenfeld and others put their kids’ money in, too.) Academe, where the professors’ brilliance was well known, was an easy sell: St. John’s University and Yeshiva University put in $10 million each; the University of Pittsburgh climbed aboard for half that. In Shaker Heights, Paragon Advisors put its wealthy clients into Long-Term. Terence Sullivan, president of Paragon, had read Merton and Scholes while getting a business degree; he felt the operation was low risk.19

在企业界，潘恩韦伯公司认为可以从长期投资基金获得投资理念，于是投资了1亿美元；其董事长唐纳德·马龙个人又追加了1000万美元。其他投资者包括百得公司养老基金、纽约大陆保险公司（后被洛伊斯收购）和总统人寿保险公司。

In the corporate world, PaineWebber, thinking it would tap Long-Term for investing ideas, invested $100 million; Donald Marron, its chairman, added $10 million personally. Others included the Black & Decker Corporation pension fund, Continental Insurance of New York (later acquired by Loews), and Presidential Life Corporation.

Long-Term于1994年2月底正式开业。为了庆祝开业，梅里韦瑟、罗森菲尔德、霍金斯和利希购买了一批上等勃艮第葡萄酒，足够他们享用数年。除了11位合伙人外，该基金还拥有约30名交易员和职员，以及价值1000万美元的SPARC工作站——这些功能强大的Sun Microsystems机器深受交易员和工程师的青睐。Long-Term的融资狂潮共筹集了12.5亿美元——虽然远未达到JM的目标，但仍然是有史以来规模最大的初创企业。20

Long-Term opened for business at the end of February 1994. Meriwether, Rosenfeld, Hawkins, and Leahy celebrated by purchasing a shipment of fine Burgundies ample enough to last for years. In addition to its eleven partners, the fund had about thirty traders and clerks and $10 million worth of SPARC workstations, the powerful Sun Microsystems machines favored by traders and engineers. Long-Term’s fund-raising blitz had netted $1.25 billion—well short of J.M.’s goal but still the largest start-up ever.20

3

3

亡命天涯

ON THE RUN

他们（Long-Term）实际上是世界上最好的金融学院。

They [Long-Term] are in effect the best finance faculty in the world.

—机构投资者​





—INSTITUTIONAL INVESTOR





命运眷顾了Long-Term。在市场行情最佳时期募集资金后，该公司在华尔街乌云密布之际，迅速将资金投入市场。投资者渴望风平浪静，但矛盾的是，市场动荡之时，机遇往往最为丰富。价格平稳时，交易枯燥乏味。价格开始波动，仿佛平静的河流中涌现出阵阵漩涡和暗流。投资者的资金被卷入这股洪流，逆流而上。曾经一路顺风顺水的两只债券如今被迫分离，原本可预测的利差也变得不再同步。投资者顿时感到茫然无措。那些意志薄弱或缺乏安全感的人可能会恐慌抛售，或者至少会选择抛售。如果抛售者足够多，一股危险的暗流可能会扭曲整个市场。而对于那些坚守资金和保持清醒头脑的投资者来说，此时正是良机。

THE GODS SMILED on Long-Term. Having raised capital during the best of times, it put its money to work just as clouds began to gather over Wall Street. Investors long for steady waters, but paradoxically, the opportunities are richest when markets turn turbulent. When prices are flat, trading is a dull sport. When prices begin to gyrate, it is as if little eddies and currents begin to bubble in a formerly placid river. This security is dragged with the current, that one is washed upstream. Two bonds that once journeyed happily in tow are now wrenched apart, and once predictable spreads are jolted out of sync. Suddenly, investors feel cast adrift. Those who are weak or insecure may panic or at any rate sell. If enough do so, a dangerous undertow may distort the entire market. For the few who have hung on to their capital and their wits, this is when opportunity beckons.

1994年，当梅里韦瑟即将完成募资工作时，格林斯潘开始担心美国经济可能过热。当时正在美联储清理办公桌并准备转投长期基金的穆林斯敦促美联储主席收紧信贷。¹ 2月，就在利率处于最低点——投资者也感到最沮丧的时候——格林斯潘出人意料地提高了短期利率，震惊了华尔街。这是五年来的首次加息。但如果这位颇具远见的美联储主席的目的是为了安抚市场，那么此举却适得其反。债券价格暴跌（当然，债券价格的走势与利率的走势相反）。而且，考虑到格林斯潘此次加息幅度仅为0.25个百分点，债券价格的跌幅远超预期。有人急于抛售债券。

In 1994, as Meriwether was wrapping up the fund-raising, Greenspan started to worry that the U.S. economy might be overheating. Mullins, who was cleaning out his desk at the Fed and preparing to jump to Long-Term, urged the Fed chief to tighten credit.¹ In February, just when interest rates were at their lowest—and, indeed, when investors were feeling their plummiest—Greenspan stunned Wall Street by raising short-term interest rates. It was the first such hike in five years. But if the oracular Fed chief had in mind calming markets, the move backfired. Bond prices tumbled (bond prices, of course, move in the opposite direction of interest rates). And given the modest nature of Greenspan’s quarter-point increase, bonds were falling more than they “should” have. Somebody was desperate to sell.

到5月份，也就是长期债券发行仅仅两个月后，30年期美国国债价格就从近期高点暴跌了16%——这在相对平静的固定收益证券领域可谓是巨大的波动——收益率也从6.2%升至7.6%。欧洲债券市场同样暴跌。包括对冲基金在内的各类投资者——其中许多对冲基金负债累累——纷纷抛售债券。迈克尔·斯坦哈特（Michael Steinhardt）就是这样一位杠杆交易员，他目睹了这一切，感到十分震惊。斯坦哈特押注欧洲债券，利率每变动0.01个百分点，他就损失700万美元。这位行事大胆的斯坦哈特在短短四天内就让投资者损失了8亿美元。乔治·索罗斯（George Soros）也受到了国际货币反弹的影响，两天内就让客户损失了6.5亿美元。²

By May, barely two months after Long-Term’s debut, the thirty-year Treasury bond had plunged 16 percent from its recent peak—a huge move in the relatively tame world of fixed-income securities—rising in yield from 6.2 percent to 7.6 percent. Bonds in Europe were crashing, too. Diverse investors, including hedge funds—many of which were up to their necks in debt—were fleeing from bonds. Michael Steinhardt, one such leveraged operator, watched in horror. Steinhardt, who had bet on European bonds, was losing $7 million with every hundredth of a percentage point move in interest rates. The swashbuckling Steinhardt lost $800 million of his investors’ money in a mere four days. George Soros, who was jolted by a ricochet effect on international currencies, dropped $650 million for his clients in two days.²

对梅里韦瑟来说，这场动荡反而是天大的好消息。一天早晨，正值抛售高峰期，梅里韦瑟走到一位交易员身边。他瞥了一眼交易员的屏幕，惊叹道：“一波又一波的人都认输了。” 梅里韦瑟深知，恐慌的投资者在争相离场时不会挑剔。他们急于抛售，推大了价差，这正是梅里韦瑟梦寐以求的获利机会。“债券市场异常高的波动性……通常伴随着价差扩大，”他在一封——对他而言——异常坦诚的致投资者信中写道。“价差扩大为增持LTCP的趋同和相对价值交易头寸创造了更多机会。”³ 在经历了两个月的平稳期后，Long-Term在5月份上涨了7%，开启了一段令人振奋的盈利期。梅里韦瑟几乎从未想过，长期投资公司有一天会和那些惊慌失措、过度杠杆化的对冲基金互换位置。但1994年的债券危机——正值长期投资公司成立之初——却引起了公司的密切关注。

For Meriwether, this tumult was the best of news. One morning during the heat of the selling, J.M. walked over to one of his traders. Glancing at the trader’s screen, J.M. marveled, “It’s wave after wave of guys throwing in the towel.” As J.M. knew, panicky investors wouldn’t be picky as they ran for the exits. In their eagerness to sell, they were pushing spreads wider, creating just the gaps that Meriwether was hoping to exploit. “The unusually high volatility in the bond markets . . . has generally been associated with a widening of spreads,” he chirped in a—for him—unusually revealing letter to investors. “This widening has created further opportunities to add to LTCP’s convergence and relative-value trading positions.”³ After two flat months, Long-Term rose 7 percent in May, beginning a stretch of heady profits. It would hardly have occurred to Meriwether that Long-Term would ever switch places with some of those panicked, overleveraged hedge funds. But the bond debacle of 1994, which unfolded during Long-Term’s very first months, merited Long-Term’s close attention.

评论人士开始注意到国际债券市场之间出现了新的关联性。《华尔街日报》指出，“看似毫不相关的市场崩盘正在美国国债市场产生连锁反应。” ⁴欧洲债券价格下跌、信孚银行交易亏损的消息、专门从事抵押贷款交易的对冲基金阿斯金资本管理公司倒闭，以及墨西哥主要总统候选人遇刺身亡等一系列看似毫不相干的事件，都加剧了美国国债价格的下跌，而这一下跌趋势始于格林斯潘的温和调整。

Commentators began to see a new connectedness in international bond markets. The Wall Street Journal observed that “implosions in seemingly unrelated markets were reverberating in the U.S. Treasury bond market.”4 Such disparate developments as a slide in European bonds, news of trading losses at Bankers Trust, the collapse of Askin Capital Management, a hedge fund that had specialized in mortgage trades, and the assassination of Mexico’s leading presidential contender all accentuated the slide in U.S. Treasurys that had begun with Greenspan’s modest adjustment.

突然间，市场之间的联系更加紧密——这对长期投资而言意义重大。这意味着一个市场的趋势可能会蔓延到另一个市场。一次孤立的暴跌可能演变成一场普遍的崩盘。衍生品可以根据任何市场进行定制，纽约的投机者可以轻而易举地押注日本，阿姆斯特丹的投机者也可以轻易地押注巴西——这使得一个市场的动荡有可能波及到其他市场。对于那些被电子屏幕束缚的交易员来说，不同市场之间的界限——例如​​，美国的抵押贷款和法国的政府贷款——几乎不复存在。它们都成了风险连续体上的不同点，而衍生品将它们连接在一起。由于交易员们争相偿还债务，瑞士信贷第一波士顿的经济学家尼尔·索斯向《华尔街日报》解释说： “你卖的不是你应该卖的，而是你能卖的。”通过杠杆化一种证券，投资者可能已经放弃了对所有其他证券的控制权。这条真理值得我们牢记：这些证券或许彼此无关，但它们的持有者却是同一批人，这使得它们在市场动荡时期实际上被联系在了一起。当大量的金融投资者都投资于同一种证券时，国界便会变得模糊不清。“分散投资以求安全”——长期投资公司赖以生存的根本理念——也需要重新审视。

Suddenly markets were more closely linked—a development with pivotal significance for Long-Term. It meant that a trend in one market could spread to the next. An isolated slump could become a generalized rout. With derivatives, which could be custom-tailored to any market of one’s fancy, it was a snap for a speculator in New York to take a flier on Japan or for one in Amsterdam to gamble on Brazil—raising the prospect that trouble on one front would leach into the next. For traders tethered to electronic screens, the distinction between markets—say, between mortgages in America and government loans in France—almost ceased to exist. They were all points on a continuum of risk, stitched together by derivatives. With traders scrambling to pay back debts, Neal Soss, an economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, explained to the Journal, “You don’t sell what you should. You sell what you can.” By leveraging one security, investors had potentially given up control of all of their others. This verity is well worth remembering: the securities might be unrelated, but the same investors owned them, implicitly linking them in times of stress. And when armies of financial soldiers were involved in the same securities, borders shrank. The very concept of safety through diversification—the basis of Long-Term’s own security—would merit rethinking.

斯坦哈特将他的损失归咎于“流动性”的突然消失，这个词在接下来的几年里将频繁出现在《长期投资》杂志的口头禅中。⁵但“流动性”只是一个稻草人论据。每当市场暴跌时，投资者都会震惊地发现买家数量不足。正如凯恩斯所观察到的，整个社会不可能拥有“流动性”。⁶错误在于认为市场有义务保持流动性，或者买家总会存在以满足卖家的需求。1994 年的真正罪魁祸首是杠杆。如果你没有负债，你就不会破产，也不会被迫出售，在这种情况下，“流动性”就无关紧要了。但一家杠杆企业可能被迫出售，否则快速累积的损失将使其破产。杠杆总是会引发这种残酷的动态，其危险性怎么强调都不为过。

Steinhardt blamed his losses on a sudden evaporation of “liquidity,” a term that would be on Long-Term’s lips in years to come.5 But “liquidity” is a straw man. Whenever markets plunge, investors are stunned to find that there are not enough buyers to go around. As Keynes observed, there cannot be “liquidity” for the community as a whole.6 The mistake is in thinking that markets have a duty to stay liquid or that buyers will always be present to accommodate sellers. The real culprit in 1994 was leverage. If you aren’t in debt, you can’t go broke and can’t be made to sell, in which case “liquidity” is irrelevant. But a leveraged firm may be forced to sell, lest fast-accumulating losses put it out of business. Leverage always gives rise to this same brutal dynamic, and its dangers cannot be stressed too often.

Long-Term 的运气可谓双喜临门：在它投入大量资金之前，利差就已经扩大；而且一旦机会出现，Long-Term 是极少数能够利用市场整体低迷局面获利的公司之一。它的交易也确实不错。这些交易并非毫无风险；它们也并非好到可以随意使用杠杆。但总的来说，这些交易既明智又具有机会主义。Long-Term 几乎立刻就开始从中获利。

Long-Term was doubly fortunate: spreads widened before it invested much of its capital, and once opportunities did arise, Long-Term was one of a very few firms in a position to exploit the general distress. And its trades were good trades. They weren’t risk-free; they weren’t so good that the fund could leverage indiscriminately. But by and large, they were intelligent and opportunistic. Long-Term started to make money on them almost immediately.

它最早的交易之一就涉及同一笔30年期国债。当然，国债（各种期限的国债）都是美国政府发行的，用于为联邦预算融资。每天约有1700亿美元的国债进行交易，它们被认为是世界上风险最小的投资。但是，30年期国债在发行后大约六个月会发生一件有趣的事情：投资者会将它们塞进保险箱或抽屉里长期持有。随着流通中的国债减少，交易难度也随之增加。与此同时，财政部发行了新的30年期国债，这笔新发行的国债迎来了它的黄金时期。在华尔街，还有大约29年半到期的旧国债被称为“非活跃债券”（off the run），而闪亮的新债券则被称为“活跃债券”（on the run）。由于流动性较差，“非活跃债券”的吸引力较低。它的交易价格开始略微折让（也就是说，你可以用更低的价格买到它，或者说，你可以获得略高的收益率）。正如套利者所说，价差出现了。

One of its first trades involved the same thirty-year Treasury bond. Treasurys (of all durations) are, of course, issued by the U.S. government to finance the federal budget. Some $170 billion of them trade each day, and they are considered the least risky investments in the world. But a funny thing happens to thirty-year Treasurys six months or so after they are issued: investors stuff them into safes and drawers for long-term keeping. With fewer left in circulation, the bonds become harder to trade. Meanwhile, the Treasury issues a new thirty-year bond, which now has its day in the sun. On Wall Street, the older bond, which has about 29 ½ years left to mature, is known as off the run; the shiny new model is on the run. Being less liquid, the off-the-run bond is considered less desirable. It begins to trade at a slight discount (that is, you can purchase it for a little less, or at what amounts to a slightly higher interest yield). As arbitrageurs would say, a spread opens.

1994年，长期投资公司注意到，这种利差异常之大。1993年2月发行的债券收益率为7.36%。六个月后，也就是8月发行的债券收益率仅低7.24%，也就是低了12个基点。每周二，长期投资公司的合伙人都会召开风险管理会议。在早期的一次会议上，几位合伙人提议押注这12个基点的利差将会缩小。仅仅说“一只债券更便宜，另一只债券更贵”是不够的。教授们需要了解利差存在的原因，这或许能揭示一个至关重要的问题：利差是否会持续，甚至是否会扩大。在这种情况下，利差似乎显得有些荒谬。毕竟，美国政府偿还29年半到期债券的可能性与偿还30年到期债券的可能性并无二致。但有些机构却过于谨慎，过于官僚主义，以至于他们只愿意持有流动性最强的债券。 Long-Term认为，许多机会源于机构有时任意的要求所造成的市场扭曲。7后者愿意为即时发行的债券支付溢价，而Long-Term的合伙人（他们曾在Salomon公司频繁进行此类交易）则乐于收取这笔费用。他们称之为“快速交易”，因为这两种债券通常在短短几个月后就会合并。实际上，Long-Term持有流动性较差的债券，却因此获得了一笔费用。

In 1994, Long-Term noticed that this spread was unusually wide. The February 1993 issue was trading at a yield of 7.36 percent. The bond issued six months later, in August, was yielding only 7.24 percent, or 12 basis points, less. Every Tuesday, Long-Term’s partners held a risk-management meeting, and at one of the early meetings, several proposed that they bet on this 12-point gap to narrow. It wasn’t enough to say, “One bond is cheaper, one bond is dearer.” The professors needed to know why a spread existed, which might shed light on the paramount issue of whether it was likely to persist or even to widen. In this case, the spread seemed almost silly. After all, the U.S. government is no less likely to pay off a bond that matures in 29 ½ years than it is one that expires in thirty. But some institutions were so timid, so bureaucratic, that they refused to own anything but the most liquid paper. Long-Term believed that many opportunities arose from market distortions created by the sometimes arbitrary demands of institutions.7 The latter were willing to pay a premium for on-the-run paper, and Long-Term’s partners, who had often done this trade at Salomon, happily collected it. They called it a “snap trade,” because the two bonds usually snapped together after only a few months. In effect, Long-Term would be collecting a fee for its willingness to own a less liquid bond.

罗森菲尔德指出：“我们很多交易都是为了提供流动性。我们买入的是大家都想卖的东西。” 罗森菲尔德显然没有意识到，由于长期基金倾向于在每个市场都买入流动性较差的证券，其资产并非完全独立，就像掷骰子的结果彼此独立一样。事实上，如果真的出现“所有人”都想抛售的情况，其资产很可能会同步下跌。

“A lot of our trades were liquidity-providing,” Rosenfeld noted. “We were buying the stuff that everyone wanted to sell.” It apparently did not occur to Rosenfeld that since Long-Term tended to buy the less liquid security in every market, its assets were not entirely independent of one another, the way one dice roll is independent of the next. Indeed, its assets would be susceptible to falling in unison if a time came when, literally, “everyone” wanted to sell.

12个基点的利差微乎其微；通常情况下，这点利差根本不值得费心。每对面值1000美元的债券，价格差异仅为15.80美元。即便利差缩小到原来的三分之二，比如几个月后，长期公司也只能从这些1000美元的债券中赚取10美元，也就是1%的收益。但是，如果利用杠杆，将这微小的利差放大呢？的确，如果真是这样呢！怀着这样的策略，长期公司买入了10亿美元的低价非流通债券，同时卖出了10亿美元的高价流通国债。这是一笔惊人的数目。合伙人一开始就将长期公司的全部资本都投入了进去！当然，他们不太可能损失太多。因为他们买入一种债券，卖出另一种，他们押注的仅仅是债券价格最终会趋于一致，而且正如前面提到的，债券利差的波动远小于债券本身的波动。你家房价可能会暴跌，但如果真的暴跌，你邻居家的房价也可能跟着暴跌。当然，价差也可能扩大，至少在短期内如此。如果两只债券的价差是12个点，谁又能保证价差不会扩大到14个点——或者，在市场极度紧张的情况下，扩大到20个点呢？

Twelve basis points is a tiny spread; ordinarily, it wouldn’t be worth the trouble. The price difference was only $15.80 for each pair of $1,000 bonds. Even if the spread narrowed two thirds of the way, say in a few months’ time, Long-Term would earn only $10, or 1 percent, on those $1,000 bonds. But what if, using leverage, that tiny spread could be multiplied? What if, indeed! With such a strategy in mind, Long-Term bought $1 billion of the cheaper, off-the-run bonds. It also sold $1 billion of the more expensive, on-the-run Treasurys. This was a staggering sum. Right off the bat, the partners were risking all of Long-Term’s capital! To be sure, they weren’t likely to lose very much of it. Since they were buying one bond and selling another, they were betting only that the bonds would converge, and, as noted, bond spreads vary much less than bonds themselves do. The price of your home could crash, but if it does, the price of your neighbor’s house will likely crash as well. Of course, there was some risk that the spread could widen, at least for a brief period. If two bonds traded at a 12-point spread, who could say that the spread wouldn’t go to 14 points—or, in a time of extreme stress, to 20 points?

长期投资公司以其一贯的精准计算得出，持有一只债券并做空另一只债券的风险仅为直接持有其中任何一只债券的二十五分之一。因此，该公司认为可以谨慎地利用这种多空套利策略二十五倍杠杆。这使其潜在利润倍增，但正如我们所见，潜在损失也随之增加。无论如何，该公司确实进行了借贷。它用从华尔街一家或多家银行借来的资金购买了价格较低的非主流债券。而它卖空的其他债券，也是通过贷款获得的。

Long-Term, with trademark precision, calculated that owning one bond and shorting another was one twenty-fifth as risky as owning either bond outright.8 Thus, it reckoned that it could prudently leverage this long/short arbitrage twenty-five times. This multiplied its potential for profit but—as we have seen—also its potential for loss. In any case, borrow it did. It paid for the cheaper, off-the-run bonds with money that it borrowed from a Wall Street bank, or from several banks. And the other bonds, the ones it sold short, it obtained through a loan, as well.

事实上，这笔交易更为复杂，尽管它算是长期投资公司业务中最简单的交易之一。长期投资公司买入非流通债券后，立即将其借给另一家华尔街公司，后者随后将现金作为抵押品汇给长期投资公司。之后，长期投资公司又将这笔现金作为抵押品，再次购入债券。在华尔街，这种短期抵押贷款被称为“回购融资”。

Actually, the transaction was more involved, though it was among the simplest in Long-Term’s repertoire. No sooner did Long-Term buy the off-the-run bonds than it loaned them to some other Wall Street firm, which then wired cash to Long-Term as collateral. Then Long-Term turned around and used this cash as collateral on the bonds that it borrowed. On Wall Street, such short-term, collateralized loans are known as “repo financing.”

这笔交易的妙处在于，长期公司的现金交易达到了完美的平衡。长期公司做多（买入）的资金与其做空（卖出）的收益完全一致。其支付的抵押品也与其收取的抵押品相等。换句话说，长期公司在完成这笔20亿美元的交易时，没有动用一分钱的自有资金。 *

The beauty of the trade was that Long-Term’s cash transactions were in perfect balance. The money that Long-Term spent going long (buying) matched the money it collected going short (selling). The collateral it paid equaled the collateral it collected. In other words, Long-Term pulled off the entire $2 billion trade without using a dime of its own cash. *

维持这一仓位并非完全没有成本。虽然交易看似简单，但实际上涉及四笔不同的支出。长期基金收取了其支付的抵押品的利息，并支付了其接收的抵押品的利息（利率略高）。它通过收取其持有债券的7.36%票息，并支付其做空债券的较低利率7.24%来弥补部分亏损。总体而言，长期基金每月需为此付出几个基点的成本。

* Maintaining the position wasn’t completely cost-free. Though a simple trade, it actually entailed four different payment streams. Long-Term collected interest on the collateral it paid out and paid interest (at a slightly higher rate) on the collateral it took in. It made some of this deficit back because it collected the 7.36 percent coupon on the bond it owned and paid the lesser 7.24 percent rate on the bond it shorted. Overall, it cost Long-Term a few basis points a month.

通常情况下，如果你从美林证券等机构借入债券，你需要提供一些额外的抵押品——比如，一张面值1000美元的国债可能需要1010美元的抵押品，而风险更高的债券则需要更多。这10美元的初始保证金，相当于债券价值的1%，被称为“折扣” 。这是美林证券为了防范债券价格上涨而采取的一种保护措施。

Now, normally, when you borrow a bond from, say, Merrill Lynch, you have to post a little bit of extra collateral—maybe a total of $1,010 on a $1,000 Treasury and more on a riskier bond. That $10 initial margin, equivalent to 1 percent of the bond’s value, is called a haircut. It’s Merrill Lynch’s way of protecting itself in case the price of the bond rises.

强制平仓自然会限制你的交易量。但如果你能避免强制平仓，那你的交易潜力将无可限量。这就像开一辆不烧汽油的车：你想开多远就开多远。更重要的是，如果你没有在美林证券占用额外的保证金，收益率也会大幅提高。

The haircut naturally acts as a check on how much you can trade. But if you could avoid the haircut, well, the sky would be the limit. It would be like driving a car that didn’t burn gas: you could drive as far as you wished. What’s more, the rate of return would be substantially higher—if you didn’t have that extra margin tied up at Merrill Lynch.

从一开始，长期基金的政策就是拒绝支付保证金，或者至少大幅降低保证金比例。这项政策无疑源于梅里韦瑟，他虽然为人谦逊有礼，但在交易、高尔夫、台球、赛马以及其他任何他涉足的领域，都展现出极强的竞争意识。罗森菲尔德和利希是两位比较随和、性格也比较随和的合伙人，他们通常负责与银行接洽，希利布兰德也会参与其中。无论如何，合伙人都会礼貌而坚定地坚持，基金资金雄厚，无需缴纳初始保证金——而且，他们绝不会与任何持不同意见的人进行交易。美林证券同意放弃通常的保证金要求，并予以配合。高盛、摩根大通、摩根士丹利以及几乎所有其他公司也都同意了。唯一一家拒绝配合的公司——派恩韦伯——几乎没有获得长期基金的任何业务。 “如果你要和他们做生意，你就别无选择，”高盛的乔恩·科尔津回忆道，他是JM的仰慕者兼竞争对手。

And from the very start, it was Long-Term’s policy to refuse to pay the haircut or else to substantially reduce it. The policy surely flowed from Meriwether, who, for all his unassuming charm, was fiercely competitive at trading, golf, billiards, horses, and whatever else he touched. Rosenfeld and Leahy, two of the more congenial and laidback partners, were usually the ones who met with banks, though Hilibrand also got involved. In any case, the partners would insist, politely but firmly, that the fund was so well heeled that it didn’t need to post an initial margin—and, what’s more, that it wouldn’t trade with anyone that saw matters differently. Merrill Lynch agreed to waive its usual haircut requirement and go along. So did Goldman Sachs, J. P. Morgan, Morgan Stanley, and just about everyone else. One firm that balked, PaineWebber, got virtually none of Long-Term’s business. “You had no choice if you were going to do business with them,” recalled Goldman Sachs’s Jon Corzine, J.M.’s admiring rival.

尽管长期基金的交易可能极其复杂，最终交易数量可达数千笔，但该基金的主要策略不过十几种。9其中一些策略，例如国债套利，涉及买卖实物证券。而其他策略，即衍生品交易，则不涉及实物证券。它们仅仅是长期基金与银行和其他交易对手进行的押注，其结果取决于各种市场价格的走势。

Although Long-Term’s trades could be insanely complex and ultimately numbered in the thousands, the fund had no more than a dozen or so major strategies.9 Some, such as the Treasury arbitrage, involved buying and selling tangible securities. The others, derivative trades, did not. They were simply bets that Long-Term made with banks and other counterparties that hinged on the fate of various market prices.

举例来说，假设一位红袜队球迷和一位洋基队球迷在赛季开始前达成协议：对方球队每得一分，双方就支付对方1000美元。长期基金的衍生品合约与之类似，只不过其收益与债券、股票等市场的波动挂钩，而非棒球比赛的好坏球。这些衍生品合约并未出现在长期基金的资产负债表上，严格意义上来说也并非“债务”。但如果市场走势不利于基金，结果显然是一样的。而且，长期基金通常无需支付衍生品交易的初始保证金；它进行这些押注时完全没有投入任何初始资本。

Imagine, by illustration, that a Red Sox fan and a Yankees fan agree before the season that each will pay the other $1,000 for every run scored by his rival’s team. Long-Term’s derivative contracts were not dissimilar, except that the payoffs were tied to movements in bonds, stocks, and so forth rather than balls and strikes. These derivative obligations did not appear on Long-Term’s balance sheet, nor were they “debt” in the formal sense. But if markets moved against the fund, the result would obviously be the same. And Long-Term generally was able to forgo paying initial margin on derivative deals; it made these bets without putting up any initial capital whatsoever.

虽然并非总是如此，但长期基金通常都能在实际证券回购融资方面获得相同的条款。此外，长期基金经常说服银行向其提供比其他基金更长期限的贷款。因此，长期基金可以更有耐心。即使银行想要收回长期基金的贷款，也无法迅速做到。“他们把所有人都逼到了墙角，”一家顶级投资银行的高管指出。

Frequently, though not always, it got the same terms on repo financing of actual securities. Also, Long-Term often persuaded banks to lend to it for longer periods than the banks gave to other funds.10 Thus, Long-Term could be more patient. Even if the banks had wanted to call in Long-Term’s loans, they couldn’t have done so very quickly. “They had everyone over a barrel,” noted a senior executive at a top investment bank.

梅里韦瑟的营销策略正是在这里真正奏效。如果银行们稍加思考，就会意识到长期基金完全掌握在他们手中。但银行们并没有把这家基金看作是一家急于求成的初创企业，而是将其视为一家由杰出学者和卓越交易员组成的耀眼公司，类似于默顿构想中的新时代“金融中介”。毕竟，人们普遍认为长期基金拥有先进且几乎万无一失的技术。银行和一些媒体也想当然地认为情况确实如此。《商业周刊》热情洋溢地宣称，该基金的博士们将引领华尔街进入“计算机新时代”。该杂志在基金成立第一年的一篇封面文章中评论道：“从未有过如此多的学术人才被赋予如此巨额的资金去押注。” 11如果一个新时代即将到来，没有人想错过。长期基金就像舞会之夜的初次亮相的名媛一样光彩夺目，所有银行都想与之共舞。

This was where Meriwether’s marketing strategy really paid dividends. If the banks had given it a moment’s thought, they would have realized that Long-Term was at their mercy. But the banks saw the fund not as a credit-hungry start-up but as a luminous firm of celebrated scholars and brilliant traders, something like that New Age “financial intermediary” conjured up by Merton. After all, it was generally believed that Long-Term had the benefit of superior, virtually fail-safe technology. And banks, like some of the press, casually assumed that it was so. Business Week gushed that the fund’s Ph.D.s would give rise to “a new computer age” on Wall Street. “Never has this much academic talent been given this much money to bet with,” the magazine observed in a cover story published during the fund’s first year.11 If a new age was coming, no one wanted to miss it. Long-Term was as fetching as a debutante on prom night, and all the banks wanted to dance.

银行毫不费力地为其宽松的信贷条款辩解。毕竟，银行持有抵押品，而且长期公司通常在每个交易日结束时以现金结算，收取盈利的款项，支付亏损的款项。长期公司资金充裕，因此其倒闭的风险似乎很小。只有当长期公司遭遇难以想象的突发性亏损时——例如，被迫一次性将大部分资产抛售到流动性不足的市场——银行家的抵押品价值才会受到威胁，银行自身才会面临损失。

The banks had no trouble rationalizing their easy credit terms. The banks did hold collateral, after all, and Long-Term generally settled up (in cash) at the end of each trading day, collecting on winners and paying on losers. And Long-Term was flush, so the risk of its failing seemed slight. Only if Long-Term lost money with unthinkable suddenness—only if, say, it was forced to dump the majority of its assets all at once and into an illiquid market—would the value of the bankers’ collateral be threatened and would the banks themselves be exposed to losses.

此外，许多银行高管，例如科尔津和美林证券的塔利，都对梅里韦瑟本人颇有好感，这使得他们的机构倾向于支持长期交易公司。但长期交易公司真正的卖点在于它与世界各地其他实力雄厚的交易员的联系。与长期交易公司合作的公司可以获得宝贵的内幕消息——这在债券市场完全合法——了解市场走向。“如何吸引人们来参加你的派对？你告诉他们，城里所有厉害人物都会来，”一位在苏黎世为长期交易公司提供融资的银行家说道，他承诺零折扣。“所以每个人都说，‘好吧，我来，但如果其他人被折扣，我也得被折扣。’”长期交易公司的做法尤其高明。合伙人可以对每家新合作的银行说，“如果我们让你们被折扣，我们就必须让所有人被折扣。”所以最终他们没有让任何人被折扣。（在少数风险较高的交易中，他们确实同意让步——但折扣幅度非常小。）

Also, many of the banks’ heads, such as Corzine and Merrill Lynch’s Tully, liked Meriwether personally, which tilted their organizations in Long-Term’s favor. But Long-Term’s real selling point was its connections to other powerful traders around the world. A firm that did business with Long-Term might gain valuable inside knowledge—totally legal in the bond world—about the flow of markets. “How do you get people to come to your party? You tell them that every cool person in town is coming,” said a banker in Zurich who financed Long-Term with a zero percent haircut. “So everyone said, ‘OK, I’ll do it, but if anyone else gets a haircut, I get one too.’ ” This was especially clever of Long-Term. The partners could say to each new bank, “If we give you a haircut, we have to give it to everyone.” So they ended up giving it to nobody. (On a small number of riskier trades they did agree to haircuts—but very skimpy ones.)

由于银行也在进行套利交易，梅里韦瑟将它们视为自己的主要竞争对手，这种看法并非毫无道理。12长期基金与索罗斯的量子基金等其他对冲基金的相似之处，远不及它与高盛等银行自营交易部门的相似之处。华尔街正逐渐从研究和客户服务转向利润丰厚的自营交易业务，这加剧了长期基金与其贷款方之间谨慎的竞争关系。

Since the banks, too, were doing arbitrage trading, Meriwether viewed them, not unjustly, as his main competitors.12 Long-Term resembled other hedge funds such as Soros’s Quantum Fund less than it did the proprietary desks of its banks, such as Goldman Sachs.
