The Street was slowly shifting from research and client services to the lucrative business of trading for its own account, fostering a wary rivalry between Long-Term and its lenders.

曾在华尔街一家大型银行工作过的JM觉得投资银行内部漏洞百出，根本无法信任，他们随时可能窃取他的交易策略。事实上，大多数投资银行都采用类似的策略。因此，为了防范风险，“长期策略”会为每笔交易的每个部分分别向不同的经纪商下单。摩根会看到一部分，美林会看到一部分，高盛会看到另一部分，但没有人能看到全部。就连“长期策略”的律师也被蒙在鼓里；他只能听到合伙人谈论“交易策略三”，仿佛“长期策略”正在研发核武库似的。

Having worked at a major Wall Street bank, J.M. felt that investment banks were rife with leaks and couldn’t be trusted not to swipe his trades for themselves. Indeed, most of them were plying similar strategies. Thus, as a precaution, Long-Term would place orders for each leg of a trade with a different broker. Morgan would see one leg, Merrill Lynch another, and Goldman yet another, but nobody would see them all. Even Long-Term’s lawyer was kept in the dark; he would hear the partners speak about “trading strategy three,” as though Long-Term were developing a nuclear arsenal.

希利布兰德尤其拒绝让银行窥探他的策略，也不愿在条款上与他们妥协。他会给交易员打个电话，买入1亿美元的债券，几秒钟后就挂断电话。 13 他直截了当地告诉美林证券：“我只关心保证金要求，我不会支付任何保证金。” 美林证券的销售员凯文·邓利维有时一天要给希利布兰德打两三次电话，试图推销他为这位精明的希利布兰德量身打造的策略。但希利布兰德的极度保密让邓利维屡屡受挫，几乎无法为他提供服务。“你几乎不可能把你的想法应用到长期资本管理公司的策略中，”邓利维说道，他是一位不拘小节的纽约人，留着寸头。“不听取华尔街的意见非常不寻常。拉里从不谈论策略。他只会告诉你他想做什么。”

Hilibrand, especially, refused to give the banks a peek at his strategies or to meet them halfway on terms. He would call a dealer, purchase $100 million in bonds, and be off the phone in seconds.13 “I’m just concerned about margin requirement, and I’m not putting up any margin,” he bluntly told Merrill Lynch. Kevin Dunleavy, a Merrill Lynch salesman, sometimes called Hilibrand two or three times a day, trying to pitch strategies he had devised with the clever Hilibrand in mind. But Dunleavy was repeatedly frustrated by Hilibrand’s obsessive secrecy, which made it nearly impossible to service the account. “Rarely could you take your ideas and implement them into LTCM’s strategy,” noted Dunleavy, an unaffected New Yorker with a military brush cut. “It was very unusual, not to take input from the Street. Larry would never talk about the strategy. He would just tell you what he wanted to do.”

该基金将业务分散开来，为每家银行选择特定的服务，并与所有银行保持距离。为了避免过度依赖任何一家银行，长期基金与高盛交易垃圾债券，与摩根大通交易政府债券和日元互换，与雷曼兄弟交易抵押贷款。美林是该基金在衍生品交易中最大的交易对手，但在回购贷款方面则远远落后。诚然，这种分而治之的策略不无道理，因为长期基金选择与拥有最专业技术的银行进行每项交易。但长期基金也因此错失了建立更紧密、更长期合作关系的机会。例如，摩根大通对长期基金非常感兴趣，渴望与其建立更紧密的合作关系，但却无法克服该基金不愿分享机密信息的障碍。“在不了解他们的需求的情况下，你怎么能向他们提出建议呢？”华尔街一家大型公司的风险管理主管疑惑道。作为套利者，合伙人倾向于将每一次交易都视为一次独立的交易，可以量化其得失。每段关系都是一次“交易”——如果其他人出价更高，交易可以重新协商或取消。合伙人之间唯一的紧密联系仅限于长期合作组织内部，这与他们在所罗门兄弟公司所珍视的团队内部的安排如出一辙。

The fund parceled out its business, choosing each bank for particular services and keeping a distance from all of them. Chary of becoming dependent on any one bank, Long-Term traded junk bonds with Goldman Sachs, government bonds and yen swaps with J. P. Morgan, mortgages with Lehman Brothers. Merrill Lynch was the fund’s biggest counterparty in derivatives, but it was far down the list in repo loans. To be sure, there was something shrewd about this divide-and-conquer strategy, for Long-Term did each set of trades with the bank that boasted the most specific expertise. But Long-Term thus forfeited the benefits of a closer, ongoing relationship. J. P. Morgan, for one, was extremely curious about Long-Term and eager to develop a closer working alliance, but it couldn’t get past the fund’s unwillingness to share confidences. “How can you propose ideas to them without knowing what their appetite is?” wondered the head of risk management at a major Wall Street firm. As arbitrageurs, the partners tended to see every encounter as a discrete exchange, with tallyable pluses and minuses. Every relationship was a “trade”—renegotiable or revocable if someone else had a better price. The partners’ only close ties were within Long-Term, mimicking the arrangement within their beloved group at Salomon.

他们是那种典型的精英——博学、内向、疏离、自律。试图让他们彼此对抗根本行不通；他们太合拍了。瑞士银行集团债券和货币部门主管安德鲁·西西里亚诺对他们之间不可思议的亲密关系感到震惊。有一次，西西里亚诺给伦敦办事处负责人维克多·哈加尼打了个电话，一两个月后又在格林威治和JM以及埃里克·罗森菲尔德联系了他们。这两位美国合伙人配合得天衣无缝；西西里亚诺有一种奇特的感觉，仿佛他仍在继续之前和哈加尼的对话。

They were a bred type—intellectual, introverted, detached, controlled. It didn’t work to try to play one off against the other; they were too much on the same wavelength. Andrew Siciliano, who ran the bond and currency departments at Swiss Bank Corporation, was stunned by their uncanny closeness. One time, Siciliano called Victor Haghani, the head of the London office, and followed up in Greenwich with J.M. and Eric Rosenfeld a month or two later. The American-based partners didn’t miss a beat; Siciliano had the eerie feeling that he was continuing the same conversation he’d had with Haghani.

并非公司内部没有矛盾。一小群人——JM、希利布兰德、罗森菲尔德和哈加尼——主导着其他合伙人。和所罗门兄弟公司一样，薪酬分配极度向高层倾斜，核心圈子攫取了超过一半的收益。这个圈子还掌握着投票权。像迈伦·斯科尔斯这样的低级别合伙人，总是想方设法争取更多的金钱和权力。但核心圈子已经合作多年；就像一个家族一样，他们之间排他性的、根深蒂固的联盟已经成为一种本能。

Not that there weren’t tensions within the firm. A small group—J.M., Hilibrand, Rosenfeld, and Haghani—dominated the rest. As at Salomon, compensation was skewed toward the top, with the inner circle garnering more than half the rewards. This group also had voting control. Lesser partners such as Myron Scholes were forever angling for more money, as well as more authority. But the inner circle had been together for years; as in a family, their exclusive and inbred alliance had became second nature.

如果要把这家公司浓缩成一个人，那非希利布兰德莫属。资深交易员往往愤世嫉俗、缺乏安全感，这是多年错误判断和侥幸脱险的结果，而希利布兰德却冷静沉着，自信得令人恼火。他工作极其努力，是纯粹的套利者；他笃信模型，坚持自己的定价策略，从不怀疑。罗森菲尔德厌恶按理论通过抛售下跌资产来进行对冲；而希利布兰德却信奉并遵循既定模式。希利布兰德的同事们对他无比敬重；每当需要快速解读市场时，他们都会自然而然地向他请教。他口才极佳，但他的回答却像未经提炼的水晶，新手难以理解。“拉里的思维能折射光线，”所罗门兄弟公司的德里克·莫恩曾这样评价他。与其他合伙人一样，希利布兰德看待问题非黑即白，甚至有过之而无不及。他为人诚实可靠，对任何他认为的不当行为都义愤填膺，但对自身狭隘圈子之外的事情却漠不关心。他的所罗门同事们常开玩笑说，按照自由主义者希利布兰德的说法，如果自家门前的街道有个坑，就应该自己动手铺好。但金钱对他来说可能比对他们任何人都重要。他真正的热情在于交易带来的智力挑战。除了家人，他对其他事物几乎不感兴趣。如果说有人能让希利布兰德稍微敞开心扉，那一定是JM。希利布兰德对这位总裁有着孝顺的感情，这或许源于他与父亲的亲密关系。罗森菲尔德对梅里韦瑟也有着类似的敬重。

If the firm could have been distilled into a single person, it would have been Hilibrand. While veteran traders tend to be cynical and insecure, the result of years of wrong guesses and narrow escapes, Hilibrand was cool and maddeningly self-confident. An incredibly hard worker, he was the pure arbitrageur; he believed in the models, stuck to his prices, was untroubled by doubt. Rosenfeld hated to hedge by selling a falling asset, as theory prescribed; Hilibrand believed and simply followed the form. Hilibrand’s colleagues respected him immensely; inevitably, they turned to him when they needed a quick read. He was highly articulate, but his answers were like unrefined crystals, difficult for novices to comprehend. “You could refract the light with Larry’s mind,” said Deryck Maughan of Salomon Brothers. Like the other partners, but to a greater degree, Hilibrand saw every issue in black and white. He was trustworthy and quick to take offense at perceived wrongdoing but blind to concerns outside his narrow sphere. His Salomon colleagues used to joke that, according to the libertarian Hilibrand, if the street in front of your home had a pothole you ought to pave it yourself. But money probably meant less to him than to any of them. He found his passion in the intellectual challenge of trading. Aside from his family, he showed interest in little else. If anyone brought Hilibrand out of himself a bit, it was J.M. Hilibrand had a filial attachment to the chief, perhaps stemming from his close relationship to his own father. Rosenfeld had a similar devotion to Meriwether.

外人很难解释JM对乐队的掌控力。他不像个明星，性格腼腆，不喜抛头露面。他说话断断续续，似乎不太习惯与人进行眼神交流。 14他拒绝谈论自己的私生活，即使是对亲密的朋友也不例外。组建Long-Term乐队后，JM和妻子搬离曼哈顿，住进了位于威彻斯特郡北塞勒姆的一处价值270万美元、占地68英亩的庄园——庄园里甚至还有一个15000平方英尺的室内恒温骑马场，专供Mimi使用。 15庄园位于一条私人车道的尽头，距离主干道四分之三英里，这条车道与他们唯一的邻居——娱乐明星大卫·莱特曼共用。为了进一步确保私密性，梅里韦瑟夫妇对房屋进行了大规模的改造，用石头加固了房屋。JM喜欢掌控自己的私生活，仿佛也是为了保护它免受不必要的动荡。

Outsiders couldn’t quite explain J.M.’s hold on the group. He was an unlikely star, too bashful for the limelight. He spoke in fragments and seemed uncomfortable making eye contact.14 He refused to talk about his personal life, even to close friends. After organizing Long-Term, J.M. and his wife moved out of Manhattan, to a $2.7 million, sixty-eight-acre estate in North Salem, in Westchester County—complete with a 15,000-square-foot heated indoor riding ring for Mimi.15 The estate was set back three quarters of a mile on a private drive that the Meriwethers shared with their only neighbor, the entertainer David Letterman. As if to make the property even more private, the Meriwethers did extensive remodeling, fortifying the house with stone. J.M. liked to control his private life, as if to shelter it, too, from unwanted volatility.

尽管他经常去家附近的教堂做礼拜，也多次参拜天主教圣地，但JM从不谈及自己的信仰。他极强的自制力令人叹服。他也从不在交易员面前敞开心扉。在公司会议上，他大多保持沉默。他欢迎合伙人之间坦诚的讨论，但他通常只在最后才发言，或者干脆保持沉默。

Though he attended a church near home and made several visits to Catholic shrines, J.M. didn’t speak about his faith, either. His self-control was implacable. Nor did he open up among his traders. At firm meetings he was mostly quiet. He welcomed frank debates among the partners, but he usually chimed in only at the very end or not at all.

公司总部位于一栋四层玻璃幕墙办公楼的一楼，这条街从富裕的格林威治中心商铺林立的街道一直延伸到长岛海峡沿岸一排维多利亚式住宅。长期投资公司不断壮大的交易员和策略师队伍中有几十人聚集在交易大厅，合伙人和非合伙人肩并肩地围坐在摆满电脑和市场屏幕的时尚半圆形办公桌旁。办公室里有一个由前租户建造的精致厨房，但合伙人们都在办公桌上吃午饭。对他们来说，食物并不重要。

The firm’s headquarters were the ground floor of a glassy four-story office complex, on a street that ran from the shop-lined center of affluent Greenwich past a parade of Victorian homes on Long Island Sound. Several dozen of Long-Term’s growing cadre of traders and strategists worked on the trading floor, where partners and non-partners sat elbow to elbow, cramped around a sleek, semicircular desk loaded with computers and market screens. The office had an elaborate kitchen that had been put in by a previous tenant, but the partners lunched at their desks. Food meant little to them.

JM、默顿和斯科尔斯（后两位是因为他们不参与交易）都有自己的私人办公室，但JM通常都在交易大厅里。交易大厅是一间红木镶板的房间，透过落地窗可以看到波光粼粼的水面，那里常常点缀着帆船。除了衣着考究的穆林斯之外，其他合伙人都穿着休闲，帆船鞋配卡其裤。房间里充斥着交易员的交谈声，但这种交谈声井然有序，不像纽约那些空旷的交易大厅里那样混乱。只有偶尔，合伙人们才会重拾旧业，玩上几局吹牛扑克。

J.M., Merton, and Scholes (the latter two because they didn’t trade) had private offices, but J.M. was usually on the trading floor, a mahogany-paneled room that looked out through a full-length picture window to the water, resplendent and often speckled with sailboats. Aside from the natty Mullins, the partners dressed casually, in Top-Siders and chinos. The room hummed with trader talk, but it was a controlled hum, not like the chaos on the cavernous New York trading floors. Only occasionally did the partners revert to their past life for a few rounds of liar’s poker.

除了仅限合伙人参加的周二风险会议外，长期投资部每周三上午还会举办面向助理的交易研究研讨会，周四下午通常还会召开另一次会议，由合伙人重点讨论某项具体交易。默顿通常在剑桥，会通过电话参与。近距离的办公环境培养了公司内部的凝聚力，但助理甚至一些合伙人都明白，他们永远无法真正融入核心圈子。一位初级交易员始终担心自己的交易会被媒体曝光，他害怕这会让他丢掉工作。格林威治的助理，甚至资深交易员，都被蒙在鼓里，以至于有些人不得不打电话给伦敦的同事，打听公司正在买卖什么。助理从不被邀请到合伙人家中——似乎有一条不成文的规定，禁止合伙人和员工私下交往。莱希曾是大学冰球运动员，他会和员工们进行一些办公室里的闲聊，但大多数合伙人对待员工都冷淡而正式。他们彬彬有礼，但只关心彼此和自己的工作。分析师、法律和会计人员是二等公民，被安排到后面的一个房间里，那里放着台球桌。

Besides the Tuesday risk meetings, which were for partners only, Long-Term had research seminars on Wednesday mornings that were open to associates and usually another meeting on Thursday afternoons, when partners would focus on a specific trade. Merton, usually in Cambridge, would join in by telephone. The shared close quarters fostered a firm togetherness, but the associates and even some of the partners knew they could never be part of the inner circle. One junior trader perpetually worried that his trades would be found out by the press, which he feared could cost him his job. Associates in Greenwich, even senior traders, were kept so much in the dark that some resorted to calling their London counterparts to find out what the firm was buying and selling. Associates were never invited back to the partners’ homes—there seemed to be an unwritten rule against partners and staff fraternizing. Leahy, a college hockey player, exchanged the normal office banter with the employees, but most of the partners treated the staff with cool formality. They were polite but interested only in one another and their work. The analysts and legal and accounting staffs were second-class citizens, shunted to a room in the back, where the pool table was.

和华尔街的其他人一样，Long-Term的员工收入颇丰。顶尖员工年收入可达100万至200万美元。公司暗中施压，鼓励员工将奖金投资于基金，但大多数人还是乐于这样做——讽刺的是，这被视为在Long-Term工作的一项重要福利。因此，员工们自信地将大部分收入再投资于基金。

Like everyone else on Wall Street, Long-Term’s employees made good money. The top staffers could make $1 million to $2 million a year. There was subtle pressure on the staff to invest their bonuses in the fund, but most of them were eager to do so anyway—ironically, it was considered a major perk of working at Long-Term. And so, the staff confidently reinvested most of their pay.

正如预期的那样，长期资本管理公司（Long-Term）的活跃债券和非活跃债券迅速反弹。长期资本管理公司神奇地赚了1500万美元——之所以说神奇，是因为它没有动用任何资本。正如斯科尔斯所承诺的那样，长期资本管理公司以5美分的价格购入，并利用杠杆将其增值。诚然，许多其他公司也做过类似的交易。“但我们的融资能力更强，”长期资本管理公司的一名员工指出。“长期资本管理公司实际上是一家融资公司。”

Just as predicted, Long-Term’s on-the-run and off-the-run bonds snapped back quickly. Long-Term made a magical $15 million—magical because it hadn’t used any capital. As Scholes had promised, Long-Term had scooped up a nickel and, with leverage, turned it into more. True, many other firms had done the same kind of trade. “But we could finance better,” an employee of Long-Term noted. “LTCM was really a financing house.”

长期基金宁愿稳赚五分钱，也不愿冒险追求不确定的利润，因为它可以像大型杂货店一样利用微薄的利润，不断积累，最终实现数千倍的收益。当然，即使是五分钱的赌注也并非绝对稳赚不赔。正如基金经理斯坦哈特最近所体会到的，杠杆投资的代价是，一旦出错，损失将成倍增加。但在1994年，长期基金几乎从未失手。事实上，它经手的几乎每一笔交易都赚得盆满钵满。

Long-Term preferred to reap a sure nickel than to gamble on making an uncertain dollar, because it could leverage its tiny margins like a high-volume grocer, sucking up nickel after nickel and multiplying the process thousands of times. Of course, not even a nickel bet was absolutely sure. And as Steinhardt, the fund manager, had recently been reminded, the penalty for being wrong is infinitely greater when you are leveraged. But in 1994, Long-Term was almost never wrong. In fact, nearly every trade it touched turned to gold.

Long-Term 将其最稳妥的投资策略称为“趋同交易”，因为这些工具会在特定日期到期，这意味着趋同似乎是必然的。其他一些交易则被称为“相对价值交易”，这类交易预期会趋同，但并不能保证。16

Long-Term dubbed its safest bets convergence trades, because the instruments matured at a specific date, meaning that convergence appeared to be a sure thing. Others were known as relative value trades, in which convergence was expected but not guaranteed.16

1994年的债券市场动荡为住房抵押贷款证券的大规模相对价值交易埋下了伏笔。抵押贷款证券是以抵押贷款组合的现金流为支撑的纸质债券。听起来枯燥乏味，但实际上并非如此。任何时候，未偿还的抵押贷款证券总额都高达约1万亿美元。它们之所以引人注目，是因为精明的投资银行家们将房主的还款分成了两个不同的资金池：一个用于支付利息，另一个用于支付本金。仔细想想——《长期》杂志也确实深入思考过——每个资金池的价值（相对于另一个资金池）会根据房主提前还款的速度而变化。如果你进行抵押贷款再融资，你就会一次性还清所有贷款——也就是一次性支付巨额本金。因此，不会再有现金流入只付息资金池。但如果你按原计划继续每月还款，你将持续支付长达30年的利息。因此，如果更多的人进行再融资，只付息证券（也称为“IO”）的价格将会下跌；如果提前还款的人减少，这些债券的价格就会上涨。对于仅偿还本金的证券（PO）来说，情况则相反。由于再融资率变化迅速，押注于本金证券或仅偿还本金的证券可能会让你大赚一笔，也可能让你损失惨重。

The bond market turmoil of 1994 seeded the ground for a huge relative value trade in home mortgage securities. Mortgage securities are pieces of paper backed by the cash flow on pools of mortgages. They sound boring, but they aren’t. Some $1 trillion of mortgage securities is outstanding at any given time. What makes them exciting is that clever investment bankers have separated the payments made by homeowners into two distinct pools: one for interest payments, the other for principal payments. If you think about it—and Long-Term did, quite a bit—the value of each pool (relative to the other) varies according to the rate at which homeowners pay off their loans ahead of schedule. If you refinance your mortgage, you pay it off in one lump sum—that is, in one giant payment of principal. Therefore, no further cash goes to the interest-only pool. But if you stand pat and keep writing those monthly checks, you keep making interest payments for up to thirty years. Therefore, if more people refinance, the interest-only securities, known as “IOs,” will fall; if fewer people prepay, they will rise. The converse is true for principal-only securities, or POs. And since the rate of refinancings can change quickly, betting on IOs or POs can make or lose you a good deal of money.

1993年，当Long-Term公司筹集资金时，美国正经历着一股再融资热潮。自越南战争以来，抵押贷款利率首次跌破7%，那些从未认真考虑过抵押贷款的婴儿潮一代突然欣喜若狂，因为每月可以节省数百美元的还款。获得最低利率成为了一种荣耀；大约五分之二的美国人在那一年进行了再融资——事实上，有些人甚至进行了两次。自然而然，利率暴跌。实际上，跌得太厉害了。除非你认为全国人民明天都会进行再融资，否则利率暴跌的价格简直低得离谱。事实上，梅里韦瑟、希利布兰德、罗森菲尔德、哈加尼和霍金斯等人都大量购买利率暴跌的债券作为个人投资。

In 1993, when Long-Term was raising capital, America was experiencing a surge of refinancings. With mortgage rates dropping below 7 percent for the first time since the Vietnam War, baby boomers who had never given their mortgages a second thought were suddenly delirious with the prospect of cutting their payments by hundreds of dollars a month. Getting the lowest rate became a point of pride; roughly two in five Americans refinanced in that one year—in fact, some folks did it twice. Naturally, the prices of IOs plummeted. Actually, they fell too much. Unless you assumed that the entire country was going to refinance tomorrow, the price of IOs was simply too low. Indeed, Meriwether, Hilibrand, Rosenfeld, Haghani, and Hawkins bought buckets of IOs for their personal accounts.

1994年，当Long-Term公司开始交易时，由于担心会出现新一轮的再融资浪潮，IO债券的价格仍然很低。比尔·克拉斯克设计了一个预测提前还款的模型，而霍金斯——一位性格外向、一头卷发、颇具乡土魅力的抵押贷款交易员——不断地将模型与实际提前还款记录进行比对。IO债券的价格似乎严重失衡，以至于霍金斯不禁怀疑：“是模型出了问题，还是这本身就是一个绝佳的投资机会？” 做事严谨的克拉斯克仔细地调整了模型，结果几乎是发出了“买入！”的信号。于是，Long-Term公司再次利用巨额杠杆，开始大量买入IO债券。该公司最终获得了巨额股份，估计价值20亿美元。

In 1994, as Long-Term was beginning to trade, IOs remained cheap for fear there would be another wave of refinancings. Bill Krasker had designed a model to predict prepayments, and Hawkins—an outgoing, curly-haired mortgage trader with backwoods charm—continually checked the model against the record of actual prepayments. The IO price seemed so out of whack that Hawkins wondered, “Is there something wrong with the model, or is this just a good opportunity?” The methodical Krasker carefully retooled the model, and it all but screamed, “Buy!” So Long-Term—once again with massive leverage—started buying IOs by the truckload. It acquired a huge stake, estimated at $2 billion worth.

如今，利率上升时，人们根本不会考虑再融资。但利率下降时，他们就会蜂拥而至，寻找抵押贷款经纪人。这意味着利率的涨跌与利率同步——因此，押注利率就如同押注利率。但合伙人并不想预测利率；这种赤裸裸的投机行为让他们感到不安，尽管他们偶尔也会这样做。由于利率受诸多因素影响，因此本质上是无法预测的。合伙人的强项在于进行高度具体的相对押注，而这些押注并不依赖于广泛的未知因素。

Now, when interest rates rise, people aren’t even going to think about refinancing. But when rates fall, they run to the mortgage broker. That means that IOs rise and fall in sync with interest rates—so betting on IOs is like betting on interest rates. But the partners didn’t want to forecast rates; such outright speculation made them jittery, even though they did it on occasion. Because interest rates depend on so many variables, they are essentially unpredictable. The partners’ forte was making highly specific relative bets that did not depend on broad unknowns.

简而言之，合伙人只是觉得，鉴于目前的利率水平，不息债券价格低廉。因此，他们巧妙地通过购买国债来对冲风险，因为国债的价格走势与利率走势相反。最终结果是消除了利率预测的任何因素。合伙人擅长识别特定的定价错误风险，并对冲所有其他风险。如果海法橙相对于富士苹果价格低廉，他们会找到一系列交易来隔离这种特定的套利机会；他们不会简单地买入所有橙子，卖出所有苹果。

In short, the partners merely felt that, given the present level of interest rates, IOs were cheap. So the partners shrewdly hedged their bet by purchasing Treasurys, the prices of which move in the opposite direction from interest rates. The net effect was to remove any element of rate forecasting. The partners excelled at identifying particular mispriced risks and hedging out all of the other risks. If Haifa oranges were cheap relative to Fuji apples, they would find a series of trades to isolate that particular arbitrage; they didn’t simply buy every orange and sell every apple.

春季利率飙升时，长期投资公司的不计息债券也随之飙升，尽管其持有的国债价格自然下跌。因此，该公司在一项交易中获利，而在另一项交易中则亏损。随后，到了1995年，利率回落，长期投资公司的国债价格上涨。但这一次，人们并没有急于进行再融资，因此长期投资公司的不计息债券保住了大部分之前的涨幅。想必，那些在1993年获得新抵押贷款的人并不急于再次办理。长期投资公司从中获利数亿美元。它的开局可谓火爆。

In the spring, when interest rates soared, Long-Term’s IOs also soared, although its Treasury bonds, of course, fell. Thus, it was ahead on one leg of its trade and behind on the other. Then, in 1995, when interest rates receded, Long-Term’s Treasurys rose in price. But this time people did not rush to refinance, so Long-Term’s IOs held on to much of their former gains. Presumably, people who had gotten new mortgages in 1993 were not so eager to do it again. Long-Term made several hundred million dollars. It was off to a sizzling start.

尽管表面看来如此，但找到这些“零钱”绝非易事。长期投资者一直在寻找交易组合——通常是多个组合——这些组合既要足够“平衡”以确保安全，又要在某些特定方面存在不平衡，从而蕴藏盈利潜力。换句话说，在任何策略中，长期投资者通常只希望接触一到两个风险因素——不多不少。一个常见的例子是收益率曲线交易——在特定国家，特定期限的债务利率可能出现异常偏差。例如，中期利率可能远高于短期利率，几乎与长期利率持平。长期投资者会精心设计一系列套利机会，押注这种利率偏差最终会消失。

Despite appearances, finding these “nickels” was anything but easy. Long-Term was searching for pairs of trades—or often, multiple pairs—that were “balanced” enough to be safe but unbalanced in one or two very particular aspects, so as to offer a potential for profit. Put differently, in any given strategy, Long-Term typically wanted exposure to one or two risk factors—but no more. In a common example—yield-curve trades—interest rates in a given country might be oddly out of line for a certain duration of debt. For instance, medium-term rates might be far higher than short-term rates and almost as high as long-term rates. Long-Term would concoct a series of arbitrages betting on this bulge to disappear.

寻找此类复杂交易的最佳场所是国际债券市场。欧洲以及第三世界国家的市场效率远低于美国市场；它们尚未被那些掌握计算机技术的套利者（或教授）榨干。对于长期投资公司而言，这些尚未开发的市场是充满机遇的理想之地。1994年，当美国债券市场的动荡蔓延至大西洋彼岸时，德国、法国和英国政府债券及其期货之间的利差扩大到了荒谬的程度。长期投资公司迅速入场并获利颇丰。 17该公司还进军了拉丁美洲市场，那里的利差也同样扩大。 18虽然仓位不大，但长期投资公司却在各个方面都积极布局——毕竟，街头巷尾可没有免费的午餐。然后，埃里克·罗森菲尔德在日本找到了一些“机会”，通过对日本股票的认股权证进行套利，对东京指数的期权进行套利——这是长期投资公司首次涉足股票领域。

The best place to look for such complex trades was in international bond markets. Markets in Europe, as well as in the Third World, were less efficient than America’s; they had yet to be picked clean by computer-wielding arbitrageurs (or professors). For Long-Term, these underexploited markets were a happy hunting ground with a welter of opportunities. In 1994, when the trouble in the U.S. bond market rippled across the Atlantic, the spreads between German, French, and British government debt and, respectively, the futures on each country’s bonds, widened to nonsensical levels. Long-Term plunged in and made a fast profit.17 It also sallied into Latin America, where spreads had widened as well.18 The positions were small, but Long-Term was pursuing every angle—you don’t find nickels lying on the street. Then, Eric Rosenfeld found a few “coins” in Japan, arbitraging warrants on Japanese stocks against options on the Tokyo index—one of Long-Term’s first excursions into equities.

到了20世纪90年代中期，欧洲已成为国际债券交易员的乐园，他们正热烈讨论货币联盟的前景。法国、德国、意大利和其他一些历史悠久的民族国家是否会真正合并货币，放弃法郎、马克和里拉，转而使用新发行的欧元，这一前景——尽管仍存在诸多疑问——令市场日益动荡不安。每位交易员的看法都各不相同——而这正是长期投资公司蓬勃发展的契机。许多投资银行押注意大利和西班牙等经济实力较弱的国家发行的债券将相对于德国债券走强，其理论依据是，如果货币联盟最终形成，将迫使整个欧洲的利率趋于一致。长期投资公司也参与了一些此类交易，但与往常一样，其合伙人不愿在宏观经济理论上投入过多资金。长期投资公司的专长在于细节。在预测地缘政治趋势方面，它并没有任何明显的优势。此外，其主要由美国人组成的合伙人都是欧洲怀疑论者。由于欧洲高度管制的经济长期落后于美国，整个欧洲大陆似乎僵化得令人绝望。瑞士合伙人汉斯·胡夫施密德试图推动经济趋同，但包括行事自由奔放的伦敦负责人维克多·哈加尼在内的美国合伙人却持反对意见。

By the mid-1990s, Europe had become a playground for international bond traders, who were hotly debating the outlook for monetary union. Its markets were increasingly unsettled by the prospect—still much in doubt—that France, Germany, Italy, and other age-old nation-states would really merge their currencies, abandoning their francs, marks, and lire for freshly minted euros. Every trader had a different view—just the sort of uncertain climate in which Long-Term thrived. Many investment banks were betting that bonds issued by the weaker countries, such as Italy and Spain, would strengthen relative to those of Germany, on the theory that if union did come about, it would force a convergence of interest rates all across Europe. Long-Term did some of these trades, but as usual, the partners were reluctant to risk too much on a broad economic theory. Long-Term’s expertise was in the details. When it came to forecasting geopolitical trends, it did not have any apparent edge. What’s more, the mostly American partners were Euro-skeptics. With Europe’s highly regulated economies perennially trailing America’s, the Continent seemed hopelessly rigid. A Swiss partner, Hans Hufschmid, tried to push the convergence theme, but the American partners, including Victor Haghani, the free-spirited London chief, resisted.

哈加尼更倾向于专注于单一国家的策略，因为这类策略风险较小。例如，他利用英国国债（相当于英国的国债）进行套利，其中一种由于税收政策不利而价格较低。当英国政府改变立场后，长期投资公司迅速获利2亿美元。 19

Haghani preferred to focus on strategies that were confined to single countries, where there would be fewer risk factors. For instance, he arbitraged two issues of gilts, the British equivalent of Treasurys, one of which was cheaper owing to an unfavorable tax treatment. When the U.K. government reversed its stance, Long-Term quickly made $200 million.19

哈加尼经常进行一国收益率曲线的反向交易。例如，他可能会做多德国十年期国债，同时卖出五年期国债。这种微妙的交易既需要精湛的数学知识，也需要对当地经济趋势有敏锐的洞察力。但至少，这种交易不需要将德国的经济趋势与西班牙等国的经济趋势进行比较。

Haghani frequently traded the yield curve of a country against itself. Thus, he might go long on Germany’s ten-year bonds and sell its five-year paper, a subtle trade that required command of the math along with a keen appreciation for local economic trends. But at least it did not require comparing the trends in Germany with, say, the trends in Spain.

报纸对长期投资公司的报道通常忽略了哈加尼，因为他为人极其低调。媒体大肆宣传梅里韦瑟的领导才能以及默顿和斯科尔斯的“模型”。但事实上，哈加尼才是关键人物。虽然梅里韦瑟掌管公司，罗森菲尔德负责日常运营，但哈加尼和资历稍长的希利布兰德对交易的影响力最大。他们同样才华横溢，精通数学，但他们的沟通方式却令外人难以理解。

Newspaper accounts of Long-Term generally overlooked Haghani, who was intensely private. The press played up Meriwether’s leadership and Merton’s and Scholes’s “models.” But in fact Haghani was a critical player. While J.M. presided over the firm and Rosenfeld ran it from day to day, Haghani and the slightly senior Hilibrand had the most influence on trading. Similarly brilliant and mathematically adept, they spoke in a code that outsiders found impenetrable.

尽管两人大多时候以团队形式运作，但哈格尼的胆识远胜于希利布兰德。哈格尼天生就是个交易员，他对市场有着敏锐的直觉，同时又兼具冲动和鲁莽的性格。如果模型显示某只证券定价错误，且公司认为已理解价格扭曲的原因，希利布兰德往往会立即跟进。而哈格尼则更相信自己的直觉，他可能会先赌一把，赌这只证券的定价还会进一步扭曲。长期投资公司成立时，哈格尼才31岁（希利布兰德34岁，罗森菲尔德40岁，梅里韦瑟46岁），这位皮肤黝黑、蓄着胡须的哈格尼总是孤注一掷。虽然他能言善辩，但与希利布兰德相比，他的说话方式却不那么直接：你永远无法判断哈格尼是在认真地挑战你，还是在玩弄权术。他身上有一种年轻人特有的冲动和自信，这或许源于他优渥的家庭背景。

Although the two operated mostly as a team, Haghani was far more daring. A natural trader, Haghani had an intuitive feeling for markets and a volatile, impulsive streak. If a model identified a security as mispriced and if the firm felt it understood why the distortion had occurred, Hilibrand tended to go right ahead. Haghani, who trusted his instincts, might gamble on the security’s becoming even more mispriced first. Barely thirty-one years old when Long-Term started (Hilibrand was thirty-four, Rosenfeld forty, and Meriwether forty-six), the swarthy, bearded Haghani routinely swung for the fences. Though a lively raconteur, he was less direct than Hilibrand: you could never tell if Haghani was challenging you in earnest or playing poker. He had a youthful impetuousness and belief in himself, perhaps the result of his privileged background.

哈加尼的父亲是伊朗一位富有的进出口商，母亲是美国人。他从小就敏锐地意识到，政治局势的复杂多变往往会让精心制定的商业计划功亏一篑。十几岁时，他曾与自己敬爱的父亲在伊朗生活了两年；后来，革命爆发，他们被迫逃离。在所罗门兄弟公司，哈加尼经常出入伦敦和东京的办事处，他力劝当地交易员采用套利集团的市场模式，并鼓励那些常常感到困惑的员工加大交易规模。他回到伦敦，加入长期资本管理公司，当时欧洲大陆正热议货币联盟。

The son of a wealthy Iranian importer-exporter and an American mother, Haghani grew up keenly aware of the political crosscurrents that often overwhelm the best-laid business plans. As a teenager, he had spent two years in Iran with his father, whom he adored; then the revolution had forced them to flee. At Salomon Brothers, Haghani had spent a lot of time in the London and Tokyo bureaus, where he had pushed the local traders to adopt the Arbitrage Group’s model of markets and had exhorted the often bewildered staffers to trade in bigger size. He returned to London with Long-Term Capital Management just as the Continent was bubbling with talk of monetary union.

哈格尼避开了伦敦金融城——相当于华尔街的伦敦金融城，而是在繁华的时尚区梅菲尔租了一间办公室。他以轻松随意的方式管理办公室，鼓励员工与他互动交流，畅所欲言。他的交易员和分析师工作时间很长，但长期基金不断增长的利润激励着他们，而看到老板骑着自行车来上班，更让他们感到敬畏。交易间隙，交易员们会去交易大厅旁的台球室，哈格尼会在那里向来访者发起挑战。（JM每次来伦敦，也总会拿起球杆，接受所有人的挑战。）哈格尼不像他的一些合伙人那样内向，他经常邀请交易员到他家吃饭。在长期基金第一个盈利丰厚的月份——五月，他召集了伦敦的所有员工，包括秘书，向他们讲述了公司的盈利情况。在纪律严明、行事隐秘的格林威治总部，这种做法会被视为异端邪说，因为那里盛行着严格的等级制度。

Haghani shunned the City, London’s buttoned-down equivalent of Wall Street, and rented quarters in Mayfair, a lively fashion district. He ran the office informally, encouraging the staff to join him in give-and-take and spirited banter. His traders and analysts worked long hours, but they were motivated by the lure of Long-Term’s growing profits and humbled by the sight of their boss trundling to the office on a bicycle. When the action abated, the traders would drift to a poolroom off the trading floor, where Haghani would issue challenges to visitors. (J.M., too, on his visits to London, would inevitably pick up the cue stick and take on all comers.) Less introverted than some of his partners, Haghani frequently invited traders home to dinner. After Long-Term’s first big month, in May, he assembled the entire London staff, including the secretaries, and told them how the money had been made. This would have been heresy at the stiffer and more secretive Greenwich headquarters, where a rigid caste system prevailed.

哈加尼最大的一笔交易是意大利——一个大胆的选择。意大利的金融和政治都一团糟。人们担心意大利可能违约，再加上意大利共产党仍然相当强大的影响力，导致意大利的利率比德国高出8个百分点之多——这是一个巨大的利差。意大利的债券市场仍在发展中，政府发行了大量债券，部分原因是为了吸引投资者。对于债券交易员来说，这是一片肥沃的沃土。显然，如果意大利能够重回正轨，那些押注意大利的人将会大赚一笔。但如果意大利没能做到这一点呢？

Haghani’s biggest trade was Italy—a bold choice. Italian finance was a mess, as was Italian politics. The fear that Italy might default on its loans, coupled with the still considerable strength of the Italian Communist Party, had pushed Italy’s interest rates to as much as 8 percentage points over Germany’s—a huge spread. Italy’s bond market was still evolving, and the government was issuing lots of paper, partly to attract investors. For bond traders, it was fertile territory. Obviously, if Italy righted itself, people who had bet on Italy would make out like bandits. But what if it didn’t?

意大利市场的情况更加复杂，因为意大利的税法十分特殊，而且政府债券有两种类型——一种是浮动利率，另一种是固定利率。奇怪的是，由于债券市场对其缺乏信任，意大利政府被迫支付的利率高于一种名为“互换”的广泛交易的利率衍生品的利率。互换利率通常与私营银行的利率接近。因此，债券市场认为意大利政府的风险高于私营银行。

The Italian market was further complicated because Italy had a quirky tax law and two types of government bonds—one of which paid a floating rate, the other a fixed rate. Strangely, the Italian government was forced (by an untrusting bond market) to pay an interest rate that was higher than the rate on a widely traded interest rate derivative known as “swaps.” Swap rates are generally close to private-sector bank rates. Thus, the bond market was rating the Italian government as a poorer risk than private banks.

哈加尼认为，市场严重高估了政府违约的风险——相对于其他风险而言。他一贯大胆，建议进行大规模套利，以利用这种所谓的定价错误。这是一场精心策划的赌博，因为如果意大利真的违约，长期投资公司的交易对手可能会放弃合同——而长期投资公司可能会血本无归。对于仍然对意大利持怀疑态度的美国合伙人来说，这是一个重大隐患。风险规避型的比尔·克拉斯克尤其担忧，合伙人就意大利问题进行了数小时的激烈辩论。

Haghani thought the market was seriously overstating the risk of the government’s defaulting—relative to the price it was putting on other risks. With characteristic derring-do, he recommended a kingsize arbitrage to exploit the supposed mispricing. It was a calculated gamble, because if Italy did default, Long-Term’s counterparties might walk away from their contracts—and Long-Term could lose its shirt. To the American partners, who remained skeptical about Italy, this was a major worry. The risk-averse Bill Krasker was especially concerned, and the partners heatedly debated Italy for hours.

简而言之，套利机会集中在市场对罗马的漠视上。但长期基金的运作从来都不简单。具体来说，最终胜出的哈加尼买入了意大利固定利率政府债券，并做空了意大利固定利率互换合约。他还买入了浮动利率政府债券，这对长期基金来说是一次重大胜利，因为很少有人能获得这种交易清淡的证券。哈加尼同时还建立了空头头寸来平衡这些头寸。起初，长期基金对整个头寸进行了对冲，购买了一份价格不菲的意大利违约保险（甚至还购买了第二份，以防保险公司破产）。但随着意大利头寸的扩大，长期基金无力继续购买更多保险，于是决定冒险一搏。一位内部人士判断，如果意大利破产，该基金可能会损失一半的资本。

In simple terms, the arbitrage zeroed in on the market’s utter lack of respect for Rome. But nothing at Long-Term was ever simple. Specifically, Haghani, who eventually prevailed, bought the fixed-rate Italian government bonds and shorted the fixed rate on Italian swaps. He also bought the floating-rate government paper, a coup for Long-Term because few others could get hold of this thinly traded security. Haghani balanced that with a short position, too. At first, Long-Term hedged the entire position, taking out a rather expensive Italian-default insurance policy (it even took out a second policy, in case the insurer went broke).20 But as the Italian position got bigger, Long-Term couldn’t afford to keep buying more insurance, and it simply took a chance. An insider judged that had Italy gone bust, the fund could have lost half of its capital.

这家几乎不受监管的对冲基金没有向投资者披露其在意大利的风险；事实上，除了泛泛而谈之外，它对投资者的资金投资方式和地点只字未提。JM的信件充斥着关于市场波动性的统计数据，却对公司的实际操作只字不提。他用一种冷漠疏离的语气掩饰自己的羞怯，仿佛透露任何信息都是在给投资者一个恩惠。“我们打算与各位投资者保持持续沟通，”他生硬地宣称。即使是JM偶尔透露的寥寥几条信息，他也要求投资者保密，仿佛Long-Term的天才就像一株娇嫩的林间植物，无法承受阳光的照射。合伙人们竭尽全力避免媒体曝光。他们甚至回购了《商业周刊》刊登过的照片版权，以防止照片公之于众。

The virtually unregulated hedge fund did not disclose its risk in Italy to investors; indeed, it didn’t tell them anything about how and where their money was invested, save for broad generalities. J.M.’s letters were saturated with statistics on volatilities but mute on what the firm was actually doing. He covered for his shyness by adopting an aloof, impersonal tone, as though he were doing his investors a favor by disclosing anything. “It is our intent to maintain ongoing communications with you, our investors,” he declared stiffly. Even the few dry nuggets that J.M. did disclose he asked investors to keep confidential, as if Long-Term’s genius were a tender woodland plant that couldn’t tolerate the glare of sunlight. The partners went to obsessive lengths to stay out of the press. They even repurchased the rights to photographs that had run in Business Week to keep their pictures from public view.

尽管Long-Term非常重视风险，但其管理存在一个严重缺陷。与银行由独立风险经理监督交易员不同，Long-Term的合伙人进行自我监管。虽然这使他们能够绕过大型机构的僵化体制，但也无人可以追究合伙人的责任。

For all its attention to risk, Long-Term’s management had a serious flaw. Unlike at banks, where independent risk managers watch over traders, Long-Term’s partners monitored themselves. Though this enabled them to sidestep the rigidities of a big organization, there was no one to call the partners to account.

交易员需要风险管理委员会的批准才能进行交易；然而，希利布兰德和哈加尼为了达到目的不择手段，总有办法如愿以偿。其他合伙人迟早会妥协，即便只是因为精疲力竭。梅里韦瑟对这种宽容的管理方式负有主要责任。如果说梅里韦瑟有什么致命的弱点，那就是他没有积极参与讨论。而且，也没有其他人能像在所罗门兄弟公司那样扮演“保姆”的角色——古特弗伦德不在了。交易员们只能自己监督自己。

Traders needed approval from the risk-management committee to initiate a trade; however, Hilibrand and Haghani, who would fight relentlessly for what they wanted, had a way of getting it. Sooner or later, the other partners would defer, if only out of sheer exhaustion. Meriwether was largely to blame for this tolerant regime. If J.M. had a cardinal weakness, it was his failure to insert himself into the debates. And there was no one else who could have played the role of nanny, as there had been at Salomon—no Gutfreund. The traders were their own watchdogs.

合伙人确实不遗余力地研究他们的交易，意大利交易就是一个典型的例子。哈加尼建立了一个情报网络，以增强他对意大利的了解。他聘请了阿尔贝托·乔瓦尼尼——先是担任顾问，后来转为全职——乔瓦尼尼曾任意大利财政部官员，也是哥伦比亚大学的教授。乔瓦尼尼也曾在麻省理工学院学习，他经常往返于伦敦和罗马之间，以便探望家人并与意大利官员闲聊。哈加尼仍然不满足，于是又请来了另一位麻省理工学院毕业生杰拉德·热诺特，他是比利时驻意大利大使的儿子，精通意大利语。“维克托一直对意大利很感兴趣，”一位同事说道。当然，“长期投资”公司与意大利中央银行关系密切，该银行已向该基金投资了1亿美元，并向其提供了1.5亿美元的贷款。

The partners did go to considerable lengths to research their trades, the Italian trade being a prime example. Haghani recruited a network of intelligence sources to bolster his knowledge of Italy. He hired—first as a consultant, later full-time—Alberto Giovannini, a former official in the Italian Treasury and professor at Columbia University. Giovannini, who had also studied at MIT, would shuttle back and forth between London and Rome, where he could see his family and gossip with Italian officials. Still not satisfied, Haghani brought in Gérard Gennotte, yet another MIT grad, who was the son of Belgium’s ambassador to Italy and was fluent in Italian. “Victor was always keen on Italy,” an associate noted. And of course, Long-Term was plugged in to Italy’s central bank, which had invested $100 million in the fund and lent it $150 million more.

然而，Long-Term 的方法过于数学化，以至于所有这些所谓的“智慧”都难以产生多大作用。它的模型简单地表明，相对于历史模式和预期风险而言，意大利债券“价格低廉”。合伙人假设，在其他条件不变的情况下，未来将与过去类似。因此，他们便投入其中。此外，它的模型几乎算不上秘密。“你随便翻开一本《金融杂志》，就能看到有人在运用这些模型，”一位驻伦敦的所罗门兄弟公司交易员在谈到意大利债券交易时指出，“任何大学一年级数学学过的人都能做到。” 事实上，其他公司的交易员多年来一直在进行类似的交易。在 Long-Term 开始交易时，意大利债券的价差已经开始收窄；竞争对手纷纷撤出。哈加尼从想要退出的所罗门兄弟公司获得了他最初的约十亿美元的意大利债券。所谓 Long-Term 拥有独特的“黑箱”的说法纯属无稽之谈。其他华尔街公司也纷纷来到麻省理工学院，大多数大银行都在采用类似的模型——而且，更重要的是，它们将这些模型应用于债券市场中相同的几十个利差。

However, Long-Term’s approach was so mathematical, it’s doubtful that all this intelligence made much difference. Its models said simply that Italy was “cheap” relative to historical patterns and anticipated risks. The partners assumed that, all else being equal, the future would look like the past. Therefore, in they went. Moreover, its models were hardly a secret. “You could pick up a Journal of Finance and see where someone was applying models,” a London-based trader at Salomon Brothers noted with respect to the Italy trade. “Anyone who had done first-year math at university could do it.” In truth, traders at other firms had been doing similar trades for years. By the time Long-Term started to trade, spreads in Italy had begun to narrow; rival firms were bidding arrivederci. Haghani got his first billion dollars’ worth or so of Italian bonds from Salomon, which wanted out. The common notion that Long-Term had a unique black box was a myth. Other Wall Street firms had also found their way to MIT, and most of the big banks were employing similar models—and, what’s more, were applying them to the same couple of dozen spreads in bond markets.

Long-Term的优势不在于其模型，而首先在于其解读模型的经验。合伙人从事此类交易已有多年。其次，该公司拥有更优厚的融资条件。在成立的第一年，Rosenfeld就与30家银行达成了回购融资协议，并与20家银行达成了衍生品融资协议——所有协议的条款都非常宽松。 21由于融资如此便捷，加上合伙人信心十足，Long-Term的交易规模更大，并且在其他公司纷纷退出市场后，它仍然能够持续地从中榨取利润。“我们关注的差异比其他人更小，”一位交易员说道，“我们认为我们可以进行更进一步的对冲，并进一步提高杠杆率。”

Long-Term’s edge wasn’t in its models but, first, in its experience in reading the models. The partners had been doing such trades for years. Second, the firm had better financing. During its first year, Rosenfeld sewed up repo financing with thirty banks and derivative facilities with twenty—all on liberal terms.21 With financing so accessible—and with the partners so supremely confident—Long-Term traded on a greater scale, and it kept squeezing nickels long after others had quit. “We focused on smaller discrepancies than other people,” one trader said. “We thought we could hedge further and leverage further.”

至少有一位观察人士对该基金看似轻率的债务投资方式深表怀疑。总部位于马萨诸塞州剑桥市的鲍普斯特集团（Baupost Group）是一家规模较小的对冲基金公司，其普通合伙人塞思·克拉曼（Seth Klarman）致信投资者，称有人向他提供了一份新基金的股份，该基金由前所罗门兄弟公司（Salomon Brothers）的债券交易员管理——显然是长期基金——但他拒绝了。克拉曼对华尔街一种看似鲁莽的趋势感到不安。拥有金融“蔬菜自动售货机”般强大工具的投资银行，正将金融资产切割成威力强大的新型证券——IO和PO——投资者们正以不顾一切的热情抢购这些证券。更糟糕的是，投资者们重新燃起了对杠杆的渴望。两位数的债券收益率已成为过去，投资者——尤其是那些“如雨后春笋般涌现”的新型对冲基金——开始通过借贷来提高收益。克拉曼不禁质疑，投资者怎么能如此确信市场流动性会始终充足呢？他担心投资者对“异常”事件的后果视而不见，例如历史上总是会打乱投资者精心制定的计划的突发性波动和偶尔发生的崩盘。克拉曼警告说，总的来说，“成功的投资者会做好充分准备，以避免百年一遇的灾难。但这种思维方式正日益过时。”谈到前所罗门交易员基金——即长期基金——克拉曼指出，鉴于其预期杠杆率，即使出现一个严重的错误也会对基金资本造成“重大打击”。“当然，如果同时出现两个重大错误，后果将是灾难性的。” 22

At least one observer had grave doubts about the fund’s seemingly cavalier approach to debt. Seth Klarman, the general partner of Baupost Group, a collection of smallish hedge funds based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, wrote to his investors that he had been offered a stake in a new fund run by former Salomon bond traders—obviously Long-Term—and had declined. Klarman was perturbed by a seemingly reckless trend on Wall Street. Investment banks possessed of the equivalent of financial Veg-O-Matics were slicing and dicing financial assets into potent, newfangled securities—IOs and POs—that investors were scooping up with reckless élan. What was worse, investors had rediscovered their thirst for leverage. With double-digit bond yields a thing of the past, investors—particularly the new hedge funds that were “popping up all over”—were resorting to borrowing to inflate their returns. How could investors be so certain that markets would always be liquid?, Klarman wondered. He feared that investors were turning “a blind eye to the consequences of ‘outlier’ events,” such as the sudden disturbances and occasional crashes that, historically, have always upset the best-laid plans of investors. In general, Klarman warned, “Successful investors have positioned them-selves to avoid the 100-year flood. Increasingly, that way of thinking has become passé.” Turning to the former Salomon traders’ fund—that is, to Long-Term—Klarman noted that, given its projected leverage, even a single serious mistake would put a “major dent” in the fund’s capital. “Two major errors at the same time, of course, would be catastrophic.”22

4

4

尊敬的投资者们

DEAR INVESTORS

严格来说，并没有什么风险——如果世界

In a strict sense, there wasn’t any risk—if the world

它一直像过去那样行事。

had behaved as it did in the past.

——默顿·米勒，经济学家和​

—MERTON MILLER, ECONOMIST AND

诺贝尔·拉·奥雷特





NOBEL LAUREATE





1994年， Long -Term基金成立第一年 就取得了28%的收益率。扣除支付给合伙人的费用后，投资者的账户增长了20%。在债券投资者普遍亏损的这一年，这无疑是惊人的成绩。10月份，当基金即将以亮眼的业绩收官时，梅里韦瑟提醒投资者不要指望这种情况会持续下去。他强调，Long-Term基金很可能也会经历亏损的年份：“很明显，即使只投资一年，也可能出现重大亏损。”所有优秀的基金经理都会写这样的信。如果他们了解自己的业务，他们就知道可能会遇到业绩不佳的年份。如果他们诚实，他们会告知投资者这一点，或者至少会尽量降低他们的预期。

LONG-TERM EARNED 28 percent in 1994, its first year of operation. After fees to the partners, its investors’ accounts rose by 20 percent. In a year in which the average investor in bonds had lost money, this was nothing short of phenomenal. In October, when it was clear that the fund would finish with impressive numbers, Meriwether warned his investors not to count on a repeat. Long-Term would very likely have years in which it lost money, J.M. stressed: “It is clear that significant losses can occur even over a one-year horizon.” All good money managers write such letters. If they understand their business, they know they can have bad years. If they are honest, they let their investors know it or at least try to temper their expectations.

然而，JM的信函远不止于此。在由他的两位学术明星——默顿和斯科尔斯——撰写的附件中，“长期基金”不仅承认亏损的可能性，还精确地计算了亏损发生的概率。正如扑克手册会告诉你抽到顺子的概率是8.51%一样，两位教授计算出，“长期基金”至少有12%的概率会亏损5%的资金（也就是说，每100年中会有12年发生这种情况）。信中还进一步列出了该基金至少亏损10%、15%和20%的精确概率。¹

Yet J.M.’s letter went a good deal further. In an attachment penned by his two academic stars, Merton and Scholes, Long-Term did not merely concede the possibility of loss, it calculated the supposed odds of its occurring, and to precise mathematical degrees. Just as a handbook of poker might tell you that the odds of drawing an inside straight were 8.51 percent, the professors calculated that Long-Term would lose at least 5 percent of its money 12 percent of the time (that is, in twelve of every hundred years). The letter went on to state the precise odds of the fund’s losing at least 10 percent, as well as 15 percent and 20 percent.¹

当然，“长期投资者”可以通过改变某些假设来调整赔率；因此，这封信里不仅有一列数字，而是好几列，就像《每日赛马报》的版面一样。关键在于，“长期投资者”对赔率的预测非常精准。这仿佛是教授们掌握了某种秘密知识，或者对世界有着独特的见解，因为普通投资者绝不会做出如此大胆的预测。大多数人，我们希望如此，都知道自己的股票可能会下跌，但如果被问及具体的赔率，他们很可能会困惑地眨眨眼。的确，“长期投资者”的这封信体现了一种不同的世界观。试想一下，如果你的孩子学校里有个学生出现了某种传染性强且可能很危险的疾病症状，你会期待收到警告，或许还会收到一些关于如何预防的建议。但如果收到校长的一封信，信中说你的孩子有19%的概率感染某种疾病，12%的概率至少缺课一周，还有2%的概率死亡，你肯定会觉得有点奇怪，甚至觉得这种说法过于武断。你会想更多地了解学校的医生，尤其是他擅长的医学领域。

Of course, Long-Term could jigger the odds by changing certain assumptions; thus the letter contained not just one column of numbers but multiple columns, like a page from the Daily Racing Form. The point was, Long-Term predicted the odds with precision. It was as if the professors had some secret knowledge or an altered view of the world, for no ordinary investor would hazard such forecasts. Most people, one hopes, know that their stocks can fall, but if asked to specify the odds, they would most likely blink in puzzlement. Indeed, Long-Term’s letter betrayed a different way of thinking about the world. Imagine, for a moment, that a student at your child’s school showed symptoms of a contagious and potentially dangerous disease. You would expect a warning, perhaps some advice on what precautions to take. But if a letter arrived from the principal stating that your child had a 19 percent chance of catching the sickness, a 12 percent chance of missing at least a week of school, and a 2 percent risk of fatality, you would find it a trifle odd, not to mention presumptuous. You would want to know more about the school’s doctor and, in particular, about the kind of medicine he practiced.

事实上，长期基金的信函充分体现了该基金的投资理念。信中并未提及具体的交易或投资，也无需赘述。只需知道，对于每一项投资，长期基金主要关注两个问题：预期平均收益是多少？以及在任何典型年份，实际收益与该平均值之间的波动幅度有多大？例如，掷骰子，平均点数为7，而实际点数与平均值的偏差不能超过5（不可能掷出超过12或低于2的点数）。此外，掷骰子的概率决定了，三分之二的情况下，你会掷出7或与7相差不超过2的点数。

In truth, Long-Term’s letter told a great deal about the fund’s philosophical “medicine.” It mentioned no specific trades or investments; it didn’t have to. It is enough to know that for each investment, Long-Term was chiefly concerned with two questions: What was the anticipated average return, and how much did the return in any typical year tend to vary from that average? With a pair of dice, for instance, the average roll is 7, and the variation from the average cannot be more than 5 (you can’t roll more than 12 or less than 2). What’s more, the odds in dice are such that two thirds of the time, you will roll either 7 or a number that is within two of 7.

因此，如果一个理智的投资者有机会以1赔1的赔率押注掷骰子点数落在5到9之间，他肯定会接受。当然，你不可能每次都掷出5到9，所以你也不会下注太多。但如果你可以掷一百万次骰子，直到最后结算呢？在这种情况下，你应该押注庄家全额赔付。你可能会掷出一次1点，也许第二次，甚至第三次。但在一百万次的掷骰子中，输的概率微乎其微。不妨试试。

Therefore, if a sensible investor was offered the chance to bet even money on rolling between 5 and 9, he would take it. Of course, you wouldn’t always roll between 5 and 9, so you wouldn’t, one hopes, wager too much. But what if you could make that bet on 1 million rolls and settle up only at the end? In that case, you should bet the house. You might roll snake eyes once, maybe a second time, perhaps a third. But over a million rolls, the chance of losing is infinitesimally small. Try it.

投资中概率的计算要困难得多；事实上，生活中很少有事情能如此精确地预测（好的算命先生寥寥无几）。我们可以推断，如果以每股 80 美元的价格购买 IBM 股票，盈利的概率比以每股 90 美元的价格购买要高，就像如果你的孩子有两个朋友生病，他的风险会比只有一个朋友生病时更大一样。但是，究竟高多少呢？我们掌握的信息不足以量化市场损失的风险或传染的风险。

It is much harder to calculate the odds in investing; indeed, very few aspects of life can be forecast so precisely (good fortune-tellers are scarce). We may deduce that if we buy a share of IBM at $80 we have a greater chance of making a profit than if we buy at $90, just as your child is at greater risk if two of his buddies are sick, rather than only one. But how much greater? We simply don’t have enough facts to quantify either the risk of market loss or the risk of contagion.

请注意，IBM股票（或传染病）与骰子之间存在关键区别。掷骰子有风险——毕竟，你可能会掷出1点——但不存在不确定性，因为你知道掷出7点以及其他任何点数的概率。投资则让我们同时面临风险和不确定性。IBM股票价格下跌存在风险，而下跌的可能性则存在不确定性。诸多变量——政治、经济、管理、竞争因素——都可能影响结果，这种不确定性几乎让我们难以承受。

Notice that there is a key difference between a share of IBM (or an infectious disease) and a pair of dice. With dice, there is risk—you could, after all, roll snake eyes—but there is no uncertainty, because you know (for certain) the chances of getting a 7 and every other result. Investing confronts us with both risk and uncertainty. There is a risk that the price of a share of IBM will fall, and there is uncertainty about how likely it is to do so. So many variables—political, economic, managerial, competitive factors—can affect the result that the uncertainty all but overwhelms us.

从这个角度来看，《长期投资》杂志的这封信代表着一次巨大的飞跃。尽管它坦诚地承认风险的存在，但它通过量化损失的可能性来消除不确定性。对于JM和他的交易员来说，资金管理与其说是一门需要一系列判断的“艺术”，不如说是一门可以精确量化的“科学”。信中写道：“粗略地讲，从长远来看，投资者大约每五个月中可能会有一个月损失5%或更多，每十年中可能会有一个月损失10%或更多。” 大约每五十年中只有一年会损失至少20%的投资组合——而默顿-斯科尔斯的通谕根本没有考虑损失更多的可能性。

Seen in these terms, Long-Term’s letter represented a dramatic leap. While it heartily acknowledged risk, it banished uncertainty by putting numerical odds on its likelihood of loss. To J.M. and his traders, money management was less an “art” requiring a series of judgments than it was a “science” that could be precisely quantified. “Roughly, over a long period of time,” the letter stated, “investors may experience a loss of 5% or more in about one month in five, and a loss of 10% or more in about one month in ten.” Only one year in fifty should it lose at least 20 percent of its portfolio—and the Merton-Scholes encyclical did not entertain the possibility of losing more.

这种神奇预言的秘密竟出奇地简单。正如掷骰子赌局的关键数字是点数偏离7的典型值一样，长期投资公司的关键数字是债券价格的通常波动率。通过将数万个债券价格输入其SPARC计算机，长期投资公司的交易员们掌握了历史波动率——也就是债券过去价格的波动幅度。而这个数字（基于数千个每日、每月和每年的时间间隔，并针对多种类型的债券计算得出）正是他们评估未来风险的基础。长期投资公司的新闻发言人彼得·罗森塔尔轻描淡写地解释说：“风险是波动率的函数。这些都是可以量化的。”梅里韦瑟、默顿、斯科尔斯等人对此深信不疑。

The secret of this magical foretelling was breathtakingly simple. Just as the key number in the dice bet was the typical variance from 7, the key number for Long-Term was the usual variance, or volatility, in bond prices. By plugging tens of thousands of bond prices into its SPARC computers, Long-Term’s traders knew the historic volatility—that is, how much bonds had fluctuated in the past. And that one number (calculated over thousands of daily, monthly, and yearly intervals and for numerous types of bonds) was the basis of their assessment of risk in the future. Peter Rosenthal, Long-Term’s press spokesman, glibly explained, “Risk is a function of volatility. These things are quantifiable.” Meriwether, Merton, Scholes, and company had no more earnest belief.

他们的投资组合就像一顶帽子，里面装着成千上万对数字，每对数字都代表着他们在特定交易中预期的波动性和收益。“他们时刻都在思考帽子里的数字，”曾在所罗门兄弟公司参与该团队工作的罗伯特·斯塔维斯指出。他们不仅关注单个数字对——例如投资回报率（IO）、意大利债券等等——而且还在思考这些数字对之间的相关性。抵押贷款的收益是否会与意大利债券的收益趋于一致？当一项交易上涨时，另一项交易下跌时，是否会出现这种情况？斯塔维斯说，合伙人会根据每项交易对收益和波动性的影响，调整其权重，既包括单笔交易，也包括整个投资组合。“他们会不断地调整投资组合的构成。”

Their portfolio was like a hat holding thousands of pairs of numbers, each representing the volatility and return they expected in a given trade. “They were thinking all the time about the numbers in the hat,” noted Robert Stavis, who worked in the group at Salomon. They were looking at the individual pairs—the IOs, the Italys, and so on—but they were also thinking about the correlations between the pairs. Would the results in mortgages tend to mimic those in Italy? Would one trade be up when the other was down? The partners adjusted the weighting of each trade according to its effect both on return and on volatility, singly and for the entire portfolio, Stavis said. “And they’d constantly be tuning the mix.”

梅里韦瑟的交易员们极其重视风险控制。他们认为，通过设定特定的波动水平就能有效控制风险，这正是他们管理基金的核心理念。如果投资组合表现过于平淡，他们就会增加借款，提高波动率；如果波动过大，他们就会降低杠杆，使基金趋于平稳。他们并没有设定具体的收益目标，而是精心设计了“波动率帽”，使其（他们认为）在大多数年份里与股市的波动幅度大致相同。波动率过高，风险就过大；波动率过低，则会错失良机。“对于任何具备他们理论背景的人来说，”曾参与该基金销售的美林证券的戴尔·迈耶指出，“波动率和收益是一回事。波动率越高，收益就越高。”

Meriwether’s traders were profoundly concerned with limiting risk. The idea that they could do so by targeting a specific level of volatility was central to how they ran the fund. If the portfolio was a little too quiet, they’d borrow more, raising the “vol”; if it was too volatile, they’d reduce their leverage, calming the fund down. Rather than target a specific return, they engineered the “hat” so that (they believed) it would fluctuate during most years about as much as the stock market did. With any more volatility, the risk would be too high. With less, they would be leaving money on the table. “To anyone with their theoretical background,” noted Merrill’s Dale Meyer, who helped sell the fund, “volatility and returns were the same thing. Increased volatility meant increased returns.”

如果这看起来不足为奇，那仅仅是因为到了20世纪90年代，这种方法已经渗透到华尔街的大部分领域。交易室接受了学者们对数字确定性的信仰；银行的风险经理们密切关注着波动率，仿佛其中蕴藏着圣杯。摩根大通的一位高管在被问及如何定义风险时，轻描淡写地回答说：“就是围绕均值的波动。”现代华尔街的自负之处在于，每天《华尔街日报》上刊登的收盘价与人寿保险公司的精算表或掷骰子游戏中已知的确定赔率一样可靠，一样能够预测未来。而这种自负很大程度上源于默顿和斯科尔斯。华尔街的每一家投资银行、每一个交易大厅都挤满了年轻有为的博士，他们都曾师从默顿、斯科尔斯或他们的门徒。那些每年花费数千万美元聘请昂贵的研究分析师（即选股专家）的公司，却在交易部门雇佣金融专业的学生，​​这些学生将资金置于风险之中，因为他们认为市场是有效的，这意味着股票价格永远是正确的，因此选股是一种骗局。

If this seems unremarkable, it is only because, by the 1990s, this approach had permeated most of Wall Street. Trading rooms had adopted the academics’ faith in numeric certainties; risk managers at banks monitored volatilities as though they contained the Holy Grail. A senior executive at J. P. Morgan, when asked how he defined risk, breezily replied, “As volatility around the mean.” The conceit of modern Wall Street was that the closing prices printed in each day’s Wall Street Journal were as reliable and predictive about the future as the actuarial tables of life insurance companies or the known and certain odds in shooting craps. And the conceit stemmed largely from Merton and Scholes. Every investment bank, every trading floor on Wall Street was staffed by young, intelligent Ph.D.s who had studied under Merton, Scholes, or their disciples. The same firms that spent tens of millions of dollars per year on expensive research analysts—i.e., stock pickers—staffed their trading desks with finance majors who put capital at risk on the assumption that the market was efficient, meaning that stock prices were ever correct and therefore that stock picking was a fraud.

长期投资公司的一些投资者几乎从小就耳濡目染地接受了这套信条。特伦斯·沙利文（Terence Sullivan）会记录他与长期投资公司的会议内容，他认为，只有发生罕见的“灾难性”事件——比如百年一遇的洪水——长期投资公司才会出现严重的失误。沙利文知道，价格有时会偏离正常水平，市场走势也会对长期投资公司不利，导致其蒙受损失。但市场在所有交易中都持续偏离正常水平，这简直是统计学上的奇迹，就像连续掷出七个1点（1）或者被闪电击中两次一样。沙利文早在匹兹堡大学商学院就明白了这一点——和所有商学院一样，这所学校深受默顿和斯科尔斯理论的影响。

Some of Long-Term’s investors had learned this credo practically in the crib. Terence Sullivan, who kept notes on his meetings with Long-Term, believed it would take a rare, “calamitous” event—maybe a once-in-a-hundred-year flood—for Long-Term to go seriously wrong. There would be times, Sullivan knew, when prices would deviate from the norm and when markets would move against Long-Term, costing it money. But for the markets in all of their trades to consistently depart from the norm would be a statistical freak, like rolling seven consecutive snake eyes or being hit by lightning twice. Sullivan had learned this long before, in business school at the University of Pittsburgh—which, like all such schools, was steeped in the teachings of Merton and Scholes.

除了提供一些咨询意见外，默顿和斯科尔斯都没有直接参与长期基金的交易。一些投资者也误以为，两位教授并没有创建那些详细阐述各种交易案例的“模型”。但默顿和斯科尔斯却是该基金的理论奠基人。正如斯科尔斯在基金创立之初所说：“我们不仅仅是一家基金，我们是一家金融科技公司。”² 更具体地说，长期基金是一项以数字方式管理风险的实验。这项实验的核心是波动率的概念，在两位合伙人看来，波动率已经取代杠杆，成为衡量风险的最佳指标。事实上，长期基金的许多交易都是为了利用价差，他们认为这些价差反映了对未来波动率风险（对长期基金而言真正重要的风险）的不准确估计。这类策略直接源于布莱克-斯科尔斯模型。

Neither Merton nor Scholes was involved in trading at Long-Term except in a minor, advisory sense. Nor, as some investors believed, did the professors create the “models” that detailed the cases for various trades. But Merton and Scholes were the fund’s philosophical fathers. As Scholes remarked at its inception, “We’re not just a fund. We’re a financial-technology company.”² More specifically, Long-Term was an experiment in managing risk by the numbers. At the center of this experiment was the notion of volatility, which had supplanted leverage, in the partners’ minds, as the best proxy for risk. Indeed, many of Long-Term’s trades were attempts to exploit spreads that, in its view, reflected an inaccurate estimate of future volatility risk—the one risk that (to Long-Term) really counted. Such strategies had evolved directly from the Black-Scholes formula.

这个公式建立在物理科学的发现之上。统计学家早就意识到了“大数定律”。粗略地说，如果你有足够多的随机事件样本，它们就会趋向于呈钟形曲线分布，大多数事件发生在平均值附近，而在两端则急剧下降。这被称为正态分布，或者用数学术语来说，是对数正态分布。一位篮球教练知道，在通常的身高分布下，在一个有100个学龄男孩的街区里，他可能会找到60到70个身高大致平均的男孩，几个矮个子，几个高个子，也许还有一个能打首发中锋。如果教练运气好，他可能会找到两个中锋。但他永远不可能在同一条街上找到20个身高七英尺（约2.13米）的球员——当然，前提是这些家庭之间没有血缘关系，否则选择就不是随机的了。正如彼得·伯恩斯坦所写，自然界的模式只能从众多随机事件的混乱无序中涌现出来。³

The formula had built on discoveries in the physical sciences. Statisticians had long been aware of the “law of large numbers.” Roughly speaking, if you have enough samples of a random event, they will tend to distribute in the familiar bell curve, with the most occurrences around the average and a sharp drop-off at either extreme. This is called the normal distribution or, in mathematical terms, the log-normal distribution. A basketball coach knows that, given the usual distribution of heights, on a block with one hundred school-age boys he is likely to find sixty to seventy boys of roughly average height, a few who are short and a few who are tall, and maybe one who could play starting center. If the coach is lucky, he might find two centers. But he would never find, say, twenty seven-footers on that single street—assuming, of course, that the families are unrelated, for otherwise the selection would not be random. As Peter Bernstein has written, nature’s pattern emerges only from the chaotic disorder of many random events.³

在布莱克、斯科尔斯和默顿看来，金融市场的价格变动也是随机的。* 没有人能够预测任何特定的价格变动，但他们假设，在足够长的时间里，所有此类价格的分布模式将与其他随机事件（例如抛硬币、掷骰子或高中生的身高）的模式相吻合。意大利债券和流通中的美国国债市场也呈现出钟形曲线，许多日子里价格波动幅度很小，只有极少数极端值，代表着市场的突然上涨或暴跌。

To Black, Scholes, and Merton, price changes in financial markets were random, too. * No one could predict any particular change, but over a long enough period, they assumed that the distribution of all such prices would mirror the pattern of other random events, like coin flips, dice rolls, or the heights of high school students. The market for Italian bonds and on-the-run Treasurys would also describe a bell curve, with many days in which prices changed only a little either up or down and a very few observations at the extremes, representing sudden upswings or market plunges.

* 布莱克-斯科尔斯公式明确指出：“我们将假设股票和期权的市场条件理想……股票价格在连续时间上服从随机游走。”

* The Black-Scholes formula explicitly states, “We will assume ideal conditions in the market for the stock and for the option. . . . The stock price follows a random walk in continuous time.”

他们认为，如果已知典型变化的幅度——即“波动率”——那么股票、债券或任何其他资产在一段时间内按一定比例上涨或下跌的概率也能推算出来。用于求解布莱克-斯科尔斯公式的微分方程改编自物理方程，这些方程描述了物理世界中的诸多现象，例如奶油在咖啡杯中的扩散方式。⁴单个分子的运动是随机的，但作为一个整体，分子会以可预测的方式从中心向外扩散。奶油永远不会全部流向杯子的一侧。

If the amount of the typical change—the “volatility”—were known, they believed, the odds that a stock, bond, or any other asset would rise or fall by some proportion over time could be derived as well. The differential equations used to solve the Black-Scholes formula were adapted from physics equations that describe, among other phenomena in the physical world, the way cream spreads through a cup of coffee.4 Any one molecule’s trip is random, but as a group, the molecules distribute themselves in predictable fashion, from the center out. The cream will never go all to one side.

布莱克-斯科尔斯模型指出，价格也不会（按预期）朝某一方向波动。在评估期权价值时，期权是指在未来以预先设定的“行权价格”购买标的证券的权利，而真正重要的是波动率，也就是标的证券价格波动的快慢。* 这符合直觉：证券价格波动越大，其价格上涨到行权价格以上的可能性就越大。

Black-Scholes says that prices don’t (predictably) go to one side either. In valuing an option, which is the right to buy a security at a stated “strike price” in the future, all that matters is the volatility, or the rate at which the underlying security jumps around. * This makes intuitive sense: the more a security fluctuates, the more likely it is to rise above the strike price.

* 决定期权价格的其他因素早在布莱克-斯科尔斯公式出现之前就为人所知。这些因素包括期权的期限、利率水平以及标的证券的当前价格与期权行权价格之间的价差。

* The other factors that determine an option’s price were known long before the Black-Scholes formula. They include the duration of the option, the level of interest rates, and the spread between the current price of the underlying security and the price at which the option can be exercised.

但布莱克-斯科尔斯模型做出了一个非常关键的假设：证券的波动率是恒定的。如果不能就IBM股票的波动率达成共识，那么说购买IBM期权的价值取决于其波动率就毫无意义。因此，这些教授将证券的波动率视为一种固有的、不变的特征。比如，你有一双蓝眼睛；IBM的波动率为X。你我或许会认为，过去无数次的市场波动不过是噪音——随意的，未必会再次出现，最好还是忘掉。但对于布莱克、斯科尔斯和默顿——以及长期投资理论——而言，这些波动蕴含着深刻的预测意义。市场的每一次涨跌都蕴含着对未来风险的精准预测。这意味着市场在每一步都是有效且理性的。

But Black-Scholes makes a very key assumption: that the volatility of a security is constant. To say that the value of an option to buy IBM depends on its volatility is meaningless unless you can agree on what its volatility is. Therefore, the professors treated the volatility of a security like an inherent, unchanging trait. You have blue eyes; IBM has a volatility of X. You or I might assume that the market fluctuations of so many yesterdays are so much noise—arbitrary, not necessarily likely to recur, and best forgotten. But to Black, Scholes, and Merton—and to Long-Term—these fluctuations were invested with deep predictive significance. Each tick of the market up or down was latent with an unerring forecast of future risk. This implied that markets were efficient and rational at every step.

默顿将这一假设更进一步。他假设波动性如此恒定，以至于价格会在“连续时间”中交易——换句话说，不会出现任何跳跃。默顿的市场就像精心冲泡的咖啡一样顺滑，价格也确实会像奶油一样流动。例如，他假设IBM的股价永远不会直接从80跌到60，而是始终会在79¾、79½和79¼这几个价位之间波动。

Merton carried the assumption a step further. He assumed that volatility was so constant that prices would trade in “continuous time”—in other words, without any jumps. Merton’s markets were as smooth as well-brewed java, in which prices would indeed flow like cream. He assumed, for instance, that the price of a share of IBM would never plunge directly from 80 to 60 but would always stop at 79 ¾, 79 ½, and 79 ¼ along the way.

交易员们在每个极其微小的时刻都会调整IBM期权的价格，使其与股票价格保持同步。同时持有IBM和股票期权的交易员，可以通过灵活的买卖操作，将他们的投资组合维持在一种理想化的、无风险的平衡状态。简而言之，默顿假设了一种完美的、无风险的套利。这种假设在市场平静时或许接近真实市场——但也仅限于此。1987年，所谓的投资组合保险（伴随着夸张的宣传）被推销给机构投资者，作为一种通过在市场下跌时持续抛售来限制损失的技巧。这些投资组合保险人加剧了后来被称为“黑色星期一”的市场崩盘。那天，市场剧烈波动。那些指望灵活控制损失的投资组合保险人，根本无法跟上华尔街爆发的恐慌，最终血本无归。

At each infinitesimal moment, traders would readjust the price of options on IBM, keeping them in synchrony with the price of the stock. And traders who owned both could—by nimbly buying or selling—keep their portfolio in an Edenic, risk-free state of balance. In short, Merton assumed a perfect, risk-free arbitrage. This assumption may approximate real markets when they are calm—but only then. In 1987, so-called portfolio insurance was marketed (with absurd ballyhoo) to institutional investors as a technique of limiting losses via continuous selling when markets fall. These portfolio insurers helped to exacerbate a market crash that was later dubbed Black Monday. That day, the market was highly discontinuous. Portfolio insurers who had counted on nimbly limiting their losses couldn’t keep pace with the panic that broke out on Wall Street and, indeed, lost their shirts.

默顿的完美套利假设是长期投资公司（以及许多其他公司）套期保值策略的关键组成部分。当然，合伙人在所罗门兄弟公司也曾运用过同样的风险假设，并积累了巨额利润——尽管偶尔也会遭受惨重损失。这让他们信心倍增。他们的交易通常都很合理，也就是说，他们的判断与概率相符。然而，该团队过去从未遭遇过失败，但这并不能保证他们已经正确计算出了海啸发生的概率——只能说明海啸发生的频率相对较低。

Merton’s perfect-arbitrage assumption was an essential building block in Long-Term’s (and many other firms’) hedging strategies. The partners, of course, had worked with the same risk assumptions at Salomon Brothers and had racked up phenomenal profits—albeit with the occasional nasty loss. This gave them tremendous confidence. Their trades usually were sensible, meaning that they were aligned with the odds. Nonetheless, the fact that the group’s ship hadn’t capsized in the past didn’t guarantee that the group had properly calculated the odds of a tidal wave—just that such waves were relatively infrequent.

默顿的理论之所以具有诱惑力，并非因为它们大多是错误的，而是因为它们几乎总是对的。正如英国散文家G·K·切斯特顿所写，生活是“逻辑学家的陷阱”，因为它几乎合乎逻辑，却又不完全合乎逻辑；它通常是明智的，但偶尔也会出乎意料：

Merton’s theories were seductive not because they were mostly wrong but because they were so nearly, or so nearly often, right. As the English essayist G. K. Chesterton wrote, life is “a trap for logicians” because it is almost reasonable but not quite; it is usually sensible but occasionally otherwise:

它看起来比实际情况更符合数学规律，更规整一些；它的精确性显而易见，但它的不精确性却隐藏起来；它的野性潜伏着。5

It looks just a little more mathematical and regular than it is; its exactitude is obvious, but its inexactitude is hidden; its wildness lies in wait.5

默顿正是落入了这个陷阱。他的“连续时间金融”理论似乎将整个金融世界包裹在一个整齐的球里。从理论上讲，它几乎解决了金融领域的所有问题，或者至少指明了解决方案：垃圾债券的估值方法、存款保险的支付标准等等，不胜枚举。他的理论似乎展现了他一直渴望的优雅与秩序。“并非所有科学中美好的事物都必须实用，”他满意地写道，“但在这里，两者兼得。” 6

Merton was prey to this very trap. His “continuous-time finance” seemed to wrap the financial universe in a tidy ball. On paper it solved, or pointed to the solutions for, virtually every problem in finance: how to value junk bonds, how much to pay for deposit insurance, you name it. His theories seemed to behold the elegance and order he had always craved. “Not all that is beautiful in science need also be practical,” he wrote with satisfaction. “But here we have both.”6

埃里克·罗森菲尔德曾在20世纪70年代就读于麻省理工学院，他视默顿为“不可思议的数学家”。他指出，默顿一篇未发表的论文就激发了一批受其启发的追随者撰写大量博士论文。当然，默顿的全部理论都建立在他对随机游走的假设之上，而这些假设与物理世界紧密相连。正如谦逊的罗森菲尔德所描述的那样，他和他的默顿门徒们常常奔向物理图书馆，寻找可以“套用到金融领域”的公式化解决方案。

Eric Rosenfeld, who had studied at MIT in the 1970s, looked up to Merton as an “unbelievable mathematician.” He noted that a single unpublished paper of Merton’s had triggered a host of dissertations by a cadre of inspired disciples. Of course, Merton’s entire oeuvre depended on his assumptions about random walks, with their close tie-in to the physical world. As the unassuming Rosenfeld described it, he and his fellow Merton protégés used to run to the physics library looking for formulaic solutions that they could “jam into finance.”

在默顿的指导下学习期间，罗森菲尔德曾参与开发金融软件，而正是这些软件将数学引入了华尔街。他和朋友米切尔·卡普尔是苹果II电脑的早期拥趸，当时这款电脑的软件还非常少。卡普尔觉得电脑很酷，而罗森菲尔德则利用量化系统进行投资和足球博彩。1978年，正在撰写论文并大量时间泡在大学计算机中心的罗森菲尔德问卡普尔能否编写一个能在苹果电脑上运行的程序。卡普尔答应了——并意识到他们找到了商机。两人合伙成立了一家名为“微型金融系统”（Micro Finance Systems）的小公司。他们发布了一款名为“Tiny TROLL”的桌面图形和统计程序，功能强大，足以完成一些实际工作。这款程序销量数千份，卡普尔和罗森菲尔德也因此赚了数十万美元。

While studying with Merton, Rosenfeld played a cameo role in developing financial software, which was the bridge that brought the math to Wall Street. He and a friend, Mitchell Kapor, were early devotees of the Apple II, at a time when little software existed for it. Kapor thought computers were cool, and Rosenfeld was using quantitative systems for investing as well as for betting on football. In 1978, Rosenfeld, who was writing his thesis and spending gobs of time at the university computer center, asked Kapor if he could write a program that would run on the Apple. Kapor did—and realized they were on to something. The two became partners in a tiny company called Micro Finance Systems. They published a desktop graphics and statistics program known as Tiny TROLL that was just powerful enough to do useful work. It sold thousands of copies, and Kapor and Rosenfeld made hundreds of thousands of dollars on it.

卡普尔曾是一名唱片骑师和超验冥想导师，他认为自己发现了下一个潮流。他开始筹划第二个创业项目，并邀请罗森菲尔德加入。但卡普尔也对金融产生了浓厚的兴趣。他被朋友关于股票如何模仿分子运动的描述深深吸引，于是进入麻省理工学院学习。然而，在卡普尔修读了默顿的金融课程后，他认为量化金融与其说是一门科学，不如说是一种信仰——一种为“被模型的力量蒙蔽”的意识形态狂热分子准备的教条。它吸引了那些渴望秩序的知识分子，但如果市场偏离模型，它就会将他们引入灾难性的歧途。卡普尔后来创立了莲花开发公司，并成为软件行业的标志性人物。罗森菲尔德在哈佛大学找到了一份教职，他将从Tiny TROLL获得的版税投入到另外两个项目中——其中一个是租来的帆船，在首航时几乎沉没——结果损失惨重。7

Kapor, a former disc jockey and teacher of transcendental meditation, thought he had discovered the next wave. He hatched plans for a second venture and invited Rosenfeld to join him. But Kapor had also caught the finance bug. He was so intrigued by his friend’s account of how stocks mimicked molecules that he enrolled at MIT. But after Kapor took Merton’s finance course, he decided that quantitative finance was less a science than a faith—a doctrine for ideologues “blinded by the power of the model.” It appealed to intellectuals who craved a sense of order but could lead them disastrously astray if markets moved outside the model. Kapor went on to form Lotus Development Corporation and became an icon of the software industry. Rosenfeld, who had gotten a job teaching at Harvard, staked his royalties from Tiny TROLL on two other ventures—one of which, a chartered sailboat, almost sank on its maiden voyage—and lost a lot of money.7

卡普尔并非唯一一个质疑默顿模型是否过于理想化而无法适用于现实世界的人。默顿在麻省理工学院的导师保罗·萨缪尔森在“长期投资”项目启动之初也对此有所怀疑。萨缪尔森是首位获得诺贝尔经济学奖的金融经济学家，他意识到“连续时间”仅仅是一种理想状态；在现实生活中，交易员需要几秒钟、几分钟甚至几个小时来分析事件并做出反应。当事件超出他们的掌控时，市场就会出现跳空。热分子不会跳出轨道；但IBM的股价肯定会跳出轨道。“这对‘长期投资’项目至关重要，”萨缪尔森指出，“布莱克-斯科尔斯公式的本质在于，你确定的不是最终的结果，而是正在采样的宇宙类型，这便引出了对数正态分布的假设。我当时（在‘长期投资’项目启动之初）就对此感到疑惑。” 8

Kapor wasn’t the only one who wondered if Merton’s model might be too tidy for the real world. Paul Samuelson, Merton’s mentor at MIT, had doubts when Long-Term was organized. Samuelson, the first financial economist to win a Nobel Prize, recognized that “continuous time” was merely an ideal state; in real time, traders took seconds, minutes, or even hours to analyze events and react. When events overwhelmed them, the markets gapped. Heat molecules didn’t jump out of line; IBM most certainly did. “This is very important to the Long-Term story,” Samuelson noted. “The essence of the Black-Scholes formula is that you know, with certainty, not what the deal of the cards will be but what kind of universe is being sampled, which gives you the assumption of the log-normal process. I wondered back then [when Long-Term started].”8

纸牌的魅力在于其宇宙是已知的；一副牌有52张，也只有52张。人寿保险则略有不同：由于人群不断增加，精算师只能依靠抽样。抽样并非完美无缺，但行之有效，因为样本量非常大，而且死亡率变化极其缓慢。但在市场中，我们永远无法确定样本是否完整。20世纪20年代，所有交易的整体格局呈现出一种面貌，而大萧条之后则截然不同。在通货膨胀的70年代，这种格局再次发生变化，在蓬勃发展的90年代，又一次发生了改变。究竟在哪个时期之后，市场格局才算“正常”？我们又如何确定下一个新时期不会再次改变格局？以IBM为例，它身处一个充满活力、瞬息万变的世界，管理者们不断面对新的可能性、新的问题和新产品，而每一项风险似乎都难以量化。如果纽约巨人队的一位经理提议依靠过去的经验来准确衡量未来的风险，他很可能会被解雇。

The beauty of cards is that the universe is known; there are fifty-two cards in a deck, and only fifty-two. Life insurance is a bit different: since new people are always being added to the universe, actuaries rely on samplings. They aren’t perfect, but they work, because the sample of people is very large and mortality rates change only very slowly. But in markets, we are never sure that the sample is complete. The universe of all trades looked one way throughout the 1920s and another way after the Great Depression. The pattern changed again during the inflationary 1970s, yet again in the effervescent 1990s. After which of these periods was the picture “normal,” and how do we know that the next new period won’t change the story again? To focus on a single company, IBM lives in a dynamic, ever-changing world, in which managers perpetually confront new possibilities, new problems, and novel products, the risks of each of which would seem impossible to quantify. If a manager at Big Blue proposed to rely on the past as an accurate gauge of future risk, he would probably be fired.

尤金·法玛是斯科尔斯的论文导师，他也十分好奇这位老学生在做什么。法玛对期权公式作为一种模型推崇备至。但把人们的钱托付给这样的模型就完全是另一回事了。20世纪60年代初，法玛撰写了关于道琼斯工业平均指数30只成分股价格走势的论文，并发现了一个惊人的模式：每只股票的极端价格波动天数都远远超过正态分布所能解释的范围。法玛研究的股票就像一个世界，大多数人的身高都处于平均水平，但每20个人中就有一个人是巨人或侏儒。极端读数，或者说“异常值”，数量之多，是随机分布无法解释的。正如法玛所说：

Eugene Fama, Scholes’s thesis adviser, wondered what his old student was up to as well. Fama had all the admiration in the world for the option formula as a model. But trusting people’s money to such models was different. In the early 1960s, Fama had written his thesis on the price movements of the thirty Dow Jones Industrial Average stocks and discovered a remarkable pattern: for every stock, there were many more days of extreme price movements than would occur in a normal distribution. Fama’s stocks were like a world in which most people were average height but every twentieth person was either a giant or a dwarf. There were too many extreme readings, or “outliers,” that random distribution could not explain. As Fama put it:

如果价格变动总体严格服从正态分布，那么对于任何股票而言，平均而言……偏离均值五个标准差以上的观测值大约每7000年才会出现一次。事实上，这种观测值似乎大约每三到四年就会出现一次。9

If the population of price changes is strictly normal, on the average for any stock . . . an observation more than five standard deviations from the mean should be observed about once every 7,000 years. In fact such observations seem to occur about once every three to four years.9

从图表上看，法玛的股票价格曲线呈钟形，两端膨胀，表明极端情况（即所谓的“尾部”）发生过多。法玛的理论无疑与斯科尔斯讨论过，对未来的长期资本有着深远的影响。法玛警告说，与模型中理想化的市场不同，现实市场会经历“不连续”的价格变动（那些令人头疼的跳跃），并且出现巨额损失的概率更高；事实上，“这样的市场本质上风险更大。” 10

Graphically, Fama’s stocks depicted a bell curve with the ends swollen, representing too many incidents at the extremes (known as the “tails”). Fama’s thesis, which he undoubtedly discussed with Scholes, was rife with implications for the future Long-Term Capital. In contrast to the idealized markets in models, Fama warned, real-life ones experienced “discontinuous” price changes (those nasty jumps) and a higher probability of large losses; indeed, “such a market is inherently more risky.”10

在长期投资公司成立之时，几乎所有金融资产的走势都与法玛研究过的股票类似，这一点已得到充分证实。 11抵押贷款证券通常也会按照模型预测运行，但总有一天，它们会毫无预兆地飙升。正如法玛所说，“生活总有其长尾效应。” 12 在JM的信发出几个月后，墨西哥比索暴跌，投资者恐慌，引发了从德克萨斯州到火地岛的连锁反应。阿根廷和委内瑞拉的市场并非各自独立，而是同时崩盘。直到财政部长、前高盛套利交易员罗伯特·鲁宾组织了救助计划，市场信心才得以恢复。

By the time Long-Term was formed, it was well documented that virtually all financial assets behaved like the stocks that Fama had studied.11 Mortgage securities might usually behave as the model predicted, but there would come a day when—with no warning at all—they would leap off the charts. As Fama put it, “Life always has a fat tail.”12 A few months after J.M.’s letter, the Mexican peso collapsed and investors panicked, setting off a chain reaction from Texas to Tierra del Fuego. The markets in Argentina and Venezuela were not independent dice; they collapsed simultaneously. Confidence wasn’t restored until Robert Rubin, the Treasury secretary and former Goldman arbitrageur, organized a bailout.

即使你只是偶尔关注一下市场，你可能也会有种直觉，股票（或债券）的波动往往难以解释；它们经常剧烈震荡。最明显的例子就是“黑色星期一”，当时市场在没有任何明显消息的情况下暴跌了23%。经济学家后来根据市场的历史波动性推断，即使从宇宙诞生之初市场每天都开放，单日跌幅如此之大的概率仍然很低。事实上，即使宇宙的生命周期重复十亿次，理论上这样的崩盘仍然“不太可能”发生。 13但它最终还是发生了。显然，过去的波动性并不能让投资者为即将到来的冲击做好准备——也不能提前预示这些冲击何时会发生。

If you follow the market even casually, you probably have a gut feeling that stocks (or bonds) are often inexplicably volatile; they do an awful lot of bouncing around. The most obvious example was Black Monday, when, on no apparent news, the market plunged 23 percent. Economists later figured that, on the basis of the market’s historic volatility, had the market been open every day since the creation of the Universe, the odds would still have been against its falling that much on any single day. In fact, had the life of the Universe been repeated one billion times, such a crash would still have been theoretically “unlikely.”13 But it happened anyway. Obviously, past volatilities do not prepare investors for shocks that lie in wait—nor do they signal in advance just when such shocks might choose to occur.

金融市场波动频繁且极端的原因在于，它比抛硬币的概率更高，也比Long-Term合伙人后来声称导致他们灾难的“百年一遇的风暴”更为常见。随机事件的一个关键条件是，每一次抛硬币都与前一次无关。硬币不会记住它已经连续三次正面朝上；第四次抛硬币的概率仍然是五五开。

There is a reason why financial markets run to extremes more often than coin flips—and more often than the “hundred-year storm” that Long-Term’s partners would later cite as the culprit behind their disaster. A key condition of random events is that each new flip is independent of the previous one. The coin doesn’t remember that it landed on tails three times in a row; the odds on the fourth flip are still fifty-fifty.

但市场是有记忆的。有时，某种趋势会延续，仅仅是因为交易员预期（或担心）它会延续。投资者盲目追随趋势，仅仅因为他们认为会有足够多的人效仿。这种动量交易与对证券进行逻辑评估毫无关系；它不符合有效市场中理性投资者的理想。但这却是人之常情。在经历了三次糟糕的市场“翻转”之后，第四次翻转可能不再完全随机。一些交易员可能已经遭受损失，被迫抛售；而另一些投资者则可能因为担心被套牢而恐慌，决定抢先一步——就像《长期》杂志创刊之初的那个春天，美国国债市场发生的情况一样。只要人类的本能存在，法玛所观察到的小幅波动，甚至是像“黑色星期一”那样的大规模波动，都有可能发生。* 14

But markets have memories. Sometimes a trend will continue just because traders expect (or fear) that it will. Investors may slavishly follow the trend for no other reason than that they think enough others will do likewise. Such momentum trading has nothing to do with logically appraising securities; it doesn’t fit the ideal of rational investors in efficient markets. But it’s human. After three bad “flips” in the market, the fourth flip may no longer be completely random. Some traders may have taken losses and be forced to sell; other investors, looking over their shoulders, may panic and decide to beat them to it—as happened with Treasury bonds during Long-Term’s inaugural spring. Wherever the human spirit is present, the little runs that Fama noticed, and even big, Black Monday–sized runs, are possible. *14

令人费解的是，法玛将余生都投入到为有效市场假说辩护中。他认为，黑色星期一是企业基本价值（或许只是一天之内）变化的理性调整。另一方面，现任美国财政部长劳伦斯·萨默斯在股灾后接受《华尔街日报》采访时表示：“有效市场假说是经济理论史上最令人震惊的错误。”

* Curiously, Fama devoted the rest of his career to justifying the efficient-market hypothesis. He argued that Black Monday had been a rational adjustment to a (one-day?) change in underlying corporate values. On the other hand, Lawrence Summers, now the U.S. Treasury secretary, told The Wall Street Journal after the crash, “The efficient market hypothesis is the most remarkable error in the history of economic theory.”

默顿的市场理论中完全缺乏这种人性化的元素。尽管他承认自己的模型代表了一种理想状态，但他的著述却充斥着完美价格和理性投资者的理念。甚至他的文风也显得生硬枯燥，仿佛他试图将生活中的情感提炼出来，简化成一种可控的抽象概念。他对所研究领域的热情在课堂上能激发学生的学习热情，但在私下里，这位卷发丰颊的教授却显得拘谨而冷漠。除了他的法拉利跑车，对他而言，天堂就是一场深入的学术讨论。他慷慨地付出时间，尤其对学生而言，但却不愿与人交流，也不愿改变自己的想法。“听他讲道就像在听葛培理布道，”一位学生回忆道。

This human spirit was totally absent from Merton’s markets. Though he acknowledged that his models represented an ideal state, his writing was suffused with the notion of perfect prices and rational investors. Even his prose was wooden and dry, as if he were trying to boil off life’s emotional content and reduce it to a controlled abstraction. His passion for his subject electrified students in the classroom, but on a personal level, the curly-haired, plump-cheeked professor was formal and aloof. Aside from his Ferrari, Heaven, to him, was a deep academic discussion. He was generous with his time, particularly with students, but not disposed to give-and-take or to changing his mind. “It was like listening to Billy Graham,” a student recalled.

狂热的默顿对投资者可能并非冷酷无情的理性机器这一可能性嗤之以鼻，并对投资者情绪失控的时刻视而不见。因此，他将自己理论对“20世纪80年代的投资组合保险产品”的贡献据为己有——仿佛他完全无视这样一个事实：当普通人尝试这些产品时，投资组合保险惨败而归。 15甚至连“投机”一词他都加上了引号，仿佛这个词可能适用于真正的投资者让他感到无比厌恶，必须用镊子夹着它。事实上，当默顿引用“凯恩斯那些著名而生动的段落”时，他是在抨击这位英国经济学家兼文学家，仅仅因为他的著作中出现了一两个生动、人性化的形容词。他患有完美信念的疾病，这使他无法妥协。当美国经济学家罗伯特·J·席勒大胆提出市场波动性过大，无法符合完全市场模型时，人们可以感受到，对于默顿而言，哪怕是抱有任何怀疑，都可能使整个理论体系崩塌：“我们几乎无需赘述这一结论的意义。如果席勒对市场有效性的否定成立，那么现代金融经济理论的这一基石的有效性将受到严重质疑。” 16

The evangelical Merton showed disdain for the very possibility that investors could be anything but calculating automatons, and he blithely ignored the times when their emotions ran riot. Thus, he took credit for the contribution that his theories made to “the portfolio-insurance products of the 1980s”—as if he were blind to the fact that, when real people had tried those products, portfolio insurance had miserably failed.15 Even the word “speculative” he put into quotes, as though the notion that it might apply to real investors was so unpleasant he had to handle it with forceps. Indeed, when Merton referred to “well-known and colorful passages by Keynes,” he was knocking the English economist and man of letters for the sin of letting a vivid, human adjective or two slip into his copy. He had the disease of perfect belief, which makes compromise impossible. When Robert J. Shiller, an American economist, dared to suggest that markets were too volatile to fit the model of perfect markets, you could sense that for Merton, to entertain any doubt at all was to risk seeing the entire edifice crumble: “We need hardly mention the significance of such a conclusion. If Shiller’s rejection of market efficiency is sustained, then serious doubt is cast on the validity of this cornerstone of modern financial economic theory.”16

长期交易员当然知道这些模型并不完美。“我们知道这套方法不能照搬照抄，”所罗门兄弟公司套利团队前成员罗伯特·斯塔维斯说道，“但这是我们目前最好的模型。看看那些凭直觉行事的老手们。他们有这个模型，有这些数据，但最终他们发现这些数据比人的直觉要可靠得多。”

The traders at Long-Term knew the models were imperfect, of course. “We know this doesn’t work by rote,” said Robert Stavis, the former member of the Arbitrage Group at Salomon. “But this is the best model we have. You look at the old-timers who went with their gut. You had this model, you had these numbers, and in the end you thought they were a lot more powerful than a guy’s gut.”
