Long-Term的交易员并非机器人。他们每周都会就模型的预测结果以及是否应该采纳模型建议进行数小时的辩论，有时甚至会激烈争论。他们也意识到“肥尾效应”的批评——即意外灾难应该被预料到——并试图调整模型以应对这种情况。但是，我们真的能够预先设定模型来应对意外情况吗？Long-Term的大部分交易风险较低，但并非零风险。风险程度也无法精确量化。问题在于，数学模型将本质上不确定的事件包装成了确定无疑的。 “比如，莫妮卡·莱温斯基带着披萨走进克林顿的办公室。你根本不知道接下来会发生什么，”Conseco的马克斯·布布利茨（他拒绝投资Long-Term）指出，“但如果你用数学方法计算，你会得出她有38%的概率会为他口交。这看起来很棒，但这完全是猜测。”

Long-Term’s traders were not automatons. They debated, sometimes hotly, for hours every week, about what the models implied and whether to do what the models recommended. They were also aware of the “fat tail” criticism—the idea that unexpected disaster should be expected—and they tried to adjust the models for it. But can one ever program for the unexpected? Most of Long-Term’s trades were low risk, but they were not no risk. Nor was the degree of risk precisely quantifiable. The problem with the math is that it adorned with certitude events that were inherently uncertain. “You take Monica Lewinsky, who walks into Clinton’s office with a pizza. You have no idea where that’s going to go,” Conseco’s Max Bublitz, who had declined to invest in Long-Term, noted. “Yet if you apply math to it, you come up with a thirty-eight percent chance she’s going to go down on him. It looks great, but it’s all a guess.”

到了20世纪90年代中期，华尔街和格林威治一样，早已彻底遗忘了这种区别。从美林证券到摩根大通再到信孚银行，各大银行都在精确计算其交易在任何一天、一个月或一年中可能出现的亏损幅度，精确到极小的分数。就连美联储也支持这类项目，其通用名称是“风险价值”（VaR）。这些项目看似复杂精妙，实则暗含着这样的疑问：“如果市场像过去那样运行，我们会损失多少？”但如果市场走势有所不同呢？正如马克·吐温所说，历史总是押韵，却不会重演。 17

By the mid-1990s, this distinction was as hopelessly lost on Wall Street as it was in Greenwich. Banks from Merrill to Morgan to Bankers Trust were computing, to the tiniest fraction, the supposed amount by which their trades could fall in any day, month, or year. Even the Federal Reserve was endorsing such programs, which went by the generic name “Value-at-Risk.” Beneath the programs’ sophisticated veneer, they amounted to asking, “If markets behave as they have in the past, how much will we lose?” But what if markets did something different? History, Mark Twain noted, rhymes; it does not repeat.17

这类项目曾经奏效，直到它们失效为止——就像1995年墨西哥的金融危机一样。而且，它们恰恰在最需要它们的时候，在意料之外的动荡时期失效了。它们就像是为所有风平浪静的日子提供的保险；它们能预测人们在正常情况下会损失多少，但却无法预测比索暴跌时的损失。耶鲁大学的货币交易员大卫·德罗萨（David DeRosa）将风险价值（VaR）比作“即将沉没者的灯塔”。摩根大通（JP Morgan）是该方法的先驱（以RiskMetrics为品牌），它坦率地承认了该方法的缺陷。在1994年10月的一份文件中（与梅里韦瑟的信件同月），摩根承认市场似乎并非像抛硬币那样随机或独立，而且波动性“本身就相当不稳定”。尽管如此，该公司及其在华尔街的众多模仿者仍然继续使用风险价值（VaR）。摩根大通银行解释说，它找不到任何“有说服力的替代方案”，仿佛这样就能弥补它的不足。

Such programs worked until they failed to work—as they did in Mexico in 1995. And they failed precisely at moments of unexpected turbulence—when they were needed most. They were like insurance for all the days when it didn’t storm; they predicted what one would lose on a normal day but not when the peso collapsed. David DeRosa, a currency trader who teaches at Yale, dubbed Value-at-Risk “a lighthouse for the soon-to-be-shipwrecked.” J. P. Morgan, which pioneered the methodology (under the brand name RiskMetrics), candidly admitted its flaws. In a document dated October 1994, the same month as Meriwether’s letter, Morgan admitted that markets did not appear to be random or independent in the way of coin flips and that volatilities “are themselves quite volatile.” Nonetheless, the firm, and its imitators all over Wall Street, continued to use Value-at-Risk. Morgan couldn’t find any “persuasive alternatives,”18 the bank explained—as if that would make up for its shortcomings.

在所有采用风险价值（VaR）策略的公司中，长期策略公司（Long-Term）堪称典范。19 教授们的附录读起来就像默顿的讲稿；它自信地告诉投资者，股市收益确实是独立（随机）分布的。此外，他们强调长期策略公司预期其收益在不同时期之间呈负相关，这意味着下跌的月份之后很可能紧接着上涨的月份，以此类推，从而进一步降低了持续亏损的可能性。“任何一个季度的低收益更有可能在下一个季度出现更高的收益，”默顿和斯科尔斯认为。从长远来看，这合乎逻辑，因为市场最终会纠正其错误。否则，购买定价错误的证券就毫无意义了。但是，如果在价格纠正之前，价格偏差进一步扩大——甚至急剧扩大——呢？就像埃克斯坦在20世纪70年代遇到的情况一样？这是这封信中没有提及的可能性。

Of all the firms that subscribed to Value-at-Risk, Long-Term was the archetype.19 The professors’ addendum read like the notes from one of Merton’s lectures; it confidently informed investors that returns in the stock market were, indeed, independently (randomly) distributed. What’s more, they stressed that Long-Term expected its returns to be negatively correlated from one period to the next, meaning that a down month would likely be followed by a good month and so on, thus making sustained losing streaks even less likely. “A low return in any one quarter may be more likely to be followed by a higher return in the subsequent quarter,” Merton and Scholes argued. Over time, that was logical, because over time markets do correct their mistakes. Otherwise, there would be no point in buying mispriced securities. But what if, before prices corrected, they got further—drastically further—out of line, as had happened to Eckstein in the 1970s? That was a possibility the letter didn’t mention.

合伙人理念的核心在于，市场正稳步变得更加高效、流动性更强、更加“连续”——更接近默顿所设想的那样。 20随着越来越多的投资者寻找定价错误的证券，以及市场消息传播速度加快，投资者纠正错误价格所需的时间似乎也更短。而且在大多数情况下，他们可能确实做到了。一个有效的市场波动性更小（不会出现黑色星期一），而且每日风险也更低。因此，价差应该会收窄。这增强了合伙人对价差收窄的信心。事实上，他们信心十足，甚至敢于使用多倍杠杆进行此类押注。

A central tenet of the partners’ philosophy was that markets were steadily getting more efficient, more liquid, more “continuous”—more as Merton had envisioned them.20 With more investors hunting for mispriced securities and with market news traveling faster, it seemed logical that investors would take less time to correct mistaken prices. And on most days, they probably did. An efficient market is a less volatile one (it has no Black Mondays) and, from day to day, a less risky one. Spreads should therefore contract. This boosted the partners’ confidence that spreads would narrow. Indeed, they were confident enough to leverage such bets many times over.

尽管全球投资者在墨西哥金融危机中损失惨重，但长期投资公司却未受影响，其令人瞩目的成功势头依然强劲。事实上，1995年，随着早期交易的成效显现，公司的业绩进一步提升。意大利不再被视为欧洲大陆的“问题儿童”，而是被誉为欧洲的设计之都，比德国更具创造力，也比法国更少受传统束缚。随着其他交易员也意识到意大利的增长潜力，罗马的债券市场开始活跃起来，长期投资公司的利润也随之飙升。21

Although global investors were burned by the Mexican fiasco, Long-Term was unaffected, and its stirring success continued. In fact, in 1995, as earlier trades bore fruit, the firm’s results improved. Italy, no longer looking like the Continent’s problem child, was being hailed as the design capital of Europe, more creative than Germany and less hobbled by tradition than France. As other traders grasped Italy’s potential for growth, the bond market in Rome began to percolate, and Long-Term’s profits swelled.21

得益于意大利市场，尤其是IO抵押贷款交易，长期基金在1995年实现了惊人的59%的税前收益率和43%的税后收益率。其中超过一半的收益来自欧洲。在成立的头两年，长期基金就获得了高达16亿美元的收益，其中意大利市场贡献了约6亿美元的利润。总而言之，这是有史以来任何基金最快、最令人瞩目的开局。对于从一开始就投资的投资者来说，即使在合伙人抽取了高额佣金之后，每一美元的初始投资也增长了71%。所罗门兄弟银行在他不在期间的困境也让JM心情大好。这家银行在1994年遭受了惨重的损失，当时盛传即将被出售。

Thanks to Italy and the IO mortgage trade in particular, Long-Term in 1995 earned an astounding 59 percent before fees and 43 percent after. A little over half of the gains came from Europe. During its first two years, in which Long-Term had earned a remarkable $1.6 billion, Italy contributed an estimated $600 million in profits. All told, it was the fastest, most impressive start by any fund ever. For an investor who had started on day one, each original dollar had swelled by 71 percent, even after the partnership group had taken its robust cut. It did not hurt J.M.’s mood that Salomon Brothers was struggling in his absence. The bank had suffered wrenching losses in 1994 and was widely rumored to be up for sale.

梅里韦瑟唯一挥之不去的担忧是，长期基金的波动性不够大。该基金曾告诉投资者，其收益波动如同手风琴一般，损失如同藏在风箱之间，但在头两年里，长期基金仅有一个月的亏损超过1%。一位投资者疑惑道：“手风琴呢？”对于诺贝尔经济学奖得主、长期基金一位投资者的顾问威廉·F·夏普来说，收益似乎异常平稳。“我们明确地问：‘风险是什么？’”夏普回忆道。“迈伦·斯科尔斯说：‘我们的目标是达到标普500指数的风险水平（波动性）。’他说：‘我们很难达到那个水平。’”

Meriwether’s only nagging worry was that Long-Term hadn’t been volatile enough. The fund had told investors to expect an accordion, with pockets of losses tucked between its bellows, but over the first two years, in only one month had Long-Term lost more than 1 percent. “Where’s the accordion?” one investor wondered. To William F. Sharpe, a Nobel Prize–winning economist and an adviser to one of Long-Term’s investors, the returns seemed surreally smooth. “We distinctly asked, ‘What’s the risk?’ ” Sharpe recalled. “Myron [Scholes] said, ‘Well, our goal is to get the risk level [the volatility] of the S&P 500.’ He said, ‘We’re having trouble getting it that big.’ ”

凭借如此辉煌的开局，Long-Term（再次与美林证券合作）毫不费力地筹集到了10亿美元的新资金。梅里韦瑟几乎要流露出一丝自豪。他在致投资者的信中提到，Long-Term的合伙人已增至16位，员工总数达到96人，其中约一半从事交易和策略工作。 22他强调了公司的精英特质——双语员工、众多博士以及先进的“金融科技”。梅里韦瑟毕生都在分析各种可能性：Long-Term将成为他毕生事业的巅峰之作——一场宏大而精心编排的风险承担交响乐。

With such a stellar start, Long-Term, again with Merrill Lynch, had no trouble raising an additional $1 billion of new money. Meriwether almost allowed himself a note of pride. Writing to investors, he noted that Long-Term had swelled to sixteen partners and ninety-six people overall, about half of them involved in trading and strategy.22 He stressed the firm’s elite character—its bilingual staffers, its many Ph.D.s, its sophisticated “financial technology.” J.M. had been parsing the odds all his life: Long-Term was to be the pinnacle of his work—a grand, supremely orchestrated symphony of risk taking.

加上新投资者的资金，该公司的股本在不到两年的时间里几乎翻了三倍，达到36亿美元。长期公司的资产也增长到了惊人的1020亿美元。因此，到1995年底，其杠杆率高达28比1。当然，其总资产回报率——包括自有资产和借入资产——远低于上述令人咋舌的回报。总资本回报率约为2.45%。 23这个微不足道的数字是长期公司如果只投资自有资金所能获得的收益。但即使是这个数字也偏高，因为它没有反映长期公司的衍生品交易，正如前文所述，这些交易并未记录在其资产负债表上。但衍生品无疑增加了长期公司的风险敞口。 （无论你是购买债券还是仅仅押注其价格，你都面临着相同的潜在收益或损失。）而这些表外交易无疑增加了长期债券的风险。

Including the money from new investors, the firm’s equity capital had, in less than two years, virtually tripled, to a total of $3.6 billion. Long-Term’s assets had also grown, to the extraordinary sum of $102 billion. Thus, at the end of 1995, it was leveraged 28 to 1. Of course, its return on total assets—both those that it owned and those that it had borrowed—was far, far less than the gaudy return cited above. This return on total capital was approximately 2.45 percent.23 This minuscule figure is what Long-Term would have earned had it invested only its own money. But even this figure is too high because it doesn’t reflect Long-Term’s derivative trades, which, as noted, weren’t recorded on its balance sheet. But derivatives most certainly increased Long-Term’s exposure. (Whether you buy a bond or simply bet on its price, you are exposed to the same potential gain or loss.) And these off-balance-sheet trades most definitely increased Long-Term’s riskiness.

考虑到其衍生品交易，其现金回报率可能不到1%。24具体数字并不重要。关键在于，其高达59%的惊人回报率几乎全部归功于杠杆的强大威力。从这个角度来看，夏普提出的问题——风险是什么？——就很难回答了。现金投资者承担的是其自有资金的风险，但长期基金并没有做出这样的前期承诺。特别是其衍生品交易，无需预先投入任何资金。该基金每天只需与银行结算，根据交易的走向支付或收取现金。长期基金没有使用营运资金，而是指定了一部分其权益作为每笔交易的担保。这部分所谓的风险资本代表了长期基金认为需要存放在金库中的资金，以备不时之需。罗森菲尔德回忆道：

Taking its derivative trades into account, its cash-on-cash return was probably less than 1 percent.24 The exact number is unimportant. The point is that almost all of its heady 59 percent return was due to the remarkable power of leverage. Seen in this light, Sharpe’s question—What was the risk?—would be difficult to answer. A cash investor risks his out-of-pocket investment, but Long-Term didn’t make such an up-front commitment. Its derivative trades, in particular, required no capital up front. The fund simply settled with its banks each day, paying or receiving cash depending on which way a trade had moved. In lieu of working capital, Long-Term designated a hypothetical slice of its equity as standing behind each trade. This so-called risk capital represented the capital that Long-Term figured it needed to keep in the vault, just in case. Rosenfeld recalled,

虽然我们没有被强制减记，但我们制定了一套风险管理流程，计算了假设的营运资金损失。我们逐笔分析了每一笔交易，然后说：“假设我们正处于非常艰难的时期，损失会有多大？”

Even though we didn’t get charged a haircut, we had a risk management process where we calculated our hypothetical working capital. We went through every trade and said, “Suppose we are in a really stressful time, how much would the haircut be?”

随着长期基金的投资策略日益多元化，该基金也开始敢于扩大仓位。它着眼于整体投资组合，因此愿意将更多“风险”资金投入到规模更大的交易中。当然，其理论依据是，多笔杠杆交易同时崩盘的可能性很小，就像保险公司不会预期所有客户都会同时提出索赔一样。

As Long-Term’s strategies grew more diverse, the fund felt comfortable taking bigger positions. It focused on its portfolio as a whole, and thus it was willing to pile bigger trades onto each of its “risk” dollars back in the vault. The theory, of course, was that the likelihood of many leveraged trades collapsing simultaneously was slim, just as an insurer does not expect that all of its clients will file claims simultaneously.

事实上，长期基金正是这样看待自己的：它把自己定位为金融风险的保险人。实际上，该基金通过持有流动性较差、风险通常较高的债券来赚取保费——这些保费指的是它从非活跃的国债、抵押贷款债券、意大利债券等产品中获得的利差。当然，保险的弊端在于，需要一段时间才能判断保费是否足够。一家财产保险公司在没有严重风暴的年份里总能盈利。但经过这样一年，甚至连续几年的良好业绩之后，我们有理由质疑：这家保险公司真的那么优秀，还是仅仅运气好？保费是否足够，还是它为太多建在木桩上的海滨房屋签发了廉价保单——而几乎没有考虑潜在的索赔风险？如果长期基金持有的每一只债券实际上都是一份“保单”，那么它承保的保单数量——以及它未来可能面临的损失——都会随着杠杆率的增加而增长。合伙人本可以问问自己，为了获得 59% 的股份，他们付出了多大的努力？风暴过后，他们可能会面临什么样的索赔？

Indeed, Long-Term thought of itself in exactly those terms: as an insurer of financial risk. In effect, the fund pocketed premiums for the hazard of owning less liquid and generally riskier bonds—the premiums being the spreads that it earned on off-the-run Treasurys, mortgage IOs, Italian bonds, and so forth. Of course, the rub with insurance is that it takes a while before one can tell whether the premium is adequate. A property and casualty insurer will always make money in a year without serious storms. But after such a year or even several good years, it is fair to ask, Was the insurer that good, or was it merely lucky? Were the premiums adequate, or was it writing too many inexpensive insurance policies for seaside homes on wooden stilts—with little thought to the potential for claims? And if each of Long-Term’s bonds was, in effect, a “policy,” the number of policies it insured—and the level of losses it could someday face—would grow with each added dollar of leverage. The question the partners could have asked themselves was, how hard had they stretched to make that 59 percent, and what sort of claims might they face after a storm?

5

5

拔河比赛

TUG-OF-WAR

这个小团队……试图将最好的金融理论与最好的金融实践相结合。

This small group . . . attempted to marry the best of finance theory with the best of finance practice.

——罗伯特· M ·厄顿





—ROBERT MERTON





所谓的“暴风雨季”，似乎永远不会到来。长期基金不仅盈利惊人，而且出奇地稳定，仿佛违背了自然规律。这只基金就像一个击球手，力量十足却从未被三振出局。合伙人们步履稳健地走上击球区，日复一日地连续击出安打。他们信心倍增，加大了杠杆力度。到1996年春季，长期基金的资产规模已高达1400亿美元，是其基础资本的30倍。尽管99%的美国人仍然不知道长期基金的存在，但它的规模却是最大的共同基金富达麦哲伦基金的2.5倍，是第二大对冲基金的4倍。¹ 梅里韦瑟、希利布兰德、哈加尼等人如今掌控的资产规模超过了雷曼兄弟和摩根士丹利，并且与所罗门兄弟的规模也仅一步之遥。尽管他们只有二三十名交易员，但他们成立仅两年的基金规模却超过了华尔街一些历史悠久的机构。这就像一枚隐形导弹，交由所谓的专家掌管，其威力之可怕，是普通投资者难以想象的。

THE RANDOM BAD MONTH, the season of storms, seemed never to come. Long-Term was not only phenomenally profitable, it was eerily consistent, as though defying a law of nature. The fund resembled a batter who hit for power but never struck out. The partners strode to the plate and rapped hit after hit, day after day. More confident than ever, they lengthened their swing, which is to say they leveraged further. By the spring of 1996, Long-Term had an astounding $140 billion in assets, thirty times its underlying capital. Though still unknown to 99 percent of Americans, Long-Term was two and a half times as big as Fidelity Magellan, the largest mutual fund, and four times the size of the next largest hedge fund.¹ Meriwether, Hilibrand, Haghani, and company now controlled more assets than Lehman Brothers and Morgan Stanley and were within shouting distance of Salomon. Though they had only a couple dozen traders, their fund—barely two years old—was bigger than some of Wall Street’s age-old institutions. A stealth missile trusted to the care of supposed experts, it had a fearsome potency unimaginable to the man on the street.

然而，对于其合作银行而言，长期投资公司的情况并非秘密。事后，有大量报道称，华尔街竟然对长期投资公司膨胀的资产总额和杠杆率毫不知情。美林证券甚至在一份新闻稿中表示：“1998年9月21日，我们才第一次了解到其持仓的总体规模和杠杆水平。”² 科曼斯基本人也宣称，长期投资公司缺乏“透明度”让他对此毫不知情，而其他几位华尔街首席执行官也表示，他们对长期投资公司的杠杆率感到震惊。³

However, Long-Term was not a secret to its banks. After the event, it was widely reported that Wall Street had somehow been ignorant of Long-Term’s swollen asset total and leverage ratio. Merrill Lynch would go so far as to state in a press release, “On September 21, [1998,] this was the first time that we learned the overall size and scale of the positions and extent of leverage.”² Komansky personally declared that Long-Term’s lack of “transparency” had kept him in the dark, and various other Wall Street CEOs professed to be shocked at Long-Term’s leverage.³

严格来说，这或许属实。科曼斯基和科尔津可能并不知情，但他们的下属却心知肚明。长期证券公司每季度向银行披露其总资产和负债，每月向投资者披露。该公司还向商品期货交易委员会（CFTC）报告了这些数据。然而，其衍生品总额仅每年披露一次——频率太低，不足以准确反映这家快速增长的公司的情况。尽管如此，这些数字（只要稍加留意）就表明，大事正在酝酿。截至1995年底，长期证券公司披露的衍生品押注总额高达6500亿美元——这可不是小数目。正如CFTC主席布鲁克斯利·伯恩坦率地承认的那样：“我们没有发现任何重大警示信号，而且我们知道这些信息相当公开。”长期证券公司的外部律师托马斯·贝尔的观点比大多数人都要正确，他指出：“人们收到了报表，问题在于未能将这些信息联系起来。”

In a strict sense, this may have been true. Komansky and Corzine may have not known. But people beneath them knew. Long-Term disclosed its total assets and liabilities to its banks on a quarterly basis and to investors every month. Long-Term also reported those numbers to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. It reported its derivative totals only annually—too infrequently to give an accurate picture of such a fast-growing firm. Still, the numbers indicated (to anyone who cared to look) that something big was brewing. Long-Term disclosed derivative bets as of the end of 1995 on a total of $650 billion of securities—not exactly chicken feed.4 As Brooksley Born, chairwoman of the CFTC, would candidly admit, “We didn’t see any major warning bells and we knew [the information] was fairly widely available.”5 Thomas Bell, Long-Term’s outside counsel, was more right than most when he observed, “People got statements. It was a failure to connect the dots.”

但这并非全部真相。仅凭长期投资公司含糊不清的披露信息，几乎毫无意义。除了“利率互换”或“政府债券”等笼统的说法外，根本无法得知其资产究竟是什么。衍生品披露尤其晦涩难懂。试想一下，如果你向当地银行申请个人贷款，却只提供“房地产资产”信息，而不说明这些房产是在阿巴拉契亚山脉还是在比佛利山庄，你会作何感想？

But this was not the whole picture either. On their own, Long-Term’s vaguely worded disclosures were next to meaningless. Aside from broad generalizations such as “interest rate swaps” or “government securities,” it was impossible to tell what its assets were. The derivative disclosures were especially opaque. Imagine asking your local bank for a personal loan on the basis of your “real estate assets” without bothering to say whether the real estate was in Appalachia or in Beverly Hills.

对于特定资产——例如抵押贷款证券或意大利债券——每家银行只了解自身对长期证券的风险敞口。高盛并不知道所罗门兄弟可能在为类似的交易提供融资；摩根大通也不知道美林证券在重复发放摩根的贷款。因此，理论上，每家银行都不知道长期证券在任何特定交易中的规模有多大。但实际上，银行完全有能力进行估算。债券套利市场相对较小。当然，银行也足够了解情况，会要求长期证券提供更具体的披露信息。而且，如果得不到满意的答复，银行当然也可以拒绝与长期证券进行业务往来。

With regard to particular assets—say, mortgage securities or Italian bonds—each bank knew only its own exposure to Long-Term. Goldman Sachs had no idea that Salomon might be financing a similar trade; J. P. Morgan would not have known that Merrill Lynch was duplicating Morgan’s loans. So in theory, each bank had no notion of how big Long-Term was in any particular trade. But in practice, the banks were in a good position to estimate. The world of bond arbitrage is relatively small. Certainly, the banks knew enough to ask for more specific disclosure. And of course, they could have declined to do business with Long-Term if satisfactory answers were not forthcoming.

但各家银行争相拓展对冲基金业务，而非减少。牛市持续五年，银行流动性充裕，对冲基金交易成为华尔街利用其过剩资本的有利可图的途径。银行通过一种被称为“出租资产负债表”的做法来实现这一点——实际上，就是将自身庞大的借贷能力转移给信用评级较低的对冲基金，而每100美元的信贷额度，银行仅收取几美分的费用。据称，长期投资公司（Long-Term）是华尔街最大的对冲基金客户，每年向华尔街支付1亿至2亿美元的费用，而每家银行都想尽可能多地分一杯羹。6 “银行争先恐后地赚取20个基点（百分之二十）的利润”——考虑到其中蕴含的风险，这简直微不足道，当时雷曼兄弟公司的交易经理约翰·苏科（John Succo）指出。

But the banks were fighting to do more hedge fund business, not less. Five years into a bull market, the banks were awash in liquidity, and the hedge fund trade was a lucrative way for Wall Street to employ its surplus capital. The banks accomplished this by a practice known as “renting out the balance sheet”—literally, transferring their enormous borrowing power to hedge funds with lesser credit ratings, a service for which they charged mere pennies on every $100 of credit. Long-Term, which was easily the Street’s biggest hedge fund customer, was reputed to be throwing off $100 million to $200 million in fees to Wall Street each year, and each of the banks wanted as big a share of the money as possible.6 “Banks were tripping over themselves to make twenty basis points [20/100 of a percent]”—a trifle given the implied risks, noted John Succo, then a trading manager at Lehman Brothers.

多达55家银行提供长期融资。7受合作伙伴们自信满满的氛围影响，各家银行竞相抬价。“人们以LIBOR（一种私营银行利率）加50个基点放贷，而正确的利率应该是LIBOR加200个基点，”总部位于巴塞尔的瑞士银行债券经理安德鲁·西西里亚诺说道。该银行专门从事衍生品交易。西西里亚诺担心格林威治基金正在占瑞士银行的便宜。这家公司对所有交易对手都施加了最大压力。

As many as fifty-five banks were giving Long-Term financing.7 Dazzled by the partners’ air of infallibility, the banks raced to top one another’s offers. “People were lending them money at LIBOR [a private-sector bank rate] plus fifty basis points when it should have been LIBOR plus two hundred points,” said Andrew Siciliano, the bond manager at the Basel-based Swiss Bank, which specialized in derivative trading. Siciliano worried that the Greenwich fund was getting the better of Swiss Bank. The firm squeezed every counterparty to the max.

长期基金巧妙地利用了银行对手续费的渴求，迫使它们以最有利的条件开展业务。该基金的交易利润率极低，银行原本可以从服务如此庞大的基金中获得的利润几乎为零。但银行始终梦想着长期基金最终能为它们带来丰厚的利润；就像沮丧却又充满希望的父母一样，它们不断地用各种好处来“犒劳”自己那“不听话的孩子”。美林证券和所罗门兄弟公司是长期基金最大的金主，至少在融资方面是如此。所罗门兄弟公司将长期基金视为其最大的客户，尤其是在欧洲互换交易方面，但两家公司错综复杂的历史背景使它们始终保持着谨慎的距离。

Long-Term deftly exploited the banks’ hunger for fees, pushing them to do business on the most advantageous of terms. The fund traded on razor-thin margins, cutting out the normal profit the banks could expect from servicing such a behemoth. But the banks didn’t stop dreaming that Long-Term would deliver them a profit at the end of the rainbow; like frustrated but hopeful parents, they kept favoring their incorrigible child with treats. Merrill Lynch and Salomon Brothers were Long-Term’s biggest sugar daddies, at least in terms of financing. Salomon counted Long-Term as its biggest customer, especially in European swaps,8 but the two firms’ intertwined histories kept them at a wary distance.

另一方面，美林证券越来越渴望与长期投资公司建立密切关系。而这家对冲基金也乐于以自己的方式进行回报。JM很快与美林证券董事长丹尼尔·塔利（Daniel Tully）结为好友，塔利家族和梅里韦瑟家族四人结成了“铁杆”关系。JM甚至让塔利成为沃特维尔高尔夫球场的合伙人，该球场位于JM在爱尔兰凯里郡的高尔夫球场内。对于塔利来说，这巩固了双方迅速建立的商业联盟，因为他对自己的祖籍地如此热爱，以至于签名时都用绿色。美林证券的下属很快意识到，董事长将长期投资公司视为特殊客户。“不仅是销售人员，整个公司都有责任支持这段关系，”塔利强调说。

Merrill Lynch, on the other hand, was increasingly eager to nuzzle up to Long-Term. And the hedge fund was happy to reciprocate—on its own terms. J.M. quickly befriended Daniel Tully, the Merrill Lynch chairman, and the Tullys and Meriwethers became a foursome. J.M. even made Tully a partner in Waterville, J.M.’s golf course in County Kerry, Ireland. To Tully, who was so devoted to his ancestral homeland that he signed his name in green, this cemented an already fast business alliance. Underlings at Merrill quickly grasped that the chairman considered Long-Term to be a special client. “It was incumbent not just on the salesperson but on the entire organization to get behind the relationship,” Tully stressed.9

JM也和科曼斯基以及赫伯·艾利森亲切交谈，他们正伺机接替塔利的职位。JM向来擅长在赌徒圈子里混，他带着美林的老板们去了贝尔蒙特赛马场，他在那里寄养马匹。JM一贯喜欢问很多问题，让客人畅所欲言，艾利森注意到，他能记住所有答案——甚至包括一些小事，比如艾利森妻子的名字——就像他能记住交易一样。JM一直很会倾听。在这个尔虞我诈的行业里，他为人正直，显得格外引人注目。“你不可能不喜欢他，”艾利森心想。10

J.M. also nuzzled up to Komansky and Herb Allison, who were waiting in the wings to take the reins from Tully. Always comfortable in betting fraternities, J.M. took the Merrill bosses to Belmont, a racetrack where he boarded horses. Typically, J.M. asked a lot of questions and let his guests do the talking, and Allison noticed that he remembered the answers—even little things, such as the name of Allison’s wife—just as he remembered trades. J.M. was always a good listener. In such a sharp-elbowed business, he stuck out as essentially decent. “You couldn’t help but like him,” Allison thought.10

长期投资公司（Long-Term）成功吸引美林证券（Merrill）的关键，在于每年在沃特维尔（Waterville）举办的为期三天的国际高尔夫球赛。沃特维尔球场享誉国际，曾接待过包括泰格·伍兹在内的众多高尔夫巨星。每家公司约有十几人参加，美林的高管们会用私人飞机陪同部分长期投资公司的合伙人前往，不过各公司自行承担费用。沃特维尔风景如画，绿草茵茵，毗邻一个古朴的爱尔兰海滨小镇。每年九月举行的这场精英盛会，其邀请函在美林公司炙手可热，公司甚至印制了印有绿、白、橙三色方格图案的“沃特维尔国际杯”T恤，这三色正是爱尔兰的代表色。比赛间隙，高尔夫球手们垂钓、享用丰盛的晚餐，然后入住舒适的民宿。早起的球手则享受着黎明时分独自挥杆、将球击入大海的壮丽景象。

The high point of Long-Term’s seduction of Merrill was an annual three-day golf competition at Waterville, an internationally renowned course that had been host to, among others, Tiger Woods. About a dozen attended from each firm, with the Merrill executives escorting some of the Long-Term partners in private jets, though each company paid its own way. Waterville was an enchanting place, carved from lush natural grasses, adjacent to a quaint seaside Irish village. Invitations to the elite affair, held each September, were hot items at Merrill, which printed “Waterville International Cup” shirts bearing checkerboards in green, white, and orange, the Irish colors. In their off-hours the golfers fished and feasted on sumptuous dinners; then they retired to an intimate bed-and-breakfast. Early risers enjoyed the solitary splendor of lofting drives into the ocean at dawn.

对梅里韦瑟来说，沃特维尔象征着他从在弗洛斯莫尔当球童一路走来的历程。他热情洋溢，乐于参与竞争，认真记录着每一杆，但也不忘在艾莉森出手时给予指导。在差点为4的球员JM的带领下，“长期”队年复一年地赢得沃特维尔杯，这让银行家们对他们的竞争精神赞叹不已。美林团队对这些套利交易员印象深刻，他们打高尔夫球的热情丝毫不亚于他们的交易技巧。美林风险经理丹尼尔·那不勒斯打趣道：“如果他们能拿到高尔夫博士学位，他们肯定会去拿。”美林外汇交易主管斯蒂芬·贝洛蒂在某个周末转向迈伦·斯科尔斯，开玩笑地问道：“迈伦，你更看重的是钱还是脑子？”斯科尔斯脱口而出：“脑子，不过也差不多了！”

For Meriwether, Waterville symbolized the distance he had come from caddying at Flossmoor. He was an animated host, thriving on the competition and taking note of every shot, but not neglecting to give Allison pointers on his release. Led by J.M., a four-handicap player, Long-Term won the Waterville Cup year after year, prompting the bankers to whistle at Long-Term’s competitive spirit. The Merrill team was impressed with the arbitrageurs, who golfed with as much élan as they traded. Daniel Napoli, Merrill’s risk manager, quipped, “If they could have earned a Ph.D. at golf, they would have.” Stephen Bellotti, who ran foreign currency trading at Merrill, turned to Myron Scholes at one of these weekends and playfully demanded, “Myron, what do you have more of—money or brains?” Scholes shot back: “Brains, but it’s getting close!”

随着业务关系日益密切，长期投资公司开始向美林证券施压，要求获得更多融资。负责长期投资公司与美林证券关系的莱希（Leahy）常说：“如果你们想让我们做交易，就得给我们提供更多资产负债表。” 美林证券逐渐放宽了融资要求。到1996年，美林证券提供的回购融资额高达65亿美元（大致相当于美林证券的总股本），衍生品融资额也相应增加。但除了在爱尔兰享受愉快的周末之外，美林证券究竟得到了什么回报却不得而知。长期投资公司只是大幅压低了报价和要价，只为给经纪商留下正常的利润。经纪商或许会提出异议，但长期投资公司却毫不妥协。

As the business relationship grew closer, Long-Term began to push Merrill Lynch for more financing. Leahy, who managed the relationship for Long-Term, would say, “If you want us to trade, you got to give us more balance sheet.” Gradually, Merrill opened the spigot. By 1996, it was providing $6.5 billion of repo financing (roughly equal to Merrill’s total equity) and proportionately more on the derivative side. But aside from pleasant weekends in Ireland, it wasn’t clear what Merrill was getting in return. Long-Term simply shaved too much from the bid and asked prices to leave a normal profit for its broker. The broker might squawk, but Long-Term wouldn’t budge.

有一次，美林回购部门的一名员工以美林对这家高风险对冲基金的投资敞口不断增加为由，拒绝批准更多信贷。但就在两家公司下一个高尔夫球周末活动前不久，这位回购员接到了一位焦急的销售员的电话：“我要去见迪克·莱希！我们不想丢脸。再追加五亿美元怎么样？” 回购员拒绝后，销售员补充道：“你必须做这些交易，否则我们就丢掉生意了。”

At one point, citing Merrill’s growing exposure to the high-risk hedge fund, a person on Merrill’s repo desk refused to approve more credit. But shortly before the firms’ next golf weekend, the repo man heard from an anxious salesman: “I’m going to see Dick Leahy! We don’t want to be embarrassed. How about putting on another five hundred million dollars?” When the repo man resisted, the salesman added, “You gotta do these trades, or we lose the business.”

美林证券的销售人员急于推销他们的“黄金客户”，他们辩解说，为“长期投资公司”（Long-Term）提供融资是与该公司进行交易的关键，而交易则能让美林掌握“长期投资公司”的订单流。当然，由于美林只能看到每笔交易的单方信息，这些信息的价值值得怀疑。融资部门和销售部门之间通常存在的良性竞争，在“长期投资公司”一方占据了绝对优势，因为美林内部的人都知道这个客户“非同寻常”。“长期投资公司”可以随意动用公司各个层级的关系，而且他们也确实这么做了。这一切始于董事长塔利，他曾是一名经纪人，对美林赢得“长期投资公司”如此多的业务感到“无比自豪”。就连被一些人嘲讽为冷酷无情的财务主管艾利森，也被“长期投资公司”的光环所吸引，并敦促下属拓展与该公司的关系。“每个人都被他们的才智所折服，”销售员邓利维回忆道。 “那就像肯尼迪的核心圈子——卡米洛特！他们拥有最优秀、最聪明的人才。”

Merrill salesmen, eager to promote their prize account, rationalized that financing Long-Term was the key to being able to trade with the firm and that trading would enable Merrill to see Long-Term’s order flow. Of course, since Merrill saw only one side of each trade, the information was of dubious value. The usually healthy tension between the financing and sales desks was tilted in Long-Term’s favor, because people at Merrill knew the account was “special.” Long-Term felt free to tap friends at every level of the firm and did so. This started with Tully, the chairman, a former broker who was “damn proud” that Merrill had won so much of Long-Term’s business. Even Allison, whom some derided as a hard-edged bean counter, got caught up in Long-Term’s glamour and urged his underlings to expand the relationship. “Everybody was enamored with their intellect,” Dunleavy, the salesman, recalled. “It was like Kennedy’s inner circle—Camelot! They had the best and the brightest.”

然而，美林的管理层最终开始感到不安——并非因为长期投资公司的杠杆，而是因为美林每年从该账户中仅赚取2500万美元，考虑到两家公司的业务规模，这简直是九牛一毛。融资部门开始反击：既然美林的资产负债表是宝贵的资源，为什么要浪费在一个吝啬的客户身上呢？

However, the Merrill executives eventually grew uneasy—not because of Long-Term’s leverage, but because Merrill was making only $25 million a year off the account, peanuts considering the two firms’ level of business. The financing desk began to fight back: Since Merrill’s balance sheet was a precious resource, why squander it on a chintzy client?

负责美林与大型机构（包括长期投资公司）业务的艾利森最终把JM叫到一边，略带讽刺地建议，美林或许也应该从交易中赚点钱。和其他与长期投资公司打交道的人一样，艾利森觉得合伙人分析每一笔交易时，都只关注单笔交易的盈亏，而忽略了整体关系。他也把这些话告诉了梅里韦瑟。

Allison, who was in charge of Merrill’s business with big institutions, including Long-Term, finally took J.M. aside, suggesting ironically that it might be nice for Merrill to make a little money on its trades, too. Like others who dealt with Long-Term, Allison felt that the partners analyzed every deal in terms of the profit and loss on discrete trades rather than in terms of the overall relationship. And he said as much to Meriwether.

JM 表示理解，但长期投资公司仍然不遗余力地向美林施压。这家公司似乎故意装聋作哑，即便冒着破坏关键联盟的风险也在所不惜。有一次，他们利用贷款文件中的技术漏洞，从美林身上榨取了700万美元。当一位高管提出抗议时，JM 皱着眉头说：“我没注意到。”但他并没有退让。

J.M. replied sympathetically, but Long-Term kept squeezing Merrill all the same. The firm seemed willfully tone-deaf, even at the risk of souring key alliances. One time, it took advantage of a technical loophole in a loan document to make $7 million at Merrill’s expense. When an executive protested, J.M. frowned and said, “I didn’t realize.” But he didn’t back down.

“他很真诚，”美林的一位高管说。“他看待世界的方式就是这样：有人赢，有人输。”

“He was sincere,” the Merrill executive said. “It was how he looked at the world: someone wins, someone loses.”

令人愤慨的是，合伙人拒绝将公司机密托付给美林，却期望获得美林债券承销的大笔份额——这可是投资银行通常只留给最尊贵客户的肥差。更令人恼火的是，长期基金试图向美林推销一份由迈伦·斯科尔斯炮制出来的非同寻常的认股权证。这份认股权证本可以让合伙人以低成本的方式将更多资金投入到自己的基金中，却让美林面临巨大的风险。美林断然拒绝。此时，这位著名的牛市投资者开始躁动不安。美林开始收回部分资产负债表份额，但它仍然是长期基金最大的银行之一。

Insultingly, the partners refused to trust Merrill with the firm’s secrets but expected to get big slugs of Merrill Lynch bond underwritings, a plum that investment banks reserve for the choicest clients. Even more galling, Long-Term tried to sell Merrill on an unusual warrant that had been concocted by Myron Scholes. The warrant would have been a cheap way for the partners to bet more money on their own fund—while exposing Merrill to serious risk. Merrill quickly refused. By now, the famous bull was growing restless. Merrill began to take back some of its balance sheet, though it remained one of Long-Term’s biggest bankers.

美林很想为长期基金提供清算服务，但长期基金拒绝了，因为他们已经从贝尔斯登获得了这项服务。贝尔斯登是JM的朋友，名叫文森特·马托内，他之前在所罗门兄弟公司工作过。清算经纪商承担着许多至关重要的职能，例如记录保存和结算交易。虽然清算通常是一项利润丰厚的业务，但贝尔斯登同意给予长期基金优厚的条件，因为它也希望获得更多长期基金的交易业务。贝尔斯登还借钱给六七位合伙人，让他们增加在基金中的个人投资。然而，长期基金很快发现，贝尔斯登可不是好惹的。

Merrill was dying to clear Long-Term’s trades, but Long-Term refused, because it got this service from Bear Stearns, where J.M. had a friend, Vincent Mattone, who had formerly been with Salomon. Clearing brokers perform many vital functions, such as record keeping and settling trades. Though clearing is usually a lucrative business, Bear had agreed to give Long-Term attractive terms because it, too, hoped to get more of Long-Term’s trading business. Bear also lent money to six or seven of the partners so they could raise their personal investments in the fund. However, Long-Term quickly discovered that Bear could not be pushed around.

首先，贝尔斯登拒绝像长期证券那样以不减记的方式提供大量融资。此外，贝尔斯登也不愿将过多的资本投入长期证券。其最重要的清算功能是提供日内信贷。对于每天可能进行数百笔交易的长期证券而言，贝尔斯登实际上扮演着银行的角色，持有长期证券的大量资产，并代表长期证券与世界各地的交易对手进行资金往来。

For one thing, Bear refused to do much financing on Long-Term’s usual no-haircut basis. What’s more, Bear was wary about risking too much of its capital on Long-Term. The most important clearing function is providing intraday credit. For Long-Term, which might do hundreds of trades in a day, Bear in effect acted as a bank, holding many of Long-Term’s assets and paying and receiving monies on Long-Term’s behalf to and from counterparties around the world.

如果没有清算经纪商，长期证券公司（Long-Term）根本无法运营——至少无法像往常那样灵活高效地运作。此外，主经纪商通常有权在不事先通知的情况下停止清算，而且很难迅速找到新的清算经纪商。因此，长期证券公司对贝尔斯登的依赖程度远超其他任何公司。而对于一家华尔街经纪公司来说，贝尔斯登本身就是一个特立独行的地方。年近七旬的董事长艾伦·格林伯格（Alan Greenberg）厌恶摩根家族和美林家族的官僚作风。他仍然坐在交易大厅里，接电话时总是粗声粗气地问候一声。他以告诫员工不要浪费回形针而闻名。格林伯格的合伙人、首席执行官詹姆斯·凯恩（James Cayne）在20世纪70年代纽约债券市场举步维艰时，凭借敢于开拓市场而声名鹊起，当时年轻的JM也曾尝试过类似的策略。在格林伯格和凯恩毫不妥协的管理下，贝尔斯登的经营风格随意、务实，并且始终以自身利益为中心。这令长期投资者感到担忧。

Without a clearing broker, Long-Term would not have been able to operate—at least not with anything like its customary flexibility or speed. Moreover, a prime broker typically has the right to stop clearing without notice, and it is difficult to get a new clearing broker in a hurry. Therefore, Long-Term was dependent on Bear Stearns to a greater extent than on any other firm. And for a Wall Street brokerage, Bear was an unconventional place. Alan Greenberg, the nearly septuagenarian chairman, despised the bureaucratic airs of the Morgans and the Merrills. He still sat on the trading floor and answered his phone with a gruff hello. He was famous for exhorting employees not to waste paper clips. Greenberg’s partner, James Cayne, the chief executive, had made his name by daring to make a market in New York City bonds in the difficult 1970s, when a young J.M. had been pursuing a similar strategy. Under Greenberg’s and Cayne’s unflinching management, Bear was informal, pragmatic, and relentlessly focused on its own self-interest. This worried Long-Term.

1994年，就在Long-Term公司刚刚起步之际，对冲基金Askin Capital——这家在抵押贷款市场遭受重创的基金——在贝尔斯登发出追缴保证金通知后倒闭。自此，Long-Term公司一直被贝尔斯登掌握着所有主动权的现实所困扰。1996年，合伙人开始积极寻求变革。

In 1994, as Long-Term was getting off the ground, Askin Capital, the hedge fund that had suffered crushing losses in the mortgage market, had collapsed after Bear had issued a margin call. The realization that Bear held all the cards had been gnawing at Long-Term ever since. In 1996, the partners began to agitate for a change.

Long-Term希望Bear公司以合同形式承诺，即使该对冲基金遭遇严重问题，Bear仍会继续为其清算交易。但Bear也担心自身的安全。如果Bear继续为一家基金清算至“零美元”，一旦该基金最终破产，Bear可能被迫兑现那些仓促达成的交易。简而言之，Long-Term和Bear都担心对方会对自己造成损害。

What Long-Term wanted was a contractual promise from Bear that it would continue to clear Long-Term’s trades, even if the hedge fund encountered serious problems. But the broker was worried about its own security. If Bear continued to clear a fund down to “dollar zero,” it could be forced to make good on eleventh-hour desperation trades should the fund eventually collapse. In short, Long-Term and Bear were each worried about the other’s ability to do it harm.

经过多次会谈，双方最终达成了一项粗略的协议。基本上，贝尔斯登愿意承诺继续为长期基金提供清算服务，前提是该对冲基金在贝尔斯登保持15亿美元的待售资金。虽然长期基金可以接受这一条件，但双方合伙人希望在正式签署协议前解决一些其他问题；其中最主要的一点，也是他们极具先见之明的一点，是他们急于在危机期间保障长期基金的灵活性。希利布兰德在阅读了有关阿斯金事件的报道后意识到，如果长期基金真的陷入困境，贝尔斯登将有能力强制清算，甚至可能以极低的价格出售。贝尔斯登还可能泄露长期基金的持仓情况，从而引发一波抛售潮。因此，希利布兰德希望确保长期基金有权追究贝尔斯登的任何侵权行为的责任，例如违反长期基金的保密义务。

Over many meetings, the two sides came to a rough agreement. Basically, Bear was willing to promise to keep clearing for Long-Term as long as the hedge fund kept $1.5 billion on call at Bear. Though this was acceptable to Long-Term, the partners wanted to resolve some other issues before they signed; chiefly, and with uncanny prescience, they were anxious to protect Long-Term’s flexibility during a crisis. Hilibrand, having read reports of the Askin debacle, realized that if Long-Term ever did stumble, Bear would be able to force a liquidation, perhaps at fire-sale prices. Bear would also be in a position to divulge Long-Term’s positions, potentially setting off a wave of selling. Thus, Hilibrand wanted to nail down Long-Term’s right to hold Bear liable for any abuses, such as breaching Long-Term’s confidentiality.

希利布兰德一如既往地咄咄逼人，不断向贝尔斯登施压。贝尔斯登的高级信贷主管迈克尔·艾利克斯认为希利布兰德极其难缠，甚至有些偏执，尽管他的一些担忧后来被证明不无道理。同样参与谈判的魅力十足的埃里克·罗森菲尔德似乎能够理解贝尔斯登的立场，而希利布兰德却无法理解。谈判如同法庭辩论，希利布兰德总能提出各种论点。双方在日益沮丧的气氛中继续谈判，但最终却一无所获。希利布兰德竭力阻止这项备受期待的清算协议的达成。

In typical Hilibrand style, he relentlessly hammered away at Bear. Michael Alix, a senior credit executive at Bear, thought Hilibrand extremely difficult and a trifle paranoid, though some of his concerns would turn out to have merit. The winsome Eric Rosenfeld, who also took part in the talks, seemed able to see Bear’s point of view; Hilibrand couldn’t. The discussions were like a legal case in which Hilibrand never ran out of arguments. The parties negotiated in mounting frustration, but nothing was signed. Hilibrand was pushing the much-sought-after clearing agreement out of sight.

长期基金也在向大通曼哈顿银行施压。该基金似乎想把整个华尔街都拉进它的掌控之中，而合伙人也足够精明，他们意识到现在正是拉拢银行的最佳时机，因为业绩良好。1994年，大通银行拒绝成为长期基金的交易对手，认为它成立时间太短。但当JM在1996年再次出现时，情况就大不相同了。JM在大通银行也有人脉：大卫·普弗鲁格，这位身材魁梧的全球信贷主管负责华尔街客户的贷款业务。这位穿着吊带裤、说话直率的普弗鲁格（发音为“弗鲁格”）曾在莫泽危机期间为JM提供咨询，当时他成功说服陷入困境的所罗门兄弟公司安排紧急信贷。如今，在1996年，普弗鲁格同意通过利率互换为长期基金提供融资——通常情况下，一方同意向另一方支付固定利率，以换取随市场浮动的利率。摩根大通还支持长期基金进行收益率曲线交易——这同样是固定收益交易员的常用策略。长期基金通过向摩根大通出售其基金2000万美元的投资，进一步深化了双方的合作关系。

Long-Term was also pressing Chase Manhattan. The fund seemed to want to draw all of Wall Street into its web, and the partners were shrewd enough to realize that the time to line up banks was now, when results were good. Chase had declined to become a counter-party in 1994, feeling that Long-Term was too new. But when J.M. returned in 1996, the reception was warmer. J.M. had a contact at Chase, too: David Pflug, the portly head of global credit, who handled loans to clients on Wall Street. The suspendered, blunt-spoken Pflug (pronounced “Fluge”) had advised J.M. during the Mozer crisis, when he had convinced the beleaguered Salomon Brothers to arrange for emergency credit. Now, in 1996, Pflug agreed to finance Long-Term on interest rate swaps—in which, typically, one side agrees to pay the other a fixed rate of interest in return for receiving a rate that floats with the market. Chase also backed Long-Term on yield-curve trades—again, a standard sonata in the fixed-income trader’s repertoire. Long-Term deepened its new alliance by selling Chase a $20 million investment in the fund.

但长期基金真正想要的是一个合作伙伴——一家能在它有特殊需求（甚至是紧急情况）时随时提供现金的银行。在与美林证券、贝尔斯登银行以及现在的摩根大通银行的无休止谈判中，合伙人似乎一直在寻找一家能像所罗门兄弟公司那样坚定支持它的机构。普夫鲁格对此表示理解，并安排了一笔来自大型银行财团的5亿美元循环贷款——换句话说，这是一笔长期基金可以根据需要随时动用的备用资金。该银行财团对这家对冲基金表现出了非同寻常的信任，同意在无需基金提供任何抵押品的情况下提供循环贷款。

But what Long-Term really wanted was a partner—a bank that would give it cash on demand when special needs (or even emergency needs) arose. In the partners’ endless negotiations with Merrill, Bear, and now Chase, they seemed to be looking for a firm that would support them as resolutely as Salomon had. Pflug was sympathetic and arranged for a $500 million revolving loan from a large syndicate of banks—in other words, a standby facility that Long-Term could tap as needed. The bank syndicate demonstrated unusual faith in the hedge fund by agreeing to fund the revolver without the fund’s having to put up any collateral.

随后，长远基金（Long-Term）如虎添翼，开始向摩根大通施压。几位合伙人开始向银行施压，要求出售一种特殊的认股权证。当然，这正是他们之前向美林证券（Merrill）申请但未获批准的同一种认股权证。认股权证是一种期权；合伙人想要获得一份以他们自己基金为标的的认股权证，以便在投资组合中已有的巨额杠杆基础上，再增加一层个人杠杆。尽管他们几乎将所有个人资产都投入了该基金，但合伙人，尤其是希利布兰德（Hilibrand），仍然渴望获得更多投资机会。他们存在一个奇怪的盲点：尽管他们为了获得一份能在危机期间保护他们的清算协议而拼死抵抗，但在投资自有资金时，他们似乎从未考虑过失败的可能性。

Then, with the revolver in its pocket, Long-Term turned up the heat on Chase. Various of the partners began to push the bank to sell them a peculiar warrant. Of course, this was the same warrant they had sought, without success, from Merrill. A warrant is an option; the partners wanted a warrant on their own fund to add a layer of personal leverage to the enormous leverage already in the portfolio. Even though they had virtually all of their personal assets in the fund, the partners, especially Hilibrand, were hot for more exposure. They suffered from a curious blind spot; though they fought like tigers for a clearing agreement that would protect them during a crisis, when it came to investing their own capital, they seemed not to consider the possibility of failing.

认股权证会使摩根大通面临难以承受的风险。根据斯科尔斯的方案，合伙人每年需向银行支付约1500万美元，具体金额取决于利率。作为回报，摩根大通将向合伙人支付他们在2亿美元基金份额中应得的收益。如果基金持续飙升，摩根大通将承担巨额潜在负债，而支付的金额却微不足道。理论上，摩根大通可以通过购买部分基金份额来对冲风险。这样，如果基金价值上涨，摩根大通就能从投资中获利。

The warrant would have exposed Chase to untenable risks. Under Scholes’s plan, the partners would pay the bank about $15 million a year, give or take, depending on interest rates. In return, Chase would pay the partners whatever they would have earned on a $200 million slice of the fund. For relative peanuts, Chase would be committing to a huge potential liability if the fund continued to skyrocket. In theory, Chase could hedge its risk by buying some of the fund for itself. Then, if the value of the fund rose, Chase would make a profit on its investment.

但如果基金下跌呢？根据默顿和斯科尔斯提出的期权理论，随着基金价值的下降，摩根大通对冲的需求也会降低。换句话说，如果长期基金下跌，摩根大通会逐步出售与该基金资产结构相似的其他资产。

But what if the fund fell? According to options theory, which Merton and Scholes had of course devised, as the value of the fund decreased, Chase would need less of a hedge. In other words, if Long-Term fell, Chase would want to gradually sell assets that mimicked those in the fund.

但这并非易事，因为长期投资公司的资产是秘密的。合伙人明确拒绝透露这些资产。普夫鲁格对长期投资公司的傲慢感到震惊：合伙人想让摩根大通承担这笔可疑交易的所有风险，却不愿透露风险究竟是什么。“我们到底该如何对冲风险？”普夫鲁格疑惑道。摩根大通对冲基金业务负责人也对此持怀疑态度。

But that would not be so easy, because Long-Term’s assets were secret. And the partners pointedly refused to disclose them. Pflug was stunned by Long-Term’s arrogance: the partners wanted Chase to shoulder all of the risks in this dubious deal without divulging what the risks were. “How the hell are we supposed to hedge it?,” Pflug wondered. The head of Chase’s hedge fund practice was skeptical as well.

但长期投资公司并未放弃认股权证。它包含诸多税收优惠——这对希利布兰德来说总是极具吸引力——因为合伙人可以将认股权证的任何利润作为资本利得申报，并递延至认股权证到期时缴纳。这一策略堪称斯科尔斯的巅峰之作——一种能够以牺牲美国政府利益为代价来提升合伙人利益的选择权。

But Long-Term would not give up on the warrant. It was rich with tax sweeteners—always alluring to Hilibrand—because the partners could claim any profits from the warrant as capital gains and defer them until the warrant expired. The concoction was Scholes’s finest hour—an option that would leverage the partners’ interest at the expense of Uncle Sam.

长期投资公司在银行里到处推销认股权证方案；JM甚至把它带到了摩根大通首席执行官沃尔特·希普利面前。希利布兰德最终提出派斯科尔斯来给银行上一堂期权定价课，但普夫卢格太聪明了，不愿与发明期权定价公式的人正面交锋。“你可以把这些希腊字母过度解读，”普夫卢格反思道，他指的是期权交易员行话中的α、β和γ。“其中一个应该加进去的希腊词是傲慢（hubris）。 ”

Long-Term pitched the warrant scheme all over the bank; J.M. even took it to Walter Shipley, Chase’s chief executive. Hilibrand finally offered to dispatch Scholes to give the bank a lesson on option pricing, but Pflug was too smart to go head-to-head with the guy who had invented the formula. “You can overintellectualize these Greek letters,” Pflug reflected, referring to the alphas, betas, and gammas in the option trader’s argot. “One Greek word that ought to be in there is hubris.”

普夫鲁格究竟察觉到了什么傲慢？这些合伙人举止谈吐并不傲慢，他们的傲慢根深蒂固。那是哈佛和麻省理工出身之人的傲慢——是那些真心相信自己比别人更聪明的人的傲慢。“你知道我们为什么赚这么多钱吗？”格雷格·霍金斯曾问过一位在所罗门公司的老朋友。“因为我们更聪明。”霍金斯甚至还试图就分子生物学——她长期专攻的领域——对一位同事的妻子进行一番说教。“你胡说八道，”她最终这样回答道。

What hubris did Pflug divine? The partners were not arrogant in their mannerisms or even in their speech; it was more deep-seated. It was the arrogance of people who had been to Harvard and MIT—of people who really believed that they were more intelligent than others. “Do you know why we make so much money?” Greg Hawkins once asked an old friend from Salomon. “It’s because we’re smarter.” Once the Hawk even tried to lecture a colleague’s wife about molecular biology, her longtime specialty. “You’re full of shit,” she finally replied.

到1996年，长期投资公司（Long-Term）的员工人数已超过百人，合伙人也积累了巨额财富。一直以来，他们都将外部投资者利润的25%作为管理费收取，而将这部分资金留在基金中，使其免受税务影响，从而加速增值。第三年即将结束时，合伙人在基金中的股份总额已达14亿美元，是最初1.5亿美元投资额的九倍。在如此短的时间内积累如此巨额财富，简直令人难以置信——而且全部来自债券利差！合伙人大胆地不断加倍投资，一夜之间跻身超级富豪之列。与那些通过不断减持股份来对冲风险的企业巨头不同，JM、希利布兰德、罗森菲尔德等人却把每一分钱都留在了基金里。当他们需要用钱时，只需赎回一部分基金，就像使用个人支票账户一样。

By 1996, Long-Term had grown to well over a hundred employees and the partners were building immense fortunes. All along, they had been deferring the 25 percent of the outside investors’ profits that they took as fees, thus leaving the money in the fund, where, untouched by the tax man, it could compound all the faster. As their third year drew to a close, the partners collectively had a stake in the fund of $1.4 billion, nine times their initial $150 million investment. It was an incredible fortune to have made in so little time—and all from bond spreads! The partners’ nervy decision to keep redoubling their bets had vaulted them into the ranks of the superrich overnight. Unlike corporate titans, who hedged their bets by continually peeling off shares, J.M., Hilibrand, Rosenfeld, and the rest left every nickel on the table. When they needed spending money, they simply redeemed a bit of the fund, which they treated like a personal checking account.

以华尔街大亨的标准来看，大多数合伙人都不算挥金如土，而且他们不屑于炫耀。他们常常取笑出声势浩大的霍金斯，因为他竟然包机请室内设计师到他在萨拉托加的乡间别墅——那里靠近霍金斯饲养纯种马的赛马场——进行装修。当霍金斯提议购买一架公司专机时，其他人坚决反对。但他们每个人都有自己挥霍无度的时候。除了沃特维尔高尔夫俱乐部，JM还拥有自己的马匹，以及三家高档高尔夫俱乐部的会员资格——纽约州的翼足高尔夫俱乐部和辛尼科克高尔夫俱乐部，以及加利福尼亚州的柏树岬高尔夫俱乐部。他还喜欢昂贵的汽车，包括一辆法拉利Testa Rossa。罗森菲尔德住在威彻斯特一栋宽敞的海滨别墅里，酷爱葡萄酒。他对葡萄酒的年份记忆犹新，他的酒窖里存放着一万瓶葡萄酒，全部直接从法国进口。仿佛为了给温文尔雅的举止增添一丝灵动，这位前教授几乎每次拜访都会带上一瓶他珍藏的伏旧园（Clos de Vougeot）或其他上等勃艮第葡萄酒。对希利布兰德而言，金钱意味着更多的隐居。他在格林威治一处绿树成荫的私人社区购置了一块15英亩、价值210万美元的地皮，并斥资400万美元建造一座3万平方英尺的豪宅。然而，即便如此挥霍，也难以撼动合伙人的银行账户。对金钱的追求或许是他们生活的重心，但正如常言所说，这远远超出了任何可以想象的生活方式所需。金钱是他们的成绩单，是他们卓越交易技巧的证明。对默顿和斯科尔斯而言，金钱为他们的学术成就增添了一份世俗的认可。

By the standards of Wall Street moguls, most of the partners were not lavish spenders, and they frowned on ostentation. They kidded the free-spending Hawkins for flying in decorators to his country home in Saratoga, near the track where Hawkins kept thoroughbreds. When Hawk suggested they buy a company jet, the others wouldn’t hear of it. But each of them had their moments. J.M. had his horses and memberships in three tony golf clubs—Winged Foot and Shinnecock in New York State and Cypress Point in California—in addition to Waterville.11 He also had a taste for pricey automobiles, including a Ferrari Testa Rossa. Rosenfeld, who lived in a spacious waterfront home in Westchester, indulged a passion for wine. He had a photographic memory for vintages and stocked his ten-thousand-bottle cellar directly from France. As if to add a twinkle to his soft-spoken demeanor, the former professor scarcely went visiting without toting along one of his cherished Clos de Vougeots or other choice Burgundies. For Hilibrand, the money meant added seclusion. He bought a fifteen-acre, $2.1 million plot in a wooded private community in Greenwich and was spending $4 million to build a lavish thirty-thousand-square-foot house.12 But even such indulgences could hardly make a dent in the partners’ bank accounts. The pursuit of money may have been central to their lives, but as is often the case, it went far beyond any conceivable lifestyle needs. The money was a scorecard, a proof of their superlative trading skills. For Merton and Scholes, it added a worldly validation to their academic successes.

围绕股份的争斗司空见惯；就像在所罗门兄弟公司一样，薪酬自然成了发泄内部矛盾的温床。斯廷博特路公司表面上的轻松氛围极具欺骗性，因为它掩盖了潜在的紧张关系，每当控制权、股份或重大投资组合变动等问题浮出水面时，这些紧张关系就会显现出来。急于向上爬的斯科尔斯脾气火爆，他对穆林斯很不友好，两人都觉得自己比对方更聪明。性格随和的南方人霍金斯对神秘莫测、专横跋扈的希利布兰德深恶痛绝。就连负责运营细节的罗森菲尔德也受到梅里韦瑟的暗中施压，梅里韦瑟会时不时抱怨说：“埃里克得想办法赚钱”，仿佛经营公司还不够似的。

Fights over shares were common; as at Salomon Brothers, compensation was the natural turf for venting internal tensions. The casual air at Steamboat Road was deceptive, for it masked latent tensions that emerged every time issues of control, shares, or big portfolio moves surfaced. The fiery Scholes, who was eager to edge his way up the ladder, was prickly with Mullins, each academic thinking he was smarter than the other. Hawkins, an easygoing southerner, deeply resented the secretive, domineering Hilibrand. Even Rosenfeld, who was in charge of operational details, came under subtle pressure from Meriwether, who would periodically grouse, “Eric has got to find a way to make some money,” as if running the firm wasn’t enough.

套利者们对那些并非直接计入利润的贡献价值视而不见；他们只看重财务收益。或许正因如此，即便在他们不再需要这些贡献之后，他们仍然执着于最大化个人净资产。他们始终不肯放弃斯科尔斯的认股权证理念，而这一理念的核心就在于利用个人财富。认股权证最终成了他们执念的一部分。

The arbitrageurs were blind to the value of contributions that didn’t drop straight to the bottom line; only financial points counted. Perhaps this was one reason they were so intent, well after they had any need, on maximizing their personal net worths. They simply wouldn’t give up on Scholes’s warrant idea, the main point of which was to leverage their personal fortunes. And the warrant became an obsession with them.

正如合伙人之前威逼利诱美林、贝尔斯登和摩根大通一样，他们开始游说瑞士联合银行（UBS）购买认股权证。这是一个令人费解的选择，因为UBS此前已经两次拒绝了长期基金。1994年，当长期基金开始腾飞时，UBS拒绝投资。不久之后，JM和哈加尼再次拜访UBS，希望获得其债券和互换交易方面的支持。但UBS担心此类交易的杠杆风险，再次拒绝了他们的请求。

Just as the partners had browbeaten Merrill, Bear, and Chase, they began to lobby Union Bank of Switzerland for the warrant. It was a curious choice, because UBS had already snubbed Long-Term twice. UBS had declined to invest in the hedge fund in 1994, when the fund was taking off. A little later, J.M. and Haghani had gone calling again, hoping to enlist UBS for bond and swap trading. But UBS feared the leverage in such trades and once again declined.

然而，长期基金继续向这家总部位于苏黎世的银行施压。更重要的是，这家对冲基金在瑞银内部还有一位关键盟友，一位名叫罗恩·坦南鲍姆的布鲁克林本地人，他曾是所罗门兄弟公司的销售员。坦南鲍姆为人友善，外表粗犷，在希利布兰德之后一年加入了纽约的所罗门兄弟公司。后来他搬到了东京，在那里担任套利集团的本地分销代理。之后他又调到了伦敦，在那里他与梅里韦瑟多次接触。起初，坦南鲍姆对梅里韦瑟感到畏惧，或许也对梅里韦瑟的交易员们敬畏有加。但多年来，坦南鲍姆逐渐成为了该团队的朋友和忠实的仰慕者。

However, Long-Term continued to press the Zurich-based bank. What’s more, the hedge fund had a key ally within UBS, a Brooklyn native and former Salomon salesman named Ron Tannenbaum. Affable and rugged-looking, Tannenbaum had joined Salomon in New York a year after Hilibrand. He had later moved to Tokyo, where he had been a sort of local distribution agent for the Arbitrage Group. Then he had transferred to London, where he had seen a lot of Meriwether. At first, Tannenbaum had been intimidated by J.M. and probably awed by J.M.’s traders. But over the years, Tannenbaum became the group’s friend and steadfast admirer.

在瑞银，坦南鲍姆负责对冲基金业务。他不断敦促上司给格林威治来的那些年轻人一个机会。与此同时，瑞银正经历着令人不安的变革。作为瑞士首屈一指的银行，瑞银长期以来都是瑞士传统银行业体制的典型代表。它深受瑞士文化的影响，从国民军而非麻省理工学院招募身材矮小的银行家，并为每位副总裁提供三种抛光木材——红木、胡桃木或松木——供其选择，用来装饰办公室。 13这家安于现状的银行惊讶地发现，国际金融的节奏不再像阿尔卑斯山那样悠闲。当竞争对手瑞士银行——一家现代化速度更快、尤其是在衍生品领域——超越瑞银时，瑞银更是感到震惊。到了20世纪90年代中期，瑞银开始反击，招募了一批积极进取的交易员。马蒂斯·卡比亚拉维塔，这位风度翩翩的瑞士银行业王子，一路晋升为首席执行官，为了重夺瑞银的霸主地位，他放任手下那些行事鲁莽的交易员们自由行动。1995年9月，瑞银急于扩张，坦南鲍姆说服董事会批准长期证券公司（Long-Term）成为其交易对手。瑞银还从美林证券挖来了一位马来西亚裔交易员林俊杰（TJ Lim），并指示他大力发展衍生品业务。因此，到1996年，长期证券公司终于在阿尔卑斯山脉站稳了脚跟。

At UBS, Tannenbaum covered hedge funds. He kept urging his bosses to give the boys from Greenwich a chance. Meanwhile, the bank was going through unsettling changes. Long the premier bank in Switzerland, UBS had epitomized the country’s tradition-bound banking establishment. Steeped in Swiss culture, it recruited gnome-like bankers from the national army rather than from MIT and offered each vice president a choice of three polished woods—mahogany, walnut, or pine—to panel his office with.13 The complacent bank had been startled to discover that international finance no longer moved at such a leisurely, Alpine pace. It had been shocked when Swiss Bank, a rival much quicker to modernize and, in particular, to embrace derivatives, had overtaken UBS. By the mid-1990s, UBS had begun to fight back, hiring a slew of aggressive traders. Mathis Cabiallavetta, a debonair prince of Swiss banking who had risen to chief executive, gave his gunslinger traders free rein in a desperate bid to regain UBS’s perch at the top. With the bank eager to grow, in September 1995, Tannenbaum persuaded the board to approve Long-Term as a counterparty. The bank also hired a Malaysian-born trader from Merrill, T. J. Lim, and gave him marching orders to gin up its derivative business. Thus, by 1996, the stage was set for Long-Term to finally gain a foothold in the Alps.

一夜之间，这家对冲基金成了瑞银最大的客户，第一年就为瑞银带来了1500万美元的收入。 14但和长期资本管理公司（LTCM）一贯的做法一样，这笔交易的利润率很低——通常只有0.5%。在一笔涉及日本股票的交易中，LTCM将利润率削减到了22.5个基点，不到0.25%。瑞银行事作风自由奔放的股票衍生品主管拉米·戈德斯坦（Ramy Goldstein）对这笔低利润率的交易表示抗议。“罗尼，他们不是客户，他们是竞争对手！”这位银发苍苍、拥有耶鲁大学博士学位的前以色列伞兵戈德斯坦对坦南鲍姆（Tannenbaum）大声说道。“别再联系我了，”他补充道，“我不想再做LTCM的交易了！”

Overnight, the hedge fund became UBS’s biggest account, netting the bank $15 million in revenue in its first year.14 But as always with Long-Term, the business was low margin—typically half of 1 percent. On one trade involving Japanese equities, Long-Term shaved the margin to 22.5 basis points, less than one quarter of a percent. Ramy Goldstein, UBS’s freewheeling head of equity derivatives, took the low-margin trade under protest. “Ronnie, they’re not customers, they’re competitors!,” Goldstein, a silver-haired former Israeli paratrooper with a doctorate from Yale University, exclaimed to Tannenbaum. “Lose my number,” he added. “I don’t want to do more LTCM deals!”

但瑞银与长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的交易才刚刚开始。随着瑞银内部管控日益放松，该行开始放手一搏。事实上，魅力四射、充满冒险精神的戈德斯坦（Goldstein）率先垂范，开展了一系列高风险的股票期权交易。与此同时，坦南鲍姆（Tannenbaum）开始考虑将长期资本管理公司的业务拓展到利润更高的产品领域。瑞银开始协助长期资本管理公司处理税务相关事宜，这也让坦南鲍姆与他在所罗门兄弟公司时期的老朋友迈伦·斯科尔斯（Myron Scholes）重聚。

But UBS’s LTCM deals had only begun. With controls at UBS growing ever looser, the bank began to swing for the fences. In fact, the charismatic Goldstein, who had a cowboy’s thirst for adventure, led the way, pursuing a raft of risky stock-option trades. Meanwhile, Tannenbaum began to think about elevating the Long-Term relationship to higher-margin products. UBS started assisting Long-Term on tax-related proposals, which reunited Tannenbaum with a good friend from his Salomon days: Myron Scholes.

由于长期基金（Long-Term）的盈利如此诱人，瑞银开始后悔之前未能投资。“天哪，这是我们犯过的最大错误，”固定收益、货币和衍生品部门主管汉斯-彼得·鲍尔（Hans-Peter Bauer）哀叹道，他之前曾拒绝投资长期基金。长期基金已经停止接受新资金，投资者的窗口似乎已经关闭。事实上，富有的瑞士人甚至愿意支付10%的溢价来回购老投资者的股份。但在1996年7月，鲍尔知道坦南鲍姆（Tannenbaum）与格林威治的那些人关系密切，于是他请这位销售员帮忙打听一下，看看他的朋友们是否愿意让银行投资。

With Long-Term showing such sexy profits, UBS was regretting its earlier failure to invest. “God, that’s the biggest mistake we ever made,” moaned Hans-Peter Bauer, head of fixed-income, currency, and derivatives, who had rejected Long-Term before. Long-Term had stopped taking new money, so the window for investors apparently was closed. Indeed, wealthy Swiss were paying 10 percent premiums to buy out old investors. But in July 1996, knowing that Tannenbaum was tight with the boys from Greenwich. Bauer asked the salesman to see if his friends might, perchance, let the bank invest.

长期投资公司（Long-Term）此时对瑞银集团（UBS）产生了浓厚的兴趣，并对其热情洋溢的推销员使出了浑身解数。该基金打破了此前不接受新资金的立场，主动提出让坦南鲍姆（Tannenbaum）个人持有部分基金份额，但瑞银集团拒绝了他的提议。当时，长期投资公司正考虑成立一只名为LTCM-X的衍生基金，专门投资于高风险交易，并专注于拉丁美洲市场。心怀不满的斯科尔斯（Scholes）将LTCM-X视为摆脱希利布兰德（Hilibrand）控制的途径，他对此越来越不满。考虑到LTCM-X的成立，该公司向摩根大通（JP Morgan）的副董事长罗伯托·门多萨（Roberto Mendoza）抛出了橄榄枝。门多萨毕业于哈佛大学，是古巴前驻英国大使的儿子。随着这些计划的推进，斯科尔斯向坦南鲍姆抛出了在LTCM-X工作的诱饵——这显然是为了拉拢长期基金与坦南鲍姆的雇主建立良好关系。10月份，斯科尔斯抛出了最终的诱饵，告诉坦南鲍姆，如果瑞银同意为长期基金的合伙人签发认股权证，那么长期基金就同意让瑞银对该基金进行大笔投资。

Long-Term was now getting very interested in UBS, and turned the charm on in its eager salesman. The fund broke with its no-new-money stance and offered Tannenbaum a slice of the fund for himself, personally, though UBS wouldn’t let him accept it. At the time, Long-Term was thinking of forming a splinter fund—LTCM-X, it was dubbed—to invest in especially high risk trades and also to focus on Latin America. The frustrated Scholes saw LTCM-X as a way to get out from under Hilibrand’s control, which he increasingly resented. With LTCM-X in mind, the firm offered a partnership to Roberto Mendoza, a Harvard-educated vice chairman at J. P. Morgan and the son of a former Cuban ambassador to Great Britain. With these plans percolating along, Scholes dangled before Tannenbaum the prospect of working for LTCM-X—presumably part of an effort to ingratiate Long-Term with Tannenbaum’s employer. In October, Scholes offered the ultimate carrot, telling Tannenbaum that the fund would agree to let UBS make a large investment in the fund—if the bank also agreed to write a warrant on the fund for the Long-Term partners.

秋季，银行董事长卡比亚拉维塔和戈德斯坦拜访了格林威治的合伙人。此时，瑞银高层虽然急于巩固与长期投资公司的合作关系，但也开始担心坦南鲍姆与他的客户走得太近了。“我们不确定罗尼是我们的人才还是你们的，”其中一人说道。JM不以为意，说道：“罗恩是个好人。”

In the fall, Cabiallavetta, the bank chairman, and Goldstein paid a call on the partners in Greenwich. By now, the UBS brass, though eager to cement the tie to Long-Term, had started to worry that Tannenbaum might be getting a little too cozy with his account. “We aren’t sure if Ronnie is our man or yours,” one of them noted. J.M. brushed off their concern, saying, “Ron’s a good man.”

合伙人们对待卡比亚拉维塔就像对待失散多年的表亲一样。几乎所有合伙人都出席了会议，只有默顿（当时在哈佛）和哈加尼（虽然从伦敦赶来，却忙着在JM的办公室里奔波处理一些紧急情况）缺席。当卡比亚拉维塔询问欧洲货币一体化的前景时，JM让穆林斯做了个简短的讲解，这给瑞士人留下了深刻的印象。只有长期基金公司有一位常驻的央行专家。会议上几乎没有人提及认股权证，但坦南鲍姆整个十一月都在撰写一份提案，准备提交给他的上级。提案的基本思路完全基于布莱克-斯科尔斯模型。期权定价公式的关键决定因素是波动率。而长期基金的波动率一直异常稳定。事实上，1996年是该基金迄今为止最稳定的一年。因此，布莱克-斯科尔斯交易员愿意以相对较低的溢价卖出该基金的看涨期权。但斯科尔斯却开出了略高的溢价，颇具风度。换句话说，假设Long-Term的业绩保持稳定，瑞银可以立即获得2500万美元的利润。戈德斯坦对此感到震惊。“罗尼，我们可能会损失好几倍的金额！”他抗议道。这笔交易的关键在于布莱克-斯科尔斯模型的致命弱点：它假设波动性是恒定的。如果Long-Term在认股权证七年的有效期内遭遇任何波动，瑞银都可能面临巨额损失。

The partners treated Cabiallavetta like a long-lost cousin. Almost all the partners attended the meeting, except for Merton, who was at Harvard, and Haghani, who, though in from London, was dashing in and out of J.M.’s office to handle some emergency. When Cabiallavetta asked about the outlook for European monetary integration, J.M. had Mullins give a little lecture, which impressed the Swiss. Only Long-Term had a resident central banker. Little was said at the meeting about the warrant, but Tannenbaum spent November writing a proposal to show to his superiors. The basic pitch was right out of the Black-Scholes model. The key determinant in the option-pricing formula is volatility. And Long-Term had been exceptionally steady. In fact, 1996 had been its steadiest year yet. Thus, a Black-Scholes trader would be willing to write a call option on the fund for a relatively small premium. Sportingly, Scholes had offered a premium that was somewhat higher. In other words, under the assumption that Long-Term’s results would remain steady, UBS could book an immediate $25 million profit. Goldstein was aghast. “Ronnie, we could lose multiples of that!” he protested. The deal hinged on the Achilles’ heel of Black-Scholes: the assumption that volatility is a constant. If Long-Term should encounter a skittish patch over the warrant’s seven-year life, UBS could face a massive loss.

坦南鲍姆写了一份堪称精妙的销售报告。他主要从关系的角度来描述认股权证的好处，列举了瑞银作为长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的合作伙伴所能获得的收益，例如了解其交易流程等等。“LTCM的负责人将帮助瑞银加速在投资组合管理、风险管理和动态资本配置方面的学习进程，”这位销售员写道。假设坦南鲍姆相信这一点，那么华尔街恐怕只剩下他一个人这么想了。毕竟，他十年来一直渴望加入长期资本管理公司的团队。他仍然津津乐道地回忆起自己最初与希利布兰德共事的情景，希利布兰德被他称为“业内最聪明的人”。当然，坦南鲍姆只是个销售员，几乎没有权力批准重大交易。但到了年底，尽管尚未签署任何协议，斯科尔斯的认股权证已经开始受到瑞银高级交易员和经理的关注。

Tannenbaum wrote a masterly sales report. He portrayed the benefits of the warrant largely in relational terms, citing what UBS would gain from being Long-Term’s partner, from seeing its trading flow, and so forth. “The Principals of LTCM will help accelerate UBS’ learning process in portfolio management, risk management, and dynamic capital allocation,” the salesman wrote. Presuming Tannenbaum believed that, he was the only one left on Wall Street who did. But then, he had nourished a wish to be part of the Long-Term gang for a decade. He was still fond of recalling how he had started out with Hilibrand, “the biggest brain in the business.” Of course, Tannenbaum was only a salesman and scarcely had authority to approve major deals. But by year-end, although nothing had been signed, Scholes’s warrant was getting a hearing from UBS senior traders and managers.

该基金1996年收益率高达57%（扣除合伙人费用后为41%），这主要得益于对日本可转换债券、垃圾债券、利率互换以及——再次——意大利债券的杠杆价差交易。此外，当法国债券的交易价格开始高于德国债券时（这似乎暗示法国的通胀风险低于德国），合伙人巧妙地押注德国经济将出现相对反弹，并取得了成功。他们1996年的总利润高达惊人的21亿美元。 15为了更直观地理解这个数字，我们可以这样理解：这群鲜为人知、从事极其冷门行业的交易员、分析师和研究人员，当年赚的钱比麦当劳在全球销售汉堡的收入还要多，比美林证券、迪士尼、施乐、美国运通、西尔斯、耐克、朗讯和吉列——这些美国企业中管理最完善、品牌最知名的公司——的收入还要高。

The fund earned 57 percent in 1996 (41 percent after the partners’ fees) thanks to leveraged spread trades on Japanese convertibles, junk bonds, interest rate swaps, and—again—Italian bonds. Also, when French bonds began to trade above German bonds (implying, curiously, that France bore less inflation risk than Germany), the partners cleverly, and successfully, bet on Germany to make a relative comeback. Their total profits in 1996 were an astounding $2.1 billion.15 To put this number into perspective, this small band of traders, analysts, and researchers, unknown to the general public and employed in the most arcane and esoteric of businesses, earned more that year than McDonald’s did selling hamburgers all over the world, more than Merrill Lynch, Disney, Xerox, American Express, Sears, Nike, Lucent, or Gillette—among the best-run companies and best-known brands in American business.

而且，他们的操作波动性极低。1996年，长期基金从未出现过1%以上的月度亏损。 16对希利布兰德、哈格尼和霍金斯来说，这些结果令人信服地证明了多元化投资的有效性。该基金多元化的交易组合完美融合，如同交响乐般和谐，就像独立掷出的骰子或默顿模型中的随机卡片一样。 17 “我们怎么把风险（即波动性）提高到足够高的水平都行，”交易员们对一位朋友说道，仿佛对自己的理论感到敬畏。“我们正在见证多元化的力量。”

And they had done it with stunningly little volatility. Not once in 1996 did Long-Term suffer a monthly loss of 1 percent.16 To Hilibrand, Haghani, and Hawkins, the results proved convincingly that diversification worked. The fund’s diverse trades were blending with symphonic perfection, like the independent dice or the random cards from a model by Merton.17 “We can’t get the risk [read: volatility] high enough,” the traders told a friend, as if awed by their own doctrine. “We’re seeing the power of diversification.”

只有梅里韦瑟（Meriwether）比较谨慎，因为他比合伙人经历过更多起伏。在伦敦的一次年终午餐会上，科斯塔斯·卡普拉尼斯（Costas Kaplanis）——JM之前在所罗门兄弟公司（Salomon Brothers）的一位交易员——对长期投资公司（Long-Term）前三年的辉煌业绩表示赞赏，但JM拒绝接受祝贺。他谦逊地回应说，至少需要六年的业绩才能确定长期投资公司的模式是否有效。或许他感觉到合伙人运气不错——遇到了一段难得的暖和天气。为了确保万无一失，长期投资公司要求其投资者——当时大约有一百人——同意未来错开提款日期。不同意的人可以把钱带回家（但没有人这么做）。这为长期投资公司提供了额外的保障，以防投资者将来想要集体撤资。

Only Meriwether, who had lived through more ups and downs than his partners, was circumspect. At a year-end luncheon in London, Costas Kaplanis, one of J.M.’s old traders from Salomon Brothers, tipped his hat to Long-Term’s spectacular first three years, but J.M. refused to accept congratulations. He humbly replied that one would need at least six years of results to say for sure that Long-Term’s formula was working. Perhaps he sensed that the partners had enjoyed some luck—an unusual stretch of balmy weather. As if to batten down the hatches, Long-Term asked its investors—now about a hundred in number—to agree to stagger the dates on which they could take out money in the future. People who did not agree could take their money home (none did). This gave Long-Term added protection should its investors ever want to withdraw en masse.

事实上，大量资金正通过竞争对手的银行和基金涌入套利市场——这更加剧了JM的悲观情绪。他知道，这些新资金正在收窄价差——的确，这也是长期基金近期盈利的原因之一。但这同时也意味着寻找新的套利机会将变得更加困难。

In fact, money was pouring into the arbitrage business via rival banks and competitor funds—an added reason for J.M.’s dour mood. This new money, he knew, was forcing spreads tighter—indeed, it was one reason for Long-Term’s recent profits. But it would make new opportunities tougher to find.

在年末致投资者的信中，JM展现了谨慎的作风。他指出，长期投资的业绩反映了“多项重要策略的趋同程度超出预期”。因此，“1996年迄今为止的净收益已大幅超出管理公司年初的预期。”

Writing to investors just before the year closed, J.M. was the model of prudence. Long-Term’s results reflected “greater than expected convergence in a number of important strategies,” he noted. As a result, “1996 net returns to date have substantially exceeded the expectations of the Management Company as of the beginning of the year.”

这并非好兆头。由于长期基金现有交易的价差已经收窄，此类交易未来盈利潜力有限。此外，该基金未能及时找到新的交易机会，以跟上其资本增长的步伐。JM 相当谦虚地几乎预言，这枚火箭终将坠落：“我们目前的判断（尽管必然不够精确）是，1997 年的净收益很可能远低于 1996 年的收益，尽管实际结果可能远高于或低于我们的预期，甚至可能出现亏损。” 18

This did not augur well. Since spreads on Long-Term’s existing trades had already narrowed, such trades offered less potential for profit in the future. Moreover, the fund had not been able to find new trades quickly enough to keep pace with the growth in its capital. Rather humbly, J.M. all but predicted that the rocket would return to earth: “Our current, but necessarily imprecise, judgment is that the net return for 1997 is likely to be materially below the 1996 return, although actual results may be considerably above or below our expectations including potential for loss.”18

6

6

诺贝尔奖

A NOBEL PRIZE

尽管经济学标榜自己是一门科学，但它仍然更像是一门艺术，而不是一门科学。

Despite its scientific pretensions, economics still remains more of an art than a science.

—R ·奥伯特· K·乌特纳





—ROBERT KUTTNER





无论Long- Term是否愿意承认，债券套利的秘密早已不复存在。到了20世纪90年代末，华尔街几乎所有投资银行都或多或少地涉足了这一领域。大多数银行都设有独立的套利部门，专门安排交易员在债券交易的各个角落寻找机会。其他银行也被格林威治的巨额利润所吸引，纷纷效仿Long-Term，试图从中牟利。然而，他们最终还是蚕食了那些吸引他们的价差；这就是自由市场惩罚成功的方式。Long-Term一直以来都饱受模仿者的困扰，但如今模仿者蜂拥而至的速度比以往任何时候都更快。价差刚一出现，竞争对手的交易员就立即填补了空缺。“其他人都在追赶我们，”罗森菲尔德抱怨道，“我们准备进行交易，但当我们开始小幅出价时，机会就消失了。”¹

WHETHER LONG-TERM wanted to admit it or not, the secret of bond arbitrage was out. By the late 1990s, almost every investment bank on Wall Street had, to some degree, gotten into the game. Most had separate arbitrage desks, with traders specifically assigned to look for opportunities in every nook and cranny of the business. Lured by the scent of the fantastic profits being earned in Greenwich, other banks were reaching for the same nickels as Long-Term. Inevitably, they whittled away the very spreads that had attracted them; thus do free markets punish success. Long-Term had always been dogged by imitators, but now the imitators were piling on faster than ever. No sooner did a spread open up than rival traders plugged it. “Everyone else was catching up to us,” Rosenfeld complained. “We’d go to put on a trade, but when we started to nibble, the opportunity would vanish.”¹

梅里韦瑟一贯鼓励公司开拓新领域。即使在所罗门兄弟公司，员工们也一直渴望扩大业务范围。他们不是已经从互换利差交易转向抵押贷款支持证券了吗？他们不是也涉足垃圾债券和欧洲债务领域了吗？事后看来，这些举措都只是小试牛刀，算不上大胆创新。但至少在合伙人看来，他们的经验似乎驳斥了“将成功经验照搬到陌生领域是危险的”这句格言。他们相信自己的模型，于是在一片未知的领域重新启动了他们的系统。

Characteristically, Meriwether encouraged the firm to explore new territory. Even at Salomon, the troops had always sought to extend their turf. Hadn’t they moved from swap spreads to mortgage-backed securities? Hadn’t they branched into junk bonds and European debt? In retrospect, such moves had been baby steps, not bold new departures. But the partners’ experience—to them, at least—seemed to belie the adage that it is dangerous to try to transport success to unfamiliar ground. Trusting their models, they simply rebooted their computers in virgin terrain.

到1997年，高风险分拆公司LTCM-X的计划已经搁浅。（摩根大通的高管门多萨决定不接受长期投资公司提出的合作邀请。）相反，合伙人开始考虑如何扩大母基金的业务范围，甚至考虑将业务拓展到公开市场之外。在长期投资公司看来，证券业务的问题在于其固有的可及性。任何人都可以购买债券，或者模仿他人的购买行为。合伙人的隐秘作风与市场粗犷的民主格格不入。他们越来越倾向于在金融领域进行流动性较差、但更具长期性的投资，以避免被他们痛恨的模仿者所染指。

By 1997, the plans for the high-risk splinter company, LTCM-X, had faded. (Mendoza, the Morgan official, had decided not to accept Long-Term’s offer of a partnership.) Instead, the partners were toying with ways of broadening the mother fund, even of going beyond public markets. From Long-Term’s point of view, the trouble with the securities business was its inherent accessibility. Anybody could buy a bond or mimic someone who did. The partners’ reclusive style ill fitted the rough democracy of markets. They were increasingly intrigued with the idea of making less liquid, more permanent investments in financial businesses, beyond the reach of hated copycats.

默顿当时正考虑与意大利国家劳动银行（Banca Nazionale del Lavoro，简称BNL）合作，向散户投资者推销共同基金。BNL是一家拥有庞大资产管理业务的意大利银行。他们的想法是将BNL的机构影响力与Long-Term的学术背景相结合，为普通民众提供产品。默顿天真地相信市场完美，极力鼓吹为普通人打造“最优投资组合”的理念。Long-Term的意大利籍负责人乔瓦尼尼被委任负责协调这项工作，而杰诺特则被派往罗马，在那里暂时居住，与BNL敲定细节。与此同时，摩根大通敦促Long-Term进一步多元化发展。摩根的高管们认为，合伙人应该“发挥”他们的智慧——实际上，是将他们的智慧和方法论应用于对冲基金常规业务范围之外的领域。于是，合伙人开始悄悄地探索建立保险业务的可能性。

Merton was exploring a joint venture with Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, an Italian bank with a big money management operation, to peddle mutual funds to retail investors. The idea was to combine BNL’s institutional clout with Long-Term’s academic pedigree and offer a product to the everyday signore. Merton, with his naive belief in perfect markets, was pushing the notion of “optimum portfolios” for the little man. Giovannini, Long-Term’s resident Italian, was deputized to coordinate the effort, and Gennotte was dispatched to Rome, where he took up temporary residence to work out details with BNL. Meanwhile, J. P. Morgan was urging Long-Term to diversify further. Morgan executives felt that the partners should “leverage” their intellect—in effect, apply their brains and methodology to businesses outside the normal scope of hedge funds. Quietly, the partners began to explore setting up an insurance operation.

尽管这些宏伟的计划进展缓慢，但长期投资公司（Long-Term）却面临着巨大的资金压力，必须尽快找到合适的投资标的。到1997年，该公司已拥有超过50亿美元的股权。如果长期投资公司想要维持其优异的回报率，就必须将这些资金进行投资。然而，长期投资公司的计算机却未能找到合适的投资机会。在一次新的尝试中，长期投资公司大胆地进入了以商业抵押贷款为抵押的证券市场——这与以常见的住房抵押贷款为抵押的IO和PO市场截然不同。长期投资公司的投资热情如此之高，以至于彻底改变了商业市场，其新发行规模几乎在一夜之间从每年300亿美元的飙升至600亿美元。希利布兰德（Hilibrand）毫不掩饰自己在商业地产领域的专业知识；不出所料，他认为公司可以在融资方面找到优势。“他们可以用极低的风险赚取利差，”一位抵押贷款银行家回忆道，“利差虽然很低，但长期投资公司拥有巨大的杠杆能力。”这是该公司的标准模式；合伙人决心尽可能地沿用这种千篇一律的模式。

While such grand ventures were progressing slowly, Long-Term was under immediate pressure to park its capital somewhere. By 1997, it had more than $5 billion in equity. If Long-Term was to sustain its splendid rate of return, that capital would have to be invested. But Long-Term’s computers were failing to find opportunities. In one new foray, Long-Term boldly crashed the market for securities backed by commercial mortgages—wholly different from the market for IOs and POs, which, of course, were backed by familiar home mortgages. Long-Term’s appetite was so stunningly large that it transformed the commercial market, which soared from $30 billion of new issues a year to $60 billion almost overnight. Hilibrand made no pretense of having expertise in commercial real estate; predictably, he felt the firm could find an edge in financing. “They could earn the carry [the spread] with very little risk,” a mortgage banker recalled. “The spread was thin, but Long-Term had a huge ability to leverage.” This was the firm’s standard formula; the partners were determined to drag their cookie cutter wherever they could.

但商业抵押贷款只是小菜一碟。股票——也就是交易的股票——则展现出更为广阔、更具诱惑力的新天地。这片天地尚未开发，因为大多数像“长期投资者”那样精于数学的交易员自然而然地避开了股票市场。尽管债券定价在很大程度上可以简化为数学计算，但股票估值则要主观得多。华尔街（以及学术界）曾设计出许多预测市场的公式，但无论多么深奥或严谨，都无一奏效。短期来看，股票价格受制于情绪化的交易员的情绪波动。长期来看，股票价格会随着企业业绩而波动，而企业业绩本身就充满不确定性，且极难预测。这需要的是判断力——而不仅仅是数学——而这种判断力是任何计算机都无法掌握的。正如经济学家伯顿·马尔基尔曾经观察到的那样，“全能的上帝也不知道普通股的合理市盈率。”² 但长期资本公司却知道——或者至少，它大胆地认为它可以将自己的模型应用于股票。

But commercial mortgages were relatively small potatoes. Equities—that is, traded stocks—loomed as a far larger and more tantalizing new frontier. It was an open frontier because most traders with Long-Term’s mathematical bent had naturally left equities alone. Although pricing a bond can largely be reduced to math, valuing a stock is far more subjective. Wall Street (and academe) had devised many a formula to forecast the market, but none, no matter how esoteric or rigorous, had worked. Over the short run, stocks are subject to the whim of often emotional traders. Over the long run, they vary with business performance, which is subject to great uncertainty and is notoriously hard to forecast. It requires judgment—not merely math—of the sort that no computer has ever mastered. As the economist Burton Malkiel once observed, “God Almighty does not know the proper price-earning multiple for a common stock.”² But Long-Term Capital did know—or at least, it boldly reckoned that it could transport its models to equities.

哈加尼一直在研究股票，尤其是欧洲股票，他认为这个领域正需要一家拥有必要量化技能的公司，但更重要的是，无需陷入个股分析的繁琐细节。罗森菲尔德也从在所罗门兄弟公司工作时就开始思考股票套利。一个吸引他的地方是，他认为股票套利与债券套利不相关。作为默顿的忠实信徒，罗森菲尔德想要的是随机的投资机会，很难想象股票之间的利差会与抵押贷款之间的利差或欧洲债券之间的利差同时扩大。³ 股票似乎属于另一个世界。从定义上讲，这并非业务的小幅扩展，而是一项激进且充满风险的实验。

Haghani had been researching equities, particularly in Europe, and he thought the field was ripe for a firm with the necessary quantitative skills but—importantly—without the need to get enmeshed in the messy details of specific-stock analysis. Rosenfeld, too, had been thinking about equity arbitrage since his days at Salomon. One attractive point was that equity arbitrage would (he supposed) be uncorrelated with bond arbitrage. Ever Merton’s disciple, Rosenfeld wanted random investment dice, and it was hard to imagine that the spreads between stocks would widen at the same moment as the spreads between mortgages or the spreads between European bonds.³ Equities seemed of a different world. By definition, this would not be a small extension of the business but a radical, risky experiment.

哈格尼的研究重点是所谓的配对股票。许多欧洲股票都以双重形式上市。例如，大众汽车同时发行普通股和“优先股”，后者拥有更高的投票权。宝马也是如此。哈格尼还研究了资产相关（但不完全相同）的股票对，例如意大利电信（Telecom Italia）及其子公司意大利电信移动（Telecom Italia Mobile），或者路易威登（Louis Vuitton）和迪奥（Dior）。由于各种原因，一对股票中的一只通常比另一只股票的价格低。因此，哈格尼发现了套利的可能。另一位麻省理工学院毕业的经济学家大卫·莫德斯特负责股票交易建模。但哈格尼才是真正的掌舵人。“莫德斯特听从维克多的指示，”一位内部人士指出。“维克多说，‘去做空这只股票’，莫德斯特就负责想办法去做。”

Haghani focused his research on so-called paired shares. Various European stocks were doubly listed. Volkswagen, for instance, listed an ordinary share and a “preference” share, the latter with superior voting rights. BMW was another. Haghani also looked at pairs of stocks with related (but not identical) assets, such as Telecom Italia, the Italian phone company, and Telecom Italia Mobile, its subsidiary, or Louis Vuitton and Dior. For various reasons, one side of a given pair often traded at a discount to its partner. Hence, Haghani spotted the potential for arbitrage. David Modest, yet another MIT-trained economist, did the modeling on equity trades. But Haghani ran the show. “Modest did what Victor told him,” one insider noted. “Victor said, ‘Go short this,’ and Modest would work out how to do it.”

配对股票交易并非完美的套利，因为每笔交易的买卖双方永远无法完全等价。大众汽车的优先股价值高于普通股，尤其是在德国和欧洲其他地区，管理层不像在美国那样有义务公平对待所有股东。没有人能确切地说出“合理”的溢价是多少，只知道例如大众汽车40%的溢价似乎过高。但价差可能会持续甚至扩大——即便车型有所不同。鉴于这些不确定性，大多数参与者都将配对股票交易的规模限制在适中范围内。但随着资金的迅速增长，长期基金逐渐形成了自己独特的“分寸感”；就像一个用百元大钞付账从不找零的人一样，它已经失去了节制的习惯。

The paired-share trades weren’t perfect arbitrages, because the two sides of each trade were never precisely equivalent. A preference share of Volkswagen was worth a premium over an ordinary share, especially as, in Germany and elsewhere in Europe, managements did not feel the same obligation as in the United States to treat all stockholders fairly. No one could say precisely what the “right” premium was, only that the 40 percent premium in VW’s case, for example, seemed excessive. But the spread could persist or even widen—the models be damned. Given such uncertainties, most players limited paired-share trades to moderate size. But with its coffers burgeoning, Long-Term was developing a sense of proportion all its own; like a man who pays for dinner with hundred-dollar bills and never asks for change, it had lost the habit of moderation.

哈加尼和莫德斯特找到了大约十五个配对股票交易，哈加尼在这些交易中投入了惊人的资金。他最看好的是皇家荷兰/壳牌石油公司，这家庞大的英荷石油集团由两家上市公司所有：荷兰皇家石油公司和英国壳牌运输公司。尽管皇家荷兰和壳牌的收入来源相同——即皇家荷兰/壳牌的股息——但历史上，这家英国公司的股价通常比其荷兰同行低约8%。这两家公司的股票由不同的投资者持有，而且荷兰股票的流动性通常更好。但这种价格差异并没有合理的解释。哈加尼认为，随着欧洲逐渐成为一个统一的经济体，国家间的差异将越来越小，皇家荷兰和壳牌之间的价差将会缩小。这在当时是一种流行的观点。

Haghani and Modest found about fifteen paired-share trades, and Haghani bet on them in staggering size. His favorite was Royal Dutch/Shell, the huge Anglo-Dutch oil consortium. Royal Dutch/ Shell was owned by two listed companies, Royal Dutch Petroleum of the Netherlands and Shell Transport of England. Although Royal Dutch and Shell got their income from the same source—that is, from dividends on Royal Dutch/Shell—the English firm had historically traded at an 8 percent or so discount to its Dutch cousin. The stocks were owned by distinct pools of investors, and the Dutch stock was typically more liquid. But there was no good reason for the price differential. With Europe becoming a single economic unit, Haghani reckoned that national differences would matter less and less, and the spread between Royal Dutch and Shell would contract. This was a popular view.

但哈加尼的持仓规模令人震惊。长期投资公司押注23亿美元——一半做多壳牌，另一半做空皇家荷兰石油——当然，没有任何保证价差会收窄。实际上，如此庞大的持仓完全缺乏流动性。

But the size of Haghani’s position was stunning. Long-Term bet $2.3 billion—half of it long on Shell, the other half short on Royal Dutch—without, of course, any assurance that the spread would contract. In practical terms, a position that large was totally illiquid.

与普遍认知相反，流动性不足本身并无不妥——除非你面临被迫仓促抛售的风险。但长期基金由于杠杆率极高，恰恰处于这种境地——正如我们所见，杠杆投资者会以惊人的速度累积损失。哈格尼无视这一屡经验证的真理，借钱进行了一笔规模巨大的交易。他当时正承受着父亲病重的压力（父亲于同年晚些时候去世），同时债券套利市场环境的恶化也让他倍感压力。然而，除了承认哈格尼开始相信自己所向披靡之外，我们无法解释皇家荷兰/壳牌交易的规模之大。“这笔交易规模大得离谱，”一位华尔街银行的高管说道。高盛也持有同样的股票。他们认为这是一笔不错的交易。但长期基金的交易规模是高盛的十倍。

Contrary to common supposition, there is nothing wrong with being illiquid—unless you are vulnerable to being forced to sell in a hurry. But Long-Term, being highly leveraged, was in that very spot—for, as we have seen, leveraged investors can accumulate losses with terrifying speed. Ignoring this oft-proven verity, Haghani struck a gargantuan trade with borrowed money. He was under stress due to the ill health of his father, who died later that year, and he felt pressure due to the deteriorating landscape in bond arbitrage. Still, there is no explaining the size of the Royal Dutch/Shell trade, other than to accept that Haghani was beginning to believe in his own invincibility. “It was ridiculously big,” said an executive at a Wall Street bank. Goldman Sachs had the same trade on. They believed it was a good trade. But Long-Term’s trade was ten times the size of Goldman’s.

在大西洋彼岸的美国，希利布兰德也活跃于股票市场。早在1995年，长期投资公司就开始涉足并购套利，也称为“风险套利”，即押注已宣布的收购案最终会完成。例如，1995年，当西屋电气同意收购哥伦比亚广播公司（CBS）时，CBS的股价飙升了20%，达到每股78美元。但这个价格仍然低于每股82美元的交易价格。因此，任何在消息公布后买入CBS股票的人，如果交易最终完成，就有机会获得5%的利润。当然，如果并购失败，股价可能会回吐全部20%的涨幅。而很多并购案最终都以失败告终。

On the American side of the Atlantic, Hilibrand also was busy in equities. As early as 1995, Long-Term had started to dabble in merger arbitrage, also known as “risk arbitrage,” or betting that announced acquisitions would actually close. In 1995, when Westinghouse agreed to buy CBS, for example, the price of CBS vaulted 20 percent, to $78 a share. But that price was still below the deal price of $82 a share. Thus, anyone who bought CBS after the announcement stood to make a 5 percent profit—if the deal closed. Of course, if the merger fell through, the stock could give back the entire 20 percent gain. And many mergers do fall through.

由于任何事件都可能导致交易失败，并购套利者必须是精明的通才——他们不仅要了解公司、所在行业、融资、反垄断和其他监管问题，还要了解整体市场状况。正因为需要如此广泛的经验，只有少数专家专门从事并购交易。​​其中最优秀的人眼光极其挑剔；他们的技能在于能够挑选出极少数最有可能成交的交易。长期基金的做法则截然不同。由于其成员声称对个股没有专业知识——事实上，他们认为股票的未来走势是随机的——该基金并没有试图挑选赢家。它只是简单地买入一篮子股票，或者说，买入几乎所有它认为稳妥的交易标的。

Since any number of events can sabotage a deal, merger arbitrageurs have to be canny jacks-of-all-trades—knowledgeable about the companies, their industries, the financing, antitrust and other regulatory issues, and the condition of markets in general. Because of the range of experience required, a small group of specialists does nothing but merger deals.
