The best of them are highly selective; their skill resides in being able to choose the very few deals that are most likely to close. Long-Term’s approach was altogether different. Since its professors claimed no expertise in individual stocks—indeed, they assumed that the future course of stocks was random—the fund made no attempt to pick the winners. It simply bought a market basket, or virtually every deal stock that it deemed a safe bet.

合伙人们曾讨论过是否聘请风险套利专家，但最终没有这样做。与此同时，希利布兰德不断买入并购股票。尽管有六位合伙人越来越感到不安，他仍然自信地大量买入。斯科尔斯和默顿认为，并购套利——尤其是在如此大规模的情况下——风险过高，原因显而易见：长期投资公司涉足的领域完全是它一窍不通的。梅里韦瑟和他的交易员们对债券市场了如指掌。在并购套利领域，JM公司没有任何优势；事实上，真正占优的是长期投资公司的竞争对手。

The partners debated hiring a risk-arbitrage specialist but didn’t. Meanwhile, Hilibrand bought deal stock after deal stock. And he confidently bought them in very big size, despite the growing discomfort of a half dozen of his partners. Scholes and Merton argued that merger arbitrage—particularly on such a scale—was excessively risky for the obvious reason that Long-Term was playing in a field in which it had absolutely no expertise. Meriwether and his traders knew the bond world inside out. In merger arbitrage, J.M. had no edge; indeed, it was Long-Term’s rivals who had the advantage.

在长期投资部门内部，关于并购套利的争论异常激烈。梅里韦瑟主持这场辩论的方式就像一场研讨会，对所有观点都持包容态度。从某种意义上说，这反而是个错误：梅里韦瑟始终没有坚持己见。在经历了如此漫长而卓有成效的合作之后，他并不愿意干预他手下那两个桀骜不驯的交易员——希利布兰德和哈加尼。梅里韦瑟的个人忠诚影响了他对投资组合的考量，这对于一位风险管理者来说是一个严重的缺陷。

Within Long-Term, the debate over merger arbitrage was fierce. Meriwether ran the debate like a seminar, tolerating all points of view. In a sense, this was a mistake: J.M. never put his foot down. After such a long and fruitful partnership, he was disinclined to intervene against his two enfant terrible traders, Hilibrand and Haghani. J.M.’s personal loyalties weighed on portfolio considerations, a serious flaw in a risk manager.

“这笔交易是我们合作以来最具争议性的，”埃里克·罗森菲尔德承认。“很多人认为我们不应该涉足风险套利业务，因为它对信息非常敏感，而我们当时并没有试图以信息敏感的方式进行交易。” 4

“This trade was by far the most controversial in our partnership,” Eric Rosenfeld admitted. “A lot of people felt we shouldn’t be in the risk arb business because it is so information sensitive and we weren’t trying to trade in an information-sensitive way.”4

如果广受欢迎的罗森菲尔德反对这项交易，公司很可能就不会进行风险套利（尤其是梅里韦瑟，他很少在不咨询这位值得信赖的门生的情况下做出决定）。然而，罗森菲尔德也倾向于站在希利布兰德和哈加尼一边，其他人最终也同意了。

The firm would most likely have steered clear of risk arbitrage had the generally popular Rosenfeld opposed the trade (Meriwether, in particular, rarely made a decision without consulting his trusted protégé). However, Rosenfeld, too, tended to side with Hilibrand and Haghani, and the others finally went along.

经验丰富的套利者很快意识到，一个新角色加入了这场游戏，而且这个角色规模庞大、不加选择——或者用罗森菲尔德的话来说，就是“对信息不敏感”。通过如此大规模的买入，长期投资公司（Long-Term）全面推高了交易股票的价格，将价差压缩到了无利可图的水平。和往常一样，长期投资公司满足于赚取相对较小的价差，因为它打算利用杠杆放大收益。尽管如此，人们仍然惊叹于长期投资公司的胆大妄为，它大摇大摆地走进华尔街一个由经验丰富的老手们耕耘多年的角落，一夜之间改写了整个领域的经济格局。长期投资公司就像一只大猩猩，所到之处，它都在宣布新的规则。

Veteran arbs quickly realized that somebody new had entered the game and that the somebody was both very big and indiscriminate—or, as Rosenfeld put it, not “information sensitive.” By buying in such volume, Long-Term was boosting deal stocks across the board, squeezing spreads to unprofitable levels. As usual, Long-Term was content to earn relatively tiny spreads because it intended to multiply its returns with leverage. Still, one marvels at Long-Term’s audacity, sauntering into a corner of Wall Street—one in which savvy veterans had been working for years—and rewriting the economics of the field overnight. Long-Term was the gorilla that announces the rules wherever it goes.

一天晚上，希利布兰德、JM和穆林斯与丹尼尔·蒂施共进晚餐。丹尼尔·蒂施是一位著名的风险套利交易员。蒂施是投资者拉里·蒂施的儿子，他感觉长期投资公司（Long-Term）似乎只从数学角度看待业务。事实上，希利布兰德总是用价差来解释所有金融难题。在风险套利中，价差通常在4%到10%之间，远高于债券价差。“和他们的业务相比，我们的业务看起来非常有吸引力，他们交易的利润只有几个基点，”蒂施指出。“唯一的问题是，如果你对政府债券的判断失误，价差可能只会变化0.5个百分点。但如果你在风险套利中判断失误，你可能会损失一半的头寸。”简而言之，并购交易价差远大于债券价差的原因在于，并购套利的风险要大得多。蒂施离开时觉得长期投资公司根本不知道自己在做什么。它既缺乏经验，又杠杆率过高——这两种因素结合起来可能会引发灾难性的后果。来自沙克高地的长期投资者特伦斯·沙利文从坊间得知该基金参与风险套利活动，并震惊地发现该基金已经偏离其既定路线如此之远。

One night, Hilibrand, J.M., and Mullins had dinner with Daniel Tisch, a prominent risk arbitrageur. Tisch, son of the investor Larry Tisch, had the impression that Long-Term was thinking about the business solely in mathematical terms. Indeed, Hilibrand expressed every financial puzzle in terms of a spread. In risk arb, spreads were roughly 4 percent to 10 percent, much greater than bond spreads. “Our business looks very attractive next to their business, where they trade to make a couple of basis points,” Tisch noted. “The only trouble is, if you’re wrong on a government bond the spread may change by a half a point. If you’re wrong on risk arb, you can lose half your position.” In short, the reason that deal spreads were so much wider than bond spreads was that you could lose a lot more money on merger arbitrage. Tisch left feeling that Long-Term didn’t know what it was doing. It was both inexperienced and highly leveraged—a potentially explosive combination. Terence Sullivan, the Long-Term investor from Shaker Heights, heard of its risk-arb involvement through the grapevine and was shocked that the fund was straying so far from its ken.

除了哥伦比亚广播公司（CBS）之外，长期投资公司最大的持仓是MCI通信公司。1996年，MCI同意被英国电信收购。CBS和MCI都需要克服重重监管障碍，而且每笔交易的耗时都比预期要长。以CBS为例，即使CBS的股价已经逼近收购价62美分，长期投资公司仍然继续增持。长期投资公司在这笔交易中的杠杆率高达20比1——而它对这笔并购交易本身并无任何专业知识。“你这是在推土机前捡镍币，”一位友好的基金经理警告罗森菲尔德，暗示着其中一笔或几笔交易随时可能失败。最终，CBS的并购交易完成了，但这反而更加鼓舞了长期投资公司进行更多类似的交易。它的投资组合最终增长到了30笔。

Apart from CBS, Long-Term’s biggest position was MCI Communications, which in 1996 agreed to be acquired by British Telecommunications. Both CBS and MCI had to clear regulatory thickets, and each deal dragged on for longer than expected. In the case of CBS, Long-Term continued to snap up shares even when CBS stock had inched to within 62 cents of the deal price. Long-Term’s leverage on the trade was 20 to 1—without its having any specialized knowledge of the merger. “You’re picking up nickels in front of bulldozers,” a friendly money manager warned Rosenfeld, alluding to the risk that one deal or another would collapse. Eventually the CBS merger was completed, which only emboldened Long-Term to do more such trades. Its portfolio would grow to thirty deals.

读者或许会好奇，长期投资公司是如何借到这么多钱来购买股票的。美联储根据一项名为“T条例”的法定条款，对股票经纪贷款（也称为“保证金”）设定了上限。过去25年来，美联储一直将保证金贷款上限设定为总投资额的50%。

Readers may be excused for wondering how Long-Term could borrow so much toward the purchase of stocks. The Federal Reserve Board, under a statutory provision known as “Regulation T,” sets a limit on broker loans for stocks, also known as “margin.” For the past twenty-five years, the Fed has set the maximum margin loan at 50 percent of the total investment.

当长期基金购买股票时，它当然要遵守T条例。但大多数情况下，长期基金构建其股票头寸并非直接购买证券。相反，该基金签订了模拟股票走势的衍生品合约。例如，如果长期基金想要在三年内获得1亿美元哥伦比亚广播公司（CBS）股票的收益，它会与瑞士银行等机构签订一份“互换”合约。长期基金同意每年支付一笔固定款项，该款项按1亿美元的利率计算。而瑞士银行则同意向长期基金支付如果其实际购买股票本应获得的利润。（如果股票下跌，则由长期基金向瑞士银行支付。）瑞士银行很可能会通过购买实际股票来对冲风险。但这并非长期基金所关心的问题。

When Long-Term purchased stocks, it of course was subject to Reg T. But for the most part, Long-Term built its equity positions without buying actual securities. Rather, the fund entered into derivative contracts that mimicked the behavior of stocks. If, for instance, Long-Term wanted to earn the return on $100 million of CBS stock over a three-year period, it would strike a “swap” contract with, say, Swiss Bank. Long-Term would agree to make a fixed annual payment, calculated as an interest rate on $100 million. And Swiss Bank would agree to pay Long-Term whatever profit would have been earned had Long-Term actually purchased the stock. (If the stock fell, Long-Term would pay Swiss Bank.) Most likely, Swiss Bank would hedge its risk by buying actual shares. But that was no concern of Long-Term’s.

对JM及其公司而言，重要的是他们可以零首付、无需披露所有常规信息，就对CBS进行巨额投资。尽管有T条例的限制，但这完全合法。毕竟，美联储只是限制了用于购买股票的贷款。长期投资公司并没有实际购买任何股票；它只是对股票走势进行场外押注——这本质上是一样的。

What mattered to J.M. and company was that they could make a huge investment in CBS with no money down and without having to make all of the usual disclosures. And despite Reg T, it was perfectly legal. The Fed, after all, merely restricted loans toward the purchase of stocks. Long-Term wasn’t purchasing anything; it was making side bets on the direction of stocks—which amounted to the same thing.

华尔街利用股权互换规避Reg T监管已有近十年之久，但近年来，这项业务的规模呈爆炸式增长。此外，银行在帮助企业规避保证金规则方面也变得越来越直白。衍生品并非一开始就如此；事实上，其背后的理念原本并无恶意。20世纪70年代末和80年代初的投资银行家们认为，简单的协议——无论是合约、衍生品，还是其他任何名称——都比实际买卖资产更能有效地转移风险。例如，在衍生品出现之前，大多数家庭都只能选择固定利率抵押贷款。即使是那些更愿意冒险一搏（即承担未来利率风险）的房主，也无计可施。银行向他和其他所有人提供的都是同样的传统固定利率贷款。这可以理解，因为抵押贷款银行也需要支付固定的利息。但通过使用衍生品（默顿最喜欢的例子之一），银行可以将固定利率贷款转换为浮动利率贷款。这个想法的精妙之处在于，对于每个客户而言，总会有其他方有着相反的需求。例如，一家公司计划在未来多年进行年度借款，因此更倾向于固定利率带来的可预测性。如果拥有固定利率抵押贷款的家庭和面临浮动利率借贷成本的公司能够互换贷款，那该多好！多亏了衍生品，他们才能做到这一点。（当然，他们当时并不知道这一点；银行自然扮演着中介的角色。）

The Street had been using equity swaps to get around Reg T for about a decade, but in recent years the scale of the business had soared. Moreover, banks had become increasingly blunt about helping firms skirt the margin rules. Derivatives had not started out this way; in fact, the premise behind them had been innocuous. Investment bankers in the late 1970s and early 1980s had had the idea that simple agreements—contracts, derivatives, call them what you like—would be a more efficient way of transferring risk than actually buying and selling assets. For example, in the prederivative era, most families were stuck with fixed-rate mortgages. Even a homeowner who would have preferred to roll the dice (i.e., assume a little risk on future rates) had no practical way to act on his sentiments. The bank offered him, and everyone else, the same conventional fixed-rate loan. That was understandable, as the mortgage bank was also paying a fixed rate for its money. But by using derivatives (a favorite example of Merton’s) the bank could convert a fixed-rate loan into a floating-rate one. The genius behind the idea is that, for every customer, there is always some other party with the opposite need. Perhaps a company planned to make annual borrowings for many years and would prefer the predictability of a fixed rate. If only a family that had a fixed-rate mortgage, and the company, which was facing varying borrowing costs, could swap loans! Thanks to derivatives, they could. (Not that they knew it; banks, naturally, acted as intermediaries.)

现代意义上的第一笔互换交易诞生于1981年。当时，IBM持有以瑞士法郎和德国马克计价的债券，并希望将这些债务转换为美元。刚刚加入所罗门兄弟公司的耶鲁大学博士大卫·斯文森建议，或许可以说服其他借款人发行与IBM债券完全相同的债务，除了以美元计价之外。世界银行显然是一个不错的选择，因为它一直热衷于持有多种货币计价的债务。为了促成借款，所罗门兄弟公司向世界银行提供了略低于市场利率的利率。随后，两家借款人互换了债务——IBM获得了美元债务，世界银行则获得了外币债务——就这样，互换交易的世界诞生了。

The first modern swap was engineered in 1981. IBM had bonds denominated in Swiss francs and German marks and wanted to convert this debt to dollars. David Swensen, a Yale Ph.D. newly arrived at Salomon, suggested that perhaps some other borrower could be persuaded to issue debt that, aside from being denominated in dollars, was identical to IBM’s. One obvious choice was the World Bank, which had an appetite for holding debt in a variety of currencies. As an inducement to borrow, Salomon gave the bank a slightly lower-than-market interest rate. Then the two borrowers switched—IBM winding up with dollar debt, the World Bank with the foreign stuff—and voilà! the world of swaps was born.

这项业务起初发展缓慢，随后呈指数级增长。很快，银行便开始用债务交换货币、利息支付、股票以及任何可以相互交换的未来现金流。1990年，未偿付的利率互换合约（仅是其中一种衍生品）价值2万亿美元。到1997年，总额飙升至22万亿美元。⁵这种迅猛增长带来的一个后果——很大程度上并非预期——是银行的财务报表变得越来越晦涩难懂。衍生品交易的披露方式对外界而言毫无意义。随着交易量的爆炸式增长，银行的资产负债表越来越难以反映其全部债务。到20世纪90年代中期，即使是许多中型银行的财务报表也变得晦涩难懂。

The business grew—at first slowly, then exponentially. Soon, banks were swapping obligations for currencies, interest rate payments, equities, any future stream of cash that could be traded for another. In 1990, there were $2 trillion worth of interest rate swaps (just one type of derivative) outstanding. By 1997, the total had soared to $22 trillion.5 One offshoot—largely unintended—of this tremendous growth was that banks’ financial statements became increasingly obscure. Derivatives weren’t disclosed in any way that was meaningful to outsiders. And as the volume of deals exploded, the banks’ balance sheets revealed less and less of their total obligations. By the mid-1990s, the financial statements of even many midsized banks were wrapped in an impenetrable haze.

银行家们忙于赚钱，根本无暇顾及这个快速发展行业中的风险或信息披露的粗糙。少数发出警告的人，例如上世纪80年代曾在所罗门兄弟公司工作的著名经济学家亨利·考夫曼，都被置之不理。考夫曼回忆道：

The bankers were too busy making money to bother about the risks or the shoddy disclosure in this fast-growing business. The few who did voice caution, such as Henry Kaufman, a noted economist who worked at Salomon in the 1980s, were ignored. Kaufman recalled:

我至今仍记得梅里韦瑟团队加入后，我们开始做利率互换交易的情景。当时我们一直在讨论应该设定什么样的交易限额。交易额不断攀升。从10亿到20亿，再到50亿。我们始终没有一个分析框架来决定应该做到什么程度。

I still remember when Meriwether’s group came in and we started doing interest-rate swaps. There was always a question of what type of limits we would set. It just kept mounting and mounting. After we had a billion it went to two billion. Then it went to five billion. There was never an analytical framework for saying how far we should go.

到1995年，当梅里韦瑟的交易员们欣然入主长期基金时，该集团的衍生品总规模已达6500亿美元。短短两年内，总额翻了一番，达到惊人的1.25万亿美元。鉴于长期基金（以及其他所有基金）披露信息的不透明性，根本无法根据具体交易来确定该基金的衍生品风险。而且，由于其许多合约都是对冲合约，往往会相互抵消，因此也无法计算长期基金的真实经济风险敞口。我们只能说，它似乎增长得非常快——华尔街各家银行的风险敞口都在快速增长。几乎不知不觉中，华尔街已经卷入了一场巨大的信任游戏，每家银行都通过一张几乎无需首付或只需少量首付的合约义务网络与邻居紧密相连。

By 1995, when Meriwether’s traders were happily ensconced at Long-Term, the group had a total derivative book worth $650 billion. Within two years, the total doubled, to an astounding $1.25 trillion. Given the opaque nature of Long-Term’s (and everyone else’s) disclosures, it was impossible to pinpoint the fund’s derivative risks according to specific trades. And since many of its contracts were hedges that tended to cancel each other out, it was impossible to calculate Long-Term’s true economic exposure. One could say only that it appeared to be growing very quickly—as were exposures up and down Wall Street. Almost imperceptibly, the Street had bought into a massive faith game, in which each bank had become knitted to its neighbor through a web of contractual obligations requiring little or no down payment.

监管机构的担忧日益加剧。到了20世纪90年代中期，华尔街已经习惯了每年一到两起衍生品“冲击”。一些银行或机构，前一天还被认为运营良好，第二天就可能因为隐藏的衍生品风险敞口而轰然倒塌。橙县银行、信孚银行、霸菱银行、德国金属集团、住友商事等公司相继披露了突如其来的巨额损失。随着个案频发，监管机构开始担忧整个系统可能遭受冲击：他们害怕，只要牵扯到某个关键因素，整个体系就会崩溃。但真的存在这样一根关键的线吗？是否存在一家与华尔街关系如此紧密的公司，其倒闭足以撼动整个体系？这种担忧或许有些杞人忧天，但并非毫无道理。正如前财政部长尼古拉斯·布雷迪所说：“每次发生火灾，这些人（衍生品交易员）都身处其中。” 6

Regulators became increasingly worried. By the mid-1990s, Wall Street had become accustomed to one or two derivative “shocks” a year. Banks or institutions considered healthy one day would go up in smoke the next due to hidden derivative exposures. One by one, Orange County, Bankers Trust, Barings Bank, Metallgesellschaft, Sumitomo Corporation, and others revealed sudden and massive losses. As the list of individual traumas grew, regulators began to fret about the possibility of a shock to the entire system: pull on the right thread, and the entire ball of string would unravel, they feared. But was there such a thread, a firm so intertwined with Wall Street that its failure could undo the system? Such fears may have been unfocused, but they were not unreasonable. In the words of Nicholas Brady, the former Treasury secretary, “Every time there’s been a fire, these guys [derivative traders] have been around it.”6

早在1994年春季，就在长期债券开始交易之际，纽约联储就对对冲基金轻易获得信贷（包括衍生品信贷）感到不安。同年4月，纽约联储执行副总裁切斯特·费尔德伯格致信纽约地区所有银行的首席执行官，告诫银行家们不要放弃其历来秉持的审慎原则。“客户的信贷额度是信贷风险管理的重要工具，”费尔德伯格警告说。 7 为了应对这些担忧，美联储监管人员于1997年与几家纽约大型银行的经理会面，讨论这些银行与对冲基金的关系。 8美联储审查人员敦促各银行加强对冲基金账户的监管，但出人意料的是，他们报告称各银行已经在改进监管。 9

As early as the spring of 1994, just when Long-Term was starting to trade, the New York Fed was becoming uneasy about hedge funds’ easy access to credit, including derivative credit. In April, in a letter to the CEOs of every bank in the New York region, Chester Feldberg, executive vice president of the New York Fed, admonished the bankers not to eschew their historic duty to prudence. “Credit limits for customers are an essential tool for credit risk management,” Feldberg warned.7 Following up such concerns, Fed regulators met with managers at several large New York banks in 1997 to discuss the banks’ relationships with hedge funds.8 The Fed examiners urged the banks to step up their monitoring of hedge fund accounts but, surprisingly, reported that the banks were already improving their supervision.9

在衍生品问题上，美联储的政策制定部门采取了自由放任的态度——这始于格林斯潘，他对这些新型金融工具的精妙之处着迷不已。在公开辩论中，格林斯潘屡次与以花旗集团的约翰·里德为首的私人银行家们联手，竭力阻止更严格的信息披露要求。即便对冲基金越来越多地利用互换交易来规避美联储自身的保证金规则，格林斯潘也对此表示赞同。令人难以置信的是，格林斯潘非但没有试图将某种形式的保证金规则扩展到衍生品领域，反而提议彻底取消保证金规则。他1995年向国会提交的证词读起来就像一份银行家的辩护状。其核心是一个看似简单却极具诱惑力的观点：更多的交易（以及由此带来的更多贷款）总是且本质上是好的，因为它能增强“流动性”。

With regard to derivatives, the policy-making arm of the Fed took a laissez-faire approach—starting with Greenspan, who was enamored with the seamless artistry of the new financial tools. In public debates, Greenspan repeatedly joined forces with private bankers, led by Citicorp’s John Reed, who were fighting tooth and nail to head off proposals for tougher disclosure requirements. Even as hedge funds increasingly used swaps to dodge the Fed’s own margin rules, Greenspan cast an approving eye. Incredibly, rather than trying to extend some form of margin rule to the derivative world, Greenspan proposed to eliminate the margin rules entirely. His 1995 testimony to Congress read like a banker’s brief. At its heart was a beguilingly simple idea: that more trading (and hence more lending) was always and inherently good because it bolstered “liquidity.”

取消这些融资限制将允许更多融资选择，从而提高经纪交易商的安全性和稳健性，并有助于更有效的流动性管理……就经纪交易商而言，美联储认为其介入监管其证券信贷并无公共政策目的。10

Removal of these financing constraints would promote the safety and soundness of broker-dealers by permitting more financing alternatives and hence more effective liquidity management. . . . In the case of broker-dealers, the Federal Reserve Board sees no public policy purpose in it being involved in overseeing their securities credit.10

适度的流动性能润滑市场运转；格林斯潘忽略的是，流动性过剩反而可能导致市场失控。 11过多的交易会助长投机，而且无论流动性多么充裕，在清算之日到来时，任何市场都无法容纳所有潜在的卖方。但格林斯潘绝非第一个被“只要流动性再多一点，就能永远避免崩盘”这种想法所迷惑的人。

A bit of liquidity greases the wheels of markets; what Greenspan overlooked is that with too much liquidity, the market is apt to skid off the tracks.11 Too much trading encourages speculation, and no market, no matter how liquid, can accommodate all potential sellers when the day of reckoning comes. But Greenspan was hardly the first to be seduced by the notion that if only we had a little more “liquidity,” we could prevent collapses forever.

除了美联储之外，唯一能够限制衍生品贷款的只有银行。但华尔街在经济繁荣时期从不自我约束。银行自身的资产负债表不断膨胀；到20世纪90年代末，华尔街的杠杆率高达25比1。 12 银行虽然流动性充裕，甚至可以说是被流动性淹没，但它们必须找到资金的流向。对冲基金是最诱人的目标。“人们都在关注世界的美好一面，”信孚银行的交易员兼对冲基金经理史蒂夫·弗里德海姆指出，“我可以借到任何我想要的金额，而且利率还在不断下降。我经常接到银行的电话，说：‘嘿，我们又给你弄到了5000万美元——我们弄到了1亿美元！’” 随着银行不遗余力地追逐基金业务，它们悄悄地放松了标准，降低了负面消息带来的风险。到1996年，华尔街每天的回购交易额达到5000亿美元，货币和利率互换交易额达到2000亿美元。 13

Save for the Fed, the only ones who could restrain derivative lending were the banks. But Wall Street never polices itself in good times. The banks’ own balance sheets were steadily ballooning; by the late 1990s, Wall Street was leveraged 25 to 1.12 Awash with liquidity if not quite drowning in it, the banks had to find an outlet for their capital. The most tempting targets were hedge funds. “People were looking at the good side of the world,” noted Steve Freidheim, a trader and hedge fund manager at Bankers Trust. “I could borrow any amount I wanted, and the rates kept coming down. I’d get calls from banks saying, ‘Hey, we got another fifty million for you—we got a hundred million!’” As banks relentlessly chased the fund business, they silently relaxed their standards, marking down the risk of possible negative news. By 1996, Wall Street was trading $500 billion in repos and $200 billion in currency and interest rate swaps every day.13

借款人无需说明其全部风险敞口；贷款人也无需询问。每家银行​​都清楚自己对单个客户的风险敞口，尤其是对长期基金的风险敞口。但没有人费心去想，这家对冲基金是否可能对其他十几家银行也存在类似的风险敞口。“你会和他们做很多生意，”瑞士银行经理西西里亚诺回忆道，“你会以为自己是他们最大的客户，但实际上你只是第十名。你简直不敢相信他们的交易量竟然这么大。”

No borrower had to account for its total exposure; no lender asked. Each bank knew the extent of its own exposure to an individual client, in particular to Long-Term. None bothered to think about whether the hedge fund might be similarly exposed to a dozen other banks. “You’d be doing big chunks of business with them,” recalled Siciliano, the manager at Swiss Bank. “You’d assume you were their number one provider, but really you were number ten. You couldn’t believe they were doing that much volume.”

瑞士银行对Long-Term公司产生了微妙而深远的影响。这家公司在衍生品领域技艺精湛，不易被格林威治的那些明星人物所折服，其发展历程与Long-Term公司颇为相似。1977年，当商品交易员开始运用默顿和斯科尔斯发明的期权公式时，从事大豆交易的爱德华·奥康纳和威廉·奥康纳兄弟创立了一家新公司，专门投资期权。奥康纳联合公司迅速成为新兴衍生品公司中最精明的公司之一。1986年，该公司聘请了来自麻省理工学院的电气工程师大卫·索罗，他言简意赅、表达精准，同时也是一位杰出的量化交易员。1987年股市崩盘后，期权交易员遭受了巨大损失，奥康纳公司意识到自身资金实力不足。花旗集团、信孚银行和瑞银集团都曾有机会收购奥康纳公司，但最终都放弃了。最终，在1991年，瑞士银行收购了该公司。这无疑是一项大胆的举措。瑞士银行业如同封闭的官僚机构，只有瑞士公民才有机会获得工作和晋升。在瑞士三大银行中，瑞士银行最为传统。瑞士银行国际部主管马塞尔·奥斯佩尔决心改变这种现状。奥斯佩尔十六岁时便开始在银行当学徒，一边上学一边在银行工作，但他曾在美林证券工作过一段时间，并意识到瑞士银行业必须现代化，否则就会像布谷鸟钟一样走向衰落。他利用奥康纳公司来撼动巴塞尔的保守文化，引入了诸如奖励交易员长期业绩的激励机制等美国式理念。1995年，奥斯佩尔促成了对英国最大投资银行SG Warburg的收购，瑞士银行从此告别了封闭的局面。

Swiss Bank had a subtle but powerful impact on Long-Term. Too sophisticated in derivatives to be easily impressed by the superstars in Greenwich, its history had paralleled Long-Term’s. In 1977, when commodity traders had begun to apply the options formula that Merton and Scholes had invented, Edward and William O’Connor, two brothers who traded soybeans, had founded a new firm to invest in options. O’Connor & Associates became one of the savviest of the new derivatives firms. In 1986, the firm hired David Solo, a terse, precise-spoken electrical engineer from MIT and a brilliant quantitative trader. After the 1987 stock market crash, when options traders suffered massive losses, O’Connor realized it needed deeper pockets. Citicorp, Bankers Trust, and UBS all had a chance to acquire O’Connor but passed. Finally, in 1991, Swiss Bank bought it. This was a bold move. Swiss banks were cloistered bureaucracies in which only Swiss nationals could hope for employment and promotion. Of Switzerland’s big three banks, Swiss Bank was the most traditional. Marcel Ospel, the head of Swiss Bank’s international division, meant to change this. Though he had started as a sixteen-year-old apprentice, splitting his time between banking and school, Ospel had done a stint at Merrill Lynch and realized that Switzerland’s banks would have to modernize or go the way of the cuckoo clock. He used O’Connor to shake up the parochial culture in Basel, injecting Yankee ideas such as an incentive system that rewarded traders for longterm performance. In 1995, Ospel engineered the purchase of S. G. Warburg, Britain’s largest investment bank, and Swiss Bank was cloistered no more.

为时已晚，奥斯佩尔在竞争对手瑞银的同行卡比亚拉维塔才意识到，瑞士银行正在打造一个远超自己银行的衍生品巨头。奥斯佩尔性格内敛腼腆，而卡比亚拉维塔则魅力四射、嗓门洪亮。卡比亚拉维塔惊慌失措，急于超越这个后起之秀。他尤其渴望与长期投资公司建立关系，他认为该公司是衍生品领域的理想合作伙伴。他认为，最好的办法就是批准迈伦·斯科尔斯的认股权证。在瑞士银行，这份认股权证遭到了断然拒绝，但在瑞银，它却悄然传到了银行高层。交易员林和衍生品主管鲍尔（他至今仍后悔当初没有投资长期投资公司）都接受了这份认股权证。瑞银的风险经理史蒂文·舒尔曼和负责交易的沃纳·博纳杜勒也表示赞同。最终，决定权落在了卡比亚拉维塔手中。 1997年6月，急于求成的瑞银同意向长期基金出售其梦寐以求的认股权证。作为协议的另一部分，瑞银承担了巨大的风险，成为该基金的最大单一投资者。

Too late, Cabiallavetta, Ospel’s counterpart at the rival UBS, realized that Swiss Bank was building a powerhouse in derivatives that outclassed his own. Charismatic and loud where Ospel was quiet and shy, Cabiallavetta panicked and became desperate to overtake the upstart. He was especially keen on building the relationship with Long-Term, which he idealized as the perfect partner in derivatives. The best way to do that, he decided, was to approve Myron Scholes’s warrant. At Swiss Bank, the warrant had been flatly rejected, but at UBS, it had percolated toward the highest echelons of the bank. Lim, the trader, and Bauer, the derivatives boss, who still regretted not having made an investment in Long-Term, had both embraced the warrant. Steven Schulman, the risk manager at UBS, had given it a favorable nod. So had Werner Bonadurer, who oversaw trading. That left it to Cabiallavetta. In June 1997, a hungry UBS agreed to sell Long-Term its long-sought warrant. In a companion part of the agreement, UBS, assuming a massive risk, became the single biggest investor in the fund.

根据协议条款，部分合伙人需向瑞银支付2.89亿美元的溢价。作为回报，瑞银承诺将未来七年内，持有价值8亿美元长期基金的投资者所获得的任何利润（无论多少）支付给合伙人。为了对冲这项义务，瑞银购买了该基金价值8亿美元的权益。此外，作为一项额外优惠，瑞银还被允许向长期基金额外投资2.66亿美元。销售员坦南鲍姆表示，这就是“基本思路”：“如果我们向他们出售其股票的看涨期权，他们就会允许我们再向该基金的股权投资三分之一。”

The terms called for a group of the partners to pay UBS a premium of $289 million. In return, UBS promised to pay the partners any profits (more or less) that an investor with $800 million worth of Long-Term would make over the next seven years. As a hedge against this obligation, UBS bought an $800 million interest in the fund. Finally, as a sweetener, the bank was permitted to invest an additional $266 million in Long-Term. That was the “basic idea,” according to Tannenbaum, the salesman: “If we wrote them calls on their own stock, they would let us invest a third again as much in the equity of the fund.”

坦南鲍姆的上司们将这份授权书视为一次政变。瑞银的经理们欣喜若狂，甚至为了这笔交易应该由银行的哪个部门来记录而争执不休。博纳杜勒坚持要将这笔交易交由固定收益部门处理——这听起来有些奇怪，但博纳杜勒和卡比阿拉维塔是好友。随后，部分交易被转移到了银行的财务部门，该部门为此支付了5%的溢价。瑞银的14位经理们认为，最终他们可以将这笔长期投资重新包装，卖给富裕的客户；与此同时，他们正窃窃私语地谈论着与梅里韦瑟建立的新战略关系。卡比阿拉维塔在香港举杯庆祝他们的联盟，他和梅里韦瑟当时正在香港参加世界银行年会，这历来是国际金融家们趋之若鹜的盛会。

Tannenbaum’s superiors regarded the warrant as a coup. UBS’s managers were so ecstatic that they fought over which division of the bank should book the transaction. Bonadurer claimed it for the fixed-income division—an odd choice, except that Bonadurer and Cabi-allavetta were close friends. Then, part of the deal was shifted to the bank’s treasury department, which paid a 5 percent premium.14 UBS’s managers figured that eventually they could repackage their Long-Term investment and sell it to wealthy clients; in the meantime, they chortled about their new strategic relationship to Meriwether. Cabiallavetta toasted their alliance in Hong Kong, where he and J.M. were attending the annual meeting of the World Bank, always a hot attraction for international financiers.

在长期投资公司，希利布兰德和斯科尔斯就认股权证的分配问题展开了激烈的争论。斯科尔斯为此绞尽脑汁，但希利布兰德财力雄厚，一如既往地想要独占鳌头。认股权证可以将合伙人的预期收入转化为资本利得，从而降低他们的税率，但更重要的动机似乎是希望获得更大的收益。假设基金增值，认股权证将像火箭燃料一样助推他们的财富增长。当然，如果基金失败，合伙人将损失2.89亿美元。但成功往往会让人对失败的可能性视而不见。就在他们专长所能发挥的领域日渐式微之际，合伙人抛弃了他们与生俱来的谨慎——这种谨慎曾让他们受益匪浅——就像脱下一件旧西装一样。

At Long-Term, Hilibrand and Scholes stormily debated how big a share of the warrant would be allotted to each. Scholes had put his brains into it, but Hilibrand had the most money and, characteristically, wanted the lion’s share. By switching the partners’ prospective income to capital gains, the warrant would lower their tax rate, but the more significant motive seemed to be the hope of further gains. Assuming the fund rose, the warrant would work on their fortunes like rocket fuel. Of course, if the fund should falter, the partners would lose the $289 million. But there is nothing like success to blind one to the possibility of failure. At the very time when the outlets for their narrow skills were closing, the partners tossed off their innate caution, which had served them so well, like an old suit.

许多人将全部净资产投入该基金。前美联储官员穆林斯是个例外；他秉持着银行家一贯的谨慎作风，选择不认购认股权证。西西里亚诺指出，除此之外，“这些人对自己所做的一切深信不疑。”合伙人还与另一家瑞士投资银行瑞士信贷达成了一项类似的认股权证协议，但规模较小。

Many put their entire net worth into the fund. Mullins, the former Fed official, was an exception; he stuck to his characteristic banker’s prudence and opted out of the warrant.15 Otherwise, Siciliano noted, “These guys believed in what they were doing with every ounce of their being.” The partners also forged a similar, though smaller, warrant deal with Crédit Suisse, another Swiss investment bank.

但这还不够。为了进一步扩大杠杆，合伙人的管理公司LTCM从三家银行——摩根大通银行、富利银行和法国里昂信贷银行——总共借款1亿美元，而合伙人又将这笔钱全部重新投入到基金中。他们渴望将数百万美元变成数十亿美元，这种渴望没有止境，也丝毫不顾及任何风险。对于这些自诩为理性信徒的人来说，他们这种冒险的追求似乎令人费解，除非他们认为成为最富有的人就等于证明自己是最聪明的人。

But even that was not enough. To leverage even further, LTCM, the partners’ management company, borrowed a total of $100 million from a trio of banks—Chase, Fleet Bank, and Crédit Lyonnais of France—which money the partners plowed right back into the fund.16 Their hunger to turn millions into billions knew no bounds, nor did it recognize any risks. For men who prided themselves on being disciples of reason, their drive to live on the edge seemed inexplicable, unless they believed that becoming the richest would certify them as also being the smartest.

仿佛是为了挑战命运，希利布兰德个人又从里昂信贷银行借了2400万美元。里昂信贷银行设立了一个项目，允许合伙人以其在基金中的权益作为抵押进行贷款。专门从事外汇交易的汉斯·胡夫施密德借了1500万美元，另外两位合伙人借的金额较小。 17此外，一些合伙人还通过他们的经纪商贝尔斯登进行了个人杠杆投资。考虑到基金本身的杠杆率已经非常高，合伙人，尤其是希利布兰德，如同在易燃的火药桶上涂抹煤油一般，危险地不断增加杠杆。与一个孤注一掷的穷人不同，已经富可敌国的希利布兰德几乎没有什么可赢的，却可能输得一无所有。

As if to tempt the fates, Hilibrand personally borrowed $24 million more from Crédit Lyonnais, which set up a program to let the partners borrow against their interests in the fund. Hans Hufschmid, who specialized in currency trades, borrowed $15 million, and two other partners borrowed lesser amounts.17 In addition, some of the partners had leveraged personally with Bear Stearns, their broker. Considering that the fund itself was so heavily leveraged, the partners, Hilibrand in particular, were dangerously adding leverage to leverage, as if coating a flammable tinderbox with kerosene. As opposed to a poor man who bets the limit on a single horse, the already rich Hilibrand had little to win and everything to lose.

瑞银认股权证在最糟糕的时刻为长期基金筹集了10亿美元的股权——当时该基金正苦苦寻找现有资金的投资标的，同时还要应对日益激烈的套利竞争。1997年上半年，该基金的税前收益率仅为13%——虽然仍然可观，但远低于此前的平均水平。其杠杆率（同样不包括衍生品）从30:1降至20:1，这表明投资机会已日渐稀少。包括斯科尔斯在内的一群持怀疑态度的合伙人对该基金的投资组合越来越感到不安。

The UBS warrant raised $1 billion of equity for Long-Term at the worst possible moment—when the fund was struggling to find places to invest the money it already had and when it was fighting off more and more competitors in arbitrage. In the first half of 1997, it earned only 13 percent before fees—still impressive, though well below its prior average. Its leverage (again, not counting derivatives) fell from 30 to 1 to 20 to 1, evidence that opportunities had grown scarce. A group of skeptical partners, including Scholes, were growing increasingly uncomfortable with the fund’s portfolio.

其中一个亮点是日本市场，Long-Term 在那里盈利颇丰，这在一定程度上要归功于大卫·莫德斯特（David Modest），一位头发花白、43岁的前学者。莫德斯特、罗森菲尔德（Rosenfeld）和一位名叫卡尔·胡滕洛赫（Carl Huttenlocher）的年轻交易员设计了一系列股票套利策略，利用日本人对期权缺乏了解以及期权定价错误这一弱点。Long-Term 的模型使这成为一项“显而易见”且利润丰厚的交易。莫德斯特是一位来自伯克利的幽默理论家，他和少数其他交易员会上夜班，一直工作到凌晨1点，直到第二天东京股市收盘。不久之后，当格林威治的人们还在沉睡时，一小部分人会赶到伦敦，赶上日本权证的开盘交易。“我们有几个像大卫（莫德斯特）这样的交易员，简直累死累活，”罗森菲尔德回忆道。1997年6月，随着 Long-Term 在东京开设办事处，交易员们终于可以恢复正常的工作时间了。该公司由黄志富（Chi-fu Huang）和阿琼·克里希纳马查尔（Arjun Krishnamachar）运营。黄志富是麻省理工学院一位备受推崇的数学家和建模专家，被 Long-Term 从高盛挖走；阿琼·克里希纳马查尔则是所罗门兄弟公司的前掉期交易员。

One bright spot was Japan, where Long-Term was extremely profitable, thanks in part to David Modest, a graying, forty-three-year-old former scholar. Modest, Rosenfeld, and a young trader named Carl Huttenlocher devised a series of equity arbitrages to exploit the Japanese lack of familiarity with, and mispricing of, options. Long-Term’s models made this an “obvious” and, indeed, highly lucrative trade. Modest, a droll theoretician from Berkeley, and a handful of others would work the graveyard shift, staying until 1 A.M., when the next day’s Tokyo market finally closed. Shortly after, while Greenwich slept, a skeleton crew would arrive in time for the opening in London, where Japanese warrants traded. “We had a couple of traders like David [Modest] just killing themselves,” Rosenfeld recalled. In June 1997, the traders were able to revert to normal hours, as Long-Term opened a Tokyo office. It was run by Chi-fu Huang, a prized MIT mathematician and expert in modeling whom Long-Term snatched away from Goldman Sachs, and Arjun Krishnamachar, a former swaps trader at Salomon.

多年来一直往返日本的JM很欣赏在日本拥有机构影响力。对于一家在东京的西方对冲基金而言，长期基金的声望非同凡响。穆林斯曾在美联储工作期间非正式地为日本政府官员提供咨询，在长期基金，他继续发挥着这一作用。无论在何处开展业务，该基金的触角都能延伸到最高层。合伙人的人脉网络是一项重要的资产。

J.M., who had been traveling to Japan for years, liked having an institutional presence there. For a Western hedge fund in Tokyo, Long-Term had remarkable cachet. Mullins, who had informally advised Japanese government officials when he had worked at the Fed, continued to do so at Long-Term. Wherever it operated, the fund’s tentacles penetrated to the highest reaches. The partners’ circle of contacts was a major asset.

即使在日本，合伙人也进行了一项颇具争议的交易。1997年，日本长期债券收益率仅为2%，看似触底。长期基金公司（Long-Term）进行了一项裸卖、未对冲的押注，赌该利率会上升——这是一种所谓的方向性交易，因为它押注的是单一利率，而非利差。许多合伙人对这项交易持怀疑态度，因为对长期基金公司而言，这笔交易的投机性异常强。但希利布兰德和哈加尼越来越不顾其他弱势合伙人的意愿，主导着公司的运营。由于业绩如此出色，人们很容易将那些反对者斥为杞人忧天。

Even in Japan, the partners pursued a controversial trade. In 1997, Japan’s long bond was yielding only 2 percent, seemingly rock bottom. Long-Term placed a naked, unhedged bet that this rate would rise—a so-called directional trade in that it was betting on a single rate as distinct from a spread. Many of the partners had doubts about the trade, which for Long-Term was unusually speculative. But Hilibrand and Haghani were increasingly running the firm irrespective of the weaker partners’ wishes. With the results so good, it was easy to dismiss the naysayers as worrywarts.

在1997年7月举行的长期基金年度股东大会上，合伙人承认他们对债券套利利差的收窄感到担忧。为了不危及长期基金作为离岸基金的法律地位，会议不得不在美国境外举行。会议地点选在多伦多机场附近的一家酒店，以便合伙人当天即可往返。只有四位合伙人（Leahy、Mullins、Rosenfeld和Scholes）以及大约25位投资者出席了会议。气氛十分低迷：利差收窄的速度比合伙人预期的要快，挤压了潜在利润。尽管Rosenfeld一向沉默寡言，但他还是透露长期基金正在涉足股票交易。投资者们顿时来了兴致。一位投资者问道：“我们听说你是风险套利领域最大的玩家。真是这样吗？”Rosenfeld含糊其辞地回答。投资者们意识到，长期基金的末日即将到来。 “你有没有计划归还这笔钱？”一位投资者问道。罗森菲尔德的回答依然含糊其辞。“好吧，不管怎样，别把我的钱还给我。”投资者说道。

At Long-Term’s 1997 annual meeting, in July, the partners admitted they were concerned about the shrinking spreads in bond arbitrage. The meeting had to be held outside the United States, so as not to jeopardize Long-Term’s legal status as an offshore fund. It was hosted in a hotel by the Toronto airport so that the partners could jet in and out in a day. Only four of them (Leahy, Mullins, Rosenfeld, and Scholes) and about twenty-five investors attended. The mood was downbeat: spreads had converged more quickly than the partners had expected, squeezing potential profits. Though typically taciturn, Rosenfeld did reveal that Long-Term was getting involved in equity trades. The small crowd of investors suddenly livened. One investor demanded, “We hear you’re the biggest player in risk arbitrage. Are you?” Rosenfeld responded evasively. The investors sensed that Long-Term was approaching a denouement. “Do you have any plan to return the money?” an investor asked. Again, Rosenfeld was vague. “Well, whatever you do, don’t return mine,” the investor said.

与套利前景黯淡不谋而合的是，两位著名的金融学教授发表了一篇论文，指出套利的风险远比其拥护者所宣称的要高——这是学术界首次对长期投资模式发起挑战。哈佛大学的安德烈·施莱弗和芝加哥大学的罗伯特·W·维什尼在著名的《金融杂志》上发表文章，极具前瞻性地警告说，如果“噪音交易者”（即不明真相的投机者）将价格推离真实价值，像长期投资这样的套利公司可能会被击垮。他们以惊人的远见预测，在这种情况下，套利者将“遭受不利的价格冲击”，并被迫在市场低点清算。 18默顿在论文发表前阅读了早期版本，但并未被说服；在剑桥的一次学者会议上，他驳斥了市场可能被击垮的说法。 19

Coincident with the dour outlook for arbitrage, two prominent finance professors published a paper arguing that arbitrage was far riskier than its adherents claimed—the first shot at Long-Term’s model fired from within academe. Writing in the prestigious Journal of Finance, Andrei Shleifer of Harvard and Robert W. Vishny of Chicago presciently warned that an arbitrage firm of Long-Term’s type could be overwhelmed if “noise traders” (meaning uninformed speculators) pushed prices away from true value. With uncanny foresight, they predicted that, in such a case, arbitrageurs would “experience an adverse price shock” and be forced to liquidate at market lows.18 Merton read an early version prior to publication but was not convinced; at a conference of scholars in Cambridge, he pooh-poohed the notion that markets could ever be overwhelmed.19

随后，在认股权证交易达成几周后的7月，国际市场剧烈震荡。泰国深陷金融违约泥潭，允许其货币自由浮动。结果，泰铢迅速下跌20%。疲软的局面蔓延至菲律宾、马来西亚和韩国的货币。面对暴跌，摩根大通新兴市场专家卡里姆·阿卜杜勒-莫塔尔宣称：“我们认为抛售被夸大了。” 20 然而，抛售仍在继续。新加坡元遭到大量抛售。只有印尼——亚洲“四小龙”中最大的国家——似乎抵抗住了冲击。随后，印尼盾单日下跌5%。不到一个月，专家们不再谈论亚洲的奇迹，而是称之为亚洲的“危机”。繁荣时期拔地而起的玻璃幕墙摩天大楼突然空置，工厂也停工了。马来西亚总理马哈蒂尔·穆罕默德指责海外“流氓投机者”，特别是乔治·索罗斯，出卖了东虎。

Then, in July, just weeks after the warrant deal, international markets were badly shaken. Thailand, beset by financial defaults, allowed its currency to float. It promptly fell 20 percent. The weakness spread to currencies in the Philippines, Malaysia, and South Korea. Responding to the sharp declines, Karim Abdel-Motaal, an emerging-markets guru at J. P. Morgan, declared, “We think the sell-offs have been exaggerated.”20 They continued anyway. Singapore’s dollar came under heavy selling. Only Indonesia, by far the largest of the Asian “Tigers,” seemed resistant. Then, on a single day, the rupiah fell 5 percent. In less than a month, pundits had stopped talking of Asia’s miracle; now it was Asia’s “crisis.” Glass-walled skyscrapers erected during the boom were suddenly going vacant, and factories stood idle. Mahathir Mohamad, the prime minister of Malaysia, blamed “rogue speculators” from overseas, specifically George Soros, for selling the Tigers out.

马哈蒂尔抓对了部分罪魁祸首，但却搞错了罪名。外国人弃船逃生很难被指责；他们的罪过在于提供了过于便捷的短期信贷，正是这些信贷让这艘船以全速驶向深渊。在财政部长罗伯特·鲁宾救助墨西哥的鼓舞下，西方银行和投资者将大量资金涌入亚洲，助长了投机性投资，并为该地区的腐败行为提供了资金支持。鲁宾敦促亚洲各国政府取消资本管制，从而允许资金涌入——尽管该地区的企业信息披露和监管严重不足，这无疑为资金流入铺平了道路。“事实很简单，一些非常老练的银行在对印尼公司的财务状况一无所知的情况下就向它们发放了贷款，”世界银行行长詹姆斯·沃尔芬森指出。21

Mahathir had some of the right culprits but the wrong crime. Foreigners could hardly be blamed for deserting a listing ship; their sin was having provided the too-easy short-term credit that had launched the ship at flank speed. Comforted by Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin’s bailout of Mexico, Western banks and investors had shoveled money at Asia, fueling speculative investments and underwriting the region’s corrupt behavior. Rubin had paved the way by urging Asian governments to lift controls on capital and thus to allow the money to pour in—despite the area’s appalling lack of corporate disclosure and regulatory oversight. “The simple fact is that very sophisticated banks loaned to Indonesian companies, without any real knowledge of their financial condition,” noted James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank.21

尽管西方投资者屡屡犯同样的错误——今天对发展中国家抱有浪漫幻想，明天便会为自己的天真后悔不已——但银行家们却始终没有吸取教训。1996年，930亿美元的外国资本涌入印尼、马来西亚、菲律宾、韩国和泰国，而当时这些国家的经济增长正在放缓。如今，同样的资金却在撤离，令全球市场动荡不安。从长期投资的角度来看，亚洲市场的起伏都具有启发意义。宽松的信贷环境（对冲基金也从中受益）导致了不明智的过度投资。随后，当形势逆转时，格林斯潘大肆吹捧的流动性却荡然无存，损失几乎是随机蔓延的。一旦市场风暴爆发，其走向便难以预料。

Though Western investors had repeatedly made the same mistake—today romanticizing the developing world, tomorrow coming to rue their naïveté—the bankers never learned. In 1996, $93 billion of foreign capital had flooded Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand even as their economies were slowing. Now that same money was draining out, unnerving markets around the world. From Long-Term’s point of view, both Asia’s uphill and downhill slopes were instructive. Easy credit, which hedge funds also enjoyed, had led to ill-advised and excessive investments. Then, when the tables had turned, Greenspan’s much-vaunted liquidity was nowhere to be found, and the damage spread almost at random. Once a typhoon breaks loose in markets, there is no telling where it will go.

夏末，该基金遭遇了一则坏消息：MCI的合并谈判价格被重新压低。MCI的股价暴跌，长期基金一夜之间损失了1.5亿美元——这是它涉足危险领域的第一个迹象。在亚洲，长期基金的投资主要集中在日本，该基金则安然度过了这场风暴。事实上，9月份是长期基金表现最好的月份之一：盈利3亿美元。

In late summer, the fund received a bit of bad news: the MCI merger was renegotiated at a lower price. MCI’s stock price collapsed, and Long-Term lost $150 million overnight—the first sign that it had been fishing in dangerous waters. In Asia, where Long-Term’s investments were primarily in Japan, the fund was weathering the storm. September, in fact, was one of Long-Term’s best months: it earned $300 million.

但公司的前景却日渐黯淡。合伙人与美林证券在沃特维尔举行了一年一度的高尔夫球聚会后，宣布了一项令人震惊的指令：长期基金的外部投资者必须收回大约一半的投资，正如那位在年会上担忧的投资者所预料的那样。“基金拥有过剩资本，”梅里韦瑟解释道。该基金的资本账户接近70亿美元，几乎与实力雄厚的美林证券的资本相当。为了强调积极的一面，梅里韦瑟补充道：“这主要是由于过去实际收益率高于预期，以及基金投资者选择的高再投资率，导致资本基础大幅增长。” 22

But the firm’s prospects were steadily dimming. When the partners returned from their annual golfing party in Waterville with Merrill Lynch, they announced a shocking diktat: outside investors in Long-Term would have to take back about half of their money, just as the investor at the annual meeting had feared. “The fund has excess capital,” Meriwether explained. The capital account was close to $7 billion, almost as much as at mighty Merrill Lynch. Accenting the positive, J.M. added, “This has occurred primarily because of a substantial increase in the capital base from the larger-than-expected, past realized rates of return, and high reinvestment rates elected by the fund’s investors.”22

然而，残酷的现实是，利差已经收窄，投资机会也已减少。随着欧洲共同货币的诞生已成定局，欧洲趋同带来的轻松获利机会也已过去。随着国界的消失，意大利和德国债券之间的利差在短短六个月内就从2个百分点缩小到了0.75个百分点。

Still, there was no getting around the harsher truth that spreads had narrowed and opportunities had diminished. With a common European currency now a fait accompli, the easy money on convergence in Europe had already been made. With borders disappearing, the spread between Italian and German bonds had shrunk from 2 percentage points to three quarters of a point in just six months.

长期投资公司的计划是，在1997年底返还1994年（公司成立第一年）的所有投资收益，并返还此后的所有投资（本金和利润）。该计划不包括合伙人和员工，也部分排除了一些大型战略投资者，例如台湾银行。长期投资公司的清算经纪商贝尔斯登的首席执行官吉米·凯恩也获得了豁免。其他投资者要求继续持有股份，但遭到了长期投资公司的拒绝。他们自然对梅里韦瑟及其手下感到愤怒，这些人本应维护投资者的利益，却给予自己特殊待遇。“这太离谱了！”一位投资者向美林证券怒斥道，“在他们需要我们的时候，我们一直在他们身边。”

Long-Term’s plan was to return, at the end of 1997, all profits on money invested during 1994, its first year, and to return all money (principal and profits) invested after that date. It excluded the partners and employees and partially excluded some big strategic investors such as the Bank of Taiwan. Jimmy Cayne, chief executive of Bear Stearns, Long-Term’s clearing broker, got an exception, too. Others demanded to stay in, but Long-Term turned them down. They were naturally angry that Meriwether and his boys, supposedly charged with watching out for their investors’ interests, were giving themselves preferential treatment. “This is outrageous!” one investor thundered to Merrill Lynch. “We were there when they needed us.”

这项计划在长期资本管理公司内部也引发了争议。JM的朋友吉姆·麦肯蒂认为，出于保守考虑，不返还本金是明智之举。形影不离的斯科尔斯和默顿也强烈反对返还本金。他们认为，这样做会损害公司作为资产管理公司的声誉。此外，由于这两位学者持有长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的股份比例远高于他们持有的投资组合股份比例，因此他们更希望看到管理的资金总额增长。另一方面，持有大量基金股份的希利布兰德和哈加尼则不希望通过引入外部股东来稀释他们的股份。不出所料，后两位最终占了上风。斯科尔斯对希利布兰德非常愤怒，认为他是个控制狂，根本不考虑合伙人的感受。

The plan was controversial within Long-Term, too. Jim McEntee, J.M.’s friend, thought simple conservatism weighed in favor of not returning capital. Scholes and Merton, an inseparable pair, were strongly opposed to giving it back as well. They felt the firm was souring its franchise as a money manager. What’s more, since the academics owned a bigger proportional share of LTCM, the management company, than they did of the portfolio, they had a personal interest in seeing the total of funds under management grow. On the other hand, Hilibrand and Haghani, who owned so much of the fund, didn’t want to dilute their stakes by including outside owners. As usual, the latter two carried the day. Scholes was furious at Hilibrand, a control freak who gave little apparent thought to his partners.

事后看来，外部投资者恳求他们继续留在基金里的情景颇具讽刺意味，而强制赎回他们的资金反而成了天赐良机。合伙人们将遭受最大的损失。然而，在当时的背景下，合伙人对财富的痴迷追求却透着一股浓重的贪婪。如今，他们已拥有了在全球范围内运营的规模，却对为他人管理资金毫无兴趣，并将他人基本排除在外。他们甚至还做出了一个不同寻常的自私举动：首次将部分员工投资的奖金也纳入了管理费的范畴！

In retrospect, the outside investors’ pleas to stay in the fund would seem ironic, and the forced redemption of their money would come to seem a godsend. It was the partners who would suffer the most. But without the benefit of hindsight, the partners’ obsessive pursuit of wealth carried more than a whiff of greed. Now that they had the scale to operate worldwide, they had no interest in managing money for others and largely froze them out. They added an unusually self-serving touch, tacking on fees, for the first time, to the bonus money invested by some of their own employees!

合伙人辩称，强制赎回是对前景黯淡的明智应对。迈伦·斯科尔斯指出，讽刺的是，就在新投资者蜂拥而至之际，长期基金却在返还资金。 23这意味着，面对利差收窄，长期基金正在谨慎地缩减规模。然而，该基金的规模丝毫没有缩水。返还资金只会减少支撑其资产的权益，而这些资产实际上根本没有缩水。事实上，在投资机会日益减少、投资组合臃肿，持有7600个仓位的情况下，该基金却像伊卡洛斯追逐太阳一样，执迷不悟地继续增加杠杆，实属不明智之举。 24

The partners justified the forced redemption as a sensible response to diminished prospects. Myron Scholes said it was ironic that Long-Term was giving money back at the same time that newcomers were piling into the field.23 The implication was that Long-Term was prudently scaling back in the face of shrinking spreads. Yet the fund was not going to shrink by one iota. Returning capital only reduced the equity supporting its assets, which weren’t, in fact, shrinking at all. Indeed, at a time when opportunities were drying up and the portfolio was bloated with 7,600 positions, the fund was defiantly and ill-advisedly leveraging itself further, like an Icarus chasing the sun.24

此外，通过强迫外部投资者出售股份，合伙人再次提高了他们在基金中的个人杠杆率。个人债务，加上管理公司的杠杆和基金本身的债务，形成了三层债务，层层叠加，岌岌可危。

Moreover, by forcing outsiders to sell, the partners were, once again, increasing their personal leverage in the fund. The personal debt, on top of the leverage in the management company and the debt in the fund itself, made for three levels of debt precariously pyramided one atop the other.

在梅里韦瑟通知投资者必须撤回投资六天后，该公司的母公司所罗门兄弟也投下了一颗重磅炸弹。在莫泽丑闻、梅里韦瑟离职以及罗森菲尔德、哈加尼、霍金斯和希利布兰德等人的离职之后，所罗门兄弟一直未能完全恢复元气。该公司曾试图重建其投资银行业务，但该业务一直未能盈利。如今，其套利部门正面临着与长期投资部门同样的压力。今年早些时候，其高管们曾一致认为，所罗门兄弟需要大量资金注入，否则将面临沦为二流公司的风险。

Six days after Meriwether informed investors that they would have to take money back, the firm’s cradle, Salomon Brothers, dropped a bombshell of its own. Salomon had never fully regained its footing after the Mozer scandal, the exit of Meriwether, and the defections of Rosenfeld, Haghani, Hawkins, and Hilibrand. It had tried to build its investment bank, but the bank hadn’t been profitable. Now its arbitrage unit was facing the same pressures as Long-Term was. Earlier in the year, its executives had agreed that Salomon would need a significant infusion of capital or risk becoming a second-class firm.

沃伦·巴菲特通过伯克希尔·哈撒韦公司是所罗门兄弟公司的最大股东，但他一贯反对向失败的企业追加投资，他认为这无异于把好钱扔进无底洞。所罗门兄弟公司的首席执行官德里克·莫恩明确表示，唯一的选择就是出售公司。“沃伦非常想卖掉公司，”一位公司董事说道。

Warren Buffett, who, through Berkshire Hathaway, was Salomon’s biggest shareholder, was constitutionally opposed to investing more money in failing enterprises, which time and again he had equated with throwing good money after bad. Deryck Maughan, the chief executive of Salomon, made it clear that the only other option was to sell the company. “Warren wanted to sell so badly,” a director of the company said.

但该找谁呢？莫恩试探性地联系了蔡斯银行，但遭到了拒绝。之后，他与旅行者保险公司（Travelers）董事长桑福德·威尔（Sanford I. Weill）共进午餐。旅行者保险公司是史密斯·巴尼（Smith Barney）的母公司。威尔是美国商界“东山再起”的典范之一。他出身于布鲁克林一家服装制造商的家庭，最初创办了一家只有四名员工的小型经纪公司，并通过并购，最终打造了巨头希尔森·雷曼兄弟公司（Shearson Lehman）。后来，他将公司卖给了美国运通公司，但在权力斗争中落败，被迫辞职。到了20世纪80年代末90年代初，他又故技重施，控制了一家小型信贷公司，并以此为契机收购了史密斯·巴尼和旅行者保险公司。他不喜欢套利，认为套利风险太大，但他梦想着打造一家顶级的投资银行，在华尔街的等级制度中，它比那些乌合之众般的经纪公司高出一个档次。威尔提议，或许史密斯·巴尼和所罗门兄弟公司可以把这两家二流银行合并起来。

But to whom? Maughan sounded out Chase, but the bank rebuffed him. Then he had lunch with Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Travelers, the insurer and parent of broker Smith Barney. Weill was one of the great second acts in American business. The son of a Brooklyn dress manufacturer, Weill had founded a humble four-man brokerage firm and, via mergers, stitched together the giant Shearson Lehman. Eventually, he had sold to American Express, lost out in a power struggle and resigned. Then, in the late 1980s and early ’90s, he had done it again, getting control of a small credit company and using it to take over Smith Barney and also Travelers. He disliked arbitrage, which he considered too volatile, but he had dreams of building a premier investment bank, a rung above the ragtag brokerage business in Wall Street’s social hierarchy. Perhaps Smith Barney and Salomon could put their two second-class banks together, Weill proposed.

与莫恩共进午餐后，韦尔再次致电，坚持如果旅行者保险公司和所罗门兄弟公司合并，他必须掌管新公司。巴菲特并不在意谁来管理新公司，他只想卖掉旧公司——当然，价格要好。韦尔提出以90亿美元的股票收购，帮助这位奥马哈投资大师摆脱了他最棘手的投资之一。巴菲特一向圆滑，称赞韦尔是创造股东价值的“天才”。韦尔的下属们震惊于他竟然为一家二流公司支付了如此巨额的收购款，尤其是一家主要利润来源是套利交易的公司，而这正是董事长所厌恶的。一位得意门生窃笑道：“桑迪花了90亿美元，就为了从沃伦·巴菲特那里得到一张证明他是一位多么伟大的投资者的文件。他到处炫耀，就像个进了糖果店的孩子一样。”

After the lunch with Maughan, Weill called back to insist that he would have to be in charge if Travelers and Salomon merged. Buffett didn’t care who ran the new company, he just wanted to sell the old one—at a good price, naturally. Weill offered $9 billion in stock, bailing the Omaha sage out of one of his most troubled investments. Ever diplomatic, Buffett praised Weill as a “genius” at building shareholder value.25 Weill’s underlings were aghast that he had paid so much for a second-rate firm, particularly one in which the primary source of profits was arbitrage, which the chairman detested. One house jester snickered, “Sandy spent nine billion dollars to get a piece of paper from Warren Buffett saying what a great investor he was. He was running around showing it to people like a kid in a candy store.”

对比长期投资公司（Long-Term）及其母公司所罗门兄弟（Salomon）各自跨越的门槛，颇为有趣。梅里韦瑟（Meriwether）在所有关键方面都成功超越了他的老东家。资本方面，长期投资公司拥有70亿美元，而所罗门兄弟只有50亿美元。利润方面，这家对冲基金在上一个完整财年盈利21亿美元，而这家投资银行的利润仅为9亿美元。所罗门兄弟仍然拥有一个盈利的套利部门，但其打造一家综合性银行的尝试却以失败告终。长期投资公司虽然也曾考虑过多元化发展，但一直保持专注，迄今为止，这无疑是一个明智的决定。然而，两家公司都清楚地意识到，套利业务正步入一个更加艰难的时期。它们的应对措施截然相反。通过将所罗门兄弟与一家业务更加多元化的合作伙伴合并，巴菲特稀释了所罗门兄弟股东在套利业务和其他业务中的权益。现在，他们将持有规模更大的旅行者银行（Travelers）的部分股份。 Long-Term的合伙人做出了截然相反的决定：他们很大程度上收购了其他合伙人的股份，从而加倍押注套利机会。讽刺的是，巴菲特将一个长期亏损的项目变成了90亿美元的财富，而Long-Term的合伙人则将一个持续盈利的项目变成了一项巨大的——且尚未实现的——未来投资。

It is interesting to contrast Long-Term and its mother firm as each crossed a threshold. Meriwether had successfully overtaken his old employer in every way that counted. In capital, Long-Term boasted $7 billion to Salomon’s $5 billion. In profits, the hedge fund had earned $2.1 billion in its last full year, compared with $900 million for the investment bank. Salomon still had a profitable arbitrage unit, but its attempt to build a broad bank had failed. Long-Term, while toying with the idea of diversifying, had remained focused, a smart decision thus far. But as both firms well knew, arbitrage was entering a tougher period. Their responses were 180 degrees apart. By merging Salomon with a more diversified partner, Buffett had diluted the Salomon shareholders’ interests in arbitrage and in the rest of Salomon’s business. Now they would own pieces of a much larger Travelers. Long-Term’s partners had made the exact opposite decision: to a great extent, they had bought out their partners, thus redoubling their bets on arbitrage. The irony was that Buffett had converted a chronic loser into $9 billion while Long-Term’s partners had converted a consistent winner into a giant—and still unrealized—bet on the future.

10月，该基金迎来了一则振奋人心的消息：默顿和斯科尔斯荣获诺贝尔经济学奖。当时正在哈佛大学授课的默顿受到了学生们长达三分钟的热烈掌声。然而，他谦逊地告诫道：“认为只要能衡量风险就能消除风险，这是一种错误的观念。” 26斯科尔斯在接受家乡报纸《渥太华公民报》的专访时，被粗暴地提醒外界对衍生品抱有多么怀疑。《公民报》大胆地问道：“您认为自己对1987年的股市崩盘负有多大责任？”这位震惊的诺贝尔奖得主结结巴巴地回答道：“完全不。真的完全不。这就像问诺贝尔，他发明了炸药，是否应该为第一次世界大战负责一样。”在追问下，斯科尔斯承认，那些按照他的理论进行交易的人——也就是动态对冲或逢低卖出——加剧了崩盘，但他将责任归咎于缺乏“流动性”，这是人们常用的替罪羊。斯科尔斯一向擅长用通俗易懂的语言解释高深的金融知识，他用简洁明了的语言描述了长期投资策略：“我们所做的就是在全球范围内寻找我们认为根据我们的模型被低估或高估的投资。然后，我们对冲我们未知的风险，比如市场因素。” 27

In October, the fund got a positive jolt: Merton and Scholes won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science. Merton, who was teaching a class at Harvard, got a three-minute ovation from his students. He humbly warned, however, “It’s a wrong perception to believe that you can eliminate risk just because you can measure it.”26 Scholes, sitting for a celebrity profile with his hometown Ottawa Citizen, was brusquely reminded of how skeptical the outside world was of derivatives. The Citizen had the temerity to inquire, “How responsible do you feel for the 1987 stock market crash?” The stunned Nobel laureate sputtered, “Not at all. Not really at all. It’s the same as asking [Alfred] Nobel if he is responsible for the First World War because he invented dynamite.” Pressed, Scholes admitted that people trading on his theory—meaning dynamically hedging, or selling on the way down—had exacerbated the crash, though he blamed a lack of “liquidity,” the familiar scapegoat. Always good at reducing high finance to everyday English, Scholes described Long-Term in refreshingly plain terms: “What we do is look around the world for investments that we think are, because of our models, undervalued or overvalued. And then we hedge out the risk of something we don’t know, like a market factor.”27

默顿和斯科尔斯在学术界获得了同行们的热烈赞誉；“六位经济学家对任何议题都有七种不同意见”的规则并不适用于布莱克-斯科尔斯定理，该定理被誉为对理论和实践的卓越贡献。罗切斯特大学的芝加哥学派经济学家格雷格·贾雷尔称其为“我们见过的最优雅、最精确的模型之一”。 28但现实真的如此精确吗？这并不重要。《经济学人》杂志评论道：“默顿先生和斯科尔斯先生在1973年所做的，就是给风险定价。” 29《华尔街日报》的一位作者从该报最珍视的信念中找到了证据，他简洁地评论道：“瑞典皇家科学院已经明确表态：市场运作良好。” 30

From their colleagues in academe, Merton and Scholes got effusive praise; the rule that six economists have seven opinions on every subject did not apply to the Black-Scholes theorem, which was hailed as a towering contribution to theory as well as practice. Gregg Jarrell, a Chicago School economist at the University of Rochester, called it “one of the most elegant and precise models that any of us has ever seen.”28 But was reality so precise? No matter. The Economist intoned, “What Mr. Merton and Mr. Scholes did, back in 1973, was to put a price on risk.”29 A writer in The Wall Street Journal found proof in the award of the newspaper’s most cherished belief, succinctly opining, “The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has made a clear statement: Markets work.”30

在那个时代表达信仰实属罕见。整个亚洲的货币和股市都在崩盘。震中先是泰国，第二天是马来西亚，接着是印尼。10月1日，印尼盾暴跌6.5%，马来西亚林吉特下跌4.5%，菲律宾比索下跌2.2%。两天后，印尼盾又暴跌了8.5%。尽管亚洲人自己埋下了危机的种子，但没有人预料到市场的残酷，也没有人预料到危机蔓延的方式如此随机。就连拉丁美洲的市场也遭受重创。在互联网时代，市场似乎被一种无形的“等离子体”连接起来，将远隔重洋的交易所的命运紧紧相连。到了10月下旬，亚洲各地的公司纷纷违约，经济衰退的阴影笼罩着大地。投机者随后将矛头指向了港元。当时仍处于英国统治下的香港政府采取了反制措施，将隔夜利率提高到了惊人的300%。该岛股市一周内下跌了23%。

It was an odd time to express one’s faith. All across Asia, currency and stock markets were imploding. One day the epicenter was Thailand, the next Malaysia, then Indonesia. On a single day, October 1, Indonesia’s rupiah plunged 6.5 percent, the Malaysian ringgit fell 4.5 percent, the Philippine peso 2.2 percent. Two days later, the rupiah plunged 8.5 percent more. Though Asians had sown the seeds of their own crisis, no one was prepared for the market’s brutality or for the random way in which the contagion spread. Even Latin American markets were pounded. In the age of the Internet, markets seemed connected by an invisible plasma linking the fate of bourses oceans apart. By late October, companies across Asia were defaulting, raising the specter of recession. Speculators then turned their guns on the Hong Kong dollar. The government, still under the British Crown, retaliated, raising overnight interest rates to a staggering 300 percent. The island’s stock market gave up 23 percent in a week.

此时，美国投资者担心亚洲的困境会引发全球经济放缓，纷纷撤离。道琼斯指数在夏季曾触及8300点的高位，但在整个10月的大部分时间里都在下跌。万圣节前的那个星期五，道琼斯指数下跌超过100点，至7715点。随后，在10月27日星期一——又一个糟糕的星期一——亚洲的“流感”终于蔓延到了美国。当天的下跌始于香港，香港股市下跌了6%。随着美国股市的复苏，纽约证券交易所遭遇了严重的抛售。交易所两次关闭，试图阻止恐慌蔓延，但都无济于事。那些出售对冲市场下跌风险的期权卖方，正疯狂抛售股票，这与十年前的“黑色星期一”如出一辙。默顿和斯科尔斯的“魔瓶”再次失灵。一如既往，这种连锁抛售——默顿在其模型中设想的动态对冲——让糟糕的一天雪上加霜。道琼斯指数暴跌554点，跌幅达7%，创历史新低。从美国到亚洲，从欧洲到拉丁美洲，全球市场市值估计损失1.2万亿美元，相当于其总市值的6%。 32仅仅两天后，尼克·布雷迪在布鲁金斯学会的演讲中，将衍生品市场隐含的杠杆效应归咎于加剧了损失：

By now, U.S. investors, fearing that Asia’s agony would trigger a global slowdown, were in full retreat. The Dow, which had reached a high of 8,300 during the summer, had fallen through most of October. On the Friday before Halloween, it fell more than 100 points, to 7,715. Then on Monday, October 27—yet another miserable Monday—Asia’s flu finally landed at America’s door. The day’s losses began in Hong Kong, where the market fell 6 percent. As America awoke, the New York Stock Exchange was hit with heavy selling. It shut down twice, trying to forestall panic, but to no avail. Option writers, who had sold insurance against a market drop, were desperately selling stocks, similar to Black Monday a decade earlier.31 Merton and Scholes’s genie had escaped from the bottle again. As always, this chain-reaction selling—the dynamic hedging that Merton had envisioned in his model—made a bad day worse. The Dow fell a record 554 points, a drop of 7 percent. Around the world, from the United States to Asia to Europe to Latin America, markets lost an estimated $1.2 trillion, or 6 percent of their total value.32 In a speech to the Brookings Institution just two days later, Nick Brady blamed the leverage implicit in derivative markets for worsening the damage:

我听过各种关于衍生品和动态对冲如何降低交易成本、增加市场深度的论点。但可以肯定的是，如果运用过度，它们带来的收益将远超其成本……上周的抛售潮中，过度杠杆所起的作用值得我们深思。33

I have heard all the arguments about how derivatives and dynamic hedging decreases transaction costs and increases the depth of markets. But certainly carried to extremes they are not worth what they cost. . . . Excess leverage’s part in last week’s sell-off is well worth a lot of thought.33

长期资本再次侥幸过关。该基金在10月和11月实现了盈亏平衡，这实属不易。事实上，对于长期资本而言，亚洲市场蕴藏着机遇。随着市场波动加剧（正如交易员所说，市场“波动性”更大），长期资本开始大量押注衍生品交易，押注股票交易将会趋于稳定——或者说股票波动性将会下降。这风险极高。所罗门兄弟公司在10月之前就曾进行过类似的押注，结果损失了1.1亿美元。但对长期资本而言，做空波动性是最自然的选择。从某种意义上说，其每一笔价差交易都是在押注波动性降低。当市场剧烈波动时，安全溢价更高；而当市场趋于稳定时，价差往往会收窄。“我们的很多交易都是‘波动性’交易，”罗森菲尔德指出。34无论以何种形式，该基金始终在押注市场趋于平静或趋于稳定。

Long-Term Capital dodged the bullet again. The fund broke even in October and November, quite an accomplishment. Indeed, for Long-Term, Asia was an opportunity. With markets whipped up (more “volatile,” as traders would say), Long-Term began to place hefty derivative bets that stock trading would settle down—or that the volatility of stocks would fall. This was risky stuff. Salomon had made this bet before October and had lost $110 million. But shorting volatility was the most natural of bets for Long-Term. In a sense, every one of its spread trades was a bet on lessened volatility. When markets are jumpy, the premium for safety is greater; when markets settle down, spreads tend to contract. “A lot of our trades were ‘vol’ trades,” Rosenfeld noted.34 In one form or another, the fund was always betting on calmer or more convergent markets.

瑞银集团（UBS）作为长期投资公司（Long-Term）的新晋大股东，也曾押注股票市场波动，而这笔交易以及其他一些复杂的交易最终给银行带来了灾难性的后果。有传言称，由戈德斯坦（Goldstein）全权负责的衍生品部门亏损严重，而戈德斯坦本人在1996年却获得了1150万美元的奖金。 35 1997年，瑞银集团的亏损总额高达6.44亿美元。在其他糟糕的交易中，瑞银集团在日本可转换债券上损失惨重，而长期投资公司对这类债券的了解更为透彻。瑞银集团首席执行官卡比亚拉维塔（Cabiallavetta）长期以来一直庇护戈德斯坦。如今，他终于意识到自己这位宠信的交易员正在毁掉这家银行。11月，卡比亚拉维塔解雇了戈德斯坦。

UBS, Long-Term’s new big investor, also had gambled on equity volatility, and that and other exotic trades were turning into a disaster for the bank. Rumors were circulating of massive losses in the derivatives unit, run (with total autonomy) by Goldstein, who had pocketed an $11.5 million bonus for 1996.35 When toted up, UBS’s losses in 1997 would reach $644 million. Among other bad trades, UBS lost heavily on Japanese convertibles, which Long-Term had understood better. Cabiallavetta, the bank’s chief executive, had long protected Goldstein. Now he finally realized that his pet trader was destroying the bank. In November, Cabiallavetta fired Goldstein.

随后，在12月，卡比亚拉维塔承认他的银行领导层失势，并低调地与宿敌瑞士银行达成合并协议。尽管卡比亚拉维塔仍将担任董事长，银行也保留了瑞银的名称，但瑞士银行显然是此次合并的赢家。巴塞尔方面填补了大部分重要职位，并将其更为保守的企业文化强加于苏黎世那些行事鲁莽的银行家们。具有讽刺意味的是，通过与这家作风张扬的竞争对手合并，瑞士银行反而成为了其此前一直拒绝的长期认股权证的签署方。

Then, in December, Cabiallavetta admitted that his bank was bereft of leadership and humbly struck a merger with the archrival Swiss Bank. Although Cabiallavetta would stay as chairman and the bank would keep the UBS name, Swiss Bank was clearly the winner. Basel filled most of the important jobs and imposed its more conservative culture on the gunslingers in Zurich. Ironically, by merging with its flamboyant rival, Swiss Bank had become a party to the Long-Term warrant that it previously had spurned.

在斯德哥尔摩，默顿和斯科尔斯下榻于格兰德酒店，这是一家豪华酒店，拥有弧形楼梯，俯瞰着老城区。在诺贝尔奖晚宴上，1200位宾客盛装出席，获奖者们与几位亲朋好友、国王和王后、几位王子以及王后的母亲同席而坐。来自瑞典各地的服务员们用银盘盛放着熏鱼，款款呈上。获奖者们兴致高昂。默顿仿佛为了确认自己身处此地，不停地询问宾客们：“你们玩得开心吗？”他简短地举杯祝酒，表达了感激之情，同时也为费舍尔·布莱克未能活着分享这份荣誉而感到惋惜。

In Stockholm, Merton and Scholes put up at the Grand, a sumptuous hotel with a curving staircase, overlooking the old city. At the Nobel banquet, a black-tie affair for 1,200, the laureates sat with a few friends and family members, the king and queen, various princes, and the queen’s mother. Waiters and waitresses who had auditioned from all over Sweden served smoked fish on silver platters. The laureates were in a bubbly mood. Merton, as if to reassure himself that he was really there, kept inquiring of his guests, “Are you having a good time?” He gave a brief toast, expressing gratitude and also regret that Fischer Black hadn’t lived to share the award.

默顿在学院的讲座重点阐述了他的期权理论所衍生的应用，涵盖了从可调利率抵押贷款到学生贷款担保再到灵活的医疗保健计划等诸多领域。“人们很快发现‘类似期权’的结构无处不在，”默顿断言，尽管因果关系似乎不太可能如此直接。默顿指出，他自己的主要贡献——这距离道琼斯指数单日暴跌554点已过去两个月——在于证明了“布莱克-斯科尔斯提出的动态交易……在持续交易的极限情况下能够提供完美的对冲”。 36

Merton’s lecture to the academy focused on the applications spawned by his option theory, ranging from adjustable-rate mortgages to student loan guarantees to flexible health care plans. “ ‘Option-like’ structures were soon seen to be lurking everywhere,” Merton asserted, though it seems unlikely that cause and effect were so direct. His own principal contribution, Merton noted—this being two months after the Dow’s 554-point one-day spill—had been to show that “dynamic trading prescribed by Black and Scholes . . . would provide a perfect hedge in the limit of continuous trading.”36

尽管节日气氛浓厚，两位诺贝尔奖得主却都对长期资本的未来深感忧虑。斯科尔斯自信地告诉他的老顾问尤金·法玛，长期资本正在稳妥地进行着上千笔小额投资，但他最终决定不将自己那百万美元诺贝尔奖金的一半投资到该基金中。 37讽刺的是，这些象牙塔里的学者比经验丰富的交易员们更能敏锐地意识到风险。斯科尔斯和默顿都过着优渥的生活。斯科尔斯开着一辆白色宝马；而身为汽车爱好者的默顿则拥有一辆深色捷豹。斯科尔斯在格林威治租了一栋可以俯瞰水景的宽敞住宅。默顿则把头发染成了红色，离开了妻子，搬进了波士顿一套时髦的公寓。但他们的财富相对较少，两人都不像他们的亿万富翁合伙人那样觉得自己刀枪不入。作为局外人而非交易员，他们拥有希利布兰德所不具备的视角。获奖者们看出，该基金正在偏离其专业领域，并在最糟糕的时刻增加风险。此外，默顿对基金的薪酬结构极为不满，因为该结构严重偏向希利布兰德和哈加尼。作为一名期权专家，他深知高级合伙人更有动力追求极致收益——正如经济学家所说的“道德风险”。交易员们在所罗门兄弟公司时展现出的那种不计后果、追求利润最大化的贪婪本性依然存在，并且仍在破坏他们与合伙人之间的关系。谨慎的模型分析师克拉斯克也忧心忡忡；他在1997年底撤出了该基金。曾在所罗门兄弟公司工作过的兰迪·希勒曾不祥地告诉一位朋友，他认为长期基金迟早会出问题。

Despite the festive mood, both laureates were deeply concerned about Long-Term’s future. Though Scholes confidently told Eugene Fama, his old adviser, that Long-Term Capital was safely making a thousand small bets, Scholes decided not to invest his half of the million-dollar Nobel bounty in the fund.37 Ironically, the ivory-tower academics had a keener sense of the risks than the seasoned traders did. Scholes and Merton were both leading the good life. Scholes drove a white BMW; Merton, the car buff, sported a dark Jaguar. Scholes had rented a spacious home overlooking the water in Greenwich. Merton had dyed his hair red, left his wife, and moved into a snazzy pad in Boston. But their fortunes were relatively small, and neither felt as invulnerable as their multimillionaire partners did. As outsiders, not traders, they had a perspective not shared by Hilibrand. The laureates could see that the fund was moving away from its sphere of expertise and adding risk at the worst possible moment. Moreover, Merton was highly agitated about the fund’s compensation structure, which was top-weighted toward Hilibrand and Haghani. As an options expert, he knew that the senior partners had an added incentive to shoot for the moon—a “moral hazard,” as economists say. The hunger the traders had shown at Salomon to make as much as possible, no matter what the scale, was still alive and still disfiguring their relations with their partners. Krasker, the cautious modeler, was worried, too; he took money out of the fund at the end of 1997. Randy Hiller, who had been part of the group at Salomon, ominously told a friend that he thought Long-Term was an accident waiting to happen.

年底，当长期投资公司向投资者返还27亿美元时，其杠杆率从18:1飙升至28:1（一如既往，不包括衍生品）。因此，尽管公司前景比以往任何时候都更加黯淡，合伙人却将杠杆率提升到了公司鼎盛时期的水平。如果算上衍生品，杠杆率可能还会更高。

At year-end, when Long-Term returned $2.7 billion to investors, its leverage ratio skyrocketed from 18 to 1 to 28 to 1 (as always, not including derivatives). Thus, though the firm’s prospects looked bleaker than ever, the partners had raised their leverage back to the level prevailing during the business’s salad days. With derivatives, it may have been even higher.

1997年，长期基金实现了25%的收益率（扣除费用后为17%），这是该基金迄今为止业绩最差的一年，但考虑到当时市场行情下滑，这仍然是一项了不起的成就。最初的投资者每投入1美元，就收回了1.82美元，而且他们最初的1美元投资仍然有效。由于高额的费用和税收递延，合伙人的收益甚至更高——远超预期。他们的资本飙升了36%，达到了惊人的19亿美元，约占该基金总额47亿美元的40%。如今，合伙人即将积累起足以媲美家族的巨额财富。

Long-Term managed to earn 25 percent (17 percent after fees) in 1997—its worst year yet but still a remarkable achievement, given the deteriorating market. The original investors got $1.82 back for each $1 they had put into the fund and still had their original dollar in. Thanks to their exorbitant fees and tax deferrals, the partners did even better—much better. Their capital soared 36 percent to an exalted $1.9 billion, some 40 percent of the fund’s total of $4.7 billion. Now the partners were on the brink of amassing dynastic fortunes.

尽管扩张的时机有些特殊，但年底时，Long-Term还是搬进了豪华的新总部。新址俯瞰着一家洗车场，在格林威治算是比较普通的，但办公室的装潢却彰显了该公司作为华尔街银行巨头的自负。宽敞的交易大厅里摆放着三排符合人体工学的可调节办公桌，并预留了未来扩张的空间。此外，还有一个三千平方英尺的健身房，男女更衣室分开，并配备了一名全职教练。两张台球桌被象征性地摆放在后方的大房间里。JM在旁边拥有一间宽敞的办公室，会议室和图书馆则环绕在办公楼周围。就像被它超越的Salomon的迷你版一样，Long-Term拥有一个（规模相当大的）数据中心，以及一台位于大楼地下的备用发电机，据说足以照亮整个格林威治一天。但考虑到公司业绩并不理想，合伙人缩减了圣诞派对的规模。气氛明显低沉。

Though it was an odd time to be expanding, at the end of the year Long-Term moved into plush new headquarters. The site, overlooking a car wash, was pedestrian for Greenwich, but the office bespoke the firm’s inflated self-image as a fixture among Wall Street banks. It had a large trading floor sporting three double rows of ergonomically adjustable desks and room to accommodate a planned expansion. It also had a three-thousand-square-foot gym with separate locker rooms for men and women and a full-time trainer. Two pool tables were ceremonially housed in a big room in the back. J.M. had a large office off to the side, and conference rooms and a library were slung around the perimeter. Like a miniversion of Salomon, the firm it had surpassed, Long-Term had a (quite large) data center as well as a backup generator under the building that supposedly could light all Greenwich for a day. But the partners cut back on the office Christmas party in deference to their modest year. The mood was noticeably subdued.

穆林斯认为公司在1997年成功化解了危机。“我们预料到了亚洲的局势——或者说，我们制定了相应的策略，”他说。 38但教授们忽略了亚洲一个更普遍的真理：在动荡时期，市场联系更加紧密，看似无关的资产也会同步涨跌。他们几乎没有注意到圣诞节前夕一条看似遥远的新闻：评级机构标准普尔下调了俄罗斯的债务评级。

Mullins felt the firm had done a good job of heading off trouble in 1997. “We anticipated Asia—or had a strategy for it,” he said.38 But the professors had overlooked the larger truism of Asia: In times of trouble, markets become more closely linked, and seemingly unrelated assets rise and fall in tandem. They barely noticed a seemingly remote news item that moved over the wires just before Christmas: Standard & Poor’s, the rating agency, had downgraded Russia’s debt.

长期资本管理公司的衰落

THE FALL OF LONG-TERM CAPITAL MANAGEMENT

7

7

波动性银行

BANK OF VOLATILITY

市场保持非理性状态的时间可能比你保持偿付能力的时间更长。

Markets can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent.

——约翰· M·艾纳德·K·艾恩斯





—JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES





1998年初，长期基金开始大量做空股票波动率。这种简单的交易对罗森菲尔德和戴维·莫德斯特来说是驾轻就熟的，但对1000个美国人中的999个来说却难以理解。然而，“股票波动率”交易比任何其他交易都更能代表长期基金的标志性交易，也正是它将该基金无可避免地推向了灾难之路。股票波动率直接源自布莱克-斯科尔斯模型。该模型基于股票波动率随时间推移保持稳定的假设。例如，股市通常每年波动约15%至20%。市场偶尔可能会出现更大的波动，但它总会回归正常——至少格林威治的数学家们是这么认为的。这种理论遵循着看不见的大数定律，该定律保证了棕色奶牛和斑点奶牛、平静的交易日和市场崩盘都遵循正态分布。对于长期投资公司的教授们来说，他们对市场深信不疑，这早已是铁律。这源于他们默顿式的市场观，即市场是一台高效的机器，它吐出新的价格，其逻辑如同热分子在云层中扩散一样随机。当模型告诉他们市场对股票波动率定价错误时，他们甚至愿意为此押上公司的命。

EARLY IN 1998, Long-Term began to short large amounts of equity volatility. This simple trade, second nature to Rosenfeld and David Modest, would be indecipherable to 999 out of 1,000 Americans. But more than any other, “equity vol” was Long-Term’s signature trade, and it set the fund ineluctably on the road to disaster. Equity vol comes straight from the Black-Scholes model. It is based on the assumption that the volatility of stocks is, over time, consistent. The stock market, for instance, typically varies by about 15 percent to 20 percent a year. Now and then, the market might be more volatile, but it will always revert to form—or so the mathematicians in Greenwich believed. It was guided by the unseen law of large numbers, which assured the world of a normal distribution of brown cows and spotted cows and quiet trading days and market crashes. For Long-Term’s professors, with their supreme faith in markets, this was written in stone. It flowed from their Mertonian view of markets as efficient machines that spit out new prices with all the random logic of heat molecules dispersing through a cloud. And when the models told them that the markets were mispricing equity vol, they were willing to bet the firm on it.

并没有一种股票或证券被称为“权益波动率”，也没有直接押注它的方法。但有一种间接的方法。记住，根据布莱克-斯科尔斯公式，期权定价的关键因素是标的资产的预期波动率。标的资产价格波动越大，期权价格就越高。因此，如果你知道期权的价格，就可以推断出市场预期的波动率水平。

There is no stock or security known as “equity vol,” no direct way of making a wager on it. But there is an indirect way. Remember that, according to the Black-Scholes formula, the key element in pricing an option is the expected volatility of the underlying asset. As the asset gets jumpier, the price of the option rises. Therefore, if you knew the price of an option, you could infer the level of volatility the market was expecting.

举个例子或许有所帮助。虽然无法直接预测佛罗里达州的天气，但在某些季节，橙汁期货的价格会根据霜冻的可能性而波动。事实上，经验丰富的交易员如果发现橙汁价格异常高，就可以推断市场预期冬季寒冷，从而导致橙子短缺。如果这位交易员认为市场的天气预报有误，他就可以通过做空橙汁来从中获利。

An analogy may be helpful. There is no direct way to bet on the weather in Florida—but in certain seasons, the price of orange juice futures fluctuates according to the likelihood of a frost. Indeed, an experienced trader could infer, if the price of juice was unusually high, that the market was expecting a chilly winter and thus a scarcity of oranges. And if the trader believed that the market’s weather forecast was wrong, he could try to profit on his opinion by shorting orange juice.

同样地，“长期”公司推断期权市场预期股市波动率约为20%。该公司认为这一推断是错误的，因为实际波动率只有15%左右。因此，该公司认为期权价格迟早会下跌。于是，“长期”公司开始做空期权——具体来说，是做空标准普尔500指数以及欧洲主要交易所相应指数的期权。用他们自己的话说，这些教授是在“卖出波动率”。

In a similar manner, Long-Term deduced that the options market was anticipating volatility in the stock market of roughly 20 percent. Long-Term viewed this as incorrect, because actual volatility was only about 15 percent. Thus, it figured that option prices would sooner or later fall. So Long-Term began to short options—specifically, options on the Standard & Poor’s 500 stock index and on the equivalent indices on the major exchanges in Europe. In their own argot, the professors were “selling volatility.”

期权交易的另一方或许并未意识到，他们实际上是在购买波动性。让我们仔细想想。通常情况下，期权的买方是股票投资者，他们希望为市场下跌购买保险。他们愿意支付少量溢价来承担崩盘的风险。而另一方面，长期投资者收取溢价，但同时也承诺在市场暴跌时支付赔款。实际上，他们出售的是双向保险（期权）——既可以防范市场暴跌，也可以防范市场暴涨。

The people on the other side of the option trade may not have realized it, but they, in turn, were buying volatility. Let’s think about them for a moment. Typically, the buyers of options were equity investors who wanted insurance against a market decline. They were willing to pay a small premium against the risk of a crash. Long-Term, on the other side, collected the premium but was committed to paying out if the market swooned. In fact, it sold insurance (options) both ways—against a sharp downturn and against a sharp rise.

这些买家不像长期投资者那样经验丰富，他们并不清楚期权价格是否合理，但就像拥有美丽海滨别墅却担心飓风季来袭的业主一样，他们想要以任何价格购买保险。当时亚洲局势依然动荡，股市也高得离谱，投资者们的焦虑不安是可以理解的。几乎每份报纸上都能看到专家预测即将爆发一场史无前例的崩盘。因此，人们愿意支付更高的价格来寻求保护，推高期权价格也就不足为奇了。欧洲的机构投资者正利用人们的恐慌情绪，推销带有下行保护的股票产品——也就是说，这些股票“不可能”下跌！为了防范股市下跌的风险，这些机构投资者也在购买保险，而长期投资者认为，这人为地推高了期权价格。

The buyers, not being as sophisticated as Long-Term, didn’t know whether option prices were right or wrong, but, like a man with a beautiful beachfront home who fears a nasty hurricane season, they wanted insurance at whatever the going rate. With Asia still in turmoil and with stocks at nosebleed levels, investors were understandably jittery. One could scarcely pick up the paper but that some pundit was predicting the crash to end all crashes. So it was hardly surprising that people were paying more for protection, driving up the price of options. Institutions in Europe were capitalizing on people’s fears by marketing equity products with downside protection—that is, equities that “couldn’t” go down! To protect themselves in case stocks did fall, these institutions, too, were buying insurance, which in Long-Term’s view was artificially inflating option prices.

如果长期基金的判断正确——期权价格确实过高——那么实际上它是在为保险收取溢价，而且在其五年的期权合约期限内，它应该能够获利。许多其他对冲基金也在进行同样的交易。这些金融公司实际上是在为普通投资者提供市场保险。这未必是愚蠢之举。这些基金的想法是：“既然人们愿意为保险支付高昂的价格，我们为什么不卖给他们呢？”

If Long-Term was right—if the price of options was too high—then in effect it was charging a premium price for insurance, and over the life of its option contracts, which was five years, it should expect to come out ahead. Many other hedge funds were doing the same trade. These financial firms were providing market insurance to ordinary investors. This was not necessarily stupid. The funds were saying, “If people are willing to pay foolish prices for insurance, why shouldn’t we sell it to them?”

但即便如此，这些交易仍然风险极大。首先，预测市场波动性向来是极其困难的——除非你相信过去能够可靠地预测未来。谁能预测亚洲危机何时爆发？谁又能预测一旦爆发，市场会如何剧烈波动？谁又能断言市场“应该”波动到什么程度？这就像预测佛罗里达是否会有霜冻一样。

But the trades were quite risky nonetheless. For one, forecasting the market’s volatility is notoriously dicey—unless you believe that the past is a reliable predictor of the future. Who could predict when a crisis in Asia might develop—or how jittery markets would become if one did? Who could say how volatile the market “should” be? It was like forecasting a frost in Florida.

更重要的是，即使最终证明其对波动率的判断是正确的，长期投资公司（Long-Term）仍然可能在股票波动率交易中亏损。由于长期期权不在交易所交易，长期投资公司不得不定制私人期权合约，并将其出售给摩根大通、所罗门兄弟、摩根士丹利和信孚银行等大型银行。这类晦涩合约的市场规模很小，只有少数几家机构以“预约交易”的方式进行交易。而且，市场本身就存在不平衡。像摩根大通这样的银行渴望从长期投资公司“购买”波动率，因为这些银行反过来又向散户投资者出售保险。简而言之，买方市场存在着天然的个人和机构群体。这就是为什么波动率的价格通常比数学家认为的合理价格略高。但在卖方市场，参与者却寥寥无几。如果没有人来卖，或者股票投资者突然更加迫切地需要保险，波动率的价格可能会更高。

What’s more, Long-Term could still lose money on the equity vol trade, even if it later turned out that its judgment about volatility had been correct. Since long-dated options don’t trade on exchanges, Long-Term had to tailor private options contracts, which it sold to big banks such as J. P. Morgan, Salomon Brothers, Morgan Stanley, and Bankers Trust. The market for such arcane contracts was thin, with only a handful of players who traded on a “by appointment” basis. And the market was inherently imbalanced. Banks such as Morgan were eager to “buy” volatility from Long-Term, because the banks, in turn, were selling insurance to retail investors. In short, there was a natural pool of people and institutions on the buying side. That’s why the price of volatility was often a bit higher than the mathematicians deemed was logical. But on the selling side, there were very few players. If no one came to sell or if equity investors suddenly became more desperate for insurance, the price of volatility could go even higher.

而长期基金每天都必须结算——根据期权价格的波动支付或收取款项。从长远来看，它或许能准确预测股票波动率，但这前提是它能承受短期的损失。五年下来，如此大额的交易带来的损失可能相当巨大。在某些日子里，可能根本没人愿意出售，在这种情况下，摩根大通可以将资产价格抬高到它认为合理的任何价格。因此，长期基金押注的不仅仅是最终的实际波动率，而是每日的推断波动率，而推断波动率取决于其他投资者愿意为期权支付的价格。实际上，它是在押注其他投资者（他们可能不那么理性）不会进一步推高价格。这与合伙人的信条截然相反，完全是投机。通过将自己置于短期波动的摆布之下，合伙人放弃了他们精确数学模型所蕴含的任何优势。

And Long-Term would have to settle up—paying or receiving monies according to how option prices moved—every day. It might be right on equity vol in the long run, but only if it could stand the pain in the short run. And over five years, the pain suffered on such a large trade could be considerable. On a given day, it was possible that no one would want to sell, in which case Morgan could mark up the asset to whatever higher price it decided was reasonable. Therefore, Long-Term wasn’t betting only on the extent of ultimate realized volatility, it was betting on day-by-day inferred volatility, as determined by what other investors would pay for options. In effect, it was betting that these other, and presumably less rational, investors wouldn’t bid up prices further. This was—so unlike the partners’ credo—rank speculation. By putting themselves at the mercy of short-term fluctuations, the partners had abandoned whatever advantage lay in their precise mathematical models.

长期基金以隐含市场年波动率为19%的价格做空期权（交易员称之为“以19%的波动率卖出”）。随着期权价格上涨，长期基金持续卖出。其他公司只是小幅卖出，而长期基金却不然，它一直在卖出。罗森菲尔德、希利布兰德和莫德斯特在格林威治进行交易；哈加尼和胡夫施密德则在伦敦进行交易。最终，他们在美国股市波动率每变化一个百分点就投入高达4000万美元，在欧洲也投入了等额资金——这或许占整个市场的四分之一。摩根士丹利给这只基金起了个绰号：波动率中央银行。

Long-Term shorted options at prices that implied a market volatility of 19 percent a year (traders refer to this as “selling volatility at 19 percent”). As option prices rose, Long-Term continued to sell. Other firms sold in tiny amounts. Not Long-Term. It just kept selling. Rosenfeld, Hilibrand, and Modest worked the trade in Greenwich; Haghani and Hufschmid did it in London. Eventually, they had a staggering $40 million riding on each percentage point change in equity volatility in the United States and an equivalent amount in Europe—perhaps a fourth of the overall market. Morgan Stanley coined a nickname for the fund: the Central Bank of Volatility.

事实上，股票波动率交易是长期投资公司的典型交易策略。在其许多价差交易中，该公司都在间接地表达对波动率的看法。合伙人认为，随着时间的推移，投资者会变得更加理性、更加稳定、更加高效——更像他们自己——因此信用利差会收窄。“我们一直都持有这种信念，”罗森菲尔德指出。1股票波动率交易正是这一理念的明确体现；它凸显了波动率在长期投资公司默顿式投资理念中的核心地位。“麻省理工学院的那些人总是想做空波动率，”安德鲁·霍尔指出，他是一位石油交易员，曾在20世纪80年代在所罗门兄弟公司工作。“学者们脑子里根深蒂固地印着布莱克-斯科尔斯模型，这些模型假设波动率服从正态分布。他们认为这些模型就是圣杯。”

Indeed, equity vol was Long-Term’s archetypal trade. In many of its spread trades, the firm was indirectly expressing an opinion on volatility. The partners believed that, over time, investors would become more rational, more steady, more efficient—more like they were—and thus that credit spreads would narrow. “We’ve always had that belief,” Rosenfeld noted.1 The equity vol trade was an explicit articulation of this doctrine; it underscored the central role that volatility played in Long-Term’s Mertonian universe. “The MIT types always want to short volatility,” noted Andrew Hall, an oil trader who had worked at Salomon in the 1980s. “Academics have embedded in their minds the Black-Scholes models that assume the normal distributions. They think these models are the Holy Grail.”

1998年初几个月，市场走势平稳。国际货币基金组织制定了对韩国的救助方案，巩固了亚洲市场的稳定趋势。在欧元即将推出的欧洲，投资者们沉浸在乐观情绪中。在美国，道琼斯指数创下历史新高。随着投资者信心的恢复，债券利差收窄。1998年初，A级债券（例如福特汽车等实力雄厚的公司发行的债券）的收益率比美国国债高出75个基点；到2月份，利差已收窄至70个基点。

In the first months of 1998, markets were smooth. The International Monetary Fund worked out a bailout of South Korea, capping a stabilizing trend in Asia. In Europe, where the launch of the euro was less than a year away, investors were bathing in a spirit of optimism. In the United States, the Dow broke into record territory. As investors regained confidence, bond spreads narrowed. At the start of 1998, A-rated bonds (those issued by strong corporations, such as Ford Motor) yielded 75 basis points more than Treasurys; by February, the spread had narrowed to 70 points.

尽管表面上看似无关，但这些乐观情绪反映出一种普遍的看法：去年秋季的危机已经过去，尽管某种程度的不安情绪依然存在。1997年10月，在亚洲金融危机爆发后，美林证券曾命令其债券交易员缩减持仓。他们确实撤出了仓位，但到了1998年初，他们又恢复了正常的交易模式。世界已经挺过了太多危机；美国和国际货币基金组织出手相救了墨西哥、泰国和韩国。“没有人相信亚洲危机会蔓延，”美林证券的风险经理丹·那不勒斯（Dan Napoli）指出，他指的是那些将公司资本投入其中的交易员。随着这种乐观情绪在各家银行的交易部门蔓延开来，信贷利差必然收窄。

Such balmy currents, though apparently unrelated, reflected a generalized feeling that the crisis of the previous fall had passed even though a certain edginess lingered. In October 1997, after the debacle in Asia, Merrill Lynch had ordered its bond traders to downsize their positions. They had in fact pulled back, but by the beginning of 1998 they were reverting to business as usual.
