The world had gotten past so many crises; it had seen the United States and the IMF rescue Mexico, Thailand, Korea. “No one believed that Asia would spread,” noted Dan Napoli, Merrill’s risk manager, referring to the traders who put the firm’s capital on the line. As such sanguine attitudes percolated up from the trading desk of bank after bank, credit spreads inevitably narrowed.

长期基金内部气氛也比较轻松。尽管基金的杠杆率有所提高，合伙人也背负了巨额个人贷款，但他们的风险敞口似乎仍在可控范围内。据估计，仅希利布兰德一人身价就高达5亿美元，梅里韦瑟的身价也接近数亿美元。而且，合伙人似乎已经对基金的投资组合进行了调整，以控制风险。根据他们的模型，他们单日交易的最大损失可能为4500万美元——对于一家资本规模是其百倍的公司来说，这当然是可以承受的。²根据同样的模型，该公司遭遇持续厄运——例如，一个月内损失40%的资本——的概率低得难以想象。 （迄今为止，即使在最糟糕的月份，他们也仅亏损了2.9%。）事实上，这些数据表明，只有发生所谓的“十西格玛事件”（即每十的二十四次方发生一次的统计异常事件），公司才有可能在一年内损失全部资本。³

The mood at Long-Term was relaxed, too. Though the fund’s leverage was up, and though the partners had taken out huge personal loans, their exposure seemed tolerable. According to one estimate, Hilibrand alone was worth half a billion dollars and Meriwether was in the low hundreds of millions. And the partners had seemingly tailored the fund’s portfolio to control the risk. According to their models, the maximum that they were likely to lose on any single trading day was $45 million—certainly tolerable for a firm with a hundred times as much in capital.2 According to these same models, the odds against the firm’s suffering a sustained run of bad luck—say, losing 40 percent of its capital in a single month—were unthinkably high. (So far, in their worst month, they had a lost a mere 2.9 percent.) Indeed, the figures implied that it would take a so-called ten-sigma event—that is, a statistical freak occurring one in every ten to the twenty-fourth power times—for the firm to lose all of its capital within one year.³

如果合伙人感到焦虑，那并非因为担心亏损，而是担心找不到足够多的盈利投资机会。随着寻找合适交易的压力越来越大，他们开始涉足更为冷门的领域，例如巴西和俄罗斯债券以及丹麦抵押贷款。负责巴西和其他新兴市场的马丁·西格尔在长期投资公司显得格格不入。作为一名老派交易员，他对模型一窍不通。西格尔曾在所罗门兄弟公司通过投资墨西哥电信公司为梅里韦瑟赚了不少钱，而梅里韦瑟出于忠诚，一如既往地给了他一份长期投资公司的工作。

If the partners were anxious, it was not about losing; it was that they wouldn’t find enough investments where they could win. As the pressure to find suitable trades mounted, they increasingly strayed into more exotic tundra, such as Brazilian and Russian bonds and Danish mortgages. Martin Siegel, who handled Brazil and other emerging markets, was a misfit at Long-Term. An old-time trader, he knew nothing about models. Siegel had made money for Meriwether at Salomon by investing in the Mexican telephone company, and J.M., typically, had given him a job at Long-Term out of loyalty.

长期基金也开始进行更多方向性押注，放弃了（部分投资组合）其标志性的谨慎对冲策略。斯科尔斯对这类交易深感不满，尤其是其在挪威克朗的大量持仓。他认为长期基金应该坚持其模型；它在挪威没有任何“信息优势”。大约一年前，哈加尼曾对长期基金投资希腊的建议勃然大怒。“你怎么能相信这个经济体？”他质问道。但当有人质疑他时，他便不再纠结于这些小问题。哈加尼觉得自己永远不会失败；他不断向合伙人施压，直到如愿以偿。

Long-Term also began to make more directional bets, abandoning (for a fraction of its portfolio) the cautious hedging strategy that had been its trademark. Scholes was deeply upset by such trades, particularly its big position in Norwegian kroner. He argued that Long-Term should stick to its models; it did not have any “informational advantage” in Norway.4 A year or so before, Haghani had exploded at the suggestion that Long-Term invest in Greece. “How can you trust this economy?” he had demanded. But when challenged himself, he cast such quibbles aside. Haghani felt he could never lose; he pushed and pushed his partners until he got his way.

该基金也进一步加深了对股票的投资。由于许多高科技公司为了管理员工股票期权计划而低价发行看跌期权（期权），长期基金大量买入了微软和戴尔等公司发行的此类看跌期权，并通过卖出标普500指数的看跌期权进行对冲。在这些交易中，莫德斯特是执行者，但哈格尼始终是幕后策划者。一位同事震惊地发现，莫德斯特甚至做空了大型公司的股票——据报道包括微软、戴尔和通用电气——这似乎是哈格尼一时兴起。莫德斯特向这位同事解释说：“维克托突然来到这里，他看好这笔交易，让我去做。”莫德斯特还多此一举地补充道：“维克托就是维克托——我能怎么办呢？”

The fund went deeper into equities, too. Knowing that many hightech companies issued puts (options) cheaply to manage their employee stock-option programs, Long-Term bought heaps of these puts, issued by companies such as Microsoft and Dell, and hedged them by selling puts on the S&P 500. Modest was the engineer in these trades, but Haghani, invariably, was the architect. An associate was stunned to find that Modest had even shorted big-company stocks—reportedly including Microsoft, Dell, and General Electric—seemingly on Haghani’s whim. Modest explained to the associate, “Victor blew into town, he liked this trade and told me to do it.” Modest added, unnecessarily, “Victor is Victor—what am I going to do?”

此时，长期投资公司（Long-Term）已无法抵挡住将资金投入某个领域的致命诱惑。该公司显然是在进行投机，通过期权押注美国股市下跌。⁵随后，一位名叫阿兰·苏尼尔（Alain Sunier）的年轻股票研究员，凭借其统计学头脑，提出购买一些股票。根据一个模型，这些股票很可能被纳入标普500指数（当一只股票被纳入指数时，许多投资组合都会被迫买入）。希利布兰德（Hilibrand）对这笔交易非常感兴趣。他无视苏尼尔的模型，抛售了苏尼尔推荐的公司，并添加了一些新的公司。而且，希利布兰德坚持要买入每家公司的大量股份。长期投资公司在这笔交易中的名义投资额飙升至惊人的20亿美元。一位同事问发生了什么事。苏尼尔耸耸肩，回答说：“他（希利布兰德）把我的所有股票都卖掉了。”

By now Long-Term was succumbing to the fatal temptation to put its money someplace. In a clear speculation, it bet on the U.S. stock market to decline, via options.5 Then, a young, statistically minded equity researcher named Alain Sunier proposed buying stocks that, according to a model, were likely to be added to the S&P index (when a stock is added to the index, many portfolios are compelled to buy it). Hilibrand got very interested in this trade. He ignored Sunier’s model, discarding Sunier’s companies and adding new ones. And Hilibrand insisted on buying hefty stakes in every one of them. Long-Term’s notional investment in the trade soared to an astronomical $2 billion. A colleague asked what had happened. Sunier threw up his arms and replied: “He [Hilibrand] turned off all my stocks.”

希利布兰德还做空了沃伦·巴菲特掌管的伯克希尔·哈撒韦控股公司，他认为伯克希尔的股价相对于其各个组成部分而言过高。但由于伯克希尔的许多资产都是私有的，希利布兰德无法收购这些部分，这使得他的套利策略显得欠妥。尽管希利布兰德通常冷静精于算计，但这次他却过于自作聪明——试图从这位亿万富翁身上牟利——并且危险地将基金的业务拓展到了其专业领域之外。这显然是不明智的。即使是精心策划的交易，合伙人也完全失去了对规模的把握。在一笔最终导致亏损的交易中，长期基金买入了喜达屋酒店及度假村发行的垃圾债券中高达15%的份额，价值4.8亿美元。喜达屋酒店及度假村是一家房地产运营商，而它本身就容易过度扩张。

Hilibrand also shorted Berkshire Hathaway, the holding company run by Warren Buffett, believing that Berkshire was overpriced relative to its individual parts. But since many of Berkshire’s assets were private, Hilibrand couldn’t buy the parts, making it a poorly conceived arbitrage. Though usually coldly calculating, Hilibrand was being a bit too clever—trying to profit at the billionaire’s expense—and dangerously moving the fund afield of its expertise. This was plainly unwise. Even on well-conceived trades, the partners had lost all sense of scale. In one trade that would lose them money, Long-Term bought a huge 15 percent share, worth $480 million, of a junk-bond issue from Starwood Hotels & Resorts, a real estate operator that itself had a tendency to overreach.

尽管他们的交易比以往任何时候都更需要严格审查，但合伙人每周的风险会议却变得越来越程式化。他们不再像研究意大利交易那样耐心地研究和分析交易。尽管他们的争论十分激烈，但结果似乎早已注定。斯科尔斯对公司持有的各种头寸规模提出抗议。毕竟，公司在一些大额交易中难以退出——这显然是一个危险信号。默顿、穆林斯和麦肯蒂也提出了抗议。但这些持不同意见的人并没有威胁要辞职，而这一举动或许会促使JM和罗森菲尔德与他们的两位顶级交易员对质。

Though their trades wanted for scrutiny more than ever, the partners’ weekly risk meetings became increasingly scripted. They no longer had the patience to research and analyze trades quite as they had done with Italy. Though their debates were heated, the results seemed preordained. Scholes protested about the size of the firm’s various positions. After all, the firm had had trouble exiting from some of its large trades—an obvious red flag.6 Merton, Mullins, and McEntee made protests, too. But the dissenters stopped short of threatening to quit, the one step that might have prompted J.M. and Rosenfeld to confront their two top traders.

希利布兰德和哈加尼根本没在听。年轻的同事们察觉到他有些冲动，这在哈加尼身上或许并不奇怪，但在希利布兰德身上却完全令人费解。求知欲旺盛的莫德斯特对不得不像一位同事戏称的那样，成为“拉里的执行奴隶”深感不满。莫德斯特是长期投资公司里少有的拥有文艺复兴时期兴趣爱好的人，他在波士顿长大，热爱艺术、文学和歌剧。他对金融的兴趣更多是出于学术而非商业目的；他一直不喜欢资深合伙人的独裁统治和对他时间的控制，直到1998年晋升为初级合伙人之前，他都一直在考虑离开。当他看到合伙人们背离了他们一贯的谨慎作风时，这家公司对他来说失去了意义。长期投资公司完全被两位资深交易员把持，变成了一家失衡的公司；它只是徒有合伙制的空壳。

And Hilibrand and Haghani weren’t really listening. Younger colleagues espied an impulsive streak, not so surprising in Haghani, perhaps, but totally baffling in the case of Hilibrand. The intellectually curious Modest was deeply resentful of having to be, as a colleague teased him, “Larry’s execution slave.” The rare Long-Term man with Renaissance interests, Modest, who was raised in Boston, loved the arts, literature, and opera. His interest in finance was more academic than entrepreneurial; he had never liked the senior partners’ autocratic reign and control over his time and had been thinking of bolting until 1998, when he had been made a junior partner. When he saw his partners departing from their trademark prudence, the firm lost all its meaning for him. Totally dominated by the two senior traders, Long-Term had become a lopsided firm; it was a partnership only in name.

华尔街对这些内部矛盾一无所知；事实上，各大银行继续对这只基金不闻不问。美林证券甚至乐于以极低的损失率，为这只基金在巴西——一个风险极高的市场——的投资提供融资。美林回购部门的员工开始感到焦虑，他们向负责对冲基金的信贷主管罗伯特·麦克唐纳抱怨长期基金在新兴市场的风险敞口。麦克唐纳只是笑了笑。“我们和这些人沆瀣一气，”他说道，“他们要是倒闭了，我们也跟着遭殃！”

Wall Street knew nothing of these internal tensions; indeed, the banks continued to give the fund a free ride. Merrill Lynch happily financed the fund in Brazil—a risky market—on the slimmest of haircuts. Becoming anxious, people on Merrill’s repo desk squawked to Robert McDonough, the Merrill credit officer responsible for hedge funds, about Long-Term’s exposure in emerging markets. McDonough just laughed. “We’re in bed with these guys,” he noted. “If they go down, we go down!”

几乎没有什么可能性比这更渺茫了。事实上，美林对格林威治的信心如此之强，以至于4月1日，123位满怀憧憬的美林高管（各自独立购买）将美林在长期投资公司的大部分股份纳入了他们的个人递延薪酬计划。接替塔利担任美林董事长的科曼斯基投入了80万美元；高管们总共投资了2200万美元。具有讽刺意味的是，作为长期投资公司的“助产士”，美林最终比任何人都更接近顶峰，而让其自身的高管们独自承受了公司衰落的后果。

Few possibilities could have seemed more remote. Indeed, so strong was Merrill’s confidence in Greenwich that on April 1, 123 starry-eyed Merrill executives purchased (in individual, separate stakes) most of Merrill’s investment in Long-Term for the executives’ personal deferred compensation plans. Komansky, who had succeeded Tully as Merrill’s chairman, put in $800,000; in total, the executives invested $22 million. Ironically, Merrill, Long-Term’s midwife, got out closer to the top than anyone else, leaving its own executives to take the downhill ride.

美林愿意为客户提供融资，是当时金融宽松氛围的体现，华尔街热衷于承销新兴市场投资，这种氛围尤为明显。俄罗斯当时普遍被吹捧为下一个资本主义的天堂。“人们说‘亚洲已经孤立，我们应该转向其他领域了’。涌入这些地区的资金数额巨大，”时任美林欧洲和英国债务市场主管的理查德·邓恩指出。在这样的时期，拒绝放贷需要非凡的勇气，因为这意味着将业务拱手让给竞争对手。“我们误判了我们需要保护的损失，”邓恩承认。“这并非我们长期投资部门的个别失误。整个市场都在向我们施压。要承受来自机构的警告，告诉你正在失去业务——这需要莫大的勇气才能站出来说‘我不干了’。华尔街在这件事上集体犯了错误。”

Merrill’s willingness to finance its client was part of a pervasive climate of financial laxity, palpable in Wall Street’s eagerness to underwrite emerging markets. Russia was commonly touted as the next capitalist nirvana. “People were saying ‘Asia was isolated, let’s move on.’ The amount of money pursuing these areas was tremendous,” noted Merrill’s Richard Dunn, then head of debt markets in Europe and the United Kingdom. At such times, it took uncommon courage to refuse to lend, for it would have meant squandering business to the competition. “We misread the haircuts that we needed to be protected,” Dunn admitted. “It wasn’t a mistake we made singly for Long-Term. The whole market was pressuring us. To suffer the organization telling you that you are losing business—it takes a tremendous amount [of courage] to stand up and say, ‘I’m not going to do it.’ The Street all got that collectively wrong.”

4月，桑迪·韦尔（Sandy Weill）仍在消化他当初对所罗门兄弟公司（Salomon）欠妥收购案的余波，却宣布了史上规模最大的金融并购案：旅行者保险公司（Travelers）与花旗集团（Citicorp）的合并。这笔交易象征着华尔街的盲目乐观情绪。30年期美国国债收益率跌破6%，让人想起梅里韦瑟（Meriwether）年轻时债券市场稳定而纯粹的景象。人们对美好未来的信念，加上普遍的借贷意愿，使得即使是信用最差的借款人也能获得低利率贷款。利差跌至多年来的最低水平。A级债券的利差降至60个基点（年初时为75个基点）。利差的收窄对长期资本（Long-Term Capital）的损益表起到了提振作用。该基金在第一季度业绩持平后，4月份实现了近3%的收益。4月底前后，利差跌至谷底，市场信心达到顶峰，长期资本的资产规模也达到了1340亿美元。短短四年多时间，该基金的投资额就翻了四倍，这还不包括合伙人的费用。扣除这部分费用后，最初投资的一美元价值已增至2.85美元——短短五十个月内，利润竟高达185%，令人震惊。

In April, Sandy Weill, still trying to digest his ill-considered acquisition of Salomon, announced the biggest financial merger in history: Travelers and Citicorp. The deal was emblematic of the Street’s Panglossian mood. Thirty-year Treasury yields had dipped below 6 percent, reminiscent of the stable and innocent bond markets of Meriwether’s youth. The belief in a brighter tomorrow, coupled with the general willingness to lend, pushed down rates for even the least creditworthy of borrowers. Spreads fell to their lowest levels in years. A-rated bonds fell to 60 points (down from 75 at the start of the year). The shrinking spreads worked like a tonic on Long-Term’s profit-and-loss statement. Having been flat in the first quarter, the fund earned almost 3 percent in April. The end of April, approximately, was the low point for spreads, the high point for confidence, and the high point for Long-Term Capital, which boasted $134 billion in assets. In just over four years, an investment in the fund had quadrupled, before accounting for the partners’ fees. After deducting this tithe, the value of a single dollar invested at the start had risen to $2.85—a phenomenal 185 percent profit in barely fifty months.

合伙人们并未止步于已有的成就，而是在迪克·莱希的带领下，在百慕大成立了一家名为Osprey Re的再保险子公司。Osprey Re的资本为2亿美元，体现了Long-Term作为金融风险保险公司的自我定位。如今，合伙人们正计划承保有形风险，例如暴风雨、地震、飓风等造成的损失。他们与意大利银行BNL合作的共同基金项目已被意大利方面搁置并取消。但合伙人们正在探索另一个新领域：私募股权投资。难道真的没有什么能动摇他们的决心吗？

Far from resting on their laurels, the partners, led by Dick Leahy, set up a Bermuda-based reinsurance subsidiary, christened Osprey Re. Osprey, which was capitalized with $200 million, reflected Long-Term’s self-image as an insurer of financial risks. Now the partners were planning to reinsure tangible risks, such as losses from severe storms, earthquakes, hurricanes, and the like. Their mutual fund venture with BNL, the Italian bank, had been tabled by the Italians and dropped. But the partners were exploring another new front: private equity ventures.7 Would nothing ever shake them?

市场一贯如此，最初的危机迹象零星分散，规模很小，而且看似毫无关联。雷曼兄弟公司股票衍生品部门主管约翰·苏科(John Succo)就是其中之一，他认为华尔街是在玩火，尤其是在衍生品中隐藏的杠杆问题上。4月底，苏科在由特立独行的通讯出版人詹姆斯·格兰特(James Grant)赞助的投资者会议上发表了讲话。在回答一个问题时，苏科断言，华尔街一些公司——或许是所有公司——的高层管理人员根本不了解他们26岁的交易员所承担的风险。他稍作补充，补充说他所在的管理层掌握的信息更全面。但他的“异端邪说”已经生效。由于暗示华尔街高层对风险毫不知情，这位“预言家”苏科被迫从雷曼兄弟公司辞职。

In the manner of markets, the first hints of trouble were scattered, small, and seemingly unrelated. John Succo, who ran the equity derivatives desk at Lehman Brothers, was among those who felt that the Street was playing with fire, specifically with the unseen leverage in derivatives. At the end of April, Succo was speaking at an investors’ conference sponsored by the maverick newsletter publisher James Grant. In response to a question, Succo declared that the senior managements at some—possibly all—Wall Street firms had no idea of the risks being run by their twenty-six-year-old traders. He hedged a bit, adding that his management was better informed. But the heresy was accomplished. For suggesting that Wall Street’s top brass was uninformed, the prophetic Succo was forced to resign from Lehman.

高盛合伙人劳埃德·布兰克费恩也对体系中的杠杆感到担忧。他曾向纽约联储交易主管彼得·费舍尔提到，人们正浪费时间试图弄清楚是否存在像墨西哥那样可能引发另一场金融危机的隐患。布兰克费恩认为，下一个重大问题将是信贷问题，而非某个特定市场的问题。他抱怨说，人们没有区分风险，并暗示信贷利差正在消失。目前，所有资产都被视为国债。

Lloyd Blankfein, a partner at Goldman Sachs, was worried by leverage in the system, too. He mentioned to Peter Fisher, who ran trading activities at the New York Fed, that people were wasting their time trying to figure out whether somewhere there lurked a Mexico that could trigger another financial crisis. Blankfein thought the next big problem would be a credit problem, not a problem specific to any one market. People weren’t distinguishing among risks, Blankfein complained, alluding to vanishing credit spreads. For the moment, everything was a Treasury bill.

对于信孚银行的史蒂夫·弗雷德海姆来说，警钟是在春季的一次新加坡和香港之行中敲响的。他意识到墨西哥经济的迅速复苏，因此也满怀希望地认为亚洲经济也能很快恢复元气。然而，弗雷德海姆在亚洲的所见所闻却令他震惊：“许多大玩家”都在撤资。在香港一家私人俱乐部的一次午餐中，一位大型银行家突然改变了一项交易的条款，以减少其在亚洲的风险敞口。弗雷德海姆带着悲观的心情回到了美国。“在那之后，我们开始做空市场，”他回忆道。当时美国国内的信贷利差从未如此之小。他感觉，如果亚洲经济依然脆弱的状况暴露出来，信贷利差只会继续收窄。

For Steve Freidheim of Bankers Trust, the alarm sounded during a spring trip to Singapore and Hong Kong. Cognizant of Mexico’s rapid recovery, he was hopeful that Asia, too, would be back on its feet in no time. But what Freidheim saw in Asia shook him: “a lot of big players” were taking money off the table. During a lunch at a private club in Hong Kong, a major banker suddenly changed the terms of a deal to reduce the banker’s exposure to Asia. Freidheim returned to the United States in a pessimistic mood. “We began to short the market after that,” he recalled. Credit spreads at home had never been tighter. There was only one way for them to go, he felt, especially if the still fragile condition of Asia should become apparent.

起初，华尔街其他交易员也开始悄然得出类似的结论。银行和证券公司开始削减风险较高、流动性较差的债券库存——而这些债券恰恰是长期基金投资组合中的标的。8 虽然抛售并非协调一致，但效果却如同协调一致一般，因为各个交易部门持有的证券基本相同。梅里韦瑟或许感到一丝疑虑，因为在与瑞士银行经理西西里亚诺会面时，梅里韦瑟表示他正在寻找将合伙人的资金投资于基金之外的途径，例如股票或房地产。梅里韦瑟补充说，他们的投资过于集中，仿佛忘记了他的合伙人最近错失了收回部分资金的机会。

Imperceptibly at first, other Wall Street traders started to reach similar conclusions. Banks and securities firms began to cut back their inventories of riskier, less liquid bonds—which, of course, were the very types of bonds in Long-Term’s portfolio.8 The selling was not coordinated, but the effect was much as if it had been, for the various trading desks generally owned the same securities. Meriwether may have felt a shudder of doubt, for in a visit with Siciliano, the Swiss Bank manager, J.M. said he was looking for ways to invest the partners’ capital outside the fund, perhaps in stocks or real estate. They were too concentrated, J.M. added, as if forgetting that his partners had recently passed up the chance to take back some of their capital.

在所有公司中，最令人不安的莫过于旅行者保险公司（Travelers）。该公司高管震惊地发现，他们新收购的子公司所罗门兄弟公司（Salomon Brothers）的固定收益套利交易员，年终奖金动辄高达1000万美元甚至更多。威尔和他的得力助手杰米·戴蒙对希利布兰德开创的明星制度深恶痛绝。根据该制度，所罗门兄弟公司（现为所罗门美邦公司）的交易员可以按利润分成。由于交易员不会因亏损而受到惩罚，他们便产生了一种扭曲的动机，尽可能地拿走公司的钱去冒险。本质上，威尔和戴蒙将套利视为一种披着羊皮的赌博。不出所料，他们对所罗门兄弟公司的主要客户——长期投资公司（Long-Term）——抱有很深的敌意。合并后不久，戴蒙向长期投资公司索要更多信息。梅里韦瑟下意识地回答说，这些信息属于机密。对格林威治毫无忠诚可言的戴蒙威胁要切断长期贷款的资金来源，JM 唯唯诺诺地服从了戴蒙的要求。9一阵新的风吹来。

By far, the firm where unease lay heaviest was Travelers. The firm’s bosses had been shocked to learn that the fixed-income arbitrageurs at Salomon Brothers, their newly acquired subsidiary, routinely took home year-end bonuses of $10 million and more. Weill and his top lieutenant, Jamie Dimon, were hostile to the star system pioneered by Hilibrand, under which traders at Salomon (now Salomon Smith Barney) took home a percentage of their profits. Since the traders were not penalized for losses, they had a perverse incentive to bet as much of the company’s money as they could. Essentially, Weill and Dimon viewed arbitrage as a dressed-up form of gambling. Not surprisingly, they took a dim view of Long-Term, a major Salomon client. Shortly after the merger, Dimon asked Long-Term for more information. Meriwether reflexively replied that such information was private. Dimon, who had no allegiance to Greenwich, threatened to cut Long-Term off, and J.M. meekly complied with Dimon’s request.9 A new breeze was blowing.

所罗门美邦套利业务联席主管罗伯特·斯塔维斯（Robert Stavis）试图拓展股票交易业务，就像长期投资公司（Long-Term）所做的那样，但他的新上司，特别是所罗门美邦全球股票主管史蒂文·布莱克（Steven Black），阻挠了他的计划。斯塔维斯渴望扩大股票波动率，但布莱克坚决反对。所罗门美邦的套利团队一直是长期投资公司的“另一个自我”，它正逐渐演变成一家更加谨慎的公司，而如果长期投资公司由詹姆斯·马歇尔（JM）以更强硬的手段领导，它或许会发展成现在的样子。

Robert Stavis, the co-head of arbitrage at Salomon, was trying to branch into equity trades, just as Long-Term was doing, but Stavis’s new bosses, particularly Steven Black, head of global equities at Salomon Smith Barney, blocked him. Stavis was eager to get bigger in equity vol, but Black put his foot down. Always Long-Term’s alter ego, the Arbitrage Group at Salomon was turning into the more prudent firm that Long-Term might have been had J.M. steered it with a firmer hand.

到了四月份，所罗门集团亏损了2亿美元，这引发了关于其未来走向的严肃讨论。斯塔维斯告诉韦尔，他应该做好进一步亏损的准备，但这并非韦尔想听到的。韦尔深知华尔街关注的是短期收益，而且他自己也对旅行者保险公司的股价着迷。意识到价差已经缩小，旅行者保险公司的高管们做出了一个合乎逻辑的决定——但梅里韦瑟却不知为何忽略了这一点——缩减业务规模。所罗门集团唯一的好消息是，旅行者保险公司即将与花旗集团合并，这使得套利交易显得不那么重要了。在谈到交易亏损的可能性时，韦尔喜欢说：“我希望公司规模足够大，这样即使发生这些爆炸性事件，也只会感觉像被针扎了一下。”加入花旗集​​团后，他的确能够做到这一点。尽管如此，为了核实情况，所罗门集团的一位高管还是致电长期基金，询问该对冲基金在交易中使用了多少资金。对方的回答是：“几乎没有。”萨洛蒙此前并未对其套利业务进行如此深入的分析，因此感到不安。显然，两家公司都过度依赖杠杆，至少萨洛蒙史密斯巴尼已经开始削减杠杆。

By April, Salomon’s group was down $200 million, prompting serious discussions about its future. Stavis told Weill that he should be prepared for further losses, which was not what Weill, who knew that Wall Street focused on short-term earnings and was himself obsessed with Travelers’ stock price, wanted to hear. Aware that spreads had diminished, the Travelers executives made a logical decision—but one that had somehow eluded Meriwether—to scale the business back. The only good news at Salomon was that Travelers’ pending merger with Citicorp made Arbitrage seem less important. In discussing the possibility of trading losses, Weill was fond of saying, “I’d like to be big enough so that when we get these explosions they will feel like pinpricks.” As part of Citicorp, he would be. Still, as a check, a Salomon official put in a call to Long-Term to find out how much capital the hedge fund was using in its trades. Its answer: “Almost none.” Salomon, which hadn’t analyzed its arbitrage business quite so intently, was unnerved. It was obvious that both firms had been relying too much on leverage, and Salomon Smith Barney, at least, began to cut back.

5月份，与长期模型预测相反，套利价差开始扩大。债券套利者遭受损失，引发了一轮规模虽小但难以打破的抛售循环。像所罗门兄弟这样的公司，由于损失导致资本减少，如今已违反了其自身计算机设定的关于资本与资产合理比例的指导原则。因此，他们抛售了更多债券。“随着人们抛售，波动性上升，”一位所罗门兄弟在伦敦的交易员回忆道，“这迫使更多人抛售。”

In May, contrary to the forecasts of Long-Term’s models, arbitrage spreads began to widen. Bond arbitrageurs suffered losses, setting off a modest but hard-to-break cycle of selling. Firms such as Salomon, which had less capital as a result of the losses, now were in violation of their own computer-determined guidelines regarding the proper ratio of capital to assets. Thus, they sold a bit more. “As people liquidated, volatility moved up,” a Salomon trader in London recalled. “That forced more people to liquidate.”

这仍然只是针眼大小的刺痛，但刺痛的针眼却比韦尔预想的要多得多。其中一针刺破了抵押贷款市场，而1994年的债券市场危机也正是从这里开始的。抵押贷款支持证券价格下跌，促使对冲基金削减其他投资，例如新兴市场。10突然间，亚洲不再平静。在亚洲四小龙中最大的国家印度尼西亚，国际货币基金组织的救助计划遇到了阻碍。随后，在5月份，街头骚乱迫使执政32年的苏哈托总统辞职。真正的革命者是货币交易员，他们迫使货币贬值，并揭露了这位腐败独裁者裙带关系政策的失败。

It was still just a pinprick, but there were more pins than Weill had reckoned on. One of them punctured the mortgage market, where the bond market trouble of 1994 had started, too. Mortgage-backed securities declined, prompting hedge funds to pare other exposures, such as in emerging markets.10 Suddenly, Asia was not so calm. In Indonesia, the biggest of the Asian Tigers, the IMF bailout ran into snags. Then, in May, street rioting forced President Suharto to resign after thirty-two years in power. The real revolutionaries had been the currency traders, who had forced a currency devaluation and exposed a corrupt autocrat’s nepotistic program as a failure.

所有人都知道投机者的下一个目标是什么；不祥的是，是俄罗斯。俄罗斯央行行长谢尔盖·杜比宁表示卢布是安全的。为了确保万无一失，他补充道：“卢布不会贬值。” 11然而到了5月底，为了阻止资本外逃，他将利率提高了三倍。俄罗斯本已摇摇欲坠的金融体系如今已濒临崩溃。与此同时，美国经济增速放缓——这通常对债券价格有利。国债收益率下降，国债与其他类型债券（例如公司债券）之间的利差开始扩大。这一趋势与长期基金的预期截然相反，该基金经历了有史以来最糟糕的一个月，亏损6.7%。

Everyone knew the speculators’ next target; ominously, it was Russia. Sergei Dubinin, chairman of the Russian central bank, said the ruble was safe. Hoping to have the definitive word, he added, “There will be no devaluation of the ruble.”11 By the end of May, he had tripled interest rates to halt the flight of capital. Russia’s financial system, already teetering, was now on the verge of collapse. In the United States, meanwhile, the economy was slowing—always bullish for bond prices. Yields on Treasurys fell, and thus the spread between Treasurys and other types of bonds, such as corporate issues, began to widen. This trend being the opposite of what Long-Term was betting on, the fund had its worst month ever, losing 6.7 percent.

尽管瑞士银行（与瑞银合并后将成为长期投资公司最大的投资者）对损失一无所知，但它开始感到不安。瑞士银行衍生品主管蒂姆·弗雷德里克森在审查了认股权证后，致电该行的西西里亚诺，警告他说：“情况不太妙。” 根本问题在于这项投资无法对冲：瑞士银行完全暴露在下行风险之下。“当时，”西西里亚诺回忆说，“这就像一个良性肿瘤。如果情况恶化，我们会遇到麻烦，但他们从未遇到过麻烦。”

Though Swiss Bank, which would be Long-Term’s biggest investor after merging with UBS, knew nothing of the losses, it was getting nervous. After reviewing the warrant package, Tim Fredrickson, the head of derivatives at Swiss Bank, called the bank’s Siciliano and warned him, “This thing isn’t too pretty.” The basic problem was that the investment was unhedgeable: Swiss Bank was completely exposed on the downside. “At that point,” Siciliano recalled, “it was like a benign tumor. If things were to go bad we’d have a problem, but they had never had a problem.”

6月，曾推销认股权证的瑞银销售员罗恩·坦南·鲍姆离开了银行——这只是这场风波中的一个小插曲。更重要的是，信用利差持续扩大。更令人担忧的是，在长期投资公司活跃的每个市场，信用利差都在扩大。问题并非出在某一种证券上；而是信贷普遍收缩，一种普遍存在的市场风险定价过低的观念。投资者寻求安全；现在他们愿意付出任何代价购买国债（这意味着他们愿意接受任何较低的收益率，只要能摆脱风险更高的债券）。

In June, Ron Tannen baum, the UBS salesman who had pitched the warrant, left the bank—a footnote in the unfolding drama. Of greater import, credit spreads continued to widen. More frightening still, they widened in every market in which Long-Term was active. The trouble wasn’t specific to any security; it was a general pulling back of credit, a pervasive sense that markets had been undercharging for risk. Investors wanted safety; now they would pay any amount to buy a Treasury (meaning that they would accept any lower yield, as long as they got out of riskier bonds).

吉姆·麦肯蒂是JM的朋友，也是唯一一个依靠直觉而非电脑进行判断的合伙人。他察觉到市场风向正在转变。他反复敦促合伙人降低公司的风险，但麦肯蒂的意见却被忽视了，因为他被认为是一个不讲科学、老派的赌徒。自从搬到康涅狄格州后，合伙人们不再需要每天在华尔街与熙熙攘攘的人群挤来挤去，他们与交易员们口口相传的那些虽不乏趣闻轶事（尽管偶尔也很有用）更加疏远了。他们很容易对麦肯蒂的警示置之不理，尤其是在酋长自己的交易也一直在亏损的情况下。一天晚上，麦肯蒂在格林威治的马颈酒馆下班后遇到了长期投资公司的总法律顾问詹姆斯·里卡兹。里卡兹第二天早上就要出发去阿拉斯加攀登麦金利山。 “等你回来的时候，世界将彻底改变，”麦肯蒂悲观地预测道。

Jim McEntee, J.M.’s friend and the one partner who relied on his nose, as distinct from a computer, sensed the trade-winds changing. He repeatedly urged his partners to lower the firm’s risks, but McEntee was ignored as a nonscientific, old-fashioned gambler. Since moving to Connecticut, the partners, who no longer had to jostle with the throngs on Wall Street every day, had become even more isolated from the anecdotal, but occasionally useful, gossip that traders pass around. They found it easy to brush off McEntee’s alarums, particularly since the Sheik’s own trades had been losing money. Increasingly frustrated, McEntee met James Rickards, Long-Term’s general counsel, after work one night at the Horseneck Tavern in Greenwich. Rickards was leaving the next morning on an expedition to climb Mount McKinley in Alaska. “By the time you get back, the world will have completely changed,” McEntee predicted darkly.

整个华尔街，麦克恩蒂的同行们都在谈论“避险潮”——也就是涌向美国国债。到6月中旬，30年期美国国债收益率已跌至5.58%，创下自1977年政府开始发行30年期国债以来的最低水平。“（国债）市场上的每个人都害怕做空，”瑞士信贷第一波士顿的策略师马修·阿莱克西告诉《华尔街日报》。12但长期资本基金（Long-Term Capital）是个例外，它每天都做空美国国债。美国国债是该基金做空以对冲其持有的风险较高债券的基本标的。随着美国国债价格上涨，其与其他债券之间的利差也随之扩大。抵押贷款支持证券的收益率比美国国债高出96个基点，跃升至113个基点。公司债券价格从99点上涨至105点，垃圾债券价格从224点上涨至266点。就连看似安全的非热门国债价格也从上涨6个基点上涨至上涨8个基点。在所有市场中，风险较高债券的溢价都在上升。在所有市场中，长期债券都在亏损。

All over Wall Street, McEntee’s fellow traders were now speaking of a “flight to quality”—that is, to Treasury bonds. By mid-June, the yield on the thirty-year Treasury had fallen to 5.58 percent, the lowest since the government had started issuing thirty-year bonds in 1977. “Everyone in the [Treasury] market is afraid to go home short,” Matthew Alexy, a strategist with Credit Suisse First Boston, told The Wall Street Journal.12 Except for Long-Term Capital, which went home short on Treasurys every day. Treasurys were the basic bond that the fund sold short to hedge the riskier bonds it owned. And as Treasurys rallied, spreads between them and other bonds widened. Mortgage-backed securities jumped from 96 basis points over Treasurys to 113 points. Corporate bonds rose from 99 to 105, and junk issues rose from 224 to 266. Even those safe-seeming off-the-run Treasurys climbed from 6 points over to 8 points over.13 In every market, the premium demanded for riskier bonds increased. In every market, Long-Term was losing money.

为何人们如此恐惧风险？亚洲再次成为导火索。在日本，日元暴跌，加剧了该国本已深陷的经济衰退。日本国债收益率暴跌——这与长期投资的预期截然相反。而日本是东亚经济的基石。随着日本进口商缩减采购规模，人们开始担忧区域性经济衰退。在印尼，印尼盾贬值了危机前价值的85%。在韩国，股市单日暴跌8%。恐惧弥漫，但每天都在不同的领域滋生。

Why this all-consuming fear of risk? Once again, Asia was the spark. In Japan, the yen was plummeting, accentuating the country’s already deep recession. Japanese bond yields were plummeting—exactly the opposite of Long-Term’s bet. And Japan was the cornerstone of the East Asian economy. With Japanese importers scaling back their purchases, there was talk of a regional depression. In Indonesia, the rupiah had lost 85 percent of its precrisis value. In South Korea, stocks plunged 8 percent in a single day. The fear was pervasive, but every day, it emerged in a different place.

来自俄罗斯的鼓声越来越响亮。6月，高盛成功为俄罗斯政府发行了12.5亿美元的五年期欧洲债券，利率仅为12%（对俄罗斯而言算是相当低的）。高盛的这次发行堪称销售技巧的胜利，一度让投资者相信俄罗斯的问题正在缓解。但高盛的动机或许并不纯粹。当然，这家银行从中赚取了数千万美元的佣金。此外，高盛当时还有2.5亿美元的俄罗斯贷款未偿还；新发行的债券让俄罗斯得以在最合适的时机偿还高盛的贷款。这家百年老店正准备上市，自然希望尽快摆脱这笔俄罗斯贷款。而高盛希望在秋季上市，因此并没有等待太久，就想看看它在俄罗斯引发的乐观情绪是否能够持续。它迅速抛售了手中的俄罗斯债券，以免被自己发行给投资者的债券所困扰。14到6月底，由于高盛、摩根大通和德意志银行发行的债券，外国市场开始对俄罗斯债券趋之若鹜。一年期俄罗斯国债利率飙升至90%。

The drumbeat from Russia grew steadily louder. In June, Goldman Sachs managed to sell $1.25 billion in five-year Eurobond notes for the Russian government at a modest (for Russia) 12 percent interest rate. Goldman’s issue, truly a triumph of salesmanship, briefly persuaded investors that Russia’s problems were abating. But Goldman’s motives may have been a trifle impure. Naturally, the bank pocketed tens of millions of dollars in fees. Moreover, Goldman had $250 million in Russian loans outstanding; the new bonds enabled Russia to pay Goldman back at a most convenient time. The century-old investment bank was preparing to sell stock to the public, and it preferred to have the Russian loan off its books. And Goldman, which was hoping to go public in the fall, did not wait long to see if the optimism it had generated in Russia lingered. It quickly unloaded its inventory of Russian bonds so as not to be stuck with the paper it had floated to investors.14 By the end of June, thanks to bonds issued by Goldman as well as J. P. Morgan and Deutsche Bank, foreign markets were beginning to choke on Russian paper. Interest rates on one-year Russian bills skyrocketed to 90 percent.

即使在美国，也出现了经济放缓的迹象。股市突然剧烈波动，期权价格飙升。对长期基金而言，隐含波动率升至27%尤为重要。由于长期基金此前在远低于此的水平做空了股票波动率，因此遭受了重大损失。6月份，该基金整体亏损10%，创下历史最差单月表现。1998年上半年，长期基金累计亏损14%，遭遇了首次持续亏损。

Even in America, there were hints of a slowdown. The stock market was suddenly volatile, and option prices jumped. Of direct significance to Long-Term, implied volatility rose to 27 percent. Having shorted equity vol at far lower levels, Long-Term was showing a substantial loss. Overall, in June, the fund lost 10 percent, by far its worst month ever. Long-Term was now down 14 percent for the first half of 1998—its first sustained losing streak.

所罗门美邦的套利集团也遭遇了亏损。韦尔曾承诺能够承受交易业绩的波动，但他最终还是无法接受。六月还没结束，他就决定关闭公司旗下的美国债券套利业务——这项业务他一直都不喜欢。人们不禁要问，既然套利业务一直是所罗门的主要盈利来源，韦尔当初为何要收购它？无论如何，所罗门开始大规模抛售资产。当然，所罗门的持仓与长期基金的交易存在相当大的重叠。因此，所罗门的抛售加速了长期基金投资组合的亏损；可以说，正是这一举动引发了该基金的持续下跌。梅里韦瑟虽然比他的创始人活得更久，但这件事却会一直萦绕在他的心头，直到他去世。

Salomon Smith Barney’s Arbitrage Group had losses, too. Weill had promised he would be able to live with volatile trading results, but he couldn’t. Before June was out, he decided to close the firm’s U.S. bond arbitrage operation, a business he had never liked. One might well ask why Weill had acquired Salomon, since Arbitrage had been its chief moneymaker. In any case, Salomon began to liquidate assets in earnest. Of course, there was a substantial overlap between Salomon’s positions and Long-Term’s trades. Thus, Salomon’s selling helped to tip Long-Term’s portfolio into negative territory; arguably, it triggered the fund’s downhill spiral. Meriwether had outlasted his creator, but it would haunt him from the grave.

与所罗门兄弟公司一样，长期投资公司也做空了简单的互换利差，这个利差源自于一种标准且广泛使用的交易利率。互换利率是指银行、保险公司和其他投资者在任何特定时刻要求的固定利率，以换取他们同意支付LIBOR利率（一种短期银行利率）。关键在于LIBOR利率是浮动的；没有人能够预测它未来的走势。通常情况下，各国互换利率的交易价格略高于该国政府债券利率。因此，互换利差是衡量信贷市场焦虑程度的一个基本指标；它是投资者为承担未来利率波动风险而要求的溢价。

Like Salomon, Long-Term had shorted a simple swap spread, a number that is derived from the interest rate on a standard, widely used trade. The swap rate is, at any given moment, the fixed rate that banks, insurers, and other investors demand to be paid in exchange for agreeing to pay the LIBOR rate, a short-term bank rate. The twist is that the LIBOR rate floats; no one knows where it will go in the future. Typically, swap rates in each country trade at a slight spread above the interest rate on the country’s government debt. Thus, this swap spread is a basic barometer of credit market anxiety; it is the premium that investors demand for taking the risk of being exposed to rate fluctuations in the future.

1998年4月，美国的互换利差为48个基点。从近期历史数据来看，这个数字相当高（20世纪90年代的大部分时间里，利差都低于35个基点，尽管在1990年的上次经济衰退期间，利差曾短暂飙升至84个基点）。长期投资公司认为经济衰退不会很快到来，因此押注利差将会收窄。在欧洲，长期投资公司的立场则更为微妙。英国的互换利差为45个基点，而德国仅为20个基点，这是一个异常大的差距。这种差异有其经济原因，但似乎只是暂时的、不自然的现象。*因此，在欧洲，长期投资公司押注这两个利差之间的差距将会收窄。

In the United States, in April 1998, the swap spread was 48 basis points. In recent historical terms, this number was high (it had been below 35 points for most of the 1990s, although, during the last recession, in 1990, it had briefly spurted to 84). Long-Term, seeing no recession on the horizon, had bet on this spread to narrow. In Europe, Long-Term’s position was more nuanced. The swap spread was 45 points in England and only 20 in Germany, an unusually wide gap. There was an economic reason for this disparity, but it seemed to be a temporary, unnatural quirk.* Thus, in Europe, Long-Term bet that the spread between the two spreads would narrow.

在英国，政府借贷较少，导致政府债券利率较低，利差扩大。相反，在德国，政府大量借贷导致利差缩小。

*In England, the government had done little borrowing, leading to lower government rates and wider spreads. In Germany, conversely, heavy government borrowing had led to narrower spreads.

Long-Term的两笔互换交易都是巧妙的趋同策略，但正如历史所证明的那样，并非稳赚不赔。互换市场规模庞大，历史数据非常适合建模分析。但正如许多其他交易一样，Long-Term的互换头寸规模过大。随着Salomon开始平仓其（非常相似的）互换头寸，Long-Term开始遭受双重损失。美国利差扩大至56个基点，英国和德国之间的利差也随之扩大。

Both of Long-Term’s swap trades were intelligent convergence plays, though not, as history had shown, sure things. The swap market was deep and had a history that was very suitable for modeling. But as had been the case in so many other trades, the size of Long-Term’s swap positions was unreasonably large. And as Salomon began to liquidate its (quite similar) swap positions, Long-Term began to lose both ways. The spread in the United States widened—to 56 points—and so did the gap between the United Kingdom’s and Germany’s.

更糟糕的是，7月份，所罗门兄弟退出美国套利市场的消息公开。一份泄露给《华尔街日报》的高层备忘录语气不祥地宣称：“随着时间的推移，套利获利的机会减少了，而风险和波动性却增加了。” 15自然而然地，各家公司的交易员开始抛售利率互换和其他套利交易，生怕被所罗门兄弟的巨额资金碾压。

What was worse, in July, word of Salomon’s exit from U.S. arbitrage became public. A memo from the brass, leaked to The Wall Street Journal, ominously declared, “Opportunity for arbitrage profits has lessened over time while the risks and volatility have grown.”15 Naturally, traders at diverse firms began to unload interest rate swaps as well as other arbitrage trades, for fear of being trampled by Salomon’s steamroller.

长期基金的合伙人严重低估了业内第二大玩家退出市场的严重性。他们原本以为会有其他套利者填补空缺。当一位初级交易员向埃里克·罗森菲尔德表达担忧时，后者却不以为然，坚称合伙人已经掌控了局面。7月，瑞士银行和瑞银合并后，西西里亚诺拜访了梅里韦瑟，后者告知西西里亚诺长期基金近期亏损的消息令他震惊不已。但JM似乎也信心满满，甚至有些如释重负。他一直期待的一两个糟糕月份终于到来了。唯一令人不安的是，长期基金的所有交易都亏损了，这是JM始料未及的。但他冷静地补充说，现在基金将利用价格下跌的机会，增持一些他看好的交易。西西里亚诺此前就对长期投资公司感到不安，他立即告知瑞银首席风险官费利克斯·费舍尔，如果长期投资公司的亏损持续下去，瑞银将面临严重风险。但两人都没有向瑞银高层管理人员发出警告。

The Long-Term partners badly underestimated the seriousness of the second biggest player in their business calling it quits. They expected other arbitrageurs to fill the void. When a junior trader voiced concern to Eric Rosenfeld, the latter brushed him off, insisting that the partners were on top of the situation. In July, after Swiss Bank and UBS merged, Siciliano visited Meriwether, who stunned Siciliano with the news of Long-Term’s recent losses. But J.M., too, seemed confident—almost relieved. Finally, the one or two bad months he had long been expecting had come. The only disconcerting note was that Long-Term had lost money on all of its trades, something J.M. hadn’t expected. But he coolly added that now the fund would take advantage of lower prices and load up on some favorite trades. Siciliano, who had already been uneasy about Long-Term, promptly advised Felix Fischer, the chief risk officer at UBS, that the bank would be seriously exposed if Long-Term’s losses continued. Neither man warned the bank’s senior management.

贝尔斯登是该基金的清算经纪商，也对长期投资基金的亏损非常关注。但到了7月份，该基金开始复苏。“由于我们能够看到每日损益表，所以我们在7月初就知道该基金已经出现了显著的复苏，”贝尔斯登的迈克·艾利克斯指出。“官方的说法是，他们重新测试了所有模型，并得出结论：6月份的亏损只是一个预期中的异常情况。这就是官方的说法。”

Bear Stearns, the fund’s clearing broker, also took a strong interest in Long-Term’s losses. But in July, the fund recovered. “Since we could see the daily P&L [profit-and-loss statement], we knew in early July there was a significant recovery,” noted Bear’s Mike Alix. “The story was, they had gone back and retested all their models and come to the conclusion that June was an expected aberration. That was the party line.”

JM谨慎地亲自通知了美林证券的艾莉森以及该基金的其他主要合伙人有关亏损的情况。他听起来总体上很放松。在给投资者的信中，JM报告说“未来的预期收益良好”。 16 在高尔夫球场上，梅里韦瑟也一如既往地神采奕奕；亏损并没有让他意志消沉。一位球友说他看起来“内心很平静”。

J.M. was careful to personally notify Allison at Merrill Lynch and other of the fund’s big partners about the losses. He generally sounded relaxed. Writing to investors, J.M. reported that “future expected returns are good.”16 Meriwether was his old self on the golf course, too; the losses hadn’t damped his spirits. A golfing friend said he seemed “at peace with himself.”

长期投资基金持续保持信心的最有力证明就是该基金不断招募新员工。合伙人一向热衷于新技术，今年夏天又聘请了八位软件专家，员工人数一度达到190人。

The surest sign of Long-Term’s continued confidence was that the fund continued to recruit new people. Always infatuated with new technology, the partners hired eight new software whizzes over the summer. The staff hit a peak of 190.

长期基金确实缩减了资产规模，旨在使其与目前已耗尽的储备相匹配。但总体抛售量很小。尽管长期基金出售了一些方向性交易，但合伙人仍热衷于持有其大型趋同头寸，例如股票波动率、互换合约和皇家荷兰/壳牌股票；他们还增持了一些头寸。 17总体而言，其资产仅从1340亿美元降至1280亿美元，杠杆率实际上上升至31倍。根据该基金的模型，长期基金已将其在典型交易日可能损失的金额从4500万美元减少到3400万美元。 18但这是一种高度机械化的风险评估方法。它依赖于过去的波动率来衡量未来：和往常一样，长期基金的合伙人仍然只关注过去。

Long-Term did pare back its assets, intending to bring them into line with its now-depleted reserves. But the total selling was slight. While Long-Term sold some directional trades, the partners were keen on holding on to their big convergence positions, such as equity vol, swaps, and Royal Dutch/Shell; they also added to some positions.17 Overall, their assets declined only to $128 billion from $134 billion, and their leverage actually rose, to thirty-one times. According to the fund’s models, Long-Term had reduced the amount it was likely to lose on a typical trading day, from $45 million to $34 million.18 But this was a highly mechanistic way of evaluating risk. It relied on past volatilities as a gauge of the future: as usual, the partners driving Long-Term had their eyes on the rearview mirror.

7月份，市场依然动荡不安。在俄罗斯，贬值的担忧并未消除，短期债券收益率飙升至令人瞠目结舌的120%年化率。然而，全球投资者——那些时刻关注CNN或彭博社新闻、似乎从不睡觉的资深交易员——的态度是，俄罗斯是个问题，但可控。正如一位俄罗斯问题专家漫不经心地指出，俄罗斯央行可以轻易关闭美元窗口，阻止资金外流。“人们不会在意，”他补充道，“只会有一些对冲基金遭受损失！” 19

In July, the markets continued to be edgy. In Russia, where fears of devaluation had not been put to bed, yields on short-term bonds soared to a dizzying 120 percent annual rate. However, the attitude of global investors—the plugged-in traders who were forever checking CNN or Bloomberg and who seemed never to sleep—was that Russia was a problem, but a contained one. As one Russia hand nonchalantly observed, the central bank could easily shut the dollar window and halt the flight of money. “People won’t care,” he added. “Just some hedge funds will get hosed!”19

如果人们漠不关心，那是因为货币警察们迅速掩盖了所有问题迹象。7月，在鲁宾部长的敦促下，国际货币基金组织和各国达成了一项226亿美元的俄罗斯救助计划，这似乎表明，没有什么金融问题是他们解决不了的。（然而，大部分救助资金最终会被俄罗斯寡头窃取并转移出境。）随后，高盛诱使投资者将短期俄罗斯债券兑换成20年期国债——仿佛俄罗斯未来20周的局势明朗，更遑论未来20年。但投资者已经不再从信用角度分析俄罗斯；他们只是老调重弹：“核大国不会违约。”这似乎与花旗银行董事长沃尔特·里斯顿的言论如出一辙。里斯顿曾在20世纪70年代和80年代初向拉丁美洲提供贷款，他宣称主权国家不会违约。

If people did not care, it was because the monetary policemen had been so quick to patch any sign of trouble. In July, at Secretary Rubin’s urging, the IMF and various nations worked out a $22.6 billion Russian bailout, seemingly demonstrating that there was no financial problem that they couldn’t fix. (Much of the bailout money would be stolen by Russian oligarchs and siphoned out of the country.) Then Goldman Sachs induced investors to swap their short-term Russian notes for twenty-year bonds—as if the next twenty weeks in Russia were clear, much less the next twenty years. But investors had stopped analyzing Russia as a credit; they were falling back on a cliché: “Nuclear powers don’t default.” It seemed an echo of Walter Wriston, the Citibank chairman who had made loans to Latin America in the 1970s and early 1980s, proclaiming that sovereign nations didn’t default.

值得称赞的是，当其他人没有察觉时，旅行者保险公司的威尔和戴蒙却嗅到了俄罗斯的危险气息。“桑迪讨厌俄罗斯，”他的一位伦敦交易员说，“他说那里一片混乱。”6月，一位国际货币基金组织官员会见了所罗门兄弟，敦促该银行支持莫斯科，并称赞了莫斯科的领导层。国际货币基金组织驻莫斯科代表团团长则采取了不同的策略，向所罗门兄弟保证，美国绝不会允许一个核大国违约。但威尔和戴蒙不愿面对意外，他们预感到俄罗斯只会带来意想不到的情况。尽管威尔对地缘政治，尤其是俄罗斯，非常感兴趣，但他认为投资银行不应该在这个领域进行投资。于是，他们下达了抛售指令。

To their credit, Travelers’ Weill and Dimon smelled a rat in Russia when others didn’t. “Sandy hated Russia,” according to one of his London traders. “He said it was lawless.” An IMF official met with Salomon in June and urged the bank to back Moscow, whose leadership he praised. The IMF mission chief in Moscow tried a different tack, assuring Salomon that the United States would never let a nuclear power default. But Weill and Dimon were uncomfortable with being exposed to surprises, and they sensed that Russia would bring nothing but. Though fascinated by geopolitics and Russia in particular, Weill thought it was a poor arena for an investment bank to be laying bets in. The order went out to sell.

长期基金和所罗门兄弟再次在交易中站在了对立面。哈加尼和霍金斯坚信俄罗斯不可能——也绝不会——让其货币崩溃。（经济学家们当时正奔走于各家对冲基金之间，包括长期基金在内，兜售着这种观点。）长期基金当然知道违约是有可能发生的。但这两位教授拥有一个模型，他们相信这个模型可以预测莫斯科违约后会发生什么。20在哈加尼看来，这完全合情合理。 “我们所做的就是依靠经验，”他后来在谈到整个投资组合时说道，“如果你不愿意从经验中得出任何结论，那你还不如袖手旁观，什么也不做。” 21但是，一个“模型”真的能够预测一个国家——不仅仅是它的市场，还有它的政客、立法者，以及人们的情感——的走向吗？对于长期基金的这种交易方式来说，俄罗斯绝对不是一个理想的试验场。脱离共产主义不到十年，正努力转型为民主社会的俄罗斯，其局势几乎天生难以预测。哈加尼的历史知识本应让他明白这一点。（丘吉尔曾在1939年宣称：“我无法预测俄罗斯的行动。它就像一个谜中谜，谜中谜。”）1998年，俄罗斯的局势也超出了计量经济学的范畴，即使是格林威治的计算机也无法预测。

Once again, Long-Term and Salomon were on opposite sides of a trade. Haghani and Hawkins were taken by the idea that Russia couldn’t—and simply wouldn’t—let its currency fail. (Economists were trooping from hedge fund to hedge fund, including Long-Term, peddling this very notion.) Long-Term knew, of course, that a default was conceivable. But the professors had a model that, they believed, forecast what would occur if Moscow did default.20 To Haghani, this was altogether reasonable. “What we did is rely on experience,” he noted later of the portfolio in general. “If you’re not willing to draw any conclusions from experience, you might as well sit on your hands and do nothing.”21 But could a “model” truly anticipate a country—not merely its markets but its politicians, its legislators, its passions, too? Russia was a singularly poor laboratory for Long-Term’s type of trading. Less than a decade removed from communism and struggling to become a democratic society, Russia was almost inherently unpredictable. Haghani’s knowledge of history should have told him that. (Churchill had declared in 1939, “I cannot forecast to you the action of Russia. It is a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma.”) In 1998, too, Russia was beyond the realm of econometrics, even of the computers in Greenwich.

美联储深知银行过度依赖过往经验进行预测的危险性。美联储最高银行监管官员在一封致各银行的公开信中警告说：“银行应避免任何认为……过去几年异常有利的经济环境会无限期持续下去的倾向。”尽管这封信讨论的是商业贷款而非资本市场，但它强调了需要考虑破产和违约等“替代情景”，而不是假设未来会是现在的无缝延续。 22与这种合理的谨慎形成鲜明对比的是，美联储主席格林斯潘仍在对不受限制的衍生品市场大加赞赏。7月30日，格林斯潘在参议院农业、营养和林业委员会作证时宣称，衍生品交易员“通过对交易对手的仔细评估，已经相当有效地管理了信用风险”。这番话只能意味着，在格林斯潘看来，像美林或摩根大通这样的公司正在仔细审查像Long-Term这样的客户——而这种观点很快就会被证明是错误的。 23

The Fed was well aware of the danger of banks basing predictions too much on the past. In an open letter to banks, the Fed’s top banking supervisor warned, “Banks should resist any tendency to assume . . . that the unusually favorable economic environment of the last few years will continue indefinitely.” Though the letter dealt with commercial loans rather than capital markets, it underscored the need to think about “alternative scenarios” such as bankruptcies and defaults, rather than assume that the future would be a seamless extension of the present.22 In contrast to this well-founded caution, Fed chief Greenspan was still singing the praises of unfettered derivative markets. On July 30, testifying before the Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition, and Forestry, Greenspan declared that derivative traders “have managed credit risks quite effectively through careful evaluation of counterparties.” The words can only mean that, in Greenspan’s view, a Merrill or a Morgan was carefully scrutinizing clients such as Long-Term—a view that would soon become demonstrably false.23

7月下半月，长期债券表现下滑，最终以持平收尾。欧美股市暴跌。8月初，俄罗斯债券价格再次下跌。华尔街银行和对冲基金抛售的传闻甚嚣尘上，抛售潮蔓延至东欧、拉丁美洲和亚洲。如今，俄罗斯的困境已不再局限于此。

In the second half of July, Long-Term’s performance tailed off. It ended the month flat. Stocks in Europe and America swooned. By early August, Russian bonds were sinking again. Rumors swirled of selling by Wall Street banks and hedge funds. And the selling spread to eastern Europe, Latin America, and Asia. Now, Russia was not so contained.

8月第二周，俄罗斯市场崩盘。8月13日，由于美元外流、外汇储备锐减、预算超支，以及主要商品石油价格暴跌33%，俄罗斯政府被迫实施卢布管制。由于缺乏可靠且偿付能力强的银行，银行系统陷入瘫痪。莫斯科股市一度暂停交易。当日收盘下跌6%，年内累计跌幅高达75%。短期利率飙升至近200%。俄罗斯长期债券价格跌至两个月前的一半，而就在两个月前，高盛还乐于为其发行浮动利率债券。

During the second week of August, Russia’s markets snapped. On August 13, with dollars fleeing the country, its reserves dwindling, its budget overtapped, and the price of oil, its chief commodity, down 33 percent, the government imposed controls on the ruble. The banking system froze for lack of reliable and solvent banks. The Moscow stock market briefly halted trading. It ended the day down 6 percent—and down 75 percent for the year. Short-term interest rates surged to almost 200 percent. Long-term Russian bonds fell to half their price of only two months earlier, when Goldman had happily floated them.

当全世界都在等待卢布贬值，而政府仍然坚称不会发生时，由共产党控制的杜马（议会下院）拒绝了国际货币基金组织敦促其采取的改革措施。随后，议员们开始休假。当政府恳求杜马复会时，议员们拒绝了——但那时，包括总统鲍里斯·叶利钦在内的许多政府领导人也都在海边的别墅度假，让国家自行解决困境。这种做法难以效仿。

As the world waited for a ruble devaluation, which the government still insisted would not occur, the Communist-dominated Duma, the lower house of Parliament, rejected reform measures urged on it by the IMF. Then the members went on vacation. When the government begged the Duma to reconvene, the members refused—but by then many government leaders, including President Boris Yeltsin, were also at seaside dachas, leaving the country to sort out its misery. It was a hard thing to model.

在美国和欧洲，一系列负面因素令市场震荡：俄罗斯危机、亚洲经济疲软、伊拉克拒绝接受全面武器核查、中国可能贬值人民币，以及克林顿总统关于其与白宫实习生莫妮卡·莱温斯基关系的证词。随着全球投资者纷纷抛售俄罗斯和亚洲资产，他们疯狂涌入美国国债市场，在无人愿意承担风险之际，国债成为了避险的堡垒。30年期国债收益率再创新低，跌至5.56%。

In the United States and Europe, markets shuddered from a swelling list of negatives: the crisis in Russia, weakness in Asia, Iraq’s refusal to permit full weapons inspections, the possibility of China devaluing its currency, and President Clinton’s testimony about his relationship with a White House intern, Monica Lewinsky. As global investors bailed out of Russia and Asia, they furiously piled into Treasurys, a bulwark of safety when no one wanted risk. Thirty-year bond yields touched another new low: 5.56 percent.

自然而然，信用利差持续扩大。自4月份债券套利达到顶峰以来，A级债券的收益率比美国国债高出60个基点，涨幅已达90个基点。美国互换利差也在上升。华尔街各大银行的套利部门都在缩减规模；资本正像逃离亚洲市场一样，从债券套利市场撤离。美联储起初对这一趋势持乐观态度。当时利差收窄，信贷过于宽松。但如今，在俄罗斯金融危机的背景下，美联储的神经却紧绷起来。

Naturally, credit spreads kept widening. Since April, the high point for bond arbitrage, A-rated bonds had moved from 60 points over Treasurys to 90 points. U.S. swap spreads were rising, too. At every Wall Street bank, arbitrage desks were cutting back; capital was fleeing from bond arbitrage just as it had fled from Asia. The Fed, at first, had been favorably disposed toward the trend. Spreads had been tight, credit too easy. But now, in the context of Russia’s meltdown, the Fed’s nerves were on edge.

长期投资公司8月份亏损——令人担忧的是，这已经是四个月以来的第三个月了。合伙人再也无法对华尔街保持冷漠。意识到正在持续清算的所罗门兄弟公司是个大麻烦，哈格尼提出收购该银行持有的全部仓位，价值约20亿美元——仅仅是为了冻结这些仓位。所罗门兄弟公司的人以为他在开玩笑——长期投资公司已经没有足够的资金来支撑如此大胆的提议——但所罗门兄弟公司的交易员们却乐见了各自命运的逆转：长期投资公司不再掌握主动权。长期投资公司的首席财务官罗伯特·舒斯塔克每天都要接听来自忧心忡忡的贝尔斯登公司的电话。摩根大通也听到了长期投资公司正在清算仓位——或者至少正在尝试清算——的传言。雷曼兄弟也听到了这些传言。尽管长期投资公司曾经对这家规模较小的投资银行不屑一顾，但现在却与雷曼兄弟公司关系密切。 “他们来找我们是为了拓展业务，”雷曼兄弟固定收益主管杰弗里·范德贝克回忆道，“我当时就想，他们的流动性可能快枯竭了。他们需要更多融资。”随着回购贷款展期，包括雷曼兄弟在内的华尔街银行最终开始向金融教授们索要保证金。

Long-Term was losing money in August—disturbingly, for the third month in four. The partners could no longer be so standoffish toward Wall Street. Realizing that Salomon, which was continuing to liquidate, was a major headache, Haghani offered to buy the bank’s whole position, worth about $2 billion—just to freeze it. Salomon’s people thought he was joking—Long-Term no longer had the capital to back such bold talk—but Salomon’s traders enjoyed the turnabout in their respective fortunes: Long-Term wasn’t calling the shots anymore. Robert Shustak, Long-Term’s chief financial officer, was having to field calls every day from a worried Bear Stearns. J. P. Morgan heard rumors that Long-Term was liquidating positions—or at least trying to. Lehman Brothers heard the rumors, too. Though Long-Term had once snubbed the smallish investment bank, now it was making nice with Lehman. “They were coming to us to do more business,” Jeffrey Vanderbeek, head of fixed income at Lehman, recalled. “I remember thinking that their liquidity might be drying up. They wanted more financing.” As repo loans were rolling over, Wall Street banks, Lehman among them, were finally asking the professors for margin.

合伙人们突然开始担忧自身安危，纷纷匆忙给顾问和律师打电话。汉斯·胡夫施密德（Hans Hufschmid）是位伦敦合伙人，他的妻子是加州人，他原本打算竞购马里布的一处房产。但胡夫施密德为了投资长期基金而背负了巨额债务，此刻却紧张起来。凭着直觉，他决定放弃购买。迈伦·斯科尔斯（Myron Scholes）则在旧金山买了一栋四层楼的房子，他的未婚妻就住在那里。这栋位于俄罗斯山（Russian Hill）的房子非常棒，拥有高高的天花板和一个可以俯瞰渔人码头的露台。它价值650万美元。不过，斯科尔斯在基金之外还有资金。而且，到目前为止，该基金的损失并不算严重。

Suddenly anxious about their personal well-being, the partners made hurried calls to their advisers and attorneys. Hans Hufschmid, a London partner who was married to a Californian, was about to bid on a house in Malibu. But Hufschmid, who had borrowed heavily to invest in Long-Term, got a case of nerves. On a hunch, he decided not to buy the house. Myron Scholes did buy a four-story home in San Francisco, where his fiancée lived. It was a fantastic home on Russian Hill, with high ceilings and a terrace overlooking Fisherman’s Wharf. It cost $6.5 million.24 But then, Scholes had money outside the fund. And the fund’s losses so far had hardly been severe.

梅里韦瑟信心满满地在八月中旬启程前往中国。合伙人认为他们有理由保持乐观；他们觉得利差已经扩大到如此程度，现在肯定只会缩小。但他们的乐观中却夹杂着一丝绝望。八月中旬，长期基金加大了对冲俄罗斯债券的投入，此前该基金已持有部分对冲俄罗斯债券以及一些未对冲的俄罗斯债券。如今，全世界都在关注俄罗斯，俄罗斯的财政状况一团糟，政府也陷入停滞，而哈加尼和一位名叫艾曼·欣迪的研究员——一位斯坦福大学的前教授——却像掌握了某个神秘东方谜题的内幕消息一样，买入了更多俄罗斯债券。诺贝尔奖和所有学位现在都无关紧要了；这两位教授是在孤注一掷。据长期基金的一位交易员说，该基金“在最后关头彻底做多俄罗斯”。另一位交易员沮丧地说：“这完全违背了我们的策略。”

Meriwether confidently went ahead with a trip to China in the middle of August. The partners thought they had reason to be optimistic; spreads had widened so much, they felt, that now, surely, they could only narrow. But their optimism had a desperate edge. In mid-August, Long-Term jumped more heavily into Russia, where it already owned hedged Russian bonds as well as some that were unhedged. Now, while the entire world was watching Russia, while its finances were in shambles and its government on hold, Haghani and a researcher named Ayman Hindy, a former professor at Stanford, bought more Russian bonds as though they had the inside scoop on that enigmatic Eastern riddle. Neither the Nobel Prize nor all the degrees mattered now; the professors were rolling the dice. According to one trader at Long-Term, the fund went “outright long in Russia—right at the end.” Said another, miserably, “It was so against our way.”

8

8

坠落

THE FALL

问题是……长期资本管理公司 (LTCM) 的灾难仅仅是一次独特的孤立事件，一次自然界的糟糕抽奖；还是此类灾难是布莱克-斯科尔斯公式本身及其可能造成的错觉（即所有市场参与者可以同时对冲所有风险）的必然结果。

The question . . . is whether the LTCM disaster was merely a unique and isolated event, a bad drawing from nature’s urn; or whether such disasters are the inevitable consequence of the Black-Scholes formula itself and the illusion it may give that all market participants can hedge away all their risk at the same time.

——默顿·H·米勒，诺贝尔文学奖得主





—MERTON H. MILLER, NOBEL LAUREATE





八月中旬，长期资本的业绩一直不佳，但任何基金，或者任何资本主义企业，迟早都会经历业绩下滑。它的声誉，如同它的资本一样，依然完好无损。它的整体业绩光鲜亮丽，在真正了解这家公司的金融精英圈子里，它的名字常常被用来形容“天才”。长期资本鲜为人知，但这正是梅里韦瑟和他的合伙人所希望的，当然，他们也希望基金能一直保持这种低调。他们几乎不可能预见到自己将在哪些重大事件中扮演重要角色，甚至成为历史性事件的主角，也不可能预见到他们的命运将会发生多么翻天覆地的变化。他们更无法想象这些事件会以如此惊人的速度发生。夏末，当华尔街人士纷纷涌向汉普顿度假时，这些合伙人已跻身美国最富有、最成功、最受尊敬的投资者之列。他们的基金拥有36亿美元的资本，其中五分之二是他们个人的。仅仅五周时间，他们就把所有钱都赔光了。

THROUGH THE MIDDLE of August, Long-Term Capital had been having a bad year, but only a bad year such as any fund, or any capitalistic enterprise, must sooner or later suffer. Its reputation, like its capital, remained intact. Its overall record sparkled, and its name, among the members of the financial cognoscenti who truly knew the firm, often gave rise to the very term “genius.” Long-Term was unknown to the general public, but that is how Meriwether and his boys wanted it, and that, of course, is how they expected the fund to remain. They could hardly have had a glimmer of the large, even historic, events in which they were to play a leading role, nor of how radically their fortunes would change. Much less could they have imagined the stunning swiftness with which such events would unfold. In late summer, as Wall Streeters scurried for the Hamptons, the partners were among America’s most prosperous, most successful, and most highly esteemed investors. Their fund had $3.6 billion in capital, of which two fifths was personally theirs. It would take only five weeks for them to lose it all.

8月17日星期一，俄罗斯宣布暂停偿还债务。政府决定宁愿用卢布支付俄罗斯工人的工资，也不愿偿还西方债券持有人的债务。它既不打算维持卢布在国际市场上的价值，也不打算这样做。简而言之，这相当于卢布贬值，而且至少在部分借款上，这相当于政府违约，而此前政府曾承诺不会这样做。俄罗斯的政策始终令人费解，它表示暂停偿还债务的条款将适用于135亿美元的本地（卢布）债务——这打破了政府兑付本国货币的原则，即使在拉丁美洲债务危机最严重的时候，这一原则也依然有效。

On Monday, August 17, Russia declared a debt moratorium. The government simply decided it would rather use its rubles to pay Russian workers than Western bondholders. Nor would it attempt to maintain the value of those rubles in foreign markets. In short, it was a devaluation and, on at least some of its borrowings, a default from a government that had promised that it would do neither. Enigmatic to the end, Russia said its moratorium would apply to $13.5 billion of local (ruble) debt—breaking the rule, honored even in the depths of the Latin American debt crisis, that a government honors its own coin.

市场反应起初较为平淡。墨西哥和巴西债券下跌，日本和多个新兴市场股市走弱。但道琼斯指数上涨近150点。美国银行秉承自1929年以来的传统，迅速宣称预计能够安然度过这场风暴，几乎不会受到任何不利影响。摩根大通首席信贷官罗伯特·斯特朗（Robert Strong）自信地向华尔街证券分析师宣称：“我不认为俄罗斯对摩根大通或其他美国银行来说是一个重大问题。”¹ 就其总债务而言，俄罗斯并无大碍，几乎可以算得上是另一个委内瑞拉。

The reaction in markets was muted, at least at first. Mexican and Brazilian bonds fell, and stocks in Japan and various emerging markets weakened. But the Dow rose nearly 150 points. American banks, honoring a tradition that extended back to 1929, quickly declared that they expected to weather the storm with little ill effect. Robert Strong, chief credit officer at Chase Manhattan, whose stock price was to fall 50 percent within six weeks, confidently proclaimed to Wall Street security analysts, “I do not view Russia as a major issue” for Chase or for other U.S. banks.¹ In terms of its total indebtedness, Russia was no big deal, barely another Venezuela.

然而，俄罗斯并非委内瑞拉。按理说，核大国不会违约。但当俄罗斯违约时，市场某些东西却随之消亡。那种认为全球金融警察总会出手相救的安慰性想法，如今被证明是谬论。这一次，国际货币基金组织（IMF）没有出手相救，罗伯特·鲁宾和七国集团（G7）等西方国家也没有匆忙出手救助。“基金组织和七国集团最终还是说了‘不’，”国际货币基金组织前高级官员莫里斯·戈德斯坦评论道。² 这一真相的影响如同西伯利亚的狂风，令全球市场不寒而栗。违约打破了投资者们懒惰却又方便的假设——安全网永远存在。它“刺破了一个道德风险泡沫”³，而这个泡沫自鲁宾出手救助墨西哥以来就一直在膨胀着人们的预期。投资者们，起初是零星的，随后是集体的，得出结论：没有哪个新兴市场是安全的。七十年来，俄罗斯的共产党人都没能像那些不负责任的资本家那样，给市场带来如此沉重的打击。

Except that Russia was not Venezuela. Supposedly, nuclear powers did not default. And when Russia did, something in the markets died. The comforting notion that the global financial cops would always be there to put matters right was now exposed as a fallacy. This time, there was no rescue by the IMF, no hurried bailout by Robert Rubin or the Group of Seven Western powers. “The fund and the G7 finally managed to say no,” remarked Morris Goldstein, a former senior IMF official.² The implications of this truth chilled global markets like a Siberian gale. The default shattered the lazy but convenient assumptions of investors that the safety net would always be there. It “punctured a moral hazard bubble”³ that had been inflating expectations since Rubin had ridden to the rescue of Mexico. Investors, at first singly and then en masse, concluded that no emerging market was safe. In seventy years, Russia’s Communists had not succeeded in dealing markets such a telling blow as did its deadbeat capitalists.

周四，也就是违约三天后，全球市场剧烈震荡。东欧和土耳其股市疲软。加拉加斯股市暴跌9.5%。委内瑞拉民众恐慌性抢购美元。规模更大的巴西股市下跌6%。德国股市下跌2%，仿佛俄罗斯的威胁真的会席卷东线。

On Thursday, three days after the default, markets around the world buckled. Shares in eastern Europe and Turkey were weak. The stock market in Caracas plunged 9.5 percent. Venezuelans panicked and rushed to buy dollars. Brazil’s far larger bolsa was off 6 percent. Germany’s stock market fell 2 percent, as if the Russian menace could actually tramp across the eastern front.

投资者如今不仅逃离新兴市场，而是逃离一切潜在的投资风险。这场恐慌证明，亚洲金融危机并未真正消散。互换利差——信贷市场的基本晴雨表——如同危险的高烧般飙升。英国巴克莱银行命令其交易员平仓英国互换的空头头寸，尽管其交易员（包括长期投资公司的交易员）认为互换价格高得离谱。巴克莱放弃交易的决定反而推高了互换价格。* 巴克莱的管理层对此毫不在意。这家银行只想脱身。它不想再承担风险了。

Investors now were running not just from emerging markets, but from investment risk wherever it lurked. The panic proved that the Asian storm had never truly been forgotten. Swap spreads—those basic thermometers of credit markets—rose like a dangerous fever. The British bank Barclays ordered its traders to unload short positions in U.K. swaps, even though its traders, like those at Long-Term, thought swaps were unreasonably high. Barclays’ decision to abandon the trade merely pushed them higher. * Barclays’ management didn’t care. The bank wanted out. It was done with taking risk.

*要平掉空头头寸，交易者必须买回其交易；因此，其效果是看涨的。

*To exit a short position, a trader must buy back his trade; thus, the effect is bullish.

第二天，8月21日星期五，各地的交易员纷纷离场。亚洲和欧洲股市暴跌。道琼斯指数在中午前下跌了280点，随后收复了大部分失地。这种明显的波动性激增给长期投资者造成了数千万美元的损失。

The next day, Friday, August 21, traders everywhere wanted out. Stock markets in Asia and in Europe plunged. The Dow fell 280 points before noon, then recouped most of its losses. This palpable surge in volatility cost Long-Term several tens of millions of dollars.

信贷市场的损失更为惨重。国债价格上涨，但这波上涨是由恐慌驱动的，因为投资者买入国债是为了抛售劣质债券。几个月前，他们还分不清各种风险，而现在，风险成了他们关注的焦点。原本一片祥和的世界突然变得黯淡无光，俄罗斯、日本，甚至克林顿-莱温斯基丑闻都让世界蒙上了阴影。在每个市场，投资者都只想要最安全的债券。在美国，最安全的债券是30年期国债；在德国，则是10年期德国国债。世界各地的人们都在买入更安全（收益率更低）的债券，卖出风险更高（收益率更高）的债券，不断拉大此类债券之间的利差。长期债券市场每分每秒都在损失数百万美元。

The damage to credit markets was far worse. Treasurys rallied, but it was a rally driven by panic, for investors bought Treasurys to get out of inferior credits. A few months before, they had not distinguished one risk from the next. Now it was all they thought of. A rose-colored world had suddenly gone dark, discolored by Russia, Japan, even the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal. In every market, investors wanted only the safest bond. In the United States, it had to be the thirty-year Treasury; in Germany, the ten-year Bund. All over the world, people were buying safer (lower-yielding) bonds and selling riskier (higher-yielding) ones, pushing the spreads between such bond pairs ever wider. Minute by minute, Long-Term was losing millions.

在格林威治，八月下旬那个阳光灿烂的星期五，长期投资公司的办公室几乎空无一人。大多数高级合伙人都休假了；这是一个闷热的早晨，员工们行动迟缓。吉姆·麦肯蒂，这位性格鲜明的“酋长”，他那些令人担忧的警告却无人理会，此刻正在照看公司。比尔·克拉斯克，这位构建了公司许多模型的合伙人，正焦急地监控着市场，不停地点击着屏幕上闪烁的页面。克拉斯克从政府债券到抵押贷款再到外债，几乎浏览了整个信贷市场。当他看到美国互换利差的报价时，他难以置信地盯着屏幕。克拉斯克知道，在交易活跃的日子里，美国互换利差的波动幅度可能只有1个点。但那天早上，互换利差却在20个点的范围内剧烈波动。最终，利差收盘时竟惊人地上涨了9个点，达到76，而4月份的利差仅为48。英国的情况也一样：互换利差飙升至 62，比 7 月份的水平高出 12 个点。

In Greenwich, on that golden late-August Friday, Long-Term’s office was largely deserted. Most of the senior partners were on vacation; it was a sultry morning, and the staff was moving slowly. Jim McEntee, the colorful “sheik” whose doleful warnings had been ignored, was minding the store. Bill Krasker, the partner who had constructed many of the firm’s models, was anxiously monitoring markets, clicking from one phosphorescent page to the next. Krasker clicked from governments to mortgages to foreign debt, the entire atlas of credit. When he saw the quotation for U.S. swap spreads, he stared at his screen in disbelief. On an active day, Krasker knew, U.S. swap spreads might change by as much as a point. But on this morning, swap spreads were wildly oscillating over a range of 20 points. They ended an astonishing 9 points higher, at 76, up from 48 in April. In Britain it was the same story: swap spreads surged to 62, a dozen points wider than they had been in July.

克拉斯克简直不敢相信自己的眼睛。他找到交易员马特·扎姆斯和公司回购员迈克·雷斯曼，激动地告诉他们这个消息。一位员工皱着眉头说：“我的天哪！”交易员们从未见过这样的行情。没错，1987年和1992年也发生过类似的情况。但长期基金的模型并没有追溯到那么久远的时期。据长期基金所知，这是百年一遇的事件——几乎不可能发生——而且基金对此毫无准备。一位分析师打电话到一位交易员家里，问道：“你想猜猜掉期利差是多少吗？”分析师告诉他后，交易员怒吼道：“去你的——以后别再给我家打电话！”

Krasker couldn’t believe it. He sought out Matt Zames, a trader, and Mike Reisman, the firm’s repo man, and heatedly broke the news. One of the staffers grimaced and said, “Holy shit.” The traders hadn’t seen a move like that—ever. True, it had happened in 1987 and again in 1992. But Long-Term’s models didn’t go back that far. As far as Long-Term knew, it was a once-in-a-lifetime occurrence—a practical impossibility4—and one for which the fund was totally unprepared. One of the analysts called a trader at home and asked, “Would you like to guess where swap spreads are?” When the analyst told him, the trader snapped, “Fuck you—don’t ever call me at home again!”

那个星期五，长期基金（Long-Term）处处亏损。信贷利差急剧扩大。抵押贷款利差飙升至121个基点，而几周前才107个基点。高收益债券利差从269个基点攀升至276个基点。非热门国债利差也从8个基点猛增至13个基点！虽然这些波动从绝对值来看似乎不大，但由于长期基金的高杠杆率和庞大的持仓规模，这些波动对其造成了巨大的影响。

That Friday, Long-Term lost money wherever it looked. Credit spreads simply exploded. Mortgage spreads surged to 121 points, up from 107 only weeks before. High-yield bonds climbed from 269 to 276. Off-the-run Treasurys vaulted from 8 basis points to 13! Though these moves may seem small in absolute terms, the effect on Long-Term was magnified by the fund’s potent level of leverage and its immense position size.

即使在看似毫不相关的市场，长期投资公司也遭受了重创。该公司持有的风险较高的俄罗斯和巴西债券暴跌，跌幅远远超过了其做空的、本应确保其投资安全的俄罗斯和巴西债券。事实上，那天所有市场都出了问题。长期投资公司曾对电信公司Ciena Corporation进行过可疑的投资，该公司当时正计划与Tellabs Inc.合并。即使Ciena的股价已逼近收购价，长期投资公司仍然继续持有。就在8月21日星期五，合并计划被推迟，Ciena的股价暴跌25.50美元，跌至每股31.25美元。长期投资公司损失了1.5亿美元。多年前，罗森菲尔德就曾被警告说，风险套利就像在迎面驶来的推土机前捡镍币一样徒劳无功。最终，他还是尝到了苦头。

Even in seemingly unrelated markets, Long-Term suffered a drubbing. The riskier Russian and Brazilian bonds that Long-Term owned plunged, and by far more than the safer Russian and Brazilian bonds that it had sold short as the hedges that were supposed to have made its bets so safe. In fact, nothing in any market went right that day. Long-Term had dubiously invested in Ciena Corporation, a telecommunications company that was planning to merge with Tellabs Inc., and had continued to hold the stock even when it had crept to within 25 cents of the acquisition price. On that same Friday, August 21, the merger was postponed and Ciena stock plummeted $25.50, to $31.25 a share. Long-Term lost $150 million. Years earlier, Rosenfeld had been warned that risk arbitrage was like picking up nickels in front of oncoming bulldozers. One had finally nipped him.

损失来自四面八方。它们来得如此之快，如此包罗万象，如此出乎意料，以至于合伙人们感到被抛弃了。他们突然失去了控制，仿佛科学之神被撼动，某种看不见的邪恶力量掌控了他们的命运。在格林威治，仅剩的几名员工疯狂地向全球各地打电话，试图联系其他合伙人。维克多·哈加尼当时在意大利，他匆匆赶回伦敦。埃里克·罗森菲尔德刚到爱达荷州的太阳谷，准备和家人一起度过两周的假期。他搭乘红眼航班返回纽约。梅里韦瑟当时在中国。他的合伙人在北京的一次晚宴上找到了他，老板随即搭乘下一班飞机回国。临行前，梅里韦瑟给高盛首席执行官乔恩·科尔津打了电话，高盛是他们主要的长期交易伙伴。梅里韦瑟告诉他：“我们遭受了严重的损失，但我们一切安好。”

The losses came from every corner. They were so swift, so encyclopedic in their breadth, so utterly unexpected that the partners felt abandoned. They had suddenly lost control, as though the gods of science had been dislodged and some unseen diabolical power had taken hold of their fates. In Greenwich, the skeleton crew frantically called around the globe to reach the other partners. Victor Haghani was in Italy; he hurried back to London. Eric Rosenfeld had just arrived in Sun Valley, Idaho, for a two-week vacation with his family. He got a red-eye back to New York. Meriwether was in China. His partners tracked him down at a dinner in Beijing, and the boss took the next flight home. Before he left, J.M. called Jon Corzine, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, a major Long-Term trading partner, at Corzine’s home. “We’ve had a serious markdown,” Meriwether advised him, “but everything is fine with us.”5

但事情并非一帆风顺。长期投资公司（Long-Term）此前经过数学计算，认为单日亏损不太可能超过3500万美元，然而就在8月的那个星期五，该公司却损失了5.53亿美元，相当于其资本的15%。年初时，该公司拥有46.7亿美元的资本，如今却骤降至29亿美元。自4月底以来，其权益已缩水超过三分之一。

But everything was not fine. Long-Term, which had calculated with such mathematical certainty that it was unlikely to lose more than $35 million on any single day, had just dropped $553 million—15 percent of its capital—on that one Friday in August. It had started the year with $4.67 billion. Suddenly, it was down to $2.9 billion. Since the end of April, it had lost more than a third of its equity.

由于一位重要客户遭受如此严重的损失，负责监控信用风险的贝尔斯登高管迈克·艾利克斯（Mike Alix）忧心忡忡，立即致电长期投资公司（Long-Term）的首席财务官罗伯特·舒斯塔克（Robert Shustak）。舒斯塔克耐心地向艾利克斯详细介绍了公司的流动性状况。舒斯塔克的沉着冷静令艾利克斯感到惊讶，在接下来的几周里，艾利克斯经常会想到舒斯塔克和其他合伙人的这种沉着冷静。艾利克斯心想，他们真是老练的扑克玩家。6

Worried by such serious losses to a major client, Mike Alix, the Bear Stearns executive who monitored credit risks, hurriedly called Robert Shustak, Long-Term’s chief financial officer. Shustak patiently went over the firm’s liquidity. Alix was amazed by Shustak’s calm, a thought that was to come to Alix often in the weeks ahead about Shustak and about the other partners. They were true poker players, Alix thought.6

惨败发生两天后，也就是8月23日星期日，合伙人们早上7点聚集在会议室。在玻璃和花岗岩打造的总部大楼外，一座喷泉正对着一座铜制鱼鹰雕塑喷水。仿佛冥冥之中自有预感，梅里韦瑟召来了总法律顾问吉姆·里卡兹，让他为大家提供建议，并记录会议内容。里卡兹曾被莫泽丑闻打得措手不及，他从惨痛的经历中明白，一旦此类事件公之于众，再想寻求建议就为时已晚。从那个星期日开始，每次合伙人开会，里卡兹——这位拥有宾夕法尼亚大学、约翰·霍普金斯大学和纽约大学学位的律师——几乎都会出席。

Two days after the debacle, on Sunday, August 23, the partners assembled in the conference room at 7 A.M. Outside the glass-and-granite headquarters, a fountain spewed jets of water over a sculpture of a copper osprey. As if stricken by a premonition, Meriwether had summoned Jim Rickards, the general counsel, to advise the group and also keep a record of the proceedings. Having been blindsided by the Mozer scandal, J.M. knew from bitter experience that once such matters became public, it was too late to seek advice. From that Sunday on, whenever the partners met, Rickards, a lawyer with degrees from Penn, Johns Hopkins, and New York University, was almost always in attendance.

JM让每位交易员汇报各自的专业领域：希利布兰德负责风险套利，霍金斯负责巴西市场，莫德斯特负责股票市场，哈加尼（从伦敦通过电话）负责英国掉期交易和皇家荷兰/壳牌石油交易。令人不安的是，尽管长期交易看起来稳健可靠，但交易员们表示却无人问津。东京的合伙人也汇报了类似的情况：根本没有买家。7在这种市场环境下，长期交易根本无法在不进一步扰乱市场的情况下退出其庞大的交易。合伙人原本以为其他套利者会意识到他们所看到的价值；但其他套利者却迟迟没有行动，这让他们百思不得其解。8现在，就像那些在遥远的战场上过度投入的将军一样，他们发现自己的退路已被堵死。

J.M. had each trader report on his area of expertise: Hilibrand on risk arb, Hawkins on Brazil, Modest on equities, Haghani (by phone from London) on U.K. swaps and Royal Dutch/Shell. Disturbingly, the traders said there was no demand for Long-Term’s trades, despite their seeming soundness. The Tokyo partners reported a similar story: there simply weren’t any buyers.7 In such a climate, there was no way Long-Term could get out of its humongous trades without moving the markets even more. The partners had assumed that other arbitrageurs would recognize the values that they saw; their failure to step forward mystified them.8 Now, like generals who overcommit to a distant war, they found the road out blocked.

出于本能，梅里韦瑟和其他高级合伙人倾向于采取相同的策略：他们会筹集新的资金，为公司提供缓冲，然后等待交易好转。他们确信价差最终会收敛，就像当年年轻的JM大胆出手拯救埃克斯坦时一样。他早期的英勇事迹几乎完美地指引了JM的职业生涯：价差总会回落。

Instinctively, Meriwether and the other senior partners gravitated toward the same strategy: they would raise fresh capital to give the firm a cushion and wait until its trades turned around. They were certain that spreads would eventually converge, just as they had when a young J.M. had daringly bailed out Eckstein. His early heroics had been an almost faultless guide to J.M.’s career: Spreads always come back.

但由于资本损失，长期基金的杠杆率已高得危险——危险之处在于，杠杆率越高，损失累积速度越快。因此，为了降低风险，合伙人必须出售一些资产。但卖什么呢？投资者只想要风险最低的债券，而长期基金并没有持有任何此类债券。并购套利或许是一个选择。长期基金的交易组合已膨胀至惊人的50亿美元，其中包括花旗集团/旅行者保险公司和MCI/世通公司（后者是MCI与英国电信从未完成的合并的后续）。合伙人认为这些合并大多会成功（事实上也确实如此）。但它们并非该基金投资组合的核心。如果所有合并都像Ciena合并案那样失败，长期基金估计可能会损失超过5亿美元——这在如今已是无法承受的风险。

But owing to its loss of capital, Long-Term’s leverage had become dangerously high—dangerous because losses accumulate faster as leverage increases. Therefore, to reduce their risk, the partners would have to sell something. But what? Investors wanted only the least risky bonds, and Long-Term didn’t own any. One candidate was merger arbitrage. Long-Term’s deal portfolio had mushroomed to a stunning $5 billion worth of merger positions,9 including Citicorp/ Travelers and MCI/WorldCom (the latter a successor to MCI’s never-consummated union with British Telecommunications). The partners thought most of these marriages would go through (as, indeed, they did). But they were hardly central to the fund’s portfolio. And if all of them did collapse, as the Ciena merger had, Long-Term calculated that it could lose more than half a billion dollars—now an intolerable risk.10

就在那个星期天晚上，罗森菲尔德给沃伦·巴菲特打了电话，巴菲特当时正在奥马哈的家中。1991年莫泽丑闻之后，罗森菲尔德曾竭尽全力帮助所罗门兄弟公司渡过危机，并帮助公司重振声誉，这赢得了巴菲特的钦佩。现在，罗森菲尔德认为，没有比巴菲特更适合推销长期投资公司并购组合的人选了。这位亿万富翁喜欢大手笔交易。他以前也做过风险套利。而且，由于交易价差不断扩大，价格也很有吸引力。

That same Sunday night, Rosenfeld called Warren Buffett, reaching him at his home in Omaha. Rosenfeld had won Buffett’s admiration in 1991 after the Mozer scandal, when he had worked diligently to get Salomon past the crisis, helping also to restore its name. Now Rosenfeld figured there was no one better to offer Long-Term’s merger portfolio to than Buffett. The billionaire liked to deal in size. He had done risk arbitrage before. And thanks to widening deal spreads, prices were attractive.

巴菲特认真地听着。但他很快指出，他已经很久没有参与并购套利了，对这方面不太了解。交易告吹。他客气地问是否还有其他需要帮忙的地方。

Buffett listened attentively. But he quickly noted that he hadn’t been involved in merger arbitrage in a while and wasn’t up to speed. No sale. Graciously, he asked if there was anything else he could do.

罗森菲尔德想不出任何办法。11

Rosenfeld couldn’t think of anything.11

第二天，8月24日，合伙人开始四处筹款。凭借他们庞大的人脉网络、辉煌的业绩和卓越的声誉，没有哪个现代的克罗伊斯能难倒他们。格雷格·霍金斯联系了乔治·索罗斯基金的一位朋友，安排了一场早餐会，邀请了梅里韦瑟、索罗斯以及这位亿万富翁的首席策略师斯坦利·德鲁肯米勒。索罗斯是一位来自共产主义匈牙利的狡猾难民，而梅里韦瑟则截然不同。索罗斯的东欧血统从他身上处处流露。他举止正式而拘谨，常常滔滔不绝地发表哲学论述。他看起来像一只上了年纪的猫头鹰。梅里韦瑟则随和、谦逊，带着浓厚的美国中西部口音；他就像街角的州立农场保险公司代理人。他们的投资风格也截然不同。“长期投资”理念认为市场是一个稳定的系统，价格围绕着一个理性均衡的中心点波动。 “我的看法不同，”索罗斯指出。 12这位投机者认为市场是有机的、不可预测的。他认为市场与正在发生的事件相互作用，并反映这些事件。它们绝非僵化或抽象的系统。正如他解释的那样，“认为市场呈现钟形曲线的想法是错误的。总会有一些异常现象，你无法根据以往的经验来预测。”俄罗斯就是一个典型的例子，索罗斯的基金刚刚在那里损失了20亿美元，而俄罗斯正是这样一个“异常现象”，它超出了教授们预测的曲线范围。

The next day, August 24, the partners started dialing for dollars. With their gilt-edged roster of contacts, their brilliant record, their lustrous reputations, no modern Croesus was beyond their reach. Greg Hawkins tapped a friend in George Soros’s fund and set up a breakfast for Meriwether, Soros, and Stanley Druckenmiller, the billionaire’s top strategist. Soros, a wily refugee from Communist Hungary, and Meriwether were as different as could be. Soros’s Eastern European origins oozed from his every pore. Formal and stiff, he had a tendency to launch into philosophical disquisitions. He looked like a graying owl. Meriwether was informal, unpretentious, midwestern; he could have been the State Farm agent down the street. They represented unlike styles in investing, too. Long-Term envisioned markets as stable systems in which prices moved about a central point of rational equilibrium. “I had a different view,” Soros noted.12 The speculator saw markets as organic and unpredictable. He felt they interacted with, and were reflective of, ongoing events. They were hardly sterile or abstract systems. As he explained it, “The idea that you have a bell-shape curve is false. You have outlying phenomena that you can’t anticipate on the basis of previous experience.” Russia, where Soros’s funds had just lost $2 billion, was an example of just such an “outlying phenomenon” that lay outside the professors’ curves.

梅里韦瑟冷静而有力地论证道，长期投资公司的市场将会迅速反弹；对于那些资金雄厚的人来说，机会巨大。索罗斯面无表情地听着，但德鲁肯米勒却连珠炮似地向梅里韦瑟抛出一连串问题。他嗅到了迅速弥补索罗斯在俄罗斯投资损失的机会。随后，索罗斯大胆表示，他愿意在8月底——也就是一周后——投资5亿美元，前提是长期投资公司能够再筹集5亿美元来恢复其资本。

Meriwether argued, calmly but persuasively, that Long-Term’s markets would snap back; for those with deep pockets, the opportunities were great. Soros listened impassively, but Druckenmiller peppered J.M. with questions. He smelled a chance to recoup Soros’s Russian losses in a hurry. Then, Soros boldly said he would be willing to invest $500 million at the end of August—that is, a week later—provided that Long-Term could restore its capital by raising another $500 million in addition.

罗森菲尔德随即联系了摩根大通，这家公司一直渴望与格林威治建立更紧密的联系。摩根大通派出了两个团队——一个精通债券，另一个精通股票——仔细审查了长期投资公司的账簿。从那时起，摩根大通和长期投资公司的人几乎一直在讨论如何挽救长期投资公司的各种头寸。13自然而然地，长期投资公司向摩根大通副董事长罗伯托·门多萨寻求帮助，该公司曾邀请他成为合伙人。尽管门多萨与合伙人关系密切，尤其是与默顿、穆林斯和罗森菲尔德，但他完全不知道长期投资公司正面临严重的困境。罗森菲尔德告诉他：“我们需要一大笔钱。”他的直率让门多萨感到震惊。可以理解的是，这位银行家想了解一些关于长期投资公司投资组合的情况。摩根大通让希利布兰德向门多萨解释一下互换头寸，但谨慎的希利布兰德拒绝了。希利布兰德几乎哽咽着说，他对自己珍贵的投资组合一无所知。他曾如此笃定——他曾如此肆意借贷。如今，他精心构建的世界开始崩塌。个人破产并非不可能。他可能大错特错，这种可能性令他崩溃。

Now Rosenfeld called J. P. Morgan, a firm that long had thirsted for closer ties to Greenwich. The bank sent two teams—one versed in bonds, the other in equities—to comb through Long-Term’s books. From then on, Morgan people and Long-Term people were talking almost constantly about how to salvage various of Long-Term’s positions.13 Naturally, Long-Term turned for help to Roberto Mendoza, the Morgan vice chairman to whom it had offered a partnership. Though close to the partners, especially Merton, Mullins, and Rosenfeld, Mendoza had had no idea that Long-Term was in serious trouble. Rosenfeld told him, “We need a large amount of money.” His bluntness shocked Mendoza. Understandably, the banker wanted to know a little something about Long-Term’s portfolio. J.M. asked Hilibrand to explain the swap position to Mendoza, but the wary Hilibrand refused. Almost in tears, Hilibrand spluttered that he couldn’t say a word about his precious portfolio. He had been so certain—he had borrowed so freely. Now his tightly ordered world was beginning to crack. Personal bankruptcy was not out of the question. The possibility that he had been so wrong was devastating.

但这一次，JM坚持：希利布兰德必须透露一些信息。这位套利交易员不情愿地照做了。合伙人的朋友门多萨信誓旦旦地保证，摩根大通（或其客户）会提供2亿美元。现在，长期投资公司还需要3亿美元；这似乎并不算多。公司律师里卡兹起草了即将完成的交易文件。

But this time, J.M. insisted: Hilibrand would have to disclose a little something. The arbitrageur grudgingly complied. Mendoza, the partners’ friend, loyally promised that Morgan (or its clients) would be good for $200 million. Now Long-Term needed $300 million more; it did not seem so much. Rickards, the house lawyer, drafted papers for an imminent closing.

8月25日星期二，梅里韦瑟又打了两个电话。其中一个是给美林总裁赫伯·艾利森的。通常情况下，两人会聊聊即将到来的沃特维尔之旅，但今年九月的高尔夫周末计划泡汤了。梅里韦瑟透露，该基金的资本已降至27亿美元。他强调，长期基金拥有充足的流动性，流动性确实不是问题——即便他真心实意，这种说法也与该基金不断攀升的杠杆率形成了天真的矛盾。梅里韦瑟仍然相信模型，而模型也仍然发出看涨信号。

On Tuesday, August 25, Meriwether made two more calls. One was to Herb Allison, the Merrill president. Ordinarily, the two would have been chatting about the upcoming trip to Waterville, but this September there would be no golf weekend. J.M. disclosed that the fund’s capital had fallen to $2.7 billion. He stressed that Long-Term had plenty of liquidity and, indeed, that liquidity wasn’t an issue—an assertion that, even if sincere, was naively at odds with the fund’s escalating leverage. J.M. still believed in the models, and the models were still flashing bullish signals.

不过，JM指出，长期基金月底必须向投资者报告亏损；如果能向他们证明有新的资金流入，他会感觉好一些。他话锋一转，强调现在投资的绝佳机会。他抛出杀手锏，暗示一位大投资者——艾莉森猜测他指的是索罗斯——已经入场。或许美林也想加入，在八月底前投入三到五亿美元？艾莉森虽然很欣赏梅里韦瑟，但觉得这个邀请有点奇怪。一周之内要筹集这么多钱，实在有点不合时宜。

Nonetheless, J.M. noted, Long-Term would have to report its losses to investors at the end of the month; he would feel better if he could show them that new money was coming in. Smoothly switching gears, he emphasized the splendid opportunity for anyone who invested now. Playing his trump card, he implied that a big investor—Allison guessed he meant Soros—was already in. Perhaps Merrill would like to join him and commit, say, $300 million to $500 million before the end of August? Though fond of Meriwether, Allison thought it was a curious invitation. It was a lot of money to be wanting in a week.

当天，JM 还给 Travelers（Salomon Smith Barney 的母公司）的 Jamie Dimon 打了个电话。他建议，与其让两家公司通过清算套利交易而互相消耗殆尽，不如将长期基金的投资组合与 Salomon 套利集团剩余的资产合并，共同管理。从某种意义上说，这是回归母公司。JM 的几位合伙人也给 Salomon 打了电话，向老朋友们寻求资金。他们说，该基金需要 10 亿美元，但进展顺利。

J.M.’s other call that day was to Jamie Dimon at Travelers, the parent of Salomon Smith Barney. Instead of the two firms pecking each other to death by liquidating arbitrage trades, he suggested, why not unite Long-Term’s portfolio with what was left of Salomon’s Arbitrage Group and manage them together? Going back to the mother firm, in a sense. A couple of J.M.’s partners called Salomon, too, soliciting their old friends for capital. They said that the fund needed $1 billion but was well on the way toward getting it.

但长期基金的处境每况愈下，非但没有好转，反而每况愈下。市场对该基金的态度持续恶化。8月26日星期一，抵押贷款利差上涨了4个点，星期二又上涨了6个点，星期三又上涨了3个点。高收益债券利差更是飙升了25个点。每一次利差的波动，都让长期基金原本充裕的资金迅速流失——该公司亏损的速度远远超过了其筹集资金的速度。面对持续不断的亏损，交易员们惊愕不已，却又无能为力，如同身处屠杀中的步兵一般茫然无措。“这太诡异了，”其中一位交易员说道，“我们每天都遭受巨额亏损，而且亏损丝毫没有停止的迹象。”该公司正在经历一场严重的资金流失。

But Long-Term was losing ground, not gaining it. Markets were steadily turning on the fund. Mortgage spreads jumped an additional 4 points that Monday, 6 more on Tuesday, and 3 more on Wednesday, August 26. High-yield spreads blew out another 25 points. With each tick, more of Long-Term’s once abundant capital drained away—the firm was losing money faster than it could raise it. Stunned by the unceasing losses and helpless to do anything about them, its traders were becoming dazed, like infantry in a slaughter. “It was bizarre,” one of them said. “Day after day we had massive losses, and they didn’t stop.” The firm was hemorrhaging.

Long-Term 知道它必须减持仓位，但它做不到——在市场承压的情况下。尽管衍生品市场被大肆宣传增长，但信贷市场却缺乏流动性。当所有人都想同时抛售时，流动性总是匮乏的。这正是模型所忽略的。当损失不断扩大时，像 Long-Term 这样的杠杆投资者将被迫抛售，否则损失将压垮他们。当一家公司不得不在没有买家的市场中出售时，价格就会超出正态分布曲线，达到极端水平。仅举一例，新闻集团债券的收益率此前一直比美国国债高出 110 个基点，但令人匪夷所思的是，尽管该公司前景丝毫未变，其收益率却飙升至高出 180 个基点。从长远来看，这样的利差或许显得荒谬。但对于高杠杆投资者而言，长远眼光并非总是唾手可得；他们或许无法撑到那时。

Long-Term knew it had to reduce its positions, but it couldn’t—not with markets under stress. Despite the ballyhooed growth in derivatives, there was no liquidity in credit markets. There never is when everyone wants out at the same time. This is what the models had missed. When losses mount, leveraged investors such as Long-Ter m are forced to sell, lest their losses overwhelm them. When a firm has to sell in a market without buyers, prices run to the extremes beyond the bell curve.
