To take just one example, yields on News Corporation bonds, which had recently been trading at 110 points over Treasurys, bizarrely soared to 180 over, even though the company’s prospects had not changed one iota. In the long run, such a spread might seem absurd. But long-term thinking is a luxury not always available to the highly leveraged; they may not survive that long.

八月底通常是市场淡季，但今年八月，债券市场的交易几乎完全停滞。新债券发行市场彻底枯竭。原定的新发行计划被突然撤回，这倒也好，因为根本没人买。小型投资者、跟风者、时髦的对冲基金、套利新手以及规模较小的欧洲交易员纷纷退出价差交易业务或撤回资金。14

The end of August is always a slow time in markets, but this August, trading in bond markets all but vanished. The market for new bond issues simply dried up. Scheduled new offerings were abruptly withdrawn, which was just as well, because there was no one to buy them. The lesser investors, the copycats, the fashionable hedge funds, the newcomers to arbitrage, and the smaller, European-based traders were quitting the spread-trading business or withdrawing their capital from it in droves.14

由于担心客户损失不断增加，银行最终收紧了对冲基金的信贷额度。信孚银行的对冲基金经理史蒂夫·弗雷德海姆收到了追加保证金通知。他的贷款经纪人态度大变。之前他们还源源不断地给他提供资金，现在却要求他追加保证金。弗雷德海姆眼睁睁地看着自己持有的债券价值跌破了抵押贷款的价值，感到十分恐惧。由于很多债券都卖不出去，弗雷德海姆只好抛售其他信贷产品——巴西、土耳其、泰国的债券、美国抵押贷款证券、高收益债券等等。卖什么并不重要，重要的是他必须卖掉一些东西。在这样的时刻，资本自然会从风险较高的资产流向风险较低的资产，而不管这些资产本身的价值如何。弗雷德海姆的行为在某种程度上促成了这种流动。华尔街成千上万个像弗雷德海姆一样的人，他们的行为叠加起来，最终酿成了一场自我实现的预言，正如默顿的父亲——“自我实现的预言”一词的创造者——所预言的那样。随着价格下跌，银行纷纷撤离对冲基金。而随着银行撤离，对冲基金不得不继续抛售。

Wary of their clients’ mounting losses, banks were finally tightening their credit lines to hedge funds. Steve Freidheim, the hedge fund manager at Bankers Trust, was getting margin calls. His loan brokers had changed their tune. Once they had shoveled money at him; now they were demanding more margin. Freidheim watched in horror as the value of his bonds sank beneath the value of the loans against them. Since many of his bonds were unsalable, Freidheim sold other credits—Brazil, Turkey, Thailand, U.S. mortgage securities, highyield bonds. It didn’t matter what he sold; the point was, he had to sell something. At such a time, capital naturally flows from riskier assets to less risky ones, irrespective of their underlying value. To a tiny degree, Freidheim’s own actions made it do so. Multiplied by a thousand other Freidheims all over Wall Street, the crisis of fear became a self-fulfilling prophecy, just as Merton’s father, who had coined the phrase, had theorized. As prices fell, banks backed away from hedge funds. And as banks backed away, hedge funds had to keep selling.

桑迪·韦尔非但没有想与长期投资公司或其他任何公司合作进行套利，反而指示手下降低对冲基金的投资比例。即便所罗门兄弟公司自身的交易员都在抛售资产，该公司也因债券套利和俄罗斯市场的损失而遭受重创。据说韦尔曾命令手下将与所罗门兄弟公司有业务往来的对冲基金数量从500家减少到20家！韦尔的好友沃伦·巴菲特密切关注着他的团队，要求详细了解伯克希尔·哈撒韦公司对冲基金的投资情况。巴菲特在经济形势严峻时会本能地收紧公司现金储备，他想知道伯克希尔旗下的保险子公司在互换交易中是否持有足够的抵押品。

Sandy Weill, far from wanting to partner with Long-Term or anyone else in arbitrage, was telling his troops to lower their exposure to hedge funds. Even as its own traders were liquidating assets, Salomon was reeling from losses in bond arbitrage as well as in Russia. Weill is said to have ordered his minions to reduce the number of hedge funds doing business with Salomon from five hundred to twenty! Weill’s buddy Warren Buffett was monitoring his people, demanding to hear, in very detailed terms, about Berkshire Hathaway’s exposure to hedge funds. Buffett, who instinctively tightened his grip on his company’s cash when times got tough, wanted to know if a Berkshire insurance subsidiary was holding adequate collateral on swap trades.15

高盛对其在互换交易中的风险敞口感到担忧，尤其是与长期投资公司（Long-Term）的交易。科尔津（Corzine）被梅里韦瑟（Meriwether）从中国打来的电话吓了一跳，回拨给梅里韦瑟后，他警告说：“我们没有得到足够的反馈。这可能会损害你的信用评级。”高盛试图从这家一向守口如瓶的对冲基金那里套取信息，但长期投资公司仍然不愿透露。它试图维持现状。但该公司已不再有足够的资金随意发号施令。在高盛和其他银行的压力下，长期投资公司的持仓情况正逐渐泄露。

Goldman Sachs was nervous about its exposure to swaps, particularly with Long-Term. When Corzine, who had been jarred by J.M.’s call from China, called Meriwether back, he warned him, “We aren’t getting adequate feedback. It could hurt your credit standing.” Goldman was trying to pry information loose from the always tight-lipped hedge fund, but Long-Term was still reluctant to share information. It was trying to operate on a business-as-usual basis. But the firm no longer had the capital to dictate terms willy-nilly. Under pressure from Goldman and other banks, knowledge of Long-Term’s positions was slowly leaking out.

现在是8月26日星期三，梅里尔的艾莉森打电话来说没戏了。艾莉森仍然一头雾水，她补充道：“约翰，我不确定筹款对你有没有好处。这可能会让人觉得你遇到了麻烦！”

Now it was Wednesday, August 26, and Merrill’s Allison called to say no dice. Still in the dark, Allison added, “John, I’m not sure it’s in your interest to raise the money. It might look like you’re having a problem!”

索罗斯设定的最后期限还有五天，而市场消息依然糟糕。股票波动率又上升了两个百分点，达到29%。拉丁美洲债券走弱。更不祥的是，西方银行开始承认在前苏联地区遭受损失。瑞士信贷第一波士顿银行和纽约共和国民银行，这两家曾是新资本主义俄罗斯的狂热拥护者，都披露了在俄罗斯的巨额亏损。一家名为“高风险机会基金”（High Risk Opportunities Fund）的卢布债券热门投资者，由位于佛罗里达州西棕榈滩的III Offshore Advisors公司管理，该基金损失惨重。纽约联邦储备银行行长威廉·麦克唐纳匆忙取消了前往怀俄明州杰克逊霍尔的行程，美联储原本计划在那里举行一年一度的夏末休会。熊市肆虐，麦克唐纳无暇顾及其他。

Soros’s deadline was five days off, and the market news continued to be bad. Equity volatility notched up two more points, to 29 percent. Bonds in Latin America weakened. Ominously, Western banks started admitting to losses of their own in the former Soviet Union. Credit Suisse First Boston and Republic National Bank of New York, both heady champions of the new capitalist Russia, disclosed huge losses there. A trendy investor in ruble debt, the appropriately named High Risk Opportunities Fund, run by III Offshore Advisors of West Palm Beach, Florida, was wiped out. William McDonough, president of the New York Fed, hurriedly canceled his trip to Jackson Hole, Wyoming, where the Fed was holding its annual late-summer retreat. With bears on the prowl, McDonough had no time for moose.

越来越绝望的梅里韦瑟和罗森菲尔德再次致电巴菲特。 16一些合伙人始终无法原谅巴菲特，因为在他们看来，巴菲特当年把梅里韦瑟赶出了所罗门兄弟公司。他们反感这位平易近人的亿万富翁喜欢说教，尤其反感他喜欢对学院派模型嗤之以鼻，而他自己则坚持简单的买入并持有普通股的策略。 17正如我们所见，长期投资公司的合伙人甚至做空了伯克希尔哈撒韦公司，结果在套利交易中损失了约1.5亿美元。但巴菲特和这些合伙人仍然互相尊重，认为他们都是才华横溢的投资人，尽管他们的投资理念不同。而现在，长期投资公司急需资金，在美国，除了比尔·盖茨之外，没有人比巴菲特更有钱。

Increasingly desperate, Meriwether and Rosenfeld placed another call to Buffett.16 Some of the partners had never forgiven Buffett for, in their eyes, riding Meriwether out of Salomon. They resented the folksy billionaire’s tendency to preach, particularly since he liked to heap disdain on academic models, which he eschewed in favor of his simple buy-and-hold approach to common stocks.17 As we have seen, Long-Term’s partners had even shorted Berkshire, an arbitrage on which they had lost about $150 million. But Buffett and the partners still respected each other as talented investors, albeit from different schools. And now Long-Term needed money, and no one in America save for Bill Gates had more of it than Buffett.

巴菲特同意会见希利布兰德，后者于8月27日星期四飞往奥马哈。此时，该公司的资本已缩水至25亿美元。当天早晨的《纽约时报》评论道：“此次市场动荡堪比记忆中最惨痛的金融危机。” 18希利布兰德登机时，他已得知东京股市下跌了3%，跌至12年来的最低点。日本财务大臣宫泽喜一表示：“最基本的一点就是不要恐慌。” 19当天，俄罗斯股市下跌了17%，较年初水平暴跌了84%。事实上，全球股市都在暴跌：伦敦下跌3%，西班牙下跌6%，巴西下跌10%。

Buffett agreed to see Hilibrand, who flew out to Omaha on Thursday, August 27. By now, the firm’s capital was down to $2.5 billion. The morning’s New York Times intoned, “The market turmoil is being compared to the most painful financial disasters in memory.”18 By the time Hilibrand was airborne, he knew that stocks in Tokyo had fallen 3 percent, to a twelve-year low. “The most basic thing is not to panic,” Kiichi Miyazawa, Japan’s minister of finance, observed.19 That day, Russian stock prices would fall 17 percent, leaving them a cool 84 percent below their level at the start of the year. In fact, markets around the world were plunging: London fell 3 percent, Spain 6 percent, Brazil 10 percent.

美国股市与全球股市同步下跌。道琼斯指数下跌357点，跌幅达4%。受全球经济衰退担忧的影响，大宗商品价格暴跌至21年来的最低点。第二天，《华尔街日报》称之为“全球追加保证金通知”。每个人都想拿回自己的钱。由于在俄罗斯的愚蠢投机中遭受损失，投资者对任何形式的风险都避之不及，即使是合理的风险也不例外。长期国债收益率跌至5.35%，创下林登·约翰逊总统任期以来的最低水平。由世界蓝筹股福特汽车公司发行的A级债券收益率飙升至比国债高出115个百分点，尽管福特的债券安全性并不比4月份低，当时其利差仅为60个百分点。投资者追求的是安全；更重要的是，他们想要的是更安全的债券所带来的安心感，无论价格如何。

America’s markets fell in sync with the world’s. The Dow dropped 357 points, or 4 percent. Commodity prices, shuddering from fear of a world recession, touched a twenty-one-year low. The next day’s Wall Street Journal would call it a “global margin call.”20 Everyone wanted his money back. Burned by foolish speculation in Russia, investors were rejecting risk in any guise, even reasonable risk. Yields on long-term Treasurys fell to 5.35 percent, the lowest since Lyndon Johnson was president. Yields on single-A credits—issued by the blue-chip Ford Motors of the world—soared to 115 over Treasurys, though Ford was no less safe a credit than in April, when it had traded at a spread of only 60. Investors wanted safety; moreover, they wanted the peace of mind that safer bonds delivered, no matter the price.

巴菲特周四在机场接了希利布兰德，并护送他回到自己的办公室。办公室位于街对面一家披萨店旁一栋浅色高层建筑里，是一间朴素的套房。希利布兰德一如既往地沉着冷静。他坦诚地谈到了长期基金的亏损，但情绪完全控制住了自己。巴菲特并没有觉得他很绝望。这位套利交易员详细地分析了他那支损失惨重的投资组合。希利布兰德强调，他看到了基金未来的巨大潜力——考虑到他个人的债务，他别无选择。但希利布兰德说，长期基金急需资金，因此他提出将基金的通常费用减半。

Buffett met Hilibrand at the airport that Thursday and escorted him back to his office, a modest suite in a pale high-rise across the street from a pizzeria. Hilibrand was his usual methodical self. He was candid about Long-Term’s losses but totally controlled. He did not strike Buffett as desperate. The arbitrageur went over his battered portfolio in detail. Hilibrand stressed that he saw great potential going forward—given his personal debts, he had little choice. But Long-Term was in a hurry to raise money, Hilibrand said, and thus he offered to cut the fund’s usual fee in half.

这对于巴菲特来说远远不够。在他看来，长期投资公司的费用本来就太高了。21 总之，至少目前来说，他对此兴趣不大。巴菲特道谢，但表示不用了。

This was hardly enough for Buffett. In his opinion, Long-Term’s fees had been too high as they were.21 In any case, he had little interest, at least for now. Buffett said thanks, but no thanks.

希利布兰德离开后给格林威治打电话，消息更加糟糕。该基金周四亏损了2.77亿美元——这是其历史上第二糟糕的单日亏损。其资本缩水至22亿美元。四年来，格林威治的智囊团赚钱的速度无人能及。如今，就像电影倒带揭示出意想不到的恐怖情节一样，他们的亏损速度也快得惊人。然而，不可思议的事情发生了。第二天，8月28日星期五，长期基金实现了盈利。信用利差收窄，基金资本增加了1.28亿美元——这是几个月来首次出现大幅增长。合伙人们心中燃起了一丝希望，期盼已久的转机终于到来了。

When Hilibrand left and called Greenwich, the news was even worse. The fund had lost $277 million Thursday—its second worst day ever. Its capital was down to $2.2 billion. For four years, the brain trust in Greenwich had made money faster than anyone else. Now, like a movie that reveals an unsuspected horror on rewind, they were losing it incomparably faster. And then the unthinkable happened. On the next day, Friday, August 28, Long-Term earned a profit. Credit spreads narrowed, and the fund’s capital rose by $128 million—its first substantial up day in months. The partners nourished a tiny hope that the long-awaited turn was at hand.

除了基金本身，合伙人还有另一个亟待解决的难题：他们个人拥有的管理公司LTCM正面临严重的现金流问题。LTCM共欠多家银行——富利银行、里昂信贷银行、大通曼哈顿银行和劳埃德银行——1.65亿美元。到了8月底，各家银行，尤其是富利银行，纷纷表示该基金业绩不佳已构成违约，因此银行有权要求偿还债务。但管理公司却无力偿还——大部分资金都已投入基金，以提高合伙人的投资回报。实际上，管理公司已濒临破产。如果这一事实公之于众，公司和基金都可能陷入恶性循环。

But the partners had another worry, aside from the fund, that required fast attention: LTCM, their personally owned management company, was facing serious cash flow problems. LTCM owed a total of $165 million to a group of banks—Fleet, Crédit Lyonnais, Chase Manhattan, and Lloyds. By late August, the banks, especially Fleet, were screaming that the fund’s poor performance constituted an event of default and that, therefore, the banks were entitled to demand repayment. But the management company didn’t have the cash—most of the money had been poured into the fund to heighten the partners’ investment. Effectively, the management company was close to being insolvent. If that fact became public, both the firm and the fund could face a debilitating spiral.

包括汉斯·胡夫施密德在内的一些合伙人，由于担心个人债务，认为长期资本管理公司（LTCM）应该出售部分基金股份来偿还银行贷款。但律师里卡兹正确地警告说，如果内部人士现在套现，而外部投资者却别无选择，那么日后可能会造成非常糟糕的后果。梅里韦瑟不想再次受到美国证券交易委员会的谴责，因此同意了里卡兹的建议。此外，他也意识到，如果合伙人都套现，他几乎不可能再向其他人寻求新的投资。无论结果如何，合伙人的资金都必须留在基金中。

Some of the partners, including Hans Hufschmid, who was worried about his personal debt, thought LTCM should simply sell some of its stake in the fund and pay off the banks. But Rickards, the lawyer, properly warned that if insiders took out money now, when the outside investors had no such option, it could look very bad later. Meriwether, who did not want a second censure from the SEC, agreed. Moreover, he realized that he could scarcely ask others for new investment if the partners were cashing out. For better or worse, the partners’ money would have to stay in the fund.

而且，该基金（与长期资本管理公司LTCM不同）也面临现金流问题。随着八月的临近尾声，基金的清算经纪商贝尔斯登给合伙人施加了压力，后者正密切关注着长期基金的股权下跌。由于希利布兰德强硬的谈判策略，该基金和贝尔斯登从未签署过任何协议，这意味着贝尔斯登可以随时停止为其清算交易。因此，希利布兰德的策略适得其反，长期基金现在完全受制于贝尔斯登。

And the fund (as distinct from LTCM) had cash flow worries, too. As August trickled away, the partners were feeling pressure from Bear Stearns, the fund’s clearing broker, which was nervously eyeing the drop in Long-Term’s equity. Thanks to Hilibrand’s hardball negotiating tactics, the fund and Bear had never signed an agreement, meaning that Bear was free to stop clearing its trades whenever it pleased. Thus, Hilibrand’s tactics had misfired, for Long-Term now was at Bear’s mercy.

释放现金的一种策略是将长期基金在不同银行进行的交易进行配对。由于没有哪家银行掌握全部信息，因此没有一家银行意识到其大部分交易都进行了对冲，并且彼此相互抵消；因此，每家银行都要求比正常情况下更高的保证金。长期基金试图将这些成对的交易转移到同一家银行，但这项工作极其繁重：该基金竟然持有多达六万个独立头寸。22

One strategy for freeing cash was to pair the trades that Long-Term had done with separate banks. Because none of its banks had the whole picture, none saw that most of its trades were hedged and tended to offset one another; therefore, each was demanding more margin than it otherwise would have. Long-Term was trying to move pairs of trades to the same house, but the job was overwhelming: the fund had a mind-boggling sixty thousand individual positions.22

长期基金早前的谨慎反而成了累赘（如果不是希利布兰德之前坚持对银行隐瞒交易情况，配对交易的问题根本不会出现）。基金鼎盛时期，希利布兰德和其他交易员可以肆无忌惮地保密甚至傲慢，但如今，他们沾沾自喜的优越感却让他们自食其果。长期基金不得不向那些被他们得罪的银行请求宽大处理。合伙人们也饱受折磨，因为他们不顾酋长的强烈反对，将27亿美元返还给了投资者。更糟糕的是，他们竟然强迫投资者接受了这笔钱！这笔钱本可以解决他们的问题，但投资者们自然不再对长期基金抱有好感，也不会主动要求追加投资。此外，许多银行自身也面临着巨大的压力。这是一个永恒的讽刺：当你最需要钱的时候，最有可能的资金来源（就 Long-Term 而言，指的是索罗斯等其他投资者，以及投资银行和机构）可能也正处于困境。

Long-Term’s earlier diffidence had become a liability (the problem of pairing trades wouldn’t have arisen but for Hilibrand’s earlier insistence on keeping banks in the dark). Hilibrand and the other traders had gotten away with being secretive and even arrogant when the fund was on top, but now their smug superiority was coming back to haunt them. Long-Term was having to plead for leniency to the very banks that it had offended. And the partners were tortured by the memory of having returned—despite the Sheik’s strenuous objections—$2.7 billion to investors. Worse, they had forced their investors to take it! That money would have solved their problems, but of course, the investors were no longer enamored of Long-Term, nor were they begging to reinvest. What’s more, many of the banks were themselves under stress. This is a timeless irony: when you need money most, the most likely sources of it (in Long-Term’s case, other operators such as Soros, as well as investment banks and institutions) are likely to be hurting as well.

合伙人开始意识到他们可能无法挺过去。他们精心打造的风险管理实验，更不用说他们获得的巨额利润，都面临着崩溃的危险。“八月底的时候，我们真是走投无路了，”罗森菲尔德承认道。他们的语气变得难以置信，并为让自己陷入如此不必要的羞辱而感到痛苦。他们如此富有，不应该陷入如此困境。新加入的合伙人莫德斯特哀叹，他的合伙关系几乎一文不值。

The partners began to sense that they might not make it. Their exquisitely wrought experiment in risk management, to say nothing of their fabulous profits, was in danger of unraveling. “We were desperate at the end of August,” Rosenfeld admitted. Their tone changed to disbelief and bitterness at having left themselves exposed to such needless humiliation. They were much too rich to have gotten into so much trouble. Modest, the newest partner, lamented that his partnership was virtually worthless.

为了避免个人资产受到长期投资公司困境的影响，合伙人们竭力采取措施，这进一步表明他们日益绝望。希利布兰德曾身价五亿美元，如今却用妻子的支票账户支付他那座奢华新宅的装修费用。梅里韦瑟则悄悄地采取措施，以躲避债主的追讨。他将自己唯一的房产——位于加州高档住宅区圆石滩的一块二十英亩的土地——过户给了妻子（他在威彻斯特的房产已经登记在米米名下）。23

In another sign of their growing desperation, the partners scrambled to keep their personal assets from being contaminated by Long-Term’s troubles. Hilibrand, once worth half a billion dollars, was paying for the work on his extravagant new mansion out of his wife’s checking account. Meriwether quietly maneuvered to protect himself from the nauseating specter of creditors. He signed over his only real estate property—a twenty-acre lot in tony Pebble Beach, California—to his wife (his Westchester estate was already in Mimi’s name).23

急需搭车的梅里韦瑟给老朋友文尼·马托内打了个电话，马托内曾是该基金在贝尔斯登的首位联系人。马托内已经退休，与JM那些优雅的教授们截然不同。他戴着金项链和小指戒指，穿着一件敞开胸口的黑色丝绸衬衫出现在长期基金的办公室。他看起来好像有三百磅重。与JM那些古怪僵硬的合伙人不同，马托内认为市场是极其人性化的机构——本质上就充满波动性，而且永远都会犯错。

Badly in need of a lift, Meriwether called an old friend, Vinny Mattone, who had been the fund’s first contact at Bear Stearns. Mattone, who had retired, was everything that J.M.’s elegant professors were not. He wore a gold chain and a pinkie ring, and he showed up at Long-Term in a black silk shirt, open at the chest. He looked as if he weighed three hundred pounds. Unlike J.M.’s strangely wooden partners, Mattone saw markets as exquisitely human institutions—inherently volatile, ever-fallible.

“你在哪里？”马托内直截了当地问道。

“Where are you?” Mattone asked bluntly.

“我们落后一半，”梅里韦瑟说。

“We’re down by half,” Meriwether said.

“你完了，”马托内回答道，仿佛这个结论无需解释。

“You’re finished,” Mattone replied, as if this conclusion needed no explanation.

梅里韦瑟第一次流露出担忧之情。“你在说什么？我们还有20亿。我们有一半——我们有索罗斯。”

For the first time, Meriwether sounded worried. “What are you talking about? We still have two billion. We have half—we have Soros.”

马托内苦笑了一下。“当你亏损一半的时候，人们会觉得你会一直亏损下去。他们会想方设法让市场对你不利。他们不会帮你展期（再融资）。你完了。 ”

Mattone smiled sadly. “When you’re down by half, people figure you can go down all the way. They’re going to push the market against you. They’re not going to roll [refinance] your trades. You’re finished.”

马托内来访后不久，梅里韦瑟和麦肯蒂去了一家当地小酒馆，这家酒馆是JM和其他一些从华尔街搬来的人士常去的地方。梅里韦瑟一边啜饮着他招牌的金汤力，一边看着他的朋友，用极其平淡的语气说道：“你是对的。”酋长看着他。“我真应该听你的，”JM说道。

Not long after Mattone’s visit, Meriwether and McEntee went for a drink at a local inn favored by J.M. and other transplanted Wall Streeters. Sipping his trademark gin and tonic, Meriwether looked at his pal and said in a voice that was completely flat, “You were right.” The Sheik looked at him. “I should have listened to you,” J.M. said.

后来，外人会评论这个团队是如何勉强维持下去的，但这却是他们唯一能接受的选择。他们的困境越深，合伙人就越不想与其他人合作，也越发团结一致。他们暂时压抑着怨恨和厌恶，避免互相指责和推卸责任。他们神情严肃而坚定，黎明即至办公室，一直工作到深夜，仿佛他们的存在本身就能止住亏损。他们连续几个小时打电话，试图清算交易，安抚老投资者，拉拢新投资者，抵御银行家的骚扰。罗森菲尔德和利希努力鼓舞士气。他们告诉员工：“我们会没事的。我们流动资金充足。我们正在筹集新资金。我们只需要缩小规模——我们承担的风险太大了。”合伙人们不断地躲进会议室，总是拉上窗帘，阻挡外界的窥探，秘密地讨论他们的问题。他们的会议似乎永无止境。他们离开时，可能有员工恳求透露一些消息。但合伙人几乎不予回应，甚至对自己的员工也不理睬。一向神经紧绷的希利布兰德则径直走过，仿佛没听见似的。

Outsiders would later comment on how the group held together, but it was their only palatable choice. The deeper their fix, the less the partners wanted to be with anyone else and the more they closed ranks. They suppressed, for the moment, their resentments and bitter dislikes; they avoided recriminations and blame. Grim and determined, they got to the office at dawn and worked late into night, as if their physical presence alone could stop the hemorrhaging. They stayed on the phone for hours, trying to liquidate trades, stroking old investors, seducing new ones, fending off bankers. Rosenfeld and Leahy tried to keep up morale. They told the staff, “We’re going to be fine. We have a lot of liquidity. We’re raising new money. We just have to be smaller—we have too much risk.” The partners continually retreated to the conference room, always with the curtains drawn to block out prying eyes, to hash out their problems in secret. Their meetings seemed endless. When they exited, a staffer might plead for a bit of news. But the partners barely responded, not even to their own employees. The tightly wound Hilibrand would brush right by as though he didn’t hear.

到了八月最后一个周末，长期基金距离满足索罗斯的条件比以往任何时候都更加遥远，而华尔街几乎所有有权开支票的人都已外出度假。长期基金连续数周每天都损失数千万甚至数亿美元，直到周五终于迎来了一次上涨。尽管希望渺茫，梅里韦瑟还是再次拨打了电话。

By the final weekend in August, Long-Term was further than ever from meeting Soros’s terms, and most everybody on Wall Street who had the power to write a check was out of town for the end of summer. Long-Term had lost scores of millions or hundreds of millions of dollars day after day, every single day for weeks—until, finally, it had enjoyed that single up day on Friday. Still hoping against hope, Meriwether made yet another round of calls.

其中一通电话打给了美林证券的丹·那不勒斯，问他觉得什么时候才能止血——好像那不勒斯或者其他任何人能知道似的。然后，JM又给西西里亚诺打了电话，联系上了瑞银在东京的经理。

One was to Merrill’s Dan Napoli, to ask when Napoli thought the bleeding would stop—as if Napoli or anyone else could know. Then J.M. called Siciliano, reaching the UBS manager in Tokyo.

“你们银行有人想投资吗？”梅里韦瑟问道。“这些交易定价错误。我们认为这是一个绝佳的机会。”JM沉着冷静地补充说，长期投资公司相信他们已经基本敲定了高达10亿美元的新资金。

“Does anyone in your bank want to invest?” Meriwether queried. “These trades are mispriced. We think we have a tremendous opportunity.” Keeping his composure, J.M. added that Long-Term believed it had up to $1 billion in other new money virtually sewed up.

不过，瑞银已经是长期投资公司最大的投资者了。“你们肯定亏损了25%。”西西里亚诺说道。

UBS, though, was already Long-Term’s biggest investor. “You must be down twenty-five percent,” Siciliano said.

JM冷冷地回答说：“更像是百分之四十五。”

J.M. replied coolly, “More like forty-five percent.”

西西里亚诺惊呆了。他想知道谁会愿意冒着风险投入第一笔十亿。他知道那个人肯定不是他。

Siciliano was stunned. He wondered who would want to risk putting in the first billion. He knew it wouldn’t be he.

8月29日星期六，梅里韦瑟给埃德森·米切尔打了电话。米切尔是美林证券的银行家，曾于1993年主导了长期基金的首次募资活动。此后，米切尔搬到了伦敦，为德意志银行创办全球债券业务。米切尔和德意志银行现在能为长期基金筹集资金吗？

On Saturday, August 29, Meriwether called Edson Mitchell, the Merrill Lynch banker who had spearheaded Long-Term’s maiden fund-raising effort in 1993. Mitchell had since moved to London to launch a global bond business for Deutsche Bank. Could Mitchell and Deutsche raise capital for Long-Term now?

米切尔说这不太可能。

Mitchell said it was unlikely.

梅里韦瑟的朋友越来越少了。当你需要钱的时候，华尔街是个冷酷无情的地方。

Meriwether was running out of friends. When you need money, Wall Street is a heartless place.

8月31日星期一，随着月底的临近，香港金融管理局（金管局）突然停止了对市场的支撑。此前一直在购买本地股票的金融安全网再次暴露出其漏洞。本地股市暴跌7%，引发了华尔街的抛售潮。道琼斯指数暴跌512点，跌幅达6%，平均跌至7539点。自7月中旬以来，该指数已累计下跌19%。刚从阿拉斯加捕捞鲑鱼归来的鲁宾部长试图通过宣称美国经济“稳健”来安抚市场。但这反而加深了人们对股市崩盘原因的疑惑，因为没有任何单一消息可以解释此次崩盘。《华尔街日报》引用了“令人失望的芝加哥采购经理人指数”，这种解释几乎荒谬可笑。该报更接近真相的是这样一条评论：“从边际角度来看，没有新增买家。” 24实体经济确实稳健，但金融市场杠杆过高，过度扩张。整个华尔街都失去了信心。默顿模型中那些冷静、不带感情色彩的交易员已经不复存在，即便他们曾经存在过。如今，他们陷入了彻底的恐慌。

On Monday, August 31, as the month ran out, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, which had been buying shares of local stocks, suddenly stopped supporting the market. Yet another safety net had been exposed as porous. The local bourse tumbled 7 percent, triggering a run on Wall Street. The Dow crashed 512 points, a 6 percent plunge that took the average down to 7,539. It had fallen 19 percent since mid-July. Secretary Rubin, back from salmon fishing in Alaska, tried to calm markets by declaring that the U.S. economy was “sound.” This merely deepened the mystery of the crash, for no one piece of news was responsible. The Wall Street Journal cited a “disappointing Chicago purchasing managers index,” an almost comically trivial explanation. The paper was closer to the truth when it noted, “On the margin, there is no incremental buyer.”24 The Main Street economy was sound, but financial markets were overleveraged and overextended. The entire Street had lost its nerve. The cool, unemotional traders of Merton’s models no longer existed, if they ever had. Now they were in full-fledged panic.

长期投资市场遭受的打击十分严重。股票波动率突破30%。国债收益率下降，信用利差进一步扩大。投资级债券的利差在那一天暴涨，从133点飙升至162点！事实上，如此巨大的利差只能通过估算得出，因为当天债券市场几乎没有任何交易。债券市场实际上已经关闭；没有人能够平仓，或者即使平仓，也会遭受惨重的损失。仿佛一颗炸弹击中了目标；交易员们盯着屏幕，屏幕却一片空白。买家踪迹全无。“8月31日是特殊的一天，”瑞士信贷第一波士顿的债券策略师柯蒂斯·尚博格表示，“交易的债券少得可怜，你只能靠猜测来判断它们在哪里。”对于一只必须减轻负担的基金来说，这个月以最可怕的债券市场景象告终：债券市场完全停滞。

The damage in Long-Term’s markets was acute. Equity volatility broke above 30 percent. Yields on Treasurys dropped, widening credit spreads ever more. Spreads on investment-grade bonds exploded upward—on that one day—from 133 points to 162! In truth, such spreads had to be inferred, because almost nothing in bond markets traded that day. The bond market had effectively closed; no one could trade out of anything, or not without suffering horrendous losses. It was as if a bomb had hit; traders looked at their screens, and the screens stared blankly back. Buyers were simply nowhere to be found. “August thirty-first was a unique day,” said Curtis Shambaugh, the bond strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. “So few issues traded, you had to guess where they were.” For a fund that had to lighten its load, the month had ended with the most nightmarish kind of bond market imaginable: no bond market at all.

8月份是信用利差有史以来最糟糕的一个月。过去，如此膨胀的利差往往预示着经济崩溃。但这一次，经济萧条并未威胁到实体经济；或许经济增速会放缓，但仅此而已。债券市场崩盘并非源于主流经济的恐慌，而是源于华尔街自身的恐慌，那里过度乐观（以及过度杠杆）的情绪突然崩溃。

August was the worst month ever recorded in credit spreads.25 In the past, such ballooning spreads had presaged an economic collapse. But this time, no depression threatened Main Street; perhaps a slowdown, but nothing more. The bond market collapse was caused by a panic not in the mainstream economy but on Wall Street itself, where too much optimism (and too much leverage) had suddenly come undone.

8月份，四分之三的对冲基金亏损，而Long-Term的损失最为惨重。短短一个月内，梅里韦瑟的团队就损失了19亿美元，相当于其资本的45%，仅剩下22.8亿美元。索罗斯的投资机会彻底破灭了。Long-Term的投资组合仍然臃肿不堪，存在安全隐患。该基金拥有1250亿美元的资产——相当于其此前总额的98%，是其如今缩水后的净资产的55倍之多——此外，其衍生品交易（例如股票波动率和互换利差）也存在巨额杠杆。这种杠杆水平根本无法承受。如果其资产继续缩水，仅剩的22.8亿美元净资产也将瞬间被吞噬殆尽。然而，鉴于交易规模之大和流动性的完全丧失，这种杠杆水平根本无法降低。

Three quarters of all hedge funds lost money in August, and Long-Term did the worst of any of them. In one dreadful month, Meriwether’s gang lost $1.9 billion, or 45 percent of its capital, leaving it with only $2.28 billion. The Soros opportunity was gone—hopelessly gone. And Long-Term’s portfolio still was dangerously bloated. The fund had $125 billion in assets—98 percent of its prior total and an extraordinary fifty-five times its now-shrunken equity—in addition to the massive leverage in its derivative bets, such as equity volatility and swap spreads. This leverage was simply untenable. If its assets continued to fall, its losses would eat through that $2.28 billion sliver of equity in an eye blink. Yet that leverage could not be reduced—not given the size of the trades and the utter loss of liquidity.

合伙人们身处一个陌生的境地，一个建模者们从未涉足的领域。斯塔维斯觉得合伙人们已经陷入了“一种他们无法理解的波动”。理论上讲，像奥古斯特那样的损失发生的概率极低；根据数学家的说法，这种惨败极其罕见，即使在宇宙的整个生命周期中，甚至在宇宙的无数次重复中，发生的可能性也微乎其微。 26但在梅里韦瑟致信公司投资者，自信地认可默顿和斯科尔斯对基金风险的精细假设不到四年后，长期基金就遭遇了这样的灾难。唉，用合伙人的话来说，“（交易之间的）相关性已经达到了1”。每笔赌注都在同时亏损。骰子并非随机掷出，或者至少看起来像是出自同一只恶意之手。

The partners were in an unfamiliar place, a territory the modelers hadn’t explored. Stavis felt the partners had gotten to “a kind of volatility they didn’t understand.” Theoretically, the odds against a loss such as August’s had been prohibitive; such a debacle was, according to the mathematicians, an event so freakish as to be unlikely to occur even once over the entire life of the Universe and even over numerous repetitions of the Universe.26 But it had happened to Long-Term not quite four years after Meriwether had written to the firm’s investors, confidently endorsing Merton and Scholes’s so finely tuned assumptions about the fund’s risks. Alas, in the partners’ lingo, the “correlations [among the trades] had gone to one.” Every bet was losing simultaneously. The dice were not being thrown at random, or at least they seemed as if tossed by the same malevolent hand.

9

9

人为因素





THE HUMAN FACTOR





9月初，梅里韦瑟不得不向投资者们通报基金的巨额亏损，他的信中措辞毫不含糊：

AT THE BEGINNING OF September, Meriwether had to tell his investors about the fund’s horrendous losses, and his letter did not mince words:

正如各位所知，俄罗斯经济崩溃引发的一系列事件导致全球市场在整个八月份出现剧烈且不断加剧的波动……不幸的是，长期资本投资组合的净资产值也大幅下降……八月份下跌了44%，年初至今下跌了52%。如此巨大的损失令我们和各位都感到震惊，尤其考虑到该基金的历史波动性¹。

As you are all too aware, events surrounding the collapse in Russia caused large and dramatically increasing volatility in global markets throughout August. . . . Unfortunately, Long-Term Capital Portfolio has also experienced a sharp decline in net asset value . . . it is down 44 percent for the month of August, and 52 percent for the year-to-date. Losses of this magnitude are a shock to us as they surely are to you, especially in light of the historical volatility of the fund.¹

然而，JM的信中对基金的未来持谨慎乐观的态度。毫无疑问，这种乐观反映了他诚实的评估，但此时合伙人对自身前景的看法已与外界的看法严重分歧。信中指出，长期基金灾难的种子早在1998年初就已埋下，当时信用利差扩大。长期基金曾押注利差会再次收窄，但投资者纷纷抛售流动性差的证券，导致利差进一步扩大。正如JM所说，由于这种“追逐流动性”的现象，“事后我们各项策略的损失出现了关联”——这种牵强的表述意在表明，长期基金“事前”已竭尽全力避免这种关联。

However, J.M.’s letter was guardedly optimistic about the fund’s future. No doubt this rosy view reflected his honest assessment, but by now the partners’ view of their prospects had seriously diverged from that of the outside world. According to the letter, the seeds of Long-Term’s disaster had been sown earlier in 1998, when credit spreads had widened. Long-Term had bet on spreads to narrow again, but investors had fled from illiquid securities, pushing spreads wider still. Owing to this “flight to iquidity,” as J.M. phrased it, “our losses across strategies were correlated after the fact”—a tortured construction intended to mean that Long-Term had done everything it could to avoid such correlations “before the fact.”

他的分析丝毫没有暗示长期投资公司内部有人犯了错误——例如，在1997年底机会寥寥无几的时候，没有及时精简资产负债表。言下之意，JM并非指责他的交易员，而是指责与他们走势相反的市场。

His analysis was devoid of any suggestion that anyone at Long-Term had made a mistake—for instance, by not trimming the balance sheet at the end of 1997, when opportunities had been so scarce. By implication, J.M. faulted not his traders but the markets that had moved against them.

梅里韦瑟向投资者保证，“我们已采取措施降低风险，这些措施与我们的资本水平相符。” 但鉴于长期资本管理公司（LTCM）几乎没有进行任何抛售，且其杠杆率已飙升至55比1（梅里韦瑟对此只字未提），这番话颇具误导性。最委婉的解释是，在希利布兰德和哈加尼的强大影响下，梅里韦瑟认为核心交易的风险并不大。他指出：“我们看到一些最佳策略蕴藏着巨大的机会。” 与此同时，梅里韦瑟断言该基金“流动性相当好”——这一点固然属实，但却未能解决LTCM（合伙人的管理公司）日益严重的现金流问题。

Meriwether assured the investors that “steps have been taken to reduce risks now, commensurate with our level of capital.” But this was a rather misleading comment, given that Long-Term had done little in the way of selling and that its leverage had bolted to 55 to 1—a fact that Meriwether omitted. The kindest explanation is that Meriwether, under the strong influence of Hilibrand and Haghani, did not consider the core trades to be all that risky. “We see great opportunities in a number of our best strategies,” he noted. In the meantime, J.M. asserted, the fund was “quite liquid”—a point that was true but that failed to address the serious cash flow problems developing at LTCM, the partners’ management company.

Long-Term于9月2日传真了这封机密信函，但其中一位投资者将其泄露给了财经新闻服务机构彭博社，彭博社甚至在最后一位投资者收到副本之前就将其公之于众。这突如其来的负面报道犹如当头棒喝。《华尔街日报》在一篇关于金融困境的报道中，将Long-Term的亏损放在了最显眼的位置²，而在线财经专栏作家詹姆斯·克莱默则尖锐地指出，“天才”一词或许应该留给莫扎特，而不是套利者³。

Long-Term faxed the confidential letter on September 2, but one of the investors leaked it to Bloomberg, the financial news service, which published it even before the last investor had gotten his copy. This dollop of unwanted publicity hit the partners like a splash of ice water. The Wall Street Journal gave top billing to Long-Term’s losses in a broader story on financial distress,² and James Cramer, an on-line financial columnist, stingingly observed that perhaps the term “genius” should be reserved for Mozart and not for arbitrageurs.³

尽管媒体的喧嚣令基金感到尴尬，但随着交易员们从汉普顿度假归来，基金预期市场会迎来转机。八月份的波动或许只是个偶然现象。“大家都去度假了，”合伙人们互相安慰道，“现在一切都会恢复正常。”然而，就在梅里韦瑟发出信函的第二天，穆迪投资者服务公司下调了巴西的债务评级。这是一个不祥之兆。那些将金融危机的种子从一个国家传播到另一个国家的全球交易员们，如今仿佛心照不宣地将目光投向了巴西。货币投机者们正向圣保罗施压，而圣保罗——效仿莫斯科那令人质疑的做法——否认货币会贬值。长期基金最不希望看到的就是另一个俄罗斯。

Though embarrassed by the hooting press, the fund was expecting a turnaround now that traders were returning from the Hamptons. August, presumably, had been a quirk. “People were on vacation,” the partners told one another. “Now it will come back.” But the day after Meriwether’s letter, Moody’s Investors Service downgraded Brazilian debt. This was a bad sign. The global traders who carried the germ of financial crisis from country to country were now, as if by unspoken accord, focusing on Brazil. Currency speculators were putting the squeeze on São Paulo, which—following the dubious example of Moscow—was denying that it would ever devalue. The last thing Long-Term wanted was another Russia.

不出所料，银行收紧了对巴西的信贷。美林总裁赫伯·艾利森召集员工于9月4日（劳动节前的星期五）开会，审查美林在新兴市场的回购交易风险敞口。艾利森曾一度非常支持与长期基金的关系，如今却质问美林为何要为该基金在巴西的交易提供融资。“你这话是什么意思，赫伯？”艾利森的一位下属反驳道，暗指老板过去对长期基金的偏爱。“都是因为你！”艾利森笑着说，并告诫员工不要再让这种事发生。

Inevitably, the banks tightened credit in Brazil. Herb Allison, Merrill’s president, called a meeting for September 4, the Friday before Labor Day, to go over Merrill’s repo exposures in emerging markets. Allison, once so supportive of the relationship with Long-Term, demanded to know why Merrill was financing the fund’s Brazilian trades. “What do you mean, Herb?” one of Allison’s underlings retorted, alluding to his boss’s former fondness for Long-Term. “It’s because of you!” Allison laughed and told his staff not to let it happen again.

银行不仅对冲基金感到不安，也对自身不断扩大的亏损感到焦虑。高盛、摩根大通、所罗门美邦、美林以及其他银行都持有巨额债券组合，这些组合虽然构成不同，但总体上与长期债券类似。这些银行也通过做空美国国债来对冲风险，因此同样面临着信用利差无情扩大的风险。此外，银行的股价也大幅下跌。损失最大的高盛尤其担心熊市会毁掉其原定于下个月进行的首次公开募股。所罗门美邦同样忧心忡忡。桑迪·韦尔担心套利交易的损失可能会危及他与花旗集团即将于10月进行的合并。在韦尔的铁腕命令下，所罗门美邦继续抛售资产。喜怒无常的哈加尼对此非常不满，甚至想买下所罗门美邦剩余的资产组合，以阻止其继续抛售。他的合伙人都觉得哈加尼疯了——长期投资公司根本没能力收购任何东西。他们几乎都怀疑，这个神经兮兮的哈加尼并没有尽力抛售资产，仿佛他暗地里享受着孤注一掷的刺激感。在伦敦的时候，他依然骑车上班，好像什么事都没发生一样。

The banks were agitated not just about hedge funds but about their own mounting losses. Goldman, Morgan, Salomon Smith Barney, Merrill, and the rest owned huge portfolios of bonds that, in different configurations, were generally similar to Long-Term’s. The banks, too, had hedged their portfolios by shorting U.S. Treasurys, and they were exposed to the same merciless widening of credit spreads. Moreover, the banks’ share prices had tumbled. Goldman, which had suffered the biggest losses, was especially nervous lest the bear market ruin its public offering, planned for the following month. Salomon was nervous, too. Sandy Weill was terrified that the losses from Arbitrage might jeopardize his pending merger with Citicorp, also slated for October. Under Weill’s steely orders, Salomon continued to liquidate. The mercurial Haghani had been so upset that he wanted to buy what remained of Salomon’s portfolio, just to stop its selling. His partners thought Haghani was daft—Long-Term wasn’t in a position to buy anything. They all but suspected that the nervy Haghani was not doing his all to unload assets, almost as though he secretly enjoyed the thrill of having everything at stake. When in London, he continued to pedal to work, as if nothing was wrong.

但合伙人注意到一个不祥的迹象：他们的交易跌幅远超其他交易。例如，垃圾债券市场出现反弹，但长期基金持有的特定债券却持续低迷。同样，英国的互换利差扩大幅度远超德国——这与长期基金的预期完全相反——而且没有任何明显的经济逻辑。在英国，互换利差飙升至82个基点，而德国则徘徊在45个基点。“这根本说不通，”一位长期基金的交易员愤愤不平地说。如果英国真的出现了避险情绪，那么从逻辑上讲，德国也应该受到影响。但无论从哪个角度来看，华尔街的交易员都像老鼠逃离沉船一样，纷纷抛售长期基金的交易。

But the partners noticed an ominous pattern: their trades were falling more than others’. There was a rally in junk bonds, for instance, but the specific issues that Long-Term owned stayed depressed.4 Similarly, swap spreads were widening in England much more than in Germany—the exact opposite of what Long-Term had bet on—without any apparent economic rationale. In the United Kingdom, swap spreads soared to 82 points, while in Germany they lingered at 45. “It didn’t make sense,” a Long-Term trader fumed. If England was suffering from a flight to quality, it should logically have struck in Germany, too. But logically or otherwise, Wall Street traders were running from Long-Term’s trades like rats from a sinking ship.

这不再是纯粹的巧合。在四处筹集资金的过程中，长期资本管理公司被迫披露了部分信息，甚至包括其投资组合的大致轮廓。讽刺的是，这家一向以保密著称的对冲基金，如今却成了一本打开的书。正如维尼·马托内（Vinny Mattone）所说，市场总是与弱者作对。而多亏了梅里韦瑟（Meriwether）的信，华尔街所有人都知道了长期资本管理公司的困境。竞争对手们开始提前抛售，以应对他们担心的长期资本管理公司即将发起的大规模清算。“人们嗅到了麻烦的气息，就开始撤离，”当时在所罗门兄弟公司（Salomon）担任交易员的科斯塔斯·卡普拉尼斯（Costas Kaplanis）评论道，“不是为了攻击长期资本管理公司，而是为了自保。”当他们猛烈抨击长期资本管理公司的交易时，莱希（Leahy）感到一阵恶心，仿佛公司的竞争对手正在替长期资本管理公司清算自己的仓位。希利布兰德（Hilibrand）说得没错：当你暴露了自己的秘密，你就赤身裸体了。

This was no longer purely coincidence. As it scavenged for capital, Long-Term had been forced to reveal bits and pieces and even the general outline of its portfolio. Ironically, the secrecy-obsessed hedge fund had become an open book. Markets, as Vinny Mattone might say, conspire against the weak. And thanks to Meriwether’s letter, all Wall Street knew about Long-Term’s troubles. Rival firms began to sell in advance of what they feared would be an avalanche of liquidating by Long-Term. “As people smelled trouble, they started getting out,” Costas Kaplanis, then a trader at Salomon, remarked. “Not to attack LTCM—to save themselves.” As they hammered away at Long-Term’s trades, Leahy felt sick, as though the firm’s competitors were liquidating Long-Term’s own positions for it.5 Hilibrand had not been wrong: when you bare your secrets, you’re left naked.

梅里韦瑟或许认为该基金流动性良好，但贝尔斯登却不这么认为。长期基金“存放在账户”中的资产——也就是它在贝尔斯登存放的现金和证券——每天都在减少。贝尔斯登越来越不愿意为该基金进行清算。更糟糕的是，每天下午向贝尔斯登汇报该基金业绩的罗伯特·舒斯塔克屡次低估了该基金的损失。这并非舒斯塔克的本意。长期基金不得不估算其许多交易的价值，尤其是那些不公开报价的衍生品。长期基金的“估价”（即价格）来自其他交易员。而现在，竞争对手银行要么为了规避风险而采取保守策略，要么趁长期基金陷入困境之际压低其交易价格，迫使舒斯塔克不得不向贝尔斯登提供更准确的数据。

Meriwether may have felt the fund was liquid, but Bear Stearns was not so sure. Long-Term’s assets “in the box”—that is, the cash and securities it kept on call at Bear—were dropping by the day. Bear was increasingly uncomfortable about clearing for the fund. Making matters worse, Robert Shustak, who updated Bear on the fund’s results every afternoon, repeatedly underestimated the fund’s losses. This wasn’t intentional on Shustak’s part. Long-Term had to estimate the value of many of its trades, particularly derivatives, which weren’t publicly quoted. Long-Term got its “marks”—its prices—from other traders. And now rival banks were either playing it safe or exploiting Long-Term’s woes by marking down its trades, forcing Shustak to go back to Bear with more accurate numbers.

贝尔斯登的信贷经理迈克·艾利克斯认为，是时候给长期基金发出警告了。艾利克斯告知舒斯塔克，如果长期基金在贝尔斯登的资产低于5亿美元，贝尔斯登将停止为其提供清算服务。为了凸显贝尔斯登的焦虑，艾利克斯命令长期基金为其通过贝尔斯登融资的部分期货合约寻找新的融资渠道。谨慎的贝尔斯登不希望对该对冲基金承担过多的风险。

Mike Alix, Bear’s credit manager, felt it was time to put Long-Term on notice. Alix advised Shustak that if Long-Term’s assets in the box went below $500 million, Bear would stop clearing for the fund. Underlining Bear’s state of agita, Alix ordered Long-Term to find new financing for some futures contracts it had financed with Bear. The prudent Bear wanted no excess exposure to the hedge fund.

来自贝尔斯登的压力也让长期基金的回购专员迈克·雷斯曼（Mike Reisman）焦躁不安。雷斯曼是长期基金的资金负责人，负责为基金债券寻找融资，而且通常都能找到最佳融资方案。他也是长期基金里最有个性的人。年仅33岁的雷斯曼是一位单口喜剧演员，在曼哈顿拥有一家名为“哥谭喜剧俱乐部”（Gotham Comedy Club）的股份。如果说谁能让办公室气氛轻松愉快，那非雷斯曼莫属。但到了9月初，这位回购专员却无心开玩笑。雷斯曼比任何人都更了解基金的状况，他告诉一位同事，如果长期基金在月底前无法筹集到新的资金，基金将失去回购额度，而没有这些额度，基金将无法生存。

The pressure from Bear put Mike Reisman, Long-Term’s repo man, in a state of agita as well. Reisman was Long-Term’s money guy, the one who found the financing, and usually the best possible financing, for its bonds. He was also the closest that Long-Term had to a genuine character. Only thirty-three, Reisman was a stand-up comic who owned a piece of the Gotham Comedy Club in Manhattan. If anyone kept the office light, it was Reisman. But in early September, the repo guy was in no mood for comedy. Reisman, who more than anyone else had his finger on the fund’s pulse, told a colleague that if Long-Term didn’t raise new money by the end of the month, the fund would lose its repo lines, without which it couldn’t survive.

员工们焦虑不安的原因不言而喻。他们自己也向基金投入了资金，却对合伙人为了挽救基金所采取的措施一无所知。这些员工默默奉献，即使前途未卜，也依然长时间工作。他们自然对那些与他们并肩作战却从不透露秘密的合伙人心怀怨恨。每当老板们关上门开会，员工们就只能咬牙切齿地等待。合伙人离开后，员工们会问：“嘿，伙计们，到底怎么回事？” 典型的回答是：“我们正在努力。” 为了获取确切的信息，员工们戏谑地发明了一个“领带指数”：打领带的合伙人越多，公司要开的会议就越多，公司的问题也就越严重！

The staff had a personal reason for feeling anxious. They had their own capital in the fund, yet they remained in the dark about what the partners were doing to save it. The employees were quiet heroes, working long days even as their future became increasingly cloudy. Naturally, they resented the partners, who worked alongside them but never shared their secrets. When the bosses shut the door for meetings, the staffers would wait with clenched teeth. When the partners exited, a staffer would say, “Hey, guys, what’s going on?” The typical response: “We’re working on it.” As a substitute for solid info, employees mockingly developed a “necktie index”: the more partners who wore a tie, the employees kidded, the more big meetings and thus the deeper the firm’s trouble!

事实上，合伙人担心员工会离职。这个问题不容忽视，因为支付员工薪水的长期资本管理公司（LTCM）资金周转极度困难。 9月第一周，富利银行要求LTCM偿还贷款。这意味着LTCM岌岌可危；富利银行随时可以使其破产。可以预见的是，如果这种情况发生，长期资本管理公司的交易对手方将会声称LTCM违反了互换协议，从而导致该基金本身破产。

The partners were, in fact, worried that the employees would bolt. The issue could not be ignored, because LTCM, which paid the employees’ salaries, was anything but liquid. In the first week of September, Fleet Bank called its loans to LTCM. This meant that LTCM was living on a thread; Fleet could put it into bankruptcy at any time. Presumably, if that happened, Long-Term’s trading counterparties would then claim a default on their swap agreements and tip the fund itself into bankruptcy.

面对迄今为止最严重的危机，合伙人将3800万美元从投资组合中转移到他们个人拥有的长期资本管理公司（LTCM），以贷款的形式注入。这笔可疑的交易为LTCM提供了资金，用于支付员工工资直至1998年底，从而为LTCM争取了一些时间。基金的外部董事批准了这笔贷款，理由是如果LTCM倒闭，基金本身也可能崩溃。然而，尽管这笔贷款在合同上是允许的，但却充满了利益冲突。合伙人在撤回——或者更确切地说，是以自身在基金中的投资为抵押进行借贷——却没有给予他们作为受托人的外部投资者同样的机会。这无疑是绝望的表现。

Facing their worst crisis yet, the partners moved $38 million out of the portfolio and into LTCM (which they personally owned) in the form of a loan. This dubious transaction provided the cash to pay salaries through the end of 1998, buying LTCM some time with the employees. The fund’s outside directors approved the loan, reasoning that if LTCM failed, the fund itself could topple. But the loan, even though contractually permissible, was shot through with conflicts of interest. The partners were withdrawing—or, technically, borrowing against—their own investment in the fund without giving the same opportunity to the outside investors for whom they were trusted fiduciaries. It was a sign of rank desperation.

即便如此巧妙的手段也无济于事。面对富利银行的威胁，LTCM说服了摩根大通银行的戴维·普夫鲁格（David Pflug）接手富利银行的贷款，总额约为4600万美元，并同意不追讨摩根大通银行尚未偿还的6200万美元贷款。罗森菲尔德对摩根大通银行的“惊人之举”感激不尽。 6但如今，LTCM欠摩根大通银行1.08亿美元，欠里昂信贷银行5000万美元，欠劳埃德银行700万美元，还欠自己基金3800万美元。

Even this fancy footwork was not enough. Still facing a threat from Fleet, LTCM persuaded David Pflug, the Chase Manhattan banker, to assume Fleet’s loans, which totaled roughly $46 million, and to agree not to call the $62 million loan already outstanding from Chase. Rosenfeld was deeply grateful for Chase’s “incredible move.”6 But now LTCM was in hock to Chase for $108 million, to Crédit Lyonnais for $50 million, to Lloyds for $7 million—and to its own fund for $38 million.

为了再次筹集资金，梅里韦瑟于9月6日，也就是劳动节前的那个星期日，致电美林证券的三位高管。美林证券的理查德·邓恩对此十分警惕，整个假期都在仔细审查该行对长期证券的风险敞口。美林证券现在担心的不仅仅是自身的直接风险敞口。邓恩在思考，如果长期证券崩盘引发抛售潮，市场将会如何发展：整个华尔街的投资者能否同时涌入同一扇门？美林证券对此忧心忡忡，于是委派销售员邓利维和信贷经理鲍勃·麦克唐纳前往格林威治了解情况。邓利维与合伙人关系友好，便直截了当地问他们：“你们还好吗？”合伙人一如既往地乐观，声称公司尽管面临困境，但资金流动性充足。邓利维后来告诉同事，合伙人对他撒了谎。7

Seeking capital yet again, Meriwether called a trio of Merrill executives September 6, the Sunday before Labor Day. Duly alarmed, Merrill’s Richard Dunn spent the holiday sifting through the bank’s exposures to Long-Term. Merrill was now worried about more than its own direct exposure. Dunn was thinking about what would happen to markets if a collapse by Long-Term sparked a run for the exits: Could the entire Street fit through the same door at once? Merrill was so concerned that it deputized Dunleavy, the salesman, and Bob McDonough, the credit manager, to get some facts in Greenwich. Dunleavy, who was on friendly terms with the partners, asked them point-blank, “Are you guys OK?” The partners, putting their usual positive spin on matters, said that the firm, despite its problems, was liquid. Dunleavy later told colleagues that the partners had lied to him.7

但JM和他的团队坚信，在利差如此之大的情况下，丰厚的回报即将到来。“我们一直梦想着能有这样的机会，”罗森菲尔德说道。8他们缺乏的是把握这些机会的手段。JM现在处境和埃克斯坦一样，面临着不得不让其他JM接手大赚一笔的局面。为了保险起见，梅里韦瑟告诉纽约联储主席比尔·麦克唐纳，长期基金正在寻求新的资金来源。JM和其他所罗门兄弟公司的高管曾因未能及时向美联储报告问题而受到批评；JM不会再犯同样的错误了。

But J.M. and company truly believed that with spreads so wide, a golden vindication lay around the corner. “We dreamed of the day when we’d have opportunities like this,” Rosenfeld said.8 What they lacked was the means to exploit them. J.M. was now in Eckstein’s position, facing the prospect of having to let some new J.M. make the killing. Just to be on the safe side, Meriwether told Bill McDonough, the New York Fed president, that Long-Term was having to look for new money. J.M. and other Salomon executives had once been criticized for not having advised the Fed of a problem early enough; J.M. would not make that mistake again.

整个八月底到九月，合伙人的情绪随着新投资前景的波动而起伏不定。他们回避了长期资本管理公司（LTCM）现金流问题的棘手问题，转而大谈特谈现在投资的所谓光明前景。摩根的门多萨仍然承诺投资2亿美元。他轻描淡写地列举了名单上的蓝筹投资者，其中包括通用电气董事长杰克·韦尔奇。然而，门多萨经常被其他事务分心，无暇顾及LTCM。他真心喜欢这家公司，但合伙人们对于门多萨究竟是他们最有效的盟友，还是仅仅是一个同情的旁观者，意见不一。无论如何，合伙人的通讯录里都存着不少大佬的名字。迈伦·斯科尔斯联系了个人电脑巨头迈克尔·戴尔，戴尔派了一个团队来审查基金的账目。随后，巴斯家族、德克萨斯州的金融家以及其他许多人也纷纷效仿。表面上看，这次闪电战类似于长期组织在 1993 年的第一次行动。

Throughout the end of August and into September, the partners’ mood gyrated with their prospects for fresh investment. They sidestepped the delicate issue of LTCM’s cash problems and dwelled on the supposedly bright prospects for anyone who invested now. Morgan’s Mendoza was still promising $200 million. He breezily dropped the names of blue-chip investors on his list, including Jack Welch, the chairman of General Electric. However, Mendoza was often distracted from LTCM by other affairs. He was genuinely fond of the firm, but the partners were divided on whether Mendoza was their most effective ally or simply a sympathetic voyeur. In any case, the partners had plenty of tony names in their own Rolodexes. Myron Scholes contacted Michael Dell, the personal-computer magnate, who sent a team to inspect the fund’s books. The Basses, the Texas financiers, and a host of others followed. Superficially, the blitz resembled Long-Term’s first campaign of 1993.

尽管他们似乎并未意识到，但这些合伙人已经失去了之前为他们打开成功之门的无敌光环。他们拥有耀眼的履历，却失去了魔力——而没有了魔力，他们也只不过是众多基金中的又一个。为了吸引出版业巨头齐夫兄弟，梅里韦瑟提出将长期基金异常高昂的管理费​​降低三年，而且仅限三年。或许这种诱饵曾经奏效，但如今，梅里韦瑟提出的仅暂时折扣的提议在齐夫兄弟看来却显得傲慢自大。这就是华尔街转瞬即逝的魅力：投资者会蜂拥而至地聘请高价基金经理，然后在他降低收费时弃之不顾。

But though they seemed not to realize it, the partners had lost the aura of invincibility that had opened doors for them before. They had the flashy résumés but not the magic—and without it, they were just another fund. Hoping to land the Ziff brothers, the publishing moguls, Meriwether offered to cut Long-Term’s uncommonly high fee for—and only for—the first three years. Perhaps such a teaser might have worked once, but now J.M.’s offer of only a temporary discount struck the Ziffs as arrogant. Such is the ephemeral glitter of Wall Street: investors will knock down the door of a high-priced manager and then abandon him when he cuts his rate.

合伙人团队还拜访了老虎基金（Tiger Management）的负责人朱利安·罗伯逊（Julian Robertson），老虎基金是一家大型对冲基金运营商。罗伯逊当时正准备披露一笔日元押注失误导致20亿美元的损失，可能无暇顾及投资。无论如何，这位精明的南方人罗伯逊对长期投资公司（Long-Term）并不感冒；他几乎没看到任何迹象表明该公司拥有任何卓越的专业技术。合伙人团队再次空手而归。如此耀眼的资历和如此耀眼的名单，却遭遇如此惨淡的结果，实属罕见。

A group of the partners also visited Julian Robertson, the head of Tiger Management, a big hedge fund operator. Robertson, who was about to disclose a $2 billion loss on a misplaced yen bet, may not have been in a speculating mood. In any case, Robertson, a shrewd southerner, was not impressed; he saw little to convince him that Long-Term had any superior expertise. Once again, the partners came up empty. Rarely had such heady credentials and such a gaudy list met with such dim results.

就连长期基金的现有投资者也开始对该基金持更为谨慎的态度。匹兹堡大学财务主管马龙·皮斯飞往格林威治拜访默顿和斯科尔斯，这两位教授在学术界几乎是英雄人物。他们对近期的亏损讳莫如深，但却极力吹捧该基金的潜力。斯科尔斯不愧是推销高手，他自信地表示，长期基金将在9月份筹集到10亿美元，并在年底前再筹集到10亿美元。但皮斯拒绝追加投资。

Even Long-Term’s existing investors were beginning to see the fund in a harsher light. Marlon Pease, the director of finance of the University of Pittsburgh, flew to Greenwich to see Merton and Scholes, who had virtual hero status in academia. The professors were close-mouthed about their recent losses but talked up the fund’s potential. Scholes, ever the salesman, expressed confidence that Long-Term would raise a billion dollars in September and another billion by year-end. But Pease declined to contribute more.9

“我们之前一直沉浸在一种如梦似幻的状态中，”斯坦福大学教授威廉·夏普说道，他曾为该基金的一位投资者提供咨询。但现在夏普从这种状态中清醒过来。当他在斯坦福的前同事斯科尔斯打电话来筹集更多资金时，夏普心存疑虑。他的客户是一位富有的华裔美国人，准备投资3000万美元；但夏普认为风险太大。他们达成一致，客户先投资1000万美元，如果长期基金能找到一位主要投资者，再投资1000万美元。他们准备将资金汇入第三方托管账户，但斯科尔斯推迟了交易完成。长期基金明白，零星筹集资金毫无意义。

“We had been lulled into this dreamlike state,” said William Sharpe, a Stanford professor who advised one of the fund’s investors. But now Sharpe snapped out of it. When Scholes, his former colleague at Stanford, called to raise more money, Sharpe was wary. His client, a wealthy Chinese American, was ready to invest $30 million; the professor said it was too risky. They agreed that the client would invest $10 million now and another $10 million if Long-Term could corral a major investor. They were ready to wire the money to an escrow account, but Scholes delayed the closing. Long-Term knew it would be pointless to collect money in small amounts.

为了争取巨额资金，梅里韦瑟继续与美林证券的赫伯·艾利森、德意志银行的埃德森·米切尔、摩根大通副董事长唐纳德·莱顿以及瑞银资产管理部门负责人加里·布林森周旋。这些华尔街巨头财力雄厚，不负众望。但他们能否被唤醒呢？尽管合伙人对前景充满乐观，但银行家们却对风险有着敏锐的嗅觉。随着长期投资公司（Long-Term）的处境日益艰难，银行家们也更有耐心等待。每过一天，“难得的机会”就只会变得更加廉价。

For the big money, Meriwether continued to angle with Herb Allison at Merrill, Edson Mitchell at Deutsche Bank, Donald Layton, a vice chairman of Chase, and Gary Brinson, who ran an asset management unit for UBS. Among them, these Wall Street lions easily had enough resources. But could the lions be roused from their den? The partners’ glowing forecasts notwithstanding, the bankers had a nose for trouble. And with Long-Term increasingly desperate, the bankers could afford to be patient. Every day that passed, the “rare opportunity” merely got cheaper.

尽管看似难以置信，但长期债券市场持续下跌。风险利差扩大至1987年股灾以来的最高水平。10公开发行股票几乎全部停止，令高盛的银行家们不寒而栗。11 B级债券的收益率比蓝筹股收益率高出570个基点——而一年前这一差距仅为200个基点。短期股票市场保险（股票波动率）的价格翻了一番。12一位期权交易员告诉《华尔街日报》：“市场仿佛被恐惧笼罩。” 13在海外，价格反映了彻底的恐慌。新兴市场债务指数的利率飙升至比美国国债高出1700个基点——而一年前这一差距仅为300个基点！14艾伦·格林斯潘发出不祥的警告，美国不能指望在这个动荡的世界中成为繁荣的绿洲。15无论何种资产，这都是风险资产的熊市。

Improbable as it seemed, Long-Term’s markets kept sinking. Riskarb spreads opened to their widest since the 1987 crash.10 Public stock offerings ground to a halt, sending a shudder through the bankers at Goldman Sachs.11 Yields on B-rated bonds climbed to 570 basis points above the yields on blue chips—up from 200 points a year before. The price of short-term stock market insurance (equity volatility) doubled.12 “It’s like a blanket of fear has descended over the market,” an options trader told The Wall Street Journal.13 Overseas, prices reflected sheer panic. Interest rates on an index of emerging-market debt soared to 1,700 points above U.S. Treasurys—up from 300 points a year before!14 Alan Greenspan ominously warned that the United States could not expect to be an oasis of prosperity in such a troubled world.15 It was a bear market in risk no matter what the asset.

长期投资公司在全球范围内押注风险。在每一次套利交易中，它都持有风险更高的资产；在每个国家，它都持有最不安全的债券。它已经重复了数百次同样的赌注，而现在，这个赌注正在亏损。

And Long-Term had bet on risk all over the world. In every arbitrage, it owned the riskier asset; in every country, the least safe bond. It had made that one same bet hundreds of times, and now that bet was losing.

9月10日，星期四，真是糟糕透了。掉期利差又上涨了7个点；其他利差也扩大了。祸不单行——或者说，这难道是某种预兆？——一枚载着十几颗环球星卫星的火箭从空中坠落爆炸。巧合的是，长期基金持有环球星的债券。合伙人们几乎要笑出声来：连老天都在跟他们作对。在风险管理会议上，交易员们轮流汇报各自的业绩。当所有人都亏损后，穆林斯讽刺地问道：“难道我们就不能赚点钱吗——哪怕一天也好？” 九月份至今，他们一次也没赚到钱。市场简直像是罢工了。除了长期基金，所有人都在抛售。

Thursday, September 10, was a very bad day. Swap spreads jumped another 7 points; other spreads widened, too. In a spot of bad luck—or was it a portent?—a rocket ferrying a dozen Globalstar satellites fell out of the sky and exploded. Long-Term, as it happened, owned Globalstar bonds. The partners almost laughed: even the heavens were against them. In the risk-management meeting, the traders went around the table, each reporting his results. When it be came clear that every trader had lost, Mullins demanded sarcastically, “Can’t we ever make money—just for one day?” So far in September, they hadn’t, not once. Markets were simply on strike. Everyone was selling now—except for Long-Term.

该基金因其庞大的规模而陷入瘫痪。周围的小鱼们正忙着抛售所有能看到的债券，但长期基金却无能为力，就像一头臃肿的鲸鱼被致命的食人鱼包围着。其惊人的持仓规模让合伙人陷入了进退两难的境地。如果他们出售哪怕一小部分大头寸——比如互换合约——都会导致价格暴跌，并降低其余所有头寸的价值。自从在所罗门兄弟公司工作以来，哈加尼就一直敦促他的同事们将持仓规模翻倍甚至翻四倍。现在他明白了，规模越大，代价也越大。

The fund was immobilized by its sheer mass. The smaller fish around it were liquidating every bond in sight, but Long-Term was helpless, a bloated whale surrounded by deadly piranhas. The frightful size of its positions put the partners in a terrible bind. If they sold even a tiny fraction of a big position—say, of swaps—it would send the price plummeting and reduce the value of all the rest. Ever since his Salomon days, Haghani had pushed his colleagues to double and even quadruple their positions. Now he saw that size extracts a price.

到了10号下午晚些时候，合伙人们意识到他们已经跨越了一个令人崩溃的心理障碍：他们的资本跌破了20亿美元。当天晚些时候，梅里韦瑟接到了他最害怕的电话——来自贝尔斯登执行副总裁沃伦·斯佩克特。长期基金的资产一度跌破5亿美元，不过到当天结束时已经恢复了。梅里韦瑟解释说，显然，长期基金的一些交易伙伴开始拖延支付到期款项。毕竟，没人愿意付钱给一个即将破产的公司。但斯佩克特已经听不进任何解释。他简短地告诉梅里韦瑟，贝尔斯登将在周日派一个团队来审查长期基金的账目。否则，周一将不会清算长期基金的交易。

By late afternoon on the tenth, the partners knew they had crossed a debilitating psychological barrier: their capital had fallen below $2 billion. It was late that day when Meriwether got the call he had dreaded—from Warren Spector, executive vice president of Bear Stearns. Long-Term’s assets in the box had dipped below $500 million, though they were restored by day’s end. Apparently, J.M. explained, some of Long-Term’s trading partners had started to take their time sending in monies due. No one wants to pay a prospective bankrupt. But Spector was past the point of explanations. He curtly told J.M. that Bear would be sending a team to look at Long-Term’s books on Sunday. Otherwise, it wouldn’t clear Long-Term’s trades on Monday.

第二天，9月11日，梅里韦瑟给科尔津打了电话。这位高盛总裁当时正从威尼斯赶来，他之前在那里庆祝了结婚纪念日。梅里韦瑟传达的信息很简单：长期基金需要尽快筹集大量资金。10亿美元已经不够了。为了生存下去，该基金至少需要筹集20亿美元。之后，梅里韦瑟再次致电麦克唐纳，详细地向这位纽约联储主席汇报了长期基金的自救进展。

The next day, September 11, Meriwether called Corzine. The Goldman chief was en route from Venice, where he had been celebrating his wedding anniversary. J.M. had a simple message: Long-Term needed to raise a lot of money in a hurry. One billion dollars was no longer enough. To have any hope of surviving, the fund would have to raise at least $2 billion. Then J.M. called McDonough again, diligently updating the New York Fed chief on Long-Term’s efforts to save itself.

周日贝尔斯登团队抵达时，长期投资公司表现得非常得体。这家公司突然展现出模范客户风范，不仅公开了账簿，还摆上了三明治。希利布兰德耐心地向来访者讲解了每一笔交易，丝毫没有抱怨的意思。梅里韦瑟和罗森菲尔德全程参与了简报会，表明长期投资公司认真对待了贝尔斯登的威胁。艾利克斯对长期投资公司的表现印象深刻，但同时也对其交易规模感到担忧。第二天，在贝尔斯登执行委员会开会后，艾利克斯再次向舒斯塔克重申，贝尔斯登确实将5亿美元的门槛视为不可逾越的底线。如果长期投资公司再次突破这一门槛，双方的合作就将结束。

When the team from Bear arrived on Sunday, Long-Term was on its best behavior. Suddenly a model client, it opened its books and set out a spread of sandwiches. Past the point of raising a fuss, Hilibrand patiently took the visitors through every trade. Meriwether and Rosenfeld attended the entire briefing, showing that Long-Term was taking Bear’s threat seriously. Alix was impressed by the performance but disturbed by the size of Long-Term’s trades. The next day, after Bear’s executive committee met, Alix reiterated to Shustak that Bear truly regarded the $500 million threshold as inviolate. If Long-Term pierced it again, the game would be over.

长期投资公司的最大股东瑞银集团（UBS）的处境比贝尔斯登还要糟糕。来自原瑞士银行的衍生品专家大卫·索罗（David Solo）意识到——为时已晚——新合并的瑞银集团将面临惨重损失。索罗在分析认股权证组合时发现，瑞银集团为了区区8%的潜在回报承担了巨大的风险——而现在，这笔回报当然永远无法实现了。“所有关于期权对冲、波动性和溢价的讨论都太荒谬了，”他在9月14日发给前瑞士银行行长、现任瑞银集团首席执行官马塞尔·奥斯佩尔（Marcel Ospel）的一封紧急邮件中写道。索罗还暗讽他们的合并伙伴，神秘兮兮地补充道：“这笔交易可是经过瑞银集团执行董事会和你们桌上许多人的批准的。”

UBS, Long-Term’s biggest investor, was feeling even worse than Bear. David Solo, a derivatives whiz from the old Swiss Bank, realized—too late—that the newly merged UBS was in for horrendous losses. As Solo analyzed the warrant package, UBS had taken a huge risk for a potential return of only 8 percent—which now, of course, it would never realize. “All this discussion of option hedging, volatility and premiums is ridiculous,” he tapped in an urgent September 14 e-mail to Marcel Ospel, formerly head of Swiss Bank and now CEO of UBS. In a dig at their merger partners, Solo added conspiratorially, “This trade was approved by the UBS group executive board and by many people sitting around your table.”

与此同时，就在那个星期一，梅里韦瑟、罗森菲尔德和利希拜访了雷曼兄弟公司。负责雷曼债券业务的杰夫·范德贝克立即询问有关该基金陷入困境的传言是否属实。“在我们回答这个问题之前，我们想先谈谈通过你们的私募股权部门筹集资金的可能性，”梅里韦瑟开门见山地说，仿佛一切正常。“我们去年返还了一些资金。现在我们看到了二十年来最好的机会。”长期基金的这种漫不经心的态度让雷曼兄弟的接待人员感到震惊。尽管如此，该基金所承受的压力还是显露无疑。梅里韦瑟要求罗森菲尔德解释一下投资组合，但随后却粗暴地打断了他——这对他视如己出的忠实合伙人来说，实属罕见的不耐烦。雷曼兄弟的人并没有因此而平静下来。

Meanwhile, that Monday, Meriwether, Rosenfeld, and Leahy called on Lehman Brothers. Jeff Vanderbeek, who ran the bond side of Lehman, immediately asked if the rumors he was hearing about the fund’s extreme distress were true. “Before we answer, what we’d like to talk about is the possibility of raising money through your private equity group,” J.M. began, as though nothing were wrong. “We gave some money back last year. Now we see the best opportunities in twenty years.” His hosts were stunned by Long-Term’s nonchalant pose. Still, the pressure it was under showed. Meriwether asked Rosenfeld to explain the portfolio but then curtly interrupted him—a rare of show of impatience toward the trusty partner whom he treated like a son. The Lehman crew was hardly mollified.

长期基金确实还有一条出路：1996年从摩根大通牵头的银行财团获得的循环信贷额度。这笔9亿美元的循环信贷额度（最初为5亿美元）是长期基金可以随时动用的备用资金。通常情况下，如果借款人遭遇所谓的“重大不利变化”，此类信贷额度会自动终止。但摩根大通急于与长期基金达成交易，却遗漏了重大不利变化条款。如果长期基金在任何会计期末的权益下降超过一半，该循环信贷额度将被取消。各家银行纷纷声称，该基金的亏损使它们摆脱了提供资金的义务。但上一个“会计期”结束于7月31日——当时长期基金仍然拥有充足的权益。因此，从技术上讲，银行仍然负有责任。由于摩根大通草拟的条款漏洞，各家银行不得不向一家破产的公司提供9亿美元的贷款。

Long-Term did have one escape hatch: the revolving credit it had obtained in 1996 from the bank syndicate led by Chase. The $900 million revolver (raised from $500 million initially) was a standby facility that Long-Term could tap when it wanted. Usually, such facilities terminate automatically if the borrower suffers a sharp deterioration, known as a “material adverse change.” But in its eagerness to deal with Long-Term, Chase had omitted the material-adversechange clause. The revolver was cancelable if, at the end of any accounting period, Long-Term’s equity fell by more than half. And the banks were squawking that the fund’s losses had freed them of their obligation to fund. But the last “accounting period” had ended on July 31—at which time Long-Term had still had plenty of equity. So technically, the banks were on the hook. Thanks to Chase’s sloppy drafting, the banks would have to lend $900 million to an insolvent.

但合伙人之间对于是否应该借款存在严重分歧。穆林斯认为不应该借款。如果基金倒闭，为什么要拖累银行？额外的贷款只会让事情更加复杂。JM、霍金斯、莫德斯特和几位诺贝尔奖得主都同意他的观点。希利布兰德、哈加尼、利希和罗森菲尔德则强烈主张动用循环信贷额度。他们问道，否则他们如何才能在贝尔斯登补充资金？克拉斯克、麦肯蒂和舒斯塔克也赞成融资。律师里卡兹指出，如果长期基金不尝试所有方案，可能会对投资者承担责任。“我们现在不必做决定，”JM最终说道，结束了这场争论。他们暂时还不需要这笔钱。

But the partners were badly split on whether they should borrow. Mullins thought they shouldn’t. If the fund went down, why take the banks with them? An additional loan would only complicate matters. J.M., Hawkins, Modest, and the Nobelists agreed. Hilibrand, Haghani, Leahy, and Rosenfeld argued strongly for drawing on the revolver. How else, they asked, could they hope to replenish their capital at Bear? Krasker, McEntee, and Shustak were for funding, too. Rickards, the lawyer, pointed out that Long-Term might be liable to its own investors if it didn’t pursue every option. “We don’t have to decide at this juncture,” J.M. finally said, cutting off the debate. They didn’t need the money quite yet.

合伙人手中仍然握有高盛和科尔津，而到了九月中旬，科尔津已成为长期投资公司唯一的希望。身材高大、蓄着胡须的科尔津，一直以来都不像个金融家。他出生于伊利诺伊州南部的一个农舍，大学时打过篮球，娶了幼儿园同班的女友。1975年，在梅里韦瑟被所罗门兄弟公司聘用一年后，科尔津加入了高盛的债券部门。他成长为一名才华横溢的交易员，虽然不如梅里韦瑟那样声名显赫，但他坦言自己非常钦佩梅里韦瑟，并将梅里韦瑟的套利部门视为自己公司的典范。随着科尔津在高盛步步高升，他始终保持着谦逊随和的作风，在西装革履的金融界，他总是穿着毛茸茸的打补丁毛衣。

The partners still had Goldman Sachs and Corzine, who now, in mid-September, emerged as Long-Term’s one best hope. Tall and bearded, Corzine had always seemed an unlikely financier. Born in a farmhouse in southern Illinois, he had played basketball in college and married a girl from his kindergarten class.16 In 1975, a year after Meriwether had been hired by Salomon, Corzine had joined the bond department at Goldman. He had developed into a talented trader, though less celebrated than Meriwether, whom he frankly admired and whose arbitrage unit he viewed as a model for his own firm. As Corzine climbed the ranks at Goldman, he remained unaffected and easygoing, known for fuzzy patched sweaters in a world of three-piece suits.

高盛是华尔街最后一家提供全方位服务的私人投资银行，它与长期投资公司（Long-Term）有一些共同之处。高盛的合伙人行事低调，而且几十年来关系异常密切。高盛的企业文化极其谨慎（在其位于百老汇大街85号的总部大厅里，丝毫看不出高盛的身影）。直到最近，高盛一直以其对蓝筹企业客户的悉心照料而闻名。作为关系型银行的倡导者，高盛一直鄙视恶意收购，甚至拒绝自营交易，其理由是交易可能会使银行与其客户产生冲突。 17但在20世纪80年代和90年代初，这些看似高雅的规矩被抛诸脑后。由斯蒂芬·弗里德曼和罗伯特·鲁宾（后来成为财政部的要职人物）组成的领导二人组自信地将业务拓展到交易领域，随着高盛的银行家们卸下“白手套”，与客户的冲突变得司空见惯。 1994年债券市场崩盘时，高盛——和长期投资公司一样，也根据波动率的统计模型设定了风险限额——遭受了巨大且破坏性的损失。高盛发现，其他交易员都清楚其杠杆头寸，而它若想脱身，必将蒙受惨重损失。18位合伙人集体离职，将重振合伙关系和业务的重任压在了1994年秋季接任的朴实无华的科尔津身上。公司最终恢复了元气，但高盛的合伙人——同样和长期投资公司的合伙人一样——意识到他们需要更多资金，这也是他们计划发行股票的原因。与此同时，科尔津进一步强调了为银行账户进行交易这项利润丰厚的业务。

Goldman, Wall Street’s last private full-service investment bank, shared certain traits with Long-Term. Its partners were secretive and, for many decades, had been unusually close. The Goldman culture was exceptionally discreet (there is no indication of Goldman’s presence in the lobby of its headquarters at 85 Broad Street). Until recent times, Goldman had been known for the care that it lavished on blue-chip corporate clients. An apostle of relationship banking, Goldman had disdained hostile takeovers and even eschewed trading for its own account, on the noble premise that trading could put the bank into conflict with its customers.17 But in the 1980s and early ’90s, such drawing room niceties were cast aside. The leadership duo of Stephen Friedman and Robert Rubin, later of Treasury fame, confidently expanded into trading, and as Goldman’s bankers removed their white gloves, conflicts with customers became common. When the bond market cracked in 1994, Goldman—which, like Long-Term, had set risk limits according to statistical models of volatility—suffered enormous and destabilizing losses. Goldman discovered that its leveraged positions were well known to other traders, and it could not get out of them without suffering heavy losses.18 Partners defected en masse, saddling the unpretentious Corzine, who took over in the fall of 1994, with the job of rebuilding the partnership as well as the business. The firm bounced back, but Goldman’s partners—again like Long-Term’s—realized that they needed more capital, which was the reason for their planned stock offering. Meanwhile, Corzine further emphasized the lucrative business of trading for the bank’s account.

科尔津此前就对与梅里韦瑟联手的想法很感兴趣，如今他占据了优势，可以从更有利的地位来应对这位竞争对手。他同意提供资金，但条件是：他要求获得合伙人管理公司一半的股份、完全掌控长期基金的投资策略，以及设定基金风险敞口上限的权利。这位和蔼可亲的金融家提出的方案无异于一次收购。然而，科尔津承诺提供高盛及其客户的10亿美元资金，并帮助长期基金筹集另外10亿美元。仅仅是让外界知道高盛站在长期基金一边，就可能止住它的颓势。梅里韦瑟无法拒绝。

Corzine had been intrigued with the idea of joining forces with Meriwether before, and now he could deal with his rival from a position of strength. He agreed to provide capital, but at a price: he demanded half of the partners’ management company, full access to Long-Term’s strategies, and the right to set a limit on the fund’s exposures. The congenial financier was proposing nothing short of a takeover. However, Corzine was offering $1 billion of Goldman’s and its clients’ money, as well as a promise to help Long-Term raise a second billion. And merely informing the world that Goldman was in Long-Term’s corner might stop the bleeding. Meriwether could not say no.

两家公司迅速达成协议，条件是高盛筹集到资金，以及长期基金通过例行审查。高盛必须抓紧时间，以免长期基金的资金进一步损失。9月14日当周，高盛递交了堆积如山的文件，并派遣罗森菲尔德、默顿和四名员工前往百老汇大街。默顿滔滔不绝地讲述两家公司合并的战略价值。高盛团队对套利交易员们连珠炮似地提问。随后，高盛的外部律师事务所苏利文·克伦威尔律师事务所的六名律师蜂拥而至，对长期基金的代表进行了严酷的盘问。

The two firms quickly struck a deal, conditional on Goldman’s raising the money and on Long-Term’s passing an inspection, a customary process. Goldman had to move fast, before any more of Long-Term’s capital was lost. The week of September 14, the fund handed over mountains of files and dispatched Rosenfeld, Merton, and four of the staff to Broad Street. Merton waxed poetic about the supposed strategic value of the two firms’ joining. A Goldman team peppered the arbitrageurs with questions. Then a half-dozen lawyers from Sullivan & Cromwell, Goldman’s outside law firm, marched in and subjected the emissaries from Long-Term to a torturous grilling.

在格林威治，高盛的侦查人员在办公室里四处搜查，不放过任何蛛丝马迹。长期基金的员工根本分不清谁是高盛的人，所以很多人都在翻阅这家对冲基金的文件。高盛团队的关键成员之一是雅各布·戈德菲尔德，他身材瘦长，才华横溢，但为人却十分粗暴。据目击者称，这位固执己见的戈德菲尔德似乎正在将长期基金严密保护的持仓数据，从长期基金自己的电脑直接下载到一台超大的笔记本电脑上（高盛后来否认了这一细节）。与此同时，高盛在纽约的交易员们正在出售部分相同的持仓。一天结束时，当这些持仓的价值大幅缩水后，长期基金办公室里的一些高盛交易员大摇大摆地走到交易台前，提出要买下这些持仓。高盛肆无忌惮地在银行和投资者之间周旋，将投资银行业最卑鄙无耻的一面展现得淋漓尽致。在 JM 和他的合伙人看来，高盛就在他们眼前对 Long-Term 进行了掠夺。

In Greenwich, Goldman’s sleuths, who had the run of the office, left no stone unturned. Long-Term’s staff couldn’t keep track of who the Goldman people were, so many were rummaging through the hedge fund’s files. A key member of the Goldman team was Jacob Goldfield, a lanky and brilliant but abrasive trader. According to witnesses, the headstrong Goldfield appeared to be downloading Long-Term’s positions, which the fund had so zealously guarded, from Long-Term’s own computers directly into an oversized laptop (a detail that Goldman later denied). Meanwhile, Goldman’s traders in New York sold some of the very same positions. At the end of one day, when the fund’s positions were worth a good deal less, some Goldman traders in Long-Term’s offices sauntered up to the trading desk and offered to buy them.19 Brazenly playing both sides of the street, Goldman represented investment banking at its mercenary ugliest. To J.M. and his partners, Goldman was raping Long-Term in front of their very eyes.

周一，高盛入侵当天，股市波动率飙升至惊人的32%！周二更是达到33%——每波动1个百分点，该基金就损失4000万美元。整个基金的投资组合都遭遇了类似的打击。长期基金的交易——尤其是其自身的交易——遭受了无情的重创，从丹麦抵押贷款到大众汽车股票，再到Station Casinos和Starwood的垃圾债券，无一幸免。长期基金以低于皇家荷兰银行8%的价格买入的壳牌运输公司股票，如今利差却灾难性地扩大至14%。就连在1998年大部分时间里都盈利的意大利债券交易，如今也出现了下滑。

On Monday, the day the Goldman invasion was launched, equity volatility climbed to an astonishing 32 percent! On Tuesday it hit 33 percent—each point cost the fund $40 million. Throughout the fund’s portfolio it was a similar story. Long-Term’s trades—its trades in particular—were mercilessly battered, from Danish mortgages to Volkswagen shares to junk bonds of Station Casinos and Starwood. Shell Transport, which Long-Term had purchased at an 8 percent discount to Royal Dutch, disastrously widened to a spread of 14 percent. Even the reliable trade in Italian bonds, which had made money during most of 1998, now fell back, too.

在全球所有资产类别中，市场都对格林威治的这家对冲基金不利。公司内部律师里卡兹向同事们称之为“长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的死亡交易”。相关性已经达到1，每次掷骰子都掷出1点（或1点）。数学家们没有预料到这种情况。他们原本认为，随机市场会导致标准的分布——出现正常的黑羊和白羊、正面和反面、J和2的模式，而不是像现在这样，每笔交易都遭受巨额损失，而且这种损失日复一日，永无止境。

In every class of asset and all over the world, the market moved against the hedge fund in Greenwich. Rickards, the house attorney, described it to colleagues as the “LTCM death trade.” The correlations had gone to one; every roll was turning up snake eyes. The mathematicians had not foreseen this. Random markets, they had thought, would lead to standard distributions—to a normal pattern of black sheep and white sheep, heads and tails, and jacks and deuces, not to staggering losses in every trade, day after day after day.

教授们忽略了一个他们心知肚明的真理：市场中，尾部总是肥硕的。他们身处远离纽约熙熙攘攘交易大厅的玻璃幕墙宫殿中，忘记了交易员并非随机分子，甚至也不是像希利布兰德那样的机械逻辑学家，而是受贪婪和恐惧驱使的人，他们能够做出群体中常见的极端行为，情绪也会出现剧烈波动。1998年夏末，债券交易人群极度恐慌，尤其是对高风险信贷产品。教授们没有建立这样的模型。他们为市场设定了一种冷冰冰的可预测性，而这在现实生活中是根本不存在的；他们忘记了支配现实交易员的掠夺性、占有欲和极强的保护本能。他们忘记了人性因素。

The professors had ignored the truism—of which they were well aware—that in markets, the tails are always fat. Stuck in their glass-walled palace far from New York’s teeming trading floors, they had forgotten that traders are not random molecules, or even mechanical logicians such as Hilibrand, but people moved by greed and fear, capable of the extreme behavior and swings of mood so often observed in crowds. And in the late summer of 1998, the bond-trading crowd was extremely fearful, especially of risky credits. The professors hadn’t modeled this. They had programmed the market for a cold predictability that it had never had; they had forgotten the predatory, acquisitive, and overwhelmingly protective instincts that govern real-life traders. They had forgotten the human factor.

梅里韦瑟向美联储的彼得·费舍尔激烈抱怨，高盛等公司正在进行“抢先交易”，即利用内幕消息进行反向交易。事实上，高盛在9月中旬的交易活动异常活跃，华尔街盛传高盛正在抛售其长期持有的互换和垃圾债券头寸。甚至有传言称，高盛的高收益债券交易员还在为此沾沾自喜。

Meriwether bitterly complained to the Fed’s Peter Fisher that Goldman, among others, was “front-running,” meaning trading against it on the basis of inside knowledge. Goldman, indeed, was an extremely active trader in mid-September, and rumors that Goldman was selling Long-Term’s positions in swaps and junk bonds were all over Wall Street. In fact, its high-yield traders were said to be bragging about it.

但高盛绝非孤例。如今，人们对长期基金的投资组合已了如指掌。所罗门兄弟几个月来一直在抛售该基金的空头头寸。德意志银行正在抛售掉期交易，而此前对股票波动率不感兴趣的美国国际集团（AIG）也突然开始竞购。如果不是为了利用长期基金的困境，为何会突然对波动率如此感兴趣？摩根大通和瑞银也在买入波动率。其中一些行为显然带有掠夺性。这种游戏与华尔街本身一样古老，规则也很简单：如果能让长期基金感受到足够的痛苦——也就是被“挤压”——该基金就会认输，回购其空头头寸。届时，任何持有这些空头头寸的人都将大赚一笔。

But Goldman was hardly alone. Knowledge of Long-Term’s portfolio was, by now, commonplace. Salomon was, and had been, pounding the fund’s positions for months. Deutsche Bank was bailing out of swap trades, and American International Group, which hadn’t shown any interest in equity volatility before, was suddenly bidding for it. Why this sudden interest, if not to exploit Long-Term’s distress? Morgan and UBS were buying volatility, too. Some of this activity was clearly predatory. The game, as old as Wall Street itself, was simple: if Long-Term could be made to feel enough pain—could be “squeezed”—the fund would cry uncle and buy back its shorts. Then, anyone who owned those positions would make a bundle.

然而，掠夺性交易的规模远小于人们的想象，更远小于后来格林威治某些偏执理论所宣称的程度。合伙人封闭的思维模式使他们极易受到阴谋论的影响，尤其因为这类解释将损失的责任推卸给他人。由于如此以自我为中心，这些套利者自然而然地认为银行也对格林威治事件耿耿于怀。

Yet the extent of predatory trading was less than one might suppose, and certainly less than was later asserted in certain paranoid theories in Greenwich. The partners’ bunkered view of the world made them highly susceptible to conspiracy theories, particularly since such explanations shifted the blame for their losses to others. Being so self-absorbed, the arbitrageurs naturally assumed that the banks were obsessed with Greenwich, too.

但事实很简单，到了9月中旬，华尔街各大银行主要担心的并非长期资本，而是自身利益。鉴于每家银行都持有与长期资本类似的大量交易，平仓是自保之举。尤其是高盛，当时亏损严重，而且距离股票发行仅剩几周时间，急于止损。

But the simple fact is that by mid-September, the Wall Street banks were not principally worried about Long-Term Capital—they were worried about themselves. Given that every bank had many of the same trades as Long-Term, exiting from their positions was a matter of self-preservation. Goldman in particular was steeped in losing trades and, with its stock offering just weeks away, was desperate to cut its losses.

银行究竟是有意从长期基金的亏损中牟利，还是仅仅为了防范格林威治预期的抛售浪潮，其实都无关紧要。无论出于何种动机，都会导致同样的结果——大规模抛售长期基金的交易。一位长期基金的交易员亲眼目睹了他最好的朋友，一位同样是前学者、现就职于德意志银行的同行，抛售了长期基金的头寸。其他交易员也明白，如果长期基金崩盘，将会引发轩然大波。“如果你认为巨头必须抛售，那么你当然也想第一个抛售，”一位高盛伦敦的交易员说道。“我们非常清楚底线在哪里；这并不违法。”

It made no difference whether the banks were consciously trying to profit at Long-Term’s expense or merely protecting themselves from the tidal wave of selling that they anticipated from Greenwich. Either motivation would have produced the same behavior—a wholesale flight from Long-Term’s trades. One Long-Term trader saw his best friend, a fellow former academic now at Deutsche Bank, dumping Long-Term’s positions. The other traders knew that if Long-Term collapsed, the ground would tremble. “If you think a gorilla has to sell, then you sure want to sell first,” noted a Goldman trader in London. “We are very clear on where the line is; that’s not illegal.”

除了美国股票市场（其内幕交易法的执行力度远超其他地区）之外，利用内幕信息进行交易的情况屡见不鲜。像所罗门兄弟和高盛这样的投资银行，它们也设有自营债券交易部门，并公开吹嘘自己如何利用“客户流向”信息。换句话说，当所罗门兄弟或高盛得知客户的动向时，它们往往也会迅速跟进。正因如此，高盛的前任管理层才拒绝涉足自营交易；利益冲突的可能性实在太大。但到了1998年，高盛已被视为一家作风强硬、不择手段的交易公司，早已放弃了任何绅士银行家的伪装。

With the exception of stocks in America, which are specifically subject to insider trading laws that are enforced as nowhere else, trading on private information goes on all the time. Investment banks that also operate proprietary bond-trading desks, such as Salomon and Goldman, publicly boasted of exploiting their knowledge of the “customer flow.” Translated, this meant that when a Salomon or a Goldman got wind of which way its customers were running, it often ran there too—and fast. This was why Goldman’s previous stewards had refused to get involved in proprietary trading; the possibility of conflicts of interest was just too great. But by 1998, Goldman was known as an aggressive, bare-knuckled trader that had long since abandoned any pretense of being a gentleman banker.

当然，如果高盛或其他任何机构利用其在提供投资银行服务过程中获取的信息，理论上可能触犯反欺诈法，尽管这种指控很难举证。科尔津本人并未否认高盛的交易员“在市场上采取了一些可能最终损害长期资本管理公司利益的行动。我们必须保护自己的利益。对此我并不感到抱歉。”

Of course, if Goldman or anyone else took advantage of information it obtained while providing investment banking help, it could, theoretically, be liable under fraud statutes, though such a charge would be difficult to prove. Corzine, for his part, did not deny that Goldman traders “did things in markets that might have ended up hurting LTCM. We had to protect our own positions. That part I’m not apologetic for.”

科尔津否认高盛因为获得了长期债券的使用权而采取了与原本不同的交易策略。他略带讽刺地补充道，考虑到高盛本季度的业绩，听到高盛被指控获取不当利润的消息，着实令人匪夷所思。20

Corzine did deny that Goldman traded any differently as a result of its access to Long-Term than it otherwise would have. Given the kind of quarter it was having, he added wryly, it was strange to hear that Goldman was accused of making untoward profits.20

由于长期基金的交易过于复杂和专业化，它完全受制于这些竞争对手。例如，只有少数几家交易商——摩根大通、所罗门兄弟、瑞银集团、法国兴业银行、信孚银行和摩根士丹利——交易股票波动率。他们知道长期基金持有大量的空头头寸，也知道该基金迟早要通过买入平仓来摆脱困境。因此，这些交易商拒绝出售。走投无路之下，长期基金联系了法国兴业银行，寻求对其持仓的报价，但这家法国银行开出的价格高得离谱：比市场价高出10个百分点！尽管荒谬至极，但当时根本没有其他潜在的股票波动率买家。最终，价格不可避免地飙升。

Long-Term was completely at such rivals’ tender mercy because its trades were so arcane and specialized. For instance, only a handful of dealers—Morgan, Salomon, UBS, Société Générale, Bankers Trust, and Morgan Stanley—traded equity volatility. They knew that Long-Term was massively short, and they knew that sooner or later the fund would have to buy its way out of the trade. So, the dealers refused to sell. In desperation, Long-Term called Société Générale, seeking a bid for its position, but the French bank quoted a ridiculously lofty price: 10 percentage points above the market! Absurd as it was, there were no other potential buyers of equity volatility. Inevitably, the price ballooned.

通常情况下，自由市场会自行消除这类泡沫。例如，1980年，亨特兄弟曾试图垄断白银市场，一度将价格推高至每盎司50美元。但随后，人们开始翻箱倒柜地寻找藏匿的白银，世界各地的废品回收商也开始将其熔化。当这些金属流入市场后，价格回落至每盎司5美元，亨特兄弟也申请了破产。但股票市场波动却极为罕见。没有人会在自家阁楼里囤积波动性，也没有过剩的供应来源。“股票市场波动是终极的空头挤压，”一位资深的长期投资者说道，“当时只有四五个交易商，而且他们拒绝出售。”

Normally, a free market cures such bubbles on its own. In 1980, for instance, the Hunt brothers had tried to corner the silver market, briefly taking the price to $50 an ounce. But then people began to sift through attics for stowed-away silver, and scrap dealers all over the world started melting it down. When all that metal reached the market, the price went back to $5 an ounce, and the Hunts filed for bankruptcy. But equity volatility was a rare bird. No one had stored volatility in his attic, there was no surplus source of supply. “Equity volatility was the ultimate short squeeze,” said a knowledgeable Long-Term employee. “There were only four or five dealers. And they refused to sell.”

随着公司亏损不断加剧，核心合伙人群体与其他合伙人之间原本就存在的隔阂愈演愈烈，最终酿成苦果。不出所料，其他合伙人将巨额财富挥霍殆尽的责任归咎于希利布兰德和哈格尼。霍金斯和希利布兰德原本就不是好朋友，如今更是水火不容，而斯科尔斯和希利布兰德也几乎断绝了往来。这些不满的合伙人不仅对希利布兰德和哈格尼的投资决策感到不满，更对他们专横跋扈、冷漠无情的行事作风深恶痛绝。斯科尔斯认为行事神秘的希利布兰德根本算不上真正的合伙人；拉里也不信任其他合伙人。讽刺的是，这正是银行一直以来所抱怨的。与此同时，麦肯蒂越来越少出现在公司。他饱受背痛的折磨，行动不便，这象征着合伙人们的绝望，而他本人也对梅里韦瑟没有听取他的警告感到愈发愤慨。

As the firm’s losses mounted, the latent divide between the inner group of partners and the others fermented into sour wine. Inevitably, the lesser partners blamed Hilibrand and Haghani for blowing so much wealth. Hawkins and Hilibrand, never the best of friends, became bitter toward each other, and Scholes and Hilibrand were barely speaking. The unhappy partners resented not just Hilibrand’s and Haghani’s investment calls but their domineering, insensitive style. Scholes felt that the secretive Hilibrand hadn’t really been a partner; Larry hadn’t trusted the others. Ironically, it was the same complaint that the banks had been making all along. McEntee, meanwhile, was increasingly absent from the firm. He was immobilized by an aching back, a symbolic expression of the partners’ despair, and increasingly bitter that Meriwether hadn’t heeded his warnings.

鉴于合伙人们神经紧绷，损失惨重，他们表现出紧张情绪也是人之常情。他们不仅损失了财富，也损失了名誉。梅里韦瑟正面临着职业生涯中第二次灾难带来的难以承受的耻辱。而他的交易员们，无论日后成就如何，都将永远因参与长期投资公司那场惊人的兴衰而被人铭记。罗森菲尔德是这群人中最情绪化、对公司最忠诚的人，他深受触动。至少，当痛苦袭来时，他并不害怕放声痛哭。

Given their frayed nerves and their enormous losses, it was only human for the partners to show some tension. They were losing not only their fortunes but also their reputations. Meriwether was facing the unbearable indignity of a second disaster in a once shining career. And his traders, no matter what they might accomplish later, would always be known for their role in Long-Term’s stupendous rise and fall. Rosenfeld, the most emotional of the group and the most devoted to the firm, was touchingly affected. At least he was not afraid to scream when the anguish overcame him.

他的老师默顿也同样心烦意乱；他心烦意乱，判若两人。默顿担心长期基金的倒闭会动摇现代金融的地位——而这正是他毕生追求的——他数度哽咽落泪。毕竟，这位教授也是个非常有人情味的人。斯科尔斯也知道，如果公司倒闭，许多人会认为他们的诺贝尔奖名誉受到了玷污。巧合的是，就在基金暴跌之际，斯科尔斯按计划回到了家乡安大略省的汉密尔顿，在那里，他作为一位从本地人成长为诺贝尔奖得主而受到表彰。他的听众对长期基金的困境一无所知，这位贵宾当时的心情一定十分煎熬。在深情地回忆起自己在那里度过的青春岁月后，斯科尔斯几乎崩溃。21

Merton, his teacher, was upset, too; he was distraught and not himself. Worrying that Long-Term’s collapse would undermine the standing of modern finance—all he had really worked for—Merton repeatedly broke into tears. The professor was wonderfully human, after all. Scholes, too, knew that if the firm failed, many would consider their Nobel Prizes tarnished. Coincidentally, as the fund plummeted, Scholes made a long-scheduled visit to his hometown, Hamilton, Ontario, where he was honored as a local boy turned Nobel laureate. His audience had no idea of the trouble at Long-Term, and the tension on the guest of honor must have been unbearable. After fondly recalling his youth there, Scholes nearly broke down.21

穆林斯的前景也黯淡了。这位精明的银行家曾幻想自己能成为艾伦·格林斯潘的继任者。如今，这已是不可能实现的了。

Mullins’s prospects had darkened, as well. The natty banker had once imagined that he might be a successor to Alan Greenspan. Now that would never happen.

然而，在这无休止的痛苦中，合伙人们大多克制住了自己的情绪。他们心中积压的怨恨从未爆发，或者说极少爆发。他们继续合作，避免争吵或公开指责。事实上，考虑到当时的处境，他们的表现已经相当出色了。这体现了他们之间的紧密联系，尤其是在核心圈子内部。他们私下抱怨，但从不偷懒。如果要追究某个人的责任，至少在那些级别较低的合伙人看来，那就是梅里韦瑟——因为他没有以更强硬的手段管理公司。而且，没有人想责怪JM。

Yet amid this unceasing agony, the partners mostly kept their feelings in check. Their simmering resentments never, or very rarely, bubbled into the open. They continued working together and refrained from shouting or openly pointing fingers. Indeed, given the circumstances, they functioned remarkably well.
