It said something about the bonds between them, particularly within the inner circle. They muttered under their breath but didn’t shirk their jobs. If any one person was to blame, at least in the eyes of the lesser partners, it was Meriwether—for not having run the firm with a stronger hand. And no one wanted to blame J.M.

梅里韦瑟一如既往地将情绪隐藏起来。尽管对亏损深感沮丧，他依然保持冷静——事实上，罗森菲尔德十五年来几乎没见过他发火。梅里韦瑟似乎只有在轻松的时刻才会卸下心防，那时，每周七天、每天十五小时的工作带来的压力，会让他产生一种荒诞感。一天凌晨两点左右，梅里韦瑟和利希、罗森菲尔德以及里卡兹坐在一起。疲惫让他们有些晕眩，于是他们开始讨论，如果公司能挺过来，就该改个名字。梅里韦瑟略带讽刺地说：“我想我们可以叫自己‘免理资本管理公司’。” 这句话逗乐了大家；梅里韦瑟的幽默总是能让他们开心起来。然后，仿佛是为了嘲讽他们惨痛的“杰作”，梅里韦瑟吹了声口哨，补充道：“哦，我们狠狠地打击了瑞士人。” 他指的是瑞银集团，那家瑞士大型投资公司。 JM开玩笑说：“我们再也无法踏足瑞士了——我们一下飞机就会被他们逮捕！”

Meriwether, typically, kept his emotions under wraps. Although deeply distressed about the losses, he stayed cool—indeed, Rosenfeld had barely seen him angry in fifteen years. Meriwether seemed to unburden himself only in moments of levity, when the tension of working fifteen-hour days, seven days a week, gave way to a sense of the absurd. One night, around 2 A.M., J.M. was sitting with Leahy, Rosenfeld, and Rickards. Exhaustion had made them giddy, and the group started to talk about renaming the company if it managed to survive. J.M. said wryly, “I guess we could call ourselves ‘No-Haircut Capital Management.’” That broke up the group; J.M.’s humor always cheered them. Then, as if to make light of their brutal handiwork, Meriwether whistled and added, “Oh, we took the Swiss down big.” He meant UBS, the big Swiss investor. J.M. joked, “We’ll never be able to set foot in Switzerland again—they’ll arrest us the moment we get off the plane!”

当高盛的银行家们四处寻找资金时，他们发现了一个梅里韦瑟没有透露的事实：高盛名单上最有希望的投资人，例如巴菲特、索罗斯、迈克尔·戴尔和沙特王子阿尔瓦利德·本·塔拉勒·本·阿卜杜勒阿齐兹·阿勒沙特，都已经被长期基金联系过，并且拒绝了该基金。科尔津对此感到非常恼火；在如此危急的情况下，长期基金不应该再故弄玄虚。

As Goldman’s bankers looked for money, they discovered a fact that Meriwether hadn’t disclosed: the best prospects on Goldman’s list, such as Buffett, Soros, Michael Dell, and Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal bin Abdulaziz al-Saud, had already been called by Long-Term—and had already rejected the fund. Corzine was more than a little piqued; with the situation so desperate, it was no time for Long-Term to be playing coy.

长期基金每天仍亏损数千万美元。它拼命地试图进行交易对冲，但进展缓慢。它不断调整仓位以维持在熊市的最低水平之上，但不断扩大的亏损，加上不利的市场价格，使其越来越接近破产边缘。该公司试图抛售其在银行的仓位，但美林和高盛对此毫无兴趣：它们在同样的交易中也投入过多。

Long-Term was still losing scores of millions of dollars each day. It was desperately trying to pair its trades, but its progress was slow. It was juggling positions to stay above its minimum at Bear, but its mounting losses, compounded by unfavorable marks (prices), moved it ever closer to the edge. The firm tried to dump positions on its banks, but the Merrills and the Goldmans had no interest: they were overinvested in the same trades.

到九月中旬，合作伙伴们祈祷有三件好事发生才能扭转市场：国会批准向国际货币基金组织提供更多援助，国际货币基金组织批准对巴西的救助计划，以及格林斯潘降低利率。​​在这三件事中，格林斯潘的决定最为关键，也最难以预测。

By mid-September, the partners were praying for three strokes of luck to turn markets: for Congress to approve more aid to the IMF, for the IMF to approve a bailout of Brazil, and for Greenspan to lower interest rates. Of the three, Greenspan was the most crucial and the least predictable.

美联储对信贷利差扩大深感担忧，纽约分行也曾多次收到关于长期投资公司困境的通报。此外，9月11日，路易斯安那州共和党众议员理查德·贝克向格林斯潘发出警告，指出对冲基金正在加剧上市银行的困境。贝克众议员从其一位摩根大通的毕业生那里获得了内幕消息，他在一封颇具洞察力的信中警告说：“我注意到，不受监管且通常杠杆率极高的对冲基金可能导致受监管金融机构的市值大幅下跌。”危机由此公开化。9月15日，乔治·索罗斯向众议院银行委员会发出警告，称俄罗斯的经济崩溃导致了全球信贷紧缩。他指责银行助长了“衍生品交易的连锁反应”——这种措辞似乎受到了他与长期投资公司秘密交易的影响。

The Fed was deeply concerned about the widening of credit spreads, and the New York branch had repeatedly been advised of Long-Term’s plight. Also, on September 11, Representative Richard Baker, a Louisiana Republican, alerted Greenspan to the fact that hedge funds were aggravating the condition of publicly traded banks. In a perceptive letter, Representative Baker, who was getting inside dope from a Morgan graduate on his staff, warned, “It has come to my attention that unregulated hedge funds which are often highly leveraged may be contributing to very substantial declines in the market value of regulated financial institutions.” The crisis was now public. On September 15, George Soros warned the House Banking Committee that Russia’s implosion had led to a global credit crunch. He blamed banks for fostering a “daisy chain of derivatives transactions”—language that seemed informed by his secret dealings with Long-Term.

第二天，9月16日，格林斯潘再次出席同一委员会的听证会。他粉碎了市场的希望，告诉国会降息是不可能的。令人难以置信的是，他再次淡化了对冲基金等不法投资者带来的风险。这位主席的轻信似乎没有止境：“对冲基金受到放贷者的严格监管，”格林斯潘断言。鉴于长期贷款机构的贷款人曾为这家失控的对冲基金提供资金，人们很难不得出这样的结论：格林斯潘要么严重脱离实际，要么故意对听到的声音充耳不闻。至少，鲁宾部长承认，牛市不可避免地削弱了许多银行家的谨慎意识。“在经历了五六七年的良好业绩之后，”他告诉委员会，“放贷者往往会变得不那么谨慎。” 22

The following day, September 16, Greenspan went before the same panel. He dashed the market’s hopes, telling Congress that a rate cut was out of the question. Incredibly, he again downplayed the risks posed by rogue investors such as hedge funds. The chairman’s credulity seemed to know no bounds: “Hedge funds are strongly regulated by those who lend the money,” Greenspan asserted. Given that Long-Term’s lenders had bankrolled the runaway hedge fund, it is hard not to conclude that Greenspan was either woefully out of touch or willfully deaf to what he had heard. Secretary Rubin, at least, acknowledged that the bull market had inevitably dulled many bankers’ sense of prudence. “Where you’ve had five, six, seven years of good results,” he told the panel, “people who extend credit tend to get a little less careful.”22

金融往往带有某种诗意的公正；它对鲁莽之徒的惩罚尤为严厉。长期基金的债权人发现，他们过去的宽容加剧了当前的危机。通常情况下，当普通客户违约时，贷款机构会持有保证金作为储备，而长期基金的资产理论上可能跌至零。银行愿意在不扣除任何费用的情况下为长期基金提供融资，使得该基金得以在极限边缘运作。如今，如果它违约，将一无所有。

Finance is often poetically just; it punishes the reckless with special fervor. Long-Term’s creditors were discovering that their past leniency had made the current crisis worse. Whereas when a typical client defaulted, a reserve would exist in the form of margin money held by lenders, Long-Term could theoretically drop all the way to zero. The banks’ willingness to finance Long-Term without any haircuts had enabled the fund to operate right up to the edge. Now, if it defaulted, nothing would be left.

不出所料，贷款方对他们所造成的后果感到震惊。“我们根本没想到他们会遇到麻烦——这些人可是以风险管理著称的。他们传授了风险管理方法，他们设计了这套方法，”美林证券风险经理丹·那不勒斯回忆道，他曾非常享受与合伙人在爱尔兰打高尔夫球的时光。“天知道，我们当时面对的是诺贝尔奖得主！” 讽刺的是，只有一群极其聪明的家伙才能把华尔街推入如此危险的境地。能力稍逊的人既无法获得融资，也无法吸引到足以催生如此巨大泡沫的追随者。

Not surprisingly, the lenders were horrified by what they had wrought. “We had no idea they would have trouble—these people were known for risk management. They had taught it; they designed it,” reflected Dan Napoli, the Merrill risk manager who had so enjoyed golfing with the partners in Ireland. “God knows, we were dealing with Nobel Prize winners!” Ironically, only a very intelligent gang could have put Wall Street in such peril. Lesser men wouldn’t have gotten the financing or attracted the following that resulted in such a bubble.

一个确凿的迹象表明，围绕该基金的信贷网络正在收紧。当时正与伯克希尔·哈撒韦公司合并的通用再保险公司几乎每天都在与长期基金就其交易定价问题进行争论。通用再保险公司衍生品子公司的伦敦负责人托尼·伊利亚（Tony Iliya）曾为长期基金的日元互换交易提供融资，他甚至在半夜叫醒东京的同事，向该基金提出索赔。

In a sure sign that the credit net around the fund was tightening, General Re, an insurance company that was in the process of merging with Berkshire Hathaway, was contesting Long-Term’s “marks”—that is, arguing about where to price its trades—virtually every day. Tony Iliya, the London-based head of General Re’s derivatives subsidiary, which had financed yen swaps with Long-Term, was waking people in Tokyo in the middle of the night to press claims against the fund.

就连摩根大通——它一方面向格林威治提供资金——另一方面也在仔细评估其对长期基金的风险敞口，为可能的违约做好准备。“情况会非常糟糕，”一位摩根大通的高管私下透露。破产并不能阻止衍生品交易对手方扣押抵押品。如果长期基金申请破产，它可能会发现传真机里塞满了来自其约五十家交易对手的索赔函。事实上，如果长期基金违约其七千份衍生品合约中的任何一份，都会自动触发其他所有合约的违约，这些合约的名义价值约为1.4万亿美元。令人匪夷所思的是，甚至仅仅是考虑破产本身就被视为违约行为。长期基金的律师们甚至都不愿提及“破产”这个词。他们把讨论包装成一场幼稚的游戏。一位律师会问另一位：“如果有一只基金亏损了很多钱，你认为它会申请破产吗？”尽管梅里韦瑟装模作样，但他心里清楚，自己只有不到一周的时间来挽救他的公司。

Even J. P. Morgan, which was offering capital to Greenwich with one hand, was sifting through its exposure to Long-Term to prepare for a possible default with the other. “It was going to be really ugly,” a Morgan executive confided. Bankruptcy does not prevent derivative parties from seizing collateral. If Long-Term filed, it could expect to find its fax machine humming with claims from each of its fifty or so counterparties. In fact, if Long-Term defaulted on any of its seven thousand derivative contracts, it would automatically trigger a default in every one of the others, which covered some $1.4 trillion in notional value. In a bizarre touch, even a contemplation of bankruptcy was considered an act of default. Long-Term’s lawyers wouldn’t even mention the B-word. They cloaked their deliberations in a childlike game. One lawyer would ask another, “What if there was a fund that lost a lot of money; do you think it would file?” Notwithstanding this playacting, Meriwether knew he had less than a week to save his firm.

长期证券的母公司所罗门美邦（Salomon Smith Barney）一直对救援行动置身事外。但9月16日星期三，所罗门美邦突然介入。该行派出了股票风险管理主管罗伯·阿德里安（Rob Adrian）、负责衍生品交易的安迪·康斯坦（Andy Constan）以及桑迪·韦尔（Sandy Weill）的儿子马克·韦尔（Marc Weill）前往格林威治。他们原本计划与高盛和其他银行代表参加一场范围广泛的会议。然而，当所罗门美邦一行人下午4点刚过抵达时，会议已经结束了。阿德里安注意到现场异常安静；大门紧闭，交易大厅空无一人。哈加尼（Haghani）将他们带到一间办公室，直截了当地宣布，议程上只剩下一个议题。“我们需要资金，”他说道。23

Salomon Smith Barney—Long-Term’s progenitor—had stayed aloof from the rescue efforts. But on Wednesday, September 16, Salomon jumped into the action. The bank sent Rob Adrian, Salomon’s head of risk management for equities, Andy Constan, who ran derivatives trading for the firm, and Marc Weill—Sandy’s son—to Greenwich. They expected to join Goldman and others of the banks in a wide-ranging meeting. However, by the time the Salomon group arrived, just after 4 P.M., the meeting was over. Adrian noticed an eerie quiet; doors were closed, and the trading floor was deserted. Haghani took them to an office and bluntly announced that only one topic remained on the agenda. “We need money,” he noted.23

哈加尼提出要带他们看那些账簿，这在当时已是公开的秘密，但韦尔知道父亲厌恶套利，不想因为看得太多而让所罗门陷入困境。于是，一行人开车回家了。

Haghani offered to show them the books, which were now an open secret, but Weill, knowing of his dad’s antipathy to arbitrage, didn’t want to compromise Salomon by seeing too much. So the group drove home.

第二天，所罗门兄弟派来了一支更资深的团队：史蒂夫·布莱克、托马斯·马赫拉斯和彼得·赫希。此时，哈格尼似乎已经惊呆了。在过去的五个交易日里，长期投资公司亏损了5.3亿美元。由于亏损持续不断，情况显得更加糟糕。9月10日星期四，该公司亏损了1.45亿美元；星期五，亏损了1.2亿美元。接下来的一周，亏损丝毫没有停止：星期一，长期投资公司亏损了5500万美元；星期二，亏损了8700万美元。9月16日星期三的情况尤其糟糕：亏损了1.22亿美元。如同圣经中描述的瘟疫一般，亏损没有丝毫缓解。哈格尼以一种冷静的口吻回顾了这些损失，仿佛这些损失发生在别人身上一样。他无法接受长期投资公司的多元化策略竟然失败了。8月份的亏损他还能理解，但9月份的亏损——在市场本应复苏的时候——却让他百思不得其解。美国掉期利差已经飙升至惊人的83个点；令人难以置信的是，英国掉期利率竟然高达88！仅这两笔交易，长期基金的巨额头寸就足以使其破产。哈加尼愤慨地指责华尔街，尤其是高盛，联手打压这家孤立无援的基金。24

The next day, Salomon sent a more senior team: Steve Black, Thomas Maheras, and Peter Hirsch. By now Haghani seemed to be in shock. Over the last five trading days, Long-Term had lost $530 million. The losses seemed even worse for having been so relentless. On Thursday, September 10, the firm had lost $145 million; on Friday, $120 million. The next week it hadn’t stopped: on Monday, Long-Term dropped $55 million; on Tuesday, $87 million. Wednesday, September 16, was especially bad: $122 million. Like a biblical plague, the losses gave no respite. Haghani went over the losses with a clinical air, as if they had happened to someone else. He couldn’t get over the fact that Long-Term’s diversification hadn’t worked. The August losses he understood, but September’s—when the markets should have recovered—baffled him. U.S. swap spreads had climbed to an astonishing 83 points; U.K. swaps, incredibly, were at 88! Long-Term’s massive positions in these two trades alone could bankrupt it. Haghani bitterly blamed Wall Street, especially Goldman, for ganging up on the friendless fund.24

尽管对高盛怒不可遏，合伙人们却异想天开地指望着这家银行能救世主一把。罗森菲尔德和其他人整周都在给高盛打电话，语气越来越绝望。尽管高盛最初持乐观态度，但至今仍未筹集到资金，而长期基金现在估计需要的不是20亿美元，而是40亿美元——这可是一笔巨款。9月17日星期四上午，梅里韦瑟、希利布兰德、罗森菲尔德和默顿前往高盛，力陈他们的诉求。科尔津和身材瘦削、棱角分明的首席财务官约翰·泰恩接待了他们。

Though furious at Goldman, the partners were, quixotically, counting on the bank as a savior. Rosenfeld and others were calling Goldman throughout the week, with growing desperation. Despite Goldman’s initial optimism, it hadn’t yet raised the money, and Long-Term now figured that it needed not two but four billion dollars—quite a sum. Meriwether, Hilibrand, Rosenfeld, and Merton went to press their case with Goldman on Thursday morning, September 17. Corzine and John Thain, the narrow-set, angular chief financial officer, ushered them in.

罗森菲尔德用一句话概括了这句话：“你们是我们最后的希望。”

Rosenfeld said, in so many words, “You’re our last chance.”

周四晚些时候，梅里韦瑟向比尔·麦克唐纳通报了长期基金的困境。讽刺的是，该基金当天盈利，这是当月首次盈利。但利润微薄，只有600万美元——远远不够，也为时已晚。长期基金的净资产已缩水至15亿美元。令人震惊的是，距离俄罗斯违约仅仅过去了一个月。短短一个月内，长期基金就损失了十分之六的资本，这是华尔街历史上最惨重的崩盘之一。

Later that Thursday, Meriwether advised Bill McDonough of Long-Term’s plight. Ironically, the fund made money that day, its first profit all month. But the profit was a pittance, $6 million—far too little and too late. Long-Term’s equity was down to $1.5 billion. It was astonishing to think that only a month had passed since Russia’s default. In that one month, Long-Term had lost six tenths of its capital, one of Wall Street’s epic collapses.

周五，长期投资公司接到了高盛的电话。泰恩指出，能拿出长期投资公司所需金额的人寥寥无几。巴菲特或许能出一大笔，索罗斯也可能愿意，但长期投资公司已经联系过他们，以及高盛名单上的几乎所有人。高盛的投资银行家彼得·克劳斯当天上午就和巴菲特谈过。巴菲特重申了他之前告诉希利布兰德的那番话，表示自己不感兴趣。其他人也都拒绝了。因此，泰恩认为这笔投资根本不可能。泰恩没有透露自己私下的想法：从各方面来看，长期投资公司似乎要倒闭了。

On Friday, Long-Term heard from Goldman. Thain noted that very few people could invest in the amounts that Long-Term needed. Buffett might be good for a chunk, and Soros might, but Long-Term had already called them, as well as virtually everyone else on Goldman’s list. Peter Kraus, a Goldman investment banker, had talked to Buffett that very morning. Buffett had reiterated that, as he had told Hilibrand, he wasn’t interested. The others had refused, too. Therefore, Thain didn’t think it was possible. Thain didn’t bother to say what he was thinking privately: to all appearances, Long-Term was going under.

但高盛并未放弃。当天，克劳斯和巴菲特又进行了几次通话。巴菲特最大的顾虑在于他不喜欢长期资本管理公司（Long-Term）复杂的合伙结构。他对该公司旗下的各种子基金毫无兴趣，更遑论长期资本管理公司（LTCM）错综复杂的细节。几十年前，巴菲特就因为类似的原因解散了自己的合伙企业；他不需要别人的合伙企业。但巴菲特告诉克劳斯，如果仅仅是收购长期资本管理公司的投资组合——当时该投资组合已大幅缩水——而不保留梅里韦瑟、他的团队或公司，这或许可行。两人进一步完善了这个想法，开始讨论伯克希尔和高盛联合竞购长期资本管理公司的资产，或许还可以联合保险公司AIG。与此同时，克劳斯向科尔津汇报了这一进展。当天，高盛一直在讨论伯克希尔-高盛联合竞购的可能性，以及其他拯救该基金的方案。

But Goldman didn’t stop trying. Kraus and Buffett spoke several more times that day. The biggest stumbling block for Buffett was that he didn’t like Long-Term’s complicated partnership structure. He had no interest in its various feeder funds and certainly none in the tangled details of LTCM. Buffett had folded his own partnership decades ago, partly for such reasons; he had no use for somebody else’s. But if it was just a matter of buying Long-Term’s portfolio—which now was pretty beaten down—without keeping Meriwether, his staff, or his company, that might work, Buffett told Kraus. Refining this thought, the two began to talk about Berkshire and Goldman jointly bidding for Long-Term’s assets, perhaps along with AIG, the insurer. Meanwhile, Kraus reported this slight progress to Corzine. Throughout the day, Goldman kicked around the notion of a Berkshire-Goldman bid as well as other ways of saving the fund.

在长期投资公司，情况变得岌岌可危。贝尔斯登公司来信明确表示，将停止清算低于5亿美元的资产——这显然是切断资金来源前的最后一步。现在是时候和摩根大通谈谈了。尽管长期投资公司认为，从法律角度讲，它可以随时动用贷款额度，但合伙人还是想听听摩根大通的官方说法。公司内部银行家穆林斯给大卫·普弗鲁格打了电话。普弗鲁格之前已经冒着风险承担了富利银行的贷款，为长期投资公司提供了保障。他会再次出手相助吗？

At Long-Term, the situation was becoming dire. The firm got a letter from Bear flatly stating its intention to stop clearing below $500 million—clearly the final step before cutting it off. Now it was time to talk to Chase. Though Long-Term felt that legally it could draw on its loan facility anytime, the partners wanted to hear Chase say so, too. Mullins, the house banker, called David Pflug. Pflug had already stuck his neck out for Long-Term by assuming Fleet’s loan. Would he do it again?

身为银行家的银行家，普夫鲁格深知，如果摩根大通和其他银团成员提供资金，他们可能就拿不回这笔钱了。但如果摩根大通不提供资金，它就可能承担责任。此外，普夫鲁格担心，如果长期投资公司倒闭，可能会波及整个华尔街。而华尔街是他们的重要客户。普夫鲁格打电话给摩根大通董事长沃尔特·希普利，说道：“我想我们别无选择。”

Pflug, a banker’s banker, knew that if Chase and the other syndicate members did fund, they might not get the money back. But if Chase didn’t fund, it could be liable. Moreover, Pflug was afraid that if Long-Term collapsed, it might reverberate all over Wall Street. And Wall Street was a major client. Calling Walter Shipley, Chase’s chairman, Pflug said, “I don’t think we have any choice.”

与此同时，长期市场再次暴跌。令人难以置信的是，股票波动率飙升至35%。美国互换利率扩大至84.5个百分点。雪上加霜的是，抵押贷款利差扩大了7个百分点，垃圾债券利差扩大了5个百分点。道琼斯指数下跌218点；日本股市跌至1986年以来的最低水平。

Meanwhile, Long-Term’s markets were tumbling again. Incredibly, equity volatility jumped to 35 percent. U.S. swaps widened to 84½. And on it went. Mortgage spreads widened by 7 points, junk bonds by 5. The Dow fell 218 points; Japanese stocks fell to levels not seen since 1986.

周五晚上，罗森菲尔德给摩根公司的彼得·汉考克打了电话。汉考克住在马马罗内克，和罗森菲尔德是同一个镇子，而且他的孩子和罗森菲尔德的孩子在同一所学校上学。这位平时沉着冷静的套利交易员此刻却异常焦躁不安；他担心贝尔斯登会停止投资，并透露长期投资公司可能撑不过下周。长期投资公司的信贷额度正在减少，而关于其持仓的谣言（其中许多是虚假的或被严重夸大的）更是雪上加霜。

Friday evening, Rosenfeld called Morgan’s Peter Hancock, who lived in Mamaroneck, the same town as Rosenfeld, and whose children attended the same school as Rosenfeld’s. The usually collected arbitrageur was highly agitated; he was petrified that Bear would pull the plug and confided that Long-Term might not survive the following week. Long-Term was losing its credit lines, and its woes were being exacerbated by rumors (many of them false or wildly exaggerated) about its positions.

罗森菲尔德一时兴起，建议摩根大通的银行家给高盛的泰恩打电话。据目前所知，这是第一次有人要求两家银行协调行动。汉考克和泰恩当晚就通了电话。

On a whim, Rosenfeld suggested that the Morgan banker call Thain at Goldman. As far as is known, that was the first time anyone had asked the banks to coordinate their efforts. Hancock and Thain spoke that night.

克劳斯是高盛收购案的牵头人，周五他带着妻子和一位客户去纽瓦克听贝多芬音乐会。中场休息时，克劳斯溜到公用电话亭，拨通了奥马哈的电话。他和巴菲特一起估算了一下交易金额。巴菲特说他要去旅行，克劳斯便回去继续听贝多芬音乐会，没有跟妻子或客户提起这件事。之后，巴菲特给即将被伯克希尔收购的通用再保险公司的约瑟夫·布兰登打了电话。“有些人已经崩溃了。他们可能撑不下去了，”这位亿万富翁警告说。“对于任何不提供抵押品或不追缴保证金的人，不要接受任何借口。不要接受任何借口。” 随后，他飞往西雅图，与比尔·盖茨率领的一个团队会面，该团队计划在阿拉斯加和一些西部国家公园进行为期两周的假期。

Kraus, the banker spearheading the Goldman effort, had taken his wife and a client to a Beethoven concert in Newark on Friday. At intermission, Kraus ducked out to a pay phone and dialed Omaha. He and Buffett penciled out some numbers for a deal. Buffett said something about going on a trip, and Kraus went back to Beethoven, saying nothing to his wife or the client. Then Buffett called Joseph Brandon of General Re, Berkshire’s soon-to-be insurance acquisition. “There are folks that are in meltdown. They may not make it,” the billionaire warned. “Accept no excuses for anyone who doesn’t post collateral or make a margin call. Accept no excuses.” Then he hopped a plane for Seattle to meet a Bill Gates–led group that was planning a two-week holiday in Alaska and some of the western national parks.25

现在，人们又开始憧憬巴菲特能够拯救长期投资公司——巧合的是，七年前他正是这么做的，拯救了所罗门兄弟公司。然而，科尔津认为美联储也应该参与进来。他联系了麦克唐纳，麦克唐纳又与其他几家大型银行的负责人进行了交谈。所有银行家都一致认为，长期投资公司的困境正在打压市场。此外，他们还担心，如果长期投资公司倒闭，可能会造成严重的市场动荡。

Now the dream was alive that Buffett would rescue Long-Term—as he had, coincidentally, Salomon seven years earlier. Nonetheless, Corzine thought the Fed should be brought into the loop. He called McDonough, who also spoke with the heads of other big banks. To a man, the bankers said that Long-Term’s troubles were depressing markets. Moreover, they were worried that if Long-Term failed it could have a seriously destabilizing effect.

考虑到这些担忧，科尔津提议让高盛向美联储介绍长期基金的投资组合。梅里韦瑟同意美联储应该听取简报，但他自然更希望由长期基金直接进行。因此，周六，这位前央行行长穆林斯致电麦克唐纳，邀请美联储前往格林威治。

With such fears in mind, Corzine offered to have Goldman brief the Fed on Long-Term’s portfolio. Meriwether agreed that the Fed should be briefed but naturally preferred to have Long-Term do it directly. Thus, on Saturday, Mullins, a former central banker, called McDonough and invited the Fed to Greenwich.

当然，麦克唐纳早就开始考虑长期方案了。他知道自己最终可能不得不出手干预；他也知道这样做会让美联储面临批评。监管者既是保护者，又是教父。他不喜欢公开作秀；当他能够谨慎地运用权力时，效果最佳，只需威胁采取行动或哄骗他人为他效力即可。在麦克唐纳看来，最理想的情况是由华尔街的某位私人领袖来策划解决方案。他和纽约联储主席约翰·怀特黑德讨论了谁能做到这一点。曾经，花旗银行的沃尔特·里斯顿或高盛的格斯·利维或许能够重振华尔街。当然，一个世纪前，老摩根完美地扮演了这一角色。但如今谁能胜任呢？麦克唐纳和怀特黑德一致认为：无人能及。华尔街有很多银行家，但没有摩根。26因此，尽管美联储只同意听取简报，不发挥积极作用，但麦克唐纳已准备好迈出第一步。

McDonough, of course, had been thinking about Long-Term for a while. He had known that eventually he might have to step in; he also knew that doing so would expose the Fed to criticism. A regulator is part protector, part godfather. He dislikes a public spectacle; he is most effective when he can wield his power discreetly, by merely threatening to act or by cajoling others to do his bidding. Most ideal, in McDonough’s mind, would be for some private Wall Street leader to orchestrate a solution. He and John Whitehead, the chairman of the New York Fed, talked about who could do it. Once, Walter Wriston of Citibank or Gus Levy of Goldman could have rallied Wall Street. A century ago, of course, J. P. Morgan, Sr., had played the part to perfection. But who could play the part today? McDonough and Whitehead agreed on the answer: no one. Wall Street had many bankers but no J. P. Morgan.26Therefore, although the Fed was agreeing only to be briefed, not to play an active role, McDonough was ready to take the first step.

会议原定于周日举行。但麦克唐纳计划前一天晚上飞往伦敦。他决定不取消会议——因为这会扰乱市场——而是派他的副手彼得·费舍尔代替他前往长期基金。麦克唐纳临行前，向格林斯潘和鲁宾简要介绍了情况，并告知他们长期基金的融资尝试失败了。27

The meeting was scheduled for Sunday. But McDonough was planning to fly to London the night before. He decided not to cancel—it would upset markets—and to send Peter Fisher, his deputy, to Long-Term instead. Before McDonough left, he briefed both Greenspan and Rubin and told them that Long-Term’s attempt to raise capital had failed.27

但高盛仍在跟进此事。巧合的是，瑞银集团驻瑞士的衍生品专家大卫·索罗当时正在纽约参加朋友的婚礼。科尔津找到了他，询问瑞银是否愿意参与长期基金的募资活动。索罗说：“可以，但你知道我们是他们最大的股权投资者吗？我认为我们的利益并不完全一致。” 科尔津对此毫不知情，显然很恼火，挂断了电话。他已经厌倦了试图拯救一家他显然仍然一无所知的公司。

But Goldman was still on the case. By chance, David Solo, the Swiss-based derivatives maven at UBS, was in New York for the wedding of a friend. Corzine tracked him down and asked if UBS would want to join a fund-raising effort for Long-Term. Solo said, “Fine, but do you realize we’re their biggest equity investor? I don’t think our interests are exactly aligned.” Corzine, who hadn’t known, rang off, obviously irritated. He was getting tired of trying to rescue a firm about which, apparently, he was still in the dark.

科尔津周六也和巴菲特通了电话，不过前提是巴菲特能从阿拉斯加峡湾深处用手机连上。“他当时在船上漂来漂去，”科尔津回忆道，语气中带着明显的恼火，“信号经常断断续续，两三个小时都联系不上。” 28巴菲特说，他以前对大自然没什么兴趣，这次旅行是被比尔·盖茨硬拉来的，“船上的人想过去看看驼鹿，而我想赶紧连上卫星信号。信号真是糟糕透了。” 29

Corzine also talked to Buffett on Saturday, though only when Buffett could get a connection via cell phone from the depths of an Alaskan fjord. “He was doing this float-around,” Corzine recalled, his exasperation showing. “You’d lose contact and couldn’t speak for two or three hours.”28 According to Buffett, who had never had much use for nature and had been arm wrestled into the trip by Bill Gates, “The guy in the boat wanted to go over and look at the moose, and I wanted to get in line with the satellite connection. It was just a horrible connection.”29

但他最终还是表达了自己的意思。巴菲特愿意让高盛处理细节，但他绝不希望自己的投资由长期资本管理公司（LTCM）管理，也不想与约翰·梅里韦瑟有任何瓜葛。之后，通话中断了。

But he got his point across all the same. Buffett was willing to let Goldman handle the details, but under no circumstances did he want his investment to be managed by LTCM or to have anything to do with John Meriwether. Then the connection blacked out.

10

10

在美联储

AT THE FED

市场可能会停止运作。

Markets would . . . possibly cease to function.

——威廉· J·M· C ·D ·奥诺夫，总裁

—WILLIAM J. MCDONOUGH, PRESIDENT,

纽约 联邦储备银行​​​​​​





FEDERAL RESERVE BANK OF NEW YORK





美联储成立于1913年，其原因众多，但最根本的原因是人们不再信任私人银行家来引导金融市场。在美联储华尔街周期性的危机。政府常常不得不低声下气地向私人银行家寻求帮助。到了进步时代，人们对​​托拉斯抱有怀疑，并坚信监管的重要性，因此他们希望有一家银行能够代表公众利益。自那时起，美联储就一直扮演着公共服务的角色，但它与私人银行和华尔街保持着密切的联系。这是一个微妙的角色，因为美联储的职责是监管银行业，而不是庇护银行家。它必须保护市场的正常运作，同时又不能显得与它所监管的银行走得太近——过于保护。

THE FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM was created, in 1913, for many reasons, but the underlying one was that people no longer trusted private bankers to shepherd the financial markets. Prior to the Fed’s founding, the government had had no effective weapon to temper the country’s economic cycles, nor was there much it could do to ease the periodic crises that afflicted Wall Street. Too often, the government had had to go hat in hand to a private banker for help. By the Progressive Era, with its suspicion of trusts and its faith in regulation, people wanted a bank that would represent the public interest. Ever since, the Fed has been a public servant but one that works in close proximity to private banks and to Wall Street. It is a delicate role, for the Fed is supposed to regulate banking but not to shelter bankers. It must protect the functioning of markets without appearing to be too close—too protective—of the banks it watches over.

美联储最常出现在公众视野的是其位于华盛顿的理事会，该理事会肩负着调整短期利率这一备受瞩目的职责。理事会主席是美国抗击通胀的首席人物，从更广义的角度来看，他也是经济的掌舵人。自1987年起担任主席的艾伦·格林斯潘，或许是历任主席中最受尊敬的一位，这得益于在他任期内美国经济的卓越表现。格林斯潘的公开讲话风格晦涩难懂，但这反而更加巩固了他作为美国经济先知的形象。

The side of the Fed most often seen in public is its governing board, in Washington, which has the high-profile job of adjusting short-term interest rates. The chairman of this body is the country’s chief inflation fighter and, in a larger sense, the steward of its economy. Alan Greenspan, who has been chairman since 1987, is probably the most respected of all those who have held the job, thanks to the economy’s stellar performance during his tenure. If Greenspan has perfected a convoluted, often impenetrable style of public utterances, this has only heightened his image as the nation’s economic oracle.

格林斯潘对美联储各分支机构的依赖程度远超人们的普遍认知，尤其是纽约联储。纽约联储的诸多职责之一，便是充当华盛顿观察市场的窗口。纽约联储主席威廉·麦克唐纳身材魁梧，他与私人银行家保持密切联系，并将所听到的消息汇报给格林斯潘。他的助手是彼得·费舍尔，1998年时，这位42岁的官僚从哈佛法学院毕业后便直接加入了美联储。费舍尔负责美联储的交易部门，并监管着价值4500亿美元的政府债券组合。当格林斯潘想要收紧或放松货币政策时，费舍尔和他的团队会通过增持或减持证券来执行指令。

More than is commonly realized, Greenspan relies on the Fed’s individual branches, particularly on the New York Fed, which, among its other roles, functions as Washington’s periscope into markets. William McDonough, the beefy president of the New York Fed, kept in close touch with private bankers and reported on what he heard to Greenspan. His associate was Peter Fisher, in 1998 a forty-two-year-old bureaucrat who had joined the Fed straight out of Harvard Law School. Fisher ran the Fed’s trading desk and oversaw a $450 billion portfolio of government securities. When Greenspan wanted to tighten or loosen monetary conditions, Fisher and his staff actually carried out the directive by either buying more securities or selling some.1

身高六英尺三英寸、一头灰白卷发的费舍尔，早在长期基金危机爆发之前就一直关注着对冲基金。在他看来，对冲基金只不过是经济日益倾向于将原本由商业银行承担的工作（例如贷款和投资）分配给专业机构的又一例证。例如，上世纪80年代，当拉丁美洲各国政府无力偿还贷款时，损失完全由几家大型银行承担。但到了90年代，当墨西哥违约时，数十家对冲基金和共同基金及其投资者——他们承担了银行向新兴市场提供资金的传统角色——却遭受了损失。费舍尔对对冲基金的总体看法与默顿关于长期基金本质上是一家银行的观点并无太大差异。

Fisher, who is six feet, three inches tall with graying curly hair, had been paying attention to hedge funds well before the Long-Term crisis. In his view, hedge funds were merely one more sign of the economy’s increasing tendency to parcel out to specialists the jobs (such as lending and investing) that had previously been handled by commercial banks. For instance, in the 1980s, when Latin American governments couldn’t pay their loans, the damage had been borne entirely by a few big banks. But in the 1990s, when Mexico defaulted, the pain was felt by dozens of hedge funds and mutual funds, and by their investors—who had assumed the banks’ traditional role of providing capital to emerging markets. Fisher’s overall view of hedge funds was not dissimilar to Merton’s notion that Long-Term was essentially a bank.

然而，长期基金并非银行，美联储对冲基金也无权管辖。如果费舍尔要求查看长期基金（或任何对冲基金）的账簿，理论上它可以拒绝。但实际上，费舍尔经常与对冲基金的交易员交谈，其中一些人会畅所欲言地分享他们对市场的看法，而所有人都默认美联储的管辖权。周日，费舍尔收到了一份邀请。

However, Long-Term was not a bank, and the Fed does not have authority over hedge funds. Had Fisher demanded to see Long-Term’s books—or any hedge fund’s—it could in theory have refused. But in practice, Fisher routinely talked to traders at hedge funds, some of whom freely shared their opinions on the market and all of whom tacitly recognized the Fed’s authority. And for Sunday, Fisher had an invitation.

费舍尔住在新泽西州梅普尔伍德，这是一个距离格林威治很远的中产阶级郊区。他取消了观看八岁儿子和六岁女儿踢足球的计划，搭乘助理迪诺·科斯的吉普车前往格林威治。在长期投资公司办公室，他们与财政部助理部长、鲁宾在高盛的前合伙人加里·根斯勒以及另一位美联储官员会合。

Canceling plans to watch his eight-year-old son and six-year-old daughter play soccer, Fisher, who lived in Maplewood, New Jersey, a middle-class suburb light-years from Greenwich, hitched a ride with Dino Kos, one of his assistants, in Kos’s Jeep. At Long-Term’s offices, they rendezvoused with Gary Gensler, an assistant secretary of the Treasury and former partner of Rubin’s at Goldman Sachs, and with another official from the Fed.

Long-Term 的办公室一片寂静。Sun 公司的工作站大多无人值守。Mullins 和其他合伙人一起领着访客进入会议室，途中经过一个房间，Fisher 注意到 Jacob Goldfield 和他的高盛团队正在那里仔细研究 Long-Term 的文件。

Long-Term’s offices were quiet. The Sun workstations were mostly unattended. Mullins ushered the visitors into the conference room with the other partners, passing by a room where, Fisher noticed, Jacob Goldfield and his Goldman team were poring over Long-Term’s files.

经过一番简短的寒暄后，希利布兰德向官员们出示了一份极其机密的文件，就连长期投资公司的大多数员工都从未见过。这份文件被称为“风险汇总表”。长期投资公司的运作方式令外人难以理解，因为它的许多头寸都包含多笔交易。更糟糕的是，它的衍生品账簿简直是一团乱麻，每份合约都与其他合约相互对冲。风险汇总表通过汇总长期投资公司在每个市场的风险敞口，简化了投资组合。

After some brief cordialities, Hilibrand showed the bureaucrats a document so secret that even most of Long-Term’s employees had never seen it. The document was known as the “risk aggregator.” Long-Term was hard for outsiders to understand because many of its positions consisted of multiple trades. What’s more, its derivatives book was a monstrosity of contracts each of which was offset by other contracts. The risk aggregator simplified the portfolio by summarizing Long-Term’s exposure to each individual market.

费舍尔仔细研究了这份报告，就像病理学家扫描X光片一样。听着汇报，他意识到情况危急。风险汇总表中的每一项风险都列在单独的一行中，这些行按类别分组到不同的方框中。例如，第一个方框是账户“LT003”，涉及“美元（FI/US）”，即美元固定收益。第一个方框中的第一条记录是：

Fisher studied the report like a pathologist scanning an X ray. As he listened to the presentation, he realized that the patient was in critical condition. Each exposure in the risk aggregator was listed in a separate row, and the rows were grouped into separate boxes by category. For instance, the first box was Account “LT003,” which dealt with “USD (FI/US),” or U.S. dollar fixed income. The first entry in the first box said:

美元Y-shift...2s-10s @ 45...-2.80...5 y-sh...14.00

USD_Y-shift . . . 2s-10s @ 45 ...-2.80 ...5 y-sh . . . 14.00

这条线使长期基金能够接触到两年期和十年期国债收益率曲线趋平的风险敞口，当时两者的利差为45个基点。每变动5个基点，长期基金就可能获利（或亏损）280万美元。预计该交易一年内的波动幅度为5次这样的波动，这意味着，根据其模型，长期基金的年度风险敞口不超过1400万美元。

This line gave Long-Term’s exposure to a flattening of the yield curve between two-year and ten-year Treasury bonds, for which the spread was then 45 basis points. For each movement of five basis points, Long-Term could make (or lose) $2.8 million. The expected volatility of the trade over one year was five such jumps, meaning that, according to its models, Long-Term’s yearly exposure was no more than $14 million.

下一条记录“USD_Z+D-shift”显示了长期基金对短期利率变动的风险敞口。直到第五行，费舍尔才看到一个真正令人震惊的数字。在“USD_Swap Spread”项下，长期基金的风险敞口高达2.4亿美元——但这假设互换利差的波动幅度始终保持在每年15个点的历史水平。而考虑到互换利差在1998年就已经波动了40个点，这个假设简直荒谬至极。仅仅第一页就有25条记录。而风险汇总表足足有15页。如此庞大的数据量令人麻木。

The next entry, “USD_Z+D-shift,” showed Long-Term’s exposure to a change in short-term interest rates. It wasn’t until the fifth line that Fisher saw a truly alarming number. Under “USD_Swap Spread,” Long-Term showed an exposure of $240 million—but that was assuming that swap spreads stuck to their historic volatility of only 15 points a year. And given that swaps had already moved in a 40-point range in 1998, that assumption had become laughable. There were twenty-five entries in all—on just the first page. And the risk aggregator went to fifteen pages. The sheer mass of it was numbing.

谈到国际交易，希利布兰德向费舍尔展示了英国债券和互换交易、丹麦抵押贷款交易、新西兰互换利差交易、香港债券交易，以及在瑞典、瑞士、德国、法国和比利时等国的各种敞口交易。费舍尔还看到了意大利、西班牙和荷兰的债券交易。

Turning to the international trades, Hilibrand showed Fisher rows of entries for bonds and swaps in Great Britain, mortgages in Denmark, swap spreads in New Zealand, bonds in Hong Kong, and various exposures in Sweden and Switzerland as well as in Germany, France, and Belgium. Fisher saw bonds in Italy, Spain, and the Netherlands, too.

随后，费舍尔看到了更多条目，这次是关于该基金的股票持仓。他对股票市场波动率的巨额条目感到震惊。接下来是长期基金在新兴市场的投资：巴西、阿根廷、墨西哥、委内瑞拉、韩国、波兰、中国、台湾、泰国、马来西亚和菲律宾。俄罗斯有三项条目，其中包括“俄罗斯硬通货方向性投资”——这意味着该基金进行了方向性投资，或者说是直接投机。

And then Fisher saw more entries, now pertaining to the fund’s positions in stocks. He was shocked by the massive entries for stock market volatility. Then came Long-Term’s exposures in emerging markets: Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Venezuela, Korea, Poland, China, Taiwan, Thailand, Malaysia, and the Philippines. There were three entries for Russia, including “Russia Hard Currency Direction”—meaning that the fund had gone directional, or speculated outright.

起初，这么多交易同时崩盘着实令人震惊。但仔细审视投资组合后，费舍尔恍然大悟：长期基金的交易之间存在关联——它们在崩盘前就已经存在相关性。“他们在世界各地都做了同样的价差交易，”费舍尔心想。根斯勒也有类似的想法：危机期间，相关性总是趋近于1。地震发生时，所有市场都会震颤。长期基金为何对此如此惊讶？

At first it seemed astonishing that so many trades should have collapsed simultaneously. But gazing over the portfolio, Fisher had an epiphany: Long-Term’s trades were linked—they had been correlated before the fact. “They had the same spread trade everywhere in the world,” Fisher thought. Gensler had a related thought: During a crisis, the correlations always go to one. When a quake hits, all markets tremble. Why was Long-Term so surprised by that?

合伙人完成风险汇总分析后，又仔细审查了另一份文件，按交易对手方细分了长期基金的风险敞口。理论上，交易对手方受到抵押品的保护。但实际上，如果该基金突然破产，所有交易对手方都会试图同步抛售，抵押品的价值必然暴跌。此外，长期基金的每个互换交易对手方都将处于“裸奔”状态，即只持有合约的一方，而另一方已不复存在。每个交易对手方都会争相中和其单边互换合约，导致市场如同银行挤兑般崩溃。长期基金估计，如果这种情况发生，其17家最大的交易对手方——包括美林、高盛、摩根大通和所罗门兄弟等银行——将面临总计28亿美元的损失。

When the partners finished with the risk aggregator, they went through another document, breaking down Long-Term’s exposure according to counterparty. In theory, its counterparties were protected by their collateral. But in fact, if the fund suddenly failed, each of its counterparties would attempt to sell—in unison—and the value of the collateral would necessarily plunge. Moreover, each of Long-Term’s swap counterparties would be “naked,” or holding on to only one side of a contract for which the other side no longer existed. Each counterparty would rush to neutralize its one-sided swaps, overwhelming markets as in a bank run. If that happened, according to Long-Term, its seventeen biggest counterparties—banks such as Merrill, Goldman, Morgan, and Salomon—would stand to lose a total of $2.8 billion.

费舍尔瞥了一眼那个数字，心想：“在正常的市场环境下，这或许还说得过去。”但市场早已摇摇欲坠，现在可能彻底失控。费舍尔在心里把潜在损失调整到30亿到50亿美元，但这仍然只是个估计。不仅仅是长期基金面临风险——整个华尔街都岌岌可危。谁知道损失何时会开始让整个系统不堪重负？谁知道这个系统是否存在崩溃的临界点？费舍尔听到的消息越多，他的心情就越糟糕。“我并不担心市场下跌，”他低声说道，“我担心的是市场根本就不会交易。”

Fisher eyeballed the number and thought, “That might be plausible in a normal market.” But markets were already sorely frayed; now they could go totally haywire. Mentally, Fisher adjusted the potential losses to $3 billion to $5 billion, and even that was a guess. It wasn’t just Long-Term that was on the hook—it was all of Wall Street. Who knew when the losses would start to strain the system? Who knew if the system had a breaking point? The more Fisher heard, the worse he felt. “I’m not worried about markets trading down,” he confided. “I’m worried that they won’t trade at all.”

参观者们对情况有了大致了解后，小组开始探讨一些解决方案。根斯勒指出，1990年，垃圾债券巨头德崇证券（Drexel Burnham Lambert）的破产申请实际上缓解了垃圾债券市场的恐慌情绪。

Once the visitors had an overview, the group began to explore some solutions. In 1990, Gensler noted, a bankruptcy filing by Drexel Burnham Lambert, the junk-bond king, had actually eased the panic in junk bonds.

但里卡兹解释说，在这种情况下，破产并不会阻止任何事情发生；它只会敲响警钟，促使交易对手开始追讨抵押品。而且，德雷克塞尔危机只涉及债券，不涉及衍生品。长期投资公司的情况要复杂得多。费舍尔知道，试图理清所有重叠的互换交易是徒劳的。此外，为公司找到买家也是不可能的。没有人会碰股票波动率之类的头寸。“所以，这是一种新的模式，”根斯勒沮丧地说。

But in this case, Rickards explained, bankruptcy would not stop anything; it would merely ring the bell for counterparties to start going after their collateral. And the Drexel crisis had involved only bonds, not derivatives. Long-Term’s case was far more complex. It would be hopeless to try to unravel all those overlapping swaps, Fisher knew. Furthermore, finding a buyer for the firm was out of the question. Nobody would touch positions such as equity volatility. “So this is a new paradigm,” Gensler said unhappily.

合伙人尤其对贝尔斯登施加的压力感到不安。费舍尔总结说，长期基金需要的是喘息之机。经过一番讨价还价，套利者和官员们想出了一个方案。假设银行在四天后的周四前来考察，前提是必须严格保密地向他们展示投资组合？经过一番快速研究后，银行可以在下周日的拍卖会上竞标这些资产。等到周一市场重新开市时，长期基金实际上就已经消失了。

The partners were particularly agitated about the pressure from Bear Stearns. What Long-Term needed, Fisher concluded, was breathing space. After some give-and-take, the arbitrageurs and officials came up with a plan. Suppose the banks were to visit four days hence, on Thursday, on the understanding that they would be shown the portfolio in the strictest confidence? After a quick study, the banks could bid for the assets at an auction the following Sunday. When markets reopened Monday, Long-Term would effectively have disappeared.

但这个计划存在一个问题：里克兹提醒他们，长期公司只剩下15亿美元的股权。扣除贝尔斯登冻结的现金以及保证金账户等占用的资金后，剩余的自由现金仅为4.7亿美元。该公司每天都在亏损数亿美元。很可能，长期公司撑不到周四。

But there was one problem with the plan: Long-Term had only $1.5 billion of equity left, Rickards reminded them. Deducting the cash locked up at Bear Stearns and the monies tied up in margin accounts and the like left free cash of exactly $470 million. The company had been losing hundreds of millions of dollars a day. In all probability, Long-Term wouldn’t make it until Thursday.

现在是周日下午四点，距离东京股市开盘仅剩几个小时。他们花了六个小时研究这个问题，却一无所获。官员们去了旁边的房间，根斯勒给财政部打了电话。中期选举还有六周；到目前为止，经济一直是政府唯一看好的方面。政府最不希望看到的就是金融崩溃。费舍尔回到合伙人身边，告诉他们：“你们很冷静，我们也很冷静，但华盛顿那边已经乱成一团了。”然后他向梅里韦瑟伸出手。梅里韦瑟说，无论如何，他都想妥善处理这个问题。“谢谢，”费舍尔说，“你是第一个提前告诉我们的人。”

And now it was 4 P.M. on Sunday, only hours from the opening of the Tokyo markets. They had spent six hours working on the problem and solved nothing. The officials went to a side room, and Gensler called the Treasury. Midterm elections were six weeks off; thus far, the economy had been the government’s one bright spot. The last thing it wanted was a financial meltdown. Rejoining the partners, Fisher told them, “You’re composed and we’re composed, but Washington is going crazy.” Then he held out his hand to Meriwether. J.M. said that, come what may, he wanted to handle the problem right. “Thanks,” Fisher said. “You’re the first one to tell us in advance.”

周日下午，科尔津与巴菲特通了电话。当时巴菲特仍在阿拉斯加峡湾巡视，似乎对能否拯救长期资本仍持观望态度。当晚，这位高盛首席执行官致电费舍尔，告诉他不要指望私人出手相救。费舍尔当时只有一个念头：“我们该如何熬过下一个周末？”他第一次提出了联合多家银行的想法。科尔津对巴菲特的收购计划并不看好，但他鼓励费舍尔这么做。²

Sunday afternoon, Corzine talked to Buffett, who was still on a tour of the Alaskan fjords and still seemed uncertain about a rescue of Long-Term. That night, the Goldman chief called Fisher and told him not to count on a private rescue. Fisher had one thought: “How do we get to another weekend?” For the first time, he broached the idea of getting a group of banks together. Corzine, who was feeling pessimistic about the Buffett bid, encouraged him.²

摩根大通也有类似的想法。过去24小时里，摩根大通东京和伦敦的分析师们一直在下载与高盛和美联储所见文件类似的资料。有趣的是，摩根大通的分析师们惊讶地发现，长期投资公司的交易并不算特别复杂。这些交易规模很大，但并不异常。不过，鉴于长期投资公司是一家债券发行公司，摩根大通对其股票投资组合的规模感到惊讶。

J. P. Morgan was having similar thoughts. Morgan analysts in Tokyo and London had spent the past twenty-four hours downloading files similar to those that had been seen by Goldman and by the Fed. Interestingly, the Morgan analysts were surprised that Long-Term’s trades hadn’t been more exotic. They were big but not unusual. Still, since Long-Term was known as a bond house, Morgan was surprised by the size of its equity book.

摩根看到了两种选择。一是让基金破产。这样一来，每家银行都会各自扣押抵押品；摩根估计，这将使大型银行每家损失5亿至7亿美元。二是摩根可以自己收购该投资组合的大部分份额。但这会带来另一个问题。摩根知道其他银行也已经看过这个投资组合。如果任何一家银行收购了它，它就会像长期基金一样——整个华尔街都会争相抢购。所以，所有银行都必须参与进来。

Morgan saw two options. One was to let the fund fail. Then every bank would seize collateral for itself; Morgan figured that would cost the bigger banks $500 million to $700 million apiece. Or, Morgan could buy big chunks of the portfolio itself. But that would pose another problem. Morgan knew that other banks had seen the portfolio. If any one bank acquired it, it would be in the same spot as Long-Term—the whole Street would be shooting at it. So all the banks would have to be in.

科尔津的想法与摩根类似，于是在周日下午给美林董事长科曼斯基打了电话。科曼斯基一半是俄罗斯东正教犹太人，一半是爱尔兰天主教徒，百分之百是布朗克斯人，当时正在准备日落后的犹太新年庆祝活动。“长期资本管理公司（LTCM）遇到了一些真正的麻烦。看起来他们一两天内就要破产了。”科尔津告诉他。他提到高盛的人去过格林威治——但没有提到高盛独家查阅了长期资本管理公司的账目。他也没有提到高盛和巴菲特目前正在考虑收购。

Corzine, who had been having thoughts similar to Morgan’s, called Komansky, the Merrill Lynch chairman, Sunday afternoon. Komansky, who is half Russian Orthodox Jewish, half Irish Catholic, and 100 percent The Bronx, was preparing for Rosh Hashanah at sundown. “LTCM has some real problems. It looks like they’re going bankrupt in a day or two,” Corzine told him. He mentioned that Goldman’s people had been in Greenwich—but not that Goldman had gotten an exclusive peek at Long-Term’s books. Nor did he mention that Goldman and Buffett were, at the moment, mulling over a takeover bid.

科曼斯基以假日为由挂断了电话，让他​​的得力助手、美林证券总裁赫伯·艾利森接听。科尔津当时正在打高尔夫，但当晚10点30分，他和艾利森终于联系上了。华尔街的顶级银行家们开始逐渐地互相沟通。由于他们的粗心大意、鲁莽的融资以及为了讨好一位自以为是的客户而做出的徒劳尝试，华尔街的银行共同酿成了这场灾难。他们最初的本能是尽可能地榨干长期投资公司的每一滴油水，但现在他们开始意识到，这样做也可能拖垮他们自己。他们一个接一个地得出结论：他们或许不得不做一件最违背他们本性的事情：他们或许不得不合作。

Komansky, citing the holiday, rang off and had Herb Allison, his trusted lieutenant and Merrill’s president, pick up the ball. Corzine was playing golf, but at 10:30 that night, he and Allison connected. Bit by bit, Wall Street’s top bankers were starting to talk to one another. Through their carelessness, their reckless financing, their vain attempts to ingratiate themselves with a self-important client, the Wall Street banks had created this fiasco together. Their instinct had been to savage as much of the carcass of Long-Term as possible, but now they had begun to see that doing so would risk bringing themselves down as well. One by one, they were concluding that they might have to do the very thing that was most antithetical to their nature: they might have to work together.

9月21日星期一，又是糟糕的一天。美国互换利差攀升至87；英国互换利差更是飙升至95。活跃国债和非活跃国债之间的利差——两者都是绝对安全的美国政府信用——竟然惊人地跃升至19个点。（就在一个月前，利差还维持在正常的6个点。）价格呈现出一种不真实的状态，仿佛交易员们正在抛售任何与长期基金有关联的资产，哪怕只是最微弱的传闻。银行正在“操纵市场”，趁着还有抵押品可捞的时候，尽可能地攫取所有抵押品。所罗门美邦的高管史蒂夫·布莱克从他在东京的团队那里得知，高盛正在“疯狂”操纵长期基金的交易，尤其是互换交易。高盛则表示，所罗门美邦在欧洲也采取了同样的做法。³

Monday, September 21, was yet another bad day. U.S. swap spreads climbed to 87; U.K. swaps soared to 95. The spread between on-the-run and off-the-run Treasurys—both of them perfectly safe U.S. government credits—jumped, incredibly, to 19 points. (Just a month before, the spread had been the customary 6 points.) Prices had an air of unreality, as though traders were selling anything connected, even by the faintest rumor, to Long-Term. Banks were “bending the marks” against the fund, grabbing all the collateral they could while there still was something to grab. Steve Black, the Salomon Smith Barney executive, heard from his troops in Tokyo that Goldman was “banging the s——” out of Long-Term’s trades, especially swaps. Goldman said Salomon was doing the same in Europe.³

临近中午，一笔数额不大的交易就让股票波动率飙升了3个百分点，达到38%！期权市场暗示着灾难性的波动水平，或许每个月都会崩盘。罗森菲尔德觉得这简直荒谬；他认为波动率上升仅仅是因为交易员们知道长期基金很脆弱——而当时这很可能是事实。4这种明显的操纵让该基金损失了1.2亿美元。正如文尼·马托内所预言的那样，贪婪的交易员们正在完成俄罗斯危机引发的长期基金的灭亡之功。

Around midday, equity volatility jerked up 3 percentage points on one rather small trade—to 38 percent! The options market was now implying a catastrophic level of volatility, maybe a crash every month. To Rosenfeld, it was simply nonsensical; it felt as though volatility was rising only because traders knew that Long-Term was vulnerable—which at that point was probably true.4 The obvious manipulation cost the fund $120 million. As Vinny Mattone had prophesied, hungry traders were finishing the job of killing Long-Term that the crisis in Russia had begun.

长期基金周一的总亏损为5.53亿美元，巧合的是，与一个月前的亏损额相同。但从百分比来看，周一的亏损更为严重：它吞噬了长期基金三分之一的权益，使其仅剩不到10亿美元。而该基金当时的资产规模仍超过1000亿美元。因此，即使不计衍生品，其杠杆率也超过100比1——这在投资史上是一个惊人的数字。如今，如果长期基金再亏损哪怕1%，它就将彻底破产。

Long-Term’s total loss on Monday was $553 million, coincidentally equal to its loss of a month before. In percentage terms, this Monday’s loss was far worse: it ate through a third of Long-Term’s equity, leaving it with just under a billion dollars. And the fund still had more than $100 billion in assets. Thus, even omitting derivatives, its leverage was greater than 100 to 1—a fantastic figure in the annals of investment. Now, if Long-Term lost even a mere 1 percent more, it would be wiped out.

尽管损失的具体数额要等到市场收盘后才能知晓，但合伙人当天早些时候就知道周一的情况已成定局。律师吉姆·里卡兹致电贝尔斯登执行副总裁沃伦·斯佩克特，威胁说如果贝尔斯登停止清算，他们将提起诉讼。基金已经没有什么可损失的了，里卡兹也心知肚明。随后，里卡兹致电摩根大通，要求立即从循环信贷额度中拨出5亿美元。

Though the magnitude of the loss wouldn’t be known until after the markets closed, the partners knew early in the day that Monday was high noon. Jim Rickards, the attorney, called Warren Spector, Bear’s executive vice president, and threatened to sue if Bear stopped clearing. The fund had nothing to lose, and Rickards knew it. Then Rickards called Chase and demanded an immediate dispersal of $500 million from the revolver.

几分钟后，总共二十四家银团银行开始争吵起来。基金主管里克兹和布鲁斯·威尔逊坚持说，银行别无选择，只能放贷。但客户去世前，他们会承认吗？坚定的普夫卢格表示，摩根大通会提供资金。不仅如此，他还电传给其他银行，告诉他们，在他看来，他们也必须提供资金。长期投资公司获得了4.75亿美元，大部分在当天就到位了（只有法国农业信贷银行坚持不肯放贷）。这笔贷款对长期投资公司的股权没有任何帮助，但对贝尔斯登来说，这笔钱算是进了账。或许，它能争取几天的时间。

Minutes later, the syndicate banks, twenty-four in all, began to squawk. Rickards and Bruce Wilson, the fund’s controller, insisted that the banks had no choice but to lend the money. But would they own up to it before the client expired? The stalwart Pflug said that Chase would fund. What’s more, he telexed the other banks and told them that, in his opinion, they would have to fund as well. Long-Term got $475 million, most within that day (only Crédit Agricole held out). The loan did nothing for Long-Term’s equity, but it was money in the box at Bear. It bought, perhaps, a few days’ time.

在美联储，费舍尔与高盛的科尔津和泰恩、美林的艾利森以及摩根大通董事长道格拉斯·华纳通了电话。这些通话让费舍尔确信，私人融资的努力正在失败——更重要的是，市场正处于崩溃的边缘。他越来越觉得这三大银行应该采取一些集体行动。艾利森和科尔津整天都在通话。艾利森不像一些交易员那样好胜，自然而然地倾向于联合行动。科尔津仍然隐藏着巴菲特的身份，他也加入了进来，但只是作为后备。那个星期一，科尔津联系了保险公司AIG的董事长莫里斯·格林伯格，并说服他加入巴菲特和高盛的联合行动。AIG拥有必要的衍生品专业知识，有了第三位成员，这个团队会更加强大。巴菲特当时正在旅行，无法联系，但他已经明确表达了自己的策略：买入投资组合，让世界看到它现在掌握在可靠的人手中，让价格回升——然后卖出。

At the Fed, Fisher was in touch by phone with Goldman’s Corzine and Thain, Merrill’s Allison, and J. P. Morgan’s chairman, Douglas Warner. The calls convinced Fisher that the private efforts to raise capital were failing—and, what’s more, that markets were on the brink of a disaster. He had a growing sense that the three big banks should take some collective action. Allison and Corzine spoke throughout the day. Allison, not as competitive as some of the traders, naturally gravitated toward a joint approach. Corzine, still concealing the Buffett card, did so as well, but only as a backstop. That Monday, Corzine contacted Maurice Greenberg, the chairman of AIG, the insurer, and convinced him to join the Buffett-Goldman bid. AIG had the necessary derivatives expertise, and with a third member, the group would be stronger. Buffett, who was traveling, was again unreachable, but he had made his strategy clear: buy the portfolio, let the world see that it was now in strong hands, let prices recover—and then sell.

在摩根大通，由门多萨、摩根大通全球债券主管彼得·汉考克和股票主管克莱顿·罗斯组成的小组也在考虑独立运作。奇怪的是，创建了长期投资组合的美林，却是三大银行中对情况了解最少的。艾利森周一花了一整天时间了解情况。当天下午，他派了一个团队乘直升机前往格林威治，以了解他的客户究竟有多绝望。希利布兰德和罗森菲尔德在犹太新年假期期间仍在工作，他们带领来访者查看了投资组合——还有谁没看过账簿吗？梅里韦瑟表现得异常冷静，甚至有些优雅。“我们误判了市场，”他承认道。

At Morgan, a group involving Mendoza; Peter Hancock, Morgan’s global bond chief; and Clayton Rose, its head of equities, was thinking about going it alone, too. Curiously, Merrill, which had brought Long-Term into being, was the least well informed of the big three banks. Allison spent Monday trying to get up to speed. He dispatched a team to Greenwich via helicopter in the afternoon to find out just how desperate his client was. Hilibrand and Rosenfeld, who were working through the Rosh Hashanah holiday, took the visitors through the portfolio—was there anyone left who had not seen the books? Meriwether remained remarkably calm, even graceful. “We misjudged the markets,” he admitted.

但JM仍然觉得长期基金的交易是稳健的——只要它能挺过这场暂时的危机，这场流动性的短暂崩溃。JM多么希望这只基金能够存活下来。他就像一个即将拥抱爱人的男人，只希望自己能驾驶飞机在暴风雨中安全着陆。但是追加保证金通知、交易员的攻击、谣言的散布、高盛的雇佣兵……

But J.M. still felt that Long-Term’s trades were sound—if it could just get past the temporary crisis, the momentary implosion of liquidity. J.M. so much wanted the fund to live. He was like a man about to embrace his lover, if only he can land his plane in a storm. But the margin calls, the traders shooting at them, the rumormongers, the mercenaries at Goldman . . .

美林团队对长期交易的庞大规模感到震惊，尤其是在股票和欧洲互换（流动性远不如美国互换）方面。“你们意识到这些头寸相当可观吗？”美林的理查德·邓恩问道。套利交易员们似乎并没有意识到这一点。美林的人对高盛无处不在的交易员戈德菲尔德的神秘出现感到困惑；他正低头摆弄着笔记本电脑，不敢直视美林的人。

The Merrill team was stunned by the huge dimensions of Long-Term’s trades, especially in equities and European swaps (which were far less liquid than U.S. swaps). “Do you realize these are fairly substantial positions?” Merrill’s Richard Dunn inquired.5 The arbitrageurs seemed not to get it. The Merrill people were puzzled by the mysterious presence of Goldfield, the ubiquitous Goldman trader; he was bent over his laptop and didn’t look the Merrill people in the eye.

周一晚上，伦敦时间——格林威治时间仍是下午——瑞银经理安迪·西西里亚诺决定必须亲自去看看这家对冲基金。他搭乘协和式飞机，在飞机上偶遇维克多·哈加尼。尽管两人抵达时都饱受时差困扰，但他们都无意入睡。他们共乘一辆豪华轿车前往格林威治，在那里，JM、罗森菲尔德和获奖者们正在会议室里举行会议。高盛仍然驻扎在大楼里，如同已经建立滩头阵地的入侵军队。会议室里弥漫着一种碉堡般的紧张气氛。合伙人们不停地谈论着高盛的交易员们如何用手机给纽约打电话——当然，他们不可能知道交易员们在说什么。但“阴谋论”已经成了合伙人们的执念。谈完高盛之后，他们又把怒火发泄到贝尔斯登身上，虚伪地暗示贝尔斯登的信件是毫无预兆地突然发出的。他们似乎完全忘记了之前有多么轻蔑，现在却沮丧地不明白朋友们为什么抛弃了他们。6

Monday night in London—still afternoon in Greenwich—Andy Siciliano, the UBS manager, decided he had to see the hedge fund first-hand. He hopped the Concorde and bumped into Victor Haghani on the flight. Though both were jet-lagged by the time they arrived, neither man had any intention of sleeping. They shared a limousine to Greenwich, where J.M., Rosenfeld, and the laureates were holding court in the conference room. Goldman was still in the building, like an invading army that had established a beachhead. In the conference room, a bunker mentality prevailed. The partners couldn’t stop talking about how the Goldman traders were calling New York on their cell phones—though of course they couldn’t know what the traders were saying. But the notion that a conspiracy had done them in had become an obsession for the partners. When they finished with Goldman, they heaped their fury on Bear Stearns, disingenuously implying that Bear had sprung its letter out of the blue. Conveniently forgetting how disdainful they had been before, the partners abjectly wondered why their friends had abandoned them.6

罗森菲尔德似乎第一百次仔细查看了投资组合，逐笔评估交易前景。西西里亚诺是唯一的局外人，他突然意识到，竟然没有人反对他的到来。长期投资公司现在没有任何秘密可言。事实上，西西里亚诺出奇地受欢迎。他就像一座桥梁，连接着公司曾经避之不及、如今却又迫切需要的外部世界。合伙人恳求西西里亚诺帮忙，传播他们仓位的内在逻辑——为了资金，什么都愿意做。他们仍在抛售。但他们的谈话中弥漫着一丝自欺欺人的气息。复仇的念头如同酸奶凝块般在暗流涌动：只要长期投资公司能够注入新的资金，价格就会迅速反弹，那些与他们做空的卑鄙投机者就会跪地求饶。

Rosenfeld went over the portfolio for what seemed the hundredth time, sizing up the prospects trade by trade. Siciliano, the only outsider, realized with a start that no one objected to his presence. Long-Term had no secrets now. In fact, Siciliano was strangely welcome. He was a bridge to the outside world the firm had shunned but now so desperately needed. The partners implored Siciliano to help, to spread the word of their positions’ inherent logic—anything for capital. They were still selling. But a faint odor of self-delusion colored their confabulations. The theme of revenge bubbled beneath the surface like the curd of sour milk: if only Long-Term could throw fresh capital into the breach, prices would snap back and those nasty opportunists who had traded against them would be begging for mercy.

到了周一，市场传言纷纷将价格的每一次小幅下跌归咎于格林威治的抛售。但主流媒体却出奇地保持沉默。自从梅里韦瑟9月2日发出那封信的第二天起，媒体就对这家失控的对冲基金只字未提。华尔街的评论员们正忙于等待克林顿总统在莫妮卡·莱温斯基性丑闻中作证的录像带的发布，据说这才是导致市场低迷的原因。费舍尔则认为，性丑闻与华尔街的低迷毫无关系。在他看来，长期基金就像一具尸体一样拖累着市场。

By Monday, market gossips were attributing every slight dip in prices to selling from Greenwich. But the general press had been stunningly silent. Since the day after Meriwether’s September 2 letter, the press hadn’t breathed a word on the runaway hedge fund. Wall Street pundits were preoccupied with the expected release of a videotape of President Clinton’s testimony in the Monica Lewinsky sex scandal, which was said to be depressing markets. Fisher was of the opinion that sex had nothing to do with what was depressing Wall Street. In his opinion, Long-Term was weighing on markets like a corpse.

在与各家银行交谈后，费舍尔得出结论：华尔街愿意参与救援，但鉴于银行家们彼此间的不信任和竞争倾向，没有一家银行愿意冒险发起救援。这样一来，救援就只能交给美联储了。科尔津仍在观望，他也持同样的观点。如果高盛的独家竞标失败，他希望避免出现一场混战。他更倾向于在美联储的保护下携手合作。赫伯·艾利森也在敦促费舍尔促成一些银行在中立的立场上进行谈判。7意识到时间紧迫，费舍尔邀请三大银行到美联储共进早餐。

After talking with the banks, Fisher concluded that Wall Street would be willing to participate in a rescue, but given the bankers’ mutual distrust and competitive predispositions, none would take the risk of initiating one. That would leave it to the Fed. Corzine, still hedging his bets, had the same thought. Should Goldman’s exclusive bid fall through, he wanted to avoid a competitive free-for-all. He would much prefer to join hands under the Fed’s protective banner. And Herb Allison was pushing Fisher to bring some banks together on neutral ground.7 Sensing that time was running out, Fisher invited the big three banks to breakfast at the Fed.

费舍尔坚称，他和麦克唐纳都不担心长期银行的损失，甚至也不担心其他公司可能遭受的损失。如果17家银行损失总额在30亿至50亿美元之间的估计属实，那么每家公司最多损失3亿美元也完全可以承受。即便损失无法承受，这些华尔街私人银行也只是将股东的资金置于风险之中；它们无权向美联储寻求帮助。

Fisher maintained that neither he nor McDonough was worried about the loss to Long-Term, nor even about the potential loss to other firms. If the estimate of $3 billion to $5 billion over seventeen banks were correct, losses of up to $300 million per firm were certainly tolerable. Even if they were not tolerable, these private Wall Street banks had put their own shareholders’ money at risk; they had no call for help from the Federal Reserve.

费舍尔关注的是更广泛的“系统性风险”概念：如果长期银行破产，债权人迫使其仓促且无序地清算，他担心这将损害整个金融体系，而不仅仅是部分大型参与者。格林斯潘后来使用了“市场瘫痪”一词，描绘出市场一片混乱，甚至可能停止运作的景象——这意味着交易员将停止交易。麦克唐纳也表达了类似的担忧——如此多的市场和如此多的参与者遭受损失，将引发清算、利率剧烈波动以及进一步损失的恶性循环：“市场……可能会停止运作一天或更长时间。”

Fisher’s concern was the broader notion of “systemic risk”: if Long-Term failed, and if its creditors forced a hasty and disorderly liquidation, he feared that it would harm the entire financial system, not just some of its big participants. Greenspan later used the phrase “a seizing up of markets,” conjuring up the image of markets in such disarray that they might cease to function—meaning that traders would cease to trade.8 McDonough evoked a parallel fear—that losses in so many markets and to so many players would spark a vicious circle of liquidations, extreme fluctuations in interest rates, and then still further losses: “Markets would . . . possibly cease to function for a period of one or more days and maybe longer.”9

自大萧条以来，美国尚未经历过真正的经济崩溃，尽管有时市场似乎正朝着崩溃的方向发展。但对金融末日的恐惧激发了丰富的文学创作，其极端表现形式与自然灾害、大规模计算机故障等题材作品如出一辙。抽象地说，没有人能断言系统性风险是否构成真正的威胁——这个词本身就模糊不清——但监管机构自然会倾向于谨慎行事。当费舍尔准备会见他的客人时，亚洲已经陷入衰退，甚至可能已经陷入萧条；俄罗斯无疑正在滑向衰退；南美洲也岌岌可危。在美国，信贷利差的大幅扩大表明贷款机构拒绝放贷——这是经济收缩的典型迹象。前一天，9月21日，美国国债收益率触及了5.05%的低点。据《华尔街日报》援引一位经济学家的话称， “如今国债纯粹是恐慌的体现”——人们害怕持有除国债以外的任何债券。 10 从瑞士到巴西再到新加坡，股市暴跌。如果费舍尔当时身处华尔街之外，他会注意到美国经济仍然相当活跃（与1929年秋季华尔街大崩盘时的情况截然不同，当时美国经济已经陷入衰退）。事实上，大多数美国人甚至没有意识到这场金融危机的存在——鲁宾部长称这是半个世纪以来最严重的金融危机。 11但美联储的脑海中却对此心知肚明。

Since the Great Depression, the United States has not experienced anything like a real meltdown, though at times markets have seemed to be spinning toward one. But the fear of a financial Armageddon has inspired an imaginative literature that at the extreme has its parallel in natural-disaster plots, mass-computer-failure sagas, and the like. In the abstract, no one can say whether systemic risk presents a real threat—the very phrase is vague and ill defined—but regulators naturally err toward caution. As Fisher readied to meet his guests, Asia was already in the throes of a recession if not a depression; Russia was most certainly falling into one; and South America was on the brink. In the United States, the vast widening in credit spreads suggested that lenders were refusing to lend—a classic sign of a contraction. The previous day, September 21, Treasury yields had touched a low of 5.05 percent. According to an economist quoted in The Wall Street Journal, “Treasurys are purely a measure of fear now”—fear of holding any bond that was not a Treasury.10 Stocks had plunged everywhere from Switzerland to Brazil to Singapore. Stepping back from Wall Street, Fisher would have noticed that America’s economy was still quite vibrant (unlike in the fall of 1929, when, by the time of the Great Crash on Wall Street, it was already in recession). Indeed, most Americans were unaware that the financial crisis—which Secretary Rubin said was the worst in half a century—even existed.11 But it certainly existed in the mind of the Fed.

费舍尔的客人——美林证券的科曼斯基和艾莉森、高盛的科尔津和泰恩以及摩根大通的门多萨——于当天早上7点半抵达。如果说高管的心情可以从其股价看出，那么费舍尔的客人当时肯定心情非常糟糕。美林证券的股价为54美元；而在7月份，其股价曾高达108美元——是现在的两倍。摩根大通的股价下跌了超过40%。高盛当时尚未上市——这意味着科尔津的心情可能是所有人中最糟糕的。在这样的市场行情下，高盛的股票根本没有出售的希望。

Fisher’s guests—Komansky and Allison from Merrill, Corzine and Thain from Goldman, and Mendoza from J. P. Morgan—arrived at 7:30 that morning. If an executive’s mood may be surmised from the price of his stock, Fisher’s visitors must have been dour indeed. Merrill’s stock was at $54; in July, it had traded at $108—twice as high. Morgan’s was off by more than 40 percent. Goldman had not yet gone public—which meant that Corzine’s mood was probably the worst of anyone’s. In such a market, Goldman could have no hope of selling stock.

费舍尔说他周日在长期投资公司待了一整天，对系统性风险感到担忧。银行家们对此表示理解。美林证券几乎处于震惊状态——并非因为长期投资公司，而是因为自身债券亏损不断扩大。美林一直刻意回避套利交易，从未想过自己会如此脆弱。摩根大通的情况虽然稍好一些，但本季度业绩也十分糟糕。高盛8月和9月的交易亏损高达15亿美元（与长期投资公司相比，这简直是天文数字）。因此，当费舍尔暗示系统面临危险时，他的客人们虽然未必会深入思考全球资本主义的运作机制，但至少出于各自的原因，都乐于相信他的话。

Fisher said he had spent Sunday at Long-Term and was worried about systemic risk. The bankers were sympathetic. Merrill Lynch was in something close to shock—not over Long-Term but over its own spiraling losses in bonds. Merrill, which had purposely shied away from arbitrage-type operations, had never dreamt that it could be so vulnerable. Morgan, though in better shape, had been having a terrible quarter. Goldman was on its way to a stunning (except in comparison with Long-Term) trading loss for August and September of $1.5 billion. Thus, when Fisher suggested that the system was in danger, his guests, without necessarily pondering the fine points of global capitalism, were, at least for their own reasons, more than ready to believe him.

每家银行都提出了不同的解决方案。科尔津透露，高盛知道一位潜在的竞购者——一位“大佬”——正伺机而动。摩根大通的门多萨提出了一项复杂的方案：持有长期债券的银行可以“买入”（即收购）其债券交易，而持有长期股票的银行则可以瓜分其股票交易。科曼斯基本人也持有大量长期债券，他认为这个方案过于复杂且耗时。他和艾利森倾向于成立一个简单的财团进行投资。

Each bank floated a different possible solution. Corzine revealed that Goldman knew of a prospective bidder—a “Mr. Big”—who was waiting in the wings. Mendoza of Morgan proposed an intricate scheme whereby the banks with debt exposure to Long-Term could “lift” (that is, acquire) its bond trades and those with equity exposure could divvy up its equity trades. Komansky, who owned a slug of Long-Term himself, thought this was far too convoluted and time-consuming. He and Allison favored a simple consortium that would make an investment.

但如果长期基金的股权继续缩水，任何解决方案都行不通。一位银行家承认，银行不得不阻止交易员们对该基金进行投机性操作。科曼斯基粗声粗气地说：“那就让那些雅皮士坐下闭嘴。” 这番话可能是对科尔津说的。科曼斯基后来表示，虽然他记不清具体是这句话，但他听说高盛的交易员们已经把“长期基金的所有持仓”下载到了自己的电脑里，高盛当然否认了这一点。无论如何，关于高盛交易的猜测已经在高管层中流传开来。“我不知道有谁确切知道这件事，”科曼斯基说，“但这个问题确实存在。” 12

But no solution could work if Long-Term’s equity continued to melt away. The banks had to stop their traders from shooting at the fund, one of the bankers admitted. Komansky said gruffly, “Well, just tell the yuppies to sit down and shut up.” The comment may have been directed to Corzine. Komansky said later that while he didn’t specifically recall the remark, he had heard that Goldman’s traders had downloaded “all of Long-Term’s positions” into their own computers, which Goldman of course denied. In any case, the speculation about Goldman’s trading had surfaced among the top executives. “I don’t know anybody who knew it as a fact,” Komansky said. “But the issue was there.”12

银行家们大约在9点半结束会议，同意派出两个小组前往Long-Term公司考察摩根大通的方案。一个小组负责研究如何增持Long-Term公司的债券头寸，另一个小组则负责研究其股票头寸。第三个小组由艾利森领导，将返回美林证券研究联合投资方案。此外，他们还同意邀请Long-Term公司最大的投资者瑞银集团加入。

The bankers adjourned around 9:30, agreeing to send two groups to Long-Term to investigate the Morgan approach. One would explore lifting Long-Term’s bond positions; the other, its equities. A third group, led by Allison, would retreat to Merrill Lynch to study the consortium idea. Also, they agreed to invite UBS, Long-Term’s biggest investor, to join them.

梅里韦瑟泰然自若地迎接了银行家们，但希利布兰德却显得憔悴而紧张；亏损已经让这位交易大师身心俱疲，而他个人的杠杆也相当高。此时，长期投资公司与前来洽谈的银行家之间的会面，已经显得刻意而又过于熟悉。合伙人们对那些不情愿的追求者感到厌倦；更糟糕的是，市场波动如此之快，银行家们根本无法判断投资组合的价值。银行家们保守地以折价估值，最终对各个部分的报价加起来几乎等于零。哈加尼似乎对他们极低的估值感到很受伤。“谢谢你们的到来，”他带着责备的语气对一位美林银行家说，“但我们认为你们的判断是错误的。你们应该和我们一起投资。”他就像一个溺水者试图向岸上的救生员提出条件；在他内心深处，他觉得自己是不会沉没的。

Meriwether greeted the bankers with aplomb, but Hilibrand looked haggard and nervous; the losses had taken a toll on the master trader, who was also so personally leveraged. By now, meetings between Long-Term and inquiring bankers had a staged, too-familiar air. The partners were weary of reluctant suitors; what’s more, markets were moving so fast that the bankers had no way of knowing what the portfolio was worth. Conservatively valuing the portfolio at a discount, the bankers arrived at bids for the various pieces that added to little more than zero. Haghani seemed wounded by their minimal valuations. “Thank you for coming,” he told a Merrill banker with an air of rebuke, “but we don’t think you’re right. You ought to be investing with us.” He was like a drowning man trying to dictate terms to a rescuer on shore; in his heart of hearts, he was unsinkable.

但长期投资公司周二再次亏损1.52亿美元，使其净资产降至7.73亿美元。贝尔斯登首席执行官吉米·凯恩告诉费舍尔，长期投资公司目前的现金足以支撑到周二，但周三可能会出现问题。13 该公司在24小时内究竟能做些什么？摩根的方案已经行不通了。科尔津也怀疑“大人物”是否会现身。这样一来，就只能指望艾利森了。

But Long-Term had sustained another loss Tuesday of $152 million, taking its equity down to $773 million. Jimmy Cayne, chief executive of Bear Stearns, advised Fisher that Long-Term had enough cash to get through Tuesday—but Wednesday could be a problem.13 What could it possibly do in twenty-four hours? The Morgan option was dead. Corzine doubted that “Mr. Big” would surface, either. That left it to Allison.

艾利森是一位五十五岁的投资银行家，在美林的高管中实属罕见，因为大多数高管都是从公司庞大的股票经纪人队伍中提拔上来的。典型的美林高管是科曼斯基，他是一位和蔼可亲、身材魁梧的前经纪人，虽然没有大学文凭，却在销售领域叱咤风云。艾利森毕业于耶鲁大学哲学系，拥有斯坦福大学工商管理硕士学位，他更像是一位书卷气十足的学者。他头​​发稀疏，略微秃顶，戴着眼镜，与其说是一位业绩斐然的“金主”，不如说是一位注重细节的人，尽管他雄心勃勃，却始终是一位称职的二把手。他无疑非常聪明，擅长拆解交易，并将各个部分重新组合，使其运转良好。周二下午，在一间可以俯瞰自由女神像的会议室里，艾利森和一小群银行家埋头苦干，敲定了一份计划。下午4 点，当四家银行和费舍尔召开电话会议时，艾莉森已经为财团拟定了一份简洁的概要，篇幅只有四分之三页。

Allison, a fifty-five-year-old investment banker, was a rarity among top executives at Merrill, most of whom had been plucked from the firm’s legion of stockbrokers. The prototypical Merrill man was Komansky, a personable, heavyset former broker who had never gotten a college diploma but had starred in sales. Allison, a philosophy major at Yale with an M.B.A. from Stanford, was far more bookish. Wispy, balding, and bespectacled, he was more a detail man than a rainmaker and—despite his ambition—a consummate number two. Undeniably smart, he had a talent for deconstructing a deal and fitting the parts into working order. Tuesday afternoon, holed up in a conference room overlooking the Statue of Liberty, Allison and a small cadre of bankers hammered away at a plan. By 4 P.M., when the four banks and Fisher hooked up in a conference call, Allison had worked up a succinct outline, on three quarters of a page, for a consortium.

艾利森的计划要想成功，需要华尔街大多数银行的支持。此外，他向费舍尔解释说，让这些银行聚在一起的唯一办法是美联储召集他们，提议召开会议。费舍尔同意了。尽管美联储坚称其并未支持任何特定方案，但监管机构还是迅速行动起来，支持美林的计划。下午6点左右，费舍尔和几位助手给包括美林、摩根大通、高盛和瑞银在内的十几家长期证券最大的交易对手银行打电话，宣布当晚8点在美联储召开紧急会议。麦克唐纳一直在伦敦与国际监管机构讨论衍生品的风险，他通过电话与费舍尔保持联系。伦敦夜幕降临时，麦克唐纳已经乘飞机返回纽约。

For Allison’s plan to have any chance, it would need the support of most of the banks on Wall Street. Moreover, he explained to Fisher, the only way to get the banks together was for the Fed to call them and offer to hold a meeting.14 Fisher agreed. While insisting that the Fed was not backing any particular approach, the regulator swung into action behind the Merrill plan. Around 6 P.M., Fisher and some aides called the dozen banks that—along with Merrill, Morgan, Goldman, and UBS—were Long-Term’s biggest counterparties and announced an emergency meeting at the Fed at eight that evening. McDonough, who had been speaking to international regulators in London about the dangers of derivatives, was in touch by phone. By nightfall in London, McDonough was jetting back to New York.

四大银行的银行家们七点钟与费舍尔会面。艾莉森的方案是十六家银行各投资2.5亿美元。泰恩坚持总额要达到40亿美元——如果少于这个数额，投资组合就会遭到攻击。但银行家们在其他所有问题上都存在分歧。投资方案应该是股权投资，还是像一些比较谨慎的银行家提议的那样，是一笔临时贷款？长期合伙人应该被允许留下，还是应该被解雇？如果他们留下，谁来控制基金？科尔津强烈主张长期合伙人应该放弃控制权。八点二十分，四家牵头银行仍在争论。与此同时，其他几家大银行的首席执行官们也陆续抵达，在会议室外等候。

Bankers from the Big Four banks met with Fisher at seven. Allison’s plan called for the sixteen banks to invest $250 million each. Thain had insisted on the $4 billion total—anything less, and the portfolio would come under attack. But the bankers disagreed on everything else. Should the package be equity or—as the more gunshy bankers proposed—a temporary loan? Should the Long-Term partners be allowed to stay, or should they be fired? If they did stay, who would control the fund? Corzine strongly argued that the Long-Term partners should forfeit control. At 8:20, the four lead banks were still debating. Meanwhile, the chief executives of the other big banks had begun to arrive and were cooling their heels outside the boardroom.

费舍尔叫停了谈话，打开厚重的木门，邀请其他人进来。这是一场盛大的聚会，汇聚了华尔街的精英。费舍尔一眼就看到了所罗门美邦联席首席执行官德里克·莫恩、摩根大通总裁托马斯·拉布雷克、贝尔斯登首席执行官吉米·凯恩、瑞士信贷第一波士顿首席执行官艾伦·惠特、摩根士丹利添惠董事长菲利普·珀塞尔，以及来自雷曼兄弟和英国巴克莱银行的高管。四大银行的高管中，费舍尔看到了科曼斯基、艾利森、科尔津、泰恩、华纳、门多萨、罗斯和大卫·索罗。十二家银行共派出了二十五位银行家——清一色的男性，而且都是中年人。即使是这些脖子粗壮的银行家，虽然彼此都很熟悉，也不习惯在这么短的时间内，在这样一个地方，看到这么多同行挤在柔软的皮背椅上，在环绕着会议室的金框油画像的静谧注视下。

Fisher called a halt, opened the massive wooden doors, and invited the others in. It was an awesome gathering, the cream of Wall Street. Fisher spied Deryck Maughan, co–chief executive of Salomon Smith Barney; Thomas Labrecque, president of Chase; Jimmy Cayne, the CEO of Bear Stearns; Allen Wheat, chief executive of Credit Suisse First Boston; Philip Purcell, chairman of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter; and senior executives from Lehman Brothers and Barclays of Britain. From the Big Four, Fisher saw Komansky, Allison, Corzine, Thain, Warner, Mendoza, Rose, and David Solo. Twelve banks had sent twenty-five bankers—all men, all middle-aged. Even these thicknecked bankers, though familiar to one another, were unaccustomed to seeing so many of their brethren on such short notice and in such a place, squeezed into soft, leather-backed chairs under the quiet gaze of the gold-framed oil portraits that rimmed the boardroom.

费舍尔虽然只是个收入微薄的官僚，但他却吸引了所有人的注意力，因为只有他才能代表如今岌岌可危的“公共利益”。费舍尔只讲了几分钟。他说，美联储希望看到私营部门能否找到一种避免混乱清算、拯救整个体系的解决方案。除此之外，他采取了中立立场，刻意回避具体细节。艾莉森说：“他就像包下了整个大厅。” 当然，费舍尔做的远不止这些。美联储不会每天都邀请华尔街的高管们到会议室，这些高管们也心知肚明。

Fisher, though a bureaucrat who earned a pittance of what his guests did, commanded their attention because he alone could represent the “public interest” that now seemed so imperiled. Fisher spoke for just a few minutes. He said the Fed was interested in seeing whether the private sector could find a solution that would avoid a chaotic liquidation—one that would spare the system. Otherwise he adopted a neutral stance, intentionally staying aloof from the particulars. Allison said, “It was like he had rented out a hall.” Of course, Fisher had done more than that. The Fed does not invite the heads of Wall Street to its boardroom every day, and the executives knew it.

环顾四周，托马斯·鲁索的第一反应是敬畏——能成为这个团队的一员，心中涌起一丝转瞬即逝的满足感。随着讨论的展开，身为雷曼兄弟首席法务官的鲁索意识到一个讽刺之处。“当你身居高位时，你对下属的具体细节究竟了解多少？”他不禁自问。他们都接受过尽职调查的培训，但却没有人接受过应对此类紧急情况的训练。

Gazing about the room, Thomas Russo’s first thought was awe—a fleeting satisfaction at being part of such a group. As the debate got under way, Russo, the chief legal officer for Lehman, became conscious of an irony. “When you get to a high level, how much do you really understand about the details under you?” he wondered. They had all been trained to exercise due diligence, but none had been trained for an emergency like this.

艾利森概述了他的计划，各家牵头银行都表示支持。科曼斯基说：“这不是我处理这笔钱的首选方案，但我认为这是正确的做法。”科曼斯基没有补充说明他担心，如果长期基金倒闭，美林惊人的交易损失将会失控。其他银行家也同样担忧。但雷曼兄弟反对，认为不应该要求他们像其他大型银行一样出资——为什么每家银行不能根据自身风险敞口进行投资呢？泰恩反驳说，这太复杂了——时间紧迫。现在，每家银行都开始为自身利益而争执。摩根大通的拉布雷克抨击贝尔斯登引发了这场危机。他知道，贝尔斯登仍然掌握着主动权。凯恩的公司每年通过为长期基金清算赚取3000万美元，他本人也是该基金的投资者，但他却保持沉默。

Allison summarized his plan, and each of the lead banks spoke in favor. Komansky said, “It’s not my first choice of what to do with the money, but I think it’s the right thing.” Komansky didn’t bother to add that he was scared that if Long-Term collapsed, Merrill’s astonishing trading losses would spiral out of control. The other bankers were worried, too. But Lehman objected that it shouldn’t be asked for the same contribution as the bigger banks—why shouldn’t each bank invest according to its exposure? Thain retorted that that was too complicated—there wasn’t time. Each bank now began to jockey for its particular interest. Chase’s Labrecque fired a shot at Bear for precipitating the crisis. Bear still held the trigger, he knew. Cayne, whose firm had earned $30 million a year clearing for Long-Term, and who was personally an investor in the fund, was notably silent.

随后，银行家们将怒火发泄在了长期投资公司身上。他们已经从格林威治那帮人身上榨取了所有想要的东西。四年来，合伙人们一直高高在上，从每家银行中挑选最好的交易，甚至毫不掩饰他们沾沾自喜的优越感。现在，合伙人们看起来像是假先知。银行家们觉得自己被骗了——他们之前太轻信了。好几个人说应该解雇合伙人。为什么要给他们钱？艾莉森和科尔津多次中断谈话，向梅里韦瑟汇报最新情况（每次通话至少有两家银行参与，以避免秘密交易的可能性）。听到大家对他的愤怒，梅里韦瑟显得十分尴尬。“听着，我会尽我所能帮忙，”他低声说道。

Then the bankers vented their ire at Long-Term. They had taken all they wanted to from the gang in Greenwich. For four years, the partners had held themselves aloof, picking off the best trades from each of the banks and not even trying to hide their smug superiority. Now the partners had the look of false prophets. The bankers felt taken—they had been so credulous. Several said the partners should be fired. Why give them the money? Allison and Corzine repeatedly broke away from the talks to give Meriwether updates (at least two banks were in on every phone call, to avoid the possibility of secret dealing). Meriwether sounded mortified to hear of the anger directed at him. “Look, I’ll help however I can,” he murmured.

高盛的泰恩对长期投资公司的情况最为了解，他描述了该投资组合的风险。与会人员一致认为任何投资都应该以股权形式进行，但除了四家牵头公司之外，其他公司都不愿做出承诺。大多数银行认为，如果长期投资公司倒闭，他们的损失不会超过2.5亿美元；何必白白浪费钱呢？艾利森表示，后果可能非常可怕，甚至比俄罗斯金融危机后还要严重。他提醒与会人员，长期投资公司拥有1000亿美元的资产和1万亿美元的名义衍生品敞口。

Goldman’s Thain, who had the most intimate knowledge of Long-Term, described the portfolio risks. The group agreed that any investment should be in the form of equity, but no one beyond the four lead firms was ready to commit. Most of the banks thought they would lose less than $250 million if Long-Term failed; why throw good money after bad? Allison said that the fallout could be truly scary, even worse than after Russia. Long-Term had $100 billion of assets and $1 trillion in notional derivative exposure, he reminded the group.

此外，它的股权结构也令人不安。如果没有期权提供的保障，一些投资者根本不会投资股票，而长期投资公司无疑是最大的期权提供商。如果没有长期投资公司，投资者很可能会抛售股票。没有哪个银行家希望看到股市进一步下跌。普夫鲁格感到房间里弥漫着一种挥之不去的恐惧。然后，他沮丧地想到，今天是他的生日，而他却被锁在会议室里度过。

Moreover, its equity positions were spooky. Some investors would not be in stocks were it not for the insurance policy provided by options, and Long-Term was easily the biggest supplier. Without Long-Term, it was possible that investors would back away from stocks. None of the bankers wanted to see the stock market tumble further. Pflug felt a pervasive fear in the room. Then he had the depressing thought that it was his birthday and he was spending it locked in a conference room.

晚上11点左右，费舍尔建议休息到第二天早上10点。艾利森和美林的一位同事汤姆·戴维斯回到办公室重新起草条款。他们不时打电话给在格林威治守候的梅里韦瑟，以解决一些细节问题。凌晨1点左右，艾利森向科尔津和门多萨汇报了情况；艾利森不想在周三出现任何意外。凌晨3点，巴黎的办公时间开始，艾利森将新条款传真给了长期投资公司的法国交易对手。然后他回家了。第二天，他需要每家银行都做出承诺。他不知道这是否可行。此前从未有人在一天之内筹集到40亿美元。

Around 11 P.M., Fisher suggested they break until ten the next morning. Allison and a Merrill colleague, Tom Davis, returned to the office to redraft the terms. Now and then, to resolve a fine point, they called Meriwether, who was keeping vigil in Greenwich. Around 1 A.M., Allison updated Corzine and Mendoza; Allison wanted no surprises on Wednesday. At 3 A.M., when the business day in Paris began, Allison faxed the new terms to Long-Term’s French counter-parties. Then he went home. The next day, he would need each of the banks to commit. He wondered if it could be done.15 No one had ever raised $4 billion in a day before.

美林意识到自己也急需一些律师。菲利普·哈里斯是世达律师事务所（Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom）的合伙人，该事务所是美林的外部法律顾问。哈里斯曾在长期基金（Long-Term）最初的募资阶段参与其中，但他专攻投资基金，也需要一位重组方面的专家。凌晨2点30分，哈里斯打电话给世达律师事务所的一位合伙人J·格雷戈里·米尔莫，把他从斯卡斯代尔的家中叫醒。米尔莫是一位五十岁左右、说话轻声细语、头发花白、戴着金框眼镜的律师，专攻破产法。米尔莫曾是一名钢琴演奏家，后来在世达律师事务所的邮件收发室找到了一份工作，之后又去法学院深造。“出了点事，”哈里斯说，“我们需要你。”

Merrill had realized it would also need some lawyers in a hurry. Philip Harris, a partner at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, Merrill’s outside law firm, had worked on Long-Term during its initial fund-raising, but Harris, who specialized in investment funds, wanted a workout specialist, too. At 2:30 A.M., Harris called a Skadden partner named J. Gregory Milmoe, waking him at his home in Scarsdale. Milmoe, a fifty-year-old soft-spoken attorney with white hair and gold-rimmed glasses, specialized in bankruptcy. A former piano player, Milmoe had gotten a job in Skadden’s mail room and later gone to law school. “Something has come up,” Harris said. “We need you.”

米尔莫承诺他明天一早就到。

Milmoe promised he’d be in first thing in the morning.

“不，”哈里斯解释说，“我们需要你现在就进来。”

“No,” Harris explained. “We need you to come in now.”

米尔莫洗了个澡，穿好衣服，跳上他的沃尔沃。他趁着曼哈顿最安静的时段，一路驶入市区。下午3点半，他到达了斯卡登律师事务所总部所在的那座闪闪发光的黑色摩天大楼，然后开始上班。

Milmoe showered, dressed, and hopped into his Volvo. He cruised into Manhattan at the city’s quietest hour. By 3:30, he reached the gleaming black skyscraper where Skadden had its headquarters and went to work.

刚从伦敦抵达的麦克唐纳周三一大早就到了美联储。手推车和加长豪华轿车在狭窄的巷道里摩肩接踵，缓慢行驶。美联储大楼高耸入云，高高的外墙直达空荡荡的阳台，仿佛建筑师想要同时展现宫殿的庄严和堡垒的坚不可摧。麦克唐纳给欧洲各央行的同行们打了电话，告知他们危机的情况。他的同事费舍尔接到了贝尔斯登的吉米·凯恩的电话。凯恩表示贝尔斯登不会参与任何救援行动。费舍尔恳求凯恩保持开放的心态。凯恩语气阴沉地说：“如果你们想让这件事成功，就别按字母顺序来。”

McDonough, who had just arrived from London, got to the Fed early Wednesday. Pushcarts were jostling for street space with stretch limousines, which moved at a ponderous pace through the narrow alleyways. The Federal Reserve building loomed above, its high outer wall rising to a vacant balcony, as if the architect had wanted to convey both the ceremony of a palace and the implacability of a fortress. McDonough called his peers at European central banks, notifying them of the crisis. Fisher, his colleague, took a call from Jimmy Cayne at Bear Stearns. Cayne said Bear Stearns would not contribute to any rescue. Fisher pleaded with Cayne to keep an open mind. Cayne said darkly, “Don’t go alphabetically if you want this to work.”

上午10点，银行家们再次聚集。周三的聚会规模更大，总共约有45人。这群人可谓华尔街权力掮客的精英荟萃：桑迪·韦尔、科曼斯基、科尔津、大通银行的拉布雷克、摩根大通的华纳、瑞士信贷第一波士顿的惠特，以及雷曼兄弟董事长理查德·富尔德。此外，还有来自五家瑞士、英国和法国银行的高管，以及纽约证券交易所主席理查德·格拉索，他因长期基金在股票波动性方面的巨大交易而被召集前来。德意志银行的埃德森·米切尔则通过电话参与了此次盛会。银行家们鱼贯走进会议室，注意到壁炉架上古董钟上方挂着乔治·华盛顿的画像，旁边是麦克唐纳前任们的画像。窗帘拉上了。那张优雅的黑边红木桌子太小，容不下这么多人；一张更大的桌布被匆匆搭在了上面。16

At 10 A.M., the bankers returned. Wednesday’s gathering was larger, about forty-five in all. The group was a who’s who of Wall Street power brokers: Sandy Weill, Komansky, Corzine, Chase’s Labrecque, Morgan’s Warner, Credit Suisse First Boston’s Wheat, and Richard Fuld, chairman of Lehman Brothers. Rounding out the spectacular assembly were executives from five Swiss, British, and French banks as well as Richard Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, who had been summoned due to Long-Term’s monster trade in equity volatility. Edson Mitchell of Deutsche Bank was connected by phone. As they filed into the boardroom, the bankers noticed the portrait of George Washington above an antique clock on the mantel, alongside those of McDonough’s predecessors. The curtains were drawn. The elegant, black-trimmed mahogany table was too small to accommodate such a crowd; a larger cover had been hastily slung over it.16

会议室本身是后来加建的，美联储于1935年购得。当时，一位在经济繁荣时期一直坚守阵地的邻近业主终于同意出售。人们戏称，美联储为了得到这间会议室，策划了股市崩盘。这个玩笑颇具讽刺意味，因为美联储在1929年初未能遏制以保证金贷款进行的股票投机，此后一直被视为一次错失良机——如果当时采取了行动，或许就能避免股市崩盘，甚至可能避免随之而来的大萧条。麦克唐纳创办长期资本公司，正是为了防止类似灾难——尽管规模较小——再次发生。

The boardroom itself was an add-on, the Fed having acquired it in 1935, when an adjacent property owner who had held out in boom times had agreed to sell. The joke was that the Fed had engineered the stock market crash to get hold of the space. The joke carried a sting, since the Fed’s failure to curb stock speculation on margin debt early in 1929 has ever since been viewed as a singular missed opportunity—one that might have averted the crash and, perhaps, the ensuing Great Depression. It was this sort of debacle—albeit on a lesser scale—that McDonough was seeking to prevent with Long-Term Capital.

然而，麦克唐纳并不在会议室里。这位美联储主席和四家牵头银行的高管们待在一间小房间里，他们俨然成了其他银行大会的流动安全委员会。那天早晨天气温暖，其他几位首席执行官不习惯被人晾在一边，开始变得不耐烦起来。

However, McDonough was not in the boardroom. The Fed president was closeted in an anteroom with the executives of the four lead banks, who had become a sort of roving Security Council to the other banks’ General Assembly. It was a warm morning, and the other CEOs, not accustomed to being kept waiting, were becoming impatient.

10点25分，麦克唐纳突然出现。这位身材魁梧、64岁的芝加哥人，头发稀疏，呈银白色，浓密的眉毛弯弯的。他宣布会议暂停至下午1点。他意味深长地补充道：“并非所有途径都已尝试过。”但拒绝进一步解释。各位CEO们目瞪口呆，完全不知所措。后来他们才知道，在四大会议开始大约十分钟后，科尔津和泰恩把麦克唐纳拉到一边，告知他们一个突如其来的新进展：巴菲特准备出价。“我以为我们同舟共济！”索罗愤怒地吼道。但麦克唐纳无法放弃这看似天赐良机的机会；他更倾向于不涉及美联储的解决方案。为了确认消息的真实性，他给当时正在蒙大拿州牧场的巴菲特打了电话。巴菲特证实，报价即将发出。在主会议室里，各位CEO们起身，脸上满是厌恶。他们对高盛背着他们进行交易感到愤怒。就连科曼斯基也觉得科尔津对此事守口如瓶。

At 10:25, McDonough, a burly, sixty-four-year-old Chicagoan with thinning silver hair and thick arching eyebrows, suddenly appeared and said he was suspending the meeting until 1 P.M. He added cryptically, “Not all avenues have been exhausted,” but refused to elaborate. The CEOs were dumbfounded and absolutely at a loss. As they learned later, about ten minutes into the meeting of the Big Four, Corzine and Thain had pulled McDonough aside, pleading a sudden new development: Buffett was ready to bid. “I thought we were in this together!” Solo snapped angrily. But McDonough could not pass up this seeming godsend; he much preferred a solution that did not involve the Fed. Just to make sure it was real, he called Buffett, who was now at a Montana ranch. Buffett confirmed that an offer was on the way. In the main room, the CEOs rose with a look of disgust. They were furious at Goldman for dealing behind their backs. Even Komansky felt that Corzine had played it too close to the vest.

在高盛投资银行家克劳斯准备书面报价的同时，巴菲特给梅里韦瑟打了个电话。“约翰，”他用那独特的南方口音说道，“你会收到一份以我的名字命名的投资组合报价。我只是想让你知道，是我。”梅里韦瑟没有明确表态。

While Kraus, Goldman’s investment banker, prepared a written offer, Buffett placed a call to Meriwether. “John,” he said in his unmistakable twang, “you’re going to get a bid for the portfolio with my name on it. I just want you to know that it’s me.” Meriwether was noncommittal.
