The partners appeared to accept responsibility; they said they did and apologized on various occasions; but they never made clear just what it was they were apologizing for. J.M. & Co. generally denied that either the leverage or the size of their portfolio had been a significant contributing factor; they denied, even, that their basic strategy had been flawed.8 Rather, in meeting after meeting, the partners blamed the irrationality and venality of other traders. They portrayed Long-Term as the victim of outside events, specifically, of a liquidity shortage in August followed by hostile front-running in September.

在美联储历史性会议一周年之际，迈伦·斯科尔斯在纽约“世界之窗”餐厅发表讲话，有力地论证了低评级债券的利差已经扩大到远超违约风险所能解释的程度。因此，斯科尔斯得出结论，这些利差必定是“流动性利差”，代表了投资者愿意为流动性更强的债券支付的溢价。这种论证存在循环论证的弊端：当价格下跌时，人们总是会归咎于买家的缺失，从而归咎于“流动性不足”。正如斯科尔斯本人所指出的，确实存在一些真实存在的、潜在的事件吓跑了买家；也就是说，投资者一直指望国际货币基金组织（IMF）救助发展中地区，但IMF却无力同时保护所有地区。

On the first anniversary of the historic meeting at the Fed, Myron Scholes cogently argued in a talk at New York’s Windows on the World restaurant that spreads on lower-rated bonds had widened to greater levels than could have been explained by mere default risk. Therefore, Scholes concluded, the spreads must have been “liquidity spreads,” representing the premium that investors were willing to pay for more liquid paper. There is a circular nature to such arguments: when prices fall, one may always blame the absence of buyers and hence of “liquidity.” As Scholes himself pointed out, there were very real, underlying events that had scared the buyers away; to wit, investors had been counting on the IMF to bail out developing regions, but the IMF had been incapable of protecting everyone at once:

我喜欢举的例子是一位父亲有几个儿子。每个儿子都认为父亲会在自己需要帮助的时候伸出援手。但是，如果他的一个儿子需要帮助，父亲能用来支持自己和其他儿子的资源就会减少。这种支持的价值就降低了。这在一定程度上解释了8 月份的流动性危机。打个比方，另一个儿子——俄罗斯——无法得到足够的支持，结果，所有其他儿子——那些欠发达国家——的信用评级都降低了。

The example I like to give is that of a father with several sons. Each son thinks that the father will support him in his time of need. But, if one of his brothers needs support, the father then has fewer resources to support his activities and also those of his other brothers. The value of the support option is diminished in value. This, in part, is the cause of the flight to liquidity in August. Figuratively, another son, Russia, could not be sufficiently supported, and as a result, all of the other sons, the underdeveloped countries, looked less credit worthy.9

斯科尔斯感叹，学术界和实践者们尚未建立起这种“压力损失流动性成分”及其对价格影响的模型。但显然，流动性不足仅仅是问题的表现，而非其根源。这些自说自话的言论中，完全没有提及长期基金自身是否也应承担这种风险。一个以每小时30英里速度行驶的司机，如果在结冰路面上打滑，可能会责怪路面；但一个以每小时100英里速度行驶的司机则不会。

Scholes lamented that academics and practitioners hadn’t modeled this “stress-loss liquidity component” and its implications for prices. But obviously, illiquidity was merely the expression of the problem, not its cause. What was missing from these self-serving sound bites was any suggestion that Long-Term had been at fault for exposing itself to such perils. A man driving a car at thirty miles an hour may blame the road if he skids on a patch of ice; a man driving at a hundred miles an hour may not.

斯科尔斯回避了“学者和从业者”为何忽视了由来已久且显而易见的流动性风险这一问题。即​​使在遭受历史性损失之后，长期基金的合伙人也未承认犯下任何根本性错误。他们辩称，他们的失败是被一场无法预见的事件——百年一遇的完美风暴——所击垮的。“我相信这一点，”罗森菲尔德在崩盘后解释道，“我确实认为这是前所未有的事情。” 10当然，这种情况并非百年一遇，而是多次发生——在墨西哥、华尔街、股票、债券、白银、泰国、俄罗斯、巴西。身陷此类金融灾难的人们通常会觉得自己格外倒霉，但金融史上充斥着“肥尾”的例子——异常且极端的价格波动，根据以往的价格走势来看，这些波动似乎难以置信。

Scholes averted the question of why “academics and practitioners” had ignored the long-established and basically self-evident liquidity risks. Even after their historic loss, the Long-Term partners admitted no essential mistake. They had been done in, they argued, by an unforeseeable event—a perfect storm such as strikes once in a hundred years. “I believe that,” Rosenfeld explained after the crash. “I do think it was something that never happened before.”10 Of course, it had happened, not once in a hundred years but many times—in Mexico, on Wall Street, in stocks, in bonds, in silver, in Thailand, in Russia, in Brazil. People caught in such financial cataclysms typically feel singularly unlucky, but financial history is replete with examples of “fat tails”—unusual and extreme price swings that, based on a reading of previous prices, would have seemed implausible.

无论他们从那场创伤中吸取了什么教训，合伙人仍然像救助前一样坚持认为，利差过大，现在是投资的好时机，机会前所未有地好。模型也这么说！事实证明他们错了——或者至少，在救助一年后，他们的判断还没有被证明是正确的。尽管华尔街复苏了，但长期基金的套利策略却未能恢复。在新东家的领导下，该基金在1998年最后一个季度表现良好，新年伊始也开局不错；但随后便急转直下。1999年夏天，美国互换利差再次飙升至112个点——甚至比前一年恐慌高峰时的天文数字还要高。百年一遇的危​​机在两年内发生了两次。

Whatever they had learned from the trauma, the partners continued to insist, just as they had before the bailout, that spreads were too wide, that now was the time to invest, that opportunities had never looked better. The models said so! On this they were proven wrong—or at least, a year after the bailout, they had yet to be proven right. Though Wall Street recovered, Long-Term’s brand of arbitrage did not. Under its new owners, the fund enjoyed a good last quarter in 1998 and a good start to the new year; then it went into a tailspin. In the summer of 1999, U.S. swap spreads once again ballooned, to 112 points—wider, even, than at the astronomical height of the previous year’s panic. The once-in-a-century flood had struck twice in two years.

1999年9月28日，也就是救助计划实施整整一年后，互换利差仍高达93点，股票波动率也达到了30%——这两项指标都远高于长期基金最初进入相应交易时的水平。救助计划实施后的第一年，该基金的收益率仅为10%，远称不上显著复苏。随后，除了这笔微薄的利润外，该基金还赎回了财团36.5亿美元的资本。实际上，到2000年初，该基金就已经清算完毕。

On September 28, 1999, exactly a year after the bailout, swap spreads remained at 93 points and equity volatility was at 30 percent—each far higher than when Long-Term had entered the respective trade. In the first year after the bailout, the fund earned 10 percent—hardly a dramatic recovery. Then, in addition to this modest profit, the fund redeemed the consortium’s $3.65 billion in capital. For practical purposes, the fund had liquidated by early 2000.

因此，长期基金的问题并非仅仅是流动性不足。或许该基金的整个策略都错了，而且1998年世界（以及长期基金自身）对信贷的看法过于乐观。证据表明，这两个因素都在起作用：长期基金误判了市场，而这种误判的影响在9月份被进一步加剧——为了避免长期基金即将崩溃，其他交易员举行了罢工，“流动性”也随之消失。

So Long-Term’s problem had not been just illiquidity. Perhaps the fund’s entire strategy had been wrong, and the world’s (and Long-Term’s) perception of credit in 1998 had been a little too rosy. The evidence suggests that both factors were at work: Long-Term misjudged the markets, and the effect of that misjudgment was sorely compounded in September, when—to protect themselves against Long-Term’s imminent collapse—other traders went on strike and “liquidity” disappeared.

艾伦·格林斯潘坦言，美联储通过出手救助长期资产公司，鼓励了未来的冒险者，或许也增加了未来发生灾难的可能性。“诚然，美联储的介入可能造成了一些道德风险，尽管这种风险可能很小，”这位美联储主席宣称。然而，他认为，如果长期资产公司突然破产，市场价格将出现“严重扭曲”，那么这些负面影响就显得微不足道了。

Alan Greenspan freely admitted that by orchestrating a rescue of Long-Term, the Fed had encouraged future risk takers and perhaps increased the odds of a future disaster. “To be sure, some moral hazard, however slight, may have been created by the Federal Reserve’s involvement,”11 the Fed chief declared. However, he judged that such negatives were outweighed by the risk of “serious distortions to market prices had Long-Term been pushed suddenly into bankruptcy.”

如果孤立地看待长期资本事件，人们往往会认同美联储的干预是正确的，就像面对一位突然精神不稳定的病人，大多数医生都会毫不犹豫地开镇静剂一样。精神崩溃的风险是立竿见影的，而成瘾的风险则是长期的。但我们必须认清长期资本事件的本质：它并非孤立事件，而是一系列政府机构（或国际货币基金组织）出手救助私人投机者的案例中的最新一起。短短十年间，这份不幸的名单不断扩大，囊括了储蓄贷款机构、过度放贷给房地产的大型商业银行、在墨西哥、泰国、韩国和俄罗斯（俄罗斯曾尝试过救助）的投资者，以及如今与长期资本有关联的各方。诚然，美联储的介入有限，而且没有动用政府资金。但如果没有美联储强大的实力和影响力，这些银行不可能联合起来；如果没有共同努力，长期资本肯定会倒闭。可以推测，银行和其他机构的损失会更严重——尽管人们认为不会像某些人所说的那样巨大。长期投资的风险敞口固然巨大，但如果分散到整个华尔街，其规模远未达到世界末日的程度。抛售总会在某个时刻停止。买家总会在某个时刻回归，市场也会趋于稳定。其他银行也可能倒闭，但这充其量只是极小的可能性。

If one looks at the Long-Term episode in isolation, one would tend to agree that the Fed was right to intervene, just as, if confronted with a suddenly mentally unstable patient, most doctors would willingly prescribe a tranquilizer. The risks of a breakdown are immediate; those of addiction are long term. But the Long-Term Capital case must be seen for what it is: not an isolated instance but the latest in a series in which an agency of the government (or the IMF) has come to the rescue of private speculators. In one decade, this unfortunate roster has grown to include the savings and loans, big commercial banks that had overlent to real estate, investors in Mexico, Thailand, South Korea, and Russia (where a bailout was attempted), and now the various parties affiliated with Long-Term Capital. It is true that the Fed’s involvement was limited and that no government money was used. But the banks would not have come together without the enormous power and influence of the Fed behind them, and without a joint effort, Long-Term surely would have collapsed. Presumably, the banks and others would have suffered more severe losses—though not, one thinks, as great as some suggested. Long-Term’s exposure was huge, but, spread over all of Wall Street, it was hardly of apocalyptic proportions. At some point the selling would have stopped. At some point buyers would have returned and markets would have stabilized. Other banks could have failed, though that was an outside chance at best.

允许此类损失发生，正是阻止大多数人和机构承担不审慎风险的关键所在。尤其是在经历了十年的繁荣和金融市场蓬勃发展之后，提醒人们愚蠢行为是要付出代价的，这绝非坏事。那些被长期经济软着陆所麻痹的投资者，是否也会对下一个即将出现问题的国家寄予厚望呢？总而言之，美联储介入的决定——尽管考虑到1998年9月的恐慌局面，这一决定可以理解——却遗憾地错失了一次为市场注入必要纪律的绝佳机会。

Permitting such losses to occur is what deters most other people and institutions from taking imprudent risks. Now especially, after a decade of prosperity and buoyant financial markets, a reminder that foolishness carries a price would be no bad thing. Will investors in the next problem-child-to-be, having been lulled by the soft landing engineered for Long-Term, be counting on the Fed, too? On balance, the Fed’s decision to get involved—though understandable given the panicky conditions of September 1998—regrettably squandered a choice opportunity to send the markets a needed dose of discipline.

麦克唐纳始终为自己的行为辩护，尽管他似乎对基金的存续感到不满，甚至有些尴尬。救助一年后，美联储主席麦克唐纳在一次不合时宜的坦率讲话中宣称：“长期资本管理公司（LTCM）即将倒闭。我可以向你们保证，这是一个令我非常满意的结果。” 12

McDonough always defended his actions, though he seemed displeased and perhaps embarrassed by the fund’s survival. A year after the bailout, in an impolitic burst of candor, the Fed president declared, “LTCM is close to being out of business. I can assure you that is a result that pleases me considerably.”12

格林斯潘更严重、持续时间更长的错误在于，他始终忽视了对衍生品进行监管和加强信息披露的必要性。危机爆发前，格林斯潘误以为银行有能力自我监管，危机爆发仅仅六个月后，他就呼吁建立一个负担更轻的监管体系。 13 他反对加强信息披露——而信息披露恰恰能让投资者成为自身的监督者，这始终是自由资本市场的最佳伙伴——这种近乎原始的反对态度，让人想起早期的格林斯潘（他深受安·兰德的影响）曾写道：“监管的基础是武力。” 14事实上，正是在那些缺乏透明度的国家（例如俄罗斯），市场才需要军队来捍卫。

Greenspan’s more serious and longer-running error has been to consistently shrug off the need for regulation and better disclosure with regard to derivative products. Deluded as to the banks’ ability to police themselves before the crisis, Greenspan called for a less burdensome regulatory regime barely six months after it.13 His Neolithic opposition to enhanced disclosure—which, because it allows investors to be their own watchdogs, is ever the best friend of free capital markets—served to remind one of the early Greenspan who (in thrall to Ayn Rand) once wrote, “The basis of regulation is armed force.”14 In fact, it is in countries that lack transparency (such as Rus-sia) that markets need to be defended by soldiers.

如果说长期投资事件证明了什么，那就是在传统证券领域行之有效的披露体系，在衍生品合约领域却无法发挥作用。简而言之，投资者对资产负债表风险相当了解，但对衍生品风险却一头雾水。尽管格林斯潘和银行都反对，但一些报告标准正在修改，漏洞依然存在。随着衍生品使用量的增长，这一缺陷终将再次困扰我们。

If the Long-Term episode proved anything, it is that the system of disclosure that has worked so well with regard to traditional securities has not been able to do the job with respect to derivative contracts. To put it plainly, investors have a pretty good idea about balance-sheet risks; they are completely befuddled with regard to derivative risks. Some of the reporting standards are being changed (over the opposition of both Greenspan and the banks), but gaping holes remain. As the use of derivatives grows, this deficiency will return to haunt us.

此外，除了改进衍生品报告之外，限制实际风险敞口也具有充分的理由。监管机构限制了摩根大通和花旗银行的贷款额度，以确保其贷款不超过一定的资本比率。监管机构这样做是有充分理由的：银行已经反复证明，如果可以，它们会突破审慎原则的界限。那么，格林斯潘为何会支持这样一种体系：只要风险敞口是以衍生品的形式存在，银行就可以随意增加任何规模的风险敞口呢？

Moreover, aside from improving reporting on derivatives, there is a strong argument to be made for restricting actual exposure. Regulators limit the amount that Chase Manhattan and Citibank can lend, so that their loans do not exceed a certain ratio of capital. The regulators do this for good reason: banks have repeatedly shown that they will exceed the limits of prudence if they can. Why, then, does Greenspan endorse a system in which banks can rack up any amount of exposure that they choose—as long as that exposure is in the form of derivatives?

美联储的双管齐下政策——危机前鸵鸟政策、危机后干预——如果被视为单一政策，则更显误入歧途。政府的重点应该始终放在预防上， 而不是积极干预。政府事先为银行等受监管机构制定规则完全合理；但代表不受监管的对冲基金进行危机干预则是另一回事。

The Fed’s two-headed policy—head in the sand before a crisis, intervention after the fact—is more misguided when viewed as one single policy. The government’s emphasis should always be on prevention, not on active intervention. It is altogether proper that the government set rules in advance for regulated bodies such as banks; crisis intervention on behalf of unregulated hedge funds is another matter.

白宫成立了一个由多机构（包括美联储）组成的专家小组——总统金融市场工作组，专门研究长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的危机。该工作组的报告总结道：“LTCM事件引发的核心公共政策问题是如何更有效地限制过度杠杆。”此外，报告还承认衍生品的作用日益增强，并指出：“资产负债表杠杆率本身不足以衡量风险。” 15然而，该报告在提出解决方案方面略显不足。报告确实呼吁对冲基金加强信息披露，银行改进风险和信贷管理政策，并制定更严格的监管标准。但这份措辞谨慎的报告于1999年4月发布，缺乏足够的力度促使国会采取行动，而国会当时对LTCM的兴趣也正在迅速减弱。“去年9月和10月，这还是个热门话题，”众议院银行委员会发言人戴维·伦克尔在危机后的那个夏天指出，“但现在不是了。” 16

The White House formed a blue-ribbon panel, the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets, a multiagency group (including the Fed) to study the Long-Term debacle. Its report concluded, “The central public policy issue raised by the LTCM episode is how to constrain excessive leverage more effectively.” Moreover, it recognized the growing role of derivatives, noting, “Balance-sheet leverage by itself is not an adequate measure of risk.”15 However, the report was weaker when it came to proposing solutions. It did call for enhanced disclosure by hedge funds, better risk and credit management policies by banks, and tougher regulatory standards. But the cautiously worded report, which was issued in April 1999, did not have the fire to provoke action from Congress, which in any case was rapidly losing interest in Long-Term. “Last September and October, it was a hot issue,” David Runkel, a spokesman for the House Banking Committee, noted the summer after the crisis. “But not now.”16

对冲基金的喧嚣也逐渐平息——这理所当然。长期基金危机恰好与一家对冲基金有关，但这场危机的始作俑者是华尔街的大型银行，它们随着自身财富的积累而放松了标准。在政府救助期间，这些银行被描绘成受害者，长期基金凭借其独有的保密手段将他们蒙在鼓里。一些银行家的清白之词也强化了这种观点。（例如，科曼斯基在离开美联储后给一位朋友打电话时说道：“当我看到他们的头寸时，我吓得腿都软了。”）随着时间的推移，这种说法越来越站不住脚。每家银行​​都清楚自己与长期基金的交易往来；他们不难推断出该基金在其他地方也进行着类似的交易。

The furor over hedge funds also died down—and appropriately so. The Long-Term crisis happened to involve a hedge fund, but the fathers of the crisis were the big Wall Street banks, which let their standards grow lax as their pocketbooks grew flush. At the time of the bailout, the banks were depicted as victims that had been kept in the dark by Long-Term’s patented secrecy. Such a view was enhanced by various bankers’ assertions of innocence. (Komansky, for one, called a friend upon leaving the Federal Reserve and declared, “When I saw their position, my fucking knees were shaking.”) With time, such claims rang increasingly hollow. Each bank had known its own exposure to Long-Term trade by trade; it did not take genius for them to infer that the fund was doing similar business elsewhere.

美联储官员帕特里克·帕金森是总统工作组成员，他在救助行动几个月后向参议院委员会作证时说：

Patrick Parkinson, a Fed official assigned to the President’s Working Group, told a Senate committee a couple of months after the rescue:

尽管LTCM承担了极高的风险，但它似乎获得了非常优厚的信贷条件……交易对手从LTCM获得的信息表明，其证券和衍生品头寸相对于其资本而言非常庞大。然而，似乎很少有人真正了解LTCM的风险状况。 17

LTCM appears to have received very generous credit terms, even though it took an exceptional degree of risk. . . . Counterparties obtained information from LTCM that indicated that it had securities and derivatives positions that were very large relative to its capital. However, few, if any, seem to have really understood LTCM’s risk profile.17

所以问题就变成了：银行家们为什么要放贷？在1999年初的一次公开研讨会上，共和银行前董事长沃尔特·韦纳坚称，银行别无选择——或者至少，除了拒绝这笔业务这种罕见而勇敢的选择之外，别无他法：“要想加入这个俱乐部，就必须遵守长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的规则。条款不容商量——要么接受，要么放弃。” 18银行接受了。他们也同样贪婪，他们被长期资本管理公司的业绩所折服，也被合伙人的声誉、学历和名望所迷惑。“我们或许是被这些超人迷住了，”韦纳承认道。这支基金在华尔街历史上独一无二，它像一枚耀眼的火箭般划破金融天空，半人半机器，似乎将一个充满不确定性的世界简化为冷酷无情的概率博弈。就像来自遥远未来的访客一样，这些教授似乎已经超越了曾经潜伏在市场阴影中的随机运气和厄运。

So the question becomes, why did the bankers lend? In a public symposium early in 1999, Walter Weiner, the former chairman of Republic, maintained that the banks had had no choice—or at least, no choice other than the rare, courageous one of rejecting business: “To enter the club, you had to play by LTCM’s rules. The terms were non-negotiable—take it or leave it.”18 The banks took it. They, too, were greedy, and they were awed by Long-Term’s performance and dazzled by the partners’ reputations, degrees, and celebrity. “We may have been mesmerized by these supermen,” Weiner acknowledged. Unique in Wall Street history, the fund had blazed across the financial skies like a luminous rocket, a half-man, half-machine that seemingly reduced an uncertain world to rigorous, cold-blooded odds. Like visitors from a remote future, the professors seemed to have superseded the random luck and ill fate that had ever lurked in the shadows of markets.

Long-Term从暴富到破产的传奇经历，为投资者提供了诸多警示。其惊人的利润在随后的巨额亏损面前显得黯然失色。正如保险公司收取高额保费，却在暴风雨来袭时赔付一样，Long-Term的利润在某种意义上并非全部“赚得”；部分利润是借来的，寄希望于周期逆转之日。任何投资——包括互联网奇才——都不能仅凭半个周期的表现来评判。

Long-Term’s saga of riches to rags was replete with lessons for investors. Its astonishing profits looked less impressive in the light of the losses that followed. As with an insurer who collects heady premiums but gives them back when a big storm hits, Long-Term’s profits were not, in a sense, all “earned”; in part, they were borrowed against the day when the cycle would turn. No investment—Internet wunderkinds included—can be judged on the basis of half a cycle alone.

事实上，长期投资公司明明看到了周期正在转变，却莫名其妙地拒绝削减风险敞口。随着利差收窄，业务风险不可避免地上升，长期投资公司反而提高了杠杆率，仿佛借贷就能把一个原本不具吸引力的业务变成一个更具吸引力的业务，而不仅仅是增加风险。如果不是因为一个重大的管理缺陷——缺乏对交易员的独立监督——长期投资公司就不会犯下这个错误。最终，每个合伙人都参加了风险管理会议，而且最终都默许了这些交易。从这个意义上讲，每个合伙人都难辞其咎。

Indeed, Long-Term saw that the cycle was turning but inexplicably refused to prune its exposures. As spreads narrowed, inevitably raising the risks in the business, Long-Term increased its leverage, as if borrowing could turn an unattractive business into a better one rather than just a riskier one. Long-Term wouldn’t have made this mistake but for a major managerial weakness: the absence of any independent check on the traders. In the end, every partner had sat through the risk-management meetings, and every one, ultimately, had acquiesced in the trades. In that sense, every partner was to blame.

长期基金对多元化投资抱​​有极高的信任——这虽是现代投资的信条之一，却被过分高估了。正如凯恩斯所言，一次深思熟虑的投资胜过许多未经深思熟虑的投资。长期基金的失败证明，鸡蛋放在不同的篮子里可能会同时破碎。此外，长期基金自欺欺人地认为其投资组合已经实现了实质上的多元化，而实际上，它只是形式上的多元化而已。基本上，该基金在所有可能的排列组合中都押注于评级较低的债券。毫不奇怪，当经济周期逆转、信贷紧缩时——这种情况在有记载的历史中周期性地出现——长期基金的交易也随之同步下跌。

Long-Term put supreme trust in diversification—one of the shibboleths of modern investing, but an overrated one. As Keynes noted, one bet soundly considered is preferable to many poorly understood. The Long-Term episode proved that eggs in separate baskets can break simultaneously. Moreover, Long-Term fooled itself into thinking it had diversified in substance when, in fact, it had done so only in form. Basically, the fund made the same bet on lower-rated bonds in every imaginable permutation. It is hardly a surprise that when the cycle turned and credit tightened—as, throughout recorded time, it periodically has—Long-Term’s trades fell in lockstep.

比较长期投资公司自1998年1月1日至政府救助期间各类交易的损失很有意思：19

It is interesting to compare Long-Term’s losses from various categories of trades from January 1, 1998, to the bailout:19

俄罗斯和其他新兴市场：4.3亿美元

Russia and other emerging markets: $430 million

发达国家定向交易（例如做空日本债券）：3.71亿美元

Directional trades in developed countries (such as shorting Japanese bonds): $371 million

股权组合（例如大众和壳牌）：2.86亿美元

Equity pairs (such as Volkswagen and Shell): $286 million

收益率曲线套利：2.15亿美元

Yield-curve arbitrage: $215 million

标准普尔500指数成分股：2.03亿美元

Standard & Poor’s 500 stocks: $203 million

高收益（垃圾债券）套利：1亿美元

High-yield (junk bond) arbitrage: $100 million

并购套利：大致持平

Merger arbitrage: Roughly even

这七类损失共计16亿美元——这是一场灾难性的后果。然而，长期保险公司原本可以挺过这些难关。

These seven categories accounted for $1.6 billion in losses—a catastrophic result. However, Long-Term could have survived them.

现在来看看它在两笔最大交易中的损失：

Now consider the losses in its two biggest trades:

互换交易：16亿美元

Swaps: $1.6 billion

股票波动率：13亿美元

Equity volatility: $1.3 billion

正是这两笔交易导致了公司的破产。长期投资公司在这些市场中的规模过大——这是一个需要警惕的错误。它的规模如此之大，以至于扭曲了公司赖以生存的市场效率。如果不是因为长期投资公司还使用了30倍的杠杆——这还不包括其衍生品账簿中隐含的巨额杠杆——这一切或许不会造成太大影响。规模大（因此流动性差）是可以的；杠杆（在谨慎的范围内）也是可以的。但是，高杠杆且流动性差的投资者无异于玩俄罗斯轮盘赌，因为他不仅要在最后一天对市场做出正确的判断，而且每一天都必须如此。（一旦判断失误，他就会破产。）长期投资公司如此自信，以至于认为市场永远不会——即使是八九月份的剧烈波动——偏离其预测如此之远。

It was these two trades that broke the firm. Long-Term got far too big in these markets—a cautionary error. It got so big that it distorted the very markets on whose efficiency the firm relied. This wouldn’t have mattered but for the fact that Long-Term also leveraged its capital 30 to 1—again, in addition to the huge leverage implicit in its derivatives book. One can be big (and therefore illiquid); one can (within prudent limits) be leveraged. But the investor who is highly leveraged and illiquid is playing Russian roulette, for he must be right about the market not merely at the end, but every single day. (One wrong day, and he is out of business.) Long-Term was so self-certain as to believe that the markets would never—not even for a wild swing some August and September—stray so far from its predictions.

这些教授深受默顿和斯科尔斯有效市场理论的影响，他们竟然相信价格会按照模型预测的方向发展。他们自负地认为模型可以预测行为的极限。事实上，模型只能根据过去的经验告诉他们什么是合理的，什么是可以预测的。教授们忽略了一个事实：人，包括交易员在内，并非总是理性的。这才是长期策略失败的真正教训。无论模型如何预测，交易员并非由硅芯片控制的机器；他们易受影响，善于模仿；他们成群结队地行动，也成群结队地撤退。

Reared on Merton’s and Scholes’s teachings of efficient markets, the professors actually believed that prices would go and go directly where the models said they should. The professors’ conceit was to think that models could forecast the limits of behavior. In fact, the models could tell them what was reasonable or what was predictable based on the past. The professors overlooked the fact that people, traders included, are not always reasonable. This is the true lesson of Long-Term’s demise. No matter what the models say, traders are not machines guided by silicon chips; they are impressionable and imitative; they run in flocks and retreat in hordes.

即使交易员的判断“正确”，市场也很难像正弦波那样精确波动。价格和价差会随着公司、政府乃至文明发展进程的不确定性而变化。它们并不比它们所反映的社会经济活动更有确定性。掷骰子的结果可以精确到小数点后一位；俄罗斯的局势则不然；交易员对俄罗斯局势的反应更难以预测。与掷骰子不同，市场不仅受风险（一种算术概念）的影响，还受笼罩未来的更广泛的不确定性的影响。不幸的是，与风险不同，不确定性是一种不确定的状态，它无法用数字来定义。

Even when traders get things “right,” markets can hardly be expected to oscillate with the precision of sine waves. Prices and spreads vary with the uncertain progress of companies, governments, and even civilizations. They are no more certain than the societies whose economic activity they reflect. Dice are predictable down to the decimal point; Russia is not; how traders will respond to Russia is less predictable still. Unlike dice, markets are subject not merely to risk, an arithmetic concept, but also to the broader uncertainty that shadows the future generally. Unfortunately, uncertainty, as opposed to risk, is an indefinite condition, one that does not conform to numerical straitjackets.

教授们模糊了这一关键区别；他们满怀信心地将他们数学上的“弗兰肯斯坦”送入世界，仿佛它能驯服生活中一切偶然因素。他们毫无自我怀疑，也毫无远见地投入如此惊人的巨额赌注。

The professors blurred this crucial distinction; they sent their mathematical Frankenstein gamely into the world as if it could tame the element of chance in life itself. No self-doubt tempered them; no sense of perspective checked them as they wagered such staggering sums.

最讽刺的是，这些教授试图解构风险并最终将其最小化，而不是——他们认为——去投机取巧地克服风险。在这一点上，该基金并非个例。事实上，“长期基金”是20世纪后期最具代表性的基金——它是一项将市场与金融经济学和计算机编程这两门新兴学科相结合的实验。几乎所有投资银行和交易部门都普遍认为，可以根据昨天的价格和波动性来推断明天的风险。这正是“长期基金”的根本错误，其惊人的损失暴露了现代金融核心——或者说大脑——的缺陷。

The supreme irony is that the professors were trying to deconstruct and ultimately to minimize risk, not—they believed—to speculate on overcoming it. In this, the fund was not unique. Long-Term was in fact the quintessential fund of the late twentieth century—an experiment in harnessing the markets to the twin new disciplines of financial economics and computer programming. The belief that tomorrow’s risks can be inferred from yesterday’s prices and volatilities prevails at virtually every investment bank and trading desk. This was Long-Term’s basic mistake, and its stunning losses betrayed the flaw at the very heart—the very brain—of modern finance.

美林证券在其1998年年报中指出：“美林证券使用数学风险模型来帮助评估其市场风险敞口。” 该行似乎开始意识到此类模型的危险性，并补充道，这些模型“可能会提供过高的安全感；因此，应限制对这些模型的依赖。” 20如果华尔街要从长期投资惨败中吸取一个教训，那应该是这一点。下次再有像默顿这样的人提出精妙的模型来管理风险和预测概率，下次再有人声称一台拥有完美记忆的计算机可以量化未来的风险时，投资者应该赶紧避而远之。

None other than Merrill Lynch observed in its annual report for 1998, “Merrill Lynch uses mathematical risk models to help estimate its exposure to market risk.” In a phrase that suggested some slight dawning awareness of the dangers in such models, the bank added that they “may provide a greater sense of security than warranted; therefore, reliance on these models should be limited.”20 If Wall Street is to learn just one lesson from the Long-Term debacle, it should be that. The next time a Merton proposes an elegant model to manage risks and foretell odds, the next time a computer with a perfect memory of the past is said to quantify risks in the future, investors should run—and quickly—the other way.

然而，华尔街似乎鲜有吸取教训之人。1999年11月，JWM Partners——其负责人包括梅里韦瑟、哈格尼、希利布兰德、利希、罗森菲尔德和阿琼·克里希纳马查尔——发布了“相对价值机会基金II”的招股说明书。根据该说明书，新基金的杠杆率将控制在相对较低的15:1，投资纪律将更加严格，公司还将采用一套“风险控制系统”，旨在“尽可能确保投资组合公司能够抵御类似1998年那样的极端事件”。任何基于以往危机设计的数学系统能否确保未来不会重蹈覆辙都值得怀疑，但对梅里韦瑟而言，JWM的成功推出无疑是又一次惊人的东山再起，而这正是华尔街闻名遐迩的“壮举”。 12 月，在经历了一场似乎要拖垮整个华尔街和他本人的史诗级崩盘，损失了 45 亿美元之后 15 个月，梅里韦瑟筹集了 2.5 亿美元，其中大部分来自命运多舛的长期资本公司以前的投资者，他又重新开始了他的事业。

On Wall Street, though, few lessons remain learned. In November 1999, JWM Partners—the principals were Meriwether, Haghani, Hilibrand, Leahy, Rosenfeld, and Arjun Krishnamachar—circulated an offering document for “Relative Value Opportunity Fund II.” According to the circular, leverage in their new fund would be held to a relatively modest 15 to 1, discipline would be tighter, and the firm would make use of a “risk control system” that had been designed “to help ensure to the extent practicable that the Portfolio Company can withstand extreme events of the type experienced in 1998.” Whether any mathematical system designed with a previous crisis in mind can ensure against future debacles is doubtful, but for Meriwether, the successful launch of JWM was yet another astonishing comeback, the sort for which Wall Street is justly famous. In December, fifteen months after he lost $4.5 billion in an epic bust that seemed about to take down all of Wall Street and more with him, Meriwether raised $250 million, much of it from former investors in the ill-fated Long-Term Capital, and he was off and running again.

后记，2010





Afterword, 2010





在长期资本管理公司（LTCM）获救整整十年后，发生了以下事件：美国政府出手救助了抵押贷款巨头房利美和房地美；雷曼兄弟破产；美联储出手救助了美国国际集团（AIG）；联邦存款保险公司（FDIC）通过将高盛和摩根士丹利转型为商业银行，使其免于破产；美国财政部出手救助了货币市场行业；以及一项旨在促进联邦政府对美国银行业投资的法案被提出（并很快获得通过）。这一切发生之时，所有市场都处于持续且不断加剧的恐慌之中。在一个关键的周末，正如十年前一样，华尔街各大公司的负责人被召集到纽约联储，再次被恳求出手救助其中一家公司，以免其倒闭拖垮整个集团。然而，贝尔斯登却明显缺席了这一行列——它是唯一一家拒绝出手救助LTCM的公司。 2008年3月，濒临破产的贝尔斯登在美联储的协助下被一家收购方全盘吞并。据说，贝尔斯登并没有从长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的失败中吸取教训。但哪家公司没有吸取教训呢？华尔街以及那些肩负其福祉重任的监管机构，是否曾如此忠实地重蹈覆辙，而且规模如此惨重？

Ten years to the month after the rescue of Long-Term Capital Management, the following events occurred: the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were bailed out by the U.S. government; Lehman Brothers failed; AIG was rescued by the Federal Reserve; the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation saved Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley from imminent peril by converting them to commercial banks; the U.S. Treasury bailed out the money market industry; and legislation was introduced (and, shortly thereafter, approved) to advance federal investment in the country’s banks. This drama unfolded while markets—all markets—were in a state of sustained and accelerating panic. Over a key weekend, just as they were a decade earlier, the heads of the Wall Street firms were summoned to the New York Fed and once again implored to rescue one of their number, lest its failure weaken the lot. One firm conspicuously missing from the group—the only one that had refused to help rescue LTCM—was Bear Stearns. In March 2008, itself on the verge of failure, Bear had been swallowed whole by an acquirer assisted by the Fed. Bear, it was said, had not learned its lesson from LTCM. But of which firm could this not be said? Was there ever a case in which all of Wall Street, and the regulators to whom its well-being was entrusted, had so faithfully reenacted a previous folly, and on such a cataclysmic scale?

《天才陨落之时》一书写于长期资本管理公司（LTCM）倒闭之后，原本是一部独立成篇的纪实作品。然而，时事往往会重新诠释看似尘埃落定的历史。在2008年市场崩盘之后，我们的故事不再显得那么偶然；十年后重温，梅里韦瑟交易员的遭遇与其说是时代的例外，不如说是时代的模板。如果说我们正生活在一个前所未有的市场动荡时代，那么LTCM的倒闭就是一个警示——可惜，这个警示被忽视了。它是毁灭性地震前的一次震颤。

When Genius Failed was written, in the aftermath of LTCM’s downfall, as a chronicle of a singular, stand-alone drama. But current events have a way of reinterpreting seemingly settled history. In the wake of the market collapse of 2008, our story looks less random; revisited a decade later, the saga of Meriwether’s traders appears to be less the exception to our time than its template. If, as it now seems, we are living in an age of unparalleled market turbulence, the fall of LTCM was a warning—alas, unheeded. It was the tremor that prefaced the devastating quake.

今昔对比显而易见。在每个关键时刻，华尔街的精英们都因过度杠杆而将公司置于危险境地。他们钟爱的是时髦而复杂的金融工具（例如长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的“股票波动率”；2008年的抵押贷款担保债务凭证），这些工具无论是普通投资者还是经验丰富的贷款机构都无力评估。不，评估工作完全依靠机械记忆，也就是依靠计算机模型，这些模型拥有对过往价格的百科全书式记忆。无论哪种情况，这些模型都没有进行前瞻性分析。21世纪头十年的房价走势图显示，房价将继续沿着其向上倾斜的曲线一路高歌猛进。信用评级机构——穆迪、标准普尔、惠誉——以及其他众多参与抵押贷款泡沫的机构，例如贷款机构、投资银行和借款人，都没有想到，这种趋势可能会出现反转，或者损失（即抵押贷款违约）的分布范围可能会超出正态分布曲线和以往经验的预测。但这正是LTCM失败的原因。格林威治的金融专家们曾一度认为，在任何交易日，他们的风险敞口都不会超过3500万美元。至少他们的模型是这么说的。但俄罗斯违约后不久，市场剧烈动荡，该基金在8月份的一天之内就损失了5.53亿美元。同样，在接下来的十年里，惠誉（Fitch）——这家将如今臭名昭著的抵押贷款证券评为AAA级的公司之一——的模型专家们甚至没有预料到房价会下跌2%或3%。而最终，房价下跌了30%甚至更多。

The similarities between then and now are plain. At each juncture, the best minds on Wall Street put their firms at risk with undue leverage. The objects of their affections were fashionably complex financial instruments (“equity volatility” in the case of LTCM; mortgage collateralized debt obligations in 2008) that neither average investors nor sophisticated lenders were capable of evaluating. No, the evaluations were performed by rote, that is, by computer models invested with an encyclopedic memory of past prices. In neither case did the models look forward. Home prices in the first decade of the twenty-first century were plotted to continue cheerily on their upward-sloping curve. It did not occur to the credit-rating agencies—Moody’s, Standard & Poor’s, Fitch—or to numerous others invested in the mortgage bubble, such as lenders, investment banks, and borrowers, that the slope could invert, or that the distribution of loss (that is, of mortgage default) could widen outside what the bell curve, and previous experience, predicted. But this was precisely what had foiled LTCM. The wizards of Greenwich took succor in the knowledge that they had, on a given trading day, no more than $35 million at risk. Or so their models said. But shortly after Russia’s default, markets were so upset that the fund lost (in a single day in August) $553 million. Just so, in the ensuing decade, the modelers at Fitch, one of the firms that stamped the now-notorious mortgage securities as triple-A, did not envision even a modest 2 or 3 percent decline in housing prices. In the event, they were to fall 30 percent and more.

因此，我们再次吸取了关于杠杆的惨痛教训（或者至少是被重新教育了一遍），也认识到了公式化风险管理的不可靠性。梅里韦瑟本人也不得不重新消化这些教训。2009年，在他创立JWM Partners（LTCM的继任者）十年后，他再次遭受了惨重的损失。这支第二支基金也最终关闭。诚然，这两个时期在关键方面存在差异。最明显的是，导致LTCM倒闭的危机源于海外，尤其是在俄罗斯；它并非美国经济根本问题的体现。而最近的危机则截然不同。这一次，麻烦始于住宅房地产，这是国内生产总值的重要组成部分。我们或许可以列举其他对比，但更值得探讨的问题是，为什么像1998年和2008年那样的市场风暴会成为金融环境的常见现象。尽管它们的起源各不相同，但每次危机引发的都是彻头彻尾的市场恐慌。此类事件正变得越来越常见，或许可以追溯到1987年10月19日（“黑色星期一”）的惨剧：道琼斯工业平均指数暴跌超过22%，却没有任何消息可以解释如此剧烈的崩盘。紧随其后的是1990年，投资者纷纷抛售垃圾债券，重创美国经济。1997年，国际外汇市场的一系列恐慌迫使众多发展中国家大幅贬值本国货币。即使是2001年安然公司的倒闭——该公司依赖于错综复杂的衍生品交易构建的不透明合伙关系——也带有现代经济弊病的鲜明特征：无限的复杂性之后便是市场动荡。在所有这些时期——至少在2008年金融危机之前——基础经济的表现总体上更为稳定。然而，本应反映经济状况的市场却日益动荡。

We have, then, relearned (or at least we have been retaught) a painful lesson about leverage, and also about the unreliability of formulaic risk management. Meriwether himself had to reabsorb such lessons. In 2009, ten years after founding JWM Partners, a successor to LTCM, he suffered horrendous losses again. This second fund was also shuttered. It is true, obviously, that the two periods differed in key respects. Most obviously, the crisis that undid LTCM germinated overseas, in particular in Russia; it was not indicative of a fundamental problem in the U.S. economy. The recent crisis most certainly was. This time, the trouble began in residential real estate, a basic component of the gross domestic product. We may draw other contrasts, but the more interesting question is why market storms, as evidenced in both 1998 and 2008, have become such a common element of the financial climate. Though their origins were distinct, the reaction to each episode was unadulterated market panic. Such occurrences are growing increasingly familiar, beginning perhaps with the spectacle of October 19, 1987 (“Black Monday”), when the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell more than 22 percent, without any news that could account for such a crash. It was followed, in 1990, by a headlong flight from junk bonds, which crippled the U.S. economy. Then, in 1997, a series of panics in international exchange markets forced a slew of developing countries to devalue their currencies sharply. Even the 2001 collapse of Enron, which was dependent on opaque partnerships contrived with interlocking derivatives, bore strong traces of the modern affliction of boundless complexity followed by market turbulence. In all this time—at least until the crash of 2008—the performance of the underlying economy was generally more stable. Yet the markets that purported to reflect it were increasingly turbulent.

情况并非一直如此。直到20世纪70年代左右，金融市场一直沉闷乏味。道琼斯指数虽有涨跌，但市场在国家和国际事务中的影响力却十分有限。即使是经验丰富的投资者，如果想要押注瑞士法郎的走势或长期利率，也鲜有可乘之机。如果有人想押注未来抵押贷款利率的下降（例如，通过浮动利率抵押贷款），当时根本没有这样的产品。金融世界一片死寂——用“固定”或许更能体现投机渠道的匮乏。资金存放的选择寥寥无几（货币市场基金并不存在），银行提供的收益率也受到严格控制。货币价值被布雷顿森林体系牢牢锁定，在各国境内，银行业受到高度监管。即使是那些留给私营部门的选择，最终也往往由中央决策者决定。银行高管们默默无闻地设定着最优惠贷款利率。德克萨斯州的石油大亨，以及后来的沙特阿拉伯酋长，决定了石油的价格。自由市场或许对大豆贸易商有利，但以今天的标准来看，这种市场的覆盖范围相对有限。

It was not always thus. Until the 1970s, or thereabouts, financial markets were a stolid and dull affair. The Dow went up and down, but the presence of markets in national as well as international affairs was limited. If an individual—even a sophisticated investor—wanted to take a flier on the direction of the Swiss franc, or of long-term interest rates, he or she had few ways of doing so. If one wished to gamble on a future decline in mortgage rates (say, with an adjustable-rate mortgage), no such product existed. The financial world was static—fixed may better communicate the lack of avenues available for speculation. There were few choices for where to park money (money market funds didn’t exist) and the yields that banks could offer were tightly controlled. Currency values were locked into place by the Bretton Woods framework, and within national boundaries, banking was highly regulated. Even such choices as were left to the private sector tended to be resolved by centralized decision-makers. Faceless bank executives set the prime lending rate. Texas oilmen and, later, Saudi sheiks set the price of oil. Free markets may have been good for soybean traders, but by today’s standards, the reach of such markets was relatively restricted.

这一切始于1971年美国放弃金本位制，世界各国开始实行浮动汇率制。这一大胆的自由化举措与贸易限制放松的趋势不谋而合。随着越来越多的商品和美元跨境流动，各国央行被迫扮演宽松的货币政策角色；它们的任务（无论它们如何否认）日益成为维护国际货币流动的平衡。通俗地说，它们必须维持市场稳定，或者说，这就是它们的目标。随着时间的推移，人们逐渐难以分辨，究竟是像乔治·索罗斯这样的全球贸易巨头在适应英格兰银行制定的规则，还是英格兰银行在适应索罗斯的策略。

All that began to change when the United States, in 1971, went off the gold standard and the world adopted floating exchange rates. This bold liberalization dovetailed with a trend toward loosening trade restrictions. With both more goods and more dollars crossing borders, central banks were forced into an accommodative role; their task (however much they denied it) was increasingly to preserve an equilibrium in international currency flows. In lay terms, they had to keep markets quiet, or that was the goal. In time, it was unclear whether a global trader such as George Soros was adapting to the rules set down by the Bank of England or whether the bank was adapting to Soros.

在20世纪70年代至80年代初期，一系列进一步的自由化改革极大地拓展了金融市场的领域。其中一些改革是为应对布雷顿森林体系的终结而做出的必要调整。（由于人们可以自由地将资金存放在全球任何地方，银行被迫展开资产争夺战，存折利率的限制也被取消。）另一些改革则是由日益盛行的自由放任主义思潮推动或促成的，这种思潮对市场自由没有任何限制。最终，金融市场与20世纪60年代固定不变的金融体系之间的转变几乎完成。期货市场的范围扩大，不仅涵盖了猪肚和小麦，还包括货币、利率和石油。衍生品交易如同野苹果般迅速蔓延——似乎每年都有新的衍生品涌现。

In the decade of the 1970s and into the early 1980s, a series of further liberalizations greatly expanded the terrain of financial markets. Some of these reforms were necessary accommodations to the end of Bretton Woods. (With people free to put their money anywhere around the globe, banks were forced to compete for their assets, and controls on passbook savings rates were eliminated.) Still other reforms were instigated, or eased, by the gathering ideology of laissez-faire, which brooked no limits on market freedoms. In due course, the change from the fixed universe of the 1960s was near-complete. Futures markets were widened to include not just pork bellies and wheat but also currencies, interest rates, and oil. Derivative plays multiplied like crab apples—every year, or so it seemed, a new species blossomed.

多样性带来了相应的复杂性增长。交易员们交易的金融工具——例如股票波动率——会让普通民众完全摸不着头脑。即使是普通的房主，曾经只提供普通三十年期抵押贷款的储蓄银行，如今也提供了种类繁多的贷款产品（房屋净值贷款、可调利率抵押贷款、期权可调利率抵押贷款），就像冰淇淋店里的冰淇淋一样琳琅满目。这不仅归功于金融家的创造力，也得益于一种新兴的风险转移机制。证券化——顾名思义，就是将固定资产转化为可交易证券的过程——将大量普通的银行贷款，例如信用卡债务和抵押贷款，转化为投资者持有的市场工具。当银行可以将债务转移到市场上时，信贷分配方式发生了微妙的转变。过去，是否放贷的决定权在于银行家。而现在，市场决定了谁应该获得融资以及融资的条件。在广泛的经济活动中，权力逐渐下放至公众（即民众）手中。2000年代，推动油价从每桶30美元飙升至140美元的并非沙特酋长，而是国际贸易商。决定企业并购方案的并非首席执行官，而是公众投资者。新型信贷衍生品取代银行家，成为决定企业能否获得融资或被迫申请破产的主要力量。甚至国家的命运也交由市场决定，市场可以瞬间提供和收回信贷——20世纪90年代亚洲和拉丁美洲的货币危机，以及2010年对希腊、爱尔兰乃至未来可能出现的其他国家的救助，便是明证。

Variety bequeathed a corresponding rise in complexity. Traders dealt in instruments—equity volatility is a good example—that would have completely baffled the average citizen. Even at the level of ordinary homeowners, savings banks that once had been content to offer plain-vanilla, thirty-year mortgages now offered as many flavors (home equity loans, ARMs, option ARMs), as Ben & Jerry’s. This owed not only to the creativity of financiers but to a new and evolving mechanism for transferring risk. Securitization—literally, the process of turning fixed assets into tradable securities—converted a large swath of ordinary bank loans, such as credit card debts and mortgages, into market instruments held by investors. When banks could offload debts onto markets, there was a subtle shift in how credit was allocated. Formerly, the decision of whether to lend had been up to the banker. Now the market determined who should be financed and under what terms. Across a broad spectrum of economic activity, authority devolved into public (i.e., popular) hands. Not Saudi sheiks, but international traders sent oil prices soaring in the 2000s, from $30 a barrel to $140. Not CEOs but public investors ruled on proposed corporate acquisitions. New derivatives in credit instruments supplanted bankers as the chief agents in determining whether corporations obtained financing or were forced to file for bankruptcy. Even the fate of countries was left to markets, which supplied and then withdrew credit in an eyeblink—witness the currency crises in Asia and Latin America in the 1990s and the bailouts in 2010 of Greece, Ireland, and maybe others to come.

市场领域的扩张并非完全是坏事，甚至可能大部分是坏事。在市场时代之前——一个像LTCM这样的公司并不存在的世界——金融界是静态的、僵化的，而且往往对经济现实反应迟钝。货币价值稳定并不一定意味着它们是正确的。对冲基金和其他交易员发挥着作用，主要目的是纠正价格偏差。但市场的平衡轮也可能脱离现实的锚定。与其他受民意影响的机构一样，市场有时会走向极端——有时甚至走向危险的极端。说市场通常是理智的，并且在确定信贷工具之间合理的利差方面通常比政府做得更好（这正是LTCM的目标），并不意味着市场总是正确的。这种区别至关重要，因为它体现了认识到市场监管的必要性与采取绝对不干预的态度之间的区别。

It is not entirely, or perhaps even mostly, a misfortune that the province of markets expanded. The financial world prior to the age of markets—a world in which firms such as LTCM did not exist—was static, inflexible, and often unresponsive to economic reality. The fact that currency values were stable did not necessarily mean that they were right. Hedge funds and other traders have their role, chiefly to correct misaligned prices. But the balancing wheel of markets can also spring loose from the mooring of reality. Like other institutions subject to popular passions, markets, on occasion, run to extremes—on occasion to dangerous extremes. To say that markets are usually sensible, and ordinarily better than government at determining the proper spread between credit instruments (the task that LTCM set out for itself), is not to say that markets are always right. The difference is crucial, for it is the difference between recognizing the need for market supervision and adopting a pose of absolute noninterference.

长期资本管理公司（LTCM）诞生于一个意识形态的温室，一个自由放任主义教条滋生的沃土。令公共监管机构（尤其是艾伦·格林斯潘）趋之若鹜的“有效”市场理论，在学术界也无人能及。这些学者们曾向我们保证，市场实际上是科学仪器，其出错的可能性与经过精确校准的火箭一样微乎其微。在学术界，没有哪两位权威人士能比得上这家对冲基金的内部理论家——诺贝尔奖得主罗伯特·默顿和迈伦·斯科尔斯，有效市场理论的上层建筑很大程度上正是建立在他们的教诲之上。在LTCM成立之前，市场失灵的多次事件本应早已让我们醒悟，不再自以为是。（郁金香泡沫呢？1929年呢？）然而，不知何故，这个神话却一直延续了下来。即使在1998年市场动荡之后，格林斯潘、罗伯特·鲁宾、拉里·萨默斯和阿瑟·莱维特组成的监管集团仍然压制了衍生品监管（至少可以说，这对于一场与衍生品密切相关的危机而言，是一种奇怪的应对方式）。国会在2000年末通过了《商品期货现代化法案》，将他们的阻挠合法化。而那时，下一个泡沫（互联网股票泡沫）已经开始破裂。

LTCM was hatched in an ideological hothouse, a fecund swamp for the doctrine of laissez-faire. The theory of “efficient” markets that so seduced public regulators, notably Alan Greenspan, was surpassed only within the high church of the academy, whose disciples assured us, for more than a generation, that markets were, in fact, scientific instruments no more capable of mishap than were properly calibrated rockets. No two priests stood higher in the academy than the hedge fund’s in-house theoretician-Nobelists, Robert Merton and Myron Scholes, on whose pedagogic shoulders much of the superstructure of efficient markets was erected. The multiple episodes of market failure predating LTCM should long ago have disabused us of the conceit of perfection. (What of the tulip bubble? What of 1929?) Somehow, the myth endured. Even after the market seizures of 1998, a regulatory cabal of Greenspan, Robert Rubin, Larry Summers, and Arthur Levitt stifled regulation of derivatives (a strange response to a crisis steeped in derivatives, to say the least). Congress codified their resistance by enacting the Commodity Futures Modernization Act late in 2000. By then, the next bubble (in dot-com stocks) was already bursting.

如今金融市场更加无处不在。泡沫增多，危害更大，也就不足为奇了——我们更容易受到市场过度波动的影响。并非所有过度波动都需要干预，无论是预防还是事后干预。但2008年的金融危机与1998年的危机如出一辙，足以澄清一些担忧。首先，有效市场或完美市场的幻想永远不应被打破。格林斯潘曾说过一句名言：私下协商的衍生品不需要监管，因为交易双方的自身利益会阻止他们将自己的机构置于风险之中。但对于长期资本管理公司（LTCM）和雷曼兄弟来说，这都不成立。由此推论，无论是对冲基金、评级机构还是银行，私人公司开发的风险模型都不能可靠地预测未来。即使政府监管机构应用这些模型，其应用也存在缺陷，因为它们将过去的市场历史视为既定真理。但我们必须强调，市场是不完美的；它们是由无数投资者组成的集合体，其中大多数投资者通常会理性行事——正如历史所表明的那样，通常是这样，但并非总是如此。

Financial markets now are more pervasive. It should be no surprise that we have more bubbles and more harmful ones—that we are left more vulnerable to market excess. Not all excesses warrant intervention, either preventively or after the fact. But 2008’s echo of 1998 was sharp enough to clarify a few concerns. First, the chimera of efficient or perfect markets should ever be laid to rest. Greenspan said famously that privately negotiated derivatives did not need regulation because the parties’ self-interest would keep them from putting their institutions at risk. It was not true for LTCM, nor was it for Lehman. As a corollary, the risk models developed by private firms, whether hedge funds, rating agencies, or banks, are not reliable guides to the future. Even when these models are applied by government regulators, their application is flawed, because they look to past market history as received truth. But markets, we must emphasize, are imperfect; they are the agglomeration of myriad investors, most of whom usually act rationally—usually, as history has shown, but not always.

即使是完全理性的投资者也会恐慌，就像剧院观众一想到火灾就会惊慌失措，以免成为最后一个离开的人一样；这种传染的威胁使得金融市场本质上不稳定。恐慌的易发性在信贷市场尤为令人担忧。信贷是贷款人对借款人的一种押注；每一笔贷款都是对偿还能力的赌博。当市场判断出现偏差时，太多人要么获得信贷，要么被拒之门外。任何一种极端情况都会导致大范围的破产。正是这种对系统性崩溃的恐惧，使得长期资本管理公司（LTCM）的倒闭和抵押贷款泡沫的破裂都造成了如此巨大的动荡。两者都是由过度负债造成的。在银行家们更成熟的时代，一家公司的倒闭并不会自动引发信贷的全面停止。而现在，当一家公司（甚至一个国家）被认为负债过重时，市场可以而且将会切断对所有企业的信贷。偿付能力变成了一种任性的决定。当那些长期需要资金的机构受到市场短期波动的影响时，其偿付能力尤其岌岌可危。LTCM并非最后一家抱怨市场对其不公平对待的金融公司；贝尔斯登和雷曼兄弟也曾表达过类似的观点。但市场很少会接受怜悯之心。目前看来，只有两种应对之策。首先，应更严格地限制那些以信贷交易为特征的赌场式市场（例如信用违约互换）。其次，社会对其偿付能力负有持续责任的机构，不应被允许过度依赖任何类型的杠杆，尤其是“热钱”（短期市场融资）。在LTCM事件之后，这些教训被刻意忽略，或许是出于一种认为此类事件不会再次发生的心理。但无论如何，2008年的事件提醒我们，LTCM的案例在未来仍具有重要的借鉴意义。这家对冲基金的崩盘来得迅猛、惨烈且异常戏剧化，但事后看来，却并不令人意外。套用默顿·米勒的话来说，与其说这是自然规律的缺陷，不如说是充斥着过度杠杆参与者、进行复杂押注的市场生态系统的必然结果。只要这种体系依然存在，长期资本管理公司（LTCM）就将继续成为时代的一个典型案例。

Even perfectly logical investors will panic, as will theatergoers at the mere possibility of fire, so as not to be last to the exit; this threat of contagion renders financial markets inherently unstable. The susceptibility to panic is especially troublesome when manifest in credit markets. Credit is a wager that the lender makes with respect to the borrower; every loan is a gamble on repayment. When the market’s calculation is off, too many people are either offered credit or denied it. Either extreme will result in widespread failures. This (the fear of systemic failure) is why both LTCM and the collapse of the mortgage bubble were so destabilizing. Each was caused by a condition of overindebtedness. In the more refined age of drawing-room bankers, one firm’s failure did not automatically trigger a generalized cessation of credit. Now, when one firm (or even one country) is seen to be overly in hock, the market can and will shut off credit to all. Solvency becomes a matter of whim. Solvency is especially precarious when institutions with a long-term need for capital are subject to the market’s short-term gyrations. LTCM was not the last financial firm to complain that the market turned on it unfairly; Bear Stearns and Lehman said similar things. But markets are rarely receptive to pleas for mercy. Only two defenses suggest themselves. The first is to restrict more tightly the types of casino-type markets (credit default swaps come to mind) that trade in credit. Secondly, institutions in whose solvency society has an ongoing interest cannot be permitted to rely too heavily on leverage of any type, and on “hot money” (short-term market funding) in particular. These lessons were dutifully ignored in the wake of the LTCM fiasco, perhaps on the theory that it wouldn’t happen again. If nothing else, the events of 2008 remind us of LTCM’s poignant significance going forward. The hedge fund’s fall was swift, brutal, and uncommonly dramatic, but it was not, in retrospect, surprising. To paraphrase Merton Miller, it was less a bad drawing from nature’s urn than the predictable result of a market ecosystem stacked with overleveraged players making convoluted bets. As long as the system remains that way, LTCM will remain a paradigm for the age.

笔记

NOTES

Epigraph: Henry T. C. Hu, “Misunderstood Derivatives: The Causes of Informational Failure and the Promise of Regulatory Incrementalism,” The Yale Law Journal, 102, no. 6 (April 1993), 1477.

2 • 对冲基金

2   •  Hedge Fund

题词：菲尔丁引文：牛津英语词典，第 2 版，第 7 卷（牛津：克拉伦登出版社，1989 年），第 94 页；霍姆斯引文：同上，第 96 页，引用霍姆斯的《旧生活、面包和报刊页》（1891 年），第 12 页。

17. James Blitz, “Bank of Italy Put $250m into LTCM,” Financial Times, October 2, 1998.

18. Author interview with Walter Weiner.

19. Author interview with Terence Sullivan; Michael Siconolfi, Anita Raghavan, and Mitchell Pacelle, “All Bets Are Off: How the Salesmanship and Brainpower Failed at Long-Term Capital,” The Wall Street Journal, November 16, 1998.

3 • 逃亡中

3   •  On the Run

题词：道格拉斯·布里登，出自约翰·穆林，《数字中的约翰·梅里韦瑟》，《机构投资者》 ，1996 年 11 月。

4 • 尊敬的投资者们

4   •  Dear Investors

题词：作者对默顿·H·米勒的采访。

Epigraph: Author interview with Merton H. Miller.

1. LTCM，致投资者的信，“附录#1，长期资本投资组合有限合伙投资的波动性和风险特征”，1994 年 10 月 10 日。

1. LTCM, letter to investors, “Addendum #1, Volatility and Risk Characteristics of Investments in Long-Term Capital Portfolio L.P.,” October 10, 1994.

2. Leah Nathans Spiro，“梦之队”，《商业周刊》， 1994 年 8 月 29 日。

2. Leah Nathans Spiro, “Dream Team,” Business Week, August 29, 1994.

3. Peter L. Bernstein，《与神对抗：风险的非凡故事》（纽约：John Wiley & Sons，1996 年），第 141-2 页。

3. Peter L. Bernstein, Against the Gods: The Remarkable Story of Risk (New York: John Wiley & Sons, 1996), 141–2.

4. Fischer Black 和 Myron Scholes，“期权和公司负债的定价”，《政治经济学杂志》， 1973 年 5 月至 6 月，第 637-654 页。许多作者都评论过该公式与物理学的联系；例如，参见 Todd E. Petzel，“Fischer Black 与衍生品革命”，《投资组合管理杂志》， 1996 年 12 月，第 87-91 页：“Black-Scholes 公式是物理学中的一个基本热交换方程。”

4. Fischer Black and Myron Scholes, “The Pricing of Options and Corporate Liabilities,” Journal of Political Economy, May–June 1973, 637–54. Many writers have commented on the formula’s link to physics; see, e.g., Todd E. Petzel, “Fischer Black and the Derivatives Revolution,” Journal of Portfolio Management, December 1996, 87–91: “The Black-Scholes formula is a basic heat exchange equation from physics.”

5. 引自伯恩斯坦，《与神对抗》，第 331 页。

5. Quoted in Bernstein, Against the Gods, 331.

6. Peter L. Bernstein，《资本理念：现代华尔街的不可思议的起源》（纽约：自由出版社，1992 年），第 216 页。

6. Peter L. Bernstein, Capital Ideas: The Improbable Origins of Modern Wall Street (New York: Free Press, 1992), 216.

7. 作者对威廉·萨尔曼的采访。

7. Author interview with William Sahlman.

8. 作者对保罗·萨缪尔森的采访。

8. Author interview with Paul Samuelson.

9. 尤金·F·法玛，“股票市场价格的行为”，重印系列，第 39 号，商业与经济数学研究中心，芝加哥大学商学院，转载自《芝加哥大学商业杂志》，第 38 卷，第 1 期（1965 年 1 月）。

9. Eugene F. Fama, “The Behavior of Stock-Market Prices,” Reprint Series, No. 39, Center for Mathematical Studies in Business and Economics, Graduate School of Business, University of Chicago, reprinted from The Journal of Business of the University of Chicago, 38, no. 1 (January 1965).

10. 同上，第 94 页。

10. Ibid., 94.

11. 最早注意到这一现象的是贝努瓦·曼德尔布罗特，他记录了棉花价格的肥尾现象。曼德尔布罗特是一位波兰裔数学家，曾在IBM和耶鲁大学工作，并指导法玛完成论文。

11. The first person to notice the phenomenon, Benoit Mandelbrot, documented fat tails in cotton prices. Mandelbrot, a Polish-born mathematician, worked at IBM and Yale and advised Fama on his thesis.

12. 作者对尤金·F·法玛的采访。

12. Author interview with Eugene F. Fama.

13. Jens Carsten Jackwerth 和 Mark Rubinstein，“从期权价格中恢复概率分布”，《金融杂志》， 51，第 5 期（1996 年 12 月），1612。

13. Jens Carsten Jackwerth and Mark Rubinstein, “Recovering Probability Distributions from Option Prices,” The Journal of Finance, 51, no. 5 (December 1996), 1612.

14. Lawrence Summers，引自 Bruce I. Jacobs，《资本理念与市场现实：期权复制、投资者行为和股市崩盘》（马萨诸塞州马尔登：布莱克威尔出版社，1999 年），第 88 页。

14. Lawrence Summers, quoted in Bruce I. Jacobs, Capital Ideas and Market Realities: Option Replication, Investor Behavior, and Stock Market Crashes (Malden, Mass.: Blackwell, 1999), 88.

15. Robert C. Merton，未出版的自传，1998 年 5 月。

15. Robert C. Merton, unpublished autobiography, May 1998.

16. Terry A. Marsh 和 Robert C. Merton，“股票市场价格理性的股息变动性和方差界限检验”，《美国经济评论》， 76，第 3 期（1986 年 6 月），483-484。

16. Terry A. Marsh and Robert C. Merton, “Dividend Variability and Variance Bounds Tests for the Rationality of Stock Market Prices,” American Economic Review, 76, no. 3 (June 1986), 483–4.

17. 引自 Christopher May，《非线性定价：理论与应用》（纽约：John Wiley & Sons，1999 年），第 29 页。May 的这本书是一部诙谐而详尽的关于市场混乱的论著，对于任何想要更多地了解为什么市场不像咖啡里的奶油那样的人来说，都是最好的解释。

17. Quoted in Christopher May, Nonlinear Pricing: Theory and Applications (New York: John Wiley & Sons, 1999), 29. May’s book, a witty and detailed treatise on market disorder, is the best account for anyone who wants to understand more about why markets are not like the cream in your coffee.

18. Till M. Guldimann，摩根大通公司全球研究部，“Risk-Metrics™—技术文档”，1994 年 10 月；尤其参见第 1-28 页。

18. Till M. Guldimann, J. P. Morgan & Co., Global Research, “Risk-Metrics™—Technical Document,” October 1994; see especially 1–28.

19. André F. Perold，“长期资本管理有限合伙公司（A）”，哈佛商学院案例 N9-200-007，1999 年 10 月 27 日，第 10 页。

19. André F. Perold, “Long-Term Capital Management, L.P. (A),” Harvard Business School, case N9-200-007, October 27, 1999, 10.

20. 作者对埃里克·罗森菲尔德的采访。

20. Author interview with Eric Rosenfeld.

21. 本节中的数字来自两个来源：长期资本投资组合的财务报表（已提交商品期货交易委员会备案）和长期资本管理公司 1999 年 1 月 13 日的内部备忘录（解释了其 1998 年的亏损）。

21. The numbers in this section are from two sources: Long-Term Capital Portfolio’s financial statement, which is on file with the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, and Long-Term Capital Management’s internal memorandum of January 13, 1999, explaining its losses in 1998.

22. LTCM，致投资者的信，1995 年 7 月 15 日。

22. LTCM, letter to investors, July 15, 1995.

23. 该数字由作者根据 1999 年 1 月 13 日 LTCM 内部备忘录中披露的月度资产总额计算得出。

6 • 诺贝尔奖

6   •  A Nobel Prize

题词：罗伯特·库特纳，“你如何称呼一位做出预测的经济学家？错误”，《商业周刊》， 1999 年 9 月 6 日。

11. 这段文字的措辞与一位早期作家的措辞非常接近，因此我必须补充一句（结尾）感谢我的父亲路易斯·洛温斯坦，感谢他所著的《华尔街出了什么问题：短期收益和缺席股东》（纽约：艾迪生-韦斯利出版社，1988 年），第 67 页。

11. The phraseology is so close to that of an earlier writer that I must add an (end)note of gratitude to Louis Lowenstein, my father, for What’s Wrong with Wall Street: Short-Term Gain and the Absentee Shareholder (New York: Addison-Wesley, 1988), 67.

13. Robert Clow and Riva Atlas, “Wall Street and the Hedge Funds: What Went Wrong,” Institutional Investor, December 1998.

14. “瑞银集团又一团糟”，《欧洲货币》， 1998 年 11 月；迈克尔·西科诺尔菲、安妮塔·拉加万和米切尔·帕塞勒，“一切都完了：长期资本的销售技巧和智力是如何失败的”，《华尔街日报》， 1998 年 11 月 16 日。

18. Andrei Shleifer 和 Robert W. Vishny，“套利的局限性”，《金融杂志》， 52，第 1 期（1997 年 3 月），35-54 页，尤其是 45 页。

18. Andrei Shleifer and Robert W. Vishny, “The Limits of Arbitrage,” Journal of Finance, 52, no. 1 (March 1997), 35–54, especially 45.

19. 作者对约翰·坎贝尔的采访。

19. Author interview with John Campbell.

20. Gregory Zuckerman，“信贷市场：外国债券受到亚洲市场动荡的冲击”，《华尔街日报》， 1997 年 7 月 16 日。

20. Gregory Zuckerman, “Credit Markets: Foreign Bonds Hit by Turmoil in Asia Markets,” The Wall Street Journal, July 16, 1997.

21. 引文出自 Nicholas D. Kristof 和 David E. Sanger 合著的《美国如何赢得亚洲让现金流入》，该文发表于1999 年 2 月 16 日的《纽约时报》，并且本节内容也大量引用了该文。

17. Lisa Endlich, Goldman Sachs: The Culture of Success (New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1999); see especially 126–8.

10 • 在美联储

结语

1. John Greenwald，《时代周刊》， 1998 年 10 月 5 日；《旧金山纪事报》， 1998年 10 月 1 日；《波士顿环球报》， 1998 年 9 月 27 日； 《费城问询报》， 1998 年 9 月 27 日；《迈阿密先驱报》， 1998 年 9 月 27 日。

2. Michael Lewis，“书呆子们是如何崩溃的”，《纽约时报杂志》， 1999 年 1 月 24 日。

2. Michael Lewis, “How the Eggheads Cracked,” The New York Times Magazine, January 24, 1999.

3. 作者对尤金·F·法玛的采访。

3. Author interview with Eugene F. Fama.

4. 刘易斯，《书呆子是如何崩溃的》。

4. Lewis, “How the Eggheads Cracked.”

5. Matt Murray，“信孚银行遭受 4.88 亿美元损失”，《华尔街日报》， 1998 年 10 月 23 日；Paul Beckett，“信孚银行前董事长预计将从德意志银行邮政离职”，《华尔街日报》， 1999 年 6 月 25 日。

5. Matt Murray, “Bankers Trust Is Hit by $488 Million Loss,” The Wall Street Journal, October 23, 1998; Paul Beckett, “Former Chairman of Bankers Trust Is Expected to Quit Deutsche Bank Post,” The Wall Street Journal, June 25, 1999.

6. Peter Truell，“获得救助的对冲基金裁减了 18% 的员工”，《纽约时报》， 1998 年 10 月 28 日。

6. Peter Truell, “Bailed-Out Hedge Fund Cutting 18% of Its Staff,” The New York Times, October 28, 1998.

7. 刘易斯，《书呆子是如何崩溃的》。

7. Lewis, “How the Eggheads Cracked.”

8. 参见 Lewis，“智囊团如何崩溃”，以及 Mitchell Pacelle、Randall Smith 和 Anita Raghavan，“投资者可能会看到‘LTCM，续集’”，《华尔街日报》，1999 年 5 月 20 日。

8. See Lewis, “How the Eggheads Cracked,” and Mitchell Pacelle, Randall Smith, and Anita Raghavan, “Investors May See ‘LTCM, the Sequel, ’ ” The Wall Street Journal, May 20, 1999.

9. Myron S. Scholes，“风险降低方法：平衡风险和回报率目标”，在1999 年 9 月 22 日至 23 日于纽约举行的《经济学人》投资会议上的演讲。

10. Author interview with Eric Rosenfeld.

12. Lynne Marek 和 Katherine Burton，“麦克唐纳称长期资本公司濒临破产”，彭博社，1999 年 10 月 1 日。

12. Lynne Marek and Katherine Burton, “Long-Term Capital Near to Being Out of Business, McDonough Says,” Bloomberg, October 1, 1999.

13. 艾伦·格林斯潘于 1999 年 3 月 19 日在佛罗里达州博卡拉顿期货业协会发表的讲话。

13. Remarks by Alan Greenspan before the Futures Industry Association, Boca Raton, Florida, March 19, 1999.

14. 《资本主义：未知的理想》，引自《经济学人》1999 年 11 月 27 日发表的《安·兰德：仍在滔滔不绝》一文。

14. Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, quoted in “Ayn Rand: Still Spouting,” The Economist, November 27, 1999.

15.“对冲基金、杠杆和长期资本管理的教训”，总统金融市场工作组报告，1999 年 4 月，第 24、29 页。

15. “Hedge Funds, Leverage, and the Lessons of Long-Term Capital Management,” Report of the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets, April 1999, 24, 29.

16. John Cassidy，“金融年鉴：定时炸弹”，《纽约客》， 1999 年 7 月 5 日。

16. John Cassidy, “Annals of Finance: Time Bomb,” The New Yorker, July 5, 1999.

18. Derivatives and Risk Management Symposium on Stability in World Financial Markets, Fordham University School of Law, January 28, 1999, as reprinted in Fordham: Finance, Securities & Tax Law Forum, IV, no. 1 (1999), 21.

19. Figures are from a presentation made by LTCM in February 1999 to an investor.

20. Merrill Lynch, 1998 Annual Report, 50.

关于作者

ABOUT THE AUTHOR

罗杰·洛温斯坦是畅销书《巴菲特：美国资本家的崛起》的作者，曾为《华尔街日报》工作十余年，并于1989年至1991年撰写该报的股市专栏“街头传闻”（Heard on the Street），1995年至1997年撰写“内在价值”（Intrinsic Value）专栏。他目前为《精明理财》（Smart Money）杂志撰写专栏，此前也曾为《纽约时报》和《新共和》等刊物撰稿。他育有三个孩子，现居新泽西州韦斯特菲尔德。

ROGER LOWENSTEIN, author of the bestselling Buffett: The Making of an American Capitalist, reported for The Wall Street Journal for more than a decade and wrote the Journal’s stock market column “Heard on the Street” from 1989 to 1991 and the “Intrinsic Value” column from 1995 to 1997. He now writes a column in Smart Money magazine, and has written for The New York Times and The New Republic, among other publications. He has three children and lives in Westfield, New Jersey.

罗杰·洛温斯坦的其他作品
